Africa News


June 1, 1997


Southern Africa;
Snow disrupts communication between South Africa & Swaziland


BYLINE: Jabu Matsebula, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - The heavy snow which cut Swaziland's capital of Mbabane off from South African on Thursday, is still affecting telephone lines between the two countries.

The most severely affected lines are those connecting Swaziland to the Mpumalanga and Gauteng province. 

Swaziland Posts and Telecommunication spokesman John Mngomezulu said on Saturday that the problem had been identified as disturbances on the main carrier optic fibre line between the two countries.

Snow damaged interupted line in the Mpumalanga highveld town of Ermelo, South Africa.

Appealing for public calm, he said they have already been given an assurance by Telcom in South African that the problem is being attended to. Because of the problems, traffic between the two countries is being routed through the alternative radio line - which he said is now jammed with callers.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

2 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1997


Business and Finance;
R3,3-million housing deal for bi-national dam project


BYLINE: Jabu Matsebula, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - A joint water commission between Swaziland and South Africa has approved an additional R3.3 million housing project to provide accommodation for the bi- national Komati Dams project.

The scheme entails the construction of two dams - the Driekoppies in Mpumalanga and the Maguga dam in Swaziland, to dam water from the Nkomazi river. 

The housing project will be sited in the town of Piggs Peak and all five separate construction contracts for the houses were awarded to Swaziland based material suppliers.

There was also an agreement on measures to accelerate resettlement activities in the project to ensure that they are in line with the construction schedule.

According to the Swaziland Government weekly newsletter, the two countries have agreed there should be greater co-operation on water issues, particularly water quality which is increasingly becoming important.

The agreement between the two countries was signed in Nelspruit last week where Swaziland was represented by the secretary in the Ministry of Natural Resources Sandile Ceko.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

3 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 1, 1997


Swaziland;
Swaziland economy to end reliance on agriculture


BYLINE: Jabu Matsebula, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

BANGKOK (Thailand) - Swaziland ruler, King Mswati III announced in Bangkok on Saturday morning that his small landlocked kingdom intended launching a major economic diversification drive to end its current dependence on agriculture.

The King said Swaziland was seeking partnerships and investment from foreign venture partners with who could offer both capital and technology skills or expertise. 

Mswati was speaking in Bangkok during a meeting with King Bhumibholo of Thailand on the second of his four day visit to the Asian Kingdom.

King Mswati said Swaziland hoped to create partnerships with Thailand investors in the light industry and manufacturing sectors.

Stressing Swaziland's natural beauty and undeveloped wildlife potential, Mswati also called for both Thai tourists and investors to take advantage of a new growth surge in the country's tourism sector.

He pointed out that the port Maputo City was barely two hours drive from the country's "unique" royalist traditional villages and game reserves and also mentioned a R20-million up-grade of Swaziland's only international airport.

King Mswati is on a two week world tour which will take in the far east and end with the OAU conference in Zimbabwe, arrived in Thailand on Wednesday after a two day visit in Singapore.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

4 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Sierra Leone Challenges Nigeria's Leadership Role


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Judging by the groundswell of international condemnation of the May 18 coup in Sierra Leone, political analysts in Lagos are of the opinion the coup-makers grossly misread the political climate, not only in their country, but in the subregion and the entire African continent.

From the Organization of African Unity, the United Nations and the British Commonwealth to the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) of which Sierra Leone is a member, rejection of the coup appears unanimous.

The O.A.U., through its Council of Ministers meeting in Harare, Zimbabwe, denounced the coup by Maj. Johnny Koroma and

The O.A.U. has vowed to make government "impossible" for Koromah and his Armed Forces Revolutionary Council which unseated the elected government of Ahmad Tejan Kabbah.

The U.N. has issued a similar threat while Commonwealth Secretary- General Emeka Anyaoku said he supported military intervention by Ecowas to reverse the coup. 

Popular opinion in Nigeria is also for military intervention by Abuja in consultation with the other Ecowas members, should diplomacy fail to bring a solution.

This appears to be in line with a recent suggestion by the Nigerian leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, that given its success in Liberia, the West African Peace Monitoring Group (Ecomog), should be transformed into a permanent peacekeeping force for the subregion.

"This will be good for peace in West Africa and the leadership role belongs to Nigeria if it manages to get over its own internal political crisis," said an African diplomat, who asked not to be named.

An American specialist on Africa, Adonis Hoffman, also said that the Sierra Leonean crisis could help narrow the diplomatic gap between Abuja and Washington.

Political relations between Nigeria and the United States have been frosty over U.S. charges of human rights abuses and the lack of democracy in Nigeria. The strain has resulted in Washington's imposition of some sanctions against Nigeria.

Hoffman, speaking in a televised interview from New York, said: "Nigeria is in political transition and has the opportunity to work closely with the U.S. to restore democracy in Sierra Leone."

Some international relations specialists believe that while the U.S. and other Western countries are busy evacuating their citizens from troubled Sierra Leone, the task of restoring democracy to that country rests squarely on the Ecowas and by implication, on Abuja. Nigeria is not only the current chairman of the community, it also has the largest contingent in the 11,000-man Ecomog force, which could be rallied to help put off the fire in Sierra Leone, the analysts said.

After several days of subtle diplomacy, Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi, in the first official statement by Abuja on the coup, said Ecowas was "taking appropriate actions to ensure that quick restoration of peace, stability and legitimate government must take place in Sierra Leone."

Ikimi said Abacha had been holding consultations with other Ecowas leaders on the matter.

Reports from Freetown say Ecomog troops have been arriving in the Sierra Leone capital.

Separate contingents of troops from Guinea and Ghana were also reported to have either arrived or were on their way to Freetown.

To underscore the concern of Ecowas leaders, Ghana President Jerry Rawlings cancelled his trip to Harare for the O.A.U. summit which began today.

Proponents of an Ecowas military intervention cite a recent situation in Lesotho, when its neigbours -- South Africa, Botswana and Zimbabwe -- forced a band of coup makers to surrender power to the government the soldiers had ousted.

Burundi's neighbours, have resorted to economic sanctions to exact several concessions from the regime of Maj. Pierre Buyoya, who staged a come-back in a coup against an elected government a year ago.

If Ecowas succeeds in restoring democracy to Sierra Leone, it would send a strong signal to the armies in other countries in the area and to the restive warlords in Liberia. Ecomog was formed because of the mayhem in Liberia in 1990. Its military control over Liberia has enabled West African leaders to broker a peace plan under which national elections are now fixed for July 19. These will effectively end the seven-year civil war in which at least 150,000 people have died in Africa's first republic.

Analysts also postulate that the situation in Sierra Leone could be an instructive lesson and a reinforcement of the general feeling of abhorrence for undemocratic government in Africa.

However, as the fear of possible large scale military intervention by Ecomog mounts in Sierra Leone, observers have counselled extreme caution to avoid endangering the lives of innocent civilians.

Popular feeling is that the military option should be a last resort because Sierra Leoneans and the entire international community stand to benefit from a peaceful resolution of the crisis.

Analysts have suggested safe conduct out of Sierra Leone and possible asylum for the coup makers.

They also say that the lessons of the coup should not be lost on the Sierra Leone leadership, especially Kabbah's embattled government who must now address issues that are likely to fuel discontent in the country.

What Sierra Leone's estimated four million people need now is an end to the seven-year civil war in which at least 10,000 people have died. The war, a spill-over from Liberia's own, has turned this mineral-rich country into a nation of poverty.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Algeria;
Casualties Rise From Algiers Bomb Blast


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

ALGIERS, Algeria (PANA) - Algerian security forces now put the at 60 the number of people killed and 48 wounded by Sunday's bomb blast Sunday in the capital, Algiers.

Initial figures were given as five dead, among them a baby, and 16 wounded. Sunday's was the second attack in Algiers in less than 48 hours. The first explosion was in a cinema Five people were wounded.

Ismalic militants have been planting bombs in the country in an attempt to gain control of the government, which they believe they should be heading.

Their campaign of terror followed cancellations of second round elections they were set to win in 1992. The militants, the Islamic Salvation Front, won the first round of elections decisively in December 1991.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

6 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Salim Gets Unprecedented Third Term Of Office


BYLINE: Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African leaders Monday voted the incumbent OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, to a third four-year term as head of the continental body, in recognition of his untiring efforts to make the OAU relevant to the challenges facing Africa.

Although he was the only candidate after Amara Essy, the foreign minister of Cote d'Ivoire withdrew from the race, the leaders decided to vote instead of adopting the procedure in the 1993 summit in Cairo, when Salim was unanimously re-elected. He was first elected to the post in 1989.

Salim received 37 votes in his favour and six against. There were two abstentions and two spoiled ballots.

Six other countries did not vote because they are under sanctions for failure to pay their assessed contributions to the regular budget of the OAU.

The OAU staff here received the news of the re-election with joy and pledged to continue working with him into the next millennium.

"He has worked hard since coming to the OAU in 1989, and made our organisation more relevant in the world today," one official said.

"Tanzania deserves to be congratulated for its part in the African liberation war. I think this is why the leaders have given another chance to Salim," another added.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

7 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Tunisia;
Tunisia Signs Sanitation Accords


BYLINE: Bouazza Ben Bouazza, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

TUNIS, Tunisia (PANA) - Tunisia has signed cooperation agreements in the area of environment and sanitation with three African and Middle- East countries in the past two weeks.

One of the agreements, signed Friday in Tunis between the ministry of environment and land development and the city council of Tripoli (Libya) envisages the design and implementation of a pilot programme in the Libyan capital in the sanitation sector. 

Apart from cooperation on preserving the ecological balance and exchange of experiences, the two parties have agreed to establish an urban leisure park in Tripoli.

The sanitation cooperation agreement covers waste collection and processing, cleaning and rehabilitation of beaches.

The agreement follows the recent visit in Libya by the Tunisian environment minister, Mehdi Mlika, who had an audience with Col. Moammar Kadhafi.

Mlika also held talks with several Libyan environment officials, who were keen to learn from the Tunisian experience.

Another agreement was signed the same day in Tunis between Tunisia and Jordan, at the end of a four-day visit by Taoufik Mahmoud Krichene, the Jordanian minister of municipal, rural and environmental affairs.

The two countries agreed to promote cooperation in the area of sanitation and management of liquid waste, natural reserves and parks.

They also decided to join efforts in the areas of roads, training and retraining of technicians, land development and environmental legislation.

In a first phase, the Tunisia-Jordan agreement will cover the construction of a pilot water purification station and a pilot unit for solid waste treatment in Jordan.

The previous week, the Senegalese minister of water development, Mamadou Faye, visited Tunisia and signed an agreement aimed at strengthening bilateral cooperation, notably between the Tunisian and Senegalese sanitation boards.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

8 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
First Ladies Demand Role In Conflict Management


BYLINE: Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African first ladies on Monday called on leaders attending the 33rd OAU summit to grant them financial assistance to enable them help the victims of conflicts.

Nigeria's first lady, Mariam Abacha, said the spouses of African leaders had been watching in horror the plight of refugees and displaced persons. 

"Set aside small percentages of your national budgets for the first ladies programme for peace," she told the OAU summit which opened in Harare on Monday.

"We want to standby you in your efforts to end conflicts" she said at Monday's opening of the summit

The summit opened in the absence of the out-going OAU chairman President Paul Biya of Cameroon due to what was described as the "ongoing legislative elections" in his country. Mariam Abacha became the first lady to address the assembly of heads of state since the inception of the OAU in 1963.

The first ladies held their first meeting in Abuja, Nigeria, in May, at the end of which they pledged to complement the efforts of the african leaders in the search for peace.

Mrs Abacha said as mothers, they have been perturbed by the sufferings of the victims of wars. "How long", she asked, "can we watch helplessly the wondering of refugees. We want to play our quota in ending conflicts".

She called for the establishment of an African eminent persons committee, to include first ladies, to assist in he management of crises.

She later presented a copy of the Abuja communique of the of the first ladies meeting to president Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, the current chairman of the OAU.

Mugabe assured the first ladies that their concern for the resolution of conflicts will not be ignored.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

9 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Mugabe Calls For Economic Emancipation


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe implored African countries on Monday to strive for economic emancipation now that the continent has largely achieved political independence. ' Addressing the opening session of the 33rd Summit of the Organisation of African Unity in Harare, Mugabe noted the continental body's founding fathers had proclaimed 34 years ago that Africa should first seek the political "kingdom" and all else would follow.

"With the achievement of freedom here in Southern Africa, we have fulfilled the political objective although our economic emancipation is yet to follow," said Mugabe. 

The current summit is the second to be held in Southern Africa following the 1972 meeting held in the Zambian capital, Lusaka.

"For many years our organisation could not hold meetings in Southern Africa by virtue of foreign occupation," said Mugabe.

"Today, however, you come as victorious brothers and sisters, triumphantly marching through the region which has become part of the organisation, now helping to define and pursue a new agenda for the common good of our continent and its peoples."

Africa's political victories, he said, had shown the need for OAU member countries to harness their energies to achieve success.

"Economic questions have now clearly come to the fore. To solve them, however, we need a correct political environment on the continent.

"Perhaps the most urgent issue facing Africa today is the vital question of peace in a number of our countries. Peace is a fundamental pre-condition of all other rights by our citizens," he said.

It was, therefore, imperative that both the OAU and individual countries give priority to the maintenance of peace through the organisation's mechanism for the resolutions of conflicts, he said.

Mugabe noted, however, that although some of the African countries and regions still needed internal peace, some progress had been made since the last OAU summit in Yaounde, Cameroon, last June.

"In Angola, for instance, the establishment of the government of national unity and reconciliation on April 11 this year, marked an important step towards genuine peace in that country," said Mugabe.

"We are also hopeful that the Angolan government is proceeding to re- establish its sovereignty over its entire territory.

"In Liberia, there is also hope that peace will be heralded by the revised Abuja agreement."

He also condemned the recent coup in Sierra Leone, saying: "democracy must be restored in that country as a matter of urgency."

The situation in the former Zaire had dramatically changed through the victory of the forces of the Democratic Alliance for the Liberation of Congo, followed by the setting up of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, headed by President Laurent Kabila, which most countries now recognized.

"The country, however, still faces many challenges which merit our attention and that of the international community in the form of assistance of all kinds," he said.

Referring to the United Nations Security Council, Mugabe said there should be no question of first and second class permanent members.

"The OAU position must be maintained that Africa is entitled to two seats with equal status in the UN Security Council," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Sierra Leone;
International Trade Union Condemns Sierra Leone Coup


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions said Monday it fully supported the call for the restoration of democracy in Sierra Leone, where West African troops are currently trying to dislodge the rebellious soldiers and restore normalcy.

The confederation's Africa regional general-secretary, Andrew Kailemebo, said in Harare that political changes on the continent should take place through due electoral processes. 

"We, therefore, appeal to all workers, the wider civil society and democratic governments throughout the continent to give maximum support to the efforts of the people of Sierra Leone to rid themselves of the military junta," he said.

African leaders attending the 33rd Organization of African Unity summit in Harare, he said, should denounce the junta and find measures to help restore democracy.

Junior members of the army led by Maj. Johnny Koromah ousted the elected government of Ahmad Tejan Kabbah May 18. The coup makers said they wanted to end the seven-year civil war in Sierra Leone and have invited the rebel Revolutionary United Front, formerly at war with successive governments in Freetown, to join the new administration.

News reports on Monday say that Guinean, Ghanaian and Nigerian troops from West Africa's Ecomog troops in Liberia have entered in Freetown in support of the ousted government.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

11 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


United States and Africa;
Clinton Requests Small Increase in Aid for Africa


BYLINE: Daniel Volman, Africa Policy Report (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Washington, DC - In its budget proposal for Fiscal Year (FY) 1998 (which begins on 1 October 1997), the Clinton Administration requested $13.324 billion for foreign operations programs, an 8.8 percent increase over the FY 1997 appropriated level of $12.25 billion.

The administration's proposed budget includes $700 million for the Development Fund for Africa and $14 million to fund the African Development Foundation.

The request for the Economic Support Fund (ESF) allocates $10 million to support democratic institution-building and election preparation in Angola and $15 million to support elections, respect for the rule of law, and enhanced government accountability in sub-Saharan Africa. The ESF request also allocates $10 million to fund U.S. Department of Justice programs to enhance the administration of justice and to provide police training throughout the world, including programs in African countries. 

The administration's request for the U.S. State Department Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs contains $2 million for regional programs in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. In Africa, the program would focus on Nigeria and South Africa, and would be used to provide customs training, enforcement and management training for counternarcotics units, technical training, and funding for demand reduction programs and public education campaigns.

In FY 1998, the administration proposes to provide $9.434 million for Migration and Refugee Assistance programs in Africa. This money would be used to fund programs administered by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the World Food Program, and other governmental and non- governmental organizations.

The administration plans to make significant increases in Foreign Military Financing (FMF) programs for Africa in FY 1998. These include $5 million to fund its proposal to create an African Crisis Response Force (ACRF) by improving and expanding the capabilities of African military forces to conduct peacekeeping and humanitarian assistance operations. Another $5 million in FMF funding would go to the East African Regional program.

This program is designed "to bolster the capabilities of East African states (Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Uganda) to thwart Sudan- sponsored terrorism and the disruption of humanitarian assistance" and "to help these three countries resist Sudan-fostered destabilization."

A further $15 million in FMF funding would go to demining programs, including those being conducted in Angola, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Namibia, and Rwanda. The administration also proposes to allocate $7 million in FMF funding to create a new program, the Enhanced International Peacekeeping Capabilities (EIPC) program. This effort is intended to create peacekeeping training centers throughout the world to implement common internationally approved peacekeeping standards.

The EIPC program would deploy American Mobile Training Teams and provide specialized training and equipment to participating military units, many of which will be from African countries.

The administration's budget proposal includes a major increase in funding for the Peacekeeping Operations (PKO) account for voluntary peacekeeping activities. These funds include $10 million for the Africa Regional Peacekeeping program to improve the peacekeeping and conflict resolution capabilities of African countries preparing for regional or international operations conducted under the auspices of the UN, the Organization of African Unity (OAU), or on a bilateral basis.

This program would be directed at Botswana, Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Malawi, Namibia, Senegal, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe; the program is also intended to strengthen the capabilities of the Southern African Development Community to conduct collective operations. The funding would be used to provide the armed forces of these countries with training assistance and military equipment.

Another $15 million in PKO funding would be used--along with the $5 million in ESF mentioned above--to create an African Crisis Response Force. This money would be used to finance training and equipment for the military units of African countries that choose to participate in this American-sponsored effort.

An additional $3 million in PKO funding would be used to provide continued support for the OAU Mechanism for Conflict Resolution, Management, and Resolution. Since the Mechanism was established in 1993, PKO funding has been used to build the OAU Conflict Resolution Center in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and to provide equipment to help the center monitor crises and deploy observer missions. The funding requested for FY 1998 would be used to train center staff and observers for future operations.

Finally, the administration is seeking a significant increase in funding for International Military and Education (IMET) programs designed to train African military personnel both overseas and at U.S. military training centers in the United States. The proposed budget for FY 1998 contains $8.015 million to pay for IMET programs for the armed forces of sub-Saharan African countries, up from an estimated $7.325 million in FY 1997. This would be used to provide training to 1,081 students; the largest contingents are expected to come from Zimbabwe (120 students), the Central African Republic (78 students), Eritrea (75 students), Mali (65 students), Benin (63 students), South Africa (60 students), Ghana (60 students), Ethiopia (58 students), Madagascar (51 students), Rwanda (50 students), Sierra Leone (50 students), and Cape Verde (50 students).

It is virtually certain, of course, that spending for most of these programs will be curtailed by the U.S. Congress, particularly in the context of the bipartisan plan to reduce overall federal spending in order to achieve a balanced budget. For example, Representative Benjamin Gilman, chair of the House International Relations Committee proposes cutting $700 million from the international affairs budget for FY 1998, including a reduction in money for the Development Fund for Africa to $575 million. Expenditures for the ESF, FMF, PKO, and IMET programs will also probably be trimmed.

Daniel Volman (dvolman@igc.apc.org) is director of the Africa Research Project, a research and educational center based in Washington, D.C., and a specialist on U.S. security policy toward Africa.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

12 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


United States and Africa;
American Assembly Report Backs U.S. Leadership Role in Africa


BYLINE: Daniel Volman, Africa Policy Report (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Washington, DC - The 19th session of the American Assembly -- held at Arden House in Harriman, New York, on 13-16 March 1997 -- was entitled "Africa and U.S. National Interests," and was devoted to an examination of issues arising out of the Africa continent, how they affect U.S. national interests in the present and the future, and what policy the United States should follow.

The 19th Assembly gathered 69 men and women representing government, business, academia, non-governmental organizations, the law, international financial institutions, labor, the military, religion, and the media.

The session was chaired by Donald F. McHenry (former U.S. Ambassador to the UN and currently University Research Professor of Diplomacy and International Affairs at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University). The project is directed by former U.S. Congressman Harold Wolpe (now at the Brookings Institution and serving as the Clinton Administration's Special Envoy to Burundi) and by former U.S. Ambassador to Zimbabwe and Tanzania David C. Miller, Jr., (now president of the Corporate Council on Africa). 

The 19th Assembly was designed as a prelude to the National Summit on Africa, a new campaign organized by Africare to expand and mobilize constituencies in the United States to press for a U.S. policy of engagement with Africa. The National Summit on Africa campaign begins operations this year with a series of regional meetings and will culminate with a major national event scheduled for 1999.

The report discusses U.S. economic interests and policy, political interests and policy, and security issues. The section on security issues presents several major policy recommendations. Among other actions, the report argues that the United States should continue to support conflict resolution activities conducted by the OAU and sub-regional organizations by allocating resources, providing technical assistance, and encouraging UN support.

The report expresses uncritical support for U.S. military training exercises in Africa and for America's International Military Training and Education (IMET) programs in Africa. And it urges the administration to raise funding for IMET programs to $30 million (from the current level of less than $10 million).

The report calls upon the United States to exercise "forceful leadership" in "international interventions, military or otherwise . . . most often within the context of the UN" in response to "major humanitarian crises." And it describes the African Crisis Response Force proposed by the Clinton Administration as "a mechanism through which the United States can recommit itself to the exercise of such leadership." However, it does not address the issue of whether U.S. troops should participate in these intervention operations.

In addition to these recommendations, it is noteworthy that the section on security issues fails to discuss, or even mention, the issue of U.S. arms transfers to Africa.

The Final Report of the 19th Assembly was issued on 20 March 1997. Copies can be obtained from the American Assembly's web site at http://www.columbia.edu/cu/assembly or (free of charge) by contacting the American Assembly, Columbia University, Suite 456, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10115; by telephone at (212) 870-3500; or by fax at (212) 870-3555.

Daniel Volman (dvolman@igc.apc.org) is director of the Africa Research Project, a research and educational center based in Washington, D.C., and a specialist on U.S. security policy toward Africa.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

13 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


United States and Africa;
Task Force Calls for 'More Aggressive' Economic Policy


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4107 words


 

Washington - Excerpts from a statement by an Independent Task Force of The Council on Foreign Relations, Inc., "Promoting U.S. Economic Relations with Africa."

I. Introduction and Summary

Significant positive developments in Africa have recently created a sense of economic and political renewal throughout much of the continent. Over two-thirds of African countries are implementing economic policy reforms that emphasize growth, private sector development, and greater openness to the global economy. Aggregate growth rates for these 35 African countries in 1995 and 1996 averaged 5 percent, more than twice the rates of the previous decade. A new generation of leadership in Africa is promoting a reform agenda that offers important opportunities for rapid economic growth and increasing African countries' participation in the global economy. Now that an increasing number of African countries are becoming strong candidates as potential trade and investment partners, the United States should be at the forefront of the industrialized world in pursuit of these new opportunities.

Recognizing the favorable economic and political trends occurring in most African countries, the Council on Foreign Relations -- while taking no position on the subject as an organization -- sponsored an independent Task Force of distinguished private citizens, committed to strengthening American ties with Africa, to make recommendations on how best to advance mutual U.S. and African interests in the sphere of economic relations. 

Despite the renewal in Africa and the quiet expansion of U.S. economic interests on the continent, the prevailing perceptions of Africa's potential remain overwhelmingly negative within parts of the policymaking and business communities, and among the larger American body politic. In the minds of many Americans, economic and political crises in a handful of traumatized countries have tended to obfuscate the impressive growth and political turnarounds occurring in many other African countries. Consequently, the Task Force believes that new opportunities to increase economic ties with Africa will require considerable Executive Branch leadership if they are to receive the attention and support they deserve. ...

The Task Force concludes that the U.S. needs a new economic policy for Africa which integrates trade and investment, aid, and debt reduction in a coherent manner aimed at expanding mutually beneficial economic ties. The Task Force notes with approval the recently increased attention given to African trade and investment issues by both the Congress and the Administration. However, the Task Force believes that legislative and executive initiatives fall short of offering a new economic policy for Africa that is as comprehensive as is warranted.

New policy must more aggressively promote trade and investment and involve all relevant government agencies, while simultaneously strengthening our development assistance programs with those African countries demonstrating the strongest commitment to economic and political liberalization and poverty reduction. It must also promote the extinction of outstanding concessional bilateral debt and a more rapid application of the new debt reduction initiative of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Finally, a new policy must include the payment of outstanding U.S. commitments to those international organizations whose programs are critical to progress in Africa, as well as a willingness to work to improve the performance of these organizations.

The Task Force calls on the President and the Secretaries of State, Commerce, and Treasury, along with the U.S. Trade Representative and the Administrator of USAID, to focus greater attention and provide stronger collective leadership on new initiatives which transform the nature and content of U.S. economic policies toward Africa. The Task Force calls upon Members of Congress to provide the Administration with the resources and support it will need to begin a new era of cooperation with an increasing number of African countries.

The Task Force is convinced that a new U.S. economic policy toward the countries of Africa should have as objectives, the following:

* Increase U.S. two-way trade with African countries and American direct investment in Africa

* Increase and strengthen U.S. development assistance in reforming countries to support sensible macro-economic policies and to help create conditions which will attract even greater investment, and produce greater trade

* Improve debt reduction as an important tool for restoring the credit-worthiness of African countries committed to economic and political liberalization and poverty reduction

* Strengthen international cooperation in support of development in Africa

II. Africa Today

Since the dawn of this decade Africa has been experiencing profound social, political and economic changes that are carrying African countries into the new millennium with greatly improved prospects for economic development and growth. This renaissance is taking place amidst equally dramatic changes in the global political economy, and portends important opportunities for African nations to deepen their participation in the international system in numerous and mutually beneficial ways. The positive trends -- of democratization, economic reform, and settlement of long-standing conflicts -- characterize the present era as the most promising period since the onset of African independence 40 years ago. While the continent's continuing problems should not be understated, it is evident that we are witnessing the inception of Africa's second independence.

A failure to fully appreciate the economic aspects of this continent-wide renewal and their bearing on Africa's security and political interests will result in lost opportunities to maximize and sustain positive change in ways benefiting not only African nations, but the U.S. and the larger global community as well. In terms of America's national interests, it should be self-evident that as we become more dependent on the expansion of world trade for our own economic well-being, the potential for significant growth in Africa -- resulting in substantial new trade and investment opportunities at high rates of return -- merits aggressive U.S. economic engagement with the continent.

III. U.S. Economic Interests in Africa

... U.S. trade with Africa is already considerable. For example, in 1996, U.S. trade with the 12 countries of Southern Africa totaled over $9 billion, a level comparable to trade with the 15 Republics of the former Soviet Union combined. Significantly, U.S. exports to Africa have grown over 20 percent a year in recent years. In 1995, U.S. businesses increased their exports to Sub-Saharan Africa by 23 percent to a total of $5.4 billion, and in 1996 that figure rose to $6.1 billion. Nevertheless, the U.S. market share in the region -- at 6.7. percent -- lags behind Japan's 7.2 percent, and well behind the 30 percent share enjoyed by the European Union. Moreover, with imports from the region totaling $15.2 billion, the U.S. still runs a significant trade deficit while most of our European allies maintain a trade surplus with the continent.

IV. U.S. Economic Policy Toward Africa

During the first four decades of Africa's independence from colonialism, American foreign policy toward the continent was overwhelmingly influenced by global competition between the U.S. and the former Soviet Union. Africa's economic development interests as well as American economic interests in Africa were largely marginalized because of the primacy of the Cold War. The end of the Cold War has led some policymakers to incorrectly conclude that there are no compelling reasons for continued U.S. economic engagement in Africa.

Until recently, U.S. economic policy toward Africa has depended on the provision of aid as the principle instrument for advancing U.S. interests. Though subordinate to Cold War imperatives, development concerns have also been a part of the motivation for U.S. aid to Africa. Whereas in the 1960s, the focus was on "promoting growth," the decade of the 1970s witnessed a shift in emphasis to poverty reduction and meeting "basic human needs". During the 1980s, aid predominantly focused on support for "structural adjustment," or stabilization programs, and trade liberalization to encourage economic recovery and growth. In the 1990s, aid has since shifted to promote good governance and political democratization as a precondition for economic development.

More recently the Clinton Administration has stated that the primary goal of U.S. economic policy toward Africa is to support sustainable development and to quicken the pace of that development, to boost U.S. trade and investment. In many ways, sustainable development embraces all of the primary objectives of the preceding decades and represents a better and more integrated understanding of Africa's development challenges.

But regardless of the particular orientation of U.S. economic policy toward Africa over the years, its effectiveness has always suffered from the low priority it received within the prevailing foreign policy agenda and within the foreign policy bureaucracy.

Moreover, by limiting economic relations with Africa to those of aid-donor and aid-recipient, instead of promoting real partnerships utilizing a full range of aid, trade, investment and debt management instruments, the U.S. wrongly casts Africa as a region of little economic significance or potential.

Frustrated by this legacy and cognizant of the economic dynamism now manifesting itself on the continent, legislators recently introduced proposals in the Congress which encourage reorienting U.S. economic policy by promoting American private sector involvement in Africa and increasing the role of trade and investment as vehicles for supporting African economic development.

At the same time, proposals to restructure and reduce the U.S. foreign aid program raise serious questions about the future of U.S. aid to Africa (with the exception of Egypt). While economic assistance to Africa was regularly undercut by Cold War geostrategic and political issues, thereby retarding sustainable development, the post-Cold War period has been characterized by a sudden dismissal of development assistance on the grounds that it has achieved little positive development impact. This trend discounts the fact that efforts to reform aid and focus more on strengthening Africans' capacity to find their own development solutions are still in their infancy, and that aid has only recently been freed of its Cold War constraints. It also ignores the increased opportunities for more effective use of aid in countries that are implementing serious reform programs.

Unfortunately, the convergence of these developments (declining aid levels and increased interest in trade) has led to an often simplistic "trade vs. aid" debate over which is the most constructive approach for changing U.S. economic policies toward Africa. Fortunately, efforts to avoid this false dichotomy are evidenced in the revised legislation.

With the recent re-introduction of the African Growth and Opportunity Act in Congress, and the upcoming G-7 Economic Summit in Denver -- where new economic initiatives on Africa will figure prominently on the agenda -- there exists a new momentum for redefining U.S. economic policy toward the continent. The Administration is working to finalize proposals for a "Partnership for Economic Growth and Opportunity in Africa" that embraces most of the items proposed in the legislation. These developments, combined with U.S. support for the World Bank/IMF debt reduction program for Highly Indebted Poor Countries, offer key components for what should become a more integrated U.S. economic policy toward Africa.

V. Recommendations

The Task Force is convinced that a new policy promoting economic relations with Africa must be driven more effectively by the White House than in the recent past, that it must strengthen the complementarity of development assistance programs and the new trade and investment initiatives, and that it must include new human and financial resource commitments to promoting greater U.S. economic engagement in Africa. In addition, a new U.S. economic policy toward Africa necessitates both greater U.S. leadership on efforts to reduce Africa's unsustainable debt burden and payment by the U.S. of outstanding commitments to international organizations whose programs are critical to Africa's economic development.

Furthermore, to create an expanded economic partnership with the African continent of significant mutual benefit to both Americans and Africans, the President with the cooperation of the Congress must broaden the proposed "Partnership for Economic Growth and Opportunity in Africa" program to include the following elements:

(details of recommendations available in full statement)

Trade and Investment

* passage of an African Growth and Opportunity Act, (that increases African access to American markets, creates enterprise funds to mobilize greater American private sector investment in Africa, increases the number of posts within key federal agencies concerned with U.S. economic policies toward Africa, creates a U.S.-Africa Economic Forum, and initiates planning for free trade agreements with African countries or groups of countries) ...

Investments in Sustainable Development

... The Task Force is convinced that there is a strong continuing role for bilateral development assistance to Africa and that current aid levels should be increased. Specifically, in order to reverse the decline in U.S. aid levels to Africa at a moment when it is more likely to be used more effectively than ever before, the Congress should authorize and appropriate up to $1 billion for the Development Fund for Africa and the African Development Foundation in each of the next five years. The Task Force believes that while more emphasis is needed on promoting trade with Africa and U.S. private investment in Africa, the United States must expand its sustainable development programs to help reduce poverty, to strengthen democratic governance and the rule of law, and to invest in human resource development, all of which are necessary to help Africa create the economic base needed to meet global competition for export markets and investment funds, and to sustain economic growth.

... The United States must also pay outstanding American commitments to the International Development Association, the African Development Bank and Fund, and the United Nations in order to carry a fair share of international cooperation in support of African development, and to maintain leadership in shaping the global economy. ...

Debt Reduction

* a commitment to push for an accelerated, improved and flexible implementation of the Highly Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) framework for debt relief in Africa with an emphasis on restoring the credit worthiness of strongly reforming countries.

* the period of eligibility for multilateral debt reduction should be reduced from six years to three years

* the debt sustainability threshold ratios for debt service should be lowered to 15-20 percent and for debt-to-exports to 150- 200 percent

V. Conclusion

African renewal, as described earlier in this statement, while largely self-generated, will nevertheless require significant international support and enhanced development cooperation if it is to be sustained. Such cooperation is equally important to the larger international community itself. The old notions of "aid donors" and "aid recipients" must give way to more relevant concepts which emphasize partnership and encompass the full range of areas of economic cooperation including trade and investment.

In the U.S., the crumbling of the old conventions that sustained foreign policy throughout much of this century, and the need to redefine the national interests that will guide it into the future, should offer Africa new opportunities for greater engagement with the United States. ...

Realistically, however, this moment of opportunity could easily be lost. Indeed, the low priority that continues to be given to African affairs by Washington despite this convergence, as well as the unchanged staple of negative stereotypes of Africa that continue to predominate American attitudes toward Africa are discouraging. These factors underline the need for new and innovative efforts to address the prevailing misperceptions of Africa's progress and of its importance to the U.S. and the global political economy as a whole. ...

The Statement of the Task Force reflects the general policy thrust and judgments reached by the group, although not all members necessarily subscribe fully to every finding and recommendation in the Statement being released today. Some members may choose to register additional views in the final published document. The council takes no institutional position on policy issues and has no affiliation with the U.S. Government. This report is the sole responsibility of the task force.

For further information about the Council or this Task Force, please contact the Public Affairs Office, Council on Foreign Relations, 58 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021. A copy of the full task force statement is available from task force rapporteur Marilyn Gayton, African Studies Program, Council on Foreign Relations, 2400 N St. NW,Washington, DC 20037; Tel: 202-862-7793; Fax: 202-862-7786; E-mail: mgayton@email.cfr.org.

Distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), the educational affiliate of the Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, No. 509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546- 7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Burundi;
Security Council Urges Negotiations in Burundi


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

United Nations - The Security Council this afternoon urged all parties in Burundi to continue pursuing a negotiated settlement of their conflict and refrain from actions that might harm such dialogue.

In a statement read out by its President, Park Soo Gil (Republic of Korea), the Council welcomed both the talks being held in Rome to complement the Arusha peace process on Burundi and the Burundi Government's commitment to a comprehensive dialogue among all the parties within the framework of that process.

Reiterating its support for the peace efforts of leaders of the region, the Council welcomed their decision to ease sanctions against Burundi to alleviate the suffering of its people. That decision was relayed to the Council in the Joint Communique of 16 April issued following the Fourth Arusha Regional Summit on the Burundi Conflict held in the United Republic of Tanzania. 

Stating its concern that instability continued in Burundi despite recent positive developments, the Council recalled its resolution 1072 (1996) of 30 August 1996, which demanded that all sides in Burundi declare a unilateral cessation of hostilities and initiate unconditional negotiations towards a comprehensive political settlement.

Expressing deep concern at the involuntary resettlement of rural populations, the Council called upon Burundi's Government to allow the people to return to their homes without hindrance.

The meeting began at 12:07 p.m. and adjourned at 12:12 p.m.

Presidential Statement

The full text of the statement, to be issued as document S/PRST/1997/32, reads as follows:

"The Security Council is concerned that, despite recent positive developments, there is continuing instability in Burundi. It recalls its resolution 1072 (1996) of 30 August 1996, in which, inter alia, it demanded that all sides in Burundi declare a unilateral cessation of hostilities and initiate unconditional negotiations with a view to reaching a comprehensive political settlement.

"The Security Council reiterates its support for the efforts of the regional leaders and takes note of the Joint Communique (S/1997/319) of 16 April 1997 issued following the Fourth Arusha Regional Summit on the Burundi Conflict held in Arusha, Tanzania. In particular, the Council welcomes the decision of the regional leaders to ease sanctions in order to alleviate the suffering of the people of Burundi.

"The Security Council welcomes the fact that talks are being held in Rome which are complementary to the Arusha process. It also welcomes the commitment of the Government of Burundi to the comprehensive political dialogue among all the parties within the framework of the Arusha process. It urges all the parties in Burundi to continue to pursue a negotiated settlement and to refrain from actions which are detrimental to such dialogue.

"The Security Council expresses its deep concern at the involuntary resettlement of rural populations and calls upon the Government of Burundi to allow the people to return to their homes without any hindrance.

"The Security Council expresses its support and appreciation to former President Nyerere as well as to the Special Representative of the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity in their efforts to find a peaceful solution to the crisis in Burundi.

"The Security Council requests the Secretary-General to continue to keep the Council informed on the situation in Burundi, especially with regard to the progress of a negotiated and peaceful settlement in the country.

"The Security Council will remain seized of the matter."

May 30, 1997


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
