15 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Rwanda;
UN To Investigate Rwanda Tribunal


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

United Nations - The Office of Internal Oversight Services would send auditors and investigators to Arusha and Kigali in September to check improvements in operations and efforts to address management errors in the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, the Fifth Committee (Administrative and Budgetary) was told this morning (May 30).

Presenting his Office's reports on the Tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia and on the United Nations Postal Administration, Under- Secretary-General for Internal Oversight Services Karl Theodor Paschke said that some of the major problems found in the Rwanda Tribunal had been addressed and remedial action taken in a number of areas. 

On the former Yugoslavia Tribunal, he said his Office had recommended cuts of at least $6 million from its 1997 budget. The content of the former Yugoslavia Tribunal report differed from the one on Rwanda because it had been inspired by Member States' concerns about the steep increase in its resource requests, rather than allegations of irregularities and mismanagement.

Saudi Arabia's representative said the unreliable financial records in the Rwanda Tribunal were a matter of concern. On the Postal Administration, he asked the Secretariat to report on the cost-sharing for space between the United Nations and the Postal Administration.

Also this morning, the Committee concluded its debate on the financing of the United Nations Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina (UNMIBH) and the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP), without statements being made.

The Committee is scheduled to meet again at 10 a.m., on Monday, 2 June, to continue discussing the financing of the two International Criminal Tribunals.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
COSATU Says 2 Million Joined Strike


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

Johannesburg - Today, more than two millions workers responded to the call by COSATU for a 24 hour general strike in support of demands for better conditions of employment.

In all cities and towns, workers also attended marches and rallies, except in KwaZulu natal where a stay away was called. Reports thus far indicate that well over a quarter of a million attended rallies and marches to hand over memoranda to Business South Africa and its affiliates.

Most of these workers come from within the ranks of COSATU and NACTU or are unaffiliated and unorganised. Unlike bosses who are often playing golf, these are the people who work between 45 hours and 60 hours a week, enjoy very little or no parental rights and whose basic conditions will be varied down if the current bill was to be passed as is. 

Today's strike is the third since the 1994 elections. All of them has been aimed at forcing employers to accede to the humble demands of workers on legislative issues pertaining to improvement of working conditions and worker rights. For the record, the previous ones were on the LRA and the constitution respectively. In all occasions, employers have advanced positions that stand in the way of democratic transformation, including the extension of democracy in the workplace.

As is often the case, most commentators have claimed that today's action means that the Alliance is about to collapse. In spite of the support we have received from the ANC, SACP and SANCO, they imply that the strike is staged in opposition to the government. Nothing can be further from the truth. The Alliance is united on the need to eradicate apartheid at the workplace and to extend worker rights and conditions that have systematically been denied over many years of oppression and exploitation. Contrary to protestation by employers, they were willing partners in our oppression and exploitation at the workplace, a situation that they would want to see continue under a new dispensation

The ANC and the Communist party have supported the need for the broadest mobilisation of workers in support of the need for progressive legislation. In a move that stunned political commentators, President Mandela marched with workers in support of a revamped LRA. He also led us in our meeting with business to press home our opposition to the lock-out during the drafting of the constitution. In general, legislative proposals by the government are aimed at correcting the imbalances and injustices of the apartheid era.

Our approach to the Basic conditions of employment bill

As COSATU, our strategy is informed by the fact that the primary aim of the statute is to overhaul the current law to give effect to the new constitution, as well as provide a floor of basic rights for all workers. This law will regulate contracts and basic conditions for most workers particularly the vulnerable and the unorganised.

WORKING HOURS

COSATU's demand is for a 40 hour working week. We would welcome it coming into effect immediately, but have placed on the table a compromise position to have it faced over a period of not more than 5 years. The phasing in should be spelt out in legislation as well as appropriate and effective mechanisms to achieve it.

We acknowledge the proposal to reduce working hours to 45 hours with immediate effect as well as the phasing in for mine workers, security guards and agricultural workers. The number of workers who will benefit from this reduction will be more than 2 million workers most of whom are unorganised or vulnerable. The reduction should however be spelt out in the statute.

MATERNITY LEAVE

We re-iterate our demand for a 6 months maternity leave of which at least 4 months should be paid. We have noted the increase in the bill from 3 to 4 months, job security as well as increased coverage. We however remain of the view that the provisions for payment and the duration should be contained in law. We do not accept the current situation where women are prejudiced with respect to UIF benefits after their dismissal soon after returning from maternity because their UIF benefits have been exhausted while on maternity leave. As a movement committed to women equality, we will fight this one to the bitter end.

VARIATIONS

We remain opposed to the proposed model on variation as contained in the Bill, particularly in relation to:

* the potential of "downward variation" under the guise of "flexibility", which would be an erosion of workers' basic rights;

* the extensive discretion of the Minister to vary (including potentially downgrade) the basic conditions of workers.

Many have said that we are against the provisions on variations because of our opposition to GEAR. Even if there was no GEAR, we would still take the same approach. It is employers who regards the same provisions as necessary for the success of GEAR. I am of the view that they are using GEAR for convenience. If there was no GEAR, they would have invented it. It after all what is contained in their Growth for all. What they hide behind is international competition. This was their approach in the previous disputes.

SUNDAY WORK

We reject the employers' demand that Sunday work be regarded as a normal day. In this regard we agree with the government approach even though there are areas that require tightening.

OVERTIME PAYMENT

We accept the government proposals on overtime payment. Business should withdraw their ridiculous proposals since they will never see the light of day.

CHILD LABOUR THRESHOLD

While we are pleased with the definition of a child in the Bill, We however remain of the view that the threshold for child labour should be 16 years.

The message from workers has gone out loud and clear! We will not accept anything short of the above demands. The ball is now formally in the court of the employers. We expect them to respond to us with revised proposals either directly or through NEDLAC. Their failure to do so will lead to the continuation of our actions. Furthermore, we will be setting a deadline for the conclusion of negotiations in NEDLAC.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Liberia;
Amnesty Calls for End to Rights Abuses in Liberia


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

London - LIBERIA: CONTINUING HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSES BY PEACE- KEEPERS MUST END AS NEW DEMOCRATIC ERA DAWNS

Immediately ending the culture of impunity which has infested Liberia for years must feature high up on the agenda of the country's first democratic government in eight years, due to be elected on 19 July, Amnesty International said today.

The statement follows an official welcome by the government, political parties and non-governmental human rights organizations of Amnesty International's recommendation to establish an independent human rights institution with the powers to investigate complaints of human rights violations and to carry out human rights education programs, as proposed by a delegation during a recent visit to Liberia.

"There was also a general consensus that the police, military and prison system needed restructuring and training in international human rights standards on law enforcement," the human rights organization said.

Civil society organizations and certain former faction leaders said they would welcome a Truth Commission, similar to that operating in South Africa, to inquire into the atrocities committed against the civilian population in Liberia. Some also called for the creation of a War Crimes Tribunal. 

Massive human rights abuses were inflicted on Liberia's 2.8 million people during its bloody civil war, lasting from 1989 to 1997. About 200,000 Liberian people were killed, over 700,000 became refugees, and an estimated 1.4 million people are internally displaced.

"The importance of finding out the truth is imperative; not just for victims and survivors of human rights abuses, but for the future of Liberia. Only when the issue of past human rights violations is addressed can there be enduring peace and true reconciliation in Liberia," Amnesty International said.

Amnesty International is also concerned about continuing human rights abuses by soldiers from the West African peace-keeping force, ECOMOG, who presently carry out regular law enforcement functions in Liberia. For example, one person was recently beaten to death and four others tortured by peace-keepers who were supposedly looking for weapons in Lajoy village in Grand Cape Mount County.

"The use of force had nothing to do with self-defence and everything to do with intimidation, interrogation and a blatant disregard for humanitarian and human rights law," Amnesty International said. During its mission, Amnesty International delegates met other victims of ECOMOG brutality who reported beatings and torture.

The UN Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) in 1995 was entrusted with the mandate to investigate and report on human rights violations. Amnesty International is disappointed that despite repeated complaints of human rights violations committed by the armed factions and the ECOMOG peace-keeping force UNOMIL has not issued detailed public reports of these investigations to the UN.

"The Security Council was informed in March that the UN had sent ECOMOG details of allegations that ECOMOG soldiers had mistreated former fighters and civilians during weapons-recovery operations but no action has so far been taken by the Economic Community of West African States or by the ECOMOG peace-keeping operation to follow up these allegations," Amnesty International said.

"We are also alarmed by the fact that no real steps have been taken to ensure that ECOMOG respects the rights of detainees or those who are questioned. In the absence of a Status of Forces Agreement, ECOMOG appears to be operating outside any legal framework and detainees remain at risk of ill-treatment."

Despite the call from the UN Commission on Human Rights for human rights monitors to be deployed at least during and after the elections, so far there are no plans for such deployment. There are currently only three United Nations human rights officers investigating and reporting on human rights violations throughout Liberia.

"Proposals for a substantial increase in the human rights presence need to be drawn up as soon as possible. A needs assessment mission should also be undertaken to consider what sort of technical cooperation and advisory services can be offered to the new police force, the army, judiciary and local human rights organizations," Amnesty International said.

Issued May 29, 1997

For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44-71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Amnesty International Launches Campaign to Assist;
Refugees


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

London - Amnesty International United Kingdom (AIUK) today launched a new campaign with the publication of Refugees - Human Rights Have No Borders, a report calling on the world's governments to fulfill their international obligations for the protection of refugees.

With the scale of human rights violations that force people into exile continuing and the number of people needing international protection rising, states are going to great lengths to prevent asylum-seekers entering their territory. The campaign aims to raise public awareness of how people become refugees and the link with human rights violations as a major cause of flight.

Over 200 local AIUK groups will take part in the campaign. Many will be leafleting the public on Saturday at major airports and ports of entry in a national day of action. 

In the UK, the organisation is urging the new Government to ensure that its commitments to a "faster, fairer and firmer" asylum process will translate into truly fair and efficient procedures, dispelling the "culture of disbelief" amongst those making decisions on asylum cases. In 1996, of the 38,960 decisions taken in asylum cases only 6% were granted refugee status.

As detained asylum-seekers around the country protest against the unfair and arbitrary detention of asylum-seekers pending the outcome of their claim, AIUK is calling on the Government to review this practice.

While welcoming several of Labour's commitments to tackling aspects of the current asylum system, AIUK is calling on the Government to carry out a wide-ranging review of the asylum process, including a reinstatement of benefits for all asylum applicants and an end to the inordinate delays in the processing of applications.

AIUK welcomes Labour's commitments not to operate the "white list" of designated countries where there is perceived to be in general no serious risk of persecution but to look at each case on its individual merits. It also welcomes indications that discrimination against those who have entered the UK via a third country will end, guaranteeing all asylum applicants an in- country right of appeal.

However, these steps have not yet come into effect. In fact, the removal of asylum-seekers to third countries was suspended on 8 May only to be resumed on 9 May.

BACKGROUND: THE INTERNATIONAL CONTEXT

Internationally, governments increasingly show a callous disregard for the impact of policies deliberately designed to prevent people who are genuinely fleeing persecution from reaching safety in their countries.

There are more than 15 million men, women and children refugees and a further 20 million people internally displaced because they have been forced to leave their homes but have not crossed an international border.

In 1951, in the aftermath of the Second World War, states formulated the Refugee Convention in order to deal with the mass outpourings of people. One of the key principles spelled out in the Convention and general international law is that of non- refoulement -- that no one should be forcibly returned to a country where his or her life or freedom would be at risk .

"Governments have made the rules on the refugees and they should now play by those rules," Amnesty International said. "The increasingly restrictive approach that more and more governments take towards refugees makes a mockery of their international and national obligations."

This restrictive approach includes limiting access to their countries, harshly applying asylum criteria, detaining asylum- seekers, temporarily protecting or forcibly repatriating refugees, and fining airlines and shipping companies if they carry people who do not have travel documents.

"While governments may have the right to control their borders, they do not have the right to refuse people access to asylum procedures," Amnesty International said.

Amnesty International's message is simple. No-one wants to be a refugee. Refugees are the product of human rights violations and their rights should not be further violated when they seek asylum.

Issued May 30, 1997

For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44-71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Kenya;
Amnesty International Sends Delegation to Kenya


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

London - An Amnesty International high level delegation led by Secretary General Pierre Sane arrives in Nairobi on 1 June 1997 for a 12-day visit to Kenya.

The delegates will be meeting with representatives of the government, political parties and non-governmental organizations to discuss the Amnesty International's concerns about the human rights situation in the country and Kenya's role in human rights protection elsewhere in Africa. 

The delegation will be launching Amnesty International's Human Rights Manifesto for Kenya, and calling on all political parties to include human rights protection and promotion in their manifestos for the forthcoming general elections. Amnesty International is particularly concerned about harassment of critics of the government, ill-treatment -- sometimes amounting to torture -- of political prisoners, prison conditions and what appears to be the use of excessive force by Police. The delegation will be calling on the government to bring Kenya's constitution into line with international standards on human rights.

During the visit the delegates hope to meet representatives of the government, including President Daniel Arap Moi, the Attorney General and Home Affairs Minister. The delegation will also meet representatives of political parties, the Kenya Human Rights Commission, the Law Society of Kenya, the National Union of Journalists and non-governmental organizations and religious communities.

For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44-71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Algeria;
HRW Report: Algerian Election Faces Problems


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3040 words


 

New York - Rampant political violence is only one of the factors standing in the way of a free and fair Algerian election on June 5, Human Rights Watch/Middle East charges in a report issued today.

Media censorship, restrictions on categories of parties, the hasty promotion of a new pro-government party, and widespread repression against suspected Islamists, their families and sympathizers all weigh heavily on voters as they go to the polls.

In the thirty-five page report, "Algeria: Elections in the Shadow of Violence and Repression," which is based on a two-week mission to Algeria in April, Human Rights Watch condemns grave human rights abuses committed both by the security forces and by armed Islamist groups. The report describes how the terror and repression have intimidated Algerians of varying political persuasions from becoming politically involved.

Those in power in Algeria have proclaimed their hope that these elections will erase the taint they incurred when the last legislative elections were cancelled in 1992. They have claimed that the vote will culminate the restoration of democracy, and have invited foreign election observers to monitor the process. 

Human Rights Watch cautions, however, against viewing the June 5 election as the capstone of the process of establishing democratic rule in Algeria. If these elections are to be a step toward ending the political stalemate, significant additional steps will be required for the Algerian people to be able, in a meaningful way, to exercise their human right to "take part in the conduct of public affairs, directly or through freely chosen representatives." This right is central to Algeria's political crisis, since it was the denial of that right during three decades of one-party rule and when authorities annulled the country's first multi-party legislative elections which led to the political violence becoming endemic, and which has diminished in the eyes of many Algerians the legitimacy of those who govern them.

Human Rights Watch calls on the international community to monitor not only the elections themselves, but conditions in Algeria after the elections, and to press the government to curtail human rights abuses and to respect fully the rights of freedom of expression, association and political participation. Aid and partnership agreements with the government of Algeria should be linked to measurable progress in these domains.

The report describes the following factors coloring the legislative elections, the first affecting what is at stake and the others detracting from the extent to which they should be considered free and fair.

A weakened National Assembly: The Assembly to be elected on June 5 is a far weaker body than the one that was to have been chosen in 1992. The new constitution, drafted by the authorities and approved in a controversial November 1996 referendum, has stripped the assembly of many of its lawmaking powers, while strengthening the office of the president and creating a second legislative chamber, one-third of whose members are appointed by the president and two-thirds of whom are elected by local officials who themselves will have been been elected by popular vote. While international human rights standards do not dictate how power should be divided among different branches of government, it is important to note the significantly reduced powers of the institution that is being elected through popular suffrage.

Ongoing political violence and repression: Although many Algerians have courageously and defiantly plunged into the campaign, the rampant violence, for which the security forces and armed Islamist groups are responsible, continues to claim scores of lives each week and has terrorized many Algerians who would wish to express their views or take part in political life. Political activists from a wide range of parties and tendencies have been assassinated since 1992, including at least five so far in the run-up to this legislative election. The report contains testimonies of Algerians who have been victimized by the security forces and by violent opposition groups.

Exclusion of parties: Certain provisions of the 1996 constitution and 1997 political parties law violate the right to freedom of association by not permitting parties based on religion, region, language or gender. The Islamist Salvation Front, the movement that was poised to win the last legislative elections, was outlawed in 1992 and remains barred from any political activity. Other parties have been required to change elements of their names and program in order to comply with the law.

Restrictions and favoritism: Authorities have to some extent restricted the political activities and coverage on state- controlled radio and television of some legal parties, particularly those that criticize the interruption of the last legislative elections. By contrast, the authorities have facilitated the rapid rise of the National Democratic Rally (RND), a party formed in February to mobilize support for the President and his government and which is running candidates in all districts.

Media censorship: Although the Algerian print press is more free than many in the Middle East and North Africa, systematic censorship in the press of security-related news and, to a lesser extent, of criticism of government corruption and performance, deprives voters of information concerning some of the key issues in this campaign. The authorities have harrassed publications and journalists associated with independent print media, and have preserved state-controlled television as a government mouthpiece. The ability of journalists to gather and disseminate news and information has also been impeded by the unprecedented assassination campaign that has cost the lives of fifty-nine media workers since 1992. Armed opposition groups are believed responsible for most of these killings.

The Human Rights Watch report addresses a series of recommendations to the government of Algeria, the countries sending election observers, and to the European Union and its member states. Human Rights Watch also makes recommendations to the armed groups.

To the government of Algeria: -End censorship and pressures on the media that aim to enforce a state monopoly on information related to the internal security situation, including human rights violations, or that aim to restrict other coverage that displeases government officials.

-End all measures designed to impede the peaceful activities and public expression of political parties and movements, including those that urge the inclusion of the FIS in negotiations with the government.

-Bring domestic legislation on political parties into conformity with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights by abolishing the prohibition on parties based on religion, gender, race or region. Such broad-based prohibitions violate the right of Algerians to freedom of association.

-Take steps to halt human rights abuses perpetrated by the security forces, including arbitrary detention, "disappearances," extrajudicial executions, and torture, that target suspected Islamist activists, their relatives, and suspected sympathizers. Such abuses are presently praticed with virtual impunity.

To the armed groups: Human Rights Watch urges all armed groups to:

-Halt immediately deliberate attacks on civilians and noncombatants, and indiscriminate attacks that disregard the protection of civilians.

-Cease all activities intended to threaten or intimidate persons because of their personal or political beliefs or activities.

Persons empowered to speak on behalf of the FIS, as a movement with aspirations to political power in Algeria, should clearly and unconditionally condemn attacks by armed Islamist groups against all civilians and other acts that violate basic human rights and humanitarian norms. These include all acts and threats of violence intended to intimidate Algerians who wish to exercise their right to political participation and association. Leaders of the FIS should utilize whatever influence they have over armed groups to end violence against and intimidation of civilians.

To the European Union and Member States:

The European Union is presently negotiating a Euro- Mediterranean Association Agreement with Algeria similar to ones already signed between the E.U. and Morocco, Israel, and Tunisia. Algeria hopes to obtain financial aid or debt relief in the context of this accord. Article 2 of each association agreement states, "Respect for the democratic principles and fundamental human rights established by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights inspires the domestic and external policies of the (European) Community and of (the other party) and constitutes an essential element of this Agreement." Human Rights Watch makes the following recommendations to the European Union and member states:

-The European Commission and Council of Ministers, and E.U. member states, should scrutinize not only the June 5 elections but also human rights conditions in the months that follow the elections, and make clear to the Algerian government that improved relations depend on the government's making tangible progress in improving in human rights practices and in giving greater substance to the right of Algerian people to participate in self-governance.

-In particular, the European Commission and Council of Ministers, and E.U. member states, should monitor the extent to which the elections represent a starting point for the government to redress some of the outstanding human rights issues for which authorities are responsible, such as the hundreds of cases of "disappearances." They should publicly acknowledge and condemn these practices by Algerian authorities, and submit lists of names of reportedly "disappeared" persons that come to their attention and request clarifications from Algiers.

-The European Commission and Council of Ministers, and E.U. member states, should assess whether state broadcasting media remain open to opposition views, as they have to a degree during the election campaign, or revert to their rigid practices of recent years, and whether the print press is allowed real freedom. They should further monitor whether the policy of granting visas relatively freely in the run-up to elections to journalists and foreign observers, including human rights monitors, will revert to the more restrictive past policy on visas.

-The European Parliament should adopt an urgent resolution, making reference to Article 2 of the draft Association Agreement with Algeria, requesting the European Commission and Council of Ministers to undertake the above recommendations and to report back to the Parliament with regard to these undertakings.

-The European Parliament should itself undertake to document human rights developments in Algeria in the post-election period.

Countries Sending Election Observers: Those countries participating in the multi-national election monitoring effort have a responsibility to provide a frank and public assessment of the atmosphere for free and fair voting, despite the difficult conditions on the ground faced by their observers. The lackluster and silent monitoring of the 1995 Algerian presidential elections by the Arab League, Organization of African Unity and the United Nations enabled the authorities to boast of the international presence without any having to face thorough monitoring or public reporting by the observers. This time, governments and multilateral institutions sending election observers must not forfeit the leverage for improvements that their presence offers. They should take steps to ensure that their observers are able to have access to potential sources of pertinent information regarding the free character of the polling, including restrictions on basic civil and political rights for all Algerians. They should ensure that their observers are able to speak publicly and promptly concerning conditions. If the observers travel with armed escorts from the security forces, assigned for their protection, they have a duty to weigh the deterrent effect this will have on ordinary citizens and party activists who might otherwise approach them with complaints about irregularities, and should identify means of enabling these potential sources to meet with them in private in order to provide them with information pertinent to the elections. If the armed security personnel are assigned against their express wishes, or if other obstacles are placed on their access or activities, observers should publicly state that such constraints can impugn the freedom and fairness of the elections themselves.

In addition, foreign governments that maintain contact with representatives of the FIS should demand, as a condition of such relations, that the FIS take specific and visible steps to implement the above recommendations that are addressed to it.

Issued May 30, 1997

For further information, contact Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972-8400 FAX: 212/972- 0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org;1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (05/22 - 06/01)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Geneva - End illegal occupation of Western Sahara, urges South African MP (24.04.97)

South Africa should do all it could to end Morocco's illegal occupation of the Western Sahara, chairman of the foreign affairs committee Raymond Suttner said. The question of Western Sahara remained a blot on the map of Africa, he said in debate on the foreign affairs budget vote.

It was important for South Africa to move towards implementing President Nelson Mandela's mid-1995 commitment to extend diplomatic relations to the Saharan Arab Democratic Republic. 

"We need, in line with out commitment to self-determination, to convince the Moroccans to vacate the area," he said.

South Africa had to be seen to ally itself with the poorest of the poor and, in international relations, with those people struggling for self determination. There were limitations on what it could do about situations far from its borders. But what it could do was vote in line with its constitutional principles when the situation arose (ANC Daily News Briefing).

Conference of the UN Special Committee on Decolonization (21- 23.05.97)

In the frame of the Decade of Eradication of Colonialism the UN Special Committee on Decolonization organized a conference at Antigua and Barbuda. The Polisario was present by its permanent representative in the USA, Mulud Said, who made a statement.

The conference adopted a declaration concerning Western Sahara, in which it affirms that the Special Committee has to observe closely the implementation of a fair and free self determination referendum for the Sahrawi people.

Solidarity (24.05.97)

A manifestation named "Six Hours For Western Sahara" took place at Brussels with the presentation of a film, a photo exhibition and political debates, in presence of a numerous public.

26.05.97 Reform of the judicial system

The president of the Supreme Court, judge Ahmed Sid Ali, has sworned the clerks, the advocates and the experts of the SADR courts. The ceremony took place with the presence of the Minister of Justice Mr. Hammati Rabbani, Mr. Mustapha Ali Sidi El Bachir, member of the National Council and wali of Awsserd, Mr. Hamada Salam Daf, president of the Council of Jurisprudence, and other personalities.

28.05.97 Morocco-Italian Interparlamentary group

An interparlamentary group with about 130 Italian deputees was founded at Rome in order to develop the friendly relationship with Moroccan people and the exchange of informations about political, social, economical and cultural matters between the two countries.

30.05.97 Disappearance

Mr Hammad Ali Hamad, Sahrawi citizen born in El Ayun in the sixties, was arrested in the night of May 26th at El Ayun by Moroccan police and disappeared (AFAPREDESA).

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax: 0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW: http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.

22 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Sports - General;
How to beat these Lions


BYLINE: Gavin Rich, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Cape Town - Harry Viljoen has one bit of advice for Carel du Plessis, who goes into his critical first hands-on week as Springbok coach: don't even think of trying to beat the Lions by taking them on wide.

Du Plessis has shown a strong inclination to promote creative back-play, but Western Province coach Viljoen is adamant, after seeing his team lose 38-21, that a wide game is not the way to go.

"I think we are going to have to try and take them up front, trying anything else might be suicidal," said Viljoen. The Lions and the Boks meet for the first time at Newlands on June 21. 

"All my backline players spoke highly of the Lions backs, and that includes James Small," said Viljoen. "I don't think we can beat the Lions by spreading the ball, because I think they have our number at the back."

Viljoen's views dovetail with those of his most impressive player on Saturday, Andrew Aitken.

The Province No 8 was also clearly impressed by the Lions' ability to run slide-rule angles into open space. "Their lines of running were extremely good, as were their ball skills," he said. "It would not surprise me one bit if the Lions reached the first test unbeaten. The scrum is the key area for them now."

Not that the two WP men believe the Lions are soft up front.

Viljoen says, however, there may be some deficiencies in the Lions' body positions when they go into the loose scrums and the Boks could exploit these. Aitken has similar reservations.

"They've got to get that scrummage sorted out," said Aitken. "If they try to run the ball in retreat against the Springboks they'll find themselves in real strife."

"We must go in low and work them from all angles," said Viljoen. "The way to beat them is to take the ball in close and work our way through at the fringes. We must try and turn them around in the forwards and we must establish some control over them before trying to move the ball down the backs."

The Province coach said his team had tried to work this plan at Newlands, but had achieved limited success because "we simply didn't have the players to do it". However he says the Boks have the material to play the game he envisages.

One of the Lions stars of Saturday, Tim Rodber, said, however, the tourists were not worried about their scrumming. "The trouble was that we took on our scrumming task as individuals and not as a pack, but that can be sorted out."

Lions forward coach Jim Telfer explained the difference in scrumming between South African and British sides. "British teams tend to go down and then relax before the ball comes in, while South Africans maintain the intensity after the hit. That is something we warned the players about beforehand, but there is nothing like first-hand experience to drum the message home," said Telfer.

Meanwhile the Lions will be strengthened this week with the imminent arrival of England flyhalf Michael Catt from Argentina.

Catt, who scored 21 points in England's 46-20 win over Argentina on Saturday, will replace injured Paul Grayson.

Catt was considered by many to be a surprise exclusion from the original Lions tour squad and many British critics consider him a superior all-round player to the more kicking-orientated Grayson.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

23 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
High-rise hotel plan for Cape Town's Foreshore


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Plans are afoot to see Cape Town get another luxury five-star hotel - this time a high-rise one, in the form of the upper 15 floors of the landmark BP Centre on the Foreshore.

This was revealed by Neil Bernstein, managing director of the Devland Group, which recently bought the building at the bottom of Long Street from the Mine Officials' Pension Fund for about R100-million.

The German property company Avanta has a stake in the Devland Group and former Lonhro chief Dieter Bock is a major shareholder in Avanta. 

The BP Centre recently lost its anchor tenant of 20 years, BP South Africa, largely because of the of the building's outdated fire safety measures.

Mr Bernstein said any future plans for the building would also include a R4-million overhaul of the fire safety equipment, including sprinkler systems on all floors.

Mr Bernstein confirmed that the company was investigating the possibility of turning the top 15 floors into a 300-room hotel aimed at business executives.

The refurbishment of the building, including the subdivision of the top 15 floors into hotel rooms, is expected to cost in the region of R120-million.

An American and a European hotel group have expressed interest in the operation of the hotel, he said.

The investigation is expected to be completed within the next two months but Mr Bernstein said "chances are very good" that the plans for the hotel would be realised.

"The building is ideally situated and suited for a hotel. It has 10 lifts, good parking ratios and superb views of Table Mountain, Signal Hill and the bay area."

He said the BP building was tilted at a 45-degree angle which ensured views through and above other buildings.

Any buildings to be constructed on the old power station site on the Foreshore would not affect the views from the top floors because of a 60m height restriction. The BP Centre is about 100m high.

If the hotel plans are realised it will be open for trade by September next year.

Commenting on the possible over-saturation of the luxury hotel market in the city, Mr Bernstein said: "We have to take a long- term view and anyway our hotel would obviously be up much quicker than the other hotels".

If the planned hotel does not go ahead, the entire building will be substantially upgraded and transformed into a five-star office block.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
The first 100 days (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town's new city manager Andrew Boraine has delivered a report on his first 100 days in office in which he focuses on the deep divisions wrought on the city by apartheid

When Cape Town's new City Manager Andrew Boraine asked some people during his first 100 days in his new job what their five top priorities were, they told him: "Housing, housing, housing, housing, and housing."

In his report to the Cape Town municipality, he also pointed out that there were more than 250 000 people in the city who could lay claim to land restitution.

It should come as little surprise that housing should have emerged as the top priority of the city's people and Mr Boraine deserves praise for having enunciated their views so succinctly in his first report. 

His concern over housing delivery and the lack of a housing policy, budget or administrative capacity will find wide resonance in a city which faces an unprecedented and growing inflow of people from many parts of the country and from abroad.

Mr Boraine's relationship with Cape Town is still very new, and the real test of his ability to manage the city's affairs will not be merely in identifying its problems - which are duplicated in almost every town and city of the country - but in finding effective and practical solutions.

That will be discouragingly difficult at a time when budgets everywhere are extremely tight, are likely to remain so for a long time to come, and when expectations are running high.

Mr Boraine and his team have set a commendable pace in their first 100 days, but the many challenging days that lie ahead will call for innovation and leadership and the support of all communities in a bold and exciting endeavour to restore unity to the greater Cape Town community and shape a brighter and more equitable future for all its citizens.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

25 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
Peace talks and a party for Irish


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Cape Town - Hopes for a breakthrough at the "bosberaad" workshop for Irish political leaders at De Hoop have been boosted after political foes socialised at the weekend.

Delegates from nine Irish groups - including Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and the militant pro-British unionists - attended a party on Saturday night, at which there was drinking and folk singing.

Roelf Meyer, the former National Party cabinet minister who is one of the chief facilitators of the workshop aimed at helping Irish leaders find a peaceful settlement in their country, described the party as a breakthrough. 

"There was socialising. There was a get-together of a social nature by all, but it did not mean they were talking to each other," Mr Meyer said.

President Mandela and his partner Graca Machel visited the workshop on Saturday and urged delegates to find a way of overcoming their differences.

Provincial Affairs and Constitutional Development Minister Valli Moosa said yesterday the workshop was proceeding smoothly. The Irish delegates were willing to learn from South Africa's transition.

"I detected a distinct willingness from the parties. I feel the delegates present here are in favour of a real negotiated settlement," Mr Moosa said.

"I had a sense that the Irish parties had set aside time to be here and participate in this workshop because of the need they have for a settlement. We found a real willingness for some movement from it. It would be presumptuous to say this would make a decisive impact on the thinking of negotiators in Ireland. Only time will tell if it has been of value or not."

Mr Meyer said the workshop had gone very well and could help lay the foundations for peace talks in Northern Ireland. "I think there was some progress. I hope their visit here will make a difference. Maybe it will help them go home with a more constructive approach to each other."

There had been good interaction among most of the parties but delegations from the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) and the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) had initially refused to have anything to do with Sinn Fein. The workshop was nearly derailed within minutes of its start on Friday when the leader of the UUP delegation, David Trimble, walked into the dining hall where Sinn Fein chief negotiator Martin McGuiness was standing. The angry unionists threatened to leave, but the organisers quelled the tensions.

To keep the antagonists apart, separate accommodation, bars and dining facilities had to be organised. South African negotiators also had to hold separate briefings.

"There were strong reservations on the side of the unionists and that meant interaction did not really take place. But as far as other parties were concerned, it was good," Mr Meyer said.

He believed the workshop had further enhanced South Africa's stature on the world stage.

"I think it was very important that South Africa could utilise this opportunity and that we were asked to do it." The conference ends today.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
Alex Boraine must resign from TRC, Nats demand


BYLINE: Political Staff, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - The confrontation between the National Party and the Truth and Reconciliation Commission increased today with a formal NP demand that TRC deputy chairman Alex Boraine resign forthwith.

The demand was reportedly delivered to the TRC with a threat that the NP would take it to court if Dr Boraine did not leave.

According to Nat-supporting newspapers, an NP letter also demanded an apology from TRC chairman Desmond Tutu, for remarks he made after the NP's second submission last month. 

Archbishop Tutu would not respond yesterday, saying he had heard nothing from the NP yet and was not prepared to "discuss the matter through the media".

The letter refers to the TRC's allegedly biased and aggressive handling of NP leader FW de Klerk during and after the NP's second submission to the commission last month. It threatens the TRC with legal action unless:

* Archbishop Tutu apologises unreservedly for his remarks and undertakes to stick to the letter of the TRC legislation, which demands even-handedness from members of the commission.

* Dr Boraine resigns immediately as deputy chairman and commissioner.

* Glen Goosen, head of the TRC's investigative unit, undertakes never again to be involved in any investigation of the NP.

NP spokesman Anneke Greyling confirmed the letter would be handed to the TRC today, but would not elaborate on legal steps the NP was considering.

The NP has previously expressed its anger over the TRC's handling of its submission, claiming commissioners' questioning of Mr De Klerk was too aggressive and revealed bias. The ANC representatives, in contrast, were handled with kid gloves, the NP said.

Legal experts were perplexed about the legal action which the NP might take, pointing out that the party's claim of bias was largely a matter of opinion on which most courts would be reluctant to rule.

"Given the nature of the TRC's work, and the fact that it is largely focused on the deeds of the former NP government, it would be extremely difficult for the NP to prove bias or unfair treatment," a senior advocate commented today.

"In any event, no court is going to tell the commission that Dr Boraine has to resign, or that certain TRC commissioners may not deal with certain matters. That is not the role of a court."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


2 June, 1997


Business and Finance;
Suspension looms for Liberty Life


BYLINE: Business Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Cape Town - The next round in the fight between Liberty Life and the other members of the powerful Life Offices Association has been postponed to July when a special meeting will decide on action against Liberty, accused of breaking the rules on payment of commissions.

The LOA's management committee has decided to recommend Liberty be suspended until the end of August. 

Liberty's payment of fees to brokers who use its new Blueprint system has drawn the fire of fellow assurers, who accuse the group of breaching the commission regulations under the Insurance Act as well as the association's code.

Competitors claim the R120 payment for entering information on clients in the company's computerised Blueprint financial needs analysis programme is an extra commission.

Liberty says the fee is not a commission but a payment to sales staff for work previously done by administrative staff, whose numbers were cut when the programme was introduced.

In a statement after Friday's management committee meeting, the LOA said a panel had found that Liberty was in breach of the code.

The issue of a possible contravention of regulations under the Insurance Act should be dealt with by the Registrar of Insurance, the LOA said.

The association has appointed a sub-committee, headed by Marius Smith of Metropolitan Life, to investigate the question of commission payable to intermediaries and to decide whether or not the regulations and the code should be amended.

At the July meeting the management committee will recommend that Liberty be "strongly reprimanded" for breaching the code of conduct and that it should be suspended from the association until the Marius Smith committee reports on August 27.

The committee hoped Liberty would change its mind and adhere to the code until it was "properly amended".


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cosatu: 'We'll step up fight'


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Cape Town - Unions today threatened to intensify mass action against the Basic Conditions of Employment Draft Bill if the Government refuses their demands for a 40-hour working week and six months' maternity leave.

The Confederation of SA Trade Unions deputy-president, Connie September, issued the warning to the Cape Argus before an estimated 5 000 marchers set off from the Grand Parade to deliver memoranda to the SA Chamber of Business and the Department of Labour offices.

She said Cosatu's executive committee would meet later this month to discuss the planned action. "If nothing happens between now and June 24, Cosatu will take a decision to intensify rolling mass action," she said. 

Cosatu called today's countrywide marches and a 24-hour general strike in a bid to compel the business community and the Government to accept its argument for a 40-hour working week and six months' maternity leave, four months of which is to be paid.

Cape Town marchers said the unwillingness of business to listen to Cosatu had forced them to strike. "We will strike again and again until they listen," said marcher Shanaaz van Blerk.

The clothing industry, one of the region's biggest employers, was virtually at a standstill today as 70 percent of its workers heeded the strike call.

"The majority of factories have reported high levels of absence," said Johan Baard, chairman of the Cape Clothing Manufacturers' Association.

Elsewhere the response was mixed. Early today, Charl Adams of the Cape Chamber of Commerce and Industry said that there appeared to be "patchy" support for the strike.

One large employer with 11 000 staff members had been unaffected, while a technical company reported an 80 percent stayaway at one branch but full attendance at another.

Essential services appeared largely unaffected by the stayaway.

The Golden Arrow bus company reported a 14 percent stayaway by staff who were members of the Cosatu-affiliated Transport and General Workers Union.

Public relations officer Jeanne Welsh said most staff were members of the Transport and Omnibus Workers Union, affiliated to the National Council of Trade Unions (Nactu), and all had reported for duty.

Metrorail spokeswoman Riana Jacobs said there had been "a 100 percent turn-out" of staff and that the numbers of passengers appeared normal.

Parliament operated on a skeleton staff after members of the Cosatu-affiliated National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu) downed tools in mid-morning and joined the stayaway.

Nehawu represents about 70 percent of Parliament's unionised workforce.

One of the region's biggest unions - the SA Municipal Workers' Union (Samwu) - announced it would join the Cosatu march from 1.30pm today after briefing staff about a successful wage deal struck last week. But it would maintain essential services.

Elsewhere the response was mixed. Johannesburg services did not appear badly hit, but in Port Elizabeth and Uitenhage, municipal services ground to a halt .


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
TRC finds another death farm in Mpumalanga


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

CAPE TOWN - The Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC)'s investigating team has found yet another Apartheid era death farm near the conservative town of Groblersdal in Mpumalanga and are still investigating for more.

Speaking from the TRC's head office in Cape Town, the head of the investigation unit, Dumisa Ntsebeza, told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Saturday that the farm is between Groblersdal and Dennilton, and used was used as the headquarters of the notorious Mbokodo gang that terrorised and killed a number of political activists in former KwaNdebele homeland. 

"We can not confirmed yet whether the farm was used as a torture centre or as a secret cemetery to bury the bodies of murdered activists," said Ntsebeza.

He added that the TRC's intelligence service team was still investigating additional leads about the farm's history after receiving a tip-off from a former member of the South African Defence Force (SADF)'s intelligent section.

"We believe that by the end of June our investigation into this farm and a number of others will be complete," he explained.

Ntsebeza added that there are basically three types of apartheid 'death farms', namely the death centres themselves where people were killed and buried like Vlakplaas, or interrogation centres were activists were tortured and lastly cemetery farms where murdered activists were secretly buried after being killed during interrogations elsewhere.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Business and Finance;
Samsung and FridgeMaster take on regional market


BYLINE: Jabu Matsebula, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Samsung has announced that it will soon be launching a new range of frost-free fridges manufactured by FridgeMaster Swaziland.

The new range will be primarily exported to South Africa but will also be sold in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia. 

The joint manufacturing agreement follows a series of contracts between Fridgemaster and Samsung aimed at expanding both their presence in the region.

A similar multi-million rand deal between Zimbabwe's Delta and FridgeMaster was also announced last week.

FridgeMaster has already sent a team of technicians to Korea as part of the Samsung agreement, to participate in the final design and initial production phases of the frost free range of fridges.

Some of the new fridges have been undergoing tests over the past month, including 'impact evaluation'.

This involves dropping the shop packaged fridges from heights of up to six feet evaluate the effects of 'Third World conditions', such as delivery vehicle accidents or rough handling would have on the new product. FridgeMaster will exclusively handle the first phases of local production of the new product at its Manzini factory.

The new range was supposed to have been launched in February but both parties decided to postpone the launch until the durability testing had been completed. FridgeMaster sales and marketing executive, Peta Palmer told African Eye News Service (South Africa) that the official launch and image advertising will be handled exclusively by Samsung.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
National minster was warned that 'Mr Housing' had been fired


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nelspruit - Group chairman of Nedcor, Chris Liebenberg, forewarned both national housing minister, Sankie Mthembi- Mahanyele and Mpumalanga Premier Mathews Phosa that the banking group was firing "Mr Housing", Kevin Gibbs.

He also told them that Nedcor was investigating a series of "highly unethical" irregularities allegedly committed by Gibbs.

Lienbenberg told Sunday Times on Saturday that the 'courtesy call' to Mthembi-Mahanyele had been made before she travelled to Mpumalanga to open Motheo Construction's R205-million rural housing project. 

The scheme is currently being investigated by the auditor general following allegations that it is costing the government R33-million more than it should, that it was awarded to Motheo before the company officially existed and that Motheo's founder and director, Thandi Ndlovu, is a close friend of Mthembi- Mahanyele.

The controversy about the scheme, first revealed by the Mail & Guardian, has already cost national housing director general Billy Cobbett his job after he objected to it.

Phosa was informed about Gibb's impending dismissal after the launch and told Liebenberg that the suspension would not affect Mpumalanga's housing programme as the government dealt only with institutions and not individuals.

Although Liebenberg stressed that Gibb's suspension and subsequent dismissal were not directly related to Motheo, he did say that the two page list of charges were "definitely highly unethical".

"Gibbs himself has the two page letter listing the charges but he is refusing to publicly disclose them so we cannot either," explained Liebenberg.

"The charges are in connection with internal regulations which Gibbs broke but I don't know if they would be considered criminal - they are however definitely highly unethical."

Insisting that the calls to Mthembi-Mahanyele and Phosa were not designed to warn them against either Motheo or the rural housing project itself, Liebenberg said that he had decided to warn the politicians simply because he knew that Gibbs had had close dealings with both their departments.

He did not telephone anyone else about the issue.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


South Africa;
Copper thief dies after cutting wrong wire


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

THABAZIMBI - An alleged copper-wire thief was killed instantly after he mistook a live electric cable for a copper telephone- wire near Eskom's Thabazimbi sub-station, African Eye News Service (South Africa) reports.

The alleged thief, Solomon Maseko's (36) decomposing body was only found after residents in the area reported repeated power black-outs and Eskom electrician, Jacob Steenkamp, was sent out to find the fault. 

"Steenknamp found Maseko lying slumped over the live power line, as if he had died in the act of cutting the cable," said police spokesman, Captain Blackie Swart.

"We strongly believe that Maseko, who was unemployed at the time of his death, mistook the electric wire for copper-wire and was killed while trying to steal it."

Swart added that Maseko's wife had last seen her husband alive ten days ago, on the night of May 20.

"We don't know exactly when he died yet, but the body was already decomposing despite the bitterly cold weather. It appears he lay there for a long time." Meanwhile, Telkom reported on Sunday that it has spent over R100 000 trying to repair or replace telephone lines which had been damaged by copper thieves.

A 24-hour toll-free number has been established for members of the public to report any copper theft in their areas.

Callers may remain anonymous and are in line to receive a reward, should the information they supply lead to convictions. The number is 0800 1108 30.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Namibia;
Geingob pledges full support


BYLINE: The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Windhoek - Defeated Swapo vice presidential candidate, Prime Minister Hage Geingob, yesterday expressed the hope that his participation in the race for the post had strengthened the democratic process within the ruling party.

Geingob, who was pipped at the post by the incumbent, the Rev Hendrik Witbooi, drew 41 per cent of the vote from delegates at the ruling party congress in Windhoek.

In a statement yesterday, Geingob warmly congratulated Witbooi on his re-election and assured him of his continued support "in the challenges he faces in the restructuring and strengthening of the party to prepare it to lead Namibia for many years". 

The Prime Minister said he was proud to have contributed to the evolution of a new culture of public debate of issues by candidates without mudslinging.

"In that sense, with the culmination of the congress, the party has come out stronger and more united than ever before to work for the benefit of all Namibians.

I have lost the elections, but it is my hope that the democratic process has become strengthened further," Geingob said.

He also said that he hoped he had exposed, once and for all, those critics who claimed he did not have a constituency

"The fact that I secured some 41 per cent of the votes at the congress clearly shows that I do have a strong constituency.

Remarkably, this constituency comprises all the thirteen regions of our country," Geingob said.

The Prime Minister also congratulated President Sam Nujoma "on his well-deserved, uncontested election as the President of the Swapo Party for another term". Undoubtedly, he added, under President Nujoma's guidance, Swapo would forge ahead with its commitment to building a better Namibia.

Geingob also thanked all those who had supported him, campaigned and voted for him. He particularly singled out Minister of Lands, Pendukeni Ithana, who had "courageously" nominated and motivated his candidature.

Witbooi, who drew 58 per cent support from the 337 delegates, was nominated by the President of the National Union of Namibian Workers (NUNW), Ponhele ya France.

LANGUAGE: English
