34 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Namibia;
Central Committee Vote Mars Congress


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Windhoek - The new Swapo Central Committee could face credibility problems following claims that the voting procedure was "a complete mess" with confusion reigning throughout the early hours of Sunday as the counting took place.

In addition, the Central Committee which was announced at the close of the Swapo Congress included only seven women out of the 58 elected candidates - a slap in the face for President Sam Nujoma's appeals for greater gender equality in the party.

Some regions failed to get any of their nominated candidates onto the ruling party's key decision-making body, while a number of well-known party faces did not get in and three deputy ministers failed to make the final cut.

The voting for the CC was dogged by problems and apparent incompetence from the outset. 

Voters were given a list of names with corresponding numbers.

Delegates then had to list the 58 numbers out of 122 candidates they preferred on a ballot paper.

However, several party sources said the procedure was severely flawed and questioned whether the result could be regarded as free and fair.

There appeared to have been two different lists of candidates with some having different numbers on each.

In addition, Festus Naholo's name appeared twice on some lists (Nos 29 and 47), while an apparent third Hardap candidate, Marlene Mungunda, was said to have been completely missed off the list.

Adding to the confusion, already-elected officials such as President Sam Nujoma, Hendrik Witbooi as vice-president and Hifikepunye Pohamba as Secretary-General appeared on the lists, although they had already been assured of seats on the CC.

Delegates claimed that according to the proper procedure the results of the elections for the other posts should have been announced before the CC vote, thereby preventing delegates from wasting their votes on candidates who had already secured CC seats by virtue of their offices.

At one point in the early hours of Sunday it appeared as if there was a possibility that the CC election would be declared null and void.

However, the results were eventually announced shortly before 05h00.

It was not clear yesterday if some of the ousted candidates would call for a new election to take place.

Numerous delegates awaiting the outcome of the CC vote also bitterly bemoaned the lengthy delay and confusion, and questioned the organisation of the CC vote. "It should have been simple and straightforward," was a frequent complaint.

One of the vote officials last night dismissed the charges of confusion and procedural irregularities as of no consequence, and said that as far as he knew no official complaints had been lodged as yet.

"There are always typographical errors," the official told The Namibian when approached for comment.

However, he maintained that these had had no effect on the final outcome and that the Central Committee election had been "more democratic than ever".

"No-one can claim they were disadvantaged," he said.

Delegates would have ignored names appearing twice, the official added. He also dismissed the possibility that the existence of at least two versions of the list would have affected the final vote, or the possibility that some Central Committee candidates having different numbers on different ballot sheets would would have influenced the final outcome.

The Namibian was unable to contact the chief presiding officer for the CC poll, Dr Albert Kawana, for comment.

A number of regions failed to get their nominated candidates onto the Central Committee, including Hardap, Karas, Khomas, Oshikoto and Otjozondupa.

The seven women elected are Libertina Amathila, Netumbo Ndaitwah, Saara Kuugongelwa, Pendukeni Ithana, Gertrude Kandanga, Clara Bohitile, and Linea Shaetonhodi.

There were 17 women candidates out a total of 122.

Foreign Minister Theo-Ben Gurirab topped the CC list with 246 votes out of a possible 337, followed by Ministers Jerry Ekandjo, Ben Amathila and Libertina Amathila.

New faces who did particularly well included Nangolo Mbumba who came 11th, Asser Kapere who finished 12th and Ignatius Shixwameni who came 14th.

Prime Minister Hage Geingob finished in 23rd position with 188 votes, while unionist Jacob Nghifindaka gave a strong showing at 21st in the list with 189 votes.

There were also some well-known figures who failed to make the final 58. Deputy minister of youth and sport, Hadino Hishongwa, will not feature in the new CC.

Also out are deputy Environment minister Nangolo Ithete and deputy transport minister Klaus Dierks.

Apart from the three deputy ministers, out went Peter Mweshihange, Iyambo Indongo, Ida Jimmy, Otto Herrigel, and MPs Pashukeni Shoombe, Walter Kemba, Willem Konjore, Angelika Muharikua, Brave Tjizera, Siegfried Wohler and National Councillor Josephine Hamutwe.

Already on the CC by virtue of their office are the secretaries of the Women's Council, Elders Council and Youth League - Erica Ramakhutla, Kanana Hishoono and Paul Kapia - plus the president, vice-president and secretary-general of the party.

The President also has the right to nominate six extra members of the CC, bringing the total to 70. He is likely to come under pressure to make all his choices women to even up the gender imbalance slightly.

It is not clear if John Pandeni as deputy secretary-general will automatically have a place on the CC as this is a new post. He may have to be nominated as one of the six presidential candidates.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Namibia;
Witbooi win reflects a vote for status quo


BYLINE: Political Staff (Analysis), The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Windhoek - The battle for the vice-presidency of Swapo proved to be the dominant issue at the party's second congress in an independent Namibia, which drew to an end in the early hours of yesterday morning.

The final result, announced after a marathon final session of the congress, was a comfortable but not overwhelming victory for the incumbent, Hendrik Witbooi, who gained 58 per cent of the delegates' votes.

Prime Minister Hage Geingob picked up 41 per cent of the vote - a respectable result which answered his critics who have claimed he had no support base within the party.

In the end it appears that delegates' votes were not decided on the basis of ideological or policy differences between the two candidates, nor their post-independence achievements, but on their personal styles. 

The energetic campaign launched by Geingob, which included widespread lobbying and full page newspaper adverts, appeared to backfire to a certain extent, with a number of party delegates preferring Witbooi's less sophisticated approach.

Geingob is a much more vigorous political personality than Witbooi and is not afraid of bluntly telling people when he thinks they are wrong or are not performing well enough.

Congress insiders said some senior MPs, including cabinet ministers, voted for Witbooi not because they were completely positive about his candidature but because they were tired of the Prime Minister's dominating political style and found Witbooi less threatening. In this sense Witbooi was something of a compromise candidate representing the status quo.

Ironically Witbooi was voted back in on the strength of the northern vote while many southern delegates backed Geingob.

Party sources said that many northern voters backed Witbooi, while hoping that a candidate from the North will emerge at a later stage to either contest the vice or presidential positions. However, party sources, even those who voted for Witbooi, said that Geingob was unlikely to be severely damaged by his loss.

In fact, by challenging Witbooi he is being credited with opening up a new political culture of democracy within the party.

QUESTION OF SUCCESSION

Witbooi's victory still leaves open the question of a successor to President Nujoma. While Witbooi is clearly a respected figure in the party, many feel that he is not in the final analysis 'presidential material'.

In this sense his victory does not make him the 'heir apparent' for the party's leadership.

Rather it opens up the question - with the 'silent man' of this congress, Hidipo Hamutenya, now emerging as a stronger contender after President Nujoma's third term.

DEBATE SHORT ON MUSCLE

While the contest between Geingob and Witbooi was historic in the sense that it set a precedent for democratic elections for Swapo leadership positions, there were other aspects of the congress which were less encouraging.

The congress was held in unnecessary secrecy with journalists kept waiting outside the Showgrounds for most of the gathering. There were no official media briefings during the Congress.

There was also apparently little meaningful debate on policy issues and most of the resolutions passed on Government's record and plans appear fairly perfunctory.

Little was made of the slow progress on land reform or other areas where Government performance could be criticised.

At the same time there were few bold new initiatives or policy ideas which appeared to come out of the congress.

Finally the chaos of the Central Committee vote was indicative of a general air of disorganisation surrounding the congress.

On a more positive note, the Central Committee put forward a number of proposals for reforming the internal workings of Swapo, which include ensuring that it becomes a party based on a paid-up membership.

New party secretary-general Hifikepunye Pohamba will face a major challenge in implementing these plans, and many at the Congress expect him to stand down from his ministerial position to concentrate on building up the party's administration.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Namibia;
Swapo backs third term 'only for Nujoma'


BYLINE: The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Windhoek - THE Swapo Congress endorsed a Central Committee proposal to ensure that President Sam Nujoma is allowed to serve a third term.

The Central Committee recommended that the Constitution be changed so that the first President of Namibia is able to serve two terms of office "upon a mandate by direct popular vote".

The motion put forward by the Central Committee said the first term of office served by Nujoma should not be regarded as a term of office in relation to the Constitution's limitations on the number of terms served. 

President Nujoma was elected by the Constituent Assembly and not by popular vote in the 1989 election (which was only for parties).

He won his first mandate by popular vote in 1994 in the presidential elections.

The wording put forward by the Central Committee makes it clear that only Nujoma will be allowed to serve three terms and subsequent presidents of Namibia will be limited to two five-year terms.

The motion also endorsed Nujoma, as the Swapo President, to be the party's presidential candidate for the next elections scheduled for 1999

In its preamble to its motion, the Central Committee cited Nujoma's "long and unbroken history of tested leadership qualities" and his role as the "founding father of the nation" as reasons for motivating a third term.

Minister of Information Ben Amathila told NBC-TV last night that a committee had been set up to work out the exact legal mechanism through which a third term for Nujoma could be assured. It is then expected that the proposal for amending the constitution will be brought before the National Assembly where it will require two-thirds backing from MPs

The Congress also resolved that an extraordinary congress should be convened during 1998 to consider amendments to the Swapo constitution.

The resolution said "there is a strong feeling that the party's political and physical infrastructure" had to be closely re-examined to maintain "the party's cohesion".

Amendment proposals need to be submitted to the Central Committee six months before the holding of the extraordinary congress.

NBC-TV reported last night that congress also passed a resolution calling for women to make up 30 per cent of candidates for the Central Committee at future congresses and 50 per cent of candidates for future national elections.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Beyond Classroom Education In Africa


BYLINE: APS Correspondent Samuel Sarpong, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - The present dearth of information in Africa might soon change into a market of affluence, hopefully by next year.

And this ambitious initiative is being undertaken by the WorldSpace Incorporated, a US-based company whose Chairman and Chief Executive Mr. Noah Samara is convinced education and information sharing among Africans in Africa would be the key that liberates the continent's immense potential.

Born of a Sudanese father and an Ethiopian mother, Samara established WorldSpace in 1990. By 1995, the company had acquired licences to operate satellites in Africa, the Middle East, Central America, the Caribbean and Asia, with a potential audience of 4.5 billion people. The project has an investment of about $1 billion. 

WorldSpace is, however, launching its first satellite, AfriStar, in June 1998 and the first major conference on its use will focus on education.

Although the WorldSpace system is designed to cater for all forms of audio broadcasting, the initial thrust is being put on education because of its dire need on the continent. Whereas there is a will to raise literacy levels in affected parts of Africa, economic policies enforced by the World Bank/International Monetary Fund (IMF) have not only meant that fewer and fewer parents can afford the high cost of sending their children to school, but also governments are unable to subsidize and expand their educational services such as building and equipping classrooms.

Samara says his investment grew out of a desire to spread information throughout Africa, having recognised the deficiencies in the system. He only added the Middle East, Caribbean and Asia to the project in order to achieve economies of scale.

Distance education, a relatively new concept in Africa, would therefore enjoy a boost when AfriStar becomes operational in June next year. Samara's project comes in handy at a time when most countries in Africa are desperately seeking means of opening up new frontiers for learning.

In Ghana for instance, efforts have been made to institute a nation-wide distance education programme in the country. Currently, tertiary institutions admit less than 40 per cent of qualified applicants because of limited space on campuses, not to mention fees that are beyond the reach of the average person. This situation usually brings in disappointment to many homes at the beginning of each academic year.

"We cannot continue making such a large number of intelligent people who are capable of pursuing university education feel they are not good enough to be given admission," says Ghana's President Jerry John Rawlings, who admits he is very much disturbed by the trend.

Pressed to do something about the situation, the government in 1996 approved a nation-wide distance education programme to help solve the problem. "Preparations are now far advanced for its implementation this year," assures Prof. Dominic Agyemang, Chairman of the Distance Education Council in Ghana.

Among the agencies that are supporting Ghana in setting up its distance education project are the Commonwealth of Learning, Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), British Overseas Development Agency (ODA), French government and the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). UNESCO has pledged US$40,000 towards the provision of equipment for the project.

The ever-increasing demand for education at all levels and the realisation that every person needs to continue to learn throughout life, has led policy makers and educationists to turn more and more to open learning and distance education. For Ghanaians in particular, distance education is indeed very significant to their aspirations.

The country has set itself the task of achieving free compulsory basic education for all her citizens of school going- age by the year 2005.

It has also been engaged in a functional literacy programme since 1991 with the objective of reaching more than 5 million people with useful education.

"These are enormous tasks and the introduction of such a vital information system like the WorldSpace will help us accelerate our pace and achieve our objectives," said President Rawlings when he opened a three-day conference on Technology and Distance Education dubbed, Opening New Frontiers For Learning in Accra late April this year.

The conference which focussed on the use of radio to spread education and information rapidly and cheaply through the length and breadth of Africa was sponsored by Ghana's Ministry of Education, Canada-based Commonwealth of Learning and WorldSpace Incorporated.

It provided opportunities for organisations and educationists to reflect on experiences in the field of distance education and ways of bringing education to a wider audience. The conference also attested to the commitment of WorldSpace to distance education and development and deliberated on how to use WordSpace's formidable technology in order to spread education throughout the continent.

WorldSpace's Samara, who gave a presentation, noted that the satellite innovation can change the quality of life in Africa. Programmes can be tailored for virtually all needs, taking into account local languages, cultures, degrees of awareness and interests.

The price for a basic receiver is expected to be around $150 although WorldSpace is hopeful that as economies occur, the price can be reduced to between $20 and $30.

The WorldSpace recognises radio as the best instrument for information and mass education for the deprived regions. "Our commitment is to provide access to our technology to enable people to improve their lives," says Samara.

Indeed, enhanced access to information is vital if people are to make informed choices. This would also assist the people of the deprived world regions to address the critical problems of literacy, health, civic education, women's issues, child survival and environment.

Since conventional means such as building more schools are not simply feasible in Africa any more because of cuts in budgetary allocations, it is opportune that Africa embraces the concept of distance education so as to receive its spark of life. Currently, educational needs are multiplying but the ability to serve these needs are diminishing.

The participants were quick to note that partnership is perhaps the best means of assisting in this ground breaking endeavour and called for the pooling of resources to make the concept a reality.

Without knowledge, Africa indeed, faces further marginalisation, they reasoned, since it remains one of the most poorly served regions in terms of information.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Congo (Kinshasa);
Making Friends With Churches and the Opposition


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1680 words


 

Kinshasa - The powerful Congolese (formerly Zairean) opposition party, the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) of veteran opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi seems to have committed a timing error by rushing to challenge the victorious Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) of the new Congolese leader Laurent Kabila.

There are reports of severe internal strains within the UDPS following the failure of the mass strike action called on May 26. Another demonstration by pro-Tshisekedi groups on May 28 was squashed by soldiers loyal to Kabila.

Observers note that the first strike action against the one- week old government of "President Kabila" failed completely when millions of workers, civil servants and shopkeepers heeded the new government's warning of severe disciplinary action on anybody getting involved in such demonstrations. There are clear indications that further protests will be suppressed. 

Kabila appears determined that if Mobutu could keep the opposition in semi inactivity, there is no real reason he should not be similarly respected given the immensity of the tasks ahead such as providing new roads, education and medicine.

Mobutu's 32 year dictatorial rule destroyed the entire infrastructure of Zaire, renamed Democratic Republic of Congo after Laurent Kabila seized Kinshasa on May 17.

The issue at stake is the failure by the 58 year-old self declared President Kabila to name Tshisekedi Prime Minister with power to appoint his own cabinet. The new government charged that Tshisekedi had rejected an influential cabinet post on May 23, and demanded the premiership, a post the new president has now abolished.

Observers predicted that the "ville mort" or dead city strike actions planned in Kinshasa by the UDPS would fail precisely because such moves were not politically justified so early in Kabila's self appointed term of office (as yet unspecified).

Critics are convinced some of the Congolese who previously supported the UPDS in its long running face- off against Mobutu's government may now see an alternative in the ADFL. Consequently they may see no reason, Mobutu having been driven out on May 17, to begin a confrontation.

This is the view of supporters of Maliba Kibasa, a rival of Tshisekedi in the UDPS, whose faction is willing to allow Kabila a reasonable transition period before passing judgement.

Tshisekedi, several times premier under Mobutu both before and after the Sovereign National Conference in 1991, has invoked the anger of Zairean and Rwandese Tutsi who form the core of the original Banyamulenge fighters who started the struggle to remove Mobutu in eastern Zaire, seven months ago.

The Banyamulenge fighters as well as Kabila still view him with a lot of suspicion since he was the first to initiate fundraising activities to help the government of Mobutu fight the rebellion in the east soon after it started.

In effect Tshisekedi, 58, may himself face a severe acid test in face of the new realities in Congo. He had been advised by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere "to take whatever post was offered and not be choosy." Nyerere advised Tshisekedi that he could not rightfully demand a specific post and expect the President to comply. Later President Mandela of South Africa and Ugandan leader Yoweri Museveni both supported Kabila's decision to abolish the post of Prime Minister. Both leaders are powerful players in the regional power equation.

Tshisekedi has substantial support in his home province of Kasai. On May 24, there were demonstrations in solidarity with him in the important diamond mining town of Mbuji Mayi in Central Kasai, but the ADFL soon extinguished them. The fear now is that his ostracism from power circles in Kinshasa could serve to create ill feelings between the people of Kasai and Kabila's own Katangese of south-eastern Congo.

Deposed President Mobutu caused great animosity between the two ethnic groups when his government orchestrated ethnic killings targeting Kasai people in Lubumbashi in the early 90s as part of the destabilisation of the "wind of change" sweeping across Congo and other African nations. The point is that in any future general elections in the new Congo, Kabila will need to have cultivated the trust of the Kasai people whether or not their son is in the political picture in Kinshasa.

Kasai people and the churches in the province were often more outspoken against Mobutu than many others. Kabila will also have to cultivate the friendship of the churches in Zaire where the episcopate in both the Catholic and Protestant churches were often seen as too close to Mobutu. These include the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Kinshasa Cardinal Etsou, Archbishop Bokeleale of the Church of Christ in Zaire (CCZ) and the leader of an indigenous church movement called the Church of Jesus Christ on Earth (CJSK) - the Kimbanguists, Simon Kimbangu. These leaders among many others, reportedly regularly enjoyed the patronage of Mr. Mobutu.

In a paper entitled Churches and the Struggle for Democracy in Zaire, Pastor Kabongo-Mbaya, a Congolese Sociologist and theologian observes: "Few bishops were really opposed to Mobutu; many were said to depend on financial aid from him as the decolonization of missionary work left some bishops insecure. Foreign grants and donations went to heads of religious congregations who, legally speaking, could in no way be required to render accounts to Zairean bishops (Catholic)." The same thing could be said of all other leading denominations.

The Archbishop of Kisangani Laurent Monsengwo Pasinya faced a severe test when in early May he returned to Kinshasa from Belgium, indeed being branded "Mobutuist," after the pro-Mobutu National Assembly voted him speaker of a proposed Transition Assembly. The ADFL of Kabila and the UPDS of Mr. Tshisekedi saw it as a ruse for Mobutu to deny imminent victory to Kabila.

Their bone of contention was that Monsengwo had abandoned and betrayed the people of Zaire when he succumbed to pressure and quit his post as speaker of the Sovereign National Congress on December 6, 1992. In that post, Monsengwo was the de facto leader of Zaire with the lofty title of President of the High Council of the Republic. Kabila will have to patch up with all these forces in the new Zaire.

Already he is not doing too badly in trying to alleviate the burdens people face. School fees has been reduced from US$100 to $60 in parts of Zaire as a means to get more children into primary school. Moreover in many parts of Zaire, extortion by soldiers demanding bribes at road barriers have been eradicated to a large extent. These steps will endear him to any future electorate.

While in Kinshasa over the last two weeks, he has mainly kept out of public sight following reports of numerous "hit squads" reportedly paid for by the deposed leader.

The latest involves a group of British mercenaries who allegedly intended to kill him in Lubumbashi, near Zambia's northern border. The report, carried in the May 18 edition of the Times of London claimed Zambia would have been the staging post for the attack. Denying the allegations, Zambia's Foreign Ministry said in a statement in Lusaka on May 26; "It is inadmissible thatZambia should be associated with machinations" to further destabilize the Central African region.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Time to Change Africa's Image is Now


BYLINE: APS Writer Wanjugu Mumia, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2294 words


 

Nairobi (APS) - With Namibia's independence and the end of apartheid in South Africa marking the realisation of pan- Africanist Ghanaian Kwameh Nkrumah's dream of a liberated Africa, there is hope that the ugly images that speak for this region can be put to shame and make room for a continent that promises life with dignity for its people.

Such were the aspirations of African delegates meeting in Midrand, Johannesburg, under the auspices of the World Council of Churches (WCC) to focus on a new vision for their continent, built on the people's willingness to work together, manage their human and natural resources responsibly and ethically, create linkages and be in partnership with one another and nature, mindful of generations who bequeathed such inheritance and those behind who deserve an even better inheritance.

The May 10-17 JUBILEE AND THE AFRICAN KAIROS; AN ECUMENICAL VISION AND AGENDA FOR LIFE conference, organised by WCC's Unit III - Justice, Peace and Creation, was a milestone in a process initiated by the WCC in 1991 under the theme, Africa through new eyes. The conference was also a culmination of a programme established in 1995 with the aim of creating opportunities for the Church in Africa to engage in dialogue with the African society and promote active solidarity with Africa. 

The 100 delegates drawn from some 25 African counties mainly comprised African Christians representing their respective churches, national councils of churches (NCCs), civic bodies, trade union and government sectors and one representative from a Muslim community.

Subjects discussed focussed on Faith and Politics, the Gospel and Culture, Mission and Partnership and Faith and Economics. These themes provided a background against which to critically assess the African Church and its moral standing and relevance to a continent that yearns for a practical spirituality that respects its people's needs and aspirations.

Stories of life with dignity narrated by the young and old, women and men, portrayed lives shaped by the embodiment of pan- Africanism in Ghana, belief in the liberation struggle despite untold sacrifices in Zimbabwe, determination to continue fighting for life and dignity inspite of a protracted war against Christians and Africans in the Sudan, and the enjoyment and aspirations of liberation from the decades-long yoke of apartheid in South Africa.

What probably made the Jubilee and African Kairos conference unique was its deviation from routine conference thesis presentations to personal accounts and reflections on Africans' understanding of life in a given setting. This format in a way brought real life into the WCC conference, presenting living examples of historical recordings and statistics. Discussions were then formed from comments and questions raised by fellow participants, and formalised with follow-up group discussions whose recommendations were reported on at the plenary sessions.

Delegates heard stories of life that were mutually inspiring and challenging while others were horrifying and appalling. Sudanese Rev. Clement Janda, Director of the Mindolo Ecumenical Centre, in Kitwe, Zambia told of the enduring pain and cries of the people of Southern Sudan where "Africa's longest and forgotten war continues. From August 1955, I have seen so much war and killings...." was the Sudanese brief description of his experiences in his country. He went on to clarify that Sudan was actually the first African nation to gain independence from the colonialists' British/Egyptians on January 1, 1956, which was soon followed by its first military coup in 1958.

Sudan enjoyed relative peace from 1972 to 1983, thanks to a permanent constitution, but the civil war that erupted in 1983 is still going on, viciously targeting mainly African and Christian Southerners since the country is governed under sharia (Islamic) law.

Clement Janda's life like that of millions of fellow southern Sudanese, has been characterised by displacement from one area to the other, hunger, the pain of seeing loved ones killed in the war, loss of community and family stability and living in exile. "Sudanese are everywhere in neighbouring countries. Our faith, be it Islam, Christianity or African traditions is our crime," he said. And went on to clarify that not all Muslims want to oppress non-Muslims.

Obviously saddened by the lack of international publicity over the "killing fields" in his country, Rev. Janda is nevertheless inspired by the commitment of churches and other organisations to intervene in the hope of ending the war and suffering. "The churches in the Sudan are united in a vision of a Sudan free from sectionalism, troubled-yes-but not destroyed. For 43 years we have been waging war, there is every reason for that conflict to b concluded," he added.

Similar stories were told by two fellow Sudanese, who requested anonymity, fearing that publicity on their part would cause problems for them back home. In emotional encounters, the pair told of their lives on the run, sufferings undergone by women and children in slavery. "We are living in Sudan as temporary citizens on contracts, because being Christians and (Black) Africans, we do not have any citizen's rights," they said.

Other varying experiences of struggles with political systems were heard from Zimbabwe, Kenya, Uganda, Central African Republic, Cameroon, Togo, Zambia, Angola, Tanzania, Mozambique and the Gambia among others.

The birth of democracy in South Africa and the process of reconciliation undertaken by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission provided a great source of inspiration and challenge to the world and the rest of Africa. Events in the Great Lakes region, especially the struggle in Zaire against Western backed dictatorship is an example of initiatives of a search for regional solution to regional problems. These experiences, for the participants at the Johannesburg meeting, were part of the unfolding African Kairos (Africa's moment of opportunity).

Recommendations drawn from discussions on Faith and Politics drew the attention of the Church to its obligation to inject a new moral culture into politics. "The church should therefore use its moral authority to preach and pressure political and religious activists to be involved in a system of good governance and management based on sound democratic principles," the meeting stated.

Church leaders were also urged to seriously reflect upon and strive to promote the virtues of integrity and accountability and to be an example to the flock and society at large in order to restore the declining moral authority of the church.

Delegates also acknowledged the existence of conflict resolution structures and mechanisms within the AACC and WCC, but said these should be revitalized and used more widely to create fora that can bring together political and religious leaders to negotiate with opposition groups in times of severe tensions, among other recommendations.

On Gospel and Culture there was general consensus on the need for inculturation and contextualisation of the Gospel, that the spirit of tolerance and diversity should be fostered as a means of attaining unity at national and community levels and that the church should recognise gender and gender related problems from the point of view of the women and take practical means aimed at addressing injustices founded on decadent cultural assumptions and values.

Reflections on Faith and Economics challenged churches to put in place structures that have justice as the fundamental basis for economy and strengthen their own capacity to engage in economic discourse by embarking on economic literacy programmes as a way of demystifying economic language. As an integral part of the economic reality of each nation, the church was reminded of its duty to encourage accountability and transparency in the conduct of economic affairs in African states.

Recommendations on Mission and Partnership generally commended existing co-operation between and among various ecumenical partners, but emphasised the need to spell out clearly the working relations between the AACC and WCC at their General Assemblies to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in October 1997 and Harare, Zimbabwe in September 1998 respectively, in order to bring about more effective stewardship of resources and avoid duplication of projects.

Both AACC and WCC were also commended for their initiatives to address the conflicts in East Africa's Great Lakes region from an ecumenical perspective with a view to seeking a peaceful resolution and finding a common solution to related problems.

It is true, delegates agreed, that Africa is home to numerous ills that threaten and deny the very existence of both private and public life as evidenced in domestic and sexual violence in the private and corruption in the public sphere. But these realities were a source of renewed commitment not despair, for the African churches and communities represented at the Jubilee and African Kairos conference.

They committed themselves to collect information on cases of domestic and sexual violence (femicide) for presentation at the AACC and WCC assemblies respectively and for use thereafter. Too, they would gather information on cases of corruption in their respective countries and churches, and creatively document the same for presentation at the WCC assembly and further use, and encourage networking with existing groups that are engaging in combatting sexual violence and corruption.

On Sudan, the participants, having heard testimonies of the sufferings endured by Southern Sudanese, committed themselves to stand by the Sudanese people, defend their right to freedom, form groups of solidarity for the systematic dissemination of information relating to the development of the situation in that region and mobilise all possible means "in our power in order to help the victims of the Sudanese conflict enjoy a life with dignity."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Cameroon;
Cameroon's Cardinal Seeks Electoral Changes


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

DOUALA (APS) - The leader of the Catholic Church in Cameroon Christian Cardinal Toumi has called for an overhaul of his country's Electoral Commission, asserting that this is the will of the Cameroon people.

In an interview on the African Service of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) on May 27 here, the Cardinal lamented that the whole structure associated with the electoral process in Cameroon - where parliamentary polls were conducted on May 17 - was deliberately designed for dishonesty and to favour President Paul Biya's ruling Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (RDPC).

Cardinal Toumi said: "The wish of the people of Cameroon is to see the establishment of an independent electoral commission." He did not vote in the controversial May 17 parliamentary elections as he was time barred due to a haphazard regulation that says the registration period ends when the date of elections is announced. 

The provisional results show Biya's RDPC got 114 out of the possible 180 seats. The official results will be proclaimed before June 6.

Cardinal Toumi insisted that millions of young people who had reached voting age and other Cameroonians had been disenfranchised.

He said relations between the Catholic Church and the government of President Paul Biya were cool. However, whenever the bishops had a point to make to the President - "which was not often," they would make an appointment before going to see him.

Multiparty democracy in Cameroon was forced on the government of President Paul Biya during the "wind of change" in much of West Africa in the early 90's.

However, the presidential elections that confirmed the supremacy of the RDPC were widely accepted internationally as rigged or fraudulent and a number of international observers - including former US President Jimmy Carter's Carter Institute pulled out entirely in protest. Most international observers agreed that the opposition Social Democratic Front (SDF) of John Fru Ndi were cheated in the rigged poll.

But other observers blame a divided opposition for the constant rout they suffer at the hands of Paul Biya's RDPC, whose leader has been in power for the last 15 years.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 2, 1997


Uganda;
New Metropolitan For Uganda's Orthodox Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) - The Orthodox Church in Uganda has a new head, replacing the first Metropolitan of Kampala, the late Theodorus Nankyama who died of cancer last January.

His Emminence Jonah Lwanga, 52, was enthroned the Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kampala and All Uganda at St. Nicholas Cathedral, Namungoona, near here. 

The Metropolitan Lwanga was enthroned by His Beatitude the Pope and Patriarch of Alexandria and All Africa, Petros VII.

Metropolitan Lwanga, a Ugandan national was the founding bishop of the Orthodox Church Bukoba Diocese in Bukoba, north- western Tanzania. Before that Metropolitan Lwanga was for 10 years the Dean of Archbishop Makarios III Seminary in Kenya.

The new Metropolitan outlined his vision for the Orthodox Church in Uganda, pledging to reorganize and re-invigorate the church in the country. The church under his leadership will strengthen its social and health services sector, he promised.

Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni was represented by the Prime Minister Mr. Kintu Musoke who used the opportunity to urge the churches to address the rising phenomenon of single parenthood. "The Metropolitan Lwanga is assuming the shepherdship of the church at a time when parental control of children is being eroded and single parenthood is becoming the norm," said the Premier, challenging the churches to tackle this social phenomenon.

The Orthodox Church in Uganda is a relatively small denomination with less than 50,000 members. It began as an indigenous split from the Uganda Anglicans, then Church Missionary Society (CMS) in 1929, but succeeded in regaining acceptance to the Greek Orthodox communion in 1946.

Uganda's population of some 18 million people comprises about 70 per cent Christians belonging mainly to the Catholic and Anglican churches. The Muslims are about 2 million, while the rest belong to other religions including African traditionalists.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Sudan;
Comboni Delighted To Have 23 Sudanese Students


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

MAPOURDIT-SOUTHERN SUDAN (APS) - The Comboni Missionaries have opened a secondary school at Mapourdit, about 1,300 kilometres south of the Sudanese capital Khartoum.

The school which opened its doors to the first 23 students mid-May, will conduct a four-year course based on a curriculum similar to one offered in neighbouring Kenyan secondary schools.

The current batch of students are all boys from the local Dinka community. "It is not our intention to make it a boys-only institution but the circumstances surrounding the establishment of the first class were such that no girls could qualify for admission," said Monsignor Caesar Mazzolari, the Apostolic Administrator of Rumbek Diocese where the school is situated. "The subsequent classes, beginning next year, will all have girls," he said. 

He also pointed out that the secondary school was not exclusively for the Dinka, but, being a non-boarding institution, it was only natural that it absorbed students from the local area which is inhabited by the Dinka.

Heading the secondary school is Fr. Michael Barton, a Comboni missionary from the USA, who has been instrumental in educational development in the region. In his line-up of teaching staff are fellow priests and sisters, as well as local qualified personnel.

"The learners," said Mgr Mazzolari, "are very enthusiastic as they know that successful completion of their course will earn them a certificate with which they can land a job, or pursue further education."

Mgr Mazzolari is equally impressed by the student population. "The population so far is quite encouraging considering that Sudan is currently at war and most of the youth have committed their energy and time to fighting for the cause of their people."

Sudan, Africa's most expansive state, has been at war since her independence in 1956, with only 11 years' hiatus from 1972- 83. Besides claiming not less than 1.3 million lives so far, the war has disrupted virtually every other aspect of life especially in the south. In some areas, for instance, formal education has ground to a halt for more than a decade.

Consequently, Sudan is today among the world's poorest and least literate states. However, missionaries have been at the forefront in keeping the fire of enlightenment a glow by establishing a host of learning institutions for the Sudanese.

"The local community holds the Comboni school in high esteem as it is the first one of its kind in the area," says Mgr Mozzolari. Already in place at the school compound are two main blocks which house a classroom, laboratory, store, library and one large reading room. The buildings are made of sun-baked blocks with (thatch) grass roofs. Plans for future expansion have already been drawn.

Apart from their educational institutions in Sudan, Comboni Missionaries also provide formal education to Sudanese refugees at the Kakuma refugee camp in northern Kenya.

In August last year, they established the Josephine Bakhita Formation Centre (JBFC)for Sudanese in Kenya's Kitale town, about 407 kilometres north-west of Nairobi. The Centre aims to train young people from Sudan as agents of evangelization, education and development.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Burundi;
Fighting Intensifies In Burundi Despite Talks


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

BUJUMBURA (APS) - Fighting between Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu rebels has intensified and was approaching Bujumbura amid reports of massacres of civilians.

The sound of heavy mortar fire echoed through the capital on May 27 as rebels and soldiers fought about 15 kilometres south- east of Bujumbura. Meanwhile, rumours swept the capital that the rebels were planning to attack it as panicked villagers fled to the capital's Musaga district, on the southern outskirts.

Gunfire was heard in Bujumbura's suburbs last week, and residents said then that rebels had infiltrated the city. 

On May 19, police clashed here with students protesting government negotiations with Hutu rebels as the national radio reported that scores of people had been killed in rebel violence in the north-east.

Radio Burundi had reported that 63 people were killed and 12 injured at two "regroupment" camps at Murwi and Buganda, in the north-eastern Cibitoke province, and blamed the rebels for the violence. It gave no further details of the attackers.

The camps were officially set up to provide protection for civilians from such attacks. Some sources say they are aimed at depriving rebels of the support of Hutu civilians.

The Tutsi-dominated army says Burundian Hutu rebels accused of the killings in Cibitoke are backed by members of the old Hutu Rwandan Armed Forces and Interahamwe militants, who are accused of carrying out the genocide of Tutsis and moderate Hutus in Rwanda in 1994.

Army spokesman Isaie Nibizi said on May 12 that 18 Interahamwe and Hutu soldiers had been killed in Cibitoke as they were returning from Zaire to Rwanda.

However, police struck students with truncheons and hauled a dozen of them into a military vehicle during the May 19 protest against talks with the Hutu National Council for the Defense of Democracy (CNDD), denounced as a "genocidal" movement.

Major Pierre Buyoya, a member of the Tutsi minority who came to power in a coup on July 25 last year, disclosed last week that negotiations were being held in Rome between his representatives and the main rebel organization CNDD, led by former Interior Minister Leonard Nyangoma.

Following the peace talks, Buyoya said, the Tutsi regime and the CNDD had agreed in principle to a ceasefire.

The Rome talks followed a relaxation of an economic blockade against Burundi imposed by regional leaders days after Buyoya's rise to power.

And on May 22 Burundi Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama also said a conference would take place in Geneva in June under the aegis of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural organization (UNESCO) to which all political factions taking part in the Burundi conflict would be invited.

"All those taking part in the conflict will be invited, including (Burundi's) armed factions," Rukingama told reporters in Brussels.

The Foreign Minister said the conference could rapidly lead to peace negotiations, the dates of which had not been fixed but he said it could be June 14.

According to Rukingama, the Geneva conference represents the "second phase" of the Rome talks. "The government could sign a ceasefire as early as tonight. The problem is that the armed factions have not been as quick to respond," he said.

Rukingama said the Burundian leadership wanted the international community to put "permanent pressure on the CNDD and the other armed factions in order to help the peace process" and convince them to "end the armed conflict."

The latest intensified fighting followed a warning on May 26 by Burundi's former ruling party, the Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU) that guerrilla warfare would erupt if Burundi's military junta refuses to restore peace and constitutional rule in the country.

In a letter circulated to the Organization of African Unity (OAU) heads of state ahead of the June 2-4 summit in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, FRODEBU president Jean Minani said "as long as 'dictator' (major Pierre) Buyoya and his junta refuse this fundamental right to Burundian people, we will never get durable peace and stability in the country.

"If equitable solution is not achieved through the OAU and international community, FRODEBU party will use all means, including the military struggle, in order to bring its ideals to a successful conclusion," Minani's letter said.

Comparing the Burundi situation to South Africa's former apartheid regime, Minani said that if the OAU and the international community had successfully destroyed racial policies and also solved serious conflicts in Mozambique and Namibia, "there is no valid reason to fail in Burundi."

The Hutu-dominated FRODEBU also appealed to the OAU and the UN to call on the security council to condemn and isolate Buyoya's Tutsi-led regime and to impose an arms embargo.

Buyoya overthrew the Hutu president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya last July in a bloodless putsch.

Leaders of East Africa's Great Lakes region immediately condemned the coup and a total economic embargo was only eased last month as Buyoya embarked on mediated peace negotiations with all factions involved in the conflict.

As Hutu guerrilla forces continue to battle the military regime. Civil war in the tiny Central African country has so far cost more than 150,000 lives, many of them peasants massacred by both sides.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Opposition Mounts Against Sierra Leone's Putschists


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

FREETOWN (APS) - Sierra Leone's military leaders, who seized power in Sierra Leone on May 25 have indefinitely suspended the country's constitution and banned all demonstrations and meetings, as internal and international opposition grows against the new regime.

In a radio broadcast late May 24, new military ruler Major Johnny Paul Koroma ordered the suspension of the country's 1991 constitution and banned all political parties "until further notice.

"As from now on, all legislation will be by military decrees," said Major Koroma, chairman of the ruling Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC), which ousted the elected regime of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, who fled to neighbouring Guinea.

"We shall soon publish a timetable for a return to democracy after free and fair elections, but we don't want any democracy that is based on tribalism and regionalism," he said in a first policy address since the army seized power on May 25. 

He accused the former civilian government of Kabbah of spending more money on local civil defence units than on the regular army.

The former government had been "treating the welfare of the Kamajors (the local civil defence unit) more seriously than the army," he said, claiming that the deposed civilian government had spent between $200,000 and 250,000 on the Armed Forces every month, which was "not reflected in the status of the ordinary soldier," while 'the Kamajors got $350,000 dollars which did not include logistics."

Major Koroma said the leader of the former rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) Corporal Foday Sankoh "will soon return to take part in the nation's development," and that the new regime "will soon put in place a broad-based government of national unity" but without saying when.

Koroma was himself released on May 25 from jail, where he had been held on treason charges from an earlier coup attempt, and has since heightened concerns by releasing some 600 prisoners from jail.

However, internal and international pressure was mounting against the 20 junior officers who led the coup, which has killed at least 100 people, amid widespread violence and looting.

The international community firmly rejected the uprising and demanded the reinstatement of the elected government.

Among other condemnations, the 15-member UN Security Council "strongly deplored this attempt to overthrow the democratically elected government, and called for an immediate restoration of constitutional order," while US State Department "called on those claiming power in Freetown to return authority promptly to the country's elected leadership and parliament."

Sierra Leone's United Nations envoy James Jonah told a news conference at the UN in New York on May 27 that he would, on behalf of President Kabbah, ask African leaders set to meet this week in Harare to impose sanctions to isolate the coup leaders.

Jonah also appealed to West African countries grouped under the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) to act quickly to restore Kabbah's 14-month-old government, and said he had received pledges from ECOWAS chairman General Sani Abacha to restore the civilian government after a direct request from Kabbah, but did not know whether military force would be used by ECOWAS.

"We have seen that delay in action leads to acceptance," said Jonah, referring to the July 1996 coup by Tutsi officers in Burundi.

Saying that he would demand a condemnation of the coup and also seek the imposition of travel sanctions against the coup leaders from the Organization of African Unity summit, Jonah declared: "We are going to make it difficult for any military leader in the future to make a coup; therefore they will know that they will get no recognition, that they will not be allowed to travel freely within the sub-region of Africa."

A naval Nigerian vessel carrying West African peacekeepers docked in Freetown on May 27 and another lay a short distance off the coast.

US helicopter-carrier, Kearsarge, would also be off Sierra Leone with 1,200 US Marines on board "in the next couple of days," a Pentagon spokeswoman said.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Orthodox Women Issue "Strong" Recommendations


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

ISTANBUL, TURKEY (APS) - Some 50 Orthodox women representing their various churches have come up with a list of recommendations concerning the role of women in the life of the Church.

The recommendations deal, among other things, with theological education, the re-evaluation of some prayers and church practices, encouraging women's ministries, full participation of Orthodox women in the life of their church and the ecumenical movement, women's contribution to spiritual growth for all, the role of priests, wives, sexism and women's ordination, says a press release from the World Council of Churches (WCC).

The women were meeting here from May 10-17 under the theme Discerning the Signs of the Times: Women in the Life of the Orthodox Church.

The meeting held within the context of the Ecumenical Decade of Churches in Solidarity with women, which will culminate at the World Council of Churches (WCC) Eighth Assembly in Harare, Zimbabwe in September 1998, was hosted by the Ecumenical Patriarch, Batholomew of Constantinople. 

The Istanbul forum was the third in a series for Orthodox women in connection with the Women's Decade. It was organised by Ms Aruna Gnanadason of the WCC Women's Desk and Orthodox theological consultant, Dr. Kyriaki Fitzgerald.

"Up to now Orthodox women felt their concerns had not been taken seriously and did not feel part of the Decade. But now they see their work very much in terms of the Decade and they have come up with some very strong recommendations," Gnanadason said.

One of the recommendations concerns theological education for women, which is seen as "a priority". it should include education at the highest level and be open to all women.

The meeting also called for a re-evaluation of some church practices, particularly citing the tradition of mothers not going to church for 40 days after childbirth and "certain prayers...for miscarriages, abortions and post-partum mothers."

Some of the women present said they felt "these practices and prayers do not properly express the theology of the Church regarding the dignity of God's creation ofthe woman and her redemption in Christ."

The women also called for new hymns to be written to reflect the lives of modern women martyrs and the sacrifices which Orthodox women continue to make.

The sensitive subject of the ordination of women was also addressed in a carefully written recommendation: "Some participants at the consultation welcome the idea that an inter- Orthodox conference on the ordination of women to the priesthood be organised, where women and men will have the opportunity to examine this topic in greater depth from both the theological and spiritual perspectives."

At a time when some within the Orthodox churches are questioning their involvement in the WCC, the Istanbul meeting recommended that the Orthodox Church appoint women delegates as representatives "to the various aspects of the ecumenical movement, whether on the international, national or parish level."

The women asked their churches "to seriously consider" complying with the WCC request that at least 50 per cent of their representatives at the Eighth Assembly be women, and to "bestow their blessings" on those women who will attend an Ecumenical Decade festival to be held in Harare just before the assembly.

"I have never seen such a strong affirmation of a commitment to the ecumenical movement as came from these Orthodox women," Gnanadason was quoted saying.

In Istanbul, conference members attended a worship service led by the Ecumenical Patriarch, who also opened the gathering. Later, the patriarch wrote to the WCC General Secretary Rev. Dr. Konard Raiser, that it had been "a blessing and a joy" to receive the participants. "Their discussions were very valuable and will prove beneficial for our holy Orthodox Church," he added.

Participants came from Egypt, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Georgia, Greece, Australia, lebanon, Poland, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Turkey,Syria, the United Kingdom and the United States.

Inaugurated in 1948, the World Council of Churches ia a fellowship of churches, now 331, in more than 100 countries in all continents from virtually all Christian traditions.

Although the Roman Catholic Church is not a member it works cooperatively with the WCC.

The highest governing body is the Assembly, which meets approximately every seven years.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Uganda;
Bishop's Wife Killed In Landmine Blast


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KITGUM-NORTHERN UGANDA (APS) - The wife of the Anglican Bishop of Kitgum Diocese, Northern Uganda died instantly on May 23 after the vehicle in which she was travelling hit a landmine on the Madi Opei road, seven kilometres north of here.

Mrs. Winfred Ochola, wife of Bishop Macleod Ochola died with four other people while seven other passengers on the pick-up sustained serious injuries and were rushed to local hospitals.

Defence Ministry sources in Uganda say the mine was an anti- tank device planted by the rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) led by Joseph Kony who is reported to be in Sudan. Apparently, the rebels had planted the device in the hope of hitting a military convoy they expected to pass on the road towards the Uganda-Sudan border where both countries have reinforced their border patrols. 

Uganda accused Sudan of helping the LRA, including providing them with anti-personnel and tank mines. Sudan on its part charges Uganda is the back-bone of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of John Garang who have won substantial territory in recent fighting in Southern Sudan.

Church of Uganda (Anglican) Archbishop Livingstone Mpalanyi Nkoyoyo was among hundreds and hundreds of mourners who attended Mrs Ochola's burial on May 25 at the All Saints Cathedral cemetery. In his message of condolence to the family, he appealed to the government to try and minimise the suffering of the people of Northern Uganda.

Dr. Martin Aliker, State Minister for Foreign Affairs described Mrs Ochola as a kind and hard working mother.

Earlier this year, during a conference in London that was organised by the Acholi people of northern Uganda to discuss the insurgency in the region, Bishop Ochola, a member of the Acholi ethnic group, bitterly criticised the leaders of the LRA based in Nairobi, Kenya - who attended the conference in London - saying, the rebel army had caused untold suffering to innocent civilians in the region.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Liberia;
Liberians Welcome New Elections Date


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

ABUJA (APS) - West African leaders have given some much-needed breathing space to politicians and election officials in war-torn Liberia, following their decision on May 21 to postpone crucial elections originally scheduled for May 30.

The polls, the first presidential and parliamentary in Liberia in more than a decade, will now be held on July 9, 1997.

Most Liberian politicians and religious leaders had complained that the initial date posed logistical and security problems.

But at their summit here on May 21, Heads of State of the 16- nation Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) adopted an earlier recommendation by the ECOWAS Foreign Ministers' meeting to postpone the summit to give Liberians a new lease of hope for political parties and the country in general. 

The ECOWAS summit also fixed August 2 as the date for inaugurating a new government in Liberia, but if a second round of voting became necessary, this could be held on August 2 and the government sworn in on August 16, an official statement issued on May 22 at the end of the summit said.

The summit also approved an election budget of $5.4 million. The elections will be the last step in the Liberian peace process under a plan hammered out in August 1995 after previous agreements failed to be implemented.

The revised Abuja accord a year later by an ECOWAS summit here followed more than a dozen failed initiatives to resolve the conflict, which destroyed almost all of Liberia's infrastructure.

Under its terms, Liberia's main warlords agreed that all factions would be dissolved by January 31, four months ahead of presidential and parliamentary elections. The combatants were finally disarmed and their factions disbanded early this year.

Liberia's civil war, ignited in December 1989 by Charles Taylor's National patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), the country's largest militia, resulted in the death of between 150,000 and 200,000 people by the end of 1995, according to United Nations estimates.

Observers here believe that the new outcome of the summit, attended by the Heads of State of Benin, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Niger and Nigeria, has "gone along way in redeeming the alleged partisan image of some ECOWAS countries."

Also attending were Ruth Perry, chairperson of Liberia's Ruling Council of State, Togo's Prime Minister and ministers from Gambia, Senegal and Sierra Leone.

On May 21, President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana denied suggestions that his country and Nigeria were supporting presidential candidates and former warlord Charles Taylor.

Taylor, whose National Patriotic Party (NPP) is better resourced and organised than its 15 rivals, had repeatedly called for the elections to be held on May 30 as initially scheduled.

But Rawlings stressed: "We have no interest in supporting any political party and we have done anything possible to demonstrate our neutrality in Liberia."

Taylor, for his part, reacted positively to the postponement, telling journalists "I am pleased with the outcome of the meeting. We are satisfied with the date and we are ready to cooperate with ECOWAS to ensure the success of the election," although a Nigerian diplomat pointed out that Taylor had no other choice after ECOWAS leaders made it clear to him that the future of Liberia was more important to them than his personal ambitions.

"The ECOWAS decision has been fair to all 16 Liberian political parties as well as giving more credibility to the entire (Abuja) peace plan in front of the international community," the diplomat added.

"Before now, it was as if everything was going on directly in favour of Taylor," said one Liberian journalist.

Two former faction leaders, Taylor and Alhaji Kromah, as well as Liberia's former Finance Minister Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf -- the only woman contesting the crucial polls -- will be among leaders of 16 political parties vying for the presidency.

Johnson-Sirleaf, a Harvard University graduate, who resigned as assistant administrator and regional director for Africa at the UN Development Programme (UNDP) to stand in the elections, declared at a press conference in the Liberian capital on May 26 that her qualifications, honesty, experience and numerous contacts made her the best choice of the Liberian people at this time.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 2, 1997


Algeria;
Scores Killed Ahead Of Algeria's Poll


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

ALGIERS (APS) - Algerian security forces have killed some 137 Islamic extremists in several anti-terrorist offensives only days ahead of legislative elections scheduled for June 5.

The El Khabar reported on May 27 that some 120 guerrillas had died near Ouarsenis, 250 kilometres south-west of Algiers, in one of the biggest operations by security forces since civil war began in this North African country early 1992. A further 14 extremists were killed in Tlemcen district, 540 kilometres west of the capital.

The Ouarsenis offensive centres on a zone that forms the headquarters of Ahmed Benaicha, number two in the Islamic Salvation Army (AIS), the armed wing of the banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS). 

Some 200 of his men are in the region, and a price of 4.5 million dinars ($90,000) has been put on Benaicha's head, according to posters displayed in recent days.

Algerian authorities are offering the reward to anyone who helps them find the leaders of three powerful armed Islamic groups, among them Anta Zouabri, 27, head of the Armed Islamic Group (GIA). That price is 1,1000 times higher than the monthly minimum wage.

While FIS leaders in exile have called for an election boycott, one of the masterminds of its 1991 showing at the ballot box began a hunger strike in his Algiers prison cell, his lawyers said.

Abdelkader Hanchani, 42, is protesting his "arbitrary detention" and the government's refusal to try him in court, the lawyers said in a statement.

He was arrested on January 23, 1992 and accused of having called for disobedience in the armed forces, through a communique published as an advertisement in the press.

The operation, which El Khabar said was begun on the basis of information from two informers, has not been officially confirmed.

The Algerian press also reported that the death toll from three car-bomb attacks over the past two days had gone up.

Meanwhile, the death toll from a car-bomb attack on May 22 in Boufarik rose to 20, with hundreds of people injured, the daily Le Matin reported, citing security sources. An official toll earlier said 12 people were killed and 31 injured.

The press also reported that two car-bomb attacks in Tlemcen, 400 kilometers from Algiers, had claimed between nine and 18 lives. The official toll said seven people were killed.

The June 5 elections will be the first for the People's National Assembly in five years, after the military annulled a December 1991 vote that the now-banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was poised to win.

That move had ignited a ruthless war with Islamic extremists, including gruesome village massacres and car-bomb attacks, which have left more than 60,000 dead, according to Western estimates.

Through a commentary on its official Algerian Press Service news agency, President Liamine Zeroual's government insisted on May 23 that it would never allow "blood-thirty criminals" to foil the June 5 polls.

Picking up on that note, the National Democratic Rally (RND), founded in April by core supporters of the president, warned on May 24 of a fresh 'drift towards Islam."

Its spokesman Hamraoui Habib-Chawki, at a press conference, urged Algerians to show "vigilance" and "maturity" to avert a repeat of the FIS near-victory more than five years ago.

Islam was being exploited for partisan ends, he said, singling out the Movement of Society for Peace (MSP), led by Cheikh Mahfoud Nahnah.

"Beware of those who promise paradise Those who did in 1991 were offering hell to the people," Habib-Chawki said.

But Nahnah hit back on May 26 by threatening not to take part in the election, saying: "We refuse to be a tool of a false democracy and to take part in a process that does not really reflect the will of the people."

Known as Hamas before it changed names to conform with Algeria's no-Islam electoral laws, the MSP was expected, with the RND, to lead the field in the vote to be held in four days' time.

Nahnah, a moderate Islamist regarded as one of the pioneers of Islamic politics in Algeria, himself took 25 per cent of the vote in the last presidential election, second to Zeroual.

While the MSP has switched its motto from "Islam is the solution" to "Peace is the solution," some RND officials have alleged that its success at the polls could trigger a new Islamist wave.

Algerian newspapers hostile to Islamists have repeatedly claimed that Nahnah is not as moderate as he claims to be, but rather a political opportunist who switches his colours as circumstances dictate.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Nigeria Defends Position On Sierra Leone


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1216 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Nigerian foreign minister Tom Ikimi said on Tuesday in Harare his country is trying to restore order in Sierra Leone whose government was ousted in a military coup last month.

Ikimi told Ziana that his country had sent its forces to help Sierra Leone in pursuit of the common goal of trying to bring peace and stability to the West African region.

"This is not interference," he said. "We, as Ecowas (the Economic Community of West African States), have always been interested in explosive situations that take place in our region which we see as endangering civilian lives and disturb peace. 

"Together with the international community we must not allow such a situation to continue.

"Nigeria is going to ensure that peace, stability and a legitimate government are restored in Sierra Leone."

Sierra Leone President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah was ousted from power by rebels led by Major Johnny Koromah on Africa Day (May 25).

Reports from the capital, Freetown, said the rebels, who had taken some people hostage, were trying to use them as a bargaining chip to further their interests.

More than 12 people were reported to have died during the Nigerian offensive launched on Monday.

The United Nations and the OAU have condemned the coup and demanded that rebel leaders should restore the ousted government.

Ikimi is representing the Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, at the 33rd Summit of heads of state and government of the Organisation of African Unity, which entered its second day here on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, Zimbabwe's human rights watchdog, Zimrights, on Tuesday served Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim, with an open letter protesting the intervention by Nigerian-led forces to reverse a May 25 coup in Sierra Leone.

In the letter, also circulated to the press and delegates at the 33rd OAU summit in Harare, Zimrights said: "As a human rights organisation, we would like to register our categorical protest at the intervention by Nigerian-led forces to reverse an eight-day old coup by Sierra Leonian troops.

"Zimrights believes that the current intervention by Nigerian-led troops in Sierra Leone is an attempt by some quarters within the oau to cleanse Nigeria's military of the late Ken Saro-wiwa's blood and, at the same time, exonerate the regime from its pariah status.

"It goes without saying that the OAU has become an ideological toy of Nigeria because of its religio-economic influence in the sub-region and huge oil resources," said the letter, signed by Zimrights executive director, David Chimhini.

There had been a "litany" of coups in Nigeria but the OAU had, in each case, "dogmatically" stuck to the provision of non-interference in the internal affairs of a member state," said Zimrights.

"Zimrights disapproves of 'big brother' politics which tramples on the rights and freedoms of minorities."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Egypt, Libya To Float Automobile Plant


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libya and Egypt have signed an agreement for the establishment of an automobile plant to produce vehicles for the Arab world. 

The agreement was signed during the visit to Tripoli last week by Egyptian industry Minister, Soleiman Ridha.

The company, with a share capital of 200-million dollars, will manufacture 100,000 cars per year, Cairo newspapers said Tuesday.

The reports said Morocco, Tunisia, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Syria intend to take part in this project, the first of its kind in the Arab World.

It did not specify where the company would be based and the brand of cars it would produce.
