Africa News


June 3, 1997


Zaire;
Kabila Wants To Alleviate Poverty


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - President Laurent Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo says his immediate task, as the country's new leader, is to boost development in the Central African state using local resources.

Kabila told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency (ZIANA) that most of the developmental programmes would largely be financed through internal resources with little external aid.

Though faced with a mammoth task of rebuilding a country where there has been no meaningful development for 32 years, under the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko, Kabila said he was confident of meeting the challenges before him head on. 

"Corruption is rampant, there are many jobless people, agriculture is poor, there are so many priorities," he said of the former state of Zaire which is saddled with a 14 billion external debt.

"External aid is important but first we must count on our own capabilities. We have potential in human resources and wealth," he added.

Kabila, who declared himself president when he took power May 17, was sworn in Thursday last week.

He is in Harare attending the 33rd Organization of African Unity (OAU) summit of heads of state and government which ends Wednesday.

With the lives of 40 million people in his hands, Kabila, 56, said he was determined to exploit the potential wealth of his country and improve standards of living.

Kabila and his rebel army took up arms in October 1996, in protest over Zairean nationality for ethnic Tutsis, the Banyamulenge.

Mobutu's government was linked with corruption and widespread abuse of human rights during most of his 32-year reign. He amassed personal fortune estimated in the billions of dollars at the peril of Africa's potentially richest nation with a wealth of minerals and rich farmland.

"The most important thing is we have liberated our country," Kabila said. "Even those who supported Mobutu say they support us now."

Asked what his feeling was towards most of Africa's leaders who never chided Mobutu over his excesses, he said: "You cannot choose your neighbors."

Kabila said the two-year period before the elections would be used to ensure some basic infrastructure and support services INL002 from SSS.115 (970603-18:01) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG114G/02E

(2) would be in place to facilitate the transition.

"If everything goes according to plan," he said, "two years is enough for us to prepare."

As for his record on democracy, which has already been criticized after he banned political activities and public demonstrations last week, Kabila said the people of Africa would "judge" him.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Inaugurates Economic Community


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - African leaders met Tuesday for their inaugural session of the African Economic Community which is geared to become a force in ridding the continent of its poverty.

Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe, who assumed the chairmanship of the 53-member Organization of African Unity at its 33rd summit in Harare, said the establishment of the highest organ of the community constituted a standard by which Africa's future economic policies would be judged.

The event was witnessed by 28 heads of state and government and three prime ministers. Mugabe said the occasion crowned efforts stretching several decades made by the O.A.U., resulting in several resolutions and declarations which laid a firm political foundation for the establishment of the community. 

Mugabe, speaking on the second day of the summit, emphasized that the pillars of the community were the African regional integration bodies specified in the Abuja Treaty adopted June 1991, which came into force in 1994.

Mugabe said the entry into force of the Abuja Treaty, establishing the AEC, vindicated the vision and commitment of successive generations of African leaders who believed that the continent could never be independent unless it took responsibility for its economic and political destiny.

What African countries are now required to do, Mugabe said, was to integrate their markets and transform their economies currently characterized by low levels of industrialization, high dependence on international trade, extremely low levels of intra-African trade and small markets.

The community, he said, should make it possible for African countries to produce competitive products that would enjoy preferential treatment in African markets.

He noted that Africa faced a hostile external economic environment induced by forces outside its control. For example, he said African countries continued to be exporters of raw materials and minerals whose prices they did not control.

Over the years, he added, the value of exports had been declining and yet the cost of importing manufactured products had been on the increase.

Africa and the entire developing world, he said, were subjected to hostile policies by the World Trade Organization and international financial institutions.

"It would appear that there is a coordinated political agenda by the north, which controls these institutions, aimed at suppressing the development of developing countries," he said.

"Africa must build bridges of solidarity with other affected countries in the ACP, group of 77 and the non-aligned movement," Mubage said. "Together we must resist the recolonization of our countries under a facade of programmes to safeguard the global environment or globalization."

Through the inaugural session of the AEC, he said, the continent had sent a strong signal that it was now empowering itself to defeat the indignities of poverty, hunger and disease through targeted joint actions in social, economic and political spheres.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Turkish Company To Build Ethiopian Cement Factory


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Turkish construction company, "Enko," is to build Ethiopia's fourth cement factory at a cost of 750 million birr (about 115.38 million U.S. dollars) in the northern city of Makale.

The cornerstone for the factory, with the capacity to produce 2,000 tons of cement per day, was laid Monday in the Tigray regional capital by Seye Abraha, a senior state official, in the presence of Turkish ambassador to Ethiopia, Murat Belhan. 

The Ethiopian News Agency reported that the factory, which will be operational in February 1999, will provide jobs for 500 people.

Ethiopia presently has three cement factories respectively located in Addis Ababa, Mugar, 40 kms (25 miles) west of Addis Ababa, and Dire Dawa in the Eastern railway city.

The cement they produce barely meet the annual needs of the country.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africans To Feature In New York Photo Exhibitions


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - Three Africans are among eight award-winning international documentary photographers whose work will feature in an exhibition opening Wednesday in New York.

The photographers are Peter Magubane of South Africa, Nadia Ben Challal of Algeria and Paul Oloko of Nigeria. 

They will join Ljalja Kuznetsova of Russia, Steve Hart of the United States, Paula Sampaio of Brazil, Mohammad Eslami-Rad and Wu Jialin of China whose work will feature at the exhibition, titled Visions.

The work of the eight photographers have been selected to receive the 1997 Mother Jones Documentary Awards.

For the awards, each photographer will receive grants ranging from 3,500 to 7,000 U.S. dollars.

In addition, the lifetime achievement award will be presented to Magubane, famous for his documentation of South Africa under the apartheid system of government.

The two-month exhibition is being sponsored by the Leica Camera Group, The Body Shop, the Mother Jones Photo Fund and the United Nations Children's Fund, which is also the host.

LANGUAGE: English

55 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Leaders Elect Human Rights Commission Members


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Egypt, Tunisia and South Africa were elected Monday by African leaders to become members of the African Commission on Human and People's Rights.

Voting during the on going 33rd summit of the Organization of African Unity had to be conducted twice because there were too many candidates needing a two-thirds majority to qualify for the posts. 

Tunisia will be represented on the commission by Halem Ben Salem, serving his second term of office. He served on the previous commission which comprised his country, Nigeria and Tanzania. Ebrahim El-Sheik will represent Egypt and Nyameko Pityana will represent South Africa.

The candidates, who are legal experts in their respective countries, will serve a six-year term.

During their meeting last week, the O.A.U. Council of Ministers, called for expediency in the establishment of the court to try human rights abuses.

This court would generally enhance the powers of the commission as people will use evidence from the commission to take their governments to court if they feel their rights have been violated.

The commission was enacted under the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 37


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4320 words


Washington DC - GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report #37, Fiscal Year (FY)1997, May 30, 1997. Note: The last situation report was dated May 23, 1997.

DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (DROC) - Background

In mid-October 1996, fighting broke out in South Kivu, Zaire between the Zairian army (FAZ) and the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire, led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting caused Rwandan and Burundian refugees to flee, prompting more than 700,000 Rwandans and 62,000 Burundians to repatriate by the end of 1996. Hundreds of thousands of refugees also fled west, scattering in small groups in Zaire. The fighting spread, with the Alliance rapidly gaining territory on all fronts, and ended when the Alliance seized Kinshasa on May 17. Kabila Consolidates Power Amid Protests In Kinshasa, Kabila named himself president of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DROC), formerly Zaire, and on May 22 he announced a cabinet without appointing a prime minister. On May 29, Kabila was formally inaugerated as head of state. 

Kabila banned anti-government political activities, including demonstrations, after public protests flared in the capital on May 23. Despite the ban, 800 to 1,000 supporters of opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi staged a march. Government troops initially allowed the marchers to proceed before dispersing them with shots in the air and beatings. In Goma, about 1,000 university students also staged a protest on May 30. They dispersed after five truckloads of DROC troops arrived and fired in the air.

Few Refugees in Kisangani-Ubundu Corridor

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Kisangani reported that as of May 30, a total of 37,221 refugees had been repatriated through Kisangani. Of the total, 3,756 were unaccompanied children (UAC), of whom 26 died during the repatriation operation, and 46 were reunited with their parents or guardians before reaching Rwanda. As of May 27, there were 253 UACs remaining in the Kisangani transit center.

Along the corridor, 13 refugees emerged from the forest surrounding Biaro (km 41) on March 28. The World Food Program (WFP) and CARE, supported by USAID, are providing hot food at Biaro for the refugees. A WFP train took food and non-food items to Obilo (km 82) on May 28, and brought back 837 refugees, including 84 UACs, to Kisangani for repatriation. Another 2,000 refugees remain at Obilo. Ubundu (km 125) was empty of refugees as of May 27. In late April, the UNHCR estimated that 91,000 refugees had gathered along the corridor. Only half are accounted for to date, and the numbers of refugees emerging from the forest during the past weeks have shrunk from several hundred to fewer than one hundred at a time.

Road Access Remains Difficult

On May 27, UNHCR/Kisangani officials were granted permission to travel by road to km 53, where the road ends. However, they turned back at km 50 after finding a DROC military vehicle that had struck an anti-tank mine. DROC authorities promised to clear the road of mines and the UNHCR has asked that a DROC military vehicle lead the rescheduled mission.

Burundian Refugees Not to Be Repatriated

There are 249 Burundian refugees registered in the Kisangani transit center. The UNHCR and local Kisangani authorities have agreed not to repatriate them and their seven compatriots in Mbandaka, because of insecurity in Burundi.

More Refugees Estimated in Mbandaka On May 23 and 24 a USAID/DART field officer visited Mbandaka, 600 km west of Kisangani, as part of a U.N./NGO team focussed on establishing and improving emergency operations at the airport transit site. The UNHCR estimated that, as of May 26, there were 18,400 Rwandan refugees in the area: 2,900 at the transit site and 15,500 hiding in forests. Those in the camps are primarily males in relatively good condition, and most had made their way to Mbandaka from the Bukavu, Goma, Opala, and Ikela areas. Of the 15,500, the UNHCR believes 7,500 are clustered along the southwestern axis, parallel to the Congo River. Another 2,000 refugees are reportedly in Djombo, 7 km south of Mbandaka; and 1,000 refugees are believed to be along the southeastern axis in Bamayana, 12 km southeast of Mbandaka. An additional 5,000 refugees are further south along the Congo River in Irebu, which reportedly is not yet in DROC control.

Relief Efforts Underway in Mbandaka

Medecins Sans Frontieres/Belgium (MSF/B), which has implemented health services in the Mbandaka region for the past five years, was the first NGO to provide assistance at the transit site. Their workers established three medical units which provide triage and consultative services, as well as basic drugs and medical services, primarily to treat malaria. Because DROC officials do not allow MSF/B expatriates to stay in Mbandaka, the NGO maintains a cadre of two local doctors and three nurses in the town.

MSF/B also has established a water distribution system at the transit site that provides 5,000 liters per day of potable water, enough for 4,000 people. Refugees received maize meal during their first week at the transit site. They supplemented the ration by trading part of it on the local market for fruit, fish, and beans. Since May 23, the refugees have received a daily distribution of UNIMIX, a high-protein porridge, and high-protein biscuits. On May 26, WFP was scheduled to deliver to Mbandaka enough food for 4,000 people for two weeks. Wet feeding kitchens, aimed at vulnerable groups among the refugees, have been established.

UACs Receive Special Attention

UNICEF provides general management and coordination of activities targeting UACs at the transit site. Save the Children (SCF) identifies and registers UACs, and the local Red Cross provides food, water, and medical assistance. Most of the UACs at the transit site are teenage boys, in contrast to the mix of young boys and girls who make up the typical UAC profile. UNICEF has established mobile teams to collect UACs directly from villages and transport them to the transit site.

Repatriation Operation

Between May 21 and 29, the UNHCR reported that 4,700 refugees were repatriated by air from Mbandaka to Kigali. Repatriation flights are now carrying up to 900 refugees daily from the transit site. There are three Ilyushin-76 aircraft, one donated by the World Food Program (WFP), transporting the refugees to Kisangani. Each aircraft can carry 300 per trip. The UNHCR intends to transport as many refugees as possible from the surrounding area to the transit site before it airlifts them to Kigali. It estimates that repatriation will last about one month.

The UNHCR has established collection points at six villages in the Mbandaka region. The collection points are used to encourage refugees to emerge from the forest, to collect information from the local villagers on the number and location of the refugees, and to serve as a meeting place for refugees awaiting transportation to the transit site.

The UNHCR has also established mobile teams that travel in UNHCR-escorted trucks to gather the refugees at each Mbandaka collection point. To date, about 700 refugees are being transport daily from the collection points to the airport transit site. Insecurity prevents mobile teams from searching the nearby forests for refugees, and there are unconfirmed reports that 140 refugees were killed by Alliance forces on May 13 in Wenji, 20 km southwest of Mbandaka. To gain local goodwill and keep people informed of the repatriation operation, the UNHCR plans this week to distribute eight shortwave radios to village chiefs in the Mbandaka region. So far, relations between the refugees and local villagers have been friendly, despite reported incidents of refugees stealing livestock and raiding crops.

Local Support; ICRC Assistance

The UNHCR hopes to limit the number of NGOs supporting the Mbandaka operation. Where possible, the UNHCR and relief agencies will use local resources. The DROC Red Cross workers have been hired to conduct daily food distributions, and to work with MSF/B in coordination with UNICEF. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) will provide guidance and management to the local Red Cross. The ICRC is paying salaries of local Red Cross workers assisting UNICEF with UAC care, and is providing logistical support.

Refugees in the ROC and CAR On May 28, UNICEF reported the presence of about 15,000 Rwandan refugees who crossed into the Republic of Congo (ROC). Of the total, about 7,500 are in Liranga, 500 km north of Brazzaville; 4,000 are in Loukolela, 80 km south of Liranga; 500-600 are in Makotopoko, 250 km north of Brazzaville, and 500 in Mpouya, 175 km north of Brazzaville. UNICEF also reports there are other small groups of refugees who have not been identified. The U.N. plans to move refugees by barge to Kintele, 30 km from Brazzaville and a three-day river journey from Liranga. When the refugees reach Kintele, they will be screened, and the armed elements among them will be separated. The refugees will then be moved to a temporary site at Bilolo, 18 km from Brazzaville.

A UNHCR team has confirmed that about 4,500 refugees are gathered in the towns of Mobaye and Kemba, on the Central African Republic (CAR) side of the Ubangi River. The refugees are mostly officials of the former Mobutu government, but the group also includes about 300 Rwandans.

Return Operation for Uvira Delayed

As of May 25, the ICRC transported 5,500 internally displaced persons (IDP) from Kisangani to Bukavu, Goma, Isiro, Bunia, and Walikale. This includes 100 IDPs who were transported between May 18- 25. Of the 100 IDPs, the ICRC trucked 47 to Walikale and flew the remainder to Goma and Bukavu. The ICRC plans to move another 900 IDPs from Kisangani to their homes in eastern Zaire. Most will travel overland to Lubutu and Walikale by truck.

The ICRC had planned to begin returning 6,000- 7,000 IDPs from Kalemie to Uvira by barge on May 29. It postponed the return because of insecurity that followed the shooting of five locals in Uvira on May 25. The local population blamed DROC soldiers for the killings and held a demonstration the next day. A riot ensued, and at least 10 people were killed.

RWANDA

11 Die in Kibuye Ambush

The police commander of the Kibuye region and ten other people died when a minibus and another vehicle were ambushed on May 26, according to a news report that quoted military sources. The attack, carried out by about 30 armed men, occurred between Kivumu and Mabanza communes in Kibuye prefecture, western Rwanda.

The attackers were believed to be members of the former Rwandan army (ex-FAR) and militia (Interahamwe).

Three Men Sentenced on Genocide Charges

Rwandan radio reported on May 22 that three men were sentenced to death in a Kibuye court on charges of genocide in 1994. Two other courts sentenced two men to life imprisonment, and another to three years imprisonment; a fourth was acquitted.

BURUNDI

Widespread Violence

The UNHCR reported that 60 people, mostly returnees, were killed on May 19 in an attack on three sites where returnees had settled at Ndava, Cibitoke province. Three days later, another attack killed one person and wounded five. An independent Burundian radio station reported the deaths of 42 people during an attack on a church in Muhuta, 31 km south of the capital, on May 14. A Burundian army spokesman said he had no information on the attack. Fighting also continues in the south, and in Bujumbura Rural province, mortar fire in the countryside can be heard in the capital.

TANZANIA

International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda

In Arusha, the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda adjourned until September 29 the trial of Jean-Paul Akayesu. He is charged with involvement in the massacre of 2,000 Tutsis during the 1994 genocide. Akayesu's lawyer said he had been unable to find witnesses to testify. On May 29, the trial of Georges Rutaganda, a high-ranking member of the Interahamwe militia, was adjourned until June 9.

USG ASSISTANCE

BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda from October 26, 1996 to February 26, 1997, and an assessment team to Zaire from February 12 to 26. The current USAID/DART was deployed on March 14, and has offices in Nairobi, Goma, and Kisangani

USAID FY 1997 Assistance to date:

BHR/OFDA Assistance

Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Welcomes Buthelezi's Remarks


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC is encouraged by statements made by IFP President Dr Mangosuthu Buthelezi on possible co-operation between the two organisations.

The essential element in this regard remains the achievement of peace and stability for all communities in KwaZulu-Natal which must be based on the universal recognition of the rights of citizens in that part of our country to support and belong to political organisations of their choice without any let or hindrance from traditional authorities or any other governmental structures. 

It is now clear that the violence which has engulfed KwaZulu-Natal for the last decade was engendered by third force elements whose aim was to thwart the transition of our country as a whole into a democracy.

The ANC gives its unequivocal support to all current efforts aimed at achieving peace and stability in the province of KwaZulu-Natal.

Whether these peace efforts will lay a basis for further advancement and co-operation between the two organisations, will be left to the constitutional structures and constituencies of both organisations to decide.

Issued by The African National Congress, Department of Information and Publicity, P.O. Box 16884, Marshalltown 2307, Johannesburg.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

58 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Marks the Last Edition Of New Nation


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Johannesburg - "The Media of the powerless," ANC Media Statement to mark the last Edition of the New Nation, 30 May 1997.

During a television debate in 1968, Bertrand Russell had occasion to draw a sharp distinction between an open mind and an empty mind. He illustrated the difference by employing the analogy of a juror, who though he/she holds an opinion regarding crime, will not give judgement in a case until he/she has heard all the relevant facts. Such a person, Russell said, has an open mind. 

Journalists, columnists, newspaper editors and consequently the newspapers they produce, like the rest of us, hold opinions. It would be childish to pretend that these prior opinions do not intrude on their work or colour their perceptions. We can but hope that, like Russell's juror, they will only pass judgement after all the relevant facts are known. In other words, we hope they have open minds.

The people of South Africa, who like their counterparts in other industrial societies, rely on a free and independent media for most of their information about the world around them, have all too often been bitterly disappointed by its performance. This was particularly true during the darkest days of National Party repression between 1961 and 1990.

The untimely disappearance of the New Nation from the South African media landscape marks the tragic end of an heroic career in this country's communications industry.

The New Nation was among a fraternity of courageous newspapers and journals that came into existence in the course of the hard fought struggles of the mid - 1980s, in order to fill the yawning gap in news, information and opinions occasioned by the supine attitude of the White-owned commercial press towards the National Party's oppressive regime. These publications came to be known as the alternative press.

Operating on shoe string budgets and sustained by donor funds from abroad, the alternative media continuously tested the outer limits of the apartheid regimes prescriptive laws to give voice to the powerless million in the urban townships, the rural areas and those engaged in the struggle for democracy. Because most of them were weeklies, they specialised in in-depth analysis and investigative journalism bringing to light some of the worst atrocities perpetrated by the National Party governments security forces.

The New Nation was established by the Catholic Bishops Conference and staffed by some of South Africa's most daring black journalists, led by Zwelakhe Sisulu. The paper quickly carved out a niche as an authoritative voice among the anti- apartheid forces coalesced in the Mass Democratic Movement. Under the able stewardship of Zwelakhe Sisulu it came to be regarded as the flagship of democratic media.

The decade during which the New Nation was born marked the decisive turning point in th post-war history of our country, when the initiative passed from the hands of the oppressive regime to the national democratic movement. The historians of the future will record and assess the contribution the New Nation made to this turn of events. Even at this early date we are however able to comment that while many other newspapers wavered and prevaricated, the New Nation stood firm; where many other editors and journalists compromised their principals, those at the New Nation refused to be cowed.

It beggars the term "temerity" that one such newspaper patronisingly refers to the New Nation as more of a "propaganda organ" than a newspaper when we recall how that very newspaper shamelessly cheered the murderous death squads of the NP that tried to assassinate Albie Sachs, now a Constitutional Court judge!!

The revelations before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission vindicate the New Nation's coverage virtually everyday, while the cheer leaders for murders of Vlakplaas desperately pray for our collective amnesia rather than admit their culpability!!

Because they remained undaunted, the editor and the journalists at the New Nation received the unwelcome attentions of the NP's secret police. Zwelakhe Sisulu was regularly detained and his newspaper was periodically banned. As one of the principal standard bearers of media freedom in this country at a time when such advocacy carried a high price, the New Nation and the courageous men and women who worked on it, can take pride in our Bill of Rights that entrenches the freedoms they sacrificed to attain.

In a heartening instance of poetic justice, the last issue of the New Nation comes off the press at a time when their chief political tormentors, the National Party, are plunging deeper and deeper into political crisis.

Long after the pages of its last edition have been yellowed by age, the people of South Africa, especially the millions who engaged in struggle, will remember the New Nation for its sterling service to our country and the cause of freedom. That is a track record any newspaper can be proud of.

Issued by The African National Congress, Department of Information and Publicity, P.O. Box 16884, Marshalltown 2307, Johannesburg.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Nats Seek SABC Audit


BYLINE: National Party (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Cape Town - The growing number of resignations at the SABC and the resultant decline in standards and quality of TV news, compel the National Party to call the minister in question, Jay Naidoo, to account.

The National Party once again demands that the stipulation in the Constitution, which makes provision for institutions receiving government funds to be subjected to performance audits by the Auditor-General, be applied to the SABC by the minister with immediate effect. All is not well - regardless of what the SABC spokesman, Mr Enoch Sithole, holds out to the world. 

The SABC, currently battling with unknown financial problems, as well as the number of resignations of top management, will have to urgently reconsider its role as public broadcaster. Foreign consultants who are being appointed at great cost to advise the SABC, do not necessarily have the expertise and experience to give the kind of advice required within the South African context. In addition, the SABC can no longer afford to appoint to management positions people who may lack expertise in the field of broadcasting.

The time has arrived for Minister Jay Naidoo to act responsibly in order to ensure that the SABC does not collapse due to the lack of managerial expertise. Government can no longer afford to carry the SABC financially merely because the SABC is the public broadcaster. For the SABC to broadcast to all and sundry that all is well, is, to say the least, extremely disquieting. Does the SABC accept that its situation is normal, or is the SABC in such a state of deterioration that it can no longer discern the difference between normality and calamity? Does the SABC really need more consultants to confirm that its voice is faltering?

Issued by Jan Bosman, National Party - Federal Council Manager, Media Affairs, PO Box 1698, Cape Town, 8000. Tel: (021) 461-5833. Fax: (021) 461-5329. http://www.natweb.co.za


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Nats Criticize COSATU Strike


BYLINE: National Party (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Adriaan Blaas, MP, Member of the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee On Labour, COSATU Action on 2 June 1997.

The action by COSATU on 2 June 1997 and the threats arising from this are economically irresponsible and insensitive towards the interests of the poorest people of South Africa. 

COSATU abuses the exclusive powerbase which it is granted by law, to blackmail organised business to its own advantage. This is evidence of a disregard of the government's Gear plan and is extremely irresponsible towards the economic objectives set for South Africa. COSATU will have to realise that South Africa will first have to work harder before it can think of self-enrichment.

COSATU is an "elite" minority group that does not include the 40% poorest people in South Africa. Its action is detrimental to the possibility of creating jobs for the unemployed. It is a selfish and irresponsible deed that is rejected by the National Party.

If it does not want to make a voluntary commitment, COSATU will have to be forced to use its powers and power base in a responsible manner in the interests of South Africa and all its people.

Issued by Jan Bosman, National Party - Federal Council Manager, Media Affairs, PO Box 1698, Cape Town, 8000. Tel: (021) 461-5833. Fax: (021) 461-5329. http://www.natweb.co.za

61 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


United States and Africa;
State Department Describes Freetown Evacuations


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2680 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers on Sierra Leone by State Department Acting Spokesman John Dinger at the Department's daily briefing June 2.

QUESTION: Do you have any idea what is going on in Sierra Leone?

MR. DINGER: Let me go through, I think, what I have, and then you can ask any further questions if you have them. The United States carried out two evacuations from Freetown on Friday and Sunday. We took out approximately 1,300 people, including approximately 400 Americans. The remaining 900 nationals were from over 40 different countries. 

All of the evacuees who had been taken to the Kearsarge were later taken on to Conakry, Guinea. About half of those evacuees left Conakry on a charter flight to Brussels on Sunday. A second charter is scheduled to depart Conakry today. Additionally, there was a British charter flight which also left Conakry on Sunday, and that carried approximately 30 Americans. That flight was to London.

We now have reports of somewhere between 12 and 30 American citizens still in Freetown.

QUESTION: Are they there voluntarily?

MR. DINGER: We believe that those Americans want to leave Sierra Leone. It is difficult to speculate on why they were not at the departure point for the first two evacuation flights, but that is beside the point.

We understand that what is happening now - the Kearsarge will remain in the area pending a determination of whether another evacuation from Freetown is possible.

Our ambassador to Sierra Leone, John Hirsch, returned to the region over the weekend and arrived on board the Kearsarge on Saturday. He is now there with Anne Wright who was the charge, now, the DCM. The two of them, particularly Ambassador Hirsch and the commander of the forces there, will make a judgment call on whether and when further evacuations can take place.

We understand that there are perhaps some 200 - it's very difficult to know how many, but perhaps 200 foreigners in the Mammy Yoko Hotel, which was the evacuation site. We also understand that there has been fighting near the hotel. It is very difficult to know specifically what is going on, of course, because communications are very difficult between Freetown and Washington or the Kearsarge.

Nevertheless, we understand that most of those foreigners are now in the basement of the Mammy Yoko Hotel. We also understand that there are some small fires in the Mammy Yoko Hotel; however, it is very difficult to know with any certainty the origin of the fires or the extent of the fires. However, the last word that we have is that the fires were relatively small and did not pose any immediate imminent direct threat to the people who have taken shelter in the basement.

The United States, of course, does not have a protecting power in Sierra Leone. We issued a new travel warning over the weekend warning, first of all, all Americans to defer travel to Sierra Leone; also again urging Americans who continue to remain in Sierra Leone to leave immediately. We ask everyone to be aware that there are no U.S. Government officials in Sierra Leone to assist them.

Nevertheless, we are in close contact with the British High Commission which is still somewhat staffed in Sierra Leone. We are cooperating closely with them on security, evacuation and political issues. We understand that the British High Commission is in touch with most, if not all of the factions in Freetown, including the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council.

We also understand that there have been discussions over the last 24 hours between the Nigerian commander of the Economic Community of West African States Monitoring Group forces in Sierra Leone and the Armed Forces Revolutionary Counsel.

We also understand that the International Committee of the Red Cross is very active in Sierra Leone, and is discussing and perhaps has even established a very fragile cease-fire with the AFRC rebels. However, there is fighting. Reportedly there has been some shelling this morning between Nigerian forces, which are securing the Mammy Yoko Hotel and other locations, and the other fighters in Freetown.

Meanwhile, on Sunday the AFRC was expanded to 26 persons. That incorporated members of previous rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone. The RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, was named vice chairman of the council. However, he remains under house arrest in Nigeria.

Meanwhile, the United States is using all diplomatic channels available to urge the rebels to quit and restore the democratically elected government of Sierra Leone. We are also supporting, to the extent we can, the fragile cease-fire between ECOMOG and rebel forces in an effort to stabilize the situation and allow, as possible, a third evacuation.

We understand as of this morning that the Nigerian forces appear to be in a defensive posture near the installations and buildings that they have been securing against attacks by the rebels. To the best of our knowledge there are currently approximately 2,000 Nigerian troops in Sierra Leone. I think that's about all I have.

QUESTION: On the statement that the Nigerians appear to be in a defensive position. Our reports say that their gunboats are shelling what appears to be the rebel headquarters. Do you know if that is true?

MR. DINGER: I can't confirm that. We obviously are aware of reports that there was at least artillery fire from the Nigerian forces this morning. We are aware of those reports, but in the midst of the chaos in Freetown, we cannot verify any of those reports.

QUESTION: Do you find that the Nigerian troops are playing a useful role stabilizing the situation?

MR. DINGER: The Nigerians have said that is their role. I would point out that my understanding is that the Nigerians have been in the vicinity of the Mammy Yoko Hotel, and they have been acting to try to defend the hotel against rebels. Certainly, if the Nigerians are protecting Americans and other foreigners in the Mammy Yoko Hotel, we would certainly be grateful for that.

QUESTION: John, there were also reports just before coming in here that the Mammy Yoko Hotel was under fire. The accounts by the Nigerian forces that apparently spoke to the wire services indicated that it was a very severe battle. How is it - is the United States or is Ambassador Hirsch in touch with the British High Commission to determine the fate of the foreigners who are at the hotel? Or does he have direct links to the hotel?

MR. DINGER: I'm not aware of any direct links between the Kearsarge and the hotel. My understanding is that there are two main means of communication. One is from the hotel to the United States or elsewhere. I understand much of the communication has been with the manager of the hotel.

Also, as you have mentioned, I think, the British High Commission remains active there, and we are in touch, as possible, with the British High Commission. So the assessment is generally being made through those communication links, and of course to the extent possible, any observations that can be made from the Kearsarge or any of its assets.

QUESTION: There is the hope here, then, that a cease-fire is established and then a determination made by the commander and the ambassador as to whether or not an evacuation is possible?

MR. DINGER: We understand that there is, to some degree, a fragile cease-fire in place. I cannot confirm that there is heavy fighting at the moment near the Mammy Yoko Hotel. I understand there has been fighting. I just can't confirm either the extent of it, or whether it goes on.

What will happen now in terms of a third evacuation is a judgment call by the people nearest the events, that is the commander on the Kearsarge of the Marines, and our Ambassador onboard. That is a judgment call - cost-risk evaluation - to decide when or if a third evacuation should take place.

QUESTION: Do you have any idea who these Americans are? They are not officials, I assume.

MR. DINGER: I can't tell you who they are, although I did just receive a call that some are journalists. Beyond that, I can't narrow it down for you. We can't even know with any certainty what the numbers are. Our numbers for Americans is between 12 and 30.

QUESTION: But you assume that they're not in any way connected with the embassy? That's what I was saying.

MR. DINGER: There are no official Americans still in Freetown.

QUESTION: John, do you know where they are in town?

MR. DINGER: Pardon me?

QUESTION: Do you know where they are in town?

MR. DINGER: They are in the basement --

QUESTION: They're all in the hotel?

MR. DINGER: All that we are aware of at the present time are in the Mammy Yoko Hotel, the vast majority in the basement. Now, I cannot rule out that there may not be other Americans still in Sierra Leone, either in Freetown or elsewhere.

I would assume that in case, for example, of dual nationals there almost certainly are still Americans elsewhere in Sierra Leone. These individuals, both the Americans and the foreigners, for whatever reason, were not at the evacuation point for either of the evacuations that took place. We understand that they are there now in hopes of being evacuated, and, of course, every consideration will be given to doing that.

QUESTION: You said 12 to 30 U.S. citizens. Does that exclude dual nationals?

MR. DINGER: No, that includes dual nationals. All American citizens are equal in our eyes.

QUESTION: Reports this morning speak about a serious level of fighting; I mean, bombing everywhere. Do you think this is a thrust by the Nigerians to change the status quo on the ground in Freetown? And if it is, will it have the blessing of the United States?

MR. DINGER: I cannot confirm the violence in Freetown of the scale, I think, that you are alluding to. Clearly, there has been fighting. No question about that. The degree of the fighting I can't confirm. Also I don't want to speculate on what Nigeria's actions or intentions are. We simply do not know. Of course, I have said before what the public statements have been for the Nigerian commander. I am unaware of any change in his public statements.

QUESTION: Anyone talk to the Nigerian Government at all?

MR. DINGER: Yes, we're in touch in the Nigerian Government and I cannot contradict what they have been saying publicly.

I would reiterate that what we believe is essential immediately is a cease-fire, an end to the violence, the people of Sierra Leone have suffered enough violence. We believe the military clique should quit and should restore authority to elected civilian leaders. Then perhaps Sierra Leone can get back on track towards democracy and to some form of stability and prosperity for the people of that country.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Bushbuckridge in flames again


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - The offices of the South African National Civic Organisation (SANCO), a school and a truck were torched during new violence over the Bushbuckridge border dispute this weekend, police said on Monday.

Police said the SANCO offices, which were next to the Mapulaneng Magistrate's Office, were burnt on Friday night, allegedly by pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators.

SANCO chairman, Chrisjan Mokoena, last week urged all civil servants and students to go back to work and school. 

Ntsie Primary School in Health Centre, near Bushbuckridge was torched on Saturday morning and the damage is estimated to be more than R600 000.

A freight truck from Rustenburg Plant in North West Province was also ambushed and set alight on Sunday between Marite and Bushbuckridge. Police were able to put out the fire before the truck burnt out.

"We have not arrested any arsonists yet, but we are following possible leads," said spokesperson of the Lowveld region of Northern Province, Captain Thomas Ramatseba.

He said some roads had been barricaded on Saturday and Sunday in Bushbuckridge and Marite, and that police were stoned but no one was injured.

"We appeal to the people of Bushbuckridge to stop throwing stones at the police. We are there to keep peace and not to solve their border dispute," he said.

The Bushbuckridge Border Committee (BBC) declared that this week would be one of mourning after a pro-Mpumalanga demonstrator, Sonto Khoza (18), was allegedly shot dead by police while toyi-toying after the Million Man March two weeks ago in Bushbuckridge.

BBC spokesperson, Prince Ndlovu, said the committee wanted national Minister of Safety and Security, Sydney Mufamadi, and Northern Province MEC for Safety and Security, Seth Nthai, to explain why Khoza was killed. A meeting planned for Thursday between the committee and MEC Nthai, to discuss the behaviour of police and the community during demonstrations, had to be postponed, however, as the committee would be attending Khoza's funeral.

Ndlovu said an interdenominational prayer rally would be held at Paulianah Stadium on Wednesday.

The Bushbuckridge border dispute has left the Mpumalanga Environmental Affairs and Tourism Department with more than R200 000 debt after it had to pay damages to several tourists who were attacked and whose vehicles were damaged by protesters.

The Department was forced to open the Albasini gate for visitors to the Kruger National Park, after the Kruger Gate road was barricaded.

Welcome Tours and Safaris spokesperson, Francois Grove, said the company lost several tourist vehicles since the start of the demonstrations, after pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators allegedly stoned the vehicles and tried to set two alight.

He said two American tourists were attacked at Acornhoek and had to leave their car at Hoedspruit as it was badly damaged.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Strike hits W Cape clothing industry


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Cape Town - Yesterday's Congress of South African Trade Unions' (Cosatu) strike cost the Western Cape's fragile clothing industry R10 million in turnover and R2 million in wages.

Cape Clothing Manufacturers' Association chairman Johann Baard said the losses were suffered when about 70% of clothing industry workers heeded Cosatu's call to strike against provisions in the Basic Conditions of Employment Draft Bill.

Cosatu is demanding a 40-hour working week, to be phased in over five years, and six months' maternity leave, with four months paid, be included in the Bill. 

"The majority of factories have reported high levels of absenteeism," Mr Baard said.

The clothing, textile and leather industries are the biggest employers in the Western Cape.

The South African Clothing and Textile Workers' Union (Sactwu) said in a statement that close to 90% or 155 000 of workers in the clothing, textile and leather industries did not report for work countrywide yesterday.

Cape Chamber of Commerce and Industry spokesman Charl Adams said about 25% of Western Cape workers did not go to work yesterday. The building and clothing industries were the hardest hit.

"The strike was not as comprehensive as people said it would be. The Western Cape compared favourably with the rest of the country," he said.

Cosatu's Western Cape secretary general Tony Ehrenreich, however, has challenged Mr Adams' estimate, saying that between 80% to 85% of employees in the province stayed away from work.

South African Chamber of Business (Sacob) labour affairs and social policy manager Janet Dickman said the strike was not supported as well as Cosatu had hoped. Support was patchy, with some industries reporting a 100% attendance figures and others 0%.

"Mass support depended on how strong organisers were in the various industries," Mrs Dickman said.

She urged Cosatu to negotiate at the National Economic Development and Labour Council before embarking on actions such as calling for strike action.

"I do not think taking to the streets is the appropriate way to achieve their aims," Mrs Dickman said.

Sapa reported that absenteeism in KwaZulu-Natal factories ranged from 20% to 80%.

Durban Chamber of Commerce and Industries spokesman Neil McGregor said most workers had heeded the call.

In Johannesburg, council officials only reported hiccups in refuse removal and street sweeping services, Sapa said.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Whitey Jacobs: no such thing as 'off-duty' in community health


BYLINE: Jenny Viall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Cape Town - We need more people like Whitey Jacobs in our health system. With no formal medical training he heads a team of community health workers who offer caring and healing to the people of Brown's Farm, an informal settlement in Philippi.

For his work over the past 10 years, Whitey has been nominated as one of six finalists for the Soul City Health Care Worker of the Year Award.

In his quiet, unassuming way he passes this honour on, saying it should rather go to the people he supervises. 

Explaining why, he tells the story of the community health worker called out at 2am to attend to a dying woman.

She spent almost 12 hours at the house, waiting for the woman's daughter to return, helping distraught family members deal with their loss.

Community health workers, says Whitey, are respected, accepted and accountable to the people they serve and there's no such thing as "off duty".

His brief is to co-ordinate 20 dedicated workers, a job which started out in a very different form when he joined the Health Care Trust 10 years ago and was trained to train others in First Aid.

Born in Guguletu, where he still lives, Whitey joined the trust as a field worker.

"In 1986, I was secretary of the Emergency Services Group. Then I was detained for two years."

He doesn't elaborate, but talks rather about the challenges of setting up health services in an area where there was none.

>From his work in a community in crisis, Whitey is well versed in the politics of health which includes the need for housing, sanitation and clean water.

That struggle continues as does the struggle for Government recognition and remuneration for community health worker programmes.

Whitey's first major drive in the area was a door-to-door survey of 200 homes.

A community health worker programme was identified as top priority and workshops were held to decide what exactly this entailed. Seven community health workers were then chosen and trained by the Primary Preventative Health Care Network, an NGO with which Whitey still works closely.

At that stage, there was no clinic in the area. "Without medical and professional support, community health programmes cannot work. We needed a support base," Whitey says.

Negotiations with local councils followed and two clinics were built. But the process wasn't quite that simple, he says. Before health committees could be formed and community health workers elected, leadership conflicts had to be sorted out.

"The trouble is that in a squatter community you can't work effectively if the leadership does not recognise you."

Whitey wears many caps: he's a problem solver, a life- skills trainer, co-ordinator and a support for his team of community health workers, the basic building blocks of primary health care.

Their work is health education, first aid and curing basic diseases and they visit homes where they treat minor ailments and pick up problems like TB which would otherwise go untreated.

People also visit them at home, and their work increasingly includes social services like counselling and advising on grants and pensions.

With the formal primary health care clinics overflowing, community health workers offer an essential service to underserved areas, he says.

"We're doing the Government's work. The CMC clinic closes at 12 and the province's day hospital, with its quota system, anything from 12 noon to 3pm. After that, people spill over to the community health worker."

Ideally, there should be one community health worker for 250 homes. The reality is one for 500 to 1 200 homes. While not ideal, the system is up and running. Sadly, it faces collapse if the Government does not support it, and soon.

"We've been funded by the European Union. But then the EU said, 'look guys we're giving money to the Government, get it from them'. Right now we are operating without stationery, and that's just one example. I'm wondering if we will get paid this month."

Funding for community health care workers is an issue not just for the Philippi project.

"The Government makes public statements to say they support community health programmes, but practically they don't. They are not putting structures in place that would enable them to support CHWs. The whole question of CHWs is a reference only in the national health plan. We go to the Government for support, they say wait for the district health system to come. That could be in 1999.

"If the Brown's Farm community health worker programmes collapse, and you can't sustain people without remuneration, the Government will be sitting with a crisis," he says. "Our major need is in fact a social worker to help with social problems. HIV is on the increase, so is child abuse. Counselling is needed. People visit from the Transkei and are stranded. They don't know where to go and are sent to health workers' homes. It's a real problem."

Whitey is working out ways to meet the challenge while he grapples with his nomination for the Soul City award.

"My feeling," he says, "is that this award is for the community health workers, those that attend to dying people at 2am. I'm only part of that."


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Surprise or bully-boy tactics? (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - Residents of the Gympie Street area of Woodstock are upset by what they term a return to apartheid tactics in an anti-crime raid during which police pulled down the front of a house

Police maintain that surprise is an essential element in arresting the perpetrators of crime, especially drug dealers who routinely destroy evidence when law enforcers arrive on the doorstep.

No one sincere about combating crime would take issue with this and it was no doubt the motivation for the weekend anti- crime raid on the Gympie Street area of Woodstock being carried out at 4am.

But where does "surprise" end and downright bullying begin? Was is really necessary to attach a chain to a security gate in a wall during the raid and literally pull down the front of someone's home with a Casspir? 

The picture of the wrecked facade in the Cape Argus yesterday must have sparked a sense of d ja vu among many readers, reminiscent as it was of the mayhem caused by jack- booted apartheid police storming into people's homes at all hours of the day or night in the interests of keeping a morally corrupt regime in power.

Memories of those days are still too fresh, the wounds too raw for police to expect support for that sort of behaviour, the paltry haul of 26 Mandrax tablets, some dagga and 18 crack crystals notwithstanding.

Equally outrageous is the cynical remark by a police spokesman that in any case the gate and wall were "not in accordance with building regulations because they were built too close to the road". Since when do the police have the right to administer jungle justice on behalf of the municipality?

While demands for action may put law enforcers between a rock and hard place in the fight against drugs, policing methods must be acceptable to society and the rights and dignity of individuals upheld regardless of who they are. Come on, George Fivaz. Where is this caring new police service about which we hear so much?


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Race to finish stadium for world cycling


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - The City of Tygerberg is winning a race against time to complete the R45-million Olympic velodrome for an international sports event next month.

The multi-purpose sports stadium with a velodrome roof has to be finished in time for the World Junior Cycling Championships. 

It will also be the main venue for Olympic cycling events if Cape Town's bid to host the 2004 Games succeeds.

Tygerberg chief executive officer Dave Wilken said good weather meant there had been no delays in construction. The roof-wetting took place last week.

"The project is on schedule and will be completed by July 1.

"We believe it will be something the Tygerberg can be very proud of," said Mr Wilken.

The council hopes to pay for the development with the proceeds of a 4,2ha land sale and by selling naming rights for the stadium. The Olympic Bid Company will contribute R5- million.

June 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Sport chief gives Bid a lift


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town's bid for the 2004 Games has earned the enthusiastic endorsement of world weightlifting boss Tamas Ajan, who says the organisation of the junior world championships here has been "fantastic".

"This is Olympic-level organisation. We could hold the senior event here, which is 10 times bigger, tomorrow. Everything has been excellent - accommodation, meals, transport, security, documentation ... everything," Dr Ajan said at a briefing last night.

But he admitted he was disappointed by the lack of spectator interest.

Entry to all events, continuing today and tomorrow at the Good Hope Centre, is free. A record 28 world records have been broken so far.

Dr Ajan said he knew weightlifting was not particularly popular in South Africa, but hoped this would change. Nevertheless, the high standard of organisation was a feather in the bid city's cap.

"If you do the same for the World Fencing Championships (July 13-19) and the Junior World Cycling Championships (July 29-August 4), it will confirm that the African people and Cape Town citizens have what it takes to organise a South African Games," he said.

Dr Ajan predicted that Cape Town would almost certainly be in the final round of the vote for the 2004 host city when the International Olympic Committee meets on September 5 to choose the winner.

Business and Finance;
Cape Wine estate to make 2004 a vintage year


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - Management at champion Boland wine estate Nelson's Creek have been anything but convinced about Cape Town's Olympic ambitions.

But on the strength of the special supplement published in the Cape Argus last week to mark the 100-day countdown to the September 5 decision, they have had a change of heart. Today, a display of international flags at the estate's entrance was replaced by a brace of bid flags. 

Winemaker and estate manager Carl Allen acknowledged the decision represented a change of heart.

After considering the arguments in the Cape Argus supplement, "we have come to the conclusion that while there certainly are arguments against holding the Olympics in Cape Town, the advantages far outweigh the disadvantages".

In fact, the wine estate is not alone. Barry and Mina Thomas of Jambo Guest House in Green Point have decked their building in bid flags and bunting and suggest all hotels, bed and breakfast establishments and guest houses should be challenged to do the same.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Rumpus over police raid on city suburb


BYLINE: Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Cape Town - Police are at the centre of a row about heavy- handed "flash raids" on homes of suspected drug dealers. During the raids, police demolish gates and walls to gain quick entry to houses to take the sleepy occupants by surprise and prevent them from destroying evidence.

Police have defended their "smash-and-grab" tactics, saying the surprise element is vital for the success of the operations. "It takes just a second or two to flush drugs worth thousands of rands down a toilet," said a seasoned narcotic squad detective. 

Police task force members backing detectives in drug raids routinely attach a heavy cable between a truck or armoured vehicle and the security gate or fence of the targeted house. They then drive off at speed, forcing open the gates.

But in some cases sections of walls and even a roof have been pulled down in the process.

In the latest raid at the weekend, a house in Page Street, Woodstock, was extensively damaged when police used this method to smash their way in while the occupants were asleep. They found 26 Mandrax tablets, a quantity of dagga and 18 crack crystals in the house, but their action caused an outcry in the community. Police spokesman Mark Romburgh said the gate and wall at the house, which were pulled down by a Casspir armoured vehicle early on Sunday, were "anyway not in accordance with building regulations because it was built too close to the road".

The raid had been carried out with the necessary search warrants which empowered police to use "required" force, he said. "Experience has taught us that if one knocks at the front door of a suspected drug dealer's house and spends 20 minutes politely requesting access, there is no surprise element and this gives the druglord time to destroy the evidence," he said.

"But notwithstanding the general air of apprehension among residents in the area as a result of intimidation by druglords, the feedback from the community was still overwhelmingly positive." Ron Paschke of the Human Rights Commission said he could not comment on the incident without having all the facts. The commission had not had any complaints about the police action, he said. In terms of the Criminal Procedure Act, there were certain circumstances under which police did not require a warrant to search premises. These were if there was a reasonable suspicion a person in a house had committed an offence.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Rasool gets tough on health


BYLINE: Jenny Viall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - The entire primary health system in the Western Cape, complaints about uncaring health workers and the ambulance service are to be probed by the team investigating the wheelbarrow death in Khayelitsha.

This was announced today by Western Cape Health Minister Ebrahim Rasool, who said he was extending the brief of the team appointed to look into the death of Thobeka Madayi.

Last month, the Cape Argus reported the death of Mrs Madayi in a wheelbarrow after she was turned away from the Nolungile community health centre in Khayelitsha. 

Her desperate husband, Vuyani Magazi, took his terminally ill wife to the clinic after being told no ambulance was available. When he arrived, staff told him they were closing and it might be quicker to get an ambulance from another clinic.

Mrs Madayi died in the street on the way to the second clinic. The report prompted a huge response from readers, who made further allegations about the uncaring attitude of health workers.

The report also highlighted the crisis at clinics and in the ambulance service.

Mr Rasool said he was giving the team more time to look into broader problems in primary health care in the Western Cape. Its report would have "a profound influence" on the provincial health system.

He had given the team until June 13 to report back and had broadened its terms of reference to enable it to identify other factors affecting primary health care delivery. The team would also investigate complaints directed at the health department.

The Deputy Speaker of the provincial parliament, Mampe Ramotsamai, heads the team and the members are John Frankish, Lynne Brown and Gabrielle Urgoiti.

Mr Rasool has briefed the team to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death of Mrs Madayi, and the reasons for the poor quality of care at community health centres in the metropole.

The brief includes questions of negligence, the lack of a caring attitude and possible disciplinary measures.

The team has also been asked to make recommendations on corrective measures, ways to improve the quality of care and staff morale at community health centres and methods of improving the management and motivation of staff.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Namibia;
Swapo's administration in a shambles


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Windhoek - Namibia's ruling party, Swapo, does not have a proper list of its own members and admits to being "administratively and technically weak".

This is revealed in the Central Committee's report to the recently completed party Congress. The report states somewhat bluntly: "No party can call itself a political party without a list of its members. The Secretariat must employ all the resources at its disposal to commence immediately with the compilation of a Party Membership register." 

The Central Committee urges that a computer database be used to register members efficiently.

Members have also been called on to pay 0,1 per cent of their salaries to the party, however the report states that "few members have been paying their membership due or contributing 0,1 per cent of their salaries".

The two organisations affiliated to Swapo - the National Union of Namibian Workers and Nanso (affiliated) - have also never paid their affiliation fees.

The report recommends that in future membership fees should be collected through sections and branches and that every full-time employed member of the party pay 1 per cent of their monthly salary to the party.

Despite the claims that party businesses are now worth N$150 million, the report states that "today the only assured source of income for the party are newly-established companies which did not reach the break-even stage".

The report paints a bleak picture of the party's finances and internal organisation stating that the party "remains administratively and technically weak".

This is in contrast to a rather rosy section of the report on Swapo companies which claims that they have increased the value of their assets sevenfold since independence.

However, the report holds out the hope that the party will become financially stable through the funding of political parties approved by the National Assembly .

Under the new funding arrangements the party is set to receive nearly N$6 million of taxpayers' money.

Despite the failure to raise funds through a paid-up membership, the report maintains that the party managed to pay its staff between 1993-1997 and fund national and regional election campaigns.

During the last financial year the party spent N$2 391 971 and received N$2 555 782. No further details are given about the nature of the expenditure or income.

The report concedes that a high turnover of party employees has "dealt a blow to the administrative efficiency of the party. The 'flight' of staff to the Government and private sector is put down to the fact that the party "could not afford the most basic conditions of service such as monthly salary, medical scheme and pension ..."

"The main reason why these committed cadres have left the party or are unavailable for the work for the party as full- time functionaries is attributable to the total absence of a scheme of employment."

The report says that "as long as this state of affairs is allowed to continue working for the party will remain unattractive as it offers no material benefits".

As a remedy the CC recommends the introduction of contracts, job descriptions, and proper conditions of employment including benefits such as pension and medical aid.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Namibia;
Swapo companies 'worth N$150m'


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Windhoek - Swapo's businesses are worth an estimated N$150 million and are expected to escalate in value to N$250 million by the end of March 1998, according to a Central Committee report tabled at the Swapo Congress.

The report says that party assets assigned for business amounted to just under N$20 million in 1990. The more than sevenfold increase is attributed to the efficient management of party assets and "tremendous added value". 

The CC report also claims that the party has created employment for more than 5 000 Namibians through its business ventures and that another 4 500 new jobs are in the pipeline. "Many foreign investors are knocking on our doors for joint ventures," the CC report adds

It is also revealed that Swapo has been investing in "strategic economic sectors" in two neighbouring states. Although the countries are not specified it is believed that they are Zimbabwe and Angola.

The report recommends that all the party's businesses contribute monthly to a trust through which money could be disbursed to the party and to invest in "healthy portfolios" to ensure maximum returns.

Swapo has established four main business arms - Kalahari Holdings (a 100 per cent holding company of Swapo), Zebra Holdings (100 per cent of shares owned by Swapo), Guinas Investments (a non-active investing company with 100 per cent of its shares owned by Swapo) and Namib Graphics ( a printing company wholly owned by Swapo).

Kalahari Holdings has a number of subsidiaries which include Namib Contract Haulage and New Dawn Video.

The report alludes to problems concerning the party's entry into the business world, stating that some party members perceive that "the incompetent, undisciplined and lazy should find employment in the party business entities.

"Such people completely ignore the professional and businesses ethics and any control is construed to being victimisation, political, nepotism, etc.

The attitude often expressed is that 'since the company belongs to the Party, it belongs to nobody' and as such warrants a free for all."

The report complains that any achievement by the Swapo businesses is regarded as resulting more from Government favouritism rather than hard work.

Swapo also runs two NGOs - the Centre for Resource Transformation (CERET) and the Swapo Veterans' Trust.

The central committee proposed that CERET be assigned to the Swapo Youth League, while the Veterans Trust already falls under the Elders' Council.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Botswana;
Botswana to assess Okavango enviro report


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Windhoek - The environmental study on the proposed pipeline linking Namibia's central areas to the Okavango river will be submitted to the Botswanan government for review before the next stage of detailed fieldwork is carried out.

The Botswanan government has said it would only be able to take a stance on Namibia's plans to draw up to 20 million cubic meters of water each year from the shared river once the entire feasibility study had been completed.

The final impact assessment statement is expected to be completed in the next three months. According to a report compiled by Water Transfer Consultants following meetings held in Botswana between Namibian Water Affairs officials and local communities, Botswana's main concern appeared to be the effect the pipeline plan would have on the Okavango Delta. 

The recently completed study indicated that Namibia's plans to draw water from the Okavango river would have an insignificant effect on the delta.

During consultations with Namibian water authorities at Shakawe in Botswana community leaders said the delta was already drying up. They feared that if Namibia was allowed to draw water from the Okavango, the people and animals of the delta would perish.

They said they saw no reason why they should allow Namibia to pump water from the delta while they had rejected a similar proposal by their government earlier.

Questions also arose during the consultations over whether Namibia had exhausted all potential aquifers or even considered the desalination of sea water.

Department of Water Affairs deputy permanent secretary Richard Fry explained during the meetings that getting water from the sea would be far more expensive for Namibia compared to tapping water from the Okavango.

However, he said more details would be provided after the environmental studies had been completed.

It has also been estimated that future water demand in Namibia will grow from about 295 million cubic meters a year in 1995 to about 600 million in the year 2020, making it imperative for Namibia to seek other alternative sources.

At a second meeting at Gumare, similar concerns to those raised at Shakawe on the possibility of the delta drying up were raised.

At Maun, the consensus among the local community was that consultations should take place after the feasibility study was completed and submitted to the authorities.

The Namibian Government is expected to make a decision soon with regards its approach towards the pipeline plan after reviewing the environmental impact study.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Air Namibia studying aircraft options


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Windhoek - Transnamib's Board of Directors is expected to make a decision soon on the type of aircraft Air Namibia will buy to replace its long-haul Boeing 747 SP.

The decision was originally expected to have been taken at a Board meeting scheduled for Friday. 

The meeting has, however, been postponed to next week Friday.

Air Namibia acting managing director Johannes Gawaxab said recently that the national carrier was close to finalising the acquisition of the replacement for the 747 SP which services the airline's intercontinental routes.

Gawaxab said the national carrier was looking at a cost- effective aircraft although he could not say what types of plane had been short-listed as possible replacements.

The final decision was entirely in the Board's hands, he added. However, sources have indicated that the Boeing 777-200 and Airbus 340 are among the hot favourites.

Meanwhile, Air Namibia, which is involved in negotiations with German carrier Lufthansa on a possible partnership agreement, has completed a feasibility study on the possibility of a Windhoek to New York flight.

According to Gawaxab, all the national carrier now had to do was to find a strategic alliance partner for the route.

And, if all goes according to plan, Air Namibia could be flying to New York sometime between June and December next year.
