Africa News


June 3, 1997


Sierra Leone;
An Update on the Coup in Sierra Leone


BYLINE: Kakuna Kerina, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

New York - The following is background information on recent developments in Sierra Leone following the military coup.

JUNE 2, 1997: The Sierra Leone army is still headquartered at Cockrill Defense Headquarters in the Aberdeen area. Unconfirmed reports state that the Nigerian negotiation team offered each of the Sierra Leone coup organizers, at an 8 p.m. meeting on June 1, 1997, financial support (of US$10,000, a house) and asylum in Nigeria if they agreed to leave the country.

Revolutionary United Front (RUF) representative Colonel Desmond refused to accept the terms and immediately went on the air via FM 99.9 (SBLS) to announce the military's planned 27-member National Ruling Council (NRC) government comprised of military officers, six RUF members, and two civilians. The NRC includes President Tejan Kabbah's former Secretary S.A.P. Bayoh, his former Chief of Army Staff Brigadier Hassan Conteh, and his former Chief of Defense Staff Brigadier Max Kanga. Charles Margai, the second civilian announced on the NRC list reportedly refused to accept the position and is now in hiding. RUF leader Foday Sankoh is slated as Vice President in NRC. 

Immediately after the RUF radio announcement, the Nigerian negotiating team broke off talks and returned to their base at Bintumani Hotel giving the Sierra Leone army and RUF an ultimatum to decide by 12 am on June 2, 1997 as to whether they would accept the proposed offer. As of the deadline, no talks have taken place between the Nigierian negotiators and the coup leaders.

Extensive firing at the Mami Yoko Hotel, which is secured by United States marines and Nigerian soldiers, was reported during the evening of June 1 after a group of Sierra Leone uniformed entered the hotel premises and started threatening Nigerian soldiers and civilians. Prior to this, U.S. boats and marines were still landing at the Mami Yoko Hotel to maintain security and facilitate the evacuation of remaining U.S. citizens. Non-governmental organization employees, citizens from neighboring African countries, and some Lebanese citizens were also being transported to Conakry, Guinea, by what is believed to be a private boat located behind Nigerian gunboats in the Lagonda area.

In the morning hours of June 2, Nigerian gunboats retaliated by firing from their location at the Lagonda area at the Cockril Defense Force army base. A British military advisor to the Sierra Leone army was wounded in the Lagonda shootout and as of late afternoon the death toll had reached 10 army casualties.

In the early afternoon of June 2, the Sierra Leone army commenced firing at the Bintumani Hotel where the ECOMOG troops and the Nigerian negotiating team are based. ECOMOG has also taken control of the OAU Village residential area, an affluent nieghborhood where Lebanese, former government ministers, and diplomats were living. ECOMOG has secured the area and is restricting access to it because there is a route through the neighborhood to the peninsula.

Thousands of individuals demonstrated on June 2 in support of the army marched from Eastern Freetown starting in the Up Gun Turntable area towards the center of the city and through to the National stadium on Savage Street. It is believed that the army organized local youth and RUF soldiers in plainclothes to demonstrate and express their solidarity with the the coup organizers.

Approaching from Hastings Air Field, east of Freetown, soldiers looted the Sierra Leone Port Authority after demanding that the local security force leave the area. The looted goods were loaded and transported to Hastings Air Field where it is believed soldiers could easily enter the bush if a full-scale military intervention occurs.

The main hospital is closed because all the medical supplies have been looted and medical personnel refuse to go to work because of the security crisis.

As of early evening June 2, the Mami Yoko Hotel was on fire with occupants hiding out in the basement.

The information contained in this alert update is the sole responsibility of CPJ. In citing this material for broadcast or publication, please credit CPJ. For further information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj.org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Congo (Kinshasa);
Amnesty Calls for Rights in Congo


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

London - Democratic Republic of Congo: Mineral wealth should not overshadow country's shameful human rights record

Amnesty International is urging African leaders -- who are meeting at an Organization of African Unity (OAU) summit in Harare -- to demand that President Laurent Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo (formerly Zaire) investigates the latest massacre in his country.

As many as 123 unarmed civilians were reportedly gunned down on 26 May by members of President Kabila's new army in South-Kivu region's Uvira town.

"President Kabila should immediately initiate an independent and impartial inquiry into the massacre and bring to justice any soldiers found responsible," Amnesty International said today. "We are appealing to African leaders to show at the OAU summit that the safety and physical integrity of human beings in ex-Zaire are more important than the country's mineral wealth." 

Sources in Uvira have informed Amnesty International that about 10 people were shot dead on the night of 25 to 26 May by gunmen believed to be members of the Alliance des forces de(/)mocratiques pour la libe(/)ration du Congo-Zaire (AFDL), Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire. On 26 May several hundred people gathered in Uvira town to demonstrate against these and other killings by the AFDL in and around Uvira.

Demonstrators, apparently carrying the bodies of the people killed the previous night, came from Kasenga, Kabindula and other localities of Uvira. The demonstrators met up at Kakungwe where they were reportedly intercepted by members of the AFDL. One soldier is said to have talked to his superiors on radio and soon after, the soldiers opened fire, killing as many as 123 demonstrators. The Uvira District Commissioner (Commissaire de zone) was reportedly shot and wounded in the incident. The circumstances are however unclear. He is reportedly hospitalized at Roi Khaled Hospital in the Burundian capital, Bujumbura.

Amnesty International is concerned that many world leaders have chosen to ignore the AFDL's shameful human rights record. Most of them have pledged support to rebuild the shattered infrastructure of ex- Zaire, but virtually none have committed themselves to help the country's new leaders improve their human rights record.

"In the wake of the military victory of Laurent Kabila and his forces, there has been an eagerness to welcome the new government and to downplay widespread human rights violations," Amnesty International said.

Laurent Kabila and the AFDL leadership have persistently denied reports of massacres by the AFDL, yet they have refused to accept independent and impartial inquiries. At the start of May 1997 they refused to allow a United Nations (UN) mission led by Roberto Garreton, the UN Special Rapporteur on (ex-) Zaire, to investigate reports of widespread massacres and other human rights crimes committed in eastern Zaire by the AFDL and other forces. After the UN Security Council expressed at the end of May 1997 concern at massacres of Hutu refugees by the AFDL, Kabila's government reportedly said in an official statement, "These so-called continuing massacres of refugees are defamatory and invented by those who failed to prevent the fall of the dictatorial regime in our country".

"Kabila cannot be allowed to hide behind the dark veil of the very poor human rights record of former President Mobutu Sese Seko," Amnesty International said.

"Gross human rights violations by Mobutu's forces cannot serve as an excuse for the AFDL and its allies to massacre thousands of unarmed refugees and ex-Zairian civilians with impunity. A population which has suffered human rights abuses for decades deserves and must expect better."

This massacre is the latest in a series of deliberate and arbitrary killings by the Tutsi-dominated AFDL since October 1996 when they launched an attack against forces of former President Mobutu Sese Seko. Thousands of unarmed civilians, mostly Rwandese Hutu refugees and (ex-) Zairian Hutu, are reported to have been deliberately and arbitrarily killed. Congolese (ex-Zairians) from other ethnic groups suspected or known to be sympathetic to the Hutu and others thought to be hostile to the Tutsi have also been targeted.

Around Uvira, tensions between the AFDL and members of the Vira, Bembe and Fulero ethnic groups considered to be opposed to Tutsi domination have been high. The AFDL is reported to have summarily executed members of these ethnic groups in South-Kivu on suspicion of belonging to armed groups opposed to the AFDL.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


Kenya;
Amnesty Criticizes Violent Break-Up of Kenya Rally


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

London - Amnesty International expressed grave concern at the use of excessive force by Kenyan security force personnel in breaking up a rally in Uhuru Park, Nairobi, earlier today, and called for the authorities to exercise restraint in dealing with any future rallies.

Several thousand people were peacefully being led in prayers by Bishop Njoya in the park when police and paramilitary forces fired teargas into the crowd without warning and violently dispersed those gathered. During subsequent disturbances in central Nairobi, police and General Services Unit (GSU) personnel arbitrarily beat bystanders as well as those involved in demonstrations and looting. 

"The teargassing and beatings meted out to peaceful protesters was unwarranted and excessive, particularly since the law under which the government declared the meeting illegal contravenes international human rights standards which Kenya has ratified," said an Amnesty spokesperson.

A high level Amnesty International delegation, led by Secretary General Pierre Sane, is due to arrive in the country on Sunday to launch its Human Rights Manifesto for Kenya, and meet with representatives of the government, political parties, non-governmental organizations and religious leaders.

The manifesto sets out reforms essential to improving human rights, including the repeal of legislation such as the Public Order Act, which was invoked by the authorities to prevent the meeting taking place, and calls on the government to bring Kenyan legislation into line with international standards.

"Kenya has ratified the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which protect the right to freedom of association denied today," the spokesperson added. "This latest incident shows the importance of the reforms outlined in our manifesto in ensuring that the fundamental rights of all Kenyans are protected in the future."

"The authorities should set up a prompt and impartial investigation into today's events, ensure that those responsible for using excessive force are brought to justice, and that the security forces follow international guidelines when dealing with future rallies."

May 30, 1997

For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44-71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/

Africa News


June 3, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Evacuates 1,232 from Freetown


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers on Sierra Leone by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns at the Department's daily briefing June 3.

QUESTION: Nick, can you bring us up to date on Sierra Leone?

MR. BURNS: I would be glad to, yes. First of all, we continue to pay a lot of attention to the situation in Freetown. It is quite worrisome. 

Today, as you know, the United States completed a third evacuation of 12 Americans and approximately 1,220 other nationals this morning from Freetown; so, almost 1,200 - 1,232, approximate, people came out this morning from - to the Kearsarge. All evacuees were taken there. They will be flown to Conakry in Guinea today and tomorrow. That brings the combined total of individuals evacuated by the Kearsarge, by the United States since Friday, to approximately 2,530 people and that includes 440 Americans.

Now, we do not anticipate any further evacuation from Freetown because we think we have got all the Americans out who want to come out. There may be a couple of Americans left who absolutely insist on staying. We cannot force people to leave, although we strongly encourage all Americans to leave and we strongly encourage all Americans not to travel to Sierra Leone given the continued fighting there.

As you know, the effort to bring about a peaceful resolution of this conflict has not succeeded. The United States is using our diplomatic skills and capacity to urge the coup leaders to quit and to restore to power the democratically elected government of Sierra Leone. We are working with a number of countries on that. We will continue to keep this situation under close review. Our ambassador, Ambassador Hirsch, and his DCM will be in Conakry in Guinea for the time being, watching out for American interests and helping those Americans who are coming out of Sierra Leone.

QUESTION: The reports we're getting seem to indicate that the Nigerians are getting the worst part of the battle and have, in fact, been beaten back. Is that what you hear?

MR. BURNS: Well, I think the official rationale -- as John has explained it to you over the last couple of days -- of the Nigerian Government is that their forces are there to restore - maintain order.

Now, obviously, there has been some fighting between the Nigerians and the rebels. Our position is that we think there ought to be a peaceful resolution here, but the end result should be that the rebels step down and that they give up their fight to control the government by dictatorial means and they restore the democratically elected president of Sierra Leone.

QUESTION: There is at least one report that hundreds of Nigerian troops have been captured and are being used as shields by the rebels or the coup forces. Do you have any knowledge of that?

MR. BURNS: Well, since we have evacuated our embassy staff and our ambassador, we are not in a position to confirm those reports, but we have seen those same reports. Betsy?

QUESTION: Nick, do you have any knowledge of relief workers being held hostage?

MR. BURNS: I'm looking at John because John, as you know, has been here. I haven't heard either. Have not heard anything about that.

QUESTION: NBC had heard that some church workers were being held hostage. I don't think it was in Freetown. It was out in the countryside.

MR. BURNS: Just haven't heard anything about that. Yes?

QUESTION: There are reports that yesterday's attack was meant to prepare for a more comprehensive one. What is the U.S. response to that? Do we support the more comprehensive attack?

MR. BURNS: Attack by the?

QUESTION: Nigerians. The firing of shells yesterday by the Nigerians.

MR. BURNS: We support a restoration of the civilian government. We hope that that can be produced by negotiations with the rebels. We have not taken a position of direct support for the Nigerians, but we do support the ambition, the objective that the rebels cannot win.

They cannot succeed in overthrowing a democratically elected government and installing in its place a bunch of military officers who don't know how to run a country, who haven't been given that mandate by the people of Sierra Leone. They ought to step down. That's our position.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 3, 1997


South Africa;
Suffer the little children ...


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Cape Town - When the Cape Argus team visited 15-year-old Nathan Ludick at his modest Philippi home, we found him playing outside with his younger brother and sister.

He looked every bit the protective older brother looking after his siblings.

Difficult to imagine, then, that only a week ago he had never before laid eyes on his younger brother and sister. He is only now beginning to get to know them. 

What makes this family's story different from others is that Nathan left home at the age of eight and grew up on the streets of central Cape Town. Living a life of petty crime, his situation could so easily have had disastrous consequences.

Last week, his life took a new turn when he returned home.

For Nathan, his cloud seems to have a silver lining and for this new beginning he has Linda Ntshinga and the Homestead programme to thank.

Linda is a street worker on a programme called Masithethe (let us speak), aimed at rehabilitating street kids and getting them to return home.

Since the Masithethe programme was launched on April 1, Linda has managed to get Nathan and six other children off the streets and back to their homes. He also has interviewed 69 new children. Of these, 38 were new to the streets, 23 had been attending the Yizani Drop-Inn Centre and eight were runaways from existing Homestead programmes.

Linda, a 24-year-old SACS matriculant, and the co-ordinator of Yizani, and Shane Egypt are entrusted with making Masithethe a success.

It is his job to patrol the streets, making contact with the children and establishing which ones are new arrivals. He has to gain their trust and try to refer them to Yizani, where many street kids come for meals and a little much-needed attention.

Linda then tries to make contact with the street kids' families to see what the home environment is, with a view to getting them off the streets and back home.

It is a hard and thankless job, but Linda feels the reward comes when he is successful with children like Nathan.

Nathan's story is similar to that of many others out on the streets.

Born in De Doorns, he grew up in Belhar where he got along well with his friends and regularly attended school. Then his family moved to Philippi and he started mixing with the wrong crowd. He got caught up in petty crime, later refusing to attend school.

One day, seven years ago, Nathan and some friends took the train to Mitchell's Plain. When they tried to return home to Philippi, they found they had caught an express train which took them straight to Cape Town.

That day was the last time Nathan saw his home.

He met up with another group of friends in Cape Town and started a life of crime on the streets, where he was influenced by other streetwise kids. He used to sleep in shop doorways and begged for food and money. To survive the cold, he sniffed glue and thinners regularly and got involved with a group who stabbed and robbed people in the city centre.

He continued this lifestyle for several years, but an incident two weeks ago made him change his ways and leave his life on the street - hopefully for good.

The leader of the group with which Nathan moved around was shot and killed.

With Linda's help, Nathan returned home and is now back "forever" and about to start working with his father.

He says his father used to drink, but has since stopped. He feels things at home are "going well" and he does not want to return to the streets.

His wish for the future is simple: "I am going to work and save money. I want to be a father of the house. I feel happy here."

I met Linda and Shane at the Yizani Drop-Inn Centre, bustling with destitute street kids who were looking for a hot meal and a shower. The kids do not stay at Yizani, but go there as a stopover before returning to the streets.

Once the kids come to Yizani, Shane and Linda try to motivate them to attend formal programmes and get them to sleep at Homestead's shelters. They then try to establish contact with the families.

Linda says: "Masithethe's main objective is to return children to their communities, so that they do not get too streetwise. I keep in contact with the kids to establish which ones are new. I try to build trust between me and them and then try to refer them to formal programmes."

What makes the Masithethe programme different from others is that it does not stop once the kids return home. Linda and Shane try to network with community structures, such as soccer clubs, to try and get the children to fit in. They do follow-up visits and take food parcels to the families.

Poverty is the umbrella cause. In some cases, there is a total breakdown of family structures and children are left to their own devices.

The outlook for street kids is bleak in most cases, but Linda is the perfect candidate to work with these kids, and he knows the importance of his job.

"I grew up in the communities they come from, I am ploughing back what I have got from the community. It is a great job," says Linda.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 4, 1997


South Africa;
Case thrown out because blind man cannot identify assailants


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Nelspruit - Six policemen accused of beating a man and blinding him five years ago were found innocent by the Nelspruit Regional Court on Monday because the man was unable to identify them in court.

The court also found the policemen innocent after a state witness failed to testify on Monday.

Magistrate Albertus Le Roux said that because state witness, John Mashinini, did not testify, the court did not have enough evidence to sentence the suspects. 

He said the complainant, Prince Ngomane (31) also could not identify the people who assaulted him because he was now blind.

During his testimony two weeks ago, Ngomane alleged that he was arrested without explanation on April 22,1992, after police mistakenly assumed that he had assaulted Constable Sydney Dibakoane.

Ngomane testified that he was taken to Hazyview Police Station where Dibakoane allegedly beat him on the face and blinded him in his left eye. He added that Constable Anton Jan van Dort, Jakobus Petrus Mosterd, Albert Madala Msimango and Sergeant Coenraad van der Merwe had also assaulted him

"On arrival, I asked Dibakoane why I was arrested but instead he grabbed me by my clothes, slapped me on the face and punched me in my eye, which closed," Ngomane had testified.

Sergeant Emmanuel Banda confirmed some of Ngomane's story and told the court that he found Ngomane in a holding cell even though he was not on the prison register.

"When I found out that he was injured, I organised for him to be taken to hospital and also told Constable Msimango to release him at once," Sgt. Banda said.

The six officers were also accused of stealing R75 from Ngomane but were found not-guilty.

"It is hard to sentence these six people because Ngomane could not identify the people who really assaulted him" said Magistrate Le Roux.


LOAD-DATE: June 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Nigeria;
Three People Reported Killed In Tank Explosion


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A massive explosion On Friday rocked a Jamaican registered oil tanker undergoing repairs at the Apapa ports in Lagos resulting in three people killed, according initial reports.

The chairman of Lagos ports security, Navy Captain Shuaibu Amodu, blamed the explosion on a gas cylinder being used for welding job on the ship, al-Zainab, docked at the Commodore anchorage. The vessel was set alight.

He said the blast was under investigation to determine casualty and whether safety measures were breached.

The ship, which was severely damaged was saved from total destruction by the timely arrival of men of the ports fire service.

Some terrified Lagos residents suspected the explosion was a continuation of the several bomb blasts that had rocked the city in the recent past.

Nigeria has witnessed eight bomb explosions in as many months, six of which in Lagos and all but one targeted against the military.

The military government has blamed the country's pro-democracy groups for the terrorist attacks, a charge denied by the groups.

Sixteen people, including exiled Nigerian literature Nobel Prize laureate, Wole Soyinka, have been charged with the bombings.

June 6, 1997


Uganda;
Army To Guard Wildlife In National Park


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The Uganda Peoples Defence Forces are training an anti poaching squad to fight poaching and insecurity in Murchison Falls National Park.

The state-owned New Vision newspaper said Friday it has learnt that the decision has been endorsed by the German Development Agency (GTZ), which is funding the 15.5-million-U.S.-dollar project to build roads, staff houses, park headquarters, bridges and other infrastructure in the 3,840 square miles (6,144 sq Km) game park. 

The two-year project began last year. The paper said the UPDF and the Uganda Wildlife Authority had confirmed the new arrangement. But the GTZ representative in Uganda, Luecke Irmgard, was not available for comment.

"Training of our rangers by the army began a few weeks ago. This came due to fears of landmines in Murchison Falls Park.

This has been introduced as a new and temporary component", the Park's executive director, Dr Eric Edroma told The New Vision on Thursday.

83 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Info Ministers To Discuss PANA & Radio


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The privatization of the Pan African News Agency and the proposed setting up of a radio station for the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) will be the major issues at a conference of African information ministers to be held in Cairo from June 17 to 19.

OAU spokesman Ibrahim Dagash told the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency, Ziana, in Harare on Friday the conference would be preceded by a one-day session of the Inter-governmental Council for Communication in Africa (ICC) on June 16.

The last ICC conference was held in Sun City, South Africa, in October 1994. 

"Major issues which will dominate debate will be the ICC programme of action for 1997-99, privatization of the Pan African News Agency (PANA) and the setting up of an OAU radio broadcasting station," said Dagash.

OAU, which established PANA in 1979 as its print media agency, now intends to establish radio transmission to broadcast programmes that would be called "Voice Of Africa".

"Such a project is very important at the moment because the OAU is trying to be very relevant and to be known to the ordinary African," said Dagash.

"The radio, we believe, is still the most far-reaching medium accessible to the African majority."

"We have had a recording studio in Ethiopia since 1990," said Dagash. "It is a radio recording studio which we need to upgrade into a radio broadcast station which will transmit our programmes throughout Africa."

On PANA, Dagash said plans to privatize the cash-strapped agency by December this year have firmed.

He said, however, that member countries had to pay off arrears totalling 40 million U.S. dollars first before the exercise could be effected. But the OAU needs only 4.7 million U.S dollars to clear the debts of the agency, he said.

If a member country paid a certain percentage of its arrears, the outstanding amount would be written off.

"Privatization of PANA is due by December this year," said Dagash. "After that member states will be relieved of paying contributions to the agency as it will be functioning on commercial basis without losing its African character.

If the members fail to pay the required 4.7 million dollars, this will eventually lead to the death of the agency," he warned.

PANA, which was established in 1979 to counter negative publicity of Africa by western agencies, started operating in 1983.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Declares French A Compulsory Language


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's federal education ministry has declared that French will be a compulsory subject in all schools starting from the next academic year.

The Ministry's Director-General Ibrahim Hashim, said Thursday while receiving a French delegation in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, the military government would provide adequate number of teachers for the programme. 

There are an estimated 9,000 French language teachers in Nigeria, but some 22,000 are needed, the education official said.

Hashim said France have agreed to grant scholarship to Nigerians annually for intensive French language study in Paris.

Nigeria, a former British colony, and African's most populous nations with more than 100 million people, shares border with several former French colonies.

Nigerian Head of State Gen. Sani Abacha has personally advocated french as the second official language for Nigeria after attending the last Franco-African conference in 1996.

Nigeria remains France's major trading partner despite the existence of subdued rivalry between Abuja and Paris for political influence in West Africa.

Political observers say nigeria's new fraternity with France could be a response to its isolation from the United States and other Western nations over democracy and human rights issues.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


85 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Congo (Kinshasa);
Congolese Franc To Be Introduced In Kinshasa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

KINSHASA, Congo (PANA) - Congo's central bank has said that large quantities of the country's new currency, the Congolese franc, has arrived at its premises in 50 and 100 franc notes.

The currency, which will replace the new Zaire which circulated under the administration of Mobutu Sese Seko, will be put in circulation as soon as the 1 franc, 10 centime and 50 centime coins are minted by l'Hotel des Monnaies in Kinshasa, the Bank of Congo said. 

The new franc will be backed by the country's gold reserve, the United States dollar and the South African rand.

It said Thursday that the new currency will exchange at 2.50 francs to the dollar.

Introduction of the new currency was announced on May 29 by Congolese President Laurent Kabila, when he was sworn in at the Supreme Court.

"We will substitute the new zaire with a healthy and strong Congolese franc," he said.

The former Congolese franc disappeared following the monetary reform of June 24, 1967. This gave birth to the zaire which was initially valued at one zaire to two U.S. dollars. But the zaire plummeted in value leading to the new zaire in 1993.

On Tuesday in Kinshasa, the new zaire was exchanging at the rate of 140,000 to the greenback.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


86 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigeria In Crucial World Cup Tie Against Kenya


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's Super Eagles paid dearly for, perhaps underestimating their Kenyan opponents when both countries met almost six months ago in an African group one qualification match for the World Cup in France 1998.

In that match, the Harambee Stars stunned the Olympic Champions and forced them to a goalless draw.

With that bitter lesson from lowly-rated Kenya, soccer fans in Lagos warn that the Kenyans, fresh from a tour in Germany, would be no pushover in the crucial second leg match Saturday in Lagos.

Nigerians cannot forget a 1977 nightmare, when the Eagles conceded an own goal against Tunisia in Lagos that sent their country out of the World Cup in Argentina. 

Now, the Eagles are in a similar circumstance. They require only a win to guarantee their second World Cup appearance after an impressive performance in U.S.A. '94.

However, from all indications, Nigeria's preparations for Saturday's encounter has been anything but smooth, at least not with the now familiar practice of players arriving late to camp.

Despite adequate notice not all the invited players made it to the national camp in the eastern city of Enugu by Thursday, when the team was due in Lagos for the last work out.

After prolonged controversy, Enugu was literally imposed on the Eagles' new French technical adviser, Phillipe Trousier, who had preferred Cote d'Ivoire. It was to Cote d'Ivoire that he took his team to prepare for the two previous group matches against Guinea in Lagos and Burkina Faso in Ouagadougou.

However Troussier, who is barely three months on the 10,000-U.S.- dollar a month job, has not known any peace for winning a scrappy 2-1 victory in both matches.

Since then, criticism has poured in from Nigerian soccer fans to sports writers and administrators. The debate has been such that there have been calls for the termination of his six-month contract.

Troussier did not help matters by overstaying in a foreign trip, perhaps in protest. When he finally returned, the national camp was not full enough for any full-scale training.

Such was the level of preparation that a disappointed sports minister, Jim Nwobodo, lambasted the players when he visited the Enugu camp to meet only about 15 of the invited 22 players.

To add to the confusion, there was a report of the planned visit of Clemens Westerhof, the Eagles' erstwhile Dutch handler. He was said to be desperately keen to retrieve the job he abandoned three years ago.

There was also considerable talk that Frenchman Claude Le Roy was also gunning for the coaching job. He was interviewed before Troussier was chosen in February after Johannes Bonfrere, from the Netherlands, abandoned Nigeria for Qatar.

Bonfrere had taken Nigeria to win Africa's first Olympic soccer gold in 1996 before quitting unceremoniously alleged disagreement with Nigerian sports authorities.

However, Nigerians are not new to what sports enthusiasts here call "shoddy preparations."

They point to the fact that many had written off the Eagles, just before they won the Africa Nations Cup in Tunisia, 1994. The same team went on to put up a superlative performance at U.S.A. '94.

However, sports commentators warn that no two matches are the same: The fact that Nigeria got away with inadequate preparation in 1994 is no guarantee it would repeat the same feat three years later.

This is in view of the fact that the Kenyans, bristling with confidence, have bolstered their morale with the prompt announcement of their squad for the match.

The Harambee Stars' German handler, Reinhardt Fabisch, has also been working quietly to transform the Kenyan squad, a feat that has earned him an extension of his contract.

Kenyan confidence also stems from the fact that they are the side that have exacted a point from the Eagles in the March to France '98.

Kenya's victory over Guinea, which counts as an advantage to the Eagles, led to the reported disbandment of the Sylli Nationale, the Guinean squad.

Players to watch in the Kenyan line-up include Musa Otieno and Mike Okoth, a hat-trick hero in their dramatic 4-3 victory over Burkina Faso in April.

Nigeria's four-goal hero, Daniel Amokachi has, however assured that there is no cause for alarm. He says the Kenyans won't pose a threat to the Eagles.

Team skipper Uche Okechukwu also says the Eagles are aware of the importance of the match to the country's qualification for the World Cup finals. One commentator has said only an outright victory in Lagos that will make the Eagles' last group match against Guinea in Conakry a formality, would be good enough for Nigerians.

"We will do our best," Okechukwu said.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sierra Leone;
West African Bolsters Its Position in Sierra Leone


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Maj. Gen. Victor Malu, commander of the West African Peace Keeping Force in Liberia (Ecomog), said Thursday that a planned military action to reverse the May 25 coup in Sierra Leone had not started.

"We had some skirmishes which we undertook just to protect ourselves," he said.

He was speaking to journalists on arrival Thursday in Lagos for consultations with Nigerian authorities on the situation in Sierra Leone. 

"We were fired upon and we had to return fire and in the course of that we sustained some casualties," he said.

He declined to elaborate, although other reports had put the death toll from Monday's exchange of gunfire at between 50 and 80 with several others injured.

Malu is also in charge of a battalion of Nigerian troops and a team of military advisers in Sierra Leone under a military pact between both countries.

The pact was in effect before the coup led by Maj. Johnny Koromah and his colleagues in the of the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council.

The putsch has been roundly condemned by the international community, including the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity.

Malu denied another report which said some 300 Nigerian soldiers were held hostage by the coup leaders.

He also said there was not need to panic over the non-evacuation of Nigerians from Sierra Leone.

On the movement of troops from Liberia to Sierra Leone, Malu said: "I can't afford to substantially deploy my men to Sierra Leone, very few and essential few have been moved to Sierra Leone."

He is in Nigeria to confer with the head of state and chairman of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, Sani Abacha. They will discuss action to take in restoring democracy in Sierra Leone.

Malu said that Ecomog troops in Sierra Leone are consolidating after the cease-fire that followed Monday's exchange of gunfire.

The battle was between Ecomog troops in Freetown and the combined team of troops loyal to the coup makers and elements of the rebel Revolutionary Unity Front.

Rebel leader Foday Sankoh, who had been in a hotel in Nigeria since March as guest of the military government, has urged his rebels to joint forces with the coup makers.

Malu noted that Ecomog's strong stance had convinced the coup makers on force's resolve to sort out issues militarily if necessary.

He said the West African force, bolstered by reinforcements from Ghana and Guinea, now occupied Sierra Leone's international airport at Lungi, from where it could operate freely to move in logistics and supplies.

The U.N. through its secretary-general Kofi Annan and the O.A.U., which just ended a summit in Harare, Zimbabwe, have given their backing to the Ecowas in its efforts to restore democracy to Sierra Leone, and militarily, if necessary.

Business and Finance;
Boart pumps $3m in water, minerals


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Boart Longyear Africa, a subsidiary of Boart Drilling of Botswana is to invest $ 3.2 m to undertake core, reverse and percussion drilling for water and mineral exploration in Zambia.

This is said in the latest edition of the Zambia Investment Centre News obtained in Ndola yesterday. 

So far, the company has been awarded contracts by Anglo Vaal ($10m) and Cyprus Amax ($ 5m) to handle Konkola North Deep Mining and Kansanshi in Solwezi. The publication says a Zambian couple has invested $1.3 m in the production of paprika for export.

Pinnacle farms ,a subsidiary company of Pinnacle Enterprise, has been given an investment licence by the Centre.

The company plans to cultivate 50 hectares of paprika on a farm in Lusaka's Chikumbi area where at least 52 Zambians will be employed.

And the centre has awarded an investment licence to a Chisamba farm which has gone into a $ 896,270 venture to produce coffee, soyabeans, wheat, maize and vegetables.

June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambia's profile attracts US investors


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia is among 22 countries whose profiles have been published by an American company called Ernst and Young to market their investment opportunities following soaring interest in Africa by investors in the United States.

The information which has been published under a theme: A guide to investing in Africa is accessible on Internet.

According to information obtained from the American Centre in Lusaka, the profiles are aimed at helping potential investors with full information about countries in Africa which are seeking investment. 

This follows the changing political and economic environment in Africa which has resulted in heightened investor interest in the continent, the guide says.

"In recognition to this we have established a communication network which enables our firm to provide service in 51 countries in Africa," it says.

The development comes in the wake of America's changing legislations which have already been ratified by President Bill Clinton to replace aid with investment and trade in Africa.

Investment in Africa will be subject of discussion during the June 20-22 G7 heads of state conference in Denver, Colorado in the US which will be attended by Russia.

Angola, Botswana, Egypt, Gabon, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia and Nigeria are some of the countries whose profiles have been published.

Others are Senegal, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Tunisia, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

The investment profiles will assist potential investors, among other things, in general information, location and size of countries, population, language, religion, climate, principal resources and a brief overview of their economies.

Information on investment incentives including tax rebates, exchange control regulations which were important for the remittance of dividends and expatriate remuneration is also available.

"Ernst and Young practices have cooperated in many cross- border transactions and our clients know that they can expect the same dedicated level of service in African countries to which they have become accustomed in their home countries," the guide says.

Lusaka - Plans to form a Mansa Chamber of Commerce and Industry have reached a final stage, interim secretary Bright Mumba said in Mufulira yesterday.

Mr Mumba said the initial paper work has been completed. 

"We have done most of the paperwork including the constitution and everybody is looking forward to have the chamber working ,"he said.

Mr.

Mumba who owns Luka Mumba hotel said the response to the chamber, the first in Luapula Province, was overwhelming.

He was confident the local business community would support the chamber to enhance development in the province.

He called on the press to educate people in the rural areas on industrial expansion in Zambia.

Mr Mumba appealed to other chambers in the Midlands and on the Copperbelt for assistance to ensure the success of the new organisation.

June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Lusaka management centre to launch masters programmes


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - The Management Development Centre International (MDCI) will launch three masters in business administration (MBA) programmes in Zambia in October.

A statement released to the Times in Lusaka yesterday says that the MDCI, who already work in the Middle East and Europe, will launch the masters programmes in conjunction with the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside of the United Kingdom (UK).

Business professionals will now have an opportunity to earn a top British degree without having to leave Zambia. 

"MDCI will offer the two year programme to students who are able to attend 10 weekend modules in Lusaka.

Top British professors and lecturers will visit Zambia to deliver the modules and to supervise the course work.

"The three programmes which are offered to students who already have a degree, or who can demonstrate that they are experienced senior professionals in their chosen career, are the general MBA, the MBA in information management and the MBA in marketing," the statement says.

Professor Geoffrey Lancaster, who is the UK's leading marketing author, will be in Lusaka to launch the programmes.

The MDCI were encouraged to come to Zambia by Mr Chilao Mutesa who is studying for his PhD at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside.

"It is important that our professional people keep up to date new business developments and skills and I think the MBA will be a most important qualification for a manager to achieve," Mr Mutesa said in Lusaka yesterday.

On June 14, Prof Lancaster, who is chairman of MDCI, and Mr Rob Rice who is managing director of MDCI, will be introduced to potential students at a one-day seminar at Pamodzi Hotel in Lusaka.

The MDCI programmes have been tried and tested in a number of countries with the most recent being Oman where there are more than 100 students, most of whom senior government officials.

Zambia;
UN agency donates dogs to DEC


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) yesterday handed over four sniffer dogs which they have donated to Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC).

UNDP presented the dogs to DEC when they arrived at the Lusaka International Airport from South Africa where they attended training. 

UNDP resident representative Mr Gary Davis said during a brief ceremony that the donation was part of the UN's continued programme to help fight drug trafficking in the region.

"These dogs were trained under the UN drug control programme. It is a continued programme to help fight drug trafficking in the region," Mr Davis said.

DEC commissioner Raphael Mungole said the dogs which will be stationed at Lusaka International Airport together with three Zambian special handlers graduated from South African Police Dog Training School where they attended a three months training in narcotics detection.

Mr Mungole said that plans were underway to acquire more dogs which will be deployed in all border posts. Home Affairs Permanent Secretary Kalombo Mwansa said when he received the dogs on behalf of Government that this was part of capacity and institution building at the DEC.

June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Lusaka drivers won't budge


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - The Union of Bus Drivers and Motor Taxis Association of Zambia (UDMTA) has rejected a Lusaka City Council (LCC) order to shift from their current bus stations to an incomplete site in the light industrial area.

Association chairman Haggai Mambwe said in Lusaka yesterday that the drivers would not move because the council had flouted procedure and the proposed new station was undeveloped.

Mr Mambwe said the LCC should have given his association written notice through a statutory instrument and develop the area before shifting their location. 

He said his association had, in fact, been asking the city council to allocate it the site they are now being forced to go to so that they could develop it from as far back as 1995 but to no avail.

"We are not going to the new station because it has no toilets, water, passenger shelter, security lights, police post and slab concrete nor tarmac," he said.

The LCC using police yesterday ordered drivers who had parked their vehicles at the Mandevu, Chaisa, Chelston, Matero, Lilanda, Kaunda Square, Sekelela and Chunga bus station to move to the new site off Mumbwa road.

Mr Mambwe condemned the use of force as illegal saying police failed to produce a letter empowering them to move all the drivers to the new site. The LCC and United Transport and Taxis Association (UTTA) agreed to temporarily shift the station to the new site to allow contractors working on Freedom way and Lumumba road do their work.

UTTA Lusaka branch administrator Harrison Mukupa emphasised that the new station was a temporary site and advised all drivers to cooperate.

But Mr Mambwe said it was time the council came up with proper plans of developing the city instead of instituting temporary measures which inconvenienced both drivers and passengers.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Science and Health;
Mothers deaths worry State


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - The numbers of pregnancy-related deaths in Zambia are among the highest in the region, Health Minister Katele Kalumba has said.

Dr Kalumba said the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) rose from 118 in 1982 to 940 out of 100,000 live births in 1990 and it was now estimated to be between 650 and 730 out of 100,000 live births.

"Pregnancy-related deaths are on the increase, we have been trying to save the children while losing the mothers. 

These deaths are due to moral, political and scientific problems," he said.

Dr Kalumba said this when he launched the National Family Planning Policy Document at Hotel Intercontinental in Lusaka on Wednesday.

He said unless something was urgently done to arrest the loss of mothers' lives, the nation would have to take the responsibility of many orphans and the creation of more orphan institutions.

Zambia's population growth rate of 3.2 per cent was one of the highest in Africa which meant that the population would be too high for the economy.

The ministry, through the implementing institutions, would ensure the protection of the family planning client against medical malpractices like interference by the providers' personal opinions or preconceived bias.

The ministry would continue to review existing legislation to ensure that health personnel were not at risk, legally or otherwise, in implementing family planning strategies and standards contained in the document.

Dr Kalumba said the purpose of the policy framework strategy and guidelines was to support and guide central hospitals, especially at district level, in the planning and implementation of the family planning component of their reproductive health programme.

He said Government supported the African Charter on Human and People's Rights which stated that the state had a duty to protect and promote moral and traditional values recognised by the community and to protect and assist the family.

"These same values, however, are under threat today from a variety of sources among which are urbanisation, technology, poverty and the HIV/AIDS spread," he said.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
ZAMNET director roasted


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Lusaka - ZAMNET managing director Shila Habeenzu was yesterday grilled by the Bobby Bwalya Unza/CBU Commission of Inquiry where he failed to explain why the two chief executives held personal shares in the company.

Mr Habeenzu, 37, of Chamba Valley fumbled and gave contradictory statements over why ZAMNET shares were sold to specific individuals who among them included Health Minister Katele Kalumba.

Chairman Justice Bwalya and other commissioners were surprised to learn that the University of Zambia released K1m to buy shares for Andrew Siwela and his deputy Jorry Mwenechanya and demanded to know whether the amount was a loan or advance. 

Mr Habeenzu said he was not present at the time ZAMNET was initiated and therefore was unable to answer the questions.

He said ZAMNET was established under a $120,000 World Bank project which among others demanded that the company be a private entity run by the university and whose shares would gradually be sold to private individuals.

The World Bank did not want the university to have more than 51 per cent shareholding.

He said the university paid out K1m to cover shares for the then registrar Jean Calder (750) Siwela (125) and Mwenechanya (125).

In 1994, shares amounting to 125 were sold to Dr Kalumba, then Health deputy minister.

On why the shares were not floated publicly, Mr Habeenzu claimed the shares would have been too expensive and when pressed further he said Unza would have not managed to satisfy that many subscribers.

He assumed Dr Kalumba was approached to buy shares because of his commitment and dedication to electronic networking.

He said dividends had not been claimed by the shareholders since inception as the money was ploughed back for re- capitalisation but he could not say how much.

Neither could he confirm whether the decision to set up ZAMNET and the shareholding was ratified by the University Council.

"Mr Habeenzu, I fore-warned you that it was premature for you to come before this commission. You clearly have no answers to the pertinent questions.

"It is a pity that you are not aware of what your organisation is all about. We are impaired because you have no knowledge of who gave birth to ZAMNET," Justice Bwalya said.

Commissioner John Muliokela said as much as ZAMNET was a well-intentioned initiative, it was important to account for public funds.

Earlier during his submission Mr Habeenzu said ZAMNET was paying Unza $340 a month in rent although the institution owed it K3m in arrears for subscription.

Lecturers and union leaders earlier this week submitted to the commission that Prof Siwela and Mwenechanya had registered themselves as businessmen on the ZAMNET board and were declaring dividends.

June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Police on Masonic trail


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - Police are investigating whether the Kabwe building in which a suspected human skull and bones, two coffins and priestly robes were found is still the Masonic temple it used to be in the 1960s.

They also want to establish if the skull is truly that of a human being.

Central Province police chief Sassassali Nungu said in an interview yesterday the Masons had used the building in 1967 when they were registered in Kabwe. 

Police questioned the proprietors of the building but later freed the three men because there was no law under which they could be prosecuted.

He said police were yet to establish whether the activities of the Masons had continued in the same building after 1967.

"We could not continue holding the three. They denied having any links with the Masonic Association and did not know where the items discovered in the building came from," he said.

Mr Nungu said police were medically examining the suspected human skull and bones found in the building which is widely believed to be a temple of the Masonic Association.

He said police did not know the members of the Masonic Association.

"Medical authorities need to ascertain whether the bones that were found in the building are human bones. It is also important for us to establish how the bones landed into the temple," he said.

Police acting on a tip-off raided the building near Kabwe Civic Centre and found two coffins, a suspected human skull and bones and church robes.

A Samfya villager beat to death his 72-year-old uncle after suspecting him of practising witchcraft, Luapula Province police chief Oliver Chibwe said.

Mr Chibwe said yesterday the incident occurred on Tuesday at 1500 hrs. Police are holding the suspect.

Trouble started when the suspect accused his uncle, Obina Mibenge, of bewitching a relative who had died in the village.

The suspect descended on his uncle hitting him with a metal object until he died.

The incident occurred at Mabo-Kunda village in Chief Kalasa Mukoso's area.

Zambia;
Sweden gives aid condition


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Sweden has promised to continue to assist Zambia but urged the Government to engage in dialogue with the opposition to access balance of payment support.

Swedish ambassador to Zambia Kristina Svensson (above) said this in Lusaka yesterday when she officiated at the inauguration of the upgraded and rehabilitated Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (Zesco) national control centre. 

Ms Svensson said her government was pleased with the steps Government had taken on good governance but implored it to engage in dialogue with the opposition to resolve political differences.

Sweden, would however, continue assisting Zambia.

"Sweden is supporting political dialogue between Government and the opposition because in a democracy all parties must give their contribution to peaceful and prosperous development of the nation. When we see this dialogue taking place we will consider to release our balance of payment support," she said.

She hailed Zambia for undertaking the liberalisation and privatisation exercises with great commitment. But the privatisation of the ZCCM and the civil service reform programme were cardinal in Zambia's economic recovery programme.

Sweden is conducting extensive research on new methods of generating of hydro-power from which Zambia will benefit.

And Energy and Water Development Minister Suresh Desai said at the same function that $200m was required to overhaul plant and machinery of Zesco.

Mr Desai said Government was currently working out measures to raise the $200m.

Part of the money would come from donors. He said the existing generation, transmission and distribution infrastructure installed over 30 years ago was slowly breaking down and almost grinding to a halt.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Worrisome events at the university (Editorial)


BYLINE: Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lusaka - Thinly disguised personal vendettas are a worrisome cocktail at the hearings at the Bobby Bwalya Commission into the University of Zambia and Copperbelt University.

Some of the submissions elicit reactions ranging from bewilderment to incomprehension.

There is just too much mud being thrown at the individuals in the Unza administration. 

Taking the pulse of unfolding submissions, we wonder whether any administration can weather such storms.

We hope with bated breath that no one is using the occasion as wanton license to vent selfish interests and petty jealousies.

So far, there is every reason to believe that some submissions are laced with dangerously derisive tones.

We appeal for submissions to be modest and seasoned with the utmost caution. Let all those making submissions guard their tongues.

They must not veer off-tangent or else we shall have no Unza left.

The commission of inquiry has been turned into a firing squad of sorts with the administration standing bound hand and foot, blindfolded and mute.

Meanwhile, we are left wondering what is happening to the primary quest for what causes the persistent interruptions at the institution.

There are those who appear to have turned the sittings into a hot commodity for political professionals.

Some rabble-rousers even in their student days, now turned lecturers, should be rowed back from their acid presentations against individuals in the administration.

We concur with the commission's chairman, Justice Bobby Bwalya, that submissions should not miss the boat in a big sort of way.

The thorny issue which needs dealing is the endless closures of the institution. Some say there is a likelihood of tribal sentiment in the pudding; some are accusing the administration of weighing heavily towards some province.

That's very unfortunate coming from some lecturers who themselves are a moral epidemic in our education institutions and not otherwise.

It's true some things have gone wrong at Unza.

But the fallacy of generalisation should be tamed.

Lecturers must also bridle their penchant towards the feeling of bitterness for the administration.

Ours is an appeal for level-headedness in their submissions.

The submissions must therefore be tailored to save the institution from collapse.

We need to hear sober submissions.

Bad-mouthing are only a potent symbol of small minds and failure.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


99 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Science and Health;
Charcoal burners cause concern in Zambia


BYLINE: Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - A senior civil servant has expressed concern at the wanton destruction of woodlands through charcoal burning in Central Province.

At the World Environment Day at Munyama primary school on the periphery of Kabwe yesterday Central Province acting assistant secretary, Thomas Nkwanga, said Government was very much concerned about environmental degradation.

Deforestation, soil erosion and shifting cultivation should be addressed seriously because they brought about poverty among rural communities. 

"Statistics show this every year due to charcoal production alone. If this state of affairs continues, there will be very few forests in few years to come especially in Chibombo and some parts of Mumbwa district," Mr Nkwanga lamented.

He explained that deforestation led to soil erosion, then siltation of streams and rivers resulted in shortage of water for agricultural activities, animals and human beings.

He attacked illegal settlements in forest reserves; settlers clearing large tracks of land for farming and charcoal production were disturbing the whole ecosystem.

He noted that there were 8000 illegal settlers in Munyama forest reserve engaged in cutting down trees for charcoal and agricultural production.

Mr Nkwanga appealed for cooperation from various ministries and departments and local communities in solving environmental problems.

The Ministry of Education should play a big role in disseminating information on the importance of the environment to youths.

"Young people are important partners and allies in raising environmental awareness and triggering environmental action.

It is by creating awareness today that we can hope to promote conservation and prevent future environment destruction," he said.

He appealed to them to play an active role in environmental issues because they would next century shoulder the burden of decisions taken by today's leaders.

Mr Nkwanga called for good management and wise use of all natural resources to ensure sustainable development because the environment was a source of essential raw materials and inputs that support human activities with regard to food, water, shelter and wood.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
'CHIPOLOPOLO' making presence felt in Jbg


BYLINE: Yuyo Kambikambi And Mwaba Phiri, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Johannesburg - 'Chipolopolo' is making it's presence felt as the bars have already been taken over by the ever-guzzling but amiable Zambians.

The excited fans are walking the streets of Johannesburg bleary-eyed with sashes of Zambian national colours draped around their necks. 

More fans in the Chipolopolo Soccer Fans Association (CSFA) convoy which leaves on Friday from Lusaka are due in Johannesburg on Saturday afternoon.

Caltex yesterday fuelled up 10 buses for the fans in Lusaka at a cost of K1.6m and southern division area manager Mubita Akapelwa pledged more support for the national team , saying his company had already spent K4m on the match.

On Wednesday, the South African Football Association (SAFA) went to Johannesburg airport to welcome Zambia but the team never came out of the plane.

It's a psychological ploy! The Press is shouting here. The Johannesburg's 'Star's' story on Zambia's alleged failure to arrive began "Zambia yesterday fired the first salvo in the psychological war in the build-up when the visiting squad failed to arrive at the Johannesburg International Airport".

The 'Star' explained how bemused and surprised SAFA officials were to find only Zambian ministers Ben Mwila, Samuel Miyanda, Sonny Mulenga, Kaunda Lembalemba, Reverend Peter Chintala and Member of Parliament Christopher Chawinga and supporters alighting from the plane.

SAFA spokesman Bucks Molatedi explained how the plane had got full in Lusaka forcing Zambia to re-schedule their arrival to Friday.

The very partisan 'Sowetan' newspaper has meanwhile warned Zambian coach George Mungwa not to rate South Africa by the side beaten 1-0 in 1992.

Sports - Soccer;
Squad heads for South Africa


BYLINE: Sports Reporters, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - zambia heads for Johannesburg today for Sunday's must-win World Cup qualifier against South Africa.

Stand-in national team coach George Mungwa said on the eve of the team's departure for South Africa that his charges were venturing to Johannesburg with an ambition of winning the match. He said Sunday's match would definitely be tough and needed a serious approach from the word go.

"We are geared for the game. Playing away at their First National Bank stadium will not scare the players. We shall go for a win," Mungwa said.

He hoped Government and FAZ had taken care of the other precautions of the team as regards meals and accommodation to ensure that they were not tampered with.

In build-up matches for the Sunday date, Zambia played Kuwait, losing 1-2 in a preparatory match in Kuwait City and Cameroun who they beat 3-0 at Lusaka's Independence stadium last weekend.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - General;
Record run puts Ramaala on track for Athens


BYLINE: Julian Drew, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Johannesburg - Last Saturday in the Dutch town of Hengelo Haile Gebrselassie missed out by a whisker on a million dollar pay-out for becoming the first man to run under eight minutes for two miles. By comparison, Hendrick Ramaala's fifth place finish in the 10 000m for a new South African record of 27:36.30 was a modest effort- nearly a minute behind Salah Hissou's current world record of 26:38.08.

For local athletics, however, it was an important step forward, picking up from the renaissance of 1995 when Ramaala and Shadrack Hoff brought South African distance running out of a lengthy period in the doldrums.

Ramaala was the revelation of the 1995 season, coming from nowhere to finish as the first South African home at the world cross country championships and reach the 10 000m final at the world championships in Gothenburg with a respectable personal best of 27:54.59. 

Last year was fraught with injury problems that kept him out of the world cross country championships and saw him perform poorly in Atlanta.

This year is Ramaala's first as a full-time athlete after graduating from Wits with an LLB last year. There are not too many articulate, black sportsmen from humble rural backgrounds who have got themselves an education and been to the Olympics, but when Ramaala went looking for sponsors he received some surprising responses.

One company representative told Ramaala they wouldn't get value for money out of him. He said a well known sprinter races week-in-week-out for them and if Ramaala wanted to come on board he would have to do likewise.

Out of necessity rather than desire Ramaala went to Europe at the end of December to race on the World Cross Challenge circuit, earning himself more than R30 000 by the time he returned at the end of January and placing him second in the rankings after five races.

That money came in handy for Ramaala who rented a flat in Johannesburg's Berea's for himself and his two younger brothers whom he is helping through their studies. It was not the smartest move for his long- term plans, however, and while he was over in Europe's freezing winter he lost much of his endurance base. He could still have rescued his situation though had it not been for the ridiculous requirements of Athletics South Africa who insisted that any athlete wanting to go to the world championships in Athens should qualify at least once in the local season.

The only opportunity to do so at the coast this year was at Port Elizabeth on February 14. A crash course of speed sessions proved insufficient and he failed to make the mark. His dismal performance at the world cross country championships in March further underlined what has been obvious for too long now. South Africa's elite middle- distance runners cannot run the world cross country championships and the local track season.

"If we run the world cross country championships then my thinking is that we mustn't run on the track until April," says Ramaala.

With a sponsorship from Mr Price under his belt Ramaala rested after the world cross country championships and then started building up for Athens. "My overall mileage was up to 200/215km a week which is the most I've ever done. I could never do that before but now I have the time to train and rest in between. I was also doing gym work three or four times a week," says Ramaala.

Going back to the formula which saw him do so well in Gothenburg Ramaala built up his endurance and used cross country league races to gauge his fitness and gain confidence. "I was training right up until last Friday (the day before the race in Hengelo) so I didn't have any speed but I didn't blow because I had good endurance," says Ramaala

"I heard before the race that there would be three groups and I decided to stick with the lead group who were aiming to go through 5 000m on 13:30 pace ( that's 27 minutes for 10 000m!). I went through 5 000m in 13:43 and just stayed behind the leaders. With four laps to go I went to the front to push the pace a bit," he says.

At 600m from home the sprint for the line began and Ramaala couldn't respond. "My stomach began to turn and I wanted to throw up. It showed I hadn't done my speedwork so I decided to reduce my pace a little."

He eventually came fifth but clipped more than three seconds off Xolile Yawa's 10- year-old South African record and paved the way for even greater things. "I wasn't tired. It felt like any other race and I believe any of our top runners can do it with the same training."

The modest Ramaala is likely to beat them to it though because when he sharpens up with some shorter races over the next month and gets ready for Athens at the beginning of August he could find he has a lot more in reserve.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


103 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - General;
The dynamic game just built for Jerry


BYLINE: Mick Cleary, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Johannesburg - The 1997 British Lions could not be further removed from their celebrated battling ancestors. The game has moved on and the Lions are hell-bent on moving with it.

While it's true that the Lions need to have more edge and tightness in their forward play, their primary concern as they swing towards the pressure cooker of provincial programmes - Northern Transvaal, Gauteng (Transvaal), and Natal within eight days starting on Saturday - is to harness their resources, play a wide, free-wheeling game and not stand toe to toe with any local enforcers.

They'll be tough and muscular when they need to be. They know too what they can offer in that department. They are unsure yet quite what they can offer in other parts of the field. They know what they would like to offer, but we have yet to see sustained evidence that brazen theory can be translated into harmonious reality. 

The Lions have declared their hand. They are looking to play a fast, interactive, seamless game where forwards and backs merge as one in the hope of destructuring the tightly choreographed defences of the modern era. "We want to play in a way that the South Africans don't expect us to play," says their coach, Ian McGeechan. "We don't want to be loose but we do want to play on the edge. We want to be ambitious and not to play in a straitjacket."

McGeechan's is a high-risk strategy in any context. With the Lions, who have existed as a team for just a few weeks, this is an audacious roll of the dice. It is also the right one. And if there is one player who convinces you of the fundamental correctness of the approach it is Jeremy Guscott. The style of play is a perfect fit for the game's most bespoke player.

Guscott scored two tries against Eastern Province. He was sharp, elusive, threatening and commanding. He shepherded the new boy, uncapped centre Will Greenwood, beautifully, with a mix of paternal care and bullish youth and confidence. Guscott's defence was also impeccable. So little is made of Guscott's shrewd, robust tackling. He is no gilded butterfly, a precious species craving gentle handling.

Guscott is the all-round centre, which is precisely why he should play there and not be shunted sideways into the wings.

The temptation to play him on the wings will be overpowering. The one area in which the Lions are spoilt for choice is at the centre. Any of Scott Gibbs, Allan Bateman, Alan Tait and the Tigers tyro, Greenwood, would grace a Lions side. Guscott has the pace, balance and perception to play on the wing, as he showed with devastating effect when he came on in that position for England as a half-time replacement against Wales. (Jack Rowell's decision to omit Guscott last season appears more crass by the day.)

For all this, the Lions would be wrong to play him out there. If their ambitious game plan is ever to come to fruition they need Guscott's withering thrust, his drifting angular runs, his probing intellect, to be in play as often as possible. To remove him from the heart of the action would be to muffle the side's creative potential.

The McGeechan medley of options is music to the ears of Guscott, the star turn of the cabaret who has so often been reduced to the role of bouncer, turfing out intruders and performing the menial chores of chasing kicks and harrying defenders. "Yes, I do wish the new laws had arrived 10 years ago and we had played this type of rugby," said Guscott, who will be 32 two days after the final Test. "It's my kind of game. In fact it's not just me who feels liberated by it; everyone does. The message is clear. We have to forget the numbers on our backs. The props have to play like centres, the centres like props. If you watch the Brazilians play football you don't know really whether they're defenders or attackers. That's the aim.

"There is no Plan A and Plan B. There is a format, and we have to fit in to it and react accordingly. I'd be disappointed if we didn't take advantage of the opportunity now. And, yes, my aim is to play centre."

The Lions have brought the best out of Guscott. This is his third tour and this is his natural habitat. His flickering genius finds true and more lasting expression among the more talented ranks of the Lions. The well- disguised competitive beast that is the real Jeremy Guscott the rugby player - the sardonic, laid-back persona is a mask of convenience to bemuse and distract - rises to the challenge of the Lions environment.

"It is special," says Guscott. "It's hard to explain precisely why because it is like one of those warm, private family moments which sound daft when you describe them to outsiders. But when everything clicks, when it all comes together and everyone is thinking and reacting the same, then it's a great feeling. I look around the squad and I think, 'Well, why can't we come through?' The whole tour party is very lively, very positive."

Guscott was smiling last week. No wonder. The British game is finally heading his direction.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
