135 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
FIFA Intervenes in Suspension of FAZ President


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - The world soccer governing body, FIFA, forced government to lift a suspension imposed on the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) president Michael Chiti.

The FAZ leader was suspended for three months by the National Sports Council of Zambia for insubordination after he defied a ministerial directive that the association holds executive committee elections by June 18.

The ban was, however, lifted after FIFA noted that a suspension imposed by a body outside the soccer governing body could not be recognised and warned Zambia of stern action if the decision was not rescinded.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


136 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia News Roundup


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Lusaka - SWEDEN DEMANDS POLITICAL DIALOGUE IN EXCHANGE FOR AID

Sweden says that it will give balance of payment aid to Zambia only if political dialogue between political parties is effected.

Sweden's ambassador to Zambia, Kristina Svensen, said that in the absence of political dialogue in the country, Sweden cannot support the country with aid because economic development must involve all political forces.

INQUIRY INTO UNIVERSITY OF ZAMBIA PROBLEMS REVEALS ALLEGED "SHADY" DEALS

An on-going Commission of Inquiry into the problems at the University of Zambia (UNZA), and the Copperbelt University (CBU), has brought to the fore accusations of "shady" deals by the university authorities and a deputy minister.

A head of department at UNZA charged that deputy health minister Professor Nkandu Luo was lecturing at the institution contrary to a recently effected code of conduct that bars political leaders from lecturing at the university. Another witness charged that UNZA had 48 bank accounts, some of which were allegedly used for siphoning money out of the institution. 

WORKERS' UNIONS DEMAND PROMPT PAYMENT OF SALARIES

Civil servants have called on the government to honour its collective agreement obligation of paying the public service workers on time to avert strikes and to boost production. The call was made after a work stoppage by about 200 general workers at Zambia's major hospital, the University Teaching Hospital in Lusaka. The workers abandoned work for two days before being persuaded to return to their tasks by union leaders. They were protesting a delay in being paid their salaries.

Some teachers around the country have also been threatening to stop work because of a delay in paying them their salaries. Government has promised that the money will soon be available. But some teachers have vowed to boycott this year's supervising of examinations and the marking of examination papers because government has in the past failed to honour its promise to pay them on time. Government recently awarded public service workers a salary increase of K40,000 (about US$35) and new conditions of service.

LIQUIDATED BANK WORKERS PROTEST

Scores of former workers of the liquidated Lima Bank, a lending institution for farmers, recently staged a protest at the Ministry of Agriculture to demand payment of their terminal benefits.

The workers, who were joined by their wives and children., demanded that they be paid their dues promptly because they and their families have been starving since the firm was closed about a month ago.

GOVERNMENT NOT TO INTERFERE IN MAIZE PRODUCTION

Government has announced that it will not interfere or take part in the production and supply of maize, Zambia's staple food, during the 1997/98 farming season. And, despite a forecast that the country could have a deficit of its annual requirement of maize, government will not restrict the exportation of the grain.

The decision is in line with the government policy of letting market forces determine prices and distribution of any farm produce. However, some observers, including those in the farming community, say that government's pull out of the agriculture sector should have been more gradual and that they now fear that because of the forecast shortage, prices of the commodity could rise beyond the reach of many Zambians.

EASTERN PROVINCE APPEALS FOR FOOD AID

The Paramount Chief of the Eastern Province has requested an immediate supply of relief food to the region because he said people in the area are starving.

Paramount Chief Mpezeni said that some people were leaving the area because they had been unable to grow enough food to last them until the next farming season. He attributed the food deficit to an inadequate supply of seed and fertiliser. The province usually has a food surplus.

In some other parts of the province, farmers have appealed to government to repair roads and bridges that were washed away by rains for them to be able to deliver their produce to markets. Works and Supply deputy minister, Celestino Chibamba, has promised to have the bridges repaired.

ZAMBIANS FACE INCREASE OF ELECTRICITY TARIFFS

Electricity consumers could soon be paying more for the commodity, following Energy Minister Suresh Desai's advice that supply cannot be increased sufficiently unless more income is generated through increased tariffs. The veiled proposal to the Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) could, however, trigger renewed opposition from consumers, many of whom already contend that the current tariffs are too high.

The minister's advice follows a warning by Zesco's consumer relations manager Louis Changula that Zambia risked becoming deficient in electricity by the year 2001 unless new energy generating stations are constructed.

CALLS FOR ABOLITION OF DEATH PENALTY CONTINUE

The pressure on government to abolish the death penalty continues to grow with an added voice coming from a seminar recently held by the Zambia Prison Fellowship Association. Participants at the seminar resolved that government should discontinue the death penalty and have life-imprisonment as the maximum penalty.

The participants noted that with Zambia being declared a Christian nation soon after the MMD came into power in 1991, it was only logical that the death penalty too be abolished. Eight condemned prisoners have been executed by hanging since 1991.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Inter-Party Conflicts Increase


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - As some parties called for dialogue between the political parties, conflicts within some of these parties have increased in recent weeks. Most hit by the internal squabbling are the ruling MMD and the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC). 

In the MMD, several middle-rank members have been suspended on charges of defying a ban on campaigning for the party presidency. The party national secretary, Michael Sata, recently undertook a tour of Luapula Province, President Chiluba's home region, where some party members charged that a cabinet minister had been campaigning in the area for the presidential elections due in the year 2001. Shortly after his trip, provincial party leaders announced the suspension of the provincial minister Norman Chibamba and a few other leaders from the party for allegedly disorganising the party. The next day, Sata nullified the suspensions and instead suspended the leaders who endorsed the suspension of Chibamba.

In the ZDC, internal wranglings have increased following the suspension of three senior members accused of going against collective responsibility. Party vice-presidents Kasuka Mutukwa (for policy), and Susan Jere (for gender), along with treasurer, Dante Saunders, were suspended after they disagreed with party president Dean Mung'omba's call to remove the MMD government "by whatever means". Several other party members have condemned the call and some of them have since resigned from the party. The three leaders have rejected their suspensions and have instead called for a national party convention at which party differences could be resolved.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Christians Fear Growth Of Satanism In Zambia


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Lusaka - When President Chiluba endorsed Zambia as a Christian nation soon after the MMD came to power in 1991, some people voiced their opposition to such a declaration.

Soon, however, the criticism died out and the Christian community in Zambia went full throttle in its efforts to spreads the faith. Recent developments in the country, however, point to the Christians facing a new form of resistance - Satanism.

Early this year, a couple of youths in the densely populated province of the Copperbelt claimed that a group of Satanists was operating under-ground and recruiting members at a rate that called for concern. They said they had been part of the group but decided to pull out of it because they realised that devil worshipping was wrong. No one paid much attention to the two youths' revelation but three months on, another confession was made by another young woman in Lusaka who disclosed that faith in Satan was growing in the capital and that the Satanists were on an aggressive campaign to outwit the spread of Christianity. 

More revelations as to the existence of devil-worship have been made over recent weeks and now Christians are beginning to take the issue more seriously, calling for concerted efforts to counter Satanism. Some of those who have broken away from the Satanist groups contend that there is a deliberate plan by the Satanists to take over the country by infiltrating various key organisations, business, the judiciary, the political field and even the church.

"This message first came in February," says Christian Unity Ministries (CUMI), national secretary Timothy Situmbeko of the alleged plot by Satanists to take over Zambia and destroy Christian institutions in Zambia. "We hesitated to tell the people about it, but continued to pray. Then early this month it was repeated." He added that there had been at least one Satanist planted in some of the many born-again churches in an effort to derail the Christian faith and cause divisions.

Africa Church of God leader, Bishop John Mambo agrees that there is a plot to destroy Christianity in Zambia. He contends that many cults have been formed in the disguise of churches and already deep divisions are beginning to show among the Christians.

Police spokesman Standwell Lungu says that there is no law that would bar Satanists from practising their faith, but the concern of many Christians is that the devil's faith is said to include human sacrifices. Some reformed devil worshipers have claimed that the drinking of human blood is part of a major ritual that Satanists have to practice. For now, however, no one has come out in the open yet to confess that he or she practices Satanism. And those that claim to have belonged to the faith have not quite been able to expose those still practising the faith. For many Christians, however, this is not an assurance that Satanism is not a serious threat.

"Christians must be ready for attacks from the devil," Zambia Episcopal Conference Secretary General, Father Ignatius Mwebe says. "The Church as a body has to fight the prince of darkness. We are his first target. Goodness is always the target of evil." Bishop Mambo also said that the mushrooming of cults was getting out of hand he wanted government to scrutinise all the churches to prevent church wars that could destroy Christianity in the country. Recent months has seen an increased number of divisions in various churches, resulting in splinter groups forming up to follow their own methods of prayer. Bishop Mambo fears that if such divisions were allowed to continue, cults could emerge and Christianity could become vulnerable to devil worshipers.

The Satanists are said to be very selective in their recruitment of members. According to a young woman who recently broke away from the devil's faith, some Satanists operate from Christian churches from which they recruit their members. She said that those in social or financial problems were often the main targets for recruitment.

Some political parties too are concerned about the increased reports of Satanism. The National Democratic Party (NDP) recently stated that the MMD government was not doing enough to curb the spread of Satanism. NDP Copperbelt Province chairman Isaac Chileshe said that government should investigate increasing reports of Satanism taking root in Zambia. The party contends that the seeds of Satanism were being planted by foreigners and it demands that the government deports those involved.

Police spokesman Lungu says action against Satanists can only be taken if there is evidence that some of their practices were, by Zambian laws, illegal. He said that investigations had been instituted on some of the charges made by reformed Satanists but that no evidence had yet come to light on which the police could base a prosecution.

For some Christians, the solution to curb the spread of Satanism is in prayer. The Baptist Church in Lusaka, for instance, has embarked on special prayers for those who may have drifted into Satanism. It is hoped that the power of prayer will help redirect them to Christianity. But with the Zambian constitution categorical that Zambia would be tolerant of other religions, there is little much else Christians can do but pray that the Christian faith will overshadow Satanism.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


United States and Africa;
Richardson to Kinshasa for Talks with Kabila


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Washington - Text of questions and answers on Sierra Leone by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns at the Department's daily briefing June 5.

MR. BURNS: My announcement is that Ambassador Bill Richardson leaves tonight for the Congo. He leaves as head of an interagency delegation at the request of Secretary Albright. That delegation will include Congresswoman Cynthia McKinney of Georgia. They plan to meet with President Laurent Kabila in Lubumbashi on Saturday. They will be meeting with other government officials of the Congo. I expect Ambassador Richardson will want to talk to the UNHCR and the International Committee on the Red Cross on humanitarian questions. 

Now, let me tell you why he is going and what he hopes to do. He is going to engage the new leadership of the Congo to see if we can make our views known to that government very directly and at a very senior level -- he is a member of the Cabinet -- and to press the following points.

First, the United States believes that the new government ought to aim itself at an inclusive political system. That means a political system that will produce democratic institutions, that will be broad-based; a government that will include members of the opposition, which the current government does; a government that will be devoted to heading the country and orienting it towards elections; and a government that will respect the civil liberties of the people, press freedoms and religious freedoms, that will be tolerant of other ethnic minorities. In Zaire, there are several hundred of them -- ethnic minorities.

Second, a government that will be devoted to a liberal economy, a free economy, and an economy that will be open to Western investment, including, we hope, American investment.

Third, a government that will put human rights at the forefront of its agenda. There have been many very serious allegations made about reported alleged human rights abuses, massacres of Rwandan Hutu refugees near Kisangani. We believe very strongly that the United Nations should be let into Kisangani to interview the refugees, to interview the rebel forces that were there, and to try to find out what happened and to try to help the government of the Congo bring those people to justice who were responsible for the massacres.

Fourth, we hope that the new government will be open to continued humanitarian assistance by the United Nations, the International Committee on the Red Cross, American and European and African non-governmental organizations. The people of the Congo are desperately poor. They are in need of medical assistance and food assistance and development assistance. We would like to see the new government of the Congo open to a cooperative relationship with the international humanitarian organizations.

Those are some of the issues that Bill Richardson will be raising on this very important trip. Now, he may go on to other countries in the region. He does not have an endpoint to the trip yet. I will keep you informed as soon as he makes those decisions. He hasn't made them yet. But the focus will be on meeting with Laurent Kabila.

QUESTION: Are the promises of assistance conditional on meeting the other criteria?

MR. BURNS: I think we have always said, the United States, and I know that other countries, are quite willing to help the government of the Congo. However, we are going to need to be assured that it is a government that is interested in a democratic evolution for the Congo and economic reform, a government that will pay attention to the human rights problem.

If we can be assured of that, then I think that the United States will be ready to extend economic assistance to the Congo. We have not yet communicated any specific numbers to them, and will not be making any ironclad promises, until we have a greater perspective to see the performance of this particular government.

QUESTION: Remember the dangling of promises of help with the elections which, it was a rather large figure that he said was insufficient, according to some accounts within the government. Are you going to whisper an amount in his ear that won't be an ironclad guarantee but give him an idea of the proportions of aid that he might expect?

MR. BURNS: I think it will certainly be put before him the clear understanding that the United States, the international development institutions and other countries are going to be ready to help the Congo. But we need to see the establishment of some of these broad-based, democratic, economic goals that are very important. We don't want to put money into a country that will go backwards. We want to put money into a country that is going to go forward on a democratic basis. Laura.

QUESTION: Is Ambassador Richardson going to try to go to Kisangani or attempt to get access to any of these areas while he is on this trip?

MR. BURNS: He has already been to Kisangani. He went up on his last trip. He interviewed some of the refugees, including a woman who had just lost her child that day. He interviewed some of the people who have been subjected to some of these brutal attacks by the rebel forces. Now, Mr. Kabila has said since then that he will hold those who perpetrated the injustices accountable, and we hope very much that that will be the case. I don't believe we have seen any of that yet, any action. We need to see the action.

So I don't believe that Bill Richardson will be going to Kisangani, having been there before to interview the refugees. Now, most of the refugees who were subject to the attacks and who have survived the attacks have moved on back to Rwanda as part of the UN-sponsored and US-financed evacuation.

QUESTION: Do you have any interim assessment of how close or how far Kabila is coming along the lines you would like him to travel?

MR. BURNS: It is quite hard to answer that question because the track record is not very long. The one good thing I can point to is that he has taken into his government some members of other political parties who are not part of the rebel alliance. That is positive.

On the negative side, as you know, he has not allowed expressions of different political views to be made public. He has shut down the ability of some of the opposition parties to demonstrate. I don't believe one can say that there is freedom of the media in the Congo. These are important criteria that we have to measure him by. You know, we have to hold people to high standards because the people of the Congo deserve that.

140 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Kenya;
Amnesty on Kenya's Legal Reforms


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Nairobi - Yesterday's announcement by President Daniel Arap Moi that the Kenyan government intends to amend the Public Order Act is a welcome recognition of the need for improvements in human rights protection, an Amnesty International delegation visiting Kenya said today.

"We welcome this recognition of the necessity of constitutional and legal reform -- which is a key message of Amnesty International's Human Rights Manifesto for Kenya," said Pierre Sane, Secretary General of the worldwide human rights organization. "However, the Public Order Act is just one of a range of laws which require repeal or amendment to guarantee the basic human rights of all Kenyans." 

"Even with the proposed amendment of this Act, the President would retain wide powers to limit the human rights stipulated in the constitution, such as those included in the Preservation of Public Security Act. By invoking these powers, the government can continue to restrict freedom of association, expression and personal liberty."

"What is needed is a strengthening of the constitution to bring it in line with Kenya's obligations under international law, including the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, adopted in Nairobi in 1981" Mr Sane added, reiterating his request to meet with President Moi to discuss the organization's manifesto.

The Public Order Act has been widely used to restrict any activity the government regards as opposition to the state, including the peaceful rally planned for Uhuru Park last Saturday, which was violently broken up by police and General Service Unit personnel.

President Moi announced the amendment of the Public Order Act and its replacement with a proposed Peaceful Assemblies Bill to cover public gatherings. However, Mr Sane argued that there are provisions in the act apart from those relating to public gatherings which need to be reformed, such as those relating to curfews and the prohibition of flags and emblems of political organizations. There must also be effective remedies for breaches of fundamental human rights, including the authority for the courts to scrutinize legislation and comment upon its constitutionality, he added.

"It's about time that Kenya breaks with its colonial legacy by repealing oppressive laws enacted at the time to deprive Kenyans from the fundamental freedoms enshrined in the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights," Mr Sane added.

Issued June 2. For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413- 5500 ,+44-71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

141 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


United States and Africa;
Amnesty Opposes Execution of South African Youth;
in Miss


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

London - United States of America: Amnesty International outraged about possible death sentence against South African teenager in Mississippi

Amnesty International is urgently calling on John Kitchens, the District Attorney of Madison County, not to impose a death sentence against Azikiwe Kambule, a 17-year- old black South African, who goes on trial for his life in Mississippi on 16 June.

"Almost the entire world has now recognised that the execution of juvenile offenders is unacceptable. It is shocking that the United States of America (USA) is still one of the few nations willing to put children to death," Amnesty International said today.

"The execution of juvenile offenders is an extremely grave human rights violation and, by executing juveniles, the USA finds itself in the company of some of the worlds' worst violators of human rights." 

Since 1990, only five countries are known to have executed people who were under 18 at the time of the crime -- Iran, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Yemen and the USA.

Kambule's co-defendant, Santonio Berry, an adult, who has admitted that he murdered Pam McGill and has also stated that Kambule was not present during the killing, has accepted a plea-bargain of life imprisonment without parole in return for his testimony against Kambule.

"That the juvenile, who may well have been under the control of the older offender and who did not actually commit the murder, is the one facing a death sentence, shows the inequalities in the administration of the death penalty in the USA," the human rights organization said.

According to information received by Amnesty International, Kambule was travelling in a car with Santonio Berry, aged 21, on 25 January 1997, when Berry spotted Pam McGill in a red sports car and decided to follow her in order to steal the car. When McGill stopped outside her home Berry forced her at gunpoint to get back into the car and told Kambule to get in the back seat. He then drove to a secluded wood, told Kambule to wait, and forced McGill to walk into the woods where he shot her. Kambule claims that he was unaware that Berry intended to steal a car until it happened and was also unaware that Berry intended to murder McGill.

In the event of a guilty verdict the jury's options for sentencing are limited to death or life imprisonment without parole. Both sentences violate the United Nations (UN) Convention on the Rights of the Child, which states: "Neither capital punishment nor life imprisonment without the possibility of parole shall be imposed for crimes committed by persons below 18 years of age."

Kambule has no criminal record or history of violence.

BACKGROUND INFORMATION

The execution of people aged 18 and under at the time of the crime is expressly forbidden under international human rights law, in recognition of the fact that the death penalty is wholly inappropriate for individuals who have not yet attained full physical or emotional maturity. Such treaties and standards include the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), the American Convention on Human Rights (ACHR), the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and the Safeguards guaranteeing protection of the rights of those facing the death penalty, adopted by the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) in 1984 (resolution 1984/50).

The US signed the ICCPR in 1977 and ratified it in April 1992. However, the US government reserved its right "subject to its Constitutional constraints" to impose capital punishment on persons below 18 years of age. The USA remains one of the few countries that has not ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

Twenty-five of the 38 US States that have the death penalty permit the execution of juvenile offenders. There are currently more than 45 juvenile offenders under sentence of death in 14 States. The majority of known executions of juvenile offenders worldwide take place in the USA (nine since 1985). The last known execution of a juvenile offender worldwide was that of Christopher Burger in the USA (Georgia) on 9 December 1993.

As of 31 July 1996, there were 53 prisoners under sentence of death in Mississippi. The method of execution is by lethal gas or by lethal injection for those sentenced to death after 1 July 1984. Four executions have taken place in Mississippi since the resumption of executions in 1983. The last prisoner to be executed in Mississippi was Leo Edwards on 21 June 1989.

For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44-71-956- 1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
ANC Statement on the OAU


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Johannesburg - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) resolution to give the go ahead to the West African Peacekeeping Force to restore the democratically elected government of Sierra Leone marks a new beginning in African politics.

This is a clear message that Africa will not tolerate undemocratic, dictatorial and militaristic regimes and no one must hide behind the OAU Charter in order to impose unpopular regimes. The significance of this decision is that once and for all Africa is shedding its image of being a continent which deals with its political problems through militaristic solutions.

The ANC therefore fully supports this resolution by the OAU. It is time now that such problems are resolved politically and through peaceful and political means.

The ANC takes this opportunity to congratulate President Robert Mugabe on his election as chairperson of the OAU. This is indicative of the increasing role that Southern Africa is playing in the affairs of Africa as a whole.

For more information, call Dr Blade Nzimande, spokesperson on International Affairs at 033161545.

Issued by The African National Congress, Department of Information and Publicity, P.O. Box 16884, Marshalltown 2307, Johannesburg. Email: info@anc.org.za


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
Take your partners for 1999


BYLINE: Zubeida Jaffer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Cape Town - On a bright shiny autumn day in Cape Town this week, the leader of Inkatha, Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi met Democratic Party leader Tony Leon.

They met to discuss finding ways of greater co-operation. They were not the only ones who have sought new forms of co- operation over the past few days.

In a small parliamentary lounge where members sip their afternoon tea, National Party leader F W de Klerk met Freedom Front leader General Constand Viljoen. 

In Gauteng, the deputy-chairman of the National Party's fundraising committee, Mr Jan Bredenkamp, announced that he was to join the Roelf Meyer initiative.

And in Parliament, the Pan Africanist Congress finally said goodbye to former leader Clarence Makwetu when Mr Michael Meundane took his place in the National Assembly.

This week has seen an ongoing flurry of activity as opposition parties seek out new allies in an attempt to strengthen their hand at the next election.

Mr Meyer's sudden departure from the National Party has attracted considerable attention. The broader question, however, is whether these opposition initiatives will constitute for the electorate a real check on political power in 1999.

A viable opposition is an essential ingredient for a healthy democracy, hence the excitement when there are signs of political realignment. Roelf Meyer is right when he says democracy has to be extended beyond the adoption of the new constitution. It will be hard to find a politician who disagrees with him on that score. However, how meaningful are these signs of realignment?

Despite the excitement among opposition politicians, it is necessary to examine the outcome of this week's "toenaderings".

The meeting in Sea Point between Dr Buthelezi and Mr Leon ended with a statement that "there will be enhanced co- operation between the parties in Parliament, provincial legislatures and local government".

After his meeting with Mr De Klerk, General Viljoen said the two parties would meet again, but that there existed fundamental differences in approach between them.

Mr Meyer told the Press Gallery Association he would know after two months of consultation how his new party would look. At a lunch held with journalists at Parliament, he was his usual affable self, smiling broadly and completely likeable. "We now have a new situation and I see tremendous opportunities," he said.

But he was unable to point to the support base from which he expected to launch his new party. "The support base I would like to see has to be representative of all communities in South Africa," he said. "The work now has to start and we must work full out for the new objectives."

Where will he get his financial support? "Money-wise, it is still too early to say now exactly where it will come from," he said, squeezing together the palms of his hands.

"I believe if I look at the responses of the business community locally, it looks like they are responsive to this idea of creating a new political home in South Africa," he said.

Any seasoned politician knows that it takes time and resources to build a party. The ANC was established in 1912 and came to power in 1994. But those were different circumstances. A more appropriate analogy would be the birth of the old Progressive Party in 1961.

Racked by differences over issues of land in 1959, the United Party split and some of its members went on to form the Progressive Party. Two years later, Mrs Helen Suzman became the first elected member of the new party. Thirteen years later, the Progressive Party was able to win four seats in Parliament.

Building a new party is not a simple matter as most of the 26 parties in the last election discovered. Shortly before the elections in 1994, a host of parties emerged. Perhaps there are some of us who still remember KISS, Keep It Straight and Simple. Seven of the parties made it to Parliament. The ACDP, one of the new parties, won two seats. The majority of new parties won negligible votes.

Viable opposition means being able to pose a threat to the re-election of politicians. The present opposition parties, when closely questioned, acknowledged that they did not represent a serious threat to the ANC in 1999.

The principal guarantee of meaningful opposition from now until 1999, lies within the ANC.

The December conference of the party will provide an indication of the extent to which real curbs on power exist.

President Mandela has made a clear statement encouraging criticism within the ANC. He is, however, not a contender at the December conference.

When ANC members gather this year, many will be conscious of the fact that their political careers depend on the public positions they take. But there are also a large number of ANC members who have little personal stake in the party.

According to the Human Sciences Research Council, those of them who are completely disillusioned will not join other parties, but will withdraw from the political process.

However, those who continue to take part, if organised effectively, will represent the only guarantee that the leadership of the movement remains on track.

Mr Meyer says he wants to restructure the South African political scene. The "two months of consultation around the country" to which he has committed himself, will be only the beginning of such restructuring.

Nor does the announcement that Jan Bredenkamp has joined Mr Meyer tell of a major realignment.

"Mr Bredenkamp is an ordinary member of the NP," said NP spokesman Jan Bosman. "He is deputy-chair of a committee and comes from a West Rand branch."

An assessment of meaningful opposition requires a closer look at the present dynamics within the ANC which play themselves out in branches and provinces and the national executive committee of the ANC - and will be on display at the December conference.

Those with real concern about immediately viable opposition would do well to watch the run-up to the conference.

It is the interplay of the balance of forces within the ANC which will provide a sharp indication of the existence of viable opposition in this country.

All other initiatives are unlikely to produce a real challenge to determining which politicians will be public representatives after the elections in 1999.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Science and Health;
Steve Biddulph: in search of the New Age male


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Cape Town - You could say that Steve Biddulph of Australia is on a mission to save the much-troubled male species from itself. For trouble is what men and fathers are in and what they face in the future - unless they change and change soon, he says.

But then again, mild-mannered and refreshingly atypical male that he is, Biddulph stresses that he is not simply a proselytiser, and thinks that when it comes to the subject of parenting, all expert advice should be treated with extreme caution and circumspection.

On a miserably cold and wet Tuesday night, about 500 parents packed a school hall to listen to what Biddulph had to say on the subject of parenting and, specifically, fathering. 

A family psychologist, he has written several books on the subject (his first was The Secret of Happy Children and his most recent is called Manhood), which have sold half a million copies and have been translated into five languages.

But first let me tell you about Biddulph himself.

Tall and lean, looking almost like an overgrown teenager, with warm, expressive hazel eyes, he is unusually self- effacing yet also exudes a quiet self-confidence.

"Good evening everyone, I'm Steve ...," is how he starts his talk.

Soon, with his easy-going, relaxed manner and a natural ability for storytelling, he has the audience eating out of his hands - and sometimes in fits of laughter.

During a chat at a city hotel, Biddulph tells me why he uses humour in talking about what is, after all, a very serious subject.

"We give that talk to around 20 000 people every year," he says.

"I think that a fair proportion of those who come are very reluctant to be there, expecting to be preached to.

"So what I did was to study people like Scottish comedian Billy Connelly and Robin Williams because I think they are wonderful storytellers. I used to work a lot with people who had severe trauma, and what you realise is that humour is so important in life and it enables you to move through uncomfortable things like nothing else.

"If you analyse last night's talk, there were some very confronting messages in the talk but because they came among so much humour, it enabled them to get past people's defences."

I ask Biddulph about his own childhood.

"I was a very shy child ... I barely spoke when I was a child at school ... I think there was a frustrated wish to be social and my kids have both got that. (He has two - a son aged 11 and a daughter, 5.

In Manhood, Steve has written about the need for men to liberate themselves, partly by being more expressive and more "emotionally free".

"I started off as quite a basket case as a young man ... my life wasn't looking all that good, but I wanted to develop and to grow and I'm relaxed now because I have undergone a liberation process. I'm now comfortable with feelings and with tears and pain - I'm comfortable with myself," he says.

"I may be funny-looking - I'm tall, my voice is unusual and my manner very animated ... the opposite of a suit and tie corporate man.

"But what I think is that inside the corporate man is a poet and a storyteller wanting to come out.

"And as the men's movement spreads around the world, more men are becoming freer and more colourful and warmer."

If there is one thing for which Biddulph is known to crusade, then it is for what he sees as the last and "possibly most essential" liberation movement of the century - the men's movement.

He stresses that it aims to produce not effeminate and effete men - a kind of "new age sensitive man" with a stronger feminine psyche than male - but rather fully masculine men who are still male in every sense of the word but who, at the same time, are able to express and to share their feelings and to communicate with their wives and with other men.

"Sometimes people say that men have to get in touch with their feminine side to be nurturing or kind.

"I think that's a terrible thing to say because it suggests that masculine doesn't go with being caring.

"But if I'm cuddling a baby or listening to a friend who is a bit distressed, then that's a masculine activity ... it's masculine to care for children and it's masculine to prepare food and there's a masculine way of doing that - I am not an imitation mother."

Bidduplh feels confident that the corner has been turned, that boys and men are changing.

Soon, he says, "we will raise a boy who is in touch with his feelings".

During his talk Biddulph tells the audience, "there are probably 100 things to know about fathering but I know five and will share them with you".

In a nutshell, his five golden rules are: "Spend time with your son."

Steve is known to have said that "if a father works more than 55 hours a week he will fail as a parent".

"If you work long hours you will damage your daughters - and you will cripple your sons," he says.

Only by spending time - and lots of it - with children, are parents able to enjoy what Bidduplh calls "those magic moments" (One never knows when they will happen).

Rule two: "Play rough and tumble games with sons". (Because little boys love to wrestle).

Three: "Teach sons to respect women". ("At age 14, a young boy notices that he is bigger than his mother. The thought crosses his mind - 'she cannot make me do it'".)

Rule Four: "Honour their tender feelings." (Allow children to be sad and to be scared.)

Bidduplh's fifth rule is one that he regards as important and often overlooked.

"Teach sons to do housework."

"If you ask your son 'How was school?' you will probably get a one word 'Fine'," he says.

"But if you spend time with him and, say, teach him how to cook a souffle, you will find he will talk more easily to you."


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
Seven arrested in pre-dawn raid on Crossroads


BYLINE: Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - Police and the defence force confiscated drugs, a stolen gun, and other stolen property in a huge pre- dawn raid on Boys Town in Old Crossroads today.

Police spokesman Mark Romburgh said the operation, by at least 400 police and soldiers, was launched at 4am after a tip-off that criminals were operating from the area.

Police from the Public Order Policing Services Unit sealed off the area with barbed wire and manned a control point while members of other units, including the Dog Unit and the Gang Unit, did door-to-door searches. 

Police arrested seven people for possession of an illegal firearm and a stolen cellphone and dealing in dagga. A stolen car, three drums of dagga, a 7.65 calibre revolver, and a new roll-up garage door were confiscated.

Simon Mpembe, chief of Pro-Active Policing in the West Metropole division, who led the raid said the operation went smoothly and he was delighted that the Boys Town community had openly welcomed the police.

Police would conduct similar raids in Crossroads and other areas more regularly in future, Director Mpembe added.

* Police have ordered a clampdown on the release of all current crime statistics - forcing the media and the public to rely on officially audited quarterly reports which will only be made public several months later.

Johannesburg police spokesman Mark Reynolds confirmed that police commissioner George Fivaz had issued the order. Mr Fivaz's order confirmed an earlier directive issued in January, Inspector Reynolds said.

Originally, the order applied only to area headquarters. Now it has been extended to local police station level. Previously stations had been allowed to release "operational statistics", a term which had never been clearly defined, he said.

Head of police communications, Director Joseph Ngobeni, said the clampdown had been ordered by the ministry of safety and security. Only quarterly reports could be released because the information would be "audited, accurate and credible". The report for the period January-March 1997 would only be released next week.

Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi's spokesman, Maxwell Malaudzi, last night denied the clampdown had been ordered by the minister, saying "it was a recommendation from police management".

Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
City fire chief douses Olympic flame in Mall


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Cape Town - An Olympic flame was to have been lit in St George's Mall, but the idea has been doused by Cape Town's fire chief as a danger to public safety.

The unlit copy of the Olympic torch has been standing in the mall outside Nedbank, one of the official sponsors of Cape Town's 2004 Bid, for several months. 

Fire chief Don Sparks told Cape Town municipality's engineering services committee yesterday it would be "irresponsible" of him to allow the flame, because of the risk of a gas explosion.

Mr Sparks said the fire service was guided by South African Bureau of Standards rules that gas cylinders be in locked cages, usually on private premises.

The gas needed for the Olympic torch would amount to "a bomb" in the mall, said Mr Sparks.

A spokesman said that Nedcor accepted the fire department's decision, and a new home would be found for the torch.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Winning on the field and off it (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Cape Town - It must be the rugby season. It's early June, the Lions are here, the slanging matches and the controversies have intensified

Rugby tours to a country as obsessed with the game as ours is are more than mere visits by international sports teams. What happens off the field often takes on a life of its own and becomes as significant as what transpires on it. 

This is not a uniquely South African phenomenon. It's the same in New Zealand, a similarly rugby-crazy country. It is definitely the case when England and Australia come to grips in an Ashes series.

Who can say how much Mark Waugh motivated England with his disparaging remarks about English cricket shortly before the present series? His contempt for the England team must have been one reason why the English bowlers were so charged up, and so successful, against Australia's batsmen yesterday.

The mind game is as vital in sport as the physical effort. That is why the psychological sparring is often more than just hype. The propaganda war between the touring British Lions and their hosts started long before our rugby visitors arrived; it has only become more intense since they landed.

Whatever their skills on the field - and these have been impressive - the Lions have shown themselves to be masters in the art of psyching their opponents.

Already they have reduced to ridicule a principal antagonist, James Small, and exposed some of our players - second-stringers admittedly - as vicious brutes, while deflecting perceptions of weaknesses on their part. They have emerged from the squabble with Small and the assault in Witbank as men of iron discipline.

All this while our rugby is again embroiled in internecine war, this time between the national coach and the WP one. The Lions must be laughing. If we can't get our off the field act together, let's hope we can do it on the field. It would be sad if we lost both battles.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


148 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
W Cape accounts for one in five Mediation cases


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Cape Town - One in five cases referred to the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) during its first two months of operation came from the Western Cape.

Of the 2 917 disputes referred to it, Gauteng province accounted for 31%.

CCMA director Charles Nupen told a news conference that the commercial and distributive sector accounted for 19% of cases. 

A surprising trend was that domestic workers and the agricultural sector accounted for 4% each of cases the CCMA handled.

Before the commission was established, domestic workers and farm labourers seldom resorted to mediation to resolve disputes with their employers, Mr Nupen said.

The CCMA was established in November to resolving disputes between employers and employees in the quickest possible time. Previously complainants had to wait for months before their cases were resolved.

Mr Nupen yesterday presented the commission's first annual report to Parliament.

It contained few surprises, with the bulk of issues mediated involving unfair dismissal disputes.

The CCMA had conducted 1 244 conciliations between November and December and had settled 86% of these, the report said.

Gauteng province, the industrial hub of South Africa, had 382 cases and the Western Cape 245.

Mr Nupen said Labour Minister Tito Mboweni had appointed an Essential Services Committee which would operate under the auspices of the CCMA.

The committee was established to investigate which sectors performed essential services, that if interrupted, could harm the South African population.

Mr Mboweni, who was also at the news conference, said the CCMA had done magnificent work in a short space of time.

The commission had resolved labour disputes that could have been harmful to the economy, Mr Mboweni said.

Earlier this year, the CCMA was reported to be drowning in a sea of cases, with workers referring the smallest disputes to the body commission.

Mr Nupen said at the time that some of the disputes could have been solved without the CCMA's intervention.

As a result of the workload, the Government granted the CCMA an increased annual budget of R120 million, which enabled it to hire an additional 40 commissioners, Mr Nupen said.

"We are in the process of interviewing people throughout the country," Mr Nupen said.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
Cape Town names big parking 'criminals'


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Cape Town - The hunt is on for Cape Town's most wanted "parking criminals", who owe thousands of rands in fines. Their cars will be impounded if they don't declare themselves to the traffic department.

A "hot-list" of the vehicles with the highest number of outstanding parking fines has been released by the department. 

Public parking enemy No 1 is a BMW, last seen in Queen Victoria Street, which has accumulated R5 400 in parking tickets.

All 43 vehicles on the May list owe more than R1 000 in fines.

Cape Town traffic chief Mark Sangster describes the offenders as "professional parking criminals who play cat- and-mouse with the traffic department".

He said the owners often did not register changes of address or notify the authorities when their vehicles changed hands.

The hot list details makes of cars, registration numbers, how much money is owed, and where the vehicles were last seen. This has been the practice of the traffic department for several years, but has not been publicised until now.

Councillor Ian Iversen suggested the list be published so Cape Town citizens could "spot the criminal" and inform the traffic department.

If the vehicles are found, they may be towed to the traffic headquarters at Gallows Hill, Green Point, in terms of a section of the Road Traffic Act.

When an owner arrives to collect a vehicle, the name and address of the responsible person will be verified and any summonses or warrants will be served.

The traffic department is not able to keep vehicles until the fines have been paid, but draft regulations to decriminalise road traffic offences authorise officials to immobilise vehicles until outstanding fines, plus a 20 percent surcharge, are paid.

The draft legislation also states that no vehicle will be licensed unless all outstanding fines, costs and levies are paid.

In the meantime, a sub-committee of councillors is formulating an action plan based on "equal justice and equal service" to deal with outstanding warrants of arrest for traffic offences.

In another move aimed at improving parking control, the council's engineering services committee has authorised a pilot scratch-card system for parking at the Rondebosch Fountain lot. Drivers will buy cards to display and scratch out the relevant window for date and time of parking.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Swaziland;
Swaziland faces national strike after negotiations fail


BYLINE: Sabelo Dlamini, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Swaziland faces crippling strikes by both teachers and civil servants after their unions abandoned salary negotiations with the small kingdom's Government on Thursday.

The Swaziland National Association of Teachers (SNAT) and Swaziland National Association of Civil Servants (SNACS) withdrew from the talks after the government refused to budge on paying civil servants for the month they were on strike in 1996. 

The 1996 strike was called by Swaziland's Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU) to press government to democratize. Teachers and civil servants joined it to press government to pay them an 18 percent salary increment.

The government refused however, offering only a 12 percent increase.

In February, the SFTU called another national strike, which collapsed because both teachers and civil servants refused to support it. SNAT subsequently led a teachers mass meeting in March to approach King Mswati lll directly with their grievances.

The King instructed Government to refund them the money withheld for the strike, because they had compensated by working during holidays to make up for "lost time".

SNAT's success however soured relations with SNACS which claimed that they had been betrayed and therefore started separate negotiations with government.

This week, SNACS and SNACS patched up their differences and presented a joint negotiating team to Government.

After the meeting with Government representatives, SNAT president Meshack Masuku said teachers have also pulled out from the talks in solidarity with the claim for refund by civil servants.

He said they cannot continue with negotiations when their colleagues have an outstanding grievance. He said they have given government until Monday to pay the outstanding money, failing which, they will consider other options.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
Heath investigation unit slams former Transkei leader


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Nelspruit - The head of South Africa's most powerful investigation unit, Judge Wilem Heath slammed former Transkei military leader Bantu Holomisa on Monday for questioning the motives of his probe into possible irregular salary increases just before the 1994 elections.

Holomisa charged two weeks ago that the unit was conducting a malicious and unsubstantiated vendetta against him for suggesting that he and his military council had irregularly increased their salaries by 20 percent just days before the 1994 elections.

The increase is allegedly costing the government R342 000 per month, indicating a potential R500-million loss over the past three years. 

The charge, first printed in the Mail & Guardian two weeks ago, follows an investigation by Heath's special unit which has reputedly already recovered or saved the government R10- billion through what it terms "search and seizure" operations.

Heath told the M&G on Wednesday that the unit, which has the same executive powers as a high court in civil matters, has also just uncovered additional information indicating that similar increases were approved for Transkei's public service commission.

It is not certain how much the additional increases is costing the government.

Holomisa emphatically denies the charges and insists that that Heath is serving "political masters" in an attempt to smear his name.

"This is the second time you have rushed into corespondence and make wild allegations without first establishing the facts ... I am far too busy to waste time on such an allegation," Heath said in a four page letter to Holomisa on Monday.

Dismissing Holomisa's allegations as completely without foundation and of being highly insulting to both the unit and Heath in person, the letter accuses Holomisa of relying on "negative views".

Holomisa in turn insists that his last promotion, from the rank of brigadier to major-general, had been in 1987 by former Transkei leader George Matanzima. Holomisa challenged Heath to publish documentation proving otherwise.

"The issue is not really about a promotion as such, in the sense that he was not given a higher rank but rather a 20 percent salary increase just before the elections," said special investigation unit member, advocate Gerhart Visagie.

"The documentation we have, including an internal Transkei memorandum, indicates that Holomisa's salary, as the military council chairman, increased from R250 158 to R303 789."

The documentation also indicates that other Transkei leaders, including the president, twelve ministers, the auditor general, public service commission chairman and a number of paramount chiefs all received the same 20 percent increase.

"We have this proof but every time we investigate anything connected to Holomisa, he immediately reacts strongly," adds Visagie.

Judge Heath confirmed that the unit's investigation into Holomisa was not yet complete but stressed that he only needed one or two more statements and a couple of weeks before initiating civil action.

"Holomisa's response to this whole thing is once again very derogatory of both me and the unit. It is not the first time that he has reacted like this. In January of last year, he wrote me a letter out of the blue accusing us of being biased for investigating a house he bought in the Transkei," said Heath

Holomisa insists that he retained his salary as a commander of the Transkei Defense Force, which includes standard tax deductible allowances, and that he has still not received his "long overdue" early retirement pension.

Holomisa reportedly qualifies for the pension in terms of the 1978 Defence Act but the government still has to process and approve his application.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
MEC misinformed legislature about housing scheme


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga Housing Board members continued to insist this week that they were never briefed about Motheo's R185-million housing project.

Amongst those questioning the scheme's approval is National Party representative, Jakkie van Heerden, who told Mail & Guardian that the board was not informed about the project.

Conceding that he had missed one board meeting in January, where Moodley claims that the scheme was discussed and approved by the board, Van Heerden said that according to the minutes of the meeting there had not been a quorum.

The minutes indicate that there were only six members at the meeting while a quorum would consist of at least eight members, he said. 

"The only thing contained in the minutes of that meeting is that the executive committee wanted approval to allocate various stands to a rural developer. There was a description of the stands but no detail on Motheo or the scheme itself."

Explaining the granting of rural housing had previously been prohibited because rural applicants seldom had a legal title deed to the land they wanted to build on, Van Heerden said he doubted that the necessary regulations and other ordinances had been drafted to allow for the scheme to be launched.

"I mean, there are loads of town councils and other bodies in the province just itching to provide housing for their rural or tribal trust residents. If these regulations existed, why has no-one else jumped in to take advantage," he asked.

"Why have there been no public adverts or education campaigns to explain to rural residents how to qualify?"

Insisting that the council had never been fully briefed on Motheo, Van Heerden added that even when news of the "massive" scheme reached board members through other channels they had been unable to ask question about it because not enough members arrive at the board's last three meetings to constitute a quorum.

"The only time we heard anything about rural housing was when Moodley gave a generalised verbal report to the board in November last year but no mention was ever made of Motheo of any similar scheme," said Van Heerden.

"The minutes of the meeting confirm this and in fact also prove that we ruled that while we are not against rural housing in any way, we felt it was important that any potential schemes be brought back to the board for full discussion before implementation or approval."

Van Heerden accused Moodley of "talking nonsense" for insisting otherwise.

Meanwhile, the chairman of Mpumalanga's standing select committee on housing, Hein Mentz this week accused housing MEC Craig Padayachee of misinforming the committee about Motheo last week.

"We don't know whether he consciously lied to us, whether he was misinformed or whether he simply did not know what was goring on in his department, but he definitely didn't give us the true facts on Motheo," Mentz told M&G on Wednesday.

Amongst the "errors" Padayachee made while testifying before the committee was his insistence that the Motheo scheme had been formally approved by the board on February 20.

"There was never a meeting on February 20 so it couldn't have been approved as he insisted, but this was just one of a string of such errors. There were just too many questions put to the department's heads that could not be answered," added Mentz.

These included an annual report which did not balance by R4,5-million. According to Mentz, officials had to scramble for days before discovering that the funds were in a developer's trust account.

"If we' hadn't noticed that the report didn't balance and hadn't asked about the figure, no-one would have known about this money just sitting there," explained Mentz.

Because of the amount of queries on both the department's annual report and proposed 1997/ 98 budget, a second standing select committee session will be held later this month. No date has yet been set for the hearing.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - General;
SADC ministers back Cape Olympics bid


BYLINE: Ronny Mamba, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - All sports ministers in the South African Development Community (SADC) countries will soon publicly announce their support for Cape Town's bid to host the Olympic Games in 2004, said Swaziland sport and home affairs minister Prince Guduza Dlamini on Thursday.

Prince Guduza told African Eye News Service (South Africa) after returning from the Lusaka meeting of SADC ministers of Information, Culture and Sport, that all member ministers were unanimous that a successful Cape Town bid would be good for the region. 

The meeting, Prince Guduza said, resolved to ask African heads of state meeting at the OAU conference in Harare to endorse the resolution.

SADC ministers are also concerned with the contribution of women in sport. Each country is to investigate ways of encouraging women participation and make recommendations to be tabled at another meeting of sports ministers in Swaziland in October.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Swaziland;
Dagga plantation found on Swaziland Prime Minister's farm


BYLINE: Ronny Mamba, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

MANZINI (Swaziland) - Royal Swazi Police have found slightly over three kilogrammes of dagga and 18 dagga 'trees' on a farm owned by Swaziland's puritan Prime Minister Sibusiso Dlamini. The police confirmed on Thursday that they have arrested a 27-year-old labourer in connection with the find at the farm, which is about 20km north east of the commercial hub of the kingdom. 

The dagga is said to have been reported to the Prime Minister by workers who found the well developed shrubs growing on an isolated portion of the farm.

According to police, the "furious" Prime Minister immediately called the them and ordered a team to stake the area out and arrest those responsible.

"We swooped on the farm over the weekend and arrested the man who planted the trees after finding dagga on him He is expected to appear in court soon," said police spokesman, Sergeant Victor Dlamini.

Dagga is often called Swaziland's gold because it is held in high esteem among international abusers who claim that it is one of the more potent varieties grown around the world.

Growers are increasingly turning to modern farming technology and now use irrigation, fertiliser and pesticides to ensure rich harvests.

Since winter is the normal harvest season for the drug, police have been busy raising remote areas of the country and destroying the crop.

Sergeant Dlamini added that police raided five farms and destroyed huge quantities of dagga in May alone.

He said police are intensifying their fight against both drug abuse, peddling and smuggling.

LANGUAGE: English

June 6, 1997


Swaziland;
Rapist claims incest is Swazi tradition


BYLINE: Ronny Mamba, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - A 47-year old man charged with the repeated rape of his 12-year-old daughter claimed in Mbabane's Magistrate's Court on Thursday that incest was a traditional Swazi family custom.

The man who may not be named to protect the identity of the minor, appeared before Mbabane Principal Magistrate and told the court that his own father was actually his grandfather who had made his daughter pregnant. 

The man cited Christian scriptures to back his claim that incest was morally acceptable.

The court also heard that the mother of the 12-year-old victim was the actually the man's half sister, born from a different mother in a Swazi polygamous family.

The case was postponed until July 8 for further police investigation.

156 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Senators' want to cut funding for "embarrassing" soccer team


BYLINE: Sabelo Dlamini, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - An international friendly game between Swaziland's National team, Sihlangu, and Malawi next month will be scrapped if two influential Swaziland senators have their way.

The two, former Prime Minister Senator Prince Bhekimpi and Senator Walter Bennet insist that spending money on the national soccer team is "investing in embarrassment".

The senators point out that the Swazi national team has established a "proud" tradition of never making it beyond the preliminaries in international tournaments but stress that it is not only the ability of the team that irks them. 

Swaziland's soccer administration they say, is in such a shambles it does not deserve public funds. The administration has been criticised for failing to collect gate takings properly. Swaziland's once illustrious football industry, which produced the likes of Scara Thindwa, now Wits University Coach, Abel Shongwe, and Chief's long-time goalie William "Cool Cat" Shongwe as well as a host of others who graced the South African professional soccer league in the Eighties has lost most of its shine.

As a soccer country, the Kingdom was ranked 106th in the world by FIFA. Now it is number 163, well behind Namibia, Lesotho and even Botswana.

It is not only the politicians who are voting with their feet. Even coaches are keeping a respectful distance these days.

Earlier this year, Thindwa, one of the celebrated soccer greats here, returned with great fanfare to coach Sihlangu against Mozambique. The squad started off playing a in polished style but disintegrated into a panic and were soundly thrashed.

At the end of the game, it was Thindwa who departed the Somhlolo stadium in a hurry, with unsportsmanly fans baying for his blood.

They blamed his game-style for the loss. He did not bother to stay long enough to explain but quit and returned to South Africa.

His successor has not lasted either. Bizzah Mkhonta, a veteran of the national team has also quit.

Last month, the fund raising committee for the team also quit en-masse, complaining of poor management by the National Football Association.

The cure from the Senators, is to switch off government funds for soccer. Maybe then, they say, things will cool down enough to find a solution.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Anti-corruption figure takes over Swaziland sugar body


BYLINE: Donny Nxumalo, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Swaziland's former anti-corruption finance minister, Derek von Wissell, is poised to take the kingdom's top agricultural job as chief executive of the powerful Swaziland Sugar Association (SSA).

Von Wissell, who recently resigned in protest from the government after he was transferred from finance to tourism, will take over from Andy Colhoun who left the Association at the end of his contract in May.

Von Wissell's transfer was linked at the time to his uncompromising stance on corruption and his exposure of leading royalty and politicians in the Swazi Bank scandal. 

Sugar is the second largest revenue earner in Swaziland's economy after customs union receipts and the SSA plays an important role in both the government and private sector's economic policy process.

An acknowledged successful businessman in the sugar business, Von Wissell became the chief of Natie Kirshs Swaki Group of companies before he was drafted into the Swaziland cabinet in 1993.

He served as minister for health, then finance before he quit in protest to his transfer to the relatively junior post of tourism - an act which soured his relationship with the Swaziland royal family.

In the past few weeks, the Swaziland Sugar Association sought a replacement for long serving CEO Andy Coulhoun who retired last week.

Although Von Wissell was the preferred choice, he faced a huge hurdle - mending his relations with the King who was angered with his resignation from the cabinet.

Palace insiders however report that he has approached the King and apologised, which has cleared the way.

Despite having the sugar industry's full backing, Von Wissell still needed the King's blessing for the job because the Royal conglomerate Tibiyo TakaNgwane holds 40 percent in the sugar industry. Tibiyo reports directly to the King.

Dr von Wissell is a very popular figure in Swaziland, after exposing a free loan racket where prominent public figures in Swaziland gave themselves free loans from the Swaziland Development and Savings Bank, known as the Swazi Bank - thus leading to its collapse.

As CEO of the sugar association, Von Wissell will be faced with the challenge of repairing relations between the South African Sugar Association which canceled links with Swaziland over market wars.

Sports - Soccer;
Kalusha donates to ZYFA


BYLINE: Chimwemwe Mwanza, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - National soccer team captain Kalusha Bwalya yesterday donated football kit worth millions of kwacha to the Zambia Youth Football Association (ZYFA).

Presenting the donation to ZYFA general secretary, Emment Mushunga, at Intercontinental Hotel, Kalusha said that the future of Zambian soccer lies in the youths and as such there was need to pump in massive investment in the development of youth football. 

"We need to help youths from Kasama, Chipata, Mansa and Mongu so that one day these same youths may play for Zambia," Kalusha said.

The kit which included football and jerseys will be used by the youths under ZYFA when a youth soccer project called Kalusha Bwalya youth tournament gets underway later this year.

Receiving the donation on behalf of ZYFA Mushunga praised Kalusha for his contribution to the development of soccer in the country.

He said that Kalusha's efforts should be emulated by many Zambians if the country has to raise its soccer standards: "We are very thankfull for the effort our captain of the national team Kalusha is making towards the development of soccer in this country."

Africa News


June 6, 1997


South Africa;
Chikane Inquires About Violations to TRC


BYLINE: South African Communication Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


Pretoria - The Reverend Frank Chikane, the Director-General in the Office of the Deputy President, Mr Thabo Mbeki, and Vice President and Pastor of the Apostolic Faith Mission of South Africa, has written a letter to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) inquiring as to whether or not anyone has applied for indemnity in respect of gross human rights violations perpetrated against him between January 1977 and June 1989.

The Revd Frank Chikane also wants to know whether or not anyone has made any disclosures relating to the issue raised above.

Between January 1977 and June 1989 the Rev. Frank Chikane was detained several times without trial, brutally beaten and tortured. His Pimville, Zone 7 house was attacked with petrol-bombs and in 1989 he was poisoned with an organophosphate chemical. 

In a letter to Chikane dated 5 November 1996 the Minister of Safety and Security, Mr Sydney Mufamadi, said that Mr Paul Erasmus, who is alleged to have knowledge about the poisoning experience, was in the witness protection programme of the Department of Justice. The Deputy Attorney-General, Dr Pretorius, is also reported to have said that subsequent to the recent evidence by former Colonel Eugene de Kock the Attorney-General's Office had become "aware of more names of possible witnesses and/or perpetrators who could assist in this investigation".

As the Police could not gain access to the witnesses it was agreed between the Department of Safety and Security and the Attorney-General that further investigations on this matter be conducted by the Office of the Attorney-General.

Revd. Frank Chikane has expressed serious concern that no progress has been reported to him in this regard. He has written a letter to the Attorney-General of the Transvaal to enquire about progress in this matter.

The Revd. Frank Chikane is also concerned about a report from the Police service that the FBI has destroyed all exhibits such as fluid samples and clothing relating to this incident. Only copies of the medical reports compiled at the time of the incident in the USA are still available.

Issued by the Office of the Deputy President, 5 June 1997, Pretoria.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia to be redeemed, assures coach Mungwa


BYLINE: Sheikh Chxifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - National squad coach George Mungwa has assured to do the nation well when the team meets Bafana Bafana in group three of the World Cup qualifier this Sunday.

Mungwa made the assurance after watching the squad yesterday afternoon in a training game against Zanaco in which the bankers forced for a one all draw at Independence Stadium. 

"We shall cross the bridge when we get there but what I can all say is that we shall do a nice job for the nation," Mungwa said ahead of the match that Zambia needs to win to brighten her chances to the World Cup finals in France next year.

Mungwa is well aware, losing to the African champions will shatter the country's dreams of qualifying for the 32 nations World Cup competitions which kicks off in June.

The squad skipper Kalusha Bwalya though has a lot of respect for the African champions was optimistic Zambia will carry the day and probably lead the team to Europe.

The team leaves this afternoon for Johannesburg ending speculation that they might camp in a neigbouring country before the day of the game to keep away from the South African 'spies'.

"There is no need of camping elsewhere, we are going straight to South Africa," said Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) treasurer Musa Kasonka Jr. who is also expected to lead the entourage.

Bafana Bafana have only beaten Zambia once during the Nelson Mandela inuaguration cup since their return to continental competition following the end of apathied in 1993.

Vice-captain Johnson Bwalya though regreting the earlier results of the games against Congo and Congo-Kishansa was now in top form than ever and promised to do his best to earn the country a passage to France.
