June 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Litana's arrival is still a secret


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - The arrival of defence pillar from his Saudi Arabian club, Al Hilal will remain a secret until he joins the squad for the Sunday do-or-break World Cup qualifier encounter against Bafana Bafana.

Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) treasurer Musa Kasonka Jr. in an interview yesterday said that it was better to keep the opponents guessing. 

"Litana is definitely coming but I can't tell you when because I don't want South Africans to know our strategy," said Kasonka in an interview yesterday.

National stand-in coach George Mungwa also assured fans that Litana would join the squad before they leave for Johannesburg today although indications are that he will fly straight to South Africa tomorrow.

The team doctor Wesley Gondwe disclosed that all the players in camp were injury free including Andrew Tembo who joined camp on Monday following a knee injury that kept him from active soccer for almost a month.

"All the players are physically alright and fit for the match unless there are any other injuries," assured Gondwe in an interview Wednesday after watching team undergo strenuous training.

The squad leaves this morning for Johannesburg by Royal Swazi and is expected to train tomorrow at the First National Bank (FNB) Stadium, the venue of the decisive encounter for France '98.

South African coach Clive Barker has said the loss by his side to Holland in the Nelson Mandela inauguration Cup last night will not have any bearing on the outcome of the Sunday game.

Barker's consolation is that most of the players he used in the match they lost 2-0 will not be in his starting line- up.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Seeing It My Way: Studying abroad (Column)


BYLINE: Mulenga Makumya, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Lusaka - I recall what the Presi- dent said a few weeks ago about the informal sector and it's role in the development of a nation. President Frederick Chiluba was addressing the nation on Labour day in Kitwe.

What I found amusing was the little Freudian slip he made which made me realise that he had some kind of hang up about his educational background. There is one statement that he made which exposed an underlying inferiority complex on his part. It was rather painful to watch and I must admit that I squirmed through the whole incident. 

The statement which made me nearly weep was the one that he made to the effect that he had been Chairman of an ILO Committee on the informal sector and "not just some Zambian committee..."

What did that statement mean? Are Zambian Committees inferior and lacking in some way? Can we not be proud of that which is Zambian ?

I was left wondering if these were the same had made such a fuss about "Zambia for Zambians". From Chiluba's statement it was quite clear that he was not for Zambia but for some outside international organisation. I suppose that if the President had been in charge of a Zambia Congress of Trade Union Committee on the informal sector he would have been ashamed to talk about it. I am sure that he would have buried this fact from the public as he does so well with so many genuinely unpalatable facts about his past.

Having heard Chiluba talk about how his knowledge about the informal sector was so advanced because it was not a Zambian committee that he chaired, I begun to understand more about our dear President. His driving force and inspiration also came into better focus as I realised that nothing in Zambia can inspire him.

This probably explains why he had to twist the truth and pretend to the Commonwealth that he had been educated abroad! This is the claim which he put into his bio data for the NewZealand Commonwealth meeting publication. Chiluba must have thought that the other leaders would think less of him if he admitted that he was educated in Zambia.

Having attended school in Musangu and at Mambilima Falls cannot be termed as being schooled abroad. Only foreigners would state that attending Zambian schools constitutes being educated abroad. Was Chiluba perhaps trying to tell us something?

I hope that one of these days Chiluba will have another address to the nation where he will devote time to explain his education abroad. After all he did so well with the explanation over the "O" and "A" levels. We all still remember the famous "ungraded pass" explaination. For his studies abroad Chiluba can always tell us, at his next address to the nation, that in this day and age of the computer and internet he had been studying abroad in cyberspace. The Commonwealth office must be at a loss as to what to do to their publication containing Chiluba's bio data. I am certain that there will be a corrigendum in any subsequent reprints of the same.

At the rate things are going I would not be too surprised if we next see Chiluba sporting an Eton or Cambridge tie. He could always borrow Lucy Sichone's Oxford tie so long as she promised not to tell.

Chiluba's hang up over everything Zambian and indigenous has even led him into giving his children the most improbable names. What would have been wrong with Mulenga, Inonge or even Mabvuto for Castro? It certainly would have more meaning and relevance.

This however could not be as we all have to know that Chiluba has an international flavour about him. The closest he got to home is with the name Patrice. Some say that infact with that one he came further than just too close to home.

It is in this light that we must look at Chiluba's statement regarding why we should listen to him over the issue of the street vendors. His years as chairman of the ILO special committee on informal sector taught him that street vendors are productive and are what we call the small scale industrial sector.

Oh by the way Mr. President, the informal sector that the international organisations try to encourage are not street vendors and thieving peddlers.

The informal sector referred to as being industry, productive and a spur to indus-trialisation would be activities like carpentry, back yard garages, blacksmithing or tailoring shops in the spare bedroom. These people produce.

Someone hawking already finished goods imported from Thailand Taiwan or South Africa does not produce anything and does not in any way spur development and industry in Zambia.

It is a pity that the President did not go to any local institutions such as Kabwe Trades or even sit on some local NGO's committee on the informal sector. Even the Tasinta group would have told him that to help people into being productive you do not give them cheap goods dumped from abroad to hawk on our streets.

I hope that the ILO committee on the informal sector that Chiluba chaired has since changed it's outlook on the informal sector and what constitutes industry.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Sweden now ties aid to dialogue


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Sweden will only consider restoring Zambia's balance of payment support when there is political dialogue in the country.

Swedish Ambassador to Zambia, Kristina Svesson, speaking at the official launching of Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation's (ZESCO) national control centre yesterday said dialogue between the government and all the political parties was essential towards the development of a nation.

"My country Sweden is supporting a political dialogue because in a democracy all parties must give their contribution to peaceful and prosperous development of the nation," Ambassador Svensson said. "When we see this dialogue taking place we will consider to release our balance of payment support." 

Ambassador Svensson, however, commended Zambia on the strides taken towards good governance.

She said she was aware that there was goodwill towards the establishment of political dialogue by the government although the "goodwill should be manifest in actions".

Environment minister Suresh Desai, speaking at same function, said his government would remain committed to dialogue with opposition political parties to enhance development in the country.

But Liberal Progressive Front president Rodger Chongwe, in an interview yesterday said, there was no dialogue between the government and all stakeholders in the country.

"Mr. Chiluba and his associates in the MMD talk about dialogue but they are doing nothing. Dialogue means talking to all political parties and cooperating partners but Chiluba is just talking to donors and not the Zambians. I am afraid he is holding the wrong side of the stick," Chongwe said. "What he must do is call all political parties and non- governmental organisations to discuss the rigged 1996 general elections and the shambolic and fake constitution so that we all come to a common stand."

Zambia Democratic Congress president, Dean Mung'omba, accused the government of lack of seriousness in implementing dialogue.

"There has been lack of seriousness by the government. All they just say in the press is that they want dialogue but do not put in place proper mechanism for dialogue. Dialogue is not just shaking hands and drinking tea and we will continue to pressure the players so that this issue is resolved," Mung'omba said.

And Zambia Independent monitoring Team president, Alfred Zulu, said the government's claims of political dialogue was just political rhetoric.

"The government has not done anything to initiate political dialogue with stake holders. All what is being said about their commitment is just political rhetoric but they have not shown any direction in the issue except for President Chiluba's statement at the Africa Freedom Day celebrations," Zulu said in an interview yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Southern Africa;
Business and Finance;
SADC trade protocol won't benefit Zambia, says Mumba


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - Zambia will not ratify the Southern African Development Community (SADC) trade protocol if the issue of "trade imbalance" in the region is not sorted out.

Musanzala MMD member of parliament, Levy Mumba, attending a three day SADC Trade workshop in Cape Town yesterday said Zambia has not benefited from the Trade protocol ever since the Maseru treaty which gave way to the birth of SADC was signed. 

"We will not ratify the protocol which was signed in Lusaka unless certain issues are resolved," Mumba said in an interview at Johannesburg International Airport on Wednesday. "The major problem are the countries such as South Africa, Namibia and Swaziland which are in SADC and the South African Customs Union (SACU). They enjoy certain rights which we non- SACU members don't. Hence making our goods less competitive in the region."

He noted that South Africa has an eye on the new Democratic Republic of Congo but warned that Zambia will make passage of South African goods bound from Zaire difficult if the foregoing is not sorted out.

"There are several issues that we shall raise," Mumba said.

Zambia is being represented by eight members of parliament, all of whom are chairmen of various parliamentary select committee's at the workshop which is being held in the Old Parliament chamber in Cape Town. The delegation leader is Foreign Committee chairman, Vernon Mwaanga - a self confessed drug-trafficker.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Electricity tariffs to go up


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - Electricity tariffs in the country will be increased over the next few years to enable Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) to recover operational costs and make a "modest profit", disclosed energy minister Suresh Desai yesterday.

Desai, officially opening the rehabilitated ZESCO's national electricity control centre yesterday, said the corporation had been operating at a loss because of uneconomic tariffs that it was charging for its services.

"The present electricity tariffs are highly sub-economic. It will remain my ministry's policy to allow electricity tariffs to gradually rise over the coming few years to levels which allow the power industry in Zambia to recover cost to make a modest profit to ensure the self sustain ability of the industry," Desai said. 

Desai said the low tariffs had resulted in slow break down of the ZESCO infrastructure which was currently in dire need of overhaul.

"We cannot continue to run the industry at loss and then expect foreign governments to foot the bill or the rehabilitation and expansion of ZESCO's infrastructure," Desai said.

The new centre would enable ZESCO to control their entire power transmission network from the headquarters in Lusaka.

Swedish Ambassador, Kristina Svesson, said her country was happy to be associated with the project and was ready to help.

Ambassador Svesson said her government had given ZESCO a grant of US$12 million for the project which included the up- grading of equipment, computerisation of the control centre and provision of expertise.

Ambassador Svesson further said Sweden's reason for assisting rehabilitate to the centre was to improve the control station to enable it give better control of the flow of electricity.

"As the surplus of the generated electricity will be exported to neignbouring countries, the modernising of the control centre means more export income to Zambia. And that is indeed needed," Ambassador Svesson said.

ZESCO, however, contributed K3 billion in local costs towards the project.

Energy Board chairman Rahel Selasini, however, said his board would help ensure protection of the consumer.

"Although our board has just been constituted we will ensure that the consumers are not exploited and also at the same time that the energy provider does not go bust," Selasini said in an interview yesterday. "We would like to see justifiable tariffs."


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia's economic growth rate to decline


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Slowed growth in the Zambian economy has been forecast for this year following poor performance by the agricultural sector.

Standard Chartered Bank Zambia, in the latest edition of its African Quarterly report on the performance of economies of countries in the region, Zambia would experience a drop in the growth of the agro sector by 12 per cent although expected investment in the mining sector is likely to make up for the fall. 

"In 1997, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is expected to slow to between four to five per cent, mainly because of the of the rebound factor in agriculture, which will have significantly less impact on the economy than last year," the Standard Chartered Bank Zambia report read in part.

Last year the agriculture sector contributed largely to growth in GDP recorded after the country achieved a good harvest which accounted for 34 per cent growth of the sector.

But this year the sector suffered adverse effects from delayed procurement and distribution of farming inputs coupled with prolonged rains which have resulted to poor yields.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Church Of Barotseland Dismisses UCZ Charges


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Allegations that the Church of Barotseland has been turned into a political mouth piece are false, said spokesman Robertson Kalaluka.

Kalaluka, reacting to press reports that some politicians have turned Church of Barotseland into a political platform and that it is intimidating members of the United Church of Zambia (UCZ) in a press release yesterday, said it was their wish to resolve the issue at a negotiation table. 

He said even though the Church of Barotseland was registered in March, this year it attained autonomous status in 1935, having been established by the Paris Evangelical Missionary Society (PEMS).

UCZ reverend, Aggrey Mushole, was quoted as having made this allegation and was supported by Oscar Mutukelwa who said Church of Barotseland was a new church.

Kalaluka said in 1965, Church of Barotseland voluntarily went into a union with the Methodist Church and the United Church of Central Africa in Rhodesia (UNCCR) to form UCZ.

Kalaluka said the Church of Barotseland and the Methodist, however, having withdrawn from the union are working out modalities of sharing the jointly owned property.

He explained that Church of Barotseland and Methodist Church jointly convened a meeting on May 28, 1997 with Synod officials with a view of doing this but they did not come.

"Finally, the likes of Reverend Mushole and Mr. Mutukelwa should refrain from wanting to resolve this matter of a serious nature through the press and should consider coming to a round table discussion," Kalaluka said.

This failure by the Synod to show up has resulted in the other two to have the same meeting on June 18.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zambia;
Reject FTJ's 'illegal' pay


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Lusaka - Reject President Frederick Chiluba's bribe given to you as salaries, Liberal Progressive Front chairman Rodger Chongwe advised Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube and other Supreme Court judges yesterday.

Chongwe, in an interview yesterday, charged that the salary increments given to Supreme Court judges and other judges by President Chiluba were unconstitutional and they should not accept them.

Chongwe, repeating his call for President Chiluba to be impeached for violating the Laws of Zambia, challenged Chief Justice Ngulube to lead the way in not accepting the President's "corrupt" salary increments.

"Justice Ngulube is the chief judge in this country and I believe he will be the last person to accept remuneration which is not properly voted for by Parliament," Chongwe said. "I look forward to hear his comment on unconstitutional salary increments being recommended to the judiciary and those paid to the judiciary since August 1996 without approval from representatives of the people of Zambia." 

Chongwe, who maintained the salaries of constitutional offices under Zambia's laws requires that an appropriation bill be brought in Parliament which the president has not done, said President Chiluba has by-passed that twice in August, last year and May 28, last week.

"I know he wants to please judges but judges, as trained lawyers, must not be bought by politicians," Chongwe said. "All the salaries awarded in August and last week are unconstitutional. I hope the Chief Justice does not accept what is unconstitutional."

Chongwe, who describes President Chiluba's actions on judges salaries as "injudicious", hopes the bench will not compromise itself through the "bribe".

"If judges succumb to such injudicious conduct they will be compromising their professionalism and no-one will respect them," Chongwe said.

National Party secretary general, Ludwig Sondashi, who like Chongwe is a practicing lawyer , also described the salary increments given to judges as constitutional.

"Judges are constitutional office holders, it is wrong for the President to award them salaries without Parliament's approval in form of a Bill," Sondashi said in an interview yesterday.

President Chiluba's latest award was made on May 28, last week under the Judges (Conditions of Service) Act the new Cap 277 of the Laws of Zambia. Section 3 of this law gives power to the President to pay "a judge such emoluments as he may by statutory instrument prescribe" while section 12 (2) allows the President to "make regulations prescribing the perquisites of office and other conditions of service including but not limited to the following - car loans, housing allowance, non-private practice allowance, funeral assistance and traveling on duty."

Section 13 attempts to repeal parts of the Constitutional Emoluments Act which relate to salaries of judges.

But lawyers interviewed say the Judges (Conditions of Service) Act is unconstitutional and that the salary increment contravenes article 119 (1) of the Constitution which states "there shall be paid to the holders of to which this article applies such salary and such allowances as may be prescribed by or under an Act of Parliament".

And 119(5) specifies the offices to which 119(1) refers and these include the Chief Justice, the Deputy Chief Justice, judges of the Supreme Court, the Attorney General, judges of the High Court, the Investigator General, the Solicitor General, Secretary to the Cabinet and the Auditor General.

And Professor Patrick Mvunga, who was leader of UNIP in Parliament when the Judges (Conditions of Service) Bill was debated between February and March last year, says he raised a lot of concerns about it at the time.

Professor Mvunga said he was worried that a constitutional matter was being taken away from Parliament and delegated to a statutory instrument for one man to decide at will salaries of judges.

Professor Mvunga further revealed that he had communicated these concerns to Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda as leader of the House but the Vice-President told him that "the judges were in favour of this arrangement because it is not cumbersome".

"Is a statutory instrument an Act of Parliament. No. This Act is therefore unconstitutional," Professor Mvunga said.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Angola;
UNSG Recommends Continuation of UN Presence in;
Angola


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

United Nations - UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has recommended a follow-on mission for Angola after the expiry, at the end of June, of the mandate of the current United Nations Angola Verification Mission, UNAVEM III.

In his report to the Security Council released on Friday, the Secretary-General recommended the establishment of the new mission as of 1 July for a period of seven months. The operation would be known as the United Nations Observer Mission in Angola, or MONUA, for its Portuguese acronym, and would have headquarters in Luanda.

The overall mandate of the follow-on mission "would be to assist the Angolan parties in consolidating peace and national reconciliation, enhancing confidence-building and creating an environment conducive to long-term stability, democratic development and rehabilitation of the country". Structurally, the mission would have the Political Division, the civilian, police, human rights, military, and administrative components, as well as the information and interpretation sections.

While noting the progress achieved so far in the peace process, the Secretary-General drew attention to the recent tensions in northern Angola. He suggested the holding of the "long-overdue" meeting between President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Dr. Jonas Savimbi inside Angola as soon as possible, to accelerate national reconciliation and the peace process in Angola.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Zaire;
UNHCR Reports More Refugees in Mbandaka


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Geneva - Small groups of about 50 to 100 refugees continue to arrive at the transit center in Mbandaka. UNHCR teams are combing the area, but are finding only a handful of refugees up and down the Congo river. There are about 400 refugees in Mbandaka awaiting to be airlifted to Rwanda. About 60 ailing refugees and 25 unaccompanied minors are scheduled to be flown to Rwanda today from Mbandaka.

On Tuesday, we received reports of a 17-year-old refugee girl raped by a soldier and the belongings of several others stolen at the transit center near the airfield at Mbandaka. After the incidents were brought to the attention of authorities, the soldier alleged to have raped the girl was publicly flogged and the two other soldiers said to be involved in robbing refugees were jailed.

Repatriation operations at the Karuba collection point near Goma remain were suspended following the killing of four refugees and a relief worker last week. We continue to discuss with the authorities resumption of operations in Karuba as soon as we get security guarantees. However, action on the killings has been stalled after several robbery incidents in Goma town against NGOs. These included a break in by armed men at the World Vision compound in Goma on Wednesday night, that prompted the withdrawal of its staff.

However, our Goma office continues with repatriation operations in other parts of the region. On Saturday, we expect to airlift about 100 refugees from the Amisi area to Rwanda.

Since the beginning of the year, UNHCR has repatriated by land and by air a total of about 225,000 Rwandan refugees from ex-Zaire. This count includes 45,000 airlifted from Kisangani and Mbandaka and 5,000 from other areas in the eastern part of the country.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Congo;
UNHCR Concerned About Refugees in Brazzaville


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Geneva - We are concerned about the situation in our transit centre 20km outside of Brazzaville. Yesterday we were denied access to the camp by armed men who appeared to be either civilians or militia in civilian clothing. The incident happened amid fighting in the city between government forces and a militia which appears to be loyal to the former President. 

The 5,000 Rwandan refugees in the camp were due to receive a food ration yesterday obviously we were unable to deliver that ration. Also the current situation appears to put in jeopardy a repatriation airlift of some of the most vulnerable people from Bilolo to Rwanda which we hoped to begin over the weekend.

The total number of Rwandan refugees in Congo is around 18,000. The group at Bilolo was the first to be transported down by barge from areas between 400 and 800 km north of Brazzaville where Rwandan refugees have crossed from the Democratic Republic of Congo. The other 13,000 people are still in these northern areas in several concentrations.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Namibia;
Namibia to consider Congo river plan


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Windhoek - The idea of taking water from the Congo River to supply Namibia's central areas, mooted by President Sam Nujoma at the Swapo Congress recently, will be considered by Government.

The Congo River runs through former Zaire. 

Over the weekend President Nujoma said a pipeline could be built where the river entered the Atlantic Ocean to carry water to the Okavango River and onwards to the Eastern Water Carrier.

However, the idea raised eyebrows in certain quarters as Namibia is currently trying to negotiate drawing an estimated 20 million cubic metres of water annually from the shared Okavango River - a project which would cost the country millions of dollars.

Richard Fry, deputy permanent secretary for Water Affairs, said the Congo idea would certainly be considered even if the Okavango pipeline link went ahead. Fry pointed out that the possibility of drawing water from the Congo was investigated a year ago and said the idea was not "out of this world".

But a lot of "diplomatic work" would have to be done first as the idea would involve a number of countries.

"Obviously this has to be studied carefully."

Due to the increase in the demand for water in the region, rivers in southern Africa such as the Zambezi and the Okavango were under pressure.

Fry said due to the volume of water in the Congo River, there was the added advantage of a bigger potential for the generation of hydro-electric power to pump the water through a pipeline.

According to President Nujoma, a pipeline to link the Congo River to the Okavango River would be less than 1 000 kilometres long.

The project, which could be implemented as a SADC initiative, would create jobs for unemployed Angolans and Namibians, noted the President.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Namibia;
Caprivi's teen sex slaves: Poverty producing 'child brides'


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Bagani - The Kxoe tribal authority this week expressed alarm over the high number of children, some as young as 11-years- old, getting married and bearing children.

The Namibian also found that socio-economic hardships are forcing young Kxoe girls to give their bodies away for money or other material benefits.

"I know of many cases in which 11-year-old Kxoe children are married and having children," senior induna of the Kxoe traditional authority in the western Caprivi, Tedius Chedau, told The Namibian on Sunday. 

Chedau said these "marriages" are becoming so frequent among 12-, 13- and 14-year-old girls that eyebrows are not even being raised, and the poverty-ravaged community is doing nothing to stop the practice.

Michael Kambuli, a teacher at the Kippie George Primary School who has lived in the area for seven years, said he knows of many girls who have got married at the age of 13.

"The main reason they are interested in marriage is they want to survive," he commented.

Chedau, showed this reporter a number of minors who have already tied the knot, among them a skinny girl at a shebeen near Bagani, who would not look out of place in grade one.

The drinking hole has gained notoriety for selling beer to minors.The young girl claimed she is "happily married", although she was without her much older partner at the shebeen.

Another child bride, innocent-looking 14-year-old Regina Johannes, said she tied the knot late last year and is already five months pregnant. Lightly dressed in a white, polka-dotted top, Regina said her parents had frowned on her marriage, but she decided to go ahead anyway.

She is married to a builder, who is in his late 20s, from another region. The pregnant girl, who was attending school at Martin Ndumba Combined School, ditched her studies after her pregnancy became visible.

Johannes however said that her marriage is not as rosy as she expected, and she is now thinking of deserting her husband, so that she can go back to school once she delivers.

According to current legislation the age of consent among girls is 16, and men can be charged with statutory rape if they have sexual relations with under-age girls.

Chedau said child brides are a new occurrence in the Kxoe community because in the past his tribe used to marry and have children in their mid-20s.

A German researcher, conducting linguistic studies on the Kxoe in that area, said some Kxoe parents have approached him saying they want to get money from people who sleep with their minor children for several nights in a row.

The researcher, who preferred not to be named, said "some parents have come to me complaining that their children are not being paid after having sex, with certain people".

He observed that the parents just want money as they are so poor and in many cases do not know the consequences of these sexual relationships.

Kxoe girls freely give their bodies away to strangers even for a bottle of beer.

All these developments are being attributed to the economic hardships and poverty afflicting most of the Kxoe community.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Namibia;
Gay rights group take their concerns to Ombudswoman


BYLINE: The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Windhoek - The Rainbow Project, a gay and lesbian rights organisation in Namibia, has lodged a formal complaint with the Office of Ombudsman about recent attacks on homosexuality by Swapo.

The Project, which lobbies for equal rights and opportunities for gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transsexuals, said they took strong exception to recent attacks by President Sam Nujoma and Swapo on their rights.

"We feel that such remarks are a violation of the Constitution of the Republic of Namibia and contrary to the policy of national reconciliation. 

"It is disappointing that these statements were made by individuals and an organisation that professes to abhor discrimination and support democracy," the Rainbow Project said.

They handed in the complaint on Wednesday "to ensure that the rights and freedoms of all persons are protected as stipulated in the Constitution of the Republic of Namibia".

The group quoted remarks made by Nujoma at a December Swapo Women's Congress meeting where he said all necessary steps had to be taken to combat foreign influences which were affecting the nation in a negative way.

"Homosexuals must be condemned and rejected in our society. It is foreign and corrupt ideology ... and such elements are exploiting our democracy," he claimed. "Steps must be taken..."

They also attached a Swapo press release, issued in January, which supported Nujoma's statement saying it was "a very wise step in the right direction".

"Homosexuality deserves a severe contempt and disdain from the Namibian people and should be uprooted totally as a practice," the party statement said.

The press release said they fully endorsed the Nujoma statement and treated an attack on him as an attack against the party.

However, the Rainbow Project feels such attacks are an incitement to violence and discrimination against law abiding citizens.

"History has shown that such remarks can lead to witch hunts and the degrading of human beings. After similar attacks made by President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe there has been an escalation of discrimination and violence against sexual minorities in that country," noted the project which was formed after the attacks.

Tunisia;
Tunisia and EXIMBANK Sign Loan Agreement


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

Tunis - Tunisia signed a loan agreement with Japan's Export- Import Bank worth 10 billion yens (about 90 million dinars)in support of the private sector in Tunisia.

The loan will be repaid over a period of 12 years with a 2- year grace period and is granted at market rates.

During the signing ceremony, the Japanese official confirmed the participation of EXIMBANK to the International Donors Meeting to be held in Tunis, June 12.

Tunisian-Portuguese Economic Cooperation

Tunis - Bilateral cooperation in economy and finance was the theme of a meeting between Finance Minister Mohamed Jeri and the Portuguese Secretary of State in charge of Competitiveness and Globalization, Mr. Fernando de Souza, who was on a working visit to Tunisia, June 3-5.

During his visit, Mr. de Souza also met with Industry Minister Slaheddine Bouguerra and discussed the ways of boosting cooperation between Tunisian and Portuguese firms.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Car Components Industry Booms in Tunisia


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Tunis - The car components sector in Tunisia involves 90 firms, provides 8200 jobs, and manufactures an increasingly diversified range of products. 30% of the firms are designed for full export and employ 90% of the workforce in the sector. One third of the firms produces exclusively original spare parts. 

Thanks to the incentives that have been provided to encourage exports and the duty-free access to the European Union market, car components exports have increased significantly in the last 5 years and the coverage rate of imports reached an average rate of 55%. 80% of exports are made up of electrical and electronic systems and include clusters of cables, engine parts, filters, clutches, etc. The bulk of exports goes to the countries of the European Union (84% in 1995).

Due to the importance of this sector, the government set up 30 training centers for over 1000 skilled workers and technicians. Tunisia also has 6 engineering schools from which over 1000 students (12% women) graduated in 1995.

Many international firms are established in Tunisia in partnership or sub-contracting projects. They include General Motors, Isuzu, NHK, Pirelli, Renault, Scania, Valeo, and Volvo.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Work on irrigation projects in progress


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

AWASSA (ENA) - Work on irrigation projects in a bid to develop 80,000 hectares of land during the coming ten years is under way in Southern Ethiopia People's Regional State.

Ato Meskely Ayele, commissioner of the regional sustainable agriculture and environmental rehabilitation commission, said although there is over 600,000 hectares of irrigable land, only 18,000 hectares of land has been utilized in the region. 

Five mini-irrigation projects with the capacity to develop 500 hectares of land will go operational as of next year, the commissioner has said adding that close to 2,000 heads of families will benefit from the projects in progress in North Omo, Gurage as well as Alabba Tembaro zones.

Preparations have been finalized to undertake other nine irrigation projects next year.

June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopians return home from Sudan


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 173 words


 

ENDASELASSIE (ENA) - About 1,034 Ethiopian refugees have returned home from Sudan, a representative of the Refugee and Returnee Affairs Administration said.

The returnees were each given 1,000 birr, a three months' ration and utensils when they left Endasilassie for their home areas, the representatives said adding that they will be given a six month ration when they reach their destinations.

About 20,000 Ethiopian refugees currently in Sudan are expected to return until the end of July under a tripartite agreement between the governments of Ethiopia, Sudan and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), it was learnt.

180 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Witness: was seven months pregnant when beaten in jail


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A prosecution witness said yesterday she was jailed for allegedly being a member of EPRP and mercilessly beaten when she was an expectant mother, seven months pregnant.

The witness testifying against the former Derg officials, told the First Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court that she was taken by force in 1978 from her office, the Anbessa Transport Enterprise to be jailed, beaten and tortured in Kebele 07 of Higher 22.

"I was sent to prison by Woizero Tinsae Birhane, a ticket dispenser and chairperson of the revolutionary squad of the enterprise who used to threaten me of extermination after delivery at a nearby spot in the Leideta area", she told the court.

"Thanks to the kebele chairman who put me on the waiting list seeing my condition that I was saved despite the decision by the chairperson for my elimination," she related to the court. 

She said she was forced to witness the beating and sufferings inflicted on inmates in addition to serving the best dishes family supplies to prisoners to members of the revolutionary squad including the chairperson.

"I recall, particularly how they tortured an inmate, Saba Tasew, dragging her on the floor with her long hair pinned to a table", she added.

The witness related to the court that she had seen after a fortnight following her release from prison the bodies of Elias Zerihun, Fikadu Getahun, Zerihun Woulde, Mengistab Woldeab and others, all her working mates thrown at the gate of the enterprise.

another witness, who had lost his two sons and a daughter during the infamous seeing one night the execution of individuals at the gate of the enterprise when he was an in- patient in the Balcha Hospital.

Ato Belete Laigefu, 81 testified that the revolutionary guard of Woreda 22 Kebele 07 came to his house late one evening in 1978 and drove him in his own car to the kebele office where he said he was detained.

They told me that I was imprisoned because I had hidden away a weapon and my children who they alleged to have been members of the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Party," he said.

The witness said the guards who he named as Sergent Haile Mariam Waddera, Kelkile and Mandefro had tied, thrashed and bayoneted him.

He said he sustained intestinal disorder as a result of the beating and had undergone surgery.

"One night I heard a gun shot and the next morning Kessete, the kebele chairman, drove the 150 of us (the prisoners) from our prison cells and red out to us the names of three women and 17 men against whom revolutionary measures (execution) were taken", he said.

The witness read out to the court the name of some of the deceased from a note which he said he had taken at the time.

She said he was released from prison after five months of detention," but the guards kept my car for their use," he added.

Another witness, Ato Yemane Berhe, said he was imprisoned in 1978 in a prison at Woredas 21 and 15.

He said while he was in prison at woreda 21 kebele 23, he was beaten and burnt with a welding machine on his back which he showed to he court.

"While I was at the kebele prison, I saw a cadre step his foot on the neck of a man with a hunchback and electrocute him," he said.

He said the man, before his death, was shouting that he was innocent and was an employee of Mitchelcotts.

Kelemua Tadesse, another witness, testified that her brother, Mekonen Tadesse, was killed in 1978 five months after he gave himself up to the Woreda 16 administrative by the name Esnef Tesfay.

"That night, we heard a gun shot. At day break, my mother run out and we followed her. My brother's body was there lying near a public shop.

My mother threw herself on the body and started wailing. the revolutionary guards came and thrashed her with a butt. Her leg was broken and eventually she lost her sight from too much weeping," the witness said.

One of defendants, Corporal Negussie Wolde asked the court not to adjourn the trial to June ten because he said he sits for the grade eight national examination which is conducted on that day.

The court considered that appeal and adjourned the trial until 12 June.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Minister calls for efforts towards environmental conservation


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Minister of Agriculture, Dr. Seifu Ketema, has called on all citizens to contribute their share of effort at conserving the environment and natural resources. He said neglect in this area has accounted for the country's "relative poverty and degradation."

Opening the Conservation Strategy of Ethiopia Launching conference held yesterday at part of events marking World Environment Day, Dr. Seifu noted that the government's policy which was ratified last April "has mounted us on a reliable first stage that would allow for improvements in the management of our natural resources and the environment." 

The minister pointed out that as the policy cannot by it self work miracles, the general public is expected to make utmost effort towards its effective implementation. He also noted that, as opposed to old beliefs, the public should now grasp the fact that conservation and development need to go hand in hand and in an integrated way.

Apart from being endowed with landscapes of incomparable beauty and diverse natural resources, it was noted, Ethiopia is one of only 12 countries in the world with abundant biodiversity and its conservation efforts would thus be beneficial "not only to ourselves but the world as a whole."

Ethiopia has always actively participated in negotiations on, and ratification of, international conventions on environmental conservation and will continue to do so, Dr. Seifu emphasized. Governmental and nongovernmental organizations and other institutions and individuals should take note of "all these realities" and undertake development activities by taking due consideration of environmental factors, the minister said.

The General Manager of the Environmental Protection Authority, Dr. Teweldeberhan Gebregziabher, said on his part that World Environment Day should give everyone the opportunity to reflect on the environment and on the need for "a solidarity of all people of the world" to protect it.

He also noted that the launching of the Ethiopian Environmental Policy assisted to the government's commitment to the protection of the country's environment and that the preparation and approval of the policy was the result of careful planning and research lasting a fairly long period of time.

Dr. Teweldeberhan further noted that the conservation strategy of Ethiopia is a process that has evolved in light of periodic information exchange and that feedbacks and recommendations received in the process shouldn't be incorporated to update it. a representative of the OAU also stressed the need for environmental conservation world wide.

The conference was later addressed by representatives of the Ethiopian Patriotic Association, youth groups and the Ethiopian former fuel wood carries women's associations who all dwelt at length upon the necessity or making every effort at conserving the environment. They noted that the legacy of past in environmental degradation and depletion shouldn't be passed onto the new generation which is expected to show utmost care for the bounties of nature.

Student youth groups sang songs appropriate to the occasion following which a symbolic tree planting ceremony within the precincts of UNECA was conducted.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Antoine d'Abbadie: 19th Century French Traveller and Scholar


BYLINE: Dr. Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2254 words


 

Addis Ababa - One of the greatest foreign scholars of Ethiopia was a French nineteenth century traveller, Antoine d'Abbadie. A man of many parts, he has not received the acclaim to which he is entitled.

Refugees

Antoine d'Abbadie's father, Michel d'Abbadie, a Basque, left France at the beginning of the French Revolution of 1789, and married an Irish woman, Miss Thompson. By her he had three sons, Antoine (our traveller), Arnauld, and Charles, and three daughters, Elisa, Clia an Julienne. All six were placed in the care of a governess, and, living abroad as refugees, did not go to France until their parents' return there around 1820. That was five years after the Revolution had come to an end.

"What is at the End of the Road?" 

Young Antoine, who was born in January 1810, was brought up by the governess, who recalls that he always had insatiable curiosity about the unknown. Story has it that he once asked her, "What is at the end of the road? "A river", she replied. "And after the river?". "A mountain". "And after the mountain?" "I do not know; I have never been there", she answered. "Well then, I will go and see", declared the precocious infant.

Antoine was taught by his governess until the age of thirteen, when he was sent to school. Then, as previously, he was, it is said, always asking questions, always wanting to know about everything. He also displayed an easy mastery of languages, both ancient and modern. He passed his baccalaurat exams, with little difficulty, in 1827, after which he proceeded to University, at Toulouse.

The "Unknown or Little Known"

While at college he seems first to have conceived the idea of exploring central Africa, by way of Tunisia and Morocco. His reading of the famous eighteenth century Scottish traveller James Bruce caused him, however, to become more interested in the Eastern part of the continent. He was consumed with the ambition of studying what he considered the "unknown or little known" countries of the area: not only their languages, but more importantly their religions, political institutions and literature.

His dreams of exploration were, however, interrupted in the autumn of 1828, when his parents moved to Paris. There he once more enrolled in University studies, and devoted himself to the study, first of law and later of science. He subsequently paid a short visit to Ireland, the country of his birth, and on one occasion there walked a distance of thirty-six kilometres in only four hours and ten minutes.

Life Ambition

After that exploit he at last felt himself physically capable, as well as mentally ready, to fulfil his life's ambition, of embarking on his journey to Ethiopia. It was, however, unavoidably delayed, for he was invited by the French Academy of Sciences to undertake a mission to Brazil, to study magnetic occurrences.

Liq Atsqu

That scientific expedition concluded, Antoine, still only twentysix years of age, at last set forth for Cairo, in 1837, with his younger brother Arnauld, who was five years his junior. From Cairo the two young men crossed Egypt, and the Red Sea, and proceeded to the island port of Massawa, then the usual point of entry for Ethiopia. They then made their way to the country's capital, Gondar, where they received a warm welcome, on 28 May, from one of its greatest scholars, the redoubtable Ethiopian judge Liq Atsqu.

Separation, and Reunion

The two brothers then separated. Antoine travelled widely, carrying out many geodesic experiments, to measure the earth's surface. Arnauld, on the other hand, was introduced to one of the greatest Ethiopian lords of the time, Dajazmach Goshu, who allowed him to accompany his army into lands south of the Blue Nile. On one of these expeditions he travelled to the source of the river, which, as far as is known, had up to then been visited by only two other Europeans: the Spanish Jesuit Pero Pais, in 1630, and the Scottish traveller James Bruce, in 1770.

After almost two years in Ethiopia, Antoine returned to Massawa, where he met his brother Arnauld, who arrived only three hours late for an appointment made twenty months earlier!

Return to Gondar

After exchanging information on their respective journeys, and exploits, the two brothers planned a second expedition to Gondar. This ran, however, into difficuties, at first because of local opposition en route, and later because Antoine's rifle misfired, wounding him in one eye. He was obliged to go for treatment to Aden and Cairo, and, on his return from Aden, was subjected to much harrassment from the British governor of Aden, the terrible Captain Haines, who considered him a French secret agent. Antoine nevertheless proved himself indomitable, and duly made his way back to Gondar, in June 1842, while Arnauld returned to his lordly friend Dajazmach Goshu.

The d'Abbadie brothers, sometimes together and sometimes separate, now travelled all over the country. By then fully adjusted to Ethiopia, they wore local dress, and walked and rode barefoot. Antoine, who adopted the Ethiopian name Mika'el, i.e. his father's name Michel, was popularly referred to in and around Gondar by the Ethiopian title mamhir, or church scholar.

Enarya, and Kafa

Antoine's travels now took him to the then little known kingdom of Enarya, south of the Blue Nile, where he was kindly received by its notable ruler, Abba Bagibo, to whom he showed several of his most interesting chemical and other experiments. The monarch, who was then allied to the ruler of the nearby kingdom of Kafa, arranged for Antoine to proceed to that territory, about which scarcely anything had yet been written in the scholarly world. Both rulers hoped to keep the Frenchman in their respective domains, but he refused to stay, and soon made his way northwards to Gondar. There he entered into the company of the city's church scholars, who showed him their manuscripts, and helped him study them, and have them copied. He also spent much of his time on a careful linguistic investigation of the Amharic language.

Tawalda Madhen and 'Abd Allah

These and other investigations kept both d'Abbadie brothers in Ethiopia until the end of 1848, when they left the country for good, taking with them two Ethiopians: Tawalda Madhen, a scholar from Gondar, and a Muslim called 'Abd Allah.

Scholar ship

Having spent twelve years in the country, and taken literally thousands of pages of notes (most of them now available at the Institute of Ethiopian Studies library, on microfilm) the two brothers were by then exceedingly well informed about all things Ethiopian. Antoine, beside carrying out numerous scientific investigations, had collected vocabularies of some thirty Ethiopian languages, containing over 40,000 words, and had assembled the largest library of manuscripts in the classical language, Ge'ez, or Ethiopic, ever collected outside the country.

Antoine's departure from Ethiopia, in 1848, was a great turning point in his life. Though he never returned to the country he had come to love, he continued to spend most of his time on its scholarly investigation. In these researches he was immensely helped by his assistant, Tawalda Madhen, who was well versed in classical Ge'ez as well as the vernacular tongue, Amharic.

During the decades which followed Antoine d'Abbadie wrote studies on a wide range of scientific, ethnographic and linguistic subjects. These included an account of thunder in Ethiopia, a description of the country's ancient coins, a detailed catalogue of the Ethiopic manuscripts he had collected, and memoirs on the Bilen and Galla, or, as they are now more often called, Oromo, peoples, among both of whom he had dwelt. He also began a translation of the Futuh al-Habasha, a sixteenth century history of the wars of Ahmad ibn Ibrahim, better known as Ahmad Gragn, which was later completed by the Austrian scholar Philipp Paulitschke. More important than any of these works was, however, d'Abbadie's invaluable Amharic- French dictionary, the Dictionnaire de la langue amaria, for which he will always be remembered. It appeared in Paris in 1881.

Eclipse of the Sun

Ethiopia was not, however, our traveller's only scholarly interest. He was a keen astronomer, who travelled to Norway in 1851 to witness a total eclipse of the sun. He also devoted much of his energies to the study of his paternal language, Basque, and over the years wrote several pioneering studies on it.

The Chateau d'Abbadia

He also built a fine residence, the Chateau d'Abbadia, in the Basque country, near Hendaye, in Southern France. He later bequeathed this building, which is still extant, to the French Academy of Sciences, as an observatory. It is decorated with several paintings depicting Ethiopian scenes, and its entrance hall contains a wooden statue of Antoine's Muslim Ethiopian colleague 'Abd Allah. The latter, it is interesting to recall, had fought, under Napoleon III, in the battle of Magenta against the Austrians in June 1859, and had later joined the Paris Commune of 1870. He was, sad to say, one of the many Communards shot in the ensuing savage repression of 1871.

Antoine himself, by then a much honoured, and highly respected, scholar, died on 19 March 1897, at the ripe old age of eighty eight.

Sports - General;
Ethiopia's National Football Team Beaten By Morocco


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian national team suffered a 0-4 defeat, by its Moroccan counterpart on Saturday. 

The match was the first leg in the qualifying competition for the 21st African Football Championship to be held next year. This wide-gap defeat will limit Ethiopia's chance of entering the African championship.

The first goal was scored in the 8th minute by Moroccan player Said Chiba, while two more were scored in the first half. The 81th minute saw the Moroccan player Hadrioui Aredlkarim scoring the fourth goal against our home team.

Morocco and Ethiopia are competing in the African Nations Cup Group 3.

June 6, 1997


Sports - General;
Haile Gebreselassie Made Honourary Citizen


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia's own Haile Gebreselassie set yet another world record by running two miles in eight minutes 1.08 seconds in Hengelo, Holland on Saturday.

Following the race, he was made an honourary citizen of the Dutch town in recognition of his talent and his annual attempts to set world records there. 

The 24-year-old Haile is the current world record holder in the 5000 meters, both indoors and outdoors, and was the 1995 world-record holder in the 10,000 meters. He has won gold medals in the 10,000 meters at the 1993 and 1995 world championships and at the 1996 Olympic Games. Haile missed out on a $1 million payout in Saturday's race by not breaking the eight-minute barrier.

"I actually feel more than a million dollars. The money is not important. I can get it in the future," said the far from disappointed runner. He will now set his sights on regaining the world record in the 10,000 meters currently held by Algeria's Salah Hissou. Compatriot Assefa Mezgebu, a training partner of Haile, won the 10,000 meters in the same meet, taking nearly 40 seconds off his previous best for the distance.

Ethiopia;
Ethiopians to Trek the Extra Mile for the Environment


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - To mark 1997 World Environment Day (WED), the group's organizing committee will plant 1000 trees on Entoto mountain, on Sunday, June 8, stated a press release issued by the Netherlands Embassy. 

The trees seedlings will be planted at the Entoto National Park, by two student representatives from each of Addis Ababa's local high school Environment Clubs. The initiative is to demonstrate the Ethiopian future generation's commitment to caring for their environment, the release added.

The theme for 1997 World Environment Day is For Life On Earth, symbolizing the need for all elements of the globe to work in harmony with one another.

186 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Speaking of People: Yoseph Taye


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

Addis Ababa - Being an architect is a thing of luxury in Ethiopia, thinks Ato Yoseph Taye Tarekegne, aged 26, while talking of the position architects occupy in the general scheme of things.

Yoseph feels the field of architecture needs improvement in our country due to the misconceptions and misunderstanding people have of the field. It is a field which enables one to get involved in real practical problems and solutions creation. It also incorporates viewing of one's presentations from different angles and moreover having responsibility in the society. 

Yoseph was a child when he first started to think in architectural terms. His father, Ato Taye Tarekegne, with a bent of the artistic greatly influenced Yoseph in his chosen career. Even as a child he liked to sketch building and wished to see them come to realty. Having completed his ESLCE exams with great distinction, the road was open for him to pursue his chosen career. He joined the Addis Ababa University, Technology Department in 1989, and graduated with a B.Sc in Architecture and Urban planning in October 1993.

Talking of the position his field of work occupies in his country, Ethiopia, the society feel that an architectural work is related to art so it is given a secondary position in relation to the primary needs such as food and clothing. But Yoseph sees architecture as one the primary needs, that is shelter.

Interesting was his graduation project of final year when he presented a proposal of a mixed use development project of 15 stories high building right adjacent to Adwa Square, Piazza. He is a one of the few fortunate young architects who saw their proposals come to a fruitful end. The Midroc Construction is planning to construct a multi-user building in the same area having a similar scheme of project.

In his short career up to now, Yoseph has undertaken a wide range of architectural activities in projects such as day care centres, clinics, schools, offices and various community buildings, and private houses as well as multi use building and hotels projects in Nazareth, Dilla, Woldia and of course Addis Ababa.

Reminiscing of his university life, he feels his education in the field helped him later on to handle challenging jobs. While he was still in the university, various proposals such as upgrading and low cost housing, a cafeteria for the swimming pool in Ghion Hotel, an industrial project for Tabor Ceramic processing, theatrical building among others were put before him.

Yoseph laughingly said the thing that most attracting to architecture was this ability to see an immediate result of his work. There is nothing like the feeling of satisfaction when one sees one's proposal built literally in bricks and stones.

There is a big "But" he says. In his experience, there is a vast difference between what he created in his mind and the realisation of that proposal. It is greatly frustrating to see one's work completely wiped out because of a misunderstanding or misconception of what the architects has in mind. The misunderstanding can be caused for various reasons: the most important being practical limitations. Yoseph good- humorously acknowledge that architects are voiceless of imagination and might not sometimes give importance to the practical limitations say the engineer or a constructor might face while implementing the ideas the architect proposes. The practical limitations might be building materials or lack of capital. One must not forget that Ethiopia is still a poor country that is yet to Carter fully to the needs of building materials. Added to these, the society was not fully exposed to the various alternatives available in the field of architectural works.

Despite these facts, Yoseph strongly feels there is a chance to innovate. Society is limited by "conventions" that are not transcending these limitations. And ways to do that is to expose the society of various creative, well thought out architectural works. Sadly, Yoseph quoting one of his instructors said Ethiopia, particularly Addis Ababa has" "many buildings but not many works of architecture."

In addition to the limitations present in a poor country like Ethiopia, there are not much of innovative architectural designs being created by the architects of our times. Just by looking at few building constructed or being constructed in the many Ethiopian cities and towns, one can easily note the faithful copying of certain architectural motifs, particularly of those having spiritual connotations. A good example was the tip of the Axum obelisk present at most of the newly built sky scapers. Yoseph also feels architects should work, strive hard to get out of this use of conventions by either handling them creatively or completely changing them.

The aim to create an architectural style that speaks for itself is burning in Yoseph's mind. He feels Ethiopia is poor in architectural giants in sharp contrast to Europe and America. His mission in life will be to develop such style so that the next generation will have some Ethiopian base to start from.

Yoseph also recommends an initiation of a societal group for the innovative and creative minds of young architects. Like the many western countries, Ethiopia also should present its public with various alternatives while building its cities and towns.

Yoseph is at present not married, and is working as freelance and in collaboration with others in architectural designs.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia, Kenya Trade Relations Said Dynamic


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Addis Ababa - Kenya and Ethiopia are in the process of establishing a new bilateral trade agreement to enhance import- export trade between the two countries.

In her talks with the Addis Tribune, Mrs Margaret A. Nyongdong, Commercial Attache of the Kenyan Embassy to Ethiopia said the arrival of a Kenya Buyer- Seller Mission to Ethiopia between the 3rd and 5th June 1997 was witness to the dynamic nature of trade relations between the two neighbouring countries. In the mission, Kenyan industrialists seek to market quality manufactured goods and to scour for raw materials and manufactured items from Ethiopia. 

The commercial Attache also disclosed the staging of an exhibition of Kenyan manufacturers and entrepreneurs scheduled in Addis Ababa June18th and 21th, 1997. The exhibition named "Kenya in Ethiopia Trade Exhibition" will illustrate Kenyan investors' strong interest in the Ethiopian trade market. She also talked of Kenya's participation in the Third Addis Ababa Chamber International Trade Fair in November last year as a clear manifestation of the amicable trade relation between the two countries.

Her Excellency also said a few Kenyan companies have expressed interest in establishing investments in Ethiopia geared towards the production of soap, detergents and aluminium products. There is also an effort to convince Kenyan investors to exploit vast investment opportunities in Ethiopia in the agricultural, manufacturing, mining and tourism sectors.

Kenya's main exports to Ethiopia include food and beverages, construction materials, body and shoe-care products, paper and paper products, oil and fats, soap, detergents, textiles, farm implements and services. Ethiopia exports to Kenya such items as spices, wine, tents and maize.

"Kenya in Ethiopia '97" Trade Exhibition to Take Place

The Kenya in Ethiopia '97 trade exhibition is set to take place from the 18th to the 21st of June 1997 at the Addis Ababa Exhibition Centre. The trade show is aimed at creating market awareness of Kenyan products, further promoting regional integration, the exchanging of ideas, disseminating industrial and trade information and strengthening trade links between Kenya and Ethiopia, according to a press release issued by organisers Network Business Promotion of Nairobi, Kenya. The exhibition also aims at promoting investment opportunities and establishing joint ventures.

Kenyans are expected to appoint various distributors of their products during the show, seek raw materials for their industries and discuss industrial technology affairs with their Ethiopian counterparts.

Some of the products which will be represented in the show are cosmetics, cement, roofing and floor materials, irrigation equipment, aluminium profiles, packaging materials, decorative and revolutionary wall coatings, electrical, timber and wood products, steel products, water treatment products, stationery, telecommunication equipment, promotional material, plastics and other assorted goods.

Among the exhibitors are the Kenya posts and telecommunication, Bamburi Cement, Gasheet (K) Ltd., Cosmo Care, Kenpoly Manufacturers Ltd. Stamet Products Ltd.,<N>Steel Makers Ltd., Timsales Ltd., Booth Manufacturing (A) Ltd., Dodlhia Packaging, and International lamps and Lighting Ltd.

June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
50 Ethiopian Patent Applicants Accepted


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa - Since the promulgation of the proclamation concerning inventions, minor invention and industrial designs two years ago, the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission was said to have accepted 50 patent applications.

According to Ato Getachew Mengiste, head of the Patent, Technology Transfer and Development Department, said the applications concern industrial applicable inventions and designs. 

Ato Getachew said the Council of Ministers has already adopted detailed directives and regulations for the implementation of the proclamation. He added that the applicants will be granted certificates of recognition as soon as the directives and regulations are issued by the Negarit Gazette.

Compared with the 40 million patent rights available world- wide, the present collection is small, Ato Getachew said. But he also added that the commissions are substantial considering the short period that has elapsed since the issuance of the proclamation.

It was also added that the commission has so far collected over 1 million of patents from abroad in order to provide services to users.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
African Leaders Renewed Confidence in Dr. Salim (Editorial)


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - The 33rd Organization of African Unity (OAU) Summit that ended in Harare on Wednesday will be remembered for many things but especially for electing Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim for a third four-year unprecedented term of office. Thirty seven nations voted for him. Six against.

Dr. Salim took the oath of office on Wednesday and pledged to work hand-in-hand with the member states for the advancement of peace, unity, democracy and for the development of Africa. He said, "As I embark on the third term, I am conscious of the challenges to make the organization more relevant as we approach the next millennium." No one would dispute that the problems of Africa are many and complex. However, Dr. Salim and his colleagues at the OAU will make a difference the future of Africa.

Africa's civil war, refugee problem, AIDS, genocide, drought and question of development need to be tackled. Dr. Salim has a good track record for his efforts. The majority of African leaders including Ethiopia have renewed their confidence. The OAU Secretary General will meet the challenge.

190 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Derg Trial Told Killing of a Minor Caused Mother's Death


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Addis Ababa - Two prosecution witnesses testified on Tuesday before the Federal High Court saying the killing of a minor caused a mother to die of deep sorrow.

In the hearing of the testimony against former Derg officials, one of the witnesses told the First Criminal bench that a minor aged 7 was among the victims who were forced to sing praises to the revolution on March 1978.

The youngsters, attending a meeting in which Tesfaye Gebre- Hiwot, chairman of the then Higher 16 and his accomplices were presiding were killed at the spot. The witness testified that he saw the corpses of the minor and others thrown on the streets. 

Another witness, a mother of one of the imprisoned youngsters, said she saw her son crawling from the torture he had undergone at the prison. She also testified that another mother of one of inmates went mad when she heard the shocking news of death of her child. The mother was said to have died of deep sorrow later on.

Witnessing of the ordeal he faced in the prison of Kebele 15 Higher 21 in 1978, another witness said he broke his leg when his torturers made him fall from the rope he was hanging to a trough filled with boiled water.

A mother of an inmate is still learning to cope with the shock she experienced after learning of the death of her son. She was given his belongings at the day she was expecting him, the witness said. Previous to the news, the mother was told by a cadre to make a feast to celebrate the release of her son.

The witness also named Professor Ambaye of the Addis Ababa University among the inmates who were killed at that time. The professor was said to have shouted when they took him out of his cell "How dare you kill me for voluntarily coming to serve my country?"

Another witness said his son was killed during the Red Terror period even after he has made him register in the then political school with the intention of saving his life. He said he implored Captain Legesse Asfaw to save his son but he as well as Captain Engidawork Mamo allegedly were responsible for his death.

The court had so far heard the testimony of 303 prosecution witnesses.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Berhan Selam Celebrates its 75th Anniversary


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - Berhan and Selam Printing Enterprise celebrated its 75th anniversary on Saturday on its grounds. The ceremony was a colourful one featuring an exhibition, and a musical show among other things. 

The exhibition was opened by Ato Wolde Michael Chemu, Minister of Culture and Information. It traced the history of the enterprise from its establishment in 1922 to the present day in photographic and graphic displays. It was said the organisation has shown an increase of 16 percent in its profit. Various types of newpapers, both private and government owned, novels and visiting and greeting cards, were shown as samples of the diverse publications the enterprise undertakes. The enterprise also functions as the sole publisher of governmental security matters such as the printing of check books, travellers check, shares certificates, stamps, bus tickets as well as passports.

During the ceremony, prizes were also presented by the director Mrs. Muluwork Gebre Hiwot. The company's soccer team, the organisers of the ceremony, senior employees who worked over 33 years in the company as well as regular customers who used the company for a long time were presented prizes.

June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Alitalia Began Flights to Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - Alitalia, the Italian carrier resumed twice- weekly flights between Rome and Addis Ababa Tuesday, June 3. Five years has elapsed since the last Alitalia was seen.

Italian Ambassador H.E. Maurizio Melani was at Bole Airport to welcome the first flight with Alitalia's General Manage, Mr. Michele Pagrelli.

Alitalia will fly to Addis Ababa on Tuesdays and Fridays on its B767ER aircraft that would give passengers enough time to catch their connecting flights from Rome to anywhere in the world.

Ethiopian airlines flies to Rome three times a week.
