June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia Suffers Losses From Animal Diseases


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - An estimated 1.5 to 2.5 billion Ethiopian birr is lost each year by Ethiopia due to animal death caused by diseases, disclosed an official of the Ministry of Agriculture.

At the opening of the annual meeting of the Ethiopian Assistant Veterinarians association, Woizero Hadera Gebru, head of the Animal and Fishery Resources and Development Department said about 150,000 km of land in Western and Southern Ethiopia is infested by the tse-tse fly. Agricultural activities in these lands are becoming difficult as there is not much of animal power.

The participants of the meeting were urged to come up with a solution that will go a long way towards the development of Ethiopia's animal resources.

Present at the conference were assistant veterinarians from various institutions and administrative regions.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Professions in Great Demand in Ethiopian Civil Service


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2694 words


 

Addis Ababa - In a recent vacancy announcement ("Addis Zemen", Ginbot 20, 1989 E.C.) by the administration of Region 3 for the various government institutions located within its territory, the largest number of recruits required is for persons trained in economics, with 163 invited to apply out of a total planned recruitment of about 513.

Accounting is in second place with 106 recruits required, distantly followed by management (48), educational administration and pedagogy (38), statistics (28), civil engineering (24) and language and literature (16). Other professions which are also in relatively significant demand are law (11), architecture (9), sanitary engineering (9), sociology (7) and geography (6). By contrast, low recruitment demand is reflected for electricity, animal science, plant science, biology, mechanical engineering, hydraulics, hydrology, geology, geophysics, history, psychology, physics, chemistry, political science, agricultural engineering, agronomy, public administration and electronics (see details below).

The personnel recruitment is intended for the regional council, education bureau, investment office, water, mining and energy development bureau, trade and industry bureau, civil service, culture, tourism and information bureau, high court, audit, labour and social affairs bureau, transport and communications bureau, Bahir-Dar Rural Technology Development Center, public works and urban development bureau, planning and economic development bureau, justice bureau, sports commission and health bureau. Hence, practically the whole civil service organisational structure in the region is covered by this latest personnel recruitment programme. Monthly salaries offered range from 420 birr to 1,290 birr. 

A number of observations could be made from the above facts and figures. First, generally the government appears to continue being the biggest employer of professionals, indicating that, far from being rolled back, the functions of the state are still expanding at a significant pace.

Second, although such large-scale recruitment by local governments is expected to alleviate the overall unemployment problem in the country, it is doubtful whether the recruited professionals will be able to make concrete contributions in the absence of conducive national economic and other policies.

Third, state personnel recruitment of the scale shown here and at the low salaries indicated, if fully implemented, is a sign that job opportunities in the private sector are limited, which means that the state sector is expanding at the expense of the sector which is, in policy terms, supposed to be the primary motive power of the national economy.

Fourth, while policy and practical development contributions of economists in terms of overall economic policy-making, project analysis, appraisal, market studies and the like are to be appreciated, the priority given to economics in the recruitment over such more directly productive professions as civil engineering, surveying, electrical engineering, architecture, mechanical engineering, hydraulics, sanitary engineering, auto mechanics, agricultural engineering, agronomy, town planning and electronics indicates a somewhat unhealthy bureaucratic bias.

Fifth, the low planned recruitment level for animal science, plant science, biology, hydrology, geophysics and chemistry points to a low degree of emphasis placed on research and development at the regional level.

Sixth, while the relative importance attached to sociology should be appreciated, the role of psychology should be equally recognised ( a nation's development programme could be undermined by a lack of understanding not only of sociological but also of psychological problems of the society concerned).

Seventh, why the importance of computerization is underemphasised in the recruitment project in the face of a growing national consciousness of the importance of information and information processing is not quite clear.

Eighth, history and political science also do not seem to have been accorded their due share, especially when considered against the country's political background where politics seems to be in the driver's seat and even history may be rewritten to serve it!

Ninth, other important professions including medicine, agricultural engineering, agronomy, town planning and electronics have been slighted.

As a whole, professions such as economics and accounting have been accorded rather too much attention whereas highly productive disciplines such as civil, mechanical and electrical engineering do not seem to have received their due share of priority; furthermore, the nearly total neglect of computerization is worrisome.

Also, why it is difficult to realise the importance of formal training in political science, when this is perhaps the only way to make "politicians" in Ethiopia aware of the complementarity of the professions, is not at all clear.

A person versed in political science would be better able to appreciate the importance of the other professions in buttressing political power with concrete social and economic achievements than a person without such training. Similarly, a person without such knowledge and experience would be more likely to act out of a crude lust for power!

Could a rough rule-of-thumb be worked out for a balanced recruitment of professionals for the civil service? This may sound like a rather difficult proposition, but an attempt could be made on the basis of the major civilian functions of the state in a market-oriented economy which include a) maintaining law and order, b) fiscal and central banking, c) providing basic economic and social infrastructure and amenities d) formulating social and economic policies conductive to private enterprise and e) conducting relevant research and development.

Out of the total 36 disciplines listed in the table above, 10, or about 28 percent, belong in the social sciences. However, taking into account only the four major disciplines, namely engineering, health, education and law, which are required in the provision of services not only to groups but also to individuals, the degree of importance that would be attached to the social sciences would be roughly 40 percent, the remaining and larger portion of 60 percent being slated for the natural and applied sciences.

However, even counting accounting as belonging in the applied sciences, slightly over 56 percent of the total number of the planned recruits shown above are intended for the social sciences, thus indicating an imbalance in personnel recruitment in Region 3.

Even more pertinent issues on the Region's planned employment plan may be raised regarding the availability of manpower with the required academic qualifications and work experience (up to ten years in some cases), the actual quality of these qualifications and experience and the practical contributions the personnel sought are expected to make in bringing about social and economic transformation in Ethiopian society.

If Region 3 succeeds in recruiting all the manpower according to its specifications, it is going to be mostly at the expense of other government institutions, although this statement may have to be qualified if recruitment from the ranks of the retired is to take place. For the Region's recruitment programme to contribute to the creation of new employment, either other government institutions should be willing to take on fresh graduates (i.e. with no experience ) or Region 3 itself should relax its recruitment conditions.

The other general issues that may be raised are: what practical, tangible contributions can, for example, an economist or a statistician make? Are the economists to be recruited capable of designing a practical overall development and projection model ? Can they conduct practical project feasibility and appraisal studies of acceptable standards?

Assuming that they are able to successfully undertake such assignments, are the government's overall economic policies conductive to the implementation of such growth models and feasibility studies? Are the statisticians to be recruited going to be in a position where they will have enough statutory authority to enforce compliance with data and information requests from relevant government and private institutions and entities, and will they have enough funding to carry out, for example, statistical surveys as may be required? In other words, when a statistician is put on the payroll under the recurrent expenditure, funding for, say, a statistical survey project would be required under the capital expenditure! Has such fiscal expenditure dove-tailing been attempted while working out the region's personnel recruitment scheme?

Finally, it is a good thing that no such statement as "priority will be given to ethnic members of the Region" is contained in the vacancy announcement, but as Region 3 is a recidivist ethnic gerrymander, there is still a possibility that an applicant may be required to be an ethnic of the Region (if indeed there is such a thing!) when he or she phones, as advised," for further information and clarifications on 20-14- 42"! It would be interesting to call Bahir Dar and find out otherwise!

A sample of skilled Labour Demand by Profession (Region 3, Ethiopia)

1. Accounting 106

2. Economics 163

3. Statistics 28

4. Management 48

5. Language and Literature 16

6. Library Science 4

7. Civil engineering 24

8. Surveying 5

9. Electricity 1

10. Educational Administration & pedagogy 38

11. Physical education 6

12. Law 11

13. Sociology 7

14. Animal science 1

15. Plant science 1

16. Biology 1

17. Architecture 9

18. Mechanical Engineering 2

19. Hydraulics 2

20. Sanitary Engineering 9

21. Hydrology 1

22. Geology 1

23. Geophysics 1

24. Computers 0 (less than 0.5)

25. History 1

26. Psychology 2

27. Physics 2

28. Chemistry 2

29. Political Science 2

30. Auto mechanics 5

31. Agricultural engineering 1

32. Agronomy 2

33. Town planning 3

34. Geography 6

35. Public administration 1

36. Electronics 1

Total 513

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
US Grants Aid to Help Fight Narcotics Trafficking


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Ethiopian Counternarcotics Unit (ECNU) was presented two mini-vans and an all terrain vehicle (ATV) worth more than 330,000 Ethiopian birr by American Ambassador David Shinn, stated an embassy press release.

The vehicles will to assist the unit in detecting and deterring narcotics trafficking in the country. It will also help the unit in meeting its transportation needs in the fight against this menace, added the release.

The keys to the vehicles were presented on Monday, 1 June, to Major Alemseged Gebre Yohannes representing the ECNU.

The American Ambassador also signed an agreement with representatives from four community development projects at the ceremony held at the US Embassy, stated another press release issued the same day.

More than 30,000 Ethiopian birr was awarded to Debre-Berhan Children's Learning and Development Centre-Water Sanitation Project (North Shoa) for the purchase of materials to construct the school's shower and latrine facility.

A second grant of 70,000 birr was handed over to the representative of the Gurage Development Association-Grain Mill to aquire grinding machinery and equipment. The Yavello Student Hostel will use its grant of more than 81,000 Ethiopian birr for the purchase of construction materials for two 36,000 litre underground water storage tanks.

The final grant of 50,000 birr was made to the St. George Orphans' Endowment Debre Berhan, (North Shoa) for materials to construct a clinic. These grants represent the latest round of awards from the Ambassador's Special Self-Help fund.

June 6, 1997


Ethiopia;
Dergue Officials Appear on Charge of Gassing


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 213 words


 

Addis Ababa - Three officials of the former government appeared before the First Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court last week, accused of killing around 24 people in Wollo region with poison gas in the late 1970's.

Accordingly, Administrator and Permanent Representative of Wollo Colonel Fantaye Yihdego, Lieutenant Haile Gebeyehu as well as Second Lieutenant Ambachew Alemu (who was being tried in absentia) are alleged to have belonged to the Revolutionary Campaign Co-ordinating Committee and killed the individuals on suspicion of being members of the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Party (EPRP).

Second Lieutenant Ambachew was also accused of having ordered the death of six other people for belonging to EPRP and a further 18 for suspected involvement with the Tigray People's Liberation Front, ENA reported.

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian Measures Against Businessmen Called Illegal


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Addis Ababa - A statement issued by the Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO) called the government's May 1 sealing of business premises, revoking of licenses and detention of businessmen illegal and a violation of human rights.

The EHRCO called on the government to "take the necessary steps to release the detained businessmen, open the business premises sealed by force, and reverse the decision to revoke and/or take away trade licenses from the businessmen." It further urged "all supporters of human rights to do their utmost to stop the injustices done to the businessmen in Addis Ababa." 

The statement recalled that on May 17, businessmen closed down their shops and held a protest rally at Mesqel Square in response to a rent increase as high as 40,000% imposed by the Addis Ababa Administration.

The businessmen went on strike on May 19 after the rally failed to draw the attention of the authorities. Around noon of that day, the government issued an ultimatum that those businesses not open by 3:00 p.m. would be sealed; and, immediately following the deadline, kept its word by sealing over 1000 shops without a court order.

The case of 200 of those shops is still under review. Some will open soon, according to Head of Region 14 Trade, Tourism and Industry Bureau Ato Estifanos Senbeta; but 29 licenses have already been cancelled. According to city administrator Ato Ali Abdo, 84 persons who are thought to have co-ordinated the strike were detained and will not be pardoned. Those participating in the strike were allowed to reopen their shops on condition that they admit they had committed an offense by going on strike and appeal for a pardon.

The statement pointed out that "there is no provision in Ethiopian laws that bans protests in the form of closing down one's own business premise", and that a trade license may be revoked only according to strict guidelines, none of which was broken in the present situation. The statement further recalled that the practice of forcing citizens to admit to committing an offense and appeal for pardon whenever they used their right to protest follows a consistent pattern. Last month, Addis Ababa University students were rounded up by police and tortured after staging a demonstration about which they had informed the government in advance.

The students were released after being forced to admit that they had committed an offence, pledge that they would never again participate in such a demonstration and sign an application form requesting a pardon.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 6, 1997


Business and Finance;
Repercussions of Eritrea's Planned Currency Change on Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2067 words


 

Addis Ababa - It is expected that, when the Eritrean monetary authorities commence, as recently declared, their currency change programme, they will announce the rate of conversion of the "Nakfa" (the name of the new currency) vis-a- vis the Ethiopian Birr which they have heretofore been using as their legal tender.

It is also anticipated that the rate of exchange between the Eritrean Nakfa and the US Dollar will be made public.

Since there are many Eritrean traders who have been using the Birr to import Ethiopian products such as "teff", coffee, leather, wood, etc., into Eritrea for commercial purposes, such traders, and in fact, many other Eritrean individuals, may not want to convert all of their Birr holdings into Nakfas which, it is anticipated, will not be acceptable in Ethiopia. So the wise thing to do from the point of view of the individual interests of such Eritreans would be to start converting before the start of the Eritrean currency change scheme at least part of their Birr holdings into US dollars which, of course, are readily acceptable both in Ethiopia and Eritrea. 

They could do this on the dollar black market in Ethiopia as the dollar black market in Eritrea would no longer be willing to accept Birr for US dollars in the wake of the introduction of the Nakfa, as Birr cash transfers across Ethiopian borders from Eritrea in the near future would presumably begin to be strictly controlled.

Another option would be to transfer that part of their Birr holdings which they do not want to convert into Nakfas to Ethiopia across the border, which, as pointed out above, is at present quite porous, and bid for foreign exchange on the Ethiopian weekly foreign exchange auction market and obtain US dollars for the importation of goods from outside the Birr area and take the imported goods to Eritrea across the border which again is only very loosely controlled with respect to commodity transfers to Eritrea. Still another alternative for these kinds of traders would be to buy Ethiopian goods such as teff, coffee, etc., in Birr before the currency conversion begins and transport them to Eritrea.

Some of these imported products may be re-exported for foreign exchange. Further, Eritreans now living in Ethiopia who wish to transfer cash to Eritrea for whatever reason are likely to do so after converting Birr into US dollars on the black market, for it is quite possible that they may be treated as foreigners after the introduction of the Nakfa for foreign exchange transfer purposes as well as for other matters involving the question of citizenship.

The other two possibilities of buying Ethiopian products such as coffee and leather and transporting them to Eritrea and bidding for foreign exchange on the foreign exchange auction market for re-export to Eritrea may also be taken advantage of.

On the other hand, there are allegations that some departments of the Eritrean state bureaucracy may have encouraged the conversion of Birr holdings of government financial and other institution into US dollars on the Ethiopian dollar black market. The allegations ring plausible as especially all the Birr holdings of the Eritrean central bank and commercial banks there are to be handed over to the National Bank of Ethiopia which has so far been the sole bank of issue for the Birr area.

As far as repercussions of the Eritrean currency change on the Ethiopian economy are concerned, one general observation that could be made is that no major negative consequences need be expected if the currency change is carried out systematically and in accordance with best-practice procedures.

All Ethiopian currency (including coins) now held by Eritrean individuals, government organisations, financial institutions and private businesses is ultimately to be handed over to the Ethiopian monetary authorities and be replaced by the new Eritrean currency.

It is quite conceivable that a sort of bilateral payments arrangement may be put in place to finance trade between Ethiopia and Eritrea in their respective domestic currencies up to a certain agreed limit. This option, however, many not be particularly favourable to Ethiopia at the moment.

On the other hand, deviations from best-practice currency change procedures on the part of the Eritrean monetary authorities could have several adverse consequences on the Ethiopian economy. Some of the irregularities that may be allowed to occur have been outlined above. If, for example, financial institutions in Eritrea somehow deliberately release a large quantity of Birr onto the Ethiopian market immediately before the commencement of the currency change for conversion in into US dollars on the Ethiopian dollar black market and possibility on the official forex auction market, the birr/dollar exchange rate may depreciate to a destabilizing degree and the action may also cause inflationary pressures.

Similarly, allowing a large quantity of Birr to cross over the border into Ethiopia for the purchase of Ethiopian products which may then be trucked or otherwise transported to Eritrea, would cause both inflationary and exchange rate problems for Ethiopia. In this respect, it is rather strange that the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE) has reportedly accumulated large claims on Eritrean banks in terms of Birr credits extended in the recent past through a correspondent account. News of the imminent currency change in Eritrea should have alerted the CBE to restrain credit extension to banks in Eritrea.

At any rate, these credit claims of the CBE on the Eritrean banking system will have to be settled in Birr before the planned currency change in Eritrea. If they are not settled before the currency change, the CBE will have no choice but to demand settlement in hard currency, preferably US dollars, which the Eritrean banking system would find difficult to comply with .

The anticipated currency change in Eritrea will complete the secession of the region from Ethiopia. Hence, existing trade, economic and financial arrangements between the two states would have to be reviewed in the context of these new would-be developments. Ethiopian exports to and imports from Eritrea would have to be subject to Ethiopia's customs and exchange control.

Similarly, Birr transfers to and from Eritrea would be illegal except the permitted amount for persons travelling abroad. With the possible exception of financing bilateral trade in goods and services in each other's currencies under a probable bilateral payments agreement, settlement for commercial transactions between the two states would be all in foreign exchange.

In other words, exports of, say, coffee, leather, and oilseeds to Eritrea would be received not in Birr as is the case now, but in US dollars. Similarly, the Eritrean authorities would demand payment in foreign exchange for oil- refining, port services and salt exports. As the Eritrean population residing in Ethiopia is large, the Ethiopian monetary authorities would be hard pressed to grant it full foreign exchange remittance privileges equal to those granted to non-Eritean foreigners. Doing so would imply a massive foreign exchange remittance outflow which Ethiopia can ill afford. However, remittance privileges may be given to Eritreans living in Ethiopia on a selective basis. For example, Eritreans who bring in foreign exchange for investment purposes and those engaged in work involving considerable technical and scientific know-how such as auto- mechnaics, civil engineering and specialised medicine may be slated for remittance privileges. An alternative would be to give such Eritrean investors and personnel the privilege of exporting Ethiopian-produced products such as "teff" and coffee against payment in Birr.

Finally, what may be some of the major steps that the Ethiopian monetary authorities would take in preparation for the planned Eritrean currency change? The following measures are expected:

Strict customs and foreign exchange control, particularly the prohibition of Birr transfers from Eritrea immediately before and during the period of Eritrea's planned currency change, which measure must continue after the currency change; Stricter surveillance of the activities of the foreign exchange black market in Ethiopia, with the possibility of a crackdown on it should the Birr depreciate to a destablizing degree; Settlement of CBE's net claims on the Eritrean banking system before the currency change; Estimation of the quantity of Ethiopian currency (i.e. currency outside banks and currency within banks) in Eritrea that must be handed over to the National Bank of Ethiopia after the currency change in Ethiopia.

Africa News


June 7, 1997


Congo (Kinshasa);
Swiss Accused Of Underrating Mobutu's Wealth


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Secretary-General of the Pan African Movement (PAM), Tajudeen Abdul-Raheem says there is a possibility Swiss banks have deliberately under-estimated the value of ousted Zairean dictator Mobutu Sese Seko's assets in order to protect the West.

Abdul-Raheem told guests at a public lecture here on Thursday night that previous estimates traced by an independent journalist exceeded 4.8 billion Swiss francs (3 billion U.S. dollars) worth of assets held by Mobutu. 

However, Democratic Republic of Congo President Laurent-Desire Kabila has said Mobutu has 11 billion Swiss francs or one billion dollars in foreign banks.

The amount exceeds the country's gross domestic product. Meanwhile, Tajudeen Abdul-Raheem has said there is need for Africans to build their own democratic institutions instead of relying on the West.

"Do not take lessons from these Westerners who act like they were born democratic," he said at the lecture.

"Democracy is a process that takes time to develop, so Africa has to go through its own stages based on its own experiences."

PAM is a grassroots organisation which seeks to restore to Africans what they lost as a result of the injustices they suffered at the hands of the West.

Abdul-Raheem also said the remaining dictators in Africa should draw lessons from the experience of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

"The political climate in Africa is changing as people are beginning to challenge existing systems," he told the 100 guests. "Zaire has proven that no dictator in Africa will ever be safe again. So dictators beware." Laurent Kabila, leader of Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (Zaire), forced dictator Mobutu Sese Seko to flee into exile last month after he had plundered the wealth of the mineral rich central African state for 32 years.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 7, 1997


Nigeria;
Ojukwu Opposes Campaign For Abacha To Succeed Himself


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Emeka Odumegwu Ojukwu, the ex-Biafra warlord, who led the abortive secessionist bid by Eastern Nigeria, has criticised those campaigning for the country's military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha to succeed himself, saying it is the turn of the Igbos to present the next civilian president.

"Whatever is the present campaign, schemings or activities for the country's president in the emerging political dispensation, let it be clearly known that it is now the turn of the Igbos (Eastern Nigeria) to produce the next president of the country and it is not negotiable," Ojukwu said.

There has been a raging campaign by a cross section of Nigerians, including some Igbo elements, urging Abacha, who took power in November 1993 from a lame-duck civilian administration, to shed his military uniform and run for presidency under his political transition programme, scheduled to end in October 1998. 

The campaigners have included cabinet ministers, serving military officers and pressure groups. The crusade has continued despite repeated denials by officials disociating government from it.

Political observers say Abacha's failure to clarify the situation has only fuelled the speculation after he said in a recent interview the decision to succeed himself was for his "constituency" to make.

Ojukwu, speaking at a fund-raising for the Igbo cause in the eastern city of Enugu on Thursday, said the Igbos had been "locked up in the room" for too long, they should "come out to the parlour."

This was a reference to the alleged marginalisation of the Igbo ethnic group since the 30-month Biafra war ended in 1970. That war pitted the igbos and others in Eastern Nigeria against the rest of the country.

Ojukwu's political leadership of the Igbos has come under strong challenge, with some critics accusing him of misleading the East into a war that killed an estimated one million Igbos.

But the ex-Biafran leader said the Igbos must now unite to take their destiny in their own hands otherwise they risked remaining the underdogs in the Nigerian federation.

Congo (Kinshasa);
Kabila Appoints Three New Ministers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

KINSHASA, Congo (PANA) - Congolese President Laurent Kabila on Friday appointed three new ministers at the end of a cabinet meeting, officials said. 

They said Prof Thomas Kanza was appointed minister of international cooperation, while Etienne Mbaya became minister of construction and emergency Works.

Julienne Lumumba, daughter of the late Patrice Lumumba, was named Deputy Minister of Information.

These appointments bring to 17 the number of ministers in the government.
