Africa News


June 7, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mozambique Premier Inaugurates Coca-Cola Plant


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

CHIMOIO, Mozambique (PANA) - Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi on Friday inaugurated a new Coca-Cola bottling factory in the central Mozambican city of Chimoio.

The factory is a joint venture between Coca-Cola, South African Bottling Company (SABCO) and the Mozambican government.

Mocumbi said that such a major investment in Chimoio was part of the government's plan "'to achieve the balanced development of the country"'. 

The policy would help reduce the existing regional imbalances, whereby the bulk of industry is concentrated in the Maputo area in the far South, he said.

Benjamin Alfredo of the Coca-Cola subsidiary, told hundreds of people at the inauguration that the new factory cost about 15 million U.S. dollars. It was built in 15 months on land that was previously virgin bush.

The factory employs 160 people, and has the capacity to produce three million cases of soft drinks a year.

"The project not only involves considerable capital investment, but also aims to increase the availability of soft drinks on the national market, simultaneously creating more employment and contributing to an increase in the gross national product and to the government's national budget," he said.

The Africa group president of the Coca-Cola company, Carl Ware, announced that Coca-Cola will invest another 45 million dollars over the next four years to double its business in Mozambique.

"We believe Mozambique is a great place to do business for any well- run, well-supported venture, and we believe the unique nature of our business will contribute significantly at every level of the Mozambican economy," he said.

"'Our commitment to our Southern African bottling partners has never been stronger and this joint venture is just the latest reflection of our growing support," he added.

Coca-Cola-Sabco already operate a successful bottling plant in Maputo, which has made Coca-Cola company drinks (coca-cola fanta and sprite) widely available in Mozambique, utterly destroying the once thriving trade in soft drinks smuggled in from South Africa.

The Chimoio plant will supply the central provinces. A new bottling plant is planned in Nampula for the north of the country.

A total of 430 people are now directly employed by Coca-Cola Sabco in Mozambique. But the company estimates that for every one of them, ten other jobs are created, mainly in the retail trade.

Ware also presented a Coca-Cola Foundation grant of 250,000 dollars to former first lady Graca Machel, president of the Mozambican Community Development Foundation (FDC), a grassroots NGO catering to the needs of women and children.

The grant is intended to "improve the quality of life for Mozambique's children", Ware said.

A release said Coca-Cola has donated over 30 million dollars in support of community development in Africa since 1990.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


203 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
OAU Exploring Areas Of Cooperation With NGOs


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) is looking for ways of cooperating with Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) on the continent, the Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, said on Saturday.

Speaking at a press conference in Dar es Salaam, Salim, said NGOs had greatly contributed in the development process of the continent hence the need for cooperation. 

"There is no reason why we should not cooperate with them," he said, adding that there has been some suspicion between governments and the organisations, as each side points an accusing finger at the other.

He said NGOs have done a good job to make sure that governments properly performed their duties of developing their people.

"We are looking for ways to help the Non-Governmental Organisations and we plan to sit with them for consultation," Salim added.

He, however, urged nationals to take active part in running the organisations rather than depending on foreigners.

The Tanzanian Government recently criticised organisations it termed "brief-case NGOs" saying it will not tolerate those of them set up to funnel public funds to private ends. This drew a sharp reaction from NGOs.

On the debts of some member countries to the OAU, Salim said the situation had now improved, with only five countries accounting for the large part of those debts. "Payment of debts is now encouraging," he added.

Salim was this week elected OAU Secretary-General for an unprecedented third four-year term.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


204 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 7, 1997


Algeria;
Ruling Party Wins Parliamentary Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The National Democratic Rally (RND) won 155 of the 380 seats in the Algerian national assembly in parliamentary polls concluded on Thursday, according to results released in Algiers on Friday..

Voter turn-out was put at 65.4 percent.

The Movement of the Islamic Society MSI (which had to drop its original name, Hamas) placed a distant second with 69 seats, while the erstwhile single party, the National Liberation Front (FLN), won 64 seats. 

The Al-Nahda Movement won 34 seats, the Front of Socialist Forces (FFS) and the Rally for Culture and Democracy (RCD) won 19 seats each.

The Workers' Party secured 4 seats while independent candidates won 11 seats in together. Three smaller parties shared the remaining five seats.

Several parties, including MSI and Al-Nahdah, challenged the results as soon as they were officially announced. Cheikh Mahfoudh Nahnah, the MSI leader, alleged vote rigging and manipulation of voters by state agents.

But the head of a United Nations team which monitored the polls, K.L. Singh, expressed satisfaction with the organisation of the elections. He said the event was a great victory for Algeria.

Meanwhile, the chairman of the victorious RND, Abdelkader Bensalah, said the election results were "a first step towards setting up legitimate state institutions and a collective victory for Algerian people."

He said the people's massive vote for the RND was a show of support to the democratise reforms initiated by the government.

It is yet to be ascertained whether this would end the bloody war being waged by the banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) since 1992 when the Algiers government cancelled polls which the FIS was poised to win.

An estimated 60,000 people, most of them ordinary people, have been killed in the mayhem.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 7, 1997


Libya;
French Businessmen Visit Libya


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libyan leader, Col. Moammar Kadhafi on Friday in Triopli, received a large delegation of French businessmen and industrialists currently visiting the country.

Kadhafi said at the meeting attended by French ambassador Josette Dallant that the tense relations between his country and the West had made it "very difficult" to develop economic cooperation between the two parties. 

However, the dispute between Tripoli and Paris over the explosion of a UTA flight in 1998 in the Tenere desert in Niger, does not prevent the French oil giants, Total and Elf Aquitaine, from continuing oil exploration and production in Libya.

Paris had accused Kadhafi's government of masterminding the blast in which many people died.

The United States also accused Libyan agents of bombing a PanAm aircraft the previous year over the town of Lockerbie in Scotland, killing more than 250 people.

Libya is currently under a United Nations air embargo initiated by the two western powers.

Washington wants two Libyans it says were involved in the Lockerbie affair to be tried in the United States but Tripoli refused to hand over the men saying such a trial should take place in a neutral country or at the international court at the Hague in Netherlands.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 7, 1997


Tanzania;
WFP Donates 9,550 Tonnes Of Food


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The World Food Programme (WFP) has donated 9,550 metric tonnes of food aid to Tanzania to be distributed to needy people in places facing food shortage.

Sources in the Prime Minister's Office told the Tanzania News Agency, (Shihata) Friday, that the food will start to be distributed in two weeks' time. 

The sources said that the food, made up of 9,100 tonnes of maize and 450 tonnes of beans worth TShs.1.55 billion (USD 2.58 million), will be distributed free of charge to the needy, especially the elderly and people in poor health.

"The able-bodied people will have to get the food through Food For Work Programme," the sources said, explaining that the types of job include brick laying and other public works in the villages.

The sources said that apart from food, WFP has also given TShs.0.713 billion (USD 1.189 million) to cover distribution expenses. The programme has also made available direct and indirect support totalling TShs.211,556,600 (USD 285,961).

About 200,000 people in 13 Tanzanian regions are facing food shortages. The regions are Tabora, Singida, Mwanza, Dodoma, Lindi, Tanga, Morogoro, Coast, Mara, Kilimanjaro, Shinyanga and Arusha.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigeria Beats Kenya 3-0, Through To France '98


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Not even a celebrated training tour of Germany, one of the world beaters in soccer, could save Kenya from a 3-0 drubbing in the hands of Olympic champions Nigeria, in one of the African qualification matches played Saturday for the World Cup in 1998.

The group one match lived up to the media hype with substitute Wilson Oruma, who over-celebrated his 83th minute goal that effectively put the game beyond the Kenyans, receiving a yellow card from Mauritian referee Lim Kee Chong for pulling off his shirt after scoring.

Oruma was lucky to get away with that warning for a repeat of a conduct that earned his teammate Austin Eguavoen the marching orders when Nigeria met Guinea April 5 in Lagos. 

Perhaps Oruma knew his team had nothing to lose having dominated the Kenyans in every department of Saturday's game in Lagos watched by a capacity crowd at the National Stadium in Surulere, a Lagos suburb.

Sunday Oliseh drew first blood, firing a blistering shot in the 12th minute that caught the Harambee Stars goalkeeper off guard.

The worst was yet to come for the Kenyans, who flew in from Germany late Friday and failed to have the essential work out to have a feel of the host's playing pitch.

Emmanuel Amunike made it 2-0 in the 44th minute for the Nigerians, ending the first half with that scoreline.

Since only one team goes through from each of Africa's five groups, the group one spot belong to the Nigerians who top this cluster, which also includes Burkina Faso with 13 points from five matches.

Nigeria's last match against Guinea in Conakry August will be a formality since none of the three other teams in the group can catch up. Kenya is placed second with seven points with Guinea and Burkina Faso trailing.

Saturday's was one of the best games by Nigeria's Super Eagles, now coached by Frenchman Phillipe Troussier, whose new 10,000-U.S.-dollar a month contract is ironically under strain for two previous narrow wins.

If Oruma was ungentlemanly for pulling off his shirt during the game, Amunike made up for that lapse by presenting referee Lee with his own jersey to rap up an evening of superlative performance by the Eagles, who gave Nigerians something to cheer about.

The Nigerian players, all professionals, were apparently buoyed by the presence in the VIP box of Nwankwo Kanu, captain of the under-23 squad that gave Nigeria the Olympic soccer gold in August 1996.

Kanu was recently certified fit to resume his fledgling career after undergoing an operation to correct a defective heart.

A delighted Kanu, who arrived just in time for Saturday's match was the toast of soccer fans who hugged and kissed a player that is tipped to star for Nigeria in France '98.

Nigeria's victory Saturday gives berth for a second consecutive World Cup appearance after the Eagles put up an impressive show at U.S.A. '94.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Algeria;
O.A.U. Satisfied With Algerian Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ALGIERS, Algeria (PANA) - The head of the Organization of African Unity Observer Mission to Algeria's legislative elections, Amadou Toumani Toure, has said he is satisfied at the conduct of Friday's polls.

"We have noted that voting took place calmly and quietly," he told reporters Saturday. 

The missions's objectives was to monitor the polls Toure said, "and not registering complaints or grievances that we have immediately transmitted to the relevant institution," the independent Elections Commission.

He said that the orderly conduct of the polls constituted a "particularly important" stage in the process of consolidation of democracy in Algeria.

The O.A.U. sent 70 observers to Algeria from its secretariat, member states, and nongovernmental organizations.

Above all, he said, the presence of the observers was "a gesture of active solidarity" with Algerians.

"We have wanted, by our presence, to share its (Algeria's) pains," he said.

Turnout at the polls reached 65.4 percent and victory went to the National Democratic Rally. It won 155 out of the 380 seat National Assembly. The Movement for an Islamic Society (formally the militant Muslim group, Hamas) followed with 69 seats. AL-Nahda movement won 34 seats.

The National Liberation Front, Algeria's former sole party, will now send 64 representatives to the assembly. The Social Forces Front and the Rally for Culture and Democracy will each have 19 seats and the Workers' Party four.

Remaining seats will be shared among independents who have won 11 and three small parties sharing five seats.

Several parties, among them the Movement for an Islamic Society and Al-Nahda, rejected the results as soon as they were officially declared.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Salim Says O.A.U. Scored Successes Over 10 years


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity, the continent's preeminent political body, has made significant progress in the past 10 years and it is something to be proud of, Secretary- General Salim Ahmed Salim said Saturday.

Reporting this Sunday, the Tanzania news agency, Shihata, quoted Salim as saying: "Success is a relative term but we have been able to offset many dangerous situations in Africa which might have erupted into civil wars." 

Sometimes, rather than heading off wars, the organizations has only been able to delay conflicts long enough to allow for a chance of negotiations.

He said the O.A.U. had been active in trying to end conflicts in the Comoros, in both the Congo Republic and the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda and Burundi. He was addressing a press conference organized by the Tanzania Journalists Association.

Salim has visited all but two of the 53 O.A.U. member states. He said that 90 percent of these travels were related to conflict solving. He dispelled the notion that he was more on tour of Africa than staying in his office in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

"I do not enjoy those travels as now air travels are more of a risk," he said.

Often, he said, he has been unable to send his top aides to represent him because often ranking state officials would not meet with his representatives. In a recent case, Salim said he was invited to the Democratic Republic of Congo. He sent his deputy who never met with anyone higher than a minister.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


210 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Science and Health;
Africa In Bid To Win Elephant Downlisting War


BYLINE: Marvellous Mapininga, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The countdown to whether Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe will win in their battle to have the elephant downlisted begins in earnest Monday when the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) gets underway in Harare.

The African elephant is, again, expected to take centre stage during the 11-day meeting.

While there are 115 agenda items, 89 tags for species and 75 proposals, the elephants, as was the case in the last three bi-annual meetings, are set to dominate this year's event.

Even Cites Secretary-General Izgrev Topkov is aware of this, hence his call last week for journalists to see "beyond elephants." At a recent news conference he said: "The Zimbabwean media should not only report on elephants. Besides the elephants there are many other animals which might steal the limelight." 

Although at least 600 plant and animal species -- including the elephant, cheetah, leopard, whales, black and white rhino -- are facing extinction and so are listed on appendix 1.

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe have launched spirited campaigns in proposing that the elephant be downlisted to appendix 2, where it could be traded under an export permit without endangering extinction of the species.

Appendix 2 includes species that are not yet endangered but are being monitored to ensure sustainable utilisation.

Species listed under this category may be traded commercially where an export permit is issued and provided trade would not be detrimental to the species in question.

Zimbabwe, for instance, contends that its elephant population of some 60,000 will not be threatened with extinction if traded commercially.

Instead, the elephant is posing a threat to human life and an ecological disaster because Zimbabwe's carrying capacity for this mammal is 35,000.

Since the ivory ban was imposed, Zimbabwe has at least 40 tonnes of ivory stockpiles. These prizes, worth 40 million zimdollars (nearly four million U.S. dollars) are gathering dust at national parks and wildlife premises, thereby losing value.

While countries lobbying for the donwlisting of the elephant say they have a strong case, they are facing stiff opposition from the United States and numerous Western-backed animal rights groups.

The U.S. has said it will oppose downlisting elephants and allow African countries with elephants to dispose of their ivory stocks.

The leader of the U.S. delegation to the meeting, Donald Barry, said Cites was critically important in safeguarding the world's wildlife and that his country would oppose the downlisting proposal.

While many other African countries would like to have their elephants downlisted, these countries do not want to speak openly on the issue. They fear upsetting the all too powerful Western countries as this could lead to their losing aid and other forms of bilateral assistance.

Analysts say the elephant issue is no longer about protecting the animals but is very much political as it is economical.

So complex is the issue that Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe are now calling for a secret ballot to choose whether the elephants should be downlisted or not.

All this is to protect delegates from intimidation by Western countries opposed to the lifting of the ivory trade ban.

"We will get full support if voting is done by secret ballot," a delegate said Friday at the two-day pre-conference meeting. "It has emerged that some countries, and even ngos, fear the economic repercussions if they do not vote the way of those who provide aid."

Concern has been raised that the U.S. would oppose the move to vote by secret ballot.

At least Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe could take comfort in the fact they are fully and openly supported by some groups.

The World Conservation Union in Zimbabwe will support the country's proposal to downlist the elephant to allow limited international ivory trade.

The agency's announcement has been regarded as a major boost to the three countries' lobby but whether it would have an impact or not is another matter altogether.

The union's pro-downlisting stance is based on a report prepared after the review of elephant management in the three concerned African states.

The report concluded that no major risks to the Zimbabwean elephant population had been identified and current levels of offtake appeared to be sustainable. "The downlisting of the elephant was a necessary step towards ensuring that local communities living adjacent to wildlife resources fully benefited from such resources and thereby give them an incentive to contribute towards wildlife conservation," said the union's national committee.

Japan is doubtless hoping that any motion to downlist elephants will be upheld. It has expressed interest in buying up to 180,000 tonnes of ivory from the three Aouthern African countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


211 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 23 - Africa (06/06)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3627 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Democratic People's Republic of Korea B) Democratic Republic of Congo, Republic of Congo (Brazzaville), Burundi, and Tanzania C) Sudan D) Angola E) Sierra Leone

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA

1. Update

a) FAO/WFP Special Alert, issued on 3 June, warns that severe food shortages are faced by the population throughout the country. b) Substantial food aid shipments are arriving in DPR Korea: 69,000 tons arrived in May; confirmed shipments for June total 192,000 tons.

B. REGIONAL OPERATION FOR THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO, RWANDA, BURUNDI AND TANZANIA (WITH INFORMATION FROM THE REPUBLIC OF CONGO)

1. Democratic Republic of Congo - information as of 5 June

a) UN missions are going to Ubundu, Ikela and Boende, to make preparations for repatriation of Rwandan refugees at these locations. b) Serious security incidents reported in Uvira and in Goma area. UNHCR temporarily suspends repatriation operations in Karuba following the killing of a local Save the Children worker and four accompanying refugees. 

2. The Republic of Congo

a) Fighting in Brazzaville interrupts planned move of Rwandan refugees by barges from Liranga and Lukolela to Bilolo accommodation centre 20 km north of the city. Repatriation operation due to commence on 6 June.

3. Burundi

a) Heavy fighting takes place close to Bujumbura. b) WFP assesses needs of displaced and regroupement sites in Bubanza and Kayanza provinces.

4. Tanzania

a) WFP to provide food for in-patients in five hospitals in areas of Kagera region hosting refugee populations. b) Barge operations out of Kigoma port to Uvira resume; operations to Bujumbura will start when food commodities allocated to Burundi arrive in Kigoma. c) WFP begins local procurement of 5,000 metric tons of maize and 480 metric tons of pulses for drought operation.

C. SUDAN

1. Update

a) June clearance for WFP/OLS flights into south Sudan not received; all relief flights from Lokichokio, Kenya, suspended since 3 June. Continued ban on WFP Hercules flights. b) Impact of ban especially felt in Bahr el Ghazal, Upper Nile and Jonglei, where serious food shortages are reported. c) First tranche of 350 metric tons of cereals dispatched by truck by WFP Kampala reaches southern Sudan for distribution to Sudanese returnees and displaced persons.

D. ANGOLA

1. Update

a) WFP to airlift food to displaced persons in Lunda Norte fleeing fighting between government troops and rebels.

E. SIERRA LEONE

1. Update - information as of 5 June

a) Fighting in Freetown following coup of 25 May subsides but harassment of civilians by street gangs and armed robbery continue. b) Large numbers of people from Freetown have reportedly left for the interior; small groups have arrived in Guinea.

PART II - DETAILS

A. DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA

1. UPDATE

1.1 A joint FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission visited DPR Korea from 17 to 24 May. Its finding have been summarized in a Special Alert issued on 3 June.

1.2 The Mission concluded that the food crisis is worsening, with a grave food security situation developing in all parts of the country.

1.3 The Government's records showed that the food stocks of the Public Distribution System (PDS) on which some 80 percent of the population rely for their basic requirements, were expected to run out by the end of June. The food situation was equally desperate for the five million collective farm workers and their families who are not covered by the PDS but receive their share of the crops at the time of harvest.

1.4 Commercial imports are mainly limited to barter arrangements because of the country's serious hard currency constraints, and are inadequate to ensure regular food supplies, even at severely reduced levels, to the majority of the population.

1.5 In assessing the prospects for the main harvest in October, the Mission found that early winter thaw in March and good rains in May had benefitted the germination and establishment of maize and also supplemented soil moisture and irrigation supplies for paddy. Maize planting had been completed by mid May and paddy transplanting was expected to be completed by early June, some two weeks in advance of normal sowing periods. However, in spite of a mass Government programme to replenish top soils last winter and increase the supply of organic fertilizers, food production this year will continue to be seriously constrained by the lack of essential inputs such as chemical fertilizers, pesticides and fuel and spare parts for machinery.

1.6 The Mission concluded that the total import requirements for the 1996/97 marketing year (November 1996 to October 1997) amounted to some 1.9 million tons. Out of this, 430,000 tons might be imported commercially with confirmed food aid contributions providing an additional 323,000 tons. The remaining uncovered requirement would thus be close to 1.2 million tons.

1.7 Recorded arrivals during the month of May total some 69,000 tons. This can be compared to 40,100 tons of food which arrived during the six-month period November 1996-April 1997. Confirmed shipments for June amount to 192,000 tons, including a bilateral contribution of 70,000 tons of maize from China. Total arrivals in June are expected to increase even further: the European Community, which in May sent a shipment of 35,400 tons of rice and maize meal, is currently discussing with WFP the possibilities of further large-scale contributions to DPR Korea.

B. REGIONAL OPERATION FOR THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO, RWANDA, BURUNDI AND TANZANIA (WITH INFORMATION FROM THE REPUBLIC OF CONGO)

1. DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - information as of 5 June

1.1 The Mbandaka repatriation is nearing its end. By 5 June, 6, 904 refugees had been repatriated to Rwanda and only a few hundred people are now left in the area. As the number of Rwandans flown home from Kisangani is 39,394, this brings the total number of refugees evacuated by air to Rwanda from these two locations to 46,298.

1.2 Approximately 2,500 refugees remain at the Kisangani transit centre awaiting evacuation to Rwanda. All the 659 refugees at Obilo, km 82, will be transported to Kisangani with the next train. Unconfirmed reports indicate that around 2,000 refugees have just arrived by boat in Ubundu, further south. A UN mission is planned for 6 June to visit the area to confirm the presence of the refugees and make the necessary preparations for their repatriation. Other UN missions are flying to Ikela and Boende with the same purpose.

1.3 The WFP airlift of food into Kisangani continues, to build up stocks for the rehabilitation programme in DR Congo.

1.4 Various security incidents were reported in Uvira, now that preparations are under way for the return of thousands of refugees from Tanzania and the return of displaced Congolese (Zaireans), who left the area in October 1996, from Kalemie. The escarpment road between Bukavu and Uvira is facing increasing security problems and a UNHCR vehicle was attacked by armed men along this route.

1.5 The security situation in the Goma area is also steadily deteriorating and the number of violent incidents targeting aid agencies is on the rise. UNHCR has temporarily suspended its operations in Karuba, a major collection point for refugees who wish to return to Rwanda, following the killing of a local Save the Children worker and four accompanying refugees. Staff of World Vision, recently established in Goma, were also attacked by armed men on 4 June.

2. REPUBLIC OF CONGO (Congo/Brazzaville)

2.1 The air repatriation from Brazzaville is planned to commence on 6 June. There are now some 5,000 Rwandan refugees at Bilolo, the accommodation centre 20 km north of this city. Eight barges provided by the Government left Brazzaville to fetch another 8,000 refugees in Liranga and Lukolela, but due to heavy fighting in Brazzaville and in the north of the country, the barge convoy returned to Brazzaville on 4 June.

2.2 A round trip by barge takes a minimum of seven to ten days but as the airstrips in the area are too small to receive large aircraft, all the refugees are to be moved to Brazzaville before being flown to Rwanda.

3. BURUNDI

3.1 Insecurity increases near the capital with sustained heavy fighting clearly audible in Bujumbura.

3.2 WFP assessment teams are evaluating the needs of displaced and regroupement sites in Bubanza and Kayanza provinces, amid reports that the food security situation of some groups is rapidly deteriorating. Once this assessment exercise is completed, WFP will start targeted distributions to needy groups, while waiting for similar exercises to cover the whole of the provinces.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 WFP, Kagera authorities and the regional Hospital Administration have signed an agreement covering WFP's assistance to in-patients in five hospitals in areas of Kagera region which have hosted refugee populations. Under this programme, WFP will provide food commodities to these hospitals, thus reducing expenses to patients and increasing their access to a basic diet while they are in hospital.

4.2 The influx of Burundian refugees into Kasulu and Kibondo districts continued during the week. Some 6,500 refugees were registered in Kasulu, most of whom had transferred from the holding centre in Kigoma town. Nduta and Mkugwa camps in Kibondo district received 261 new arrivals.

4.3 Barge operations out of Kigoma port have resumed. The first barge from Uvira arrived in Kigoma, was loaded, and departed on 4 June to Uvira. Lake operations to Bujumbura are also due to begin soon, once food commodities allocated to Burundi arrive in Kigoma.

4.4 Drought operation: WFP has begun the local procurement of 5,000 metric tons of maize and 480 metric tons of pulses in Tanzania. These commodities are expected to be delivered starting next week, for distribution to drought-affected persons. NGOs will effect distribution to those families identified as no longer having any purchasing power. Special attention will be given to vulnerable persons, children and the elderly. WFP teams will monitor the distribution and ensure those targeted are reached. The impact of the food distributions will also be assessed.

C. SUDAN

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP/Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) have still not received June clearance for flights into the south, resulting in suspension of all relief flights from Lokichokio, Kenya, since 3 June. In addition, a continued ban on WFP C-130 flights, in place since 30 March (with the exception of one air drop which took place on 30 May), has had serious consequences on displaced and war-affected persons throughout the south.

1.2 The situation is especially critical in Bahr el Ghazal, Upper Nile and Jonglei, where significant food shortages and cases of severe malnutrition have been reported by OLS.

1.3 Over the past two months, an average of 20 percent of the total planned beneficiaries in the South have received food assistance, with only 9 percent of planned air deliveries taking place in southern Sudan. WFP delivery into the south with Buffalo aircraft was 450 metric tons. The flights of the Buffalo aircraft were also suspended between 6-16 May and since 3 June.

1.4 The breakdown of the total limited food distribution (830 metric tons) which was possible during the period 1-31 May, to a total of 212,230 war-affected and displaced persons, is as follows: Bahr el Ghazal: 150 metric tons to 50,250 beneficiaries; Jonglei/Upper Nile: 73 metric tons to 61,675 beneficiaries; and Equatoria: 607 metric tons to 100,300 beneficiaries.

1.5 WFP Kampala reports that the first tranche of 350 metric tons of cereals dispatched by WFP from Uganda has now arrived in southern Sudan for distribution to Sudanese returnees and displaced persons. Between June and August another 1,828 metric tons of mixed commodities will be sent by WFP Kampala to Yei County and 167 metric tons to Western Equatoria. This operation, initiated in late April, involved the use of 10 long-haul private trucks for the route Kampala/Koboko, near the border with Sudan, and a dozen short-haul trucks for the rest of the route.

D. ANGOLA

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP will begin an emergency food airlift to assist displaced persons in Lunda Norte. Internally displaced began arriving in N'Zaji village on 19 May, reportedly fleeing fighting between government troops and rebels in surrounding areas. By 1 June, 2,100 persons had arrived and reports speak of 200 new arrivals per day since then. Most of the displaced people, who are being accommodated in a makeshift camp, are in good condition. Some children, however, show signs of malnutrition.

1.2 Emergency food assistance for 3,000 persons and supplementary food rations for 100 malnourished children will be airlifted. A team from WFP Luanda and the WFP Saurimo sub- office in Lunda Sul province has been dispatched to the area to supervise and monitor food distribution. Meanwhile, WFP implementing partner in N'Zaji, the Lutheran World Federation, is distributing food from stocks of a WFP-assisted project to the displaced persons until airlifted commodities arrive.

E. SIERRA LEONE

1. UPDATE - information as of 5 June

1.1 Fighting in Freetown which followed the coup of 25 May has subsided significantly over recent days. However, there are on-going reports of the harassment of civilians by street gangs, and an increase in armed robbery.

1.2 Civilians from Freetown have been reportedly fleeing in large numbers to the interior regions and small influxes of refugees have been reported in Guinea. The situation remains stable in Liberia, where no new refugees have been reported. WFP staff is on stand-by in border areas to monitor the situation. Contingency plans are in place in preparation for any sudden mass influxes from Sierra Leone.

1.3 WFP Sierra Leone international staff, all of whom were evacuated last week, are being redeployed to WFP operations in Guinea and Liberia until such time as their return to Sierra Leone is possible. WFP national staff in Freetown are reported safe.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 23 of 1997 - June 6, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 23 - Africa (06/06)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3627 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Democratic People's Republic of Korea B) Democratic Republic of Congo, Republic of Congo (Brazzaville), Burundi, and Tanzania C) Sudan D) Angola E) Sierra Leone

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA

1. Update

a) FAO/WFP Special Alert, issued on 3 June, warns that severe food shortages are faced by the population throughout the country. b) Substantial food aid shipments are arriving in DPR Korea: 69,000 tons arrived in May; confirmed shipments for June total 192,000 tons.

B. REGIONAL OPERATION FOR THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO, RWANDA, BURUNDI AND TANZANIA (WITH INFORMATION FROM THE REPUBLIC OF CONGO)

1. Democratic Republic of Congo - information as of 5 June

a) UN missions are going to Ubundu, Ikela and Boende, to make preparations for repatriation of Rwandan refugees at these locations. b) Serious security incidents reported in Uvira and in Goma area. UNHCR temporarily suspends repatriation operations in Karuba following the killing of a local Save the Children worker and four accompanying refugees. 

2. The Republic of Congo

a) Fighting in Brazzaville interrupts planned move of Rwandan refugees by barges from Liranga and Lukolela to Bilolo accommodation centre 20 km north of the city. Repatriation operation due to commence on 6 June.

3. Burundi

a) Heavy fighting takes place close to Bujumbura. b) WFP assesses needs of displaced and regroupement sites in Bubanza and Kayanza provinces.

4. Tanzania

a) WFP to provide food for in-patients in five hospitals in areas of Kagera region hosting refugee populations. b) Barge operations out of Kigoma port to Uvira resume; operations to Bujumbura will start when food commodities allocated to Burundi arrive in Kigoma. c) WFP begins local procurement of 5,000 metric tons of maize and 480 metric tons of pulses for drought operation.

C. SUDAN

1. Update

a) June clearance for WFP/OLS flights into south Sudan not received; all relief flights from Lokichokio, Kenya, suspended since 3 June. Continued ban on WFP Hercules flights. b) Impact of ban especially felt in Bahr el Ghazal, Upper Nile and Jonglei, where serious food shortages are reported. c) First tranche of 350 metric tons of cereals dispatched by truck by WFP Kampala reaches southern Sudan for distribution to Sudanese returnees and displaced persons.

D. ANGOLA

1. Update

a) WFP to airlift food to displaced persons in Lunda Norte fleeing fighting between government troops and rebels.

E. SIERRA LEONE

1. Update - information as of 5 June

a) Fighting in Freetown following coup of 25 May subsides but harassment of civilians by street gangs and armed robbery continue. b) Large numbers of people from Freetown have reportedly left for the interior; small groups have arrived in Guinea.

PART II - DETAILS

A. DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA

1. UPDATE

1.1 A joint FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission visited DPR Korea from 17 to 24 May. Its finding have been summarized in a Special Alert issued on 3 June.

1.2 The Mission concluded that the food crisis is worsening, with a grave food security situation developing in all parts of the country.

1.3 The Government's records showed that the food stocks of the Public Distribution System (PDS) on which some 80 percent of the population rely for their basic requirements, were expected to run out by the end of June. The food situation was equally desperate for the five million collective farm workers and their families who are not covered by the PDS but receive their share of the crops at the time of harvest.

1.4 Commercial imports are mainly limited to barter arrangements because of the country's serious hard currency constraints, and are inadequate to ensure regular food supplies, even at severely reduced levels, to the majority of the population.

1.5 In assessing the prospects for the main harvest in October, the Mission found that early winter thaw in March and good rains in May had benefitted the germination and establishment of maize and also supplemented soil moisture and irrigation supplies for paddy. Maize planting had been completed by mid May and paddy transplanting was expected to be completed by early June, some two weeks in advance of normal sowing periods. However, in spite of a mass Government programme to replenish top soils last winter and increase the supply of organic fertilizers, food production this year will continue to be seriously constrained by the lack of essential inputs such as chemical fertilizers, pesticides and fuel and spare parts for machinery.

1.6 The Mission concluded that the total import requirements for the 1996/97 marketing year (November 1996 to October 1997) amounted to some 1.9 million tons. Out of this, 430,000 tons might be imported commercially with confirmed food aid contributions providing an additional 323,000 tons. The remaining uncovered requirement would thus be close to 1.2 million tons.

1.7 Recorded arrivals during the month of May total some 69,000 tons. This can be compared to 40,100 tons of food which arrived during the six-month period November 1996-April 1997. Confirmed shipments for June amount to 192,000 tons, including a bilateral contribution of 70,000 tons of maize from China. Total arrivals in June are expected to increase even further: the European Community, which in May sent a shipment of 35,400 tons of rice and maize meal, is currently discussing with WFP the possibilities of further large-scale contributions to DPR Korea.

B. REGIONAL OPERATION FOR THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO, RWANDA, BURUNDI AND TANZANIA (WITH INFORMATION FROM THE REPUBLIC OF CONGO)

1. DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO - information as of 5 June

1.1 The Mbandaka repatriation is nearing its end. By 5 June, 6, 904 refugees had been repatriated to Rwanda and only a few hundred people are now left in the area. As the number of Rwandans flown home from Kisangani is 39,394, this brings the total number of refugees evacuated by air to Rwanda from these two locations to 46,298.

1.2 Approximately 2,500 refugees remain at the Kisangani transit centre awaiting evacuation to Rwanda. All the 659 refugees at Obilo, km 82, will be transported to Kisangani with the next train. Unconfirmed reports indicate that around 2,000 refugees have just arrived by boat in Ubundu, further south. A UN mission is planned for 6 June to visit the area to confirm the presence of the refugees and make the necessary preparations for their repatriation. Other UN missions are flying to Ikela and Boende with the same purpose.

1.3 The WFP airlift of food into Kisangani continues, to build up stocks for the rehabilitation programme in DR Congo.

1.4 Various security incidents were reported in Uvira, now that preparations are under way for the return of thousands of refugees from Tanzania and the return of displaced Congolese (Zaireans), who left the area in October 1996, from Kalemie. The escarpment road between Bukavu and Uvira is facing increasing security problems and a UNHCR vehicle was attacked by armed men along this route.

1.5 The security situation in the Goma area is also steadily deteriorating and the number of violent incidents targeting aid agencies is on the rise. UNHCR has temporarily suspended its operations in Karuba, a major collection point for refugees who wish to return to Rwanda, following the killing of a local Save the Children worker and four accompanying refugees. Staff of World Vision, recently established in Goma, were also attacked by armed men on 4 June.

2. REPUBLIC OF CONGO (Congo/Brazzaville)

2.1 The air repatriation from Brazzaville is planned to commence on 6 June. There are now some 5,000 Rwandan refugees at Bilolo, the accommodation centre 20 km north of this city. Eight barges provided by the Government left Brazzaville to fetch another 8,000 refugees in Liranga and Lukolela, but due to heavy fighting in Brazzaville and in the north of the country, the barge convoy returned to Brazzaville on 4 June.

2.2 A round trip by barge takes a minimum of seven to ten days but as the airstrips in the area are too small to receive large aircraft, all the refugees are to be moved to Brazzaville before being flown to Rwanda.

3. BURUNDI

3.1 Insecurity increases near the capital with sustained heavy fighting clearly audible in Bujumbura.

3.2 WFP assessment teams are evaluating the needs of displaced and regroupement sites in Bubanza and Kayanza provinces, amid reports that the food security situation of some groups is rapidly deteriorating. Once this assessment exercise is completed, WFP will start targeted distributions to needy groups, while waiting for similar exercises to cover the whole of the provinces.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 WFP, Kagera authorities and the regional Hospital Administration have signed an agreement covering WFP's assistance to in-patients in five hospitals in areas of Kagera region which have hosted refugee populations. Under this programme, WFP will provide food commodities to these hospitals, thus reducing expenses to patients and increasing their access to a basic diet while they are in hospital.

4.2 The influx of Burundian refugees into Kasulu and Kibondo districts continued during the week. Some 6,500 refugees were registered in Kasulu, most of whom had transferred from the holding centre in Kigoma town. Nduta and Mkugwa camps in Kibondo district received 261 new arrivals.

4.3 Barge operations out of Kigoma port have resumed. The first barge from Uvira arrived in Kigoma, was loaded, and departed on 4 June to Uvira. Lake operations to Bujumbura are also due to begin soon, once food commodities allocated to Burundi arrive in Kigoma.

4.4 Drought operation: WFP has begun the local procurement of 5,000 metric tons of maize and 480 metric tons of pulses in Tanzania. These commodities are expected to be delivered starting next week, for distribution to drought-affected persons. NGOs will effect distribution to those families identified as no longer having any purchasing power. Special attention will be given to vulnerable persons, children and the elderly. WFP teams will monitor the distribution and ensure those targeted are reached. The impact of the food distributions will also be assessed.

C. SUDAN

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP/Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) have still not received June clearance for flights into the south, resulting in suspension of all relief flights from Lokichokio, Kenya, since 3 June. In addition, a continued ban on WFP C-130 flights, in place since 30 March (with the exception of one air drop which took place on 30 May), has had serious consequences on displaced and war-affected persons throughout the south.

1.2 The situation is especially critical in Bahr el Ghazal, Upper Nile and Jonglei, where significant food shortages and cases of severe malnutrition have been reported by OLS.

1.3 Over the past two months, an average of 20 percent of the total planned beneficiaries in the South have received food assistance, with only 9 percent of planned air deliveries taking place in southern Sudan. WFP delivery into the south with Buffalo aircraft was 450 metric tons. The flights of the Buffalo aircraft were also suspended between 6-16 May and since 3 June.

1.4 The breakdown of the total limited food distribution (830 metric tons) which was possible during the period 1-31 May, to a total of 212,230 war-affected and displaced persons, is as follows: Bahr el Ghazal: 150 metric tons to 50,250 beneficiaries; Jonglei/Upper Nile: 73 metric tons to 61,675 beneficiaries; and Equatoria: 607 metric tons to 100,300 beneficiaries.

1.5 WFP Kampala reports that the first tranche of 350 metric tons of cereals dispatched by WFP from Uganda has now arrived in southern Sudan for distribution to Sudanese returnees and displaced persons. Between June and August another 1,828 metric tons of mixed commodities will be sent by WFP Kampala to Yei County and 167 metric tons to Western Equatoria. This operation, initiated in late April, involved the use of 10 long-haul private trucks for the route Kampala/Koboko, near the border with Sudan, and a dozen short-haul trucks for the rest of the route.

D. ANGOLA

1. UPDATE

1.1 WFP will begin an emergency food airlift to assist displaced persons in Lunda Norte. Internally displaced began arriving in N'Zaji village on 19 May, reportedly fleeing fighting between government troops and rebels in surrounding areas. By 1 June, 2,100 persons had arrived and reports speak of 200 new arrivals per day since then. Most of the displaced people, who are being accommodated in a makeshift camp, are in good condition. Some children, however, show signs of malnutrition.

1.2 Emergency food assistance for 3,000 persons and supplementary food rations for 100 malnourished children will be airlifted. A team from WFP Luanda and the WFP Saurimo sub- office in Lunda Sul province has been dispatched to the area to supervise and monitor food distribution. Meanwhile, WFP implementing partner in N'Zaji, the Lutheran World Federation, is distributing food from stocks of a WFP-assisted project to the displaced persons until airlifted commodities arrive.

E. SIERRA LEONE

1. UPDATE - information as of 5 June

1.1 Fighting in Freetown which followed the coup of 25 May has subsided significantly over recent days. However, there are on-going reports of the harassment of civilians by street gangs, and an increase in armed robbery.

1.2 Civilians from Freetown have been reportedly fleeing in large numbers to the interior regions and small influxes of refugees have been reported in Guinea. The situation remains stable in Liberia, where no new refugees have been reported. WFP staff is on stand-by in border areas to monitor the situation. Contingency plans are in place in preparation for any sudden mass influxes from Sierra Leone.

1.3 WFP Sierra Leone international staff, all of whom were evacuated last week, are being redeployed to WFP operations in Guinea and Liberia until such time as their return to Sierra Leone is possible. WFP national staff in Freetown are reported safe.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 23 of 1997 - June 6, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


213 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
World Cup Berths Decided


BYLINE: Paul Ejime & Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondents, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerians were Sunday still celebrating their country's second World Cup qualification after the Super Eagles' trounced Kenya's Harambee Stars 3-0 on their way to France '98.

Lagos, the nation's economic hub, has been agog with jubilation which started soon after Mauritian referee Kim Lee Chong blew the final whistle.

Many soccer fans, drumming and dancing took to the streets and rounded off the merriment in beer palors.

The match was broadcast live by the Nigerian Television Authority with each of the Eagles three goals greeted by resounding ovation at the Lagos National Stadium and across the country. 

Although it is not the first time Nigeria, the Olympic champions, has qualified for the World Cup finals, the build-up to Saturday's match was not without hitches.

Problems arose over the choice of camp site for the Eagles and the tactics of their new technical adviser the Frenchman, Phillipe Troussier, which Nigerian fans considered suspect.

While the Nigerians pre-occupied themselves with the needless debates rather than preparation, Kenya took its squad on a three-week playing tour of Germany under their German coach, Reinhardt Fabisch.

As it turned out, the critics were proved wrong. The match was no more than a practice session for the Eagles array of stars.

Fabisch admitted that much in his post-match interviews.

"My boys did play well but they lost to the Nigerians who are superiors," he said.

The Eagles' impressive performance in Nigeria's first World Cup appearance in U.S.A.'94 was, he added, "the beginning of good things to happen to Nigerian and African soccer."

Fabisch said: "The Super Eagles will go far in France '98. They will go beyond the quarter-finals and may even qualify for finals with their present skills."

An over-joyed Nigerian sports minister, Jim Nwobodo, described the Eagles performance as "simply wonderful."

He told reporters: "We showed that we are not only the Olympic champions but the current best African team."

Former Nigerian Vice President Augustus Aikhomu, an avid soccer fan, said he was happy with the win.

"I wish our team good luck," he added.

Eagles pointman Daniel Amokachi, nicknamed "the Bull", said his squad hoped to do better in France than at U.S.A. '94.

"I'm sure there is going to be a difference this time," he said.

Nigeria lost to Italy in the second round of the 1994 tournament.

Apparently reacting to the warning from soccer buffs against over- celebration, the chairman of the Nigerian Football Association (NFA), Abdulmumini Aminu, said with the France '98 ticket assured, his association would concentrate on preparation.

He said the association had already received invitations from Brazil, Germany, Japan, Korea and South Africa ahead of the World Cup.

"We cannot accept all these invitations but we will endeavour to take on those that can help us in our preparation," Aminu said.

The association will also organize friendly matches at home "so that (the press) can participate in evaluating their (Eagles) performance and pointing out where we have gone wrong," he said.

Nigerian's French coach, Troussier, who is architect of Saturday's victory is anything but happy.

"My future now depends on the N.F.A. and the people of Nigeria. I am not expecting any favour from anybody as I believe my job will speak for me," he said at post-match news conference.

This is a reference to strong speculation that his new 10,000-U.S.- dollar a month contract was on the line.

These was reinforced by the unexplained presence in Lagos Saturday of the Eagles' former coach, Clemens Westerhof, of the Netherlands. He abandoned Nigeria after leading the Eagles to a high point of the nation's soccer in U.S.A. '94.

Westerhof insists he is jobless and on vacation but would not mind being called back to handle the Eagles.

Some fans see the VIP treatment Westerhof received at the stadium during the Nigeria-Kenya match as perhaps being a veiled warning to Troussier.

Nigeria still has an outstanding match against Guinea in August in the qualification series. But its outcome will be a formality, since the Eagles have already secured the sole ticket in the four-nation group one Africa zone, which includes Burkina Faso.

Meanwhile, soccer-crazy Zambians in the capital, Lusaka, were in a subdued mood Monday, following their 3-0 defeat Sunday in Johannesburg by South Africa's Bafana Bafana.

This loss ended the Zambia's hopes for a first World Cup soccer final.

"It is unbelievable. I could not believe it when the referee blew the final whistle It is just too much," said Joshua Zulu who had watched the game on television.

His sentiments were echoed by several other disappointed fans who spoke to PANA in Lusaka, Monday.

"I have not eaten anything since Sunday. All the appetite has gone. It is like a funeral for me and other members of the family," George Tembo said.

The Zambian team played two international friendly preparatory games against Cameroon and Kuwait before its encounter with South Africa.

Zambia failed to qualify for the U.S.A '94 World Cup soccer finals following a controversial 1-0 loss to Morocco in a crucial qualifying match played in Casablanca.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


214 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Burundi;
First Women Police In Macho Capital


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Previously the preserve of men, the Burundian National Gendarmerie, the military police, has trained 1,000 women in three months for police and traffic duty.

Women began appearing in the streets of the capital last week, INL002 from SSS.067 (970609-18:12) QN PANAINL . PANADKR MSG066G/02E

(2) attracting the curious looks of motorists and pedestrians more accustomed to being hassled by men in blue uniforms, blue and white helmets.

However, like their male counterparts the females have demonstrated equal authority in dealing with criminals and recalcitrant drivers. Female gendarmes control traffic efficiently at Bujumbura's main roads and the commander of the Special Traffic Police, Tharcisse Nduwayo, says he is proud of his graduates.

"About a hundred have been sent to our service for a one-month practical placement in road traffic regulation and crime control," he said. "They are carrying out their mission correctly and without any complex."

The patrolwomen acknowledge that they are working in an environment marked by the prejudices of a macho society.

"But what an exalting job it is," said Virginie Eniyongere, accompanied by Marie-Christine Ninybuka and Jovithe Niyonima, on their way back to barracks.

Like all pupils in the final year of secondary education and undergraduate students, the three young women were conscripted for military service. The government needed them in its fight against an armed rebellion by the National Council for the Defence of Democracy.

For that challenge, all conscripts were trained for service in the infantry.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Mugabe Opens Cites Conference


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The conference of the parties to the the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) began Monday with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe challenging the international community to accept that a well monitored, evaluated and ecosystem-managed habitat could support sustainable utilization.

Mugabe told the 10th Cites meeting that there should be encouragement of sustainable utilization and development for those countries whose actions upheld scientifically accepted standards, while penalizing which abused the environment.

"To refuse to accept the principle of differentiated responsibilities will mean doom for the international environmental movement and certainly disaster to natural resources covered by Cites Convention," Mugabe said.

Some 5,000 delegates are attending the meeting, the second to be held in Africa after the 1983 meeting hosted by Botswana. 

The opening of this meeting in the Zimbabwe capital, Harare, was spiced with a traditional African flavour of song and dance by a troupe clad in warrior garb of animal skins and wielding knobkerries (short sticks with a tennis ball size knobs at one end) and shields.

This meeting has a participation of 96.3 percent, the highest in the 25-year history of the convention.

Mugabe, who last week assumed the chairmanship of the 53-member Organization of African Unity, spoke for the entire continent. He said that some of the world's plant and animal species were threatened with extinction due to absolute poverty within the populations of developing nations which has led to over-reliance on natural resources for survival, especially in rural areas.

Other causes, he said, were the loss of habitat because of deforestation and human and animal pressure. He added that developing countries, where natural resources were a significant contributor to the gross domestic product, had to service their debt

He told delegates of the situation in Zimbabwe where a commitment to natural resource conservation was demonstrated by the fact that 15 percent of the country was classified reserved forests and national parks.

If areas under the Communal Areas Management Programme for Indigenous Resources (Campfire) were included, he said, 30 percent of Zimbabwe's mass was under wildlife management.

There is legislation in Zimbabwe to ensure the sustainable use and conservation of Zimbabwe's biological heritage.

Mugabe told the meeting that Zimbabwe's management of the environment and natural resources was fashioned to meet the development interests of the present generation without jeopardizing those of posterity.

"Our people, through their representative and democratically elected councils, are now able to participate in wildlife management," he said.

"They now understand the value which they derive from better environmental management principles since they associate wildlife and other natural resources with their own socio-economic development," he added.

The principle of anticipating and preventing negative environmental impacts, he said, was less costly and more effective than correcting such problems.

"To safeguard the future generations' right to resources, we believe in environmental impact assessments," he said.

He told delegates that Zimbabwe protected its natural resources, especially wildlife, at great expense. The army, police, national parks scouts and rangers are mobilized to guard against poachers.

Water also has to be pumped from underground sources for the animals as they tend to be found in arid and semi-desert conditions.

He drew laughter from delegates when he said that Zimbabwe believed that every species should pay its way to survival and with the management strategies that had been devised, most species would survive.

Saying they have too many elephants, Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe have been lobbying delegates to the current Cites conference to have elephants downgraded from Apendix I of endangered species to Appendix II. The later permits trade under a permit without endangering the species with possible extinction


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Africa In Bid To Win Elephant Downlisting War


BYLINE: Marvellous Mapininga, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The countdown to whether Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe will win their battle to have the elephant downlisted from the list of animals at risk of extinction began Monday when the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) gets underway in Harare.

The African elephant is, again, expected to take centre stage during the 11-day meeting.

While there are 115 agenda items, 89 tags for species and 75 proposals, the elephants, as was the case in the last three bi-annual meetings, are set to dominate this year's event.

Even Cites Secretary-General Izgrev Topkov is aware of this, hence his call last week for journalists to see "beyond elephants." At a recent news conference he said: "The Zimbabwean media should not only report on elephants. Besides the elephants there are many other animals which might steal the limelight." 

Although at least 600 plant and animal species -- including the elephant, cheetah, leopard, whales, black and white rhino -- are facing extinction and so are listed on appendix 1.

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe have launched spirited campaigns in proposing that the elephant be downlisted to appendix 2, where it could be traded under an export permit without endangering extinction of the species.

Appendix 2 includes species that are not yet endangered but are being monitored to ensure sustainable utilisation.

Species listed under this category may be traded commercially where an export permit is issued and provided trade would not be detrimental to the species in question.

Zimbabwe, for instance, contends that its elephant population of some 60,000 will not be threatened with extinction if traded commercially.

Instead, the elephant is posing a threat to human life and an ecological disaster because Zimbabwe's carrying capacity for this mammal is 35,000.

Since the ivory ban was imposed, Zimbabwe has at least 40 tons of ivory stockpiles. These prizes, worth nearly four million U.S. dollars are gathering dust at national parks and wildlife premises, thereby losing value.

While countries lobbying for the donwlisting of the elephant say they have a strong case, they are facing stiff opposition from the United States and numerous Western-backed animal rights groups.

The U.S. has said it will oppose downlisting elephants and allow African countries with elephants to dispose of their ivory stocks.

The leader of the U.S. delegation to the meeting, Donald Barry, said Cites was critically important in safeguarding the world's wildlife and that his country would oppose the downlisting proposal.

While many other African countries would like to have their elephants downlisted, these countries do not want to speak openly on the issue. They fear upsetting the all too powerful Western countries as this could lead to their losing aid and other forms of bilateral assistance.

Analysts say the elephant issue is no longer about protecting the animals but is very much political as it is economical.

So complex is the issue that Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe are now calling for a secret ballot to choose whether the elephants should be downlisted or not.

All this is to protect delegates from intimidation by Western countries opposed to the lifting of the ivory trade ban.

"We will get full support if voting is done by secret ballot," a delegate said Friday at the two-day pre-conference meeting. "It has emerged that some countries, and even ngos, fear the economic repercussions if they do not vote the way of those who provide aid."

Concern has been raised that the U.S. would oppose the move to vote by secret ballot.

At least Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe could take comfort in the fact they are fully and openly supported by some groups.

The World Conservation Union in Zimbabwe will support the country's proposal to downlist the elephant to allow limited international ivory trade.

The agency's announcement has been regarded as a major boost to the three countries' lobby but whether it would have an impact or not is another matter altogether.

The union's pro-downlisting stance is based on a report prepared after the review of elephant management in the three concerned African states.

The report concluded that no major risks to the Zimbabwean elephant population had been identified and current levels of offtake appeared to be sustainable. "The downlisting of the elephant was a necessary step towards ensuring that local communities living adjacent to wildlife resources fully benefited from such resources and thereby give them an incentive to contribute towards wildlife conservation," said the union's national committee.

Japan is doubtless hoping that any motion to downlist elephants will be upheld. It has expressed interest in buying up to 180,000 tonnes of ivory from the three Southern African countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


United States and Africa;
State Department on Richardson Mission and Brazzaville


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2267 words


 

Washington - Transcript of questions and answers on the visit by UN Ambassador Bill Richardson to Congo, from the daily briefing at the State Department by Department spokesman Nicholas Burns, June 9.

MR. BURNS: I also want to let you know I just had a phone conversation with our Assistant Secretary of State John Shattuck, who's in Kigali. He accompanied Ambassador Bill Richardson to Lubumbashi and to Kisangani over the weekend for their talks with Mr. Laurent Kabila. John left the Richardson party when Richardson came back to the United States. John visited Kisangani on his own; he went to Goma, and he's now in Kigali.

We believe that it will now be possible for the United Nations advance team that will investigate the allegations of mass murder in and near Kisangani - for that team to arrive in Congo on June 20; and for the full investigation to begin on July 7. John Shattuck interviewed personally Rwandan Hutu refugees who were caught up in the atrocities a couple of months back. 

He has heard first-hand reports of killings by forces in the area of refugees most disturbing. As you know, when Ambassador Richardson met with Mr. Kabila over the weekend, Ambassador Richardson was able to elicit from Mr. Kabila a promise that the government of the Congo will cooperate with the United Nations in investigating these very serious allegations of mass atrocities.

We hope that Mr. Kabila will now turn these promises into action on the ground. It is one thing to make a promise. It is quite another thing to actually come through and make sure that every member of the government of Congo, including soldiers from the rebel alliance who may have been in and around Kisangani several months back when that town was besieged, that they be made available to the UN investigating team so that the people who committed these murders will be brought to justice. That's a very important commitment that he has made. What will be more important is to see that commitment turned into action by the Congo Government.

Secondly, I do want to correct a story in the papers over the weekend. This issue has to deal with American economic assistance to Congo. Secretary Albright has not made a decision on whether or not the United States will be extending assistance to Congo and what that amount will be. I'm not blaming the journalists and the newspapers here. I think there may have been some incorrect backgrounding out of some of the officials who were in Congo over the weekend.

I want to be very clear about this because I have talked to the Secretary about this. The United States will base our decision on whether we extend economic assistance to Congo on the actions of the government in Kinshasa. The actions will be very clear. It has to do with whether or not the government is going forward towards political and economic reform, or whether it's not; whether the government is going to cooperate on issues like investigating mass atrocities. These are important. For the life of me, I don't know how this $50 million figure got into the press. Again, I am not blaming the journalists. I am not blaming the newspapers.

I think there is some incorrect and ill advised backgrounding, and it ought to stop, because the Secretary of State makes these decisions. This is a very important decision, and she has not yet made this particular decision.

QUESTION: Could you bring us up to date on the situation in Brazzaville, across the river from oasis of peace and democracy, Kinshasa?

MR. BURNS: Well, I think you know that since June 5th, the situation in Brazzaville has been chaotic and violent. There has been continuing fighting between the Congolese military forces and the paramilitary forces loyal to the former president, Denis Sassou Nguesso. The situation remains quite confused as we speak. I just spoke to the head of our task force, up on the seventh floor, on Congo-Brazzaville. I can tell you that our American embassy continues to be operating, but under quite adverse circumstances. The embassy took an RPG hit over the weekend, also some small arms fire. We don't believe that this fire was directed at the embassy; we think it was just sporadic fire and it was coincidental. We have 28 American diplomats in Congo-Brazzaville. We'd like to bring that number down to 15 American diplomats in the next day or two if we can. The problem is, we've not been able to evacuate those Americans. It's simply unsafe to do so.

They are safe, and if we can get them out through the services of the French Government - you know the French have put in several hundred troops into Brazzaville today - or any other charter aircraft, we will do so. We will only do so under safe conditions. In addition to that, we believe there are approximately 200 private American citizens in Congo-Brazzaville, 75 of whom are probably in the capital city. The embassy is in contact with as many of those people as we can be through our radio network. We are advising Americans, any Americans listening to this through the Voice of America or BBC, to keep their heads down, to stay where they are, not to go out into the streets because it's quite dangerous in the streets of Brazzaville right now. We'll be in touch with them as the best way to get them out of Brazzaville as soon as we can.

Now, I will say that we're very grateful for the quick action of the French Government to try to protect international interests in Brazzaville. We're working very closely with the French Government. Politically, we believe in very strong terms that the government and the rebel forces ought to agree to an immediate cease-fire, and then to a restoration of the constitution, as it was in power before the fighting broke out. Presidential elections are scheduled for July 27th. We believe that if there can be a cease-fire and talks between the government and the rebel movement, it may still be possible to implement the presidential elections on the 27th of July.

The only other thing I'd say, George, is that yesterday we issued a travel warning, advising American citizens to defer travel to Congo-Brazzaville. It is our very strong wish that American citizens not travel there. It is simply too dangerous. They're literally taking their life into their hands if they choose to do that. Still on this situation, Bill?

QUESTION: Yes, Nick, yes, indeed. Two questions. One, does the U.S. have any capability with the Kearsarge in that - has the Kearsarge left that area?

MR. BURNS: The Kearsarge has left. It's no longer off the coast of West Africa. It's heading towards the Mediterranean.

QUESTION: And I take it the U.S. has no intentions of getting involved in the Brazzaville evacuation. That would be a French operation, strictly?

MR. BURNS: We're going to have to take this on a day-to-day basis.

QUESTION: Okay.

MR. BURNS: Obviously, what is first and foremost in our minds is the security of our American citizens -- private Americans, as well as our embassy staff. If they can be brought out by the French or by chartered aircraft, that is the best solution. But we will take this one step at a time.

Under Secretary Tom Pickering was involved in this crisis all throughout the weekend. Secretary Albright was briefed over the weekend. She was briefed on a couple of occasions today. So we are giving this high-level attention. It's a very serious situation for the Americans and the other foreigners who are trapped in Brazzaville today. Crystal.

QUESTION: Is the United States - there were reports - I believe it was in the Post today that Mobutu soldiers, ex-soldiers, have found a home with the ex-president.

MR. BURNS: With Mobutu?

QUESTION: No, no, not with --

MR. BURNS: The ex-president?

QUESTION: I'm sorry the ex-president of Congo --

MR. BURNS: Oh, Brazzaville --

QUESTION: Congo, Congo, not --

MR. BURNS: You mean, Mr. Sassou Nguesso.

QUESTION: Yes, there you go. And - I didn't know how to pronounce his name, and I wasn't going to try. So you did it for me. But there seems to be a rift going - a siding going on there, is the United States worried about this siding? And is the United States worried that there are going to be other eruptions in Africa? It seems as though we are in the midst of a lot of flash points --

MR. BURNS: It's a terribly unstable time in Central Africa, and, indeed, in West Africa, with the situation in Sierra Leone.

But I can't say that we are aware exactly who all these rebel fighters are and whether not some of them may have been buttressed by former members of President Mobutu's presidential guard or military.

All I can say is that the United States is very concerned and disappointed that these rebel fighters chose to take up arms. There is a government in Congo-Brazzaville. The way to resolve problems is not to fight and kill people and produce mass chaos in this capital city and throughout the country, rather it is to sit down and talk through problems. That is the rational way to proceed with problem solving.

So we are very disappointed that this situation has come to pass. But our first concern has got to be the safety of our own citizens, always. After that, of course, we will want to exert whatever influence Ambassador Aubrey Hooks can, our very fine ambassador in Brazzaville, to see that a cease-fire is put into place.

Now let me just tell you, since I always think it is important to say when foreign service officers do good things, one of our consular officers, Ava Rogers went out over the weekend, taking great danger upon herself, to try to find American citizens who we thought were in a particular neighborhood in Brazzaville. She and a Marine guard went out. They were unable to get to the Americans, but our deputy chief of mission then went out and was able to get to a certain group of Americans.

These American foreign service officers are putting their own lives on the line and trying to help American citizens. That is their obligation and duty, obviously to defend American citizens, not to take their life in their hands, but to do what they can to help American citizens, and I wanted to draw attention to Ava Rogers, who I think acted heroically over the weekend to find American citizens caught up in the fighting.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
