Africa News


June 9, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. 'Commends' Algeria for Elections


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Washington - Statement on Algeria issued by State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns, June 9, followed by questions and answers at the Department's daily briefing.

MR. BURNS: The United States commends the government of Algeria for holding parliamentary elections and for inviting international observers to monitor them. We'd like to praise the Algerian people for their courage in turning out in such high numbers at the polls last week. The Algerian people are the best judge of how the election results will contribute to the process of national reconciliation in Algeria. A multiparty assembly holds the potential to move this process a step forward. 

We do urge the government of Algeria to address the issues raised by international observers and political parties, as Algeria prepares for municipal and local elections. The election campaign also marked a commendable increase in the openness of Algerian television and radio. We hope that increased openness will continue, as Algeria moves toward peace, stability and democracy that so many Algerians have desired for such a long period of time. I'll be glad to take questions on that issue, on the issue of international observation, once we get to questions.

QUESTION: Yes. On Algeria, I'm unclear about your statement. You're considering the elections are reasonably free and fair, or what's your assessment about the report of the observers?

MR. BURNS: I would not use the words free and fair to describe the Algerian elections, simply because the international monitors, in whom we have great trust, did not use those words. Clearly, there were some problems with the Algerian election in the way it was carried out. We do think it's positive, however, that people voted in great numbers; and it's positive that the government was able to open up television and radio to political debate and political discourse. So our statement is an attempt, really to congratulate the people of Algeria, first and foremost; and secondly, to ask the government to continue with this small step forward in openness, because we think that might be a way to provide some positive momentum in relations between the government and others. Lord knows, Algeria needs that after all the terrorism and the violence and the killings of the past several years.

LANGUAGE: English

219 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Geneva - WEEKLY NEWS WEEK 23 02.-08.06.1997

02-03-04.06.97 OAU summit

In his speech at the opening of the 33th session of the OAU summit in Harare (Zimbabwe), the UN Secretary General K. Annan affirmed that the United Nations have increased its efforts to solve the Western Sahara question.

04.06.97 Spain

According to a report of the Ministery of Foreign Affairs exposed at the Senate, the Spanish government estimes that the Western Sahara conflict is a decolonization matter and will only be resolved by a fair and free self determination referendum for the Sahrawi people. 

04-05.06.97 Two days visit of Moroccan Prime Minister in Spain, with essentially economical purposes (Morocco's debt to Spain is of 2 billions US].

05.06.97 Morocco and Polisario to meet in London

Former U.S. Secretary of State James Baker convoked the two parties involved in the dispute over the Western Sahara for talks in London, scheduled for June 11 and 12. The UN Special Envoy will meet separately the representatives of Morocco and of the Polisario Front, before the discussions to which Algeria and Mauritania will also assist as observers.

The encounters are organized by the Foreign Office and the UN Office in London. The Polisario Front immediately accepted the invitation. Till June 9 there was no declaration from the Moroccan government.

06-07-08.06.97 San Sebastian Conference

The International Conference on information and communication about Western Sahara brought together some 150 people from all continents.

At the opening session the Mayor of the Spanish city denounced the "wall of silence" which surrounds the W.S. conflict. The chief of Information Section of the OAU, Mr. D. Orjiako, traansmitted the support of his organization and the greetings of its Secretary general Mr Salim Ahmed Salim. The intervening specialists, reporters and professionnals of medias from India, Algeria, Mexico and the United States analysed what Mr Ash Narain Roy named a "conspiracy of silence" and showed some possibilities how to break it. The conclusions of the two days workshops are drawn up in a final document which will be available soon and we will bring up again later.

07.06.97 International Day of solidarity with the disappeared Sahrawi

In occasion of the International Day of solidarity with the disappeared Sahrawi the AFAPREDESA, in a press release,exprimes its preoccupation because of the persistent violations of Human Rights in Western Sahara. The Moroccan occupants are committing serious violations of H.R., especially forced disappearency, arbitrary arrests, unfair trials, political crimes, limitation of freedom of movement and of freedom of expression.

Prepared by ARSO (Association de soutien a un referendum libre et regulier au Sahara occidental). CP 2229, CH-2800 DELEMONT 2. Tel./Fax: 0041 32 422 87 17. E-mail: arso@hei.unige.ch. WWW: http://heiwww.unige.ch/arso/.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
NP Supports Closed Hearings in Durban


BYLINE: National Party (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Sheila Camerer MP, chief spokesperson on Justice

The National Party has no problem in principle if the TRC decides to hold the hearings of a TRC Committee in camera in KwaZulu-Natal. In fact, when the TRC Bill was debated in the Justice Portfolio Committee 2 years ago we repeatedly warned that if hearings were held in public, particularly in KZN, it would give impetus to the bloody revenge killings that are endemic in that province. When this was put to Dr Boraine who gave evidence to the Committee at the time, he agreed that it was a problem but could not offer a solution. Now the TRC has suggested a solution and we must be thankful for small mercies.

However, what is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. The National Party has consistently warned that in many cases public hearings would tend to tarnish the reputation of innocent people, inflame emotions, provoke vengeance and do little for national reconciliation. This is true for KZN but also for other regions of the country.

We suggest the TRC should apply this principle to its hearings in all regions where desirable, preferably to all such hearings.

The composition of such a TRC committee concerned must be balanced - though this is difficult to achieve with the present commissioners - and subject to scrutiny.

Issued by Jan Bosman, National Party - Federal Council Manager, Media Affairs, PO Box 1698, Cape Town, 8000. Tel: (021) 461-5833. Fax: (021) 461-5329. http://www.natweb.co.za


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

221 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Tunisia;
Amnesty: 'The Widening Circle Of Repression'


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

London - The human rights situation in Tunisia remains a source of concern, despite the recent release of some prisoners of conscience. The circle of repression continues to widen.

Victims of arbitrary detention, torture or ill-treatment and imprisonment after unfair trials are not only political opponents: Human rights defenders and activists, trade unionists, and wives and relatives of political prisoners and refugees are increasingly targeted.

Public liberties, already much restricted in the last few years, have been further curtailed. 

Human rights defenders and activists find it increasingly difficult to carry out their activities. In the past few years human rights defenders have been arrested, imprisoned, tortured, intimidated and harassed for their work on behalf of the most vulnerable victims.

"If pressure and harassment are not enough to intimidate human rights defenders, the Tunisian authorities use other methods, such as imprisonment and torture.

Often they also confiscate their passports, disconnect their telephone and intercept their mail so as to cut them off from the outside world," Amnesty International said today.

In a 19-page report published today Amnesty International shows the gap which exists between the discourse of the Tunisian authorities, who continue to reiterate their commitment to respecting human rights, and a reality where the most fundamental rights are violated daily.

An increasing number of people, including many women and even children, are subjected to retaliation because of their family links with political opponents.

Wives of Islamist political prisoners and refugees are the first victims of this repression. Their freedom of conscience and of movement are restricted, their physical and mental integrity and their right to privacy are often violated.

Often prevented from working, from leaving the country or from moving freely within the country, these women are kept under strict surveillance. They are routinely arrested and interrogated about the activities of their exiled husbands, about their contacts with them, and about their sources of subsistence: They are often subjected to torture, including sexual abuse; some have been forced to divorce and others have been imprisoned for long periods, and their children have been traumatized by police raids conducted both during the day and at night.

In addition, anyone who gives them any help, however minimal, risks being prosecuted.

Hundreds of people have been accused of "unauthorized collection of funds" and imprisoned just for having helped families of political prisoners and refugees.

"It is difficult to reconcile such practices with the Tunisian authorities's discourse in favour of women's rights," Amnesty International said.

Samira Ben Salah, mother of four young girls and married to an exiled Islamist opponent, came under pressure after her husband fled the country in 1991. She was frequently arrested and in 1992 she was sentenced to six months' imprisonment. After her release from prison, arrests and interrogations continued; in detention she was undressed, tortured, sexually abused, threatened with rape and forced to file a divorce procedure. Her ordeal lasted until the end of 1996, when, after strong international pressure, she was able to leave Tunisia with her daughters to join her husband in Germany.

If the case of Samira Ben Salah and of some other women have been finally resolved and they have been able to obtain passports for themselves and their children, dozens of other women continue to suffer similar injustice. After years of ordeal and with no prospect of any solution in the near future, some women have chosen to take the risk of leaving the country with their children without travel documents. Some are now in a difficult situation in neighbouring countries and others have been arrested before they could cross the border.

Rachida Ben Salem was arrested on 18 May with her two small daughters as she was attempting to cross into Libya, from where she was hoping to be able to go to join her husband, a political refugee in Holland. She is now detained on charges of belonging to a criminal gang and risks a long prison sentence.

Amnesty International and other human rights organizations have continued to raise their concerns with the Tunisian authorities. However, detainees continue to be held in secret detention and tortured in the Ministry of the Interior itself. The scale and persistency of the violations, and the lack of action on the part of the authorities, show that such violations are tolerated or even encouraged at the highest level of the Tunisian Government.

"Complaints lodged by victims of such violations are usually ignored or, worse still, can result in further violations as a means of punishment," Amnesty International said.

While welcoming the release of six prisoners of conscience in the past few months, and the recent release on bail of the trade unionists who were detained since last April, Amnesty International renews its call on the Tunisian authorities to take without delay concrete measures to put an end to the daily human rights violations.

The organization calls in particular for the release of all men and women prisoners of conscience, an end to the practice of torture, the setting up of independent and impartial investigations, and an end to intimidation and harassment.

Issued 9 June. For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44- 71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Kenya;
Amnesty International Delegation Meets With Government


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

London - A high-level Amnesty International delegation led by Secretary General Pierre Sane today met with members of the Kenyan government led by Vice President George Saitoti and urged the government to live up to commitments to improve the country's human rights record.

The delegation from the world-wide human rights organization raised concerns with various representatives of the government including torture, deaths in suspicious circumstances, the use of the excessive force by the police and prison conditions. These concerns were included in a memorandum sent to the government last month. 

"We appreciate the opportunity to enter into dialogue with the government about our human rights concerns in Kenya," Mr Sane said. "During the meeting the Vice President made public commitments to address our concerns and we will be closely monitoring how these commitments are implemented."

"We look forward to continuing dialogue with the government and hope that the government's commitments to respect international standards on human rights will be translated into action to improve the fundamental rights of all Kenyans."

At the meeting, the Vice President committed the government to investigating all cases of torture and to bringing those found responsible to justice. He assured the delegation that police brutality and the unlawful use of force is not tolerated and in the case of unlawful killings, police officers will be prosecuted.

Mr Sane rejected arguments about national sovereignty put forward by the Vice President saying that "both the Organization of African Unity and the United Nations have recognized that human rights do not fall solely within the domain of national sovereignty. The Kenyan people are entitled to the same basic rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as any other citizen of the world. By ratifying international standards such as the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights the Kenyan government has acknowledged that it is the responsibility of the international community to scrutinize, monitor and demand that the government lives up to its obligations".

Those present at the meeting also included the Attorney General, the Solicitor General, the Commissioner of Prisons, the Commissioner of Police, the Minister of Health, the Minister of Education and Secretary General of KANU, the Director of the CID and the Permanent Secretaries of the President and Ministry of Health. The Amnesty International delegation is due to have follow-up meetings with the Attorney General and Commissioner of Prisons to concentrate on specific areas such as legal reform and the human rights record of the Kenyan Police.

Issued 5 JUNE 1997. For further information, contact Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ,+44-71-413-5500 ,+44- 71-956-1157. Email: amnesty@amnesty.org. Web: http://www.amnesty.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Many Cape guest houses not built to last


BYLINE: Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - There could be quite a few "casualties" in the Cape Peninsula's booming guest house sector over the next few years, a study by the Cape Technikon tourism research unit has found.

The research project established that the majority of the guest houses in the Peninsula have been in existence for no longer than three years and have not yet experienced a full economic cycle of between five and seven years.

Most of the guest houses have not yet experienced a full downturn in the tourism sector and it is expected that some of them would not survive it, the study has found. 

Another problem identified for the industry was that 60 percent of all earnings came from foreigners, which meant that spiralling crime, the "What happens if Mandela dies?" factor and a downturn in the economy could cause the clientele to dry up overnight.

"In such a situation only well-organised and established houses will survive," the researchers reported.

Private guest houses were identified as the biggest part of the formal accommodation sector, accounting for 36,2 percent of all the formal accommodation establishments in the region.

Although a guest house requires a relatively high capital outlay, it is relatively easy to start one, as there are virtually no legalities involved.

The study found that more than 70 percent of all guest houses are either sole proprietors or partnerships and only 23 percent have opted for legal protection as companies or close corporations.

English was the most common business language used by guest house owners, followed by German.

The number of people employed in the industry was estimated at 958, with an additional 252 finding part-time work in the sector.

There are about 3 300 beds available in guest houses in the Peninsula.

During the period of the study - one week in October last year - the average occupancy rate was 51 percent. A profile of 59 guest house owners found the majority to be "no fools", with 52,8 percent boasting a post-matriculation qualification.

Only 32 percent of the guest houses surveyed belonged to the Guest House Association of South Africa, and about 55 percent were members of Captour.

Word of mouth was the most popular promotional method used to advertise guest houses, followed by advertisements in magazines, according to the study.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
The leading lady of Cape Town's mega events


BYLINE: Don Lilford, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Cape Town - If Beryl Eichenberger, promotions manager of Independent Newspapers Cape and recent winner of the 1997 Rotary Press Award, had not carved a successful career for herself in promotions/public relations, she could have made it big on the stage.

Who says? Not Beryl herself, but people who have watched her in action at major events like the Cape Argus/Pick 'n Pay Cycle Tour, The Cape Times/Southern Life Big Walk and many others.

Diminutive but extrovert Beryl certainly has the dynamism, energy and chutzpah to have made it big in front of the footlights before a critical audience.

But she herself is pretty dismissive of her early stage career. 

"When I was a little girl growing up in Sussex in England, the elder sister of twins, I had so much excess energy that my father simply had to find extra things for me to do," she recalls. "He also didn't want me to be saddled with a Sussex accent for the rest of my life. So one of the things he did was to send me to elocution lessons.

"I was the only Jewish girl in the class and I chose Shylock from The Merchant of Venice. I'm not very big now, but I was widgy then. Looking back, it must have been a real hoot for the audience to see this tiny little thing up on stage, rubbing her hands with glee, and intoning 'Many a time and oft on the Rialto...'

"Later, when I was working in London, I joined an amateur dramatic society and was selected to play the part of Rosa Gonsalez, a whore, in Tennessee Williams' play Summer and Smoke. I threw myself whole- heartedly into the part to the extent that, on opening night, I walked off with one of the essential props and nearly ruined the play for the leading man and leading lady. Anyway, they were all very nice about it and said I had played the part really well!"

By this time, however, Beryl was serious about a business career. She came to South Africa 28 years ago "more or less to find myself". She loved the country immediately and made it her home.

"I'm a retailer by trade - I suppose you could say a creative retailer," she said. "I studied dress design in the UK, but when I arrived and joined Truworths I went into the display field. I then went to Greatermans, where I was fortunate to work for a boss who saw my potential for special events. For five years I did a lot of special fashion events and shows, liaising with television and contracting people like David Hall Green and Doreanne Berry to compere them.

"I learned a lot working with them and watching them, to the extent that I was later able to compere some myself.

"I had a high-profile job in Johannesburg when my then friend, now my husband, was transferred to Cape Town and he asked me to join him. There was no equivalent in Cape Town of the job I had in Johannesburg and I joined Woolworths. I worked there for 12 years and got brilliant training, first as a buyer - selector as they called it - and then in their PR division, where I worked closely with the public.

"Six years ago, when the job of promotions manager became vacant at the Cape Argus, I applied for it and got it."

What are the most stimulating events she and her department are involved in?

"Well, obviously the cycle tour, first and foremost, though I've never sat on a bicycle. It's far too painful. The whole job revolves around working with Rotary as part of a team. Each person is a cog in the wheel and when that wheel starts turning it doesn't stop until the tour is over.

"It's a huge event - 27 000 riders from 32 000 entries this year. We had to disappoint 5 000 because the roads wouldn't take them. The Cape Times Big Walk has 15 000 entries annually and going up. Together, these two events raise R1 million for the Rotary coffers every year.

"And there are many other community-based events: the Gun Run, the LifeCycle Expo, the Food and Drink Festival, the Waterfront Wine Festival and so on."

They call her Beryl "Just in Case" Eichenberger or Beryl "We'll Make a Plan" Eichenberger, because years of experience have taught her to leave nothing to chance. Her most palpitating emergency?

"There have been many. One I remember was when a huge canvas hall, not a marquee, that had been erected at the Waterfront for the Miss Rave competition finals blew down. The October south-easter got hold of it and by the time it had finished the tent, or what was left of it, looked as if a giant foot had trodden on it.

"There we were with just two days to go before the event and 1 500 tickets sold. We had just 48 hours to find a suitable venue, with stage, changing rooms, accommodation for the audience, etc. Eventually we found a vacant warehouse at A Berth and in 24 hours, working around the clock, we transformed it into a glittering show venue. As a venue it was such a surprising success that for two or three years afterwards it was still being used for exhibitions."

The comprehensive citation for Beryl's Rotary Press Award includes this line: "Not only does Mrs Eichenberger assist with the overall organisation of the events mentioned (The Argus cycle tour, Big Walk and others), she goes beyond the call of duty in exhibiting friendship and help to Rotary. She is a true and loyal friend." But Beryl will not accept the kudos alone.

"This is a team effort," she said of the Independent Newspapers (Cape) promotions department. "There are eight of us and we depend very much, one upon the other. We call ourselves the A-Team because we make your promotions come together - and we deliver."


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
'Fake champagne' sale bid probed


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - French champagne producers will investigate reports that Paarl wine co-operative KWV tried to sell thousands of cases of sparkling wine disguised as champagne.

KWV has denied press reports last week that a plan was approved by senior executives in 1990 to pass off sparkling wine as champagne in the United States and Europe. The reports said the wine was to be sold in special bottles imported by KWV from France.

Andre Enders, head of the Comite Interprofessionnel des Vins de Champagne, the French champagne producers' body, said his association viewed the allegations in a serious light. "We will undertake our own investigation," he said.

Interviewed by telephone from his offices at Epernay in Champagne, Mr Enders said the association would contact St Gobain, the French glass manufacturer from whom KWV allegedly imported more than 250 000 champagne bottles, as well as the suppliers of corks to KWV.

"But of course anyone can buy these bottles and use them, provided the contents are labelled correctly. There is also no ban on using the same corks as we use for champagne. But if the corks were labelled with the word 'champagne', that is not acceptable".

Mr Enders said the goal of his association's investigation was to tighten protection for champagne producers and the public.

"If this has happened once it can happen again. The public pays the price for champagne and has a right to the authentic product."

He hit out at the American authorities who allegedly refused to allow the fake champagne to enter the United States but did not take the matter further.

"It is as if they only wanted to protect their own public," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
Byzantine intrigue in SABC's towers


BYLINE: Helen Grange, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Cape Town - The most striking aspect of the unfolding SABC TV drama is the anarchic "each man for himself" ethos which has apparently gripped the news department for more than two years and climaxed in the latest exodus of senior executives from the corporation.

For the sake of simplicity, some observers have placed the staff into three vaguely political camps - each trying to muscle out the others - but informed sources say the reality is less conspiratorial and more an insidious battle by individuals to survive in a fog of uncertainty.

The catalyst for the latest shake-out was the controversial entrance of the irascible Allister Sparks, whose appointment as editor of news and current affairs was the last straw for editor-in- chief Joe Thloloe, who resigned in outrage.

SABC chief executive Zwelakhe Sisulu has remained tightlipped about his actions, although it is well known that he and Thloloe have had numerous clashes over management style and restructuring. 

As one observer puts it: "Thloloe came from a different kind of newspaper tradition, and associated himself strongly with the Black Editors Forum. Sisulu has long since dissociated himself from the BEF and has become a highly ambitious corporate animal who sits on a number of boards. Their styles contrasted."

But it was the apparently secretive way in which Mr Sisulu went about his negotiations with Mr Sparks - who has to all intents and purposes replaced Mr Thloloe - that prompted Mr Thloloe to quit.

He wrote that he had left "because the Sparks arrangements were made behind my back and I had to hear them in the corridors of the SABC".

It has since emerged that Mr Sisulu offered Mr Thloloe a newly created administrative position, that of head of department, which Mr Thloloe refused and which, according to one insider, is now a post with a big question mark over it.

Mr Sparks' appointment, on the other hand, has met with some opposition from outside the corporation - although Mr Sparks himself has emphasised that the welcome inside has been positive.

Mr Sisulu has been castigated by the Inkatha Freedom Party for surrendering editorial integrity in what is perceived as a political sop to the African National Congress, while some independent observers have questioned the "irony" of hiring a white print journalist without a strong track record in the television industry.

It's strongly held in some quarters that Mr Sparks, who has been wanting to work hands-on at the SABC for a long time, according to a former board member, is a pivotal player in the rise to power of a coterie of people from the Institute for the Advancement of Journalism (of which he is executive director) - people with a longstanding history of struggle journalism.

Mr Sisulu's association with Mr Sparks is a close one, dating back to the Rand Daily Mail. He is hoping Mr Sparks' intervention in restructuring TV news and providing on-the-job training for reporters will deliver the long-overdue improvements to the service and, some say, ease the pressure Mr Sisulu has been under from the Government to effect a more visible transition in the news content.

He may not have anticipated, however, the effect of his decision on Mr Thloloe's senior appointees, including head of news Ivan Fynn and head of current affairs Sarah Crowe, who both tendered their resignations last week in solidarity with Mr Thloloe's sentiments.

Nonetheless, given that Mr Thloloe's senior, TV chief executive Jill Chisholm, had only shortly before announced that her contract would not be renewed, it's not surprising that Mr Thloloe's staff felt under siege.

Critical observers say Mr Thloloe was languishing with a poor team of executives and journalists and that, while he was highly regarded as a newsman, he did not have the necessary training skills.

At the same time, credence has been given to speculation that the new breed of TV journalists, including political editor Phil Molefe, his deputy Ivor Powell and presenters Max du Preez and Jacques Pauw, are pushing for the removal of the "old guard" with the leak of a memo by Mr Molefe. It says a clique with an NP agenda has been sabotaging the work of reporters.

The "old guard" is seen to be represented by long-serving staff members headed by executive producer Jeremy Thorpe, fired recently for criticising the decision to scrap the SA Press Association service.

The irony is this: despite months of treachery and intrigue at the top, the reporters have been churning out the news - all but oblivious to the "crisis".

One of the reporters remarked: "The poisoned brew tastes the same, no matter what hand is stirring it."

It's another way of reflecting on what has become increasingly evident at the SABC - that there has been a distinct lack of good leadership in a task which is perhaps unrealistically ambitious.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
Bid team, Pagad set for talks on gangs


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - The Bid Company is to set up a meeting with People Against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad) to make clear its withdrawal from the controversial gangs-for-peace initiative.

The severing of the Olympic connection with the gangs initiative was spelt out in a letter to Pagad last week. 

However, at a weekend rally attended by about 300 people, Pagad repeated its demand that Chris Ball and other members of the Bid Company executive be removed, and he warned that if this was not met Pagad would have no choice but to boycott businesses which had sponsored the bid, including Pick 'n Pay, Caltex, Mercedes Benz and Telkom.

Yesterday's rally was called to protest against the now-defunct alliance between the Cape Town Community Olympic Forum and the Community Outreach Forum.

The Olympic connection with the initiative was ended last week when the Olympic Forum - which operates independently from the Bid Company - withdrew.

The intiative is now be monitored and co-ordinated by other community organisations as part of a broad anti-crime campaign. It will be known as the Peace Intiative.

Pagad said it was not against the Olympics as such but against any Olympic Games of which drug dealers and gangsters could be part.

Pagad national co-ordinator Abdus-Salaam Ebrahim said the breaking up of the alliance was a "victory for Pagad and for all who assisted".


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
The problems at the SABC (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - Of all the old apartheid structures which had to be transformed with the advent of full democracy in South Africa, none presented a more pressing or difficult challenge than the SABC. From having been the public voice and propaganda arm of a shameful and repressive order, the complex State-owned electronic media monopoly had to be changed into a politically independent organisation capable of meeting the demands of a profoundly different social, economic and political system. 

While the transformation is far from complete, it has been embarked upon with vigour and commitment and in many important areas impressive progress has been made. Unavoidably, though, problems have arisen. Among them is an alarming operational deficit, accompanied by disturbing allegations of mismanagement, profligate spending and theft, and the unexpected departure of some of the most influential and respected news and administrative staff.

Given the number of people who depend entirely on radio or television for their daily information about the diverse and rapidly changing society they live in, the crisis at the SABC is cause for grave concern. The corporation is an essential element in the process of nation building; it is the key player in fostering not only a new sense of national identity but a spirit of reconciliation and national unity. It also has a vital role to play in education and in many other fields.

To serve the unique needs of the emerging new South Africa, the SABC will have to resolve its problems urgently and effectively - and, above all, it must be seen to be doing so. The corporation's setbacks cannot be allowed to overwhelm it, or divert it from the commendable course it embarked upon a few short years ago.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
Four held in hijack murders


BYLINE: Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Cape Town - Police were questioning four people today in connection with the hijacking and murder of a Simon's Town doctor and his fianc e, whose bodies were found in Mitchell's Plain yesterday.

The men were arrested early today by a Mitchell's Plain police patrol, who found two pistols in their possession.

Police are investigating the possibility that Dr Tatilal "Rolly" Kessow, 56, and his fianc e, Henrietha Millward, 54, were kidnapped after visiting a casino in Lansdowne late on Saturday, before being shot dead in their car and dumped near a rubbish heap. 

In their night of terror on the Cape Flats the hijackers abducted Dr Kessow and Mrs Millward and shot both in the head, then used Dr Kessow's BMW to hold up and rob two petrol attendants.

The cold-blooded shooting of a motorist beside his broken-down car in Lansdowne is also being investigated by detectives, who were piecing together the gang's movements yesterday.

The trail of death came to light when police found the bodies of Dr Kessow and Mrs Millward on the corner of Mitchell Road and Highlands Road, Mitchell's Plain, about 3.25am yesterday. The couple went to Lansdowne after visiting family in Grassy Park, according to a relative, who could not say where exactly they had planned to go.

But police learned that Dr Kessow was a keen gambler, raising fears that he and his fianc e were stalked at the casino and attacked as they left.

Their bodies were found without valuables, jewellery or cash. Mrs Millward's pants had been undone but police did not believe she had been raped.

At 3.15am a gang using Mr Kessow's BMW pulled up in the forecourt of a service station in Morgenster Road, about 2km from where the bodies were found.

There the gang, armed with a revolver, held up attendants and robbed them of a jacket, a radio-cassette player and cigarettes, all valued at about R400.

At 4.50am the same gang attacked staff of a service station in Camberwell Road, Lansdowne, where they got away with R1 600 in takings.

Police were scanning the garage's closed-circuit security video recording to see if they could spot images of the gang.

Meanwhile Lansdowne police were called to the scene of a murder in Orion Road, where a gang in a light-coloured BMW pulled up behind a man whose car had broken down at about 4.30am.

A witness told police that one of the gang opened fire and killed the motorist during an argument.

Police are withholding the dead man's identity until his family has been notified of the incident.

Detectives were eventually called to Observatory, where a resident found Dr Kessow's car abandoned in Herschel Road about 8am.

The back seat was soaked with blood and the car's two right wheels were damaged as if it had hit a curb at high speed.

Forensic experts examining the car found a spent cartridge, packets of cigarettes, a drinking glass and a liquor bottle top. The forensic specialists combed the car for fingerprints.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Swaziland set to scrap investor's 5-year tax holiday


BYLINE: Ntsika Mdluli, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Swaziland will scrap the five year tax holiday it currently offers as an investment incentive to foreign investors when the kingdom's new Investment Bill is tabled in Parliament during the first week of July.

The Bill, which has just been approved by Swaziland's Cabinet, was released for circulation amongst stakeholders on Friday.

The Bill, being piloted by the Ministry of Enterprise and Employment aims at charting a new strategy for luring direct foreign investment (FDI) into the country seeks to provide fresh incentives to attract investment particularly in the manufacturing sector. 

New incentives include the scrapping of the five year tax holiday and replacing it with a system of investment credits, a targeted companies tax rate, a different tax rate for small companies and a low sectoral rate for manufacturing.

In place of discriminatory incentives, the corporate tax rate, currently at 37.5% has been adjusted to 30%. The rate will be reduced by a further 5% to 25% within five years.

The Bill's broad-based objectives include promotion of local and foreign investment, protection of investment, settlement of investment disputes, establishment of an investment promotion centre and setting up a one stop service for investors.

While generally optimistic and supportive of the spirit behind the Bill, Swaziland industry is adopting a "wait and see" attitude until the its impact on the Kingdom's regional competitiveness is known.

"We are supportive of the concept but we have emphasised that investment should be a one-stop concept not a one-more-stop concept," Swaziland Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCI) Executive Director, Harvey Bird said.

Bird said the Chamber, while appreciating the financial and tax incentives, feels they should not be seen as more important than the country's regional competitiveness.

"Many countries in the Southern Africa region have lower corporate tax rates than Swaziland," Bird said.

The Chamber's involvement in Swaziland's investment promotion legislation dates back to a report by Irish consultant Patrick Padriac, whose recommendations are the base for the new Investment Promotion Bill.

"We must demonstrate that we are facilitating new investment in the Kingdom," Bird said.

Federation Swaziland of Swaziland Employers (FSE) Deputy Executive Director, Muhawu Maziya said the new investment incentives should help the Kingdom survive regional competition.

"The region is opening up to new competition," he said.

Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU) Assistant Secretary General Jabu Nxumalo said the manufacturing sector's investment incentives should include investors' easy access to operational land, an Export Processing Zone (EPZ) and effective trade liberalisation.

"It is government's responsibility to legislate investor friendly laws, settle disputes at the point of origin and invest in dialogue," he said.

The SFTU is opposed to the corporate tax cuts being carried over to the workers.

"The taxes should be such that the small man does not end up paying for the big corporations," he said.

The federation sees the focus of new initiative being shifted to new investment, especially in the manufacturing sector.

"We support any policy that is promulgated as long as it takes into account the social life, welfare of the people and investment," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
Home-made coal stoves claim yet more victims


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

MIDDLEBURG - Police reported on Sunday that yet another elderly couple died of carbon monoxide poisoning on Saturday after using a traditional coal brazer in their room to fight the bitter Highveld cold.

Police spokesman, Captain Doep du Plooy told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Sunday that Christina Mabena (65) and her common law husband, Jacobus Jiyane (47) were found dead in their bed by their daughter at 14h30, after a worried neighbour sent a child to summon her from her in-laws. 

The neighbour reportedly became concerned about the couple after they failed to answer their door despite his knocking. When there was still no answer at midday, he sent the child to fetch their daughter. "We understand that it gets really cold, but this is the second elderly couple in two weeks to be killed by home-made coal stoves. The problem is that people seal all their windows and air vents to keep the cold out and then light these coal fires in what are basically drums," he explained.

"The monoxide build up is so gradual that the victims slip into a coma and then death without even realising it."

The stove or brazers are know as imbawula and are believed to be the most popular form of indoor heating in poor rural areas.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

South Africa;
Three more Mpumalanga prisoners escape


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

DELMAS - Another three awaiting trial prisoners escaped from Mpumalanga police cells on Sunday after hack-sawing their way through the iron-bars on their cell's skylight, African Eye News Service (South Africa) reports. Nineteen awaiting trial prisoners escaped from holding cells or police vehicles during separate incidents last week. None of the escapees have been re-arrested yet.

Provincial police spokesman, Captain Doep du Plooy confirmed that the three most recent escapees bust out of their Delmas Police Station cell just hours after they were arrested house break and theft on Sunday morning.

Police are still not certain where they obtained the hack-saw from, which they used to cut their cell's bars at roughly 02h00.

Du Plooy added that the escapee's names could not yet be released as they have not appeared in court.

Police are still following possible leads to re-arrest them.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Airlines get Zambian directive


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Government has directed Aero Zambia and the Kenyan Airways to put in place arrangements that would ensure equitable sharing of business.

Acting Communications and Transport Minister Suresh Desai said yesterday until the arrangements were made, Kenya Airways flights would remain suspended.

"The two airlines have been asked to make arrangements for equitable sharing of passenger traffic. As long as these arrangements are not in place, the status remains the same," Mr Desai said. 

But sources, earlier said President Chiluba had ordered the Ministry of Communications and Transport to facilitate the resumption of Kenya Airways flights to Lusaka immediately.

Mr Chiluba at the weekend said an airborne Kenya Airways flight from Lilongwe to Lusaka on May 12 was denied landing rights in Lusaka.

Mr Chiluba said this when he met representatives from the two airlines, the Ministry of Communications and Transport, and a delegation from Kenya on Friday.

He assured the Kenyans that the matter would be investigated and he would hold responsible whoever stopped the flight from proceeding to Lusaka.

Sources said the officials from civil aviation maintained they were merely acting on instructions from the ministry to stop the aircraft from landing on Zambian soil.

According to documents available to this paper, the Kenyan government requested on February 13 for a fourth frequency (Monday/Thursday) through the Zambian Ministry of Communications and Transport which was approved by Deputy Minister Gilbert Mululu on February 26.

"The bilateral air services agreement between Zambia and Kenya clearly allows either party to request for an additional frequency if need arises. Whoever ordered the aircraft to turn back was not in the meeting at State House that's for sure," the sources said.

Mr Chiluba has ordered the ministry to lift the suspension on Kenya Airways so the airline resumes Monday/Thursday flights to Lusaka.

The Kenyan delegation included its transport and communications minister Wilson Ayah, Kenya high commissioner to Zambia Joseph Sefu, deputy secretary (transport) Julius Okara, state attorney and delegation legal counsel Nathan Birundu and Kenya Airways managing director Brian Davies.

The Zambia delegation comprised Mr Desai, his deputy Mr Mululu, Aero Zambia chief executive David Tokoph, managing director Youndewossen Mengistu and many other civil aviation and transport officials.

Kenya Airways has lost about $130,000 between May 12 to June 2 and risks losing over $1m if the Monday/Thursday summer flights do not resume.

"The loss is $25,000 per round trip and that doesn't include revenue lost from connecting traffic out of Europe, Middle East on the inbound leg into Nairobi.

"The stoppage is a blow to the partnership we have with KA. It means we are in serious breach of agreement," the sources said.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


Zambia;
Health boards jobs up for grabs


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Lusaka - The Central Board of Health (CBH) has finally been delinked from Government and all health workers will have to reapply for their jobs.

Health Minister Katele Kalumba who announced the move at the weekend said the decision would take effect on August 1 and only 69 employees would be retained at the ministry.

Dr Kalumba on Friday signed statutory instrument number 76 to herald the new measures. 

"All jobs will be advertised and contracts signed thereafter. The whole exercise should be completed by August 1. We are now implementing the National Health Services Act of 1995," Dr Kalumba said.

He said Government would now only deal with policy issues, the budget allocation for health, relations with donors, strategic management and advocacy.

The issue of terminal benefits to employees before transferring them to Health Management Boards (HMB) had already been taken care of.

Dr Kalumba said Government would work closely with non- governmental organisations (NGOs), the donors and all interested groups to foster a higher delivery of health services.

He observed that passion had been substituted with hostilities by some health workers even in mission hospitals. He urged health workers to treat their jobs as a calling and not as routine work.

There was need for valuable services to be offered to the sick in the new setting.

"As all jobs are up for grabs in the health boards, only the best people will be retained. We need to give quality health services based on mutual respect by both partners," he said in an interview.

Dr Kalumba also said Government had signed a memorandum of understanding with church-run medical institutions in the delivery of health services.

The memorandum defines the rights, obligations and entitlements of both parties.

UNICEF resident representative Mark Stirling in another development said his organisation would continue to assist Government to ensure all families, children in particular, received better medical services.

UNICEF would act as a bridge between Government and NGOs. It would facilitate dialogue.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: The curtain drawn (Editorial)


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - The curtain has drawn on Zambia's aspirations to play at the 1998 World Cup finals in France.

Yesterday's loss to South Africa's Bafana Bafana signalled the end of Zambia's aspirations in the World Cup race.

That Zambia is out of contention for a World Cup finals place should not be treated as the end of the road. 

Of course, Zambia will not be among the creme de la creme of nations to line-up in France next year but this does not mean Zambia is dead and buried as one of the top teams on the continent.

Zambia has yet to make her presence felt on the international scene since the Seoul Olympics, all because of a misguided approach which is crippling soccer.

Nigeria learnt from Zambia how to win but Zambia has been failing to turn its abundant talent into goal-getters.

Yesterday's 0-3 whacking from South Africa says it all about the calibre of the game in Zambia and not the players.

Whereas players with beautiful ball skills and natural acumen are readily available, the people who are charged with the responsibility of nurturing their talent are not there.

The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has lamentably failed to organise the national team let alone clubs.

The endless list of successive FAZ executives have fallen far below expectations when it has come to driving the national team and clubs to higher heights.

The preparations for the national team for international matches have always been half-baked yet Government's financial support is ready at all times.

The dream of Zambia playing at the World Cup will not be realised if Zambia continues pretending that all is well with the administration of soccer.

Government offered to fund the team's training before the South Africa match yet FAZ did not put forward any proposals for the simple reason that the executive is busy seeking a fresh mandate in the June 28 elections.

Zambia's failure to beat South Africa yesterday and consolidate the chance of playing at the World Cup finals is all the fault of the FAZ executive and not players.

The FAZ executive has let the nation down and has no moral right to seek a fresh mandate.

Fine, the officials don't play soccer but they have an obligation to prepare the team through effective training matches.

A deliberate policy should be in place to ensure as many players from the league are exposed to international soccer, a trait which other countries have tapped but FAZ blocks.

As long as FAZ remains the domain of so-called long-serving administrators who are not achievers, Zambia will continue to sink as the continent's soccer force.

Zambia lost yesterday, but Zambia is far from finished so long we get the bearings right but not with people at the helm of FAZ who cannot scent victory.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Business and Finance;
Southern Africa's economic grouping set for successes


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - The Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) is convinced the African Economic Community (AEC) will succeed because it has the backing of African regional economic groupings.

Comesa acting secretary general Erastus Mwencha said in an interview in Lusaka on Friday that it were the regional groupings building into a continental economic body.

"Comesa welcomes the introduction of the African Economic Community as it is in line with the principle of globalisation that is taking place around the world. 

"We cannot afford to continue thinking small in terms of our trade markets because we will lose out. We need a big market into which any of the countries on the continent will have easy access," Mr Mwencha said.

He said Comesa signed a protocol that provided for the establishment of AEC at the recent Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit in Harare.

Mr Mwencha agreed with Comesa authority vice chairman and Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni that the continental body should involve private businessmen to succeed.

"I believe the organisation will be driven by businessmen involved in the regional groupings in various regions. Getting the private sector into the integration process is the essence of all these integration efforts.

"After all the private businessmen are the people who do business. Without them, we cannot achieve market integration," he said.

Mr Museveni was quoted after the 33rd OAU heads of state summit last week in Harare as having said that the AEC was headed for failure unless the private sectors of individual countries were allowed to run the affairs of the organisation.

Most of the African states have ratified the establishment of the AEC to create a common market for the continent.

Meanwhile Mr Mwencha dispelled speculation that the Comesa secretariat had dismissed its directors of trade and customs Zewde Demissie and director of transport and communications Anastase Munyabarenzi.

Mr Mwencha said the two directors were just normally retiring from the organisation.

Zambia;
First Lady Vera donates K2.5m


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - First Lady Vera Chiluba has donated K2.5m and one hammermill to Chingola district Hope Foundation.

She made the donation during the fundraising luncheon held at Nchanga Mine Club on Saturday, Mrs Chiluba said Hope Foundation was offering the donation to help the less privileged in society and alleviate their suffering She urged women to stand up and fight the problems fellow mothers and children were facing in trying to grapple with the hard times. She said the fundraising luncheon demonstrated that people were concerned with the plight of the needy in society particularly women and children.

"We can only achieve this by working together in harmony," she said.

At the same function Chingola mayor Marcelino Bwembya pledged K500,000 on behalf of the Chingola Municipal Council to the Hope Foundation.

Mzakaka Company donated K200,000 and former MMD district chairman Mwansa Wapabeti offered to supply stationery for three months as well as paint the building in which the hammermill would be installed. He also donated K20,000 cash.

Most of the councillors who attended the luncheon pledged their sitting allowances for two sessions while area MP Dr Ladislas Kamata pledged K50,000. - ZIS.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


Zambia;
State stalls in clearing suppliers


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Government has continued to stall over the payment of over K10bn it owes food suppliers because of double-dealing by some members, Food Suppliers Association national chairman George Mwambazi has charged.

Mr Mwambazi said at the weekend that although suppliers were instructed to stop delivering food to Government institutions until all the debt was cleared, some of them had defied the directive. 

He said the development had created suspicion in Government on whether suppliers were genuine.

Government had also taken advantage of the confusion and was making no effort to repay the huge debt.

"We agreed that we should stop supplying food to Government institutions until the whole debti s cleared. But we have suppliers who are still supplying to Government institutions and are being paid cash. This is unfair to those who are owed money," he said.

Mr Mwambazi said although the prisons department owed food suppliers more than K5bn, Government had only managed to pay K400m which was a drop in the ocean.

He warned suppliers that unless they observed the ban on supplying food to Government institutions, all those who are owed money would never get it.

Mr Mwambazi said it was impossible for suppliers to sue Government and the only way to win the fight was to work together.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Zambia;
Swindled farmers cry for help


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Peasant farmers in Chief Chitanda's area in Chibombo who were swindled out of millions of Kwacha by a maize buyer last year have appealed to Government to help them recover their money.

The farmers said in Kabwe their efforts to trace the whereabouts of the trader, Mr Siyoto Mumbula of Siyohako Investments Limited have failed, hence the need for Government's intervention.

Two of the farmers, Mr Gilbert Mpande of Kaponya village and Mr Petulo Haadunka from Fulabunga village said since last December when they reported the case to Kabwe police to date there were no signs that they would recover their money. 

Narrating their ordeal, Mr Mpande said in October last year Mr Mumbula introduced himself to farmers in Chief Chitanda's area.

He said on October 18 last year the buyer collected 40 x 90kg bags of white maize from Mr Mpande and another 177 x 90kg from Mr Haadunka, promising to pay K15,000 per bag after 30 days from the date of collection.

Mr Mpande explained that afer 30 days of waiting farmers started traveling to Kabwe to chase for their money and it was not until November 23 last year when Mr Mpande was given K150,000 as down payment . He said other farmers were not paid a single ngwee.

Mr Mpande said after persistent knocks at his office at the former Zambia National Wholesale and Marketing Corporation (ZNWMC) the Mr Siyoto travelled to the area where he promised to pay the affected farmers in form of fertiliser, but he never returned.

A month later when they found the his office closed , farmers went to his home in Natuseko site and service where they only found his wife who told them her husband was still in Lusaka scouting for fertiliser.

But when the farmers went back on January 2 this year, they found the man had shifted his family to an unknown place and to date they have not traced him.

Mr Mpande who said they have since then been calling at the police pointed out that their families were now starving while their animals have died from corridor and other diseases because they have no money to buy drugs. -Zana/ZIS.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


Zambia;
Give more to God - Chiluba


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - President Chiluba has urged Zambians to donate more to the church to enable the preaching of the gospel country-wide.

Speaking in Monze on Saturday when he officiated at the launching of the New Revised Tonga Bible, Mr Chiluba urged the people to give more to the cause of God instead of spending money on social vices like beer drinking. 

"Sacrifice a little bit more and give enough to the church , let us give to the work of God and spend less on beer," the president said

He also challenged Christians to confess their sins to god positively so that they can receive salvation.

And speaking at the same occasion, secretary of the Bible Society of Zambia Mr Mpundu Mutala, said they new revised Tonga Bible has tried to harmonise all Tonga speaking people by using Universally accepted words to Tongo , Lenje and Ila.

Mr Mutala said it took in society 25 years to do the translation at the cost of K40m.

Meanwhile, President Chiluba who was accompanied by Minister at State House, Eric Silwamba and Special Assistant for Economy Donald Chanda returned to Lusaka on Saturday afternoon.

The president was seen off by the Southern province Min Elias Miyanda. -Zana.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
SA shatter Zambia's World Cup hopes


BYLINE: Yuyo Kambikambi, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - It is all over. Zambia yesterday bowed out of the race, yet again, of the World Cup championship billed for France next year's when they suffered their worst defeat in 10 years at the hands of South Africa's Bafana Bafana.

All the dreams that the Zambian soccer fans had envisioned of donning national colours at the prestigious championship in France went up in smoke in a space of five minutes, no thanks to Helman Mkhalele and Phil Masinga first half goals. 

Right from the blow of the first whistle, Zambia went into the game too relaxed and casual for anyone's liking, what the porous defence and the once perfect pair of Harrison Chongo and Elijah Litana clearly failing to tick.

It was doomsday for anyone singing the famous Chipolopolo anthem as a swift Mkhalele ably cut his way through the midfield and slotted in the first Bafana Bafana goal in the 11th minute with a shot that left Zambia's goal minder Davies Phiri, sprawling on the ground, not knowing what had hit him.

One for the hosts and nil for the visitors. The second goal was too much to handle as it came in just five minutes after the first through a Phil "Chippa" Masinga shot that was a creation from Mkhalele in the 16th minute.

Mexico based skipper Kalusha Bwalya tried all he could to revive his passive side but alas, even the famous goal poacher Paul Chellah and once feared Dennis Lota failed to co-ordinate and make any sense of the first half.

On resumption, Zambia led by a fit Jonson Bwalya came into the game with a lot more vigour and inspiration than before, with a few good flashes from Mordon Malitoli who handled the right wing well but still, striking force was too blunt.

John "shoes" Moshoeu and doctor Khumalo handled their midfield with precision and showed off their expertise and abundant talent than Hilary Makasa and Andrew Tembo trying to find their feet half the time.

The line, hook and sinker came through super substitute Mark Williams who came in for Shaun Barlett and scored the last goal of the day in the 75th minute after Khumalo collected a loose ball and passed it to Williams who made no mistake of finding the net.

"We tried our best and I think it simply was not our day. We were rather shaky as we saw all the goals come on counter-attack," were stand-in national coach George Mungwa's words after the 90 minutes nightmare.

He added: "It took time to settle down also but I guess we now have to concentrate on the Africa Cup and hope we can win that cup." With the pressure obviously on Zambia, Lota found himself being handed a yellow card in 87th minute after he still went for a ball that South Africa's goal keeper Andre Arendse had already picked up leading to a near scuffle with Mark Fish in the thick of things.

Bafana Bafana coach Clive Barker commended the Zambian team for a good match and said: "The 3-0 was not really a true reflection of the game as Zambia also had many chances though we seemed to have used ours ably."


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Namibia;
Namibian Broadcasting faces wages crisis


BYLINE: Tabby Moyo, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Windhoek - A crisis over salary increases has once again flared up at the Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC).

On Thursday a strike was averted by union leaders while more negotiations with management and the Board of Directors were opened up, according to an NBC Namibia Public Workers' Union (Napwu) Shop Steward Council member.

The unionist told The Namibian that an eight per cent increase across-the-board hike proposed by management had been rejected by NBC employees. 

The national broadcaster has faced simmering discontent on the wage front for a number of years.

And yesterday the Napwu representative said that despite the fact that numerous surveys sanctioned by the station's board had revealed that NBC staffers were grossly underpaid, nothing tangible had yet emerge.

Staff representatives were now considering taking tougher measures to ensure that staff grievances were addressed.

He said a recent survey had indicated that NBC employees, in all grades, were underpaid by about 33,31 per cent.

"All we are requesting now is for our salaries to be adjusted to the job market level. We have collected signatures from the employees to show the Board that people are serious," he said

He warned that this was the last time the union would try and reach a compromise with the Board as employees had been patient for the last six years and could no longer go on negotiating.

Although the NBC was run as a parastatal, employees in other Government institutions, such as reporters, were paid far better.

He said if the trend continued, the NBC would end up with 'the dead wood' as its competent employees would continue to seek greener pastures elsewhere.

Over the years the NBC has lost some of its most competent presenters, producers and reporters mostly to other Government institutions where they are offered better packages.

NBC employees have also complained that with the implementation of the Wage and Salary Commission (Wascom) proposals they have been left worse off than before.

When the matter was laid before Prime Minister Hage Geingob when he met the NBC Board recently, he apparently said the NBC first needed to generate its own income before employees could clamour for pay hikes.

However, disgruntled employees point out that this approach should then also be applied to the state-funded news agency, Nampa, and the state-funded newspaper, New Era.

At present the NBC receives close to N$50 million from Government.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 9, 1997


Namibia;
Rukoro urges tender reform


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Windhoek - The Attorney-General has called for a thorough review of tender procedures and Tender Board practices, in the face of public criticism of government tendering.

"I recommend that a review be undertaken to ascertain whether the legislation and procedures regarding the awarding of tenders are adequately transparent and fair to ensure that tenders are awarded impartially," Vekuii Rukoro told an ethics and anti-corruption seminar at the weekend.

Rukoro also questioned whether the current composition of the Tender Board was adequate and whether independent members should be added. 

Another aspect which needed investigation was whether adequate procedures existed to ensure that specifications were not written to favour certain companies "and that the evaluations done by ministries are disinterested."

Rukoro noted that the Tender Board must have adequate staff to evaluate tenders competently and independently of the ministry requesting the contract.

On contracts awarded by local authorities and parastatals, he said there was an absence of comprehensive laws regulating the awarding process which should be fair, impartial and open.

Commenting on civil servants, who apparently lived beyond their means, Rukoro suggested that new anti-corruption legislation should make provision for investigating these individuals.

"Under the anti-corruption statutes of other countries, a public servant is guilty of corruption if he maintains a standard of living that is above his known sources of income."

"For example, if a junior customs and excise official is known to have a fleet of expensive cars or to take expensive vacations abroad, questions may arise as to whether bribes or kick-backs were received by that official in the course of his duty," he pointed out.

Rukoro said there should be a general criminal prohibition against the use of public office for private gain.

Speaking on the same platform, opposition MP, Hans-Eric Staby noted that a culture of corruption thrived in secrecy.

He accused the building industry of fostering selective transparency and secrecy which encouraged rumour and corruption.

Appealing for transparency in the sector, he said: "Secret arrangements that might be quite innocent will be perceived as unethical simply because of their secrecy."

Staby also said negotiated contracts and exemptions from Tender Board Regulations triggered suspicions, especially when the state was involved.

The seminar was officially opened by Prime Minister Hage Geingob who pledged to root-out corruption.

South African Minister of Water Affairs, Professor Kadar Asmal was guest speaker.

Government ministers, members of the diplomatic corps and representatives from the private sector attended the seminar.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 9, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Commission Delays Durban Hearings


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - The Truth Commission today (6 June) decided to postpone the planned hearings for next week (10 - 20 June) to a date to be announced.

The hearing has been postponed for various reasons, prominent among them being the fact that a large number of the people to whom warning letters were addressed by the Commission, advising them that they would be implicated in a detrimental way by witnesses at the hearing, did not receive the notices.

These notices (sent in terms of section 30 of the Act) were sent at the beginning of May, to these persons, many of whom are retired or former members of the South African Police and South African Defence Force, via nodal points or central communication points in the SA Police and Defence Force. 

The Commission has only now become aware of the fact that many of the people to whom warning notices were sent, did not receive the notices at all, and in other cases, only received the notices during the last week. Lawyers acting for the persons named in the notices, have indicated to the Commission that their clients require further time within which to consider the allegations against them, and to prepare for the hearing.

Furthermore, after studying documents which certain witnesses who are to appear at the hearing will refer to, it became clear to the Commission that such documents refer to persons to whom warning notices had not been sent.

In all the circumstances, the Commission has decided that in order to ensure that there can be no possible prejudice to the rights of any person who may be detrimentally implicated at the hearing, that it would be in the public interest to postpone the hearing for approx. 6 weeks.

The hearing will now take place towards the end of July, on a date to be announced by the Commission.


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Protest Over Activist's Slaying


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your urgent intervention in the following situation in Ethiopia.

Brief description of the situation :

The International Secretariat has been informed by reliable sources of their grave concerns over the extra judicial or arbitrary execution of Ato Assefa Maru (37), human rights activist, member of both the Executive Committee of the Ethiopian Teachers Association (ETA) and the Executive Committee of the Ethiopian Human Rights Council.

According to the information received, Ato Assefa Maru was surrounded and shot with a kalashinkov, an automatic gun, and a hand grenade by several policemen on 8 May 1997 while he was walking home in Woreda 12 Kebele 06 to his office in Addis Ababa. It is alleged that the policemen did not order Ato Assefa Maru to stop nor did they fired any warning shots, but deliberately aimed at his head and chest. Following his death his body was searched and his briefcase was taken away by the policemen. 

According to the information received, approximately twenty-five minutes after Ato Assefa Maru, was killed, policemen searched his house and took away tape cassettes and Ethiopian Human Rights Council and ETA papers. At the same time at the ETA office, policemen detained on the premises 34 persons including ETA's leaders and staff as well as others who had gone there for private business. The following day, policemen came back with a search warrant and searched the offices and took away documents, while the staff were denied access to the office.

The Federal Police Investigation Coordination Department has apparently claimed that members of an anti-peace group which calls itself the Ethiopian Unity Patriots Front have been taken into custody and that Ato Assefa Maru, who they claimed had replaced the Front's leader and had been co- ordinating its activities, was shot dead while trying to escape.

The sources strongly refute the suggestion that Ato Assefa Maru was a member of the Ethiopian Unity Patriots Front. During the house search, no fire arms were found.

Action requested: Please write to the Ethiopian Authorities requesting that they:

i. take immediate action to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of all 34 persons mentioned above;

ii. order their immediate release if they are still detained without valid charges or, if such charges exist, bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and guarantee their full procedural rights;

iii. guarantee an impartial and exhaustive enquiry into the death of Ato Assefa Maru and the other events described above, identify those responsible, bring them to trial, and apply the penal, civil, and/or administrative sanctions provided by law;

iv. take all necessary measures to guarantee the family's right to redress;

v. ensure in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Addresses: His Excellency S.E. M. Fisseha Yimer Aboye, ambassador of the Federal Republic of Ethiopia, Permanent Mission, Rue de Moillebeau 56, P.O. Box 338, 1211 Geneva, Switzerland. Fax : + 740 11 29

His Excellency Dr Negaso Gidada, President of the Federal Republic of Ethiopia, Office of the President, P O Box 1031, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Fax : + 2511 552030

Mr. Mahteme Solomon, Minister of Justice, Ministry of Justice, P O Box 1370, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Fax : + 2511 550722

Geneva, 4 June 1998

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS-Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: June 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
Government to spend M15 million on Voter Cards


BYLINE: Tsebo Mats'asa, Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Maseru - The government of Lesotho will spend about M15 million on production of Voters Registration Cards (VRCs) which will be given to voters for the forthcoming general multi-party elections, the Chief Electoral Officer Mr. Lebohang Tsepane said in Maseru last week.

The VRCs will be produced to curb the problem of unclear identity during the elections.

It is not clear whether people will have to pay for the cards, but it is believed that the government will give an explanation on this issue when the Independent Electoral Commission(IEC) is launched. 

Issuance of VRCs will be made sometime in March 1998. "Machines will be put in every registration station in each constituency where people will be photographed," said Tsepane.

Tsepane said that similar birth dates of many voters appearing in the 1993 voters roll were found to be accurate and correct.

Tsepane was reacting to the complaints made by some political parties that such birth dates similarities may mean that some dubious deals in the making of the voters roll.

He said that his office re-registered some people to check the accuracy of the roll.

"Indeed we found out that these were the real dates in which those people were born," he said.

Tsepane is also of the idea that holding of both general multi-party elections and local government elections separately will cost the government a lot of money.

He argued that funds for the general multi-party election alone are not enough and at the moment he is working on a proposal for funds top- up.

The chief electoral officer said that M15 million was budgeted for the multi-party general elections and about the same amount will be needed.

This amount is separate to that of VRCs, which means that the government may need about M45 million for the general multi-party election only.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
