Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
Juvenile Justice: Females in Prison


BYLINE: Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Maseru - Continuing our series on juvenile justice in Lesotho this week we look at how juveniles are treated by the law, and in practice. Mopheme also visited the juvenile wing of the female prison and talked to some of the detainees.

Young girls who commit crimes in Lesotho are sent to the juvenile wing of the Female Prison in Maseru. 

Like the Juvenile Training Centre for boys, which we reported on recently, the juvenile wing of the Female Prison is a place of rehabilitation, and not supposed to be a prison environment. However unlike the JTC, which has its own grounds the girl's wing is part of the adult prison.

Although the girls are treated differently to the adult prisoners - they sleep in a separate dormitory and have access to primary education - they do not have the same vocational and recreational facilities as the boys at the JTC.

Most of the 22 girls currently detained at the Girl's Unit have a similar story to tell. Tseli's (not her real name) story is typical.

Tseli's Story Tseli is one of the young offenders detained at the Girl's Unit of the female prison in Maseru. Since arriving there 6 months ago she has not had a single visitor. Despite the winter coldness Tseli walks around the prison yard barefoot. She has no shoes.

"We supply uniforms and blankets and basic toiletries," explains M'e Machachamise, the Warden, "but we cannot supply shoes. The girls' parents or guardians have to do that. Girls who do not get visits from parents or friends are often without some basic items. We cannot supply underwear or face cloths either. Parents should bring money for the girls to buy these things. If there are no visitors the girl usually does without such items, except what she had when she arrived here." Tseli's crime is theft, the most common crime among girls. She was a house maid and stole money from her employer. "I worked long hours each and every day, from very early in the morning to late at night", she says. "The house had eight rooms and I had to look after two children.

In the six months I was working I never got a day off. I never got to talk to people my own age, except when I was hanging clothes on the washing line. It was very lonely." Tseli asked for a pay rise but her employer's would not give her one so she stole money.

"Many of the girl's who are sent here are domestics who have stolen from an employer says," M'e Machachamise. Often they steal because they are not paid. Also you find many of the girls have left their parent's home, perhaps due to some family problems and are on the streets stealing to meet their needs."

Talking to the girls Mopheme discovered that over half have do not receive regular visits. Eight girls have not had a single visitor since they arrived. Kekeletso (not her real name) arrived at the prison in 1994, when she was 15.

Her crime was stealing M550.00 from a passenger in a taxi. "I don't know why my parents have never visited me," she says with tears streaming down her face. In three years I have had no visits from anyone. I will go and ask my family to forgive me when I am released but I don't think they will want me back."


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
Ntsu flies with the BCP colours


BYLINE: Lawrence Keketso, Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Maseru - Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle has successfully staged a coup against his own Basutoland Congress Party (BCP) and formed a new one. The new government was unofficially formed in Parliament yesterday afternoon when Mokhehle asked his supporters in parliament to cross the floor and rally behind him.

Mokhehle then addressed a press conference before a packed Parliament with MP's and the public, while session adjourned for the afternoon. 

But, the break time lapsed and time was extended as the National Assembly Sergeant in Arms continously made a reminder that the press conference was held on borrowed time and that Parliament session had to resume.

According to Mokhehle, BCP is old and has finished its job. He said the BCP main task was to get freedom for Basotho and his new party Lesotho Congress for Democracy (LCD) is promote and develop the true democratic governance of the people by the people.

The new government still under the leadership of Mokhehle has been kidnapped by the new party LCD he formed with his supporters at the weekend meeting on Saturday.

He advised the remaining leadership of the BCP to register as an official opposition in Lesotho Parliament and advise the Speaker of the New Opposition Leader.

When asked about his stated intent to leave active politics by the end of the year, Mokhehle said it is not yet the end of the year. He however said though he is ill and old, it does not mean an old man can not work for his children.

The new party whose slogan is "puso ea sechaba ka sechaba" - government of the people by the people - bears the same colours like the former except that this one has double black and they flying eagle.

The party leader is Mokhehle, deputised by Pakalitha Mosisili. On the chair is Thebe Motebang assisted by Mopshatla Mabitle. Shakhane Mokhehle rocks the Secretary-Generalship chair of the party assisted by Notsi Molopo. PRO is Pashu Mochesane deputised by Thabiso Melato, Treasurer is Lira Motete, Editor Monyane Moleleki, while members are Makatla Makatla and Kelebone Maope.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
World Class Historic Corruption (Editorial)


BYLINE: Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Maseru - It all started as a mere bickering, or so it appeared. Later it turned out to be a teething-struggle for succession. It then developed into a circus that took almost two years. 

And, instead of laughing, spectators were annoyed while the electorate and supporters suffered indigny of having cast their votes for turncoat politicians in the kraal of Basutoland Congress Party (BCP).

The entire leadership of the BCP had long lsot its root. It has lost direction, it has no vision and its future is bleak. In the words of its founder "it is dead." Dr Ntsu Mokhehle and his deputy Mr Molapo Qhobela had been at loggerheads for the simple questions of power and digging of the past to fuel animosity among members of the BCP to justify their harum scarum political behaviour.

Thanks God it did not take them up to the coming 1998 general election.

Blood was smelling when it came to nomination of candidates for the party's constituencies.

Now, at last there is solution. Water and paraffin. Followers of the ailing Mokhehle have thrown the towel into the ring because their best boxer is hors de comabt with clout injury. In the meantime, Qhobela, who has also reached the retiring age as far as modern politics is concerned, got what he wanted by clever political horse-trading.

Mokhehle has desrted and left Qhobela with BCP to exercise his muscles with all ease Qhobel is now the head that wears the crown. No more "tired and old Ntsu, his younger brother and uneducated miners." Qhobela must show his way.

But Mokhehle is taking a rest. He has opted to punch Qhobela and his henchmen from a distance by forming his new political party, Lesotho Congress Democracy (LCD). The worst part of it is that it has been formed through corrupt means and its formation has cost the public dearly. But it all depends on the opposition and public approval of this corruption.

Thousands of public money; several hours which should have been invested to the entire public affairs and public properties have been misused by the government to form a political party. Cabinet ministers have exploited whatever is within their reach in their public offices and official capacities to rob the public for the sake of the new party.

Cabinet ministers, who are holding their positions on the ticket of BCP have been using day and night public stationery, telephones, electricity, offices, desks and vehicles organising for the formation of the new party.

BCP under the leadership of Qhobela, appears to be a bad looser. They have lost their hard-fetched government to LCD. In fact BCP is starting from the scratch to work for a new government, if they have no means to deprive Mokhehle of their entitlement.

What the leaders of BCP and the new party as well, need now is a serious introspection Reformation of the party with dynamic modern democratic noms that allow diverse participation of members without time frame restrictions toward a truly democratic organisation that will convey democratci principles into government is inevitable to any political organisations aiming to survive in the 20th century. New blood should hold the reins while old blood should hold advisory positions.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
The Eagle has landed - the Eagle has flown (Editorial)


BYLINE: Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Maseru - Say the Eagle has Landed or say it has flown, depending on where you stand. But, there was yet another political precedence set in Lesotho yesterday which will certainly amaze the whole world. All in all, it appears to have been within the constitutional boundaries of the country. 

Some people may not agree that it was a coup, but it was, but from within and a very silent one, and a very clever one.

What is now becoming evident, from the mouths of the defectors, is that the structures of the Basutoland Congress Party did not allow the fully swing of a democratic existence within the party, and thus the long and queued leadership struggle which went from a court to another court.

Sad, and very sad indeed that at this eleventh hour, some "goodmen" will come and open the eyes of the people.

Things being where they are now, it is worth challenging the mind, eyes and ears, to make own judgement, as to what has been a problem in the governance of the BCP. Was it the Pressure Group or the Majela-Thoko (Conservatives). Now balancing scale has been put upright and the voters can make their own clear choices.

Even though some political analysts are already foreseeing a political setback, which could somehow develop into a hectic confusion for Basotho, others say in the name of democracy and progress towards the development of democratic structures in the country, things could not have come at this better moment.

by the look of things, the new party may experience good support, and then until, as some critics see it, when the old man retires from active politics, then like in some other political parties, like Basotho National Party and National Progressive Party, candidates would be making empty promises to the people in the name of the good past....

This and others have been very surprising moves in Lesotho politics, that instead of set philosophies and ideologies, politicians turn to believe and propagate their canvassing around personalities and may be to some extent had gotten good votes...!

Like Dr. Mokhehle has stated that he is forming the new party for his children (supporters), it will not be surprising that even after he has completely quit, his name would still feature prominently his children's campaigns for being elected, as if he would still be in office.

The struggle for power had almost gotten too much into the voters disillusioned hearts and the absolute split will certainly rekindle some political competitiveness, even though the competition results will be drawn from leading personalities and not on promises and set policies.

However, come 1998, and what will be born of that new era may be a total disaster for the nation or a total breakthrough in Lesotho's political stability and good democratic governance. The nation has been placed in a make it or break type of situation, and if until now the smaller opposition parties (as they are always called) are still fast asleep, they will be dealt like those girls in the Bible who forgot to fill their lamps with oil before the bride came, and they will never ever be allowed in.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
City livestock and prostitutes


BYLINE: Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Maseru - The new Maseru City Council is to be congratulated for taking up its job seriously. They want to make a clean sweep of Maseru City by implementing livestock control regulations (Mopheme June 3-9, 1997).

The regulations are a colonial baggage which merit thorough review before prosecuting livestock owners who do not heed MCC's appeal to observe the regulations. Their implementation has eluded past administrations since 1966. The MCC, in a democratic administration, should save itself the embarrassment of its predecessors by appearing like a toothless bulldog. 

Surprisingly, city livestock have a lot in common with city prostitutes.

And city' is understood to include the expansive Maseru peri-urban areas where many poor women keep one or two dairy cows and few chickens.

Both livestock and prostitutes in the city are a product of poverty, and therefore invoke a sense of compassion.

They are also a product of male affluence; and since the affluent often call the shots, the MCC might find itself banging its head against a brick wall. Keeping livestock and engaging in prostitution are a male pastime. The former has cultural underpinnings. This is why a cow or any bovine is culturally elevated to molimo o nko e metsi' (a god with a wet nose!) On the other hand, male clients in prostitution trade merely express Freudian instinct of male dominance over and subordination of the female. Like with the animals which cohabit with their partners instinctively, the end result is promiscuity with all its implications such as infection with AIDS, for humans, and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).

Since the city livestock unlike their counterparts, pose no threat to spread of this scourge of diseases, it would be reasonable, if not prudent, for MCC to re-examine its priorities. Control of STDs is a much more pressing and urgent problem in Maseru city than livestock.

The Director of Parks and Recreation, Mrs Leratang Monare, may be correct in reminding the public that "livestock control regulations within the city are necessary in the interests of public health, reduction of traffic hazards---------".

But the moonlight' ladies are a worse traffic hazard and menace especially after drinking away their earnings and invading, in their drunken stupor, dangerously speeding motorists. Saving their life from physical injury and from being a reservoir of STDs is a much more urgent humanitarian act of compassion than immediate concern for livestock in the city. At least, livestock is never seen staggering around the streets, Mountain Brewery has not done enough marketing yet! These observations should not be misconstrued to imply condoning keeping of livestock in the city. Rather, the intention is to convey a sense of balance in the approach to our city's problems and for MCC to reassess its priorities.

There is nothing wrong with MCC attempting to emulate the not-so-poor cities like some of Johannesburg's wealthy suburbs studded with horse stables and dairy farms; Zurich's hilly and exclusive periurban residences overlooking clean Brown Swiss cowsheds; Lago's market centres where roaming goats appear to coexist happily with marketeers; or Nairobi city's lush greenery meticulously mowed by majestic Masai's herds.

But in poor Lesotho, colonial regulations "prohibit livestock in government proprieties in the city centre and in properties below one acre. Properties of one acre and above are allowed two large livestock, and livestock such as sheep, goats, pigs, oxen and donkeys are prohibited" Government property, what of police stables and MCC animal slaughterhouse? Livestock was prohibited in properties below one acre because during the colonial days only Basotho lived in such properties while the masters who lived in mini-farms in the city could keep two large stock, usually a cow and a horse for pleasure riding. As for other classes of livestock which poor Mosotho could keep, there was a total ban.

What will MCC do about large poultry units in the city? And dogs.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
Interrogation In Hotel Room 453


BYLINE: Khutliso Sekoati, Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Maseru - A young priest got terrified. He feared for his life as he saw a 9mm firearm being pulled out of the hotel room cabinet drawer. Glancing at the fatal weapon, he could smell death.

Father Antony "Scar" Monyau of the diocesan order of priests at Our Lady of Victories - Mofumahali oa Tlholo- was being interrogated in room 453 of the Hotel Victoria on Lt. Phakiso Molise's skipping the country to seek asylum in the neighbouring South Africa. 

Far from any suspicion, the priest was asked by police officer Major George Mofolo in a telephone conversation to phone the latter's colleague officer Kizito Mhlakaza who was obviously booked at the Victoria Hotel, a member of the Lesotho Hotels.

"He asked me to meet him at the hotel. When I entered the room I found him with two other people- a woman and a man- whom I suspected were also policemen. As I got in, the other dashed out," said Monyau in an exclusive interview with Mopheme-The Survivor.

According to him the young police officer, a product of the St.

Augustine's Seminary which also groomed Monyau to the priesthood said Molise "has talked and said you helped him skip the country, adding that what we did was not good and wanted to know if we did so under any instructions.

"He told me he was the only one to pull us out of the menace as the issue was dangerous," noted Monyau who categorically denied any links with Molise.

Later on after an hour interrogation that started at 7.00pm, Mhlakaza wisely lured the celibate to accompany the woman. Instead he offered them a M30 to pay for a night cab to ferry them to their places.

Before the trio got out of the hotel room, Mhlakaza pulled a gun out of a drawer, a move that swiftly hurled the priest into uncertainty and fear for death.

"I said if anything happens the woman will have to testify. She said we'll only be two when we return from accompanying her." But the policeman silently hang his weapon on the-----.

Eventually the suspecting priest, in company with Mhlakaza, drove his Golf model car to ferry the police woman to Florida estates, after which he drove back his interrogator to the hotel.

In yet another shocking incident, the priest was again interrogated by Major Mofolo, one Lt. Matsoso who is a member of the thriving Catholic Life Group (CLG) at Our Lady of Victories and their colleague one Matona. He was told he had dug his finger on police issue.

"I asked him what they meant because on that day in question- February 16- I was conducting mass at the Lesotho Defence Force (LDF) barracks at which I asked the congregation to pray for peace.

The aggressive policemen, who were bitterly coughing out a spree of questions to the suspect, wanted to know if he knew Molise. He said he had only seen his photograph on Moeletsi oa Basotho newspaper, adding "I was familiar with the face." After he strongly warned them that it would the first time to arrest a priest in a democratic rule, Matsoso wondered how they would protect the church if "we didn't tell the truth," and they asked him to act respectably.

He questioned them as to why they were not making inquiries from the Palace for the fact that the government had announced Molise was hiding there.

He had also been asked if he knew one Fr Khoza of Ladybrand South Africa, who is alleged to have also assisted in fleeing Molise from the country.

Another priest who has also been wrecked by police unwarranted fury is Rev Patrick Sekome, also a diocesan priest at the Cathedral of Our Lady of Victories.

He was suspected to have given shelter to Molise and Sergeant Thabang Makateng who is still at large and helped them skip the country to take refuge in South Africa.

According to Fr. Sekome, who studied at the St. Augustine's Seminary together with Mhlakaza, a graduate in Bachelor of Philosophy, Major Mofolo and policeman Matona told him their four sources confirmed that he was allegedly involved in sneaking out the two policemen.

"They said Archbishop Bernard Mohlalisi had said Makateng might have been at his house because he found the latter's note requesting to be linked with lawyers. I told them if that was so I would have known because I work under Archbishop Mohlalisi. I also told them that some people have severely suffered because of lies and that we were aware some of the police officers were plotting to assassinate us." He then asked them why they did not enquire from the Palace where Molise was suspected to be taking refuge. A third priest who also toiled under police wrath is Fr Augustinus Mahlaku. He was also questioned on any links with Molise and Makateng's fleeing the country.

Royal Lesotho Mounted Police head of press section Captain Sekoateng Serabele said the names of the priests were mentioned by the people who were interviewed by the police during their investigations.

"It's not that they were regarded as criminals. We just wanted them to say what they knew and they have denied any links," he told Mopheme- The Survivor last week.

Asked if conducting an interview in a hotel room was a normal practice, he said as long as policeman wanted to get information he "can conduct his interview at any place", but added that the meeting might have been on friendly basis.

He denied the newspaper any access to interview the policemen who interrogated the church ministers saying "that might jeopardize ongoing investigations," and added that could not happen because those police officers are not public relation officers.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Lesotho;
Mokhehle is Good Riddance - Qhobela


BYLINE: Lawrence Keketso, Mopheme/The Survivor (Maseru)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Maseru - Tensions mounted the whole of yesterday morning in the National Assembly as members awaited the announcement of a new political party formed by the Prime Minister Dr. Ntsu Mokhehle and his supporters at the Saturday meeting held at the Cooperatives College in Maseru.

The long wait seemed not to come to an end as MPs started using harsh language attacks against each other while debates on Amendment Bill on 1970's Dismissed Public Servants were on.

Members of Parliament alike members of the public were not sure as to whether Prime Minister Mokhehle would resign with his supporters from government and form an opposition in parliament. But, there was sure an important announcement to be made and all waited crossing their fingers .for a tail of head.....

As at that time there seemed to be any possible move, even members of the BCP Pressure Group did not move about much or stray in case they had to form a new government in a drama. 

It was only in the afternoon when MPs were unofficially asked to cross the floor with the new government that it bacame clear that the Prime Minster had within the provisions of the Constitution - if that be - staged a coup against his own government and formed a new one, without shaking any constitutional democratic foundations...! The formation of the new party by Mokhehle and others was viewed by many critics as a win by the Pressure Group, and this was followed by jubilations and celebrations throughout the weekend by the BCP non-supporters of Mokhehle. But, in Mokhehle's words, it looks like it's a win over nothing...! Mokhehle said during the press conference yesterday afternoon, there was a struggle for executive positions in the BCP, but now that they have left, the new BCP leadership has been left with empty seats.

Mokhehle does not however want to dictate the fate of the BCP. He had said it has done its job well and now it is old. It fought for the freedom of Basotho and that has been achieved, what is needed now is the promotion and expansion of the democratic strutures within the political set up of Lesotho so that Basotho can taste a fair and good democratic governance.

While some critics say it is too late for the old man to realize that the goals and objectives that his former party - that he, himself, founded over forty years ago - were pursuing are overtaken by time, they feel he has done more damage to himself that he thinks.

Some argue that it would now be difficult for the electorate to put total trust to a man who is one day shouting ride-on and the next day whispering pull back.

But, as critics and opinions would come from all sides without fail, the only final test that both Mokhehle and Qhobela now in their different corners, have to face is the man in the village, the woman in the street, the teenager at school, and everybody who can cast a vote in Lesotho. The answer is not far from being found, .....come 1998 and the people will make their choice...

In Molapo Qhobela's words, Mokhehle's quit "...has been such a bloody good riddance..." and continues that the rock that has always been on the way for the BCP to move ahead has now been removed.

He however said the BCP Executive will now accept the provocation by Mokhehle that they should register as an official opposition in parliament. "We are not to fall for that bribe package," said Qhobela who further added that the BCP won elections in 1993, and that all members of the National Assembly except one (Bofihla Nkuebe) were voted by BCP. He said Dr. Mokhehle is only trying to turn things up-side-down, while he himself should register for the official opposition and not the ruling party which won elections in 1993.

Qhobela said BCP now has one turn to normalise the leadership and observe the High Court rulings which will observed by the holding of the party national conference on July 26-27, 1997, and from there they are not looking back but are going forward into the villages and towns and continue with politicking.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


254 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Workshop on rural land use and forestry policy underway


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - In Ethiopia and other countries in similar stages of development where the economy is mostly based on farm products, land is an "indispensable natural resource," it was noted by the minister of Agriculture yesterday when opening a four-day workshop on rural land use and forest conservation policy.

The proper use of land depends on periodic survey of the potentials of a certain region and its utilization for years without damaging its productivity, Dr. Seifu Ketema said. due to lack of rural land use and forest conservation strategies in the past, however, different natural resources have been exposed to uncontained have been exposed to uncontained deterioration or damage in the highland areas where agricultural development is extensive, the Minister pointed out.

According to the minister, the survey carried out in 1978 in these areas indicated that 2 million hectares of land were exposed to excessive damage and have since become unproductive. Some 14 million hectares of land have meantime been badly eroded whereas 27 million hectares have been exposed to partial soil erosion and degradation, he said, adding that an estimated 2 billion metric tones of soil are being washed away to neighboring countries every year. 

The Minister also noted that the dense forests which covered as much as 40% of the country's land surface a century ago have since been reduced to 2.7% and the annual deforestation rate stands at 200,000 hectares.

Ato Tamiru Habte, head of the Forestry and Wildlife, Soil and Land use Technology and Regulatory Department, said earlier that studies showed that if the present rate of deforestation continues Ethiopia will be without any forest stands by the year 2004. The annual loss of forests is estimated at birr 65 million (10 million dollars), he added.

According to both officials, the draft document on proposed policy and strategies is meant to find lasting solutions to these and related problems the country is encountering.

They also called on the participants of the workshop to thoroughly discuss the draft document and come up with appropriate suggestions.

Dr. George Kasberger, GTZ-Project Advisory Assistance to the forest Administration, on his part widely elaborated on the importance of forestry based on the experiences of the Federal Republic of Germany.

Dr. Kasberger also elaborated on some key issues relevant to the current situation in Ethiopia.

Around 53 department and bureau heads, team leaders and experts representing the Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples, Oromia, Afar, Dire Dawa, Region 14, Benshangul-Gumuz and Harari as well as invited guests were present during the opening session.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


255 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Relief Food Distributed To Drought Victims


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Mizan Teferi (ENA) - About 482 quintals of relief food has been distributed to close to 3,000 drought victims in two woredas of Bench- Maji Zone, the early-warning system committees of the woredas disclosed.

The stated amount of relief food transported from Mizan Teferi town to Dizina and Surma woredas by helicopter is part of the 796 quintals of grain and nutritious food sent to the zone by the government.

The present consignment is not adequate for the number of drought victims in the woredas is increasing, members of the committee said adding that although there aren't any registered death tolls, health professionals are striving to contain a diarrhea epidemic that broke out in the area. 

According to Ato Melke Mekonnen, head of the zonal disaster prevention and preparedness department, the food aid was meant only to one woreda, however, it is distributed to two woredas due to the seriousness of the problem.

A team has also been sent to the zone to assess the magnitude of the problem.

Meanwhile, over 2,000 quintals of grain and nutritious food has perished, sealed off in two stores of the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Office of the Dodota Sere Woreda in Arsi Zone, workers of the office and residents disclosed.

According to the sources, 2,000 quintals of wheat, 187 quintals of lentil and 151,000 liters of cooking oil were stockpiled in two stores in Dera and Sere towns though they were supposed to be distributed among peasants whose crops have been damaged last year by drought.

However, the sources said, no distribution of relief food was effected due to the absence of the storekeeper.

The grain has got infested with weeviles for the stores have been sealed since October 1996, the source said.

Asked to comment on the issue Ato Nigussie Worku, representative of the zonal disaster prevention and preparedness department admitted the stocking of the nutritious food and ascribed the failure in the distribution to the imrisonment of the store-keeper in connection with Red Terror.

He also said in an attempt to solve the problem the case was reported to the zonal council and to concerned bodies and is still pending decision.

Ato Redwan Usman, head of the social affairs section in the council said on his part he has been contacting conerned bodies to over come the problem.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


256 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Three colleges to offer new programmes next year


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egizabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Minister of Education disclosed here yesterday that three existing colleges in the country will launch new programmes in diverse disciplines as of the beginning of the next Ethiopian academic year.

Submitting the Ministry's annual performance report to the 51st regular session of the Lower House of Parliament, W/ro Genet Zewdie said that the new programmes will be offered by Arbaminch Institute of Water Technology (AIWT), Bahir Dar Polytechnique Institute (BPI,) and Jimma Health Science College (JHC). She said that they were carefully selected so as to meet the priority needs of the country.

According to the Minister, AIWT will offer mechanical, electrical and civil engineering courses, BPI will provide programmes in industrial engineering and textile technology, while the JHC will conduct programmes in civil, electrical and mechanical engineering as well as in accounting and management.

W/ro Genet also spoke of a number of policy and practical measures aimed at solving the trained man-power shortage which the country faces. She said: "In addition to awarding scholarships in India to a number of Ethiopians, preparations are being finalized to strengthen and expand the post-graduate programmes of Addis Ababa University." She said that new post graduate programmes in engineering economics, management and the basic sciences will soon start.

The Minister briefed the House of Peoples' Representatives on major accomplishments in raising the present standard of education so as to produce problem-solving personnel.

W/ro Genet noted a progressive increase in student enrollment, more so in women, both in primary and tertiary levels. According to her, 9,067 students are currently taking degree and diploma courses in the various institutions of higher learning across the country.

Several Mps raised relevant questions which the Minister along with her deputy, answered in detail.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Ethiopia;
Workshop on rural land use and forestry policy underway


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words

260 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Stock Slip Among Emerging Markets


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1015 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Returns from the top five Zimbabwean stocks dropped during the first five months of 1997 under heavy selling pressure from investors, analysts said Wednesday.

The market analyst, Dataworld Nominees, said in its latest newsletter that Zimbabwe was now ranked 13th out of 27 emerging markets in terms of the performance of the top five stocks. 

"Over the month of May 1997, the country was ranked the fifth worst performer," it said.

The Zimbabwe Stock Exchange (ZSE) has been reeling under selling pressure since April. This has been due to profit-taking by investors after announcement of the controversial central bank decision on transfer of dual quoted shares.

In its latest report on emerging markets, the International Finance Corporation says that the Zimbabwe Stock Market's performance, so far this year, in terms of the Investable Indexes, was 17.4 percent in United States dollar terms. Its returns, based on the broader based Global Indexes measure, was 10.7 percent.

The Investable Index is based on price movements in the top five capitalised shares on the ZSE, while the Global Index is calculated on 22 stocks selected from industrial and mining counters.

The top five capitalised stocks are Delta, Barclays, Bindura, Zimsun and Wankie.

Meanwhile, the revival of the watershed Industrial Index continued Wednesday following another day of robust performance by the heavyweights, First Merchant Bank and Caps.

The two counters surged ahead 200 and 100 cents to close at 4,100 and 2,700 cents respectively, movements which pushed the index 64 to 10,294.28 points.

Wednesday's increase meant the 59-counter index has gained 230 points or 2 percent since Monday.

The Mining Index put on nearly two points to close at 999.70.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


261 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
CITES Secretariat Supports Limited Ivory Trade


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species secretariat has conditionally accepted the proposal by three Southern African countries to remove the elephant from the list of endangered species.

In a document to be discussed by some 1,500 delegates attending the meeting in Harare, Zimbabwe, the secretariat accepted proposals by Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe. These countries are calling for limited trade in ivory stocks which have accumulated since 1989 but gave conditions which, first, must be met. 

The countries propose that the conference of parties approve export quotas for a specified period of 1998 and 1999 of existing registered stocks of raw ivory for the exclusive purpose of disposing of accumulated ivory stocks.

The secretariat noted that the three countries had proposed procedures and conditions for the export of ivory stocks, limited quantities and limited number of shipments, as well as inspection of shipments by any adherents to the convention, including the secretariat.

The document says trade in live animals, hunting trophies, hides and non-commercial personal effects as proposed by Zimbabwe was unobjectionable.

"The African population in Namibia is stable and those in Botswana and Zimbabwe is increasing," the secretariat said. "Although there is concern about funding for anti-poaching activities in Zimbabwe, there is no basis for predicting a decline in population."

Southern Africa has a 300,000-kilogram stockpile of ivory. This accounts for at least half of all of Africa's stocks and could generate at least 330 million zimdollars (30 million U.S. dollars).

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe are proposing that elephants be moved from the endangered species list from Appendix I to Appendix II, which allows for controlled trade in elephant products.

Although optimistic, Zimbabwean officials said they feared that some countries would not support the downlisting because of threats from some non-governmental organizations.

Zimbabwe needs a two-thirds vote before its proposal to downlist the animal can be accepted.

Meanwhile, debate on the proposed downlisting of the African elephant to allow controlled trade was deferred indefinitely Wednesday as some delegates were without documents relating to the topic.

"We could not debate on the elephant today because most of the delegates did not have enough documents, and I do not know when they will be ready," David Brackett, who chaired the committee meeting, said.

Resolutions of the committee have to be ratified by the conference but cannot be debated during the meeting.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


262 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Jonah, The Diplomat, Haunts Sierra Leone's Putschists


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - A military showdown with a combined West African force is likely the main fear of the junior officers who toppled Sierra Leone's democratically-elected government May 25.

But while the Nigerian-led forces are deploying and efforts continue to seek a negotiated solution to the crisis, the putschists face another formidable foe: James Jonah, Sierra Leone's United Nations envoy.

Since the coup halted Sierra Leone's slow recovery from years of civil war and cut short its fledgling democracy, Jonah has embarked on a diplomatic offensive to deny international recognition to the new military leaders.

From the United Nations, where he retired in 1994 after some 30 years of service, to the Organization of African Unity and the Economic Community of West African States, Jonah has tapped his wide-ranging contacts in seeking to isolate the coup plotters and their rebel allies. 

At the just-concluded Africa summit in Harare, Zimbabwe, where the Sierra Leonean diplomat represented his country, he succeeded in obtaining a strong O.A.U. condemnation of the coup. The organization also supported possible military action to reverse the coup.

Jonah has also succeeded in putting the soldiers on the defensive by alleging, at a meeting Monday with the president of the U.N. Security Council, that the coup leaders were planning genocide against supporters of the ousted president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah.

Jonah asked the council to issue a warning to the soldiers and to set up an ad-hoc tribunal to try the putschists "if any harm should come to the people of Sierra Leone".

The credibility of the soldiers has also been severely dented by reports that the soldiers have asked for a 46-million-U.S.-dollar pay- off to step down and allow Tejan Kabbah to return.

To show his utter disdain for the coup makers, Jonah has used an arsenal of scathing words, describing them variously as "renegade soldiers", "a little bunch of illiterate thugs" and a "group of pretenders masquerading as the government of my country."

He even called them "naive" for daring to recall him, in the wake of the coup, as Sierra Leone's permanent representative to the United Nations.

But Jonah, unusually blunt for a diplomat, has also attacked the media, which he has used effectively since the coup, or any group he perceived as seeking to delay a reversal of the coup, the country's third in five years.

In his second press conference since the coup, at the UN headquarters in New York, he lambasted the media Monday for "not accurately reporting" the shelling of Sierra Leone's military headquarters by Nigerian gunboats last week.

Jonah said the media "missed the point" in focusing on an alleged retreat by Nigerian forces rather than the "inhuman action" by the coup plotters.

He also accused the British charity group, International Alert, which tried to mediate in the crisis, of seeking to "strengthen" the coup by seeking Security Council involvement.

Asked if the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) should seek the council's mandate before using force in Sierra Leone, he said: "We don't need to do that because Ecowas has demonstrated that it is a credible regional organization, more than any of them (Security Council members) have done."

Jonah, 63, may have every reason to be angry. Since his retirement he has devoted his time and energy to his country, presiding over a successful political transition as chairman of Sierra Leone's interim national electoral commission and participating in reconciliation efforts as a member of the country's National Security Council.

Now, faced with the prospect of another transition program under the regime of Maj. Johnny Koromah, which has asked to stay in power for 18 months, Jonah's fuse is very short.

"We in Sierra Leone are tired of military regimes," he said. "We cannot spare the time to tolerate this new military coup."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Congo;
O.A.U. Chairman Calls For End To Fighting In Brazzaville


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Organization of African Unity Chairman Robert Mugabe appealed Wednesday for an immediate truce to the fighting in Brazzaville, the capital of the Republic of Congo, where government troops are trying to disarm the country's militia ahead of elections.

"I urgently appeal to all sides to the conflict to agree to an immediate cease-fire and begin negotiations," Mugabe, also Zimbabwe's president, said. 

The O.A.U., he said, was ready to help the government and its opposition prevent further loss of life and property.

"In calling for an end to the hostilities, we are mindful of the elections scheduled for July 27 where the people of Congo should be allowed to make their democratic choice in an environment free of violence," Mugabe said.

Violence broke out Thursday when the army attacked the home of former President Denis Sassou-Nguesso, in an effort to disarm his militia. Sassou-Nguesso, a former army officer, intends to contest the elections.

The fighting is the worst since post-election clashes in 1993 and 1994 in which 2,000 people were killed.

June 11, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Journalist Killed in Sierra Leone


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

New York -Ishmael Jalloh, a freelance journalist who worked for a number of independent newspapers including "Punch", "Storm" and "Vision", was killed during a 3 June 1997 battle in Allentown (east of Freetown) between a combined battalion of soldiers of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) and Sierra Leone Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC) against Nigerian ECOMOG soldiers.

According to CPJ sources, while Jalloh was covering the fighting his entire left arm and shoulder were ripped off by a rocket-propelled grenade, and he died as result of his wounds. 

Jalloh was recognized the following day by an unnamed fellow journalist who was present when bodies of slain RUF and AFRC soldiers were being removed from the beach by an AFRC truck. It is believed that Jalloh's body was buried in a mass grave with AFRC and RUF casualties in an undisclosed section of Allentown on 4 June.

For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina (x 103) or Selam Demeke (x 118) at CPJ, 330 Seventh Ave., New York, NY 10001, U.S.A., tel: +1 212 465 1004, fax: +1 212 465 9568, e-mail: kkerina@cpj.org, sdemeke@cpj.org, Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.

The information contained in this alert is the sole responsibility of CPJ. In citing this material for broadcast or publication, please credit CPJ.

June 11, 1997


South Africa;
ANC Not Surprised At Negative Response


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal is not surprised by the negative response of the National Party and the Democratic Party in KwaZulu Natal as articulated by Danie Schutte and Wessel Nel respectively, towards the ANC proposed Peace Package. Indeed, the response of these white racist parties is a clear indication that we are on the correct track. If the proposal had received the support of the NP and DP then there would have been something fundamentally wrong with the ANC's Peace Package.

These tiny white racist parties would be obliterated from the political scene of KwaZulu Natal if the political violence which only consumes African lives were to come to an end. Political violence is in the political interest and the main reason for the continued political existence of the NP and DP in KwaZulu Natal. It is therefore in their interest to keep on fanning the fires of violence.

For them the killings of Africans is like watching an interesting film. The negative comments by Mr Bantubonke Holomisa were also expected. It further exposes who Holomisa is - a former leader of a bantustan system whose main thrust was to divide, rule and kill Africans. Holomisa, true to the bantustan system he was part of, would want to see more Africans being killed in KwaZulu Natal.

Anyway, Holomisa cannot pretend forever. He has finally found his real place, the arm pit of Roelf Meyer. Mr Roelf Meyer as the former Deputy-Minister of Police is in an advantageous position. At the Deputy- Minister of Police he was privy to know all the agents of the apartheid regime's security forces. He may have already started to regroup these agents under his arm pit.

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Department of Information and Publicity.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


United States and Africa;
Africans Must Have Voice in Economic Policymaking


BYLINE: Washington Office on Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Washington - The Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) and twenty-two religious and secular organizations have issued a statement calling on the leaders of industrialized nations to consult with Africans before making policy decisions which affect African nations.

The heads of government of the Group of Seven (G7) countries Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States will hold their annual economic summit in Denver, Colorado from June 20 to June 22. The event has become known as the Denver Summit of Eight in recognition of the inclusion of the Russian leader, Boris Yeltsin, in most of the summit deliberations.

The Summit participants are expected to consider measures to promote economic liberalization in Africa and to accelerate the integration of African nations into global economic networks. 

The CBC and the organizational endorsers of the statement, "Africa and the Denver Economic Summit," insist that African representatives should be take part in reaching decisions that directly affect African nations. They fear that, otherwise, the Summit will repeat the errors of the 1884-84 Berlin Conference, at which the major European powers and the United States carved up the African continent, establishing colonial enclaves and imposing commercial regulations.

TEXT OF STATEMENT

Africa and the Denver Economic Summit

We applaud the industrialized nations participating in the Denver Summit of Eight for the decision to pay particular attention to Africa. However, we greatly regret that the participants will have no opportunity to consult directly with African officials. If Africa is to be on the agenda, Africans should be at the table.

It is imperative that the Denver Summit of Eight not become a modern- day Berlin Conference at which powerful nations make decisions about Africa's future without consulting Africans themselves. Africans across the continent are initiating projects and debating policies consistently and constructively. We urge policy makers to recognize these developments and to establish a mechanism to facilitate systematic consultation with all those whose lives will be affected by the choices made. This requires that the summit participants initiate a dialogue that involves not only their counterparts in African governments, but also a broad cross-section of African public, private, and civil society sector representatives. We hope that such discussions would develop a comprehensive program of action for consideration at the 1998 economic summit.

We recognize that Africans do not speak with one voice, nor are all individuals and groups equally well-equipped to make their voices heard. Consequently, a particular effort must be made to consult with those who typically find themselves on the political and economic periphery: rural dwellers, women, workers, youth, the unemployed, elderly, and disabled. We fear that, in the absence of these perspectives, certain principles fundamental to policy development and assessment will be ignored. These include criteria that have already emerged from our own discussions with African community and civil society organizations and that resonate with our experiences in domestic struggles for social and economic justice:

1. The single most important question which must be asked about any Africa initiative, whether multilateral or bilateral, is: What impact will the action have on Africa's economically poor majorities and the most marginalized sectors of each society?

2. Programs and policies should be designed to produce explicit, tangible benefits for poor communities. It should never be assumed that benefits will "trickle down" from the economically or politically powerful to the marginalized.

3. Action must be undertaken simultaneously on a number of fronts and policies must interlock to form a coherent and comprehensive whole. Initiatives in one area must not be undermined by action (or inaction) in another.

4. All multilateral and bilateral initiatives should facilitate and model increased popular participation in decision making, greater accountability of officials, and improved transparency. Such "process" concerns should take precedence over a rigid insistence on any particular economic regime.

June 6, 1997

Signed:

Congressional Black Caucus

Africa Faith and Justice Network

Africa Fund

Africa Policy Information Center

African-American Institute

American Committee on Africa

American Friends Service Committee Washington Office

Bread for the World

Catholic Relief Services

Center of Concern

Church World Service / Lutheran World Relief

Constituency for Africa

Friends Committee on National Legislation

Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers Justice and Peace Office

Mennonite Central Committee Missionaries of Africa

Oxfam America

Presbyterian Church (USA)

Society of African Missions Office of Justice and Peace

TransAfrica

Union of American Hebrew Congregations

Unitarian Universalist Service Committee

Washington Office on Africa

Distributed by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for- profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Top Cape clothing company on a roll


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - While most Cape clothing manufacturers are struggling in tough market conditions, uniform supplier Sparks & Ellis is farming out a large chunk of its production to keep up with demand.

Sparks & Ellis, a subsidiary of Cape Union Mart, is the oldest supplier of law enforcement and corporate security uniforms in South Africa.

Leonard Jocum, Sparks & Ellis' director of marketing and procurement, said the company had decided to go the outsourcing route some four years ago when it was awarded a major contract by Telkom. 

"We didn't have the capacity to meet the increased production and made a strategic decision to limit our internal manufacturing facilities, rather farming out the excess demand to people from previously disadvantaged communities," Mr Jocum said.

"So far this year 30 percent of our manufacturing has taken place outside our own manufacturing facility, either to organisations that we have seen grow into medium sized factories, or to individuals who perform the more specialist tasks for us such as the embroidery on an officer's peak cap."

Mr Jocum believed that this was true empowerment, creating employment and capital among disadvantaged communities.

"The people we are dealing with are probably not going to fill out state tender forms because they don't have the capacity to handle the volume - if we can help them get the volume through the group - that is empowering them."

Sparks & Ellis first outsourcing venture was with Cheryl Masoet, a supervisor at a clothing factory who had been laid off.

Ms Masoet began her business with six employees out of her garage at home, and has seen her business, Eez Clothing, graduate to a small factory in Lansdowne with 15 employees.

Eez Clothing produces parka jackets and other warm clothing for Sparks & Ellis.

Here Sparks & Ellis learned its first lesson, sending back the first batch of clothing because it did not meet specification.

"We realised we had to give continual support and training and, in some cases, lend them machines to perform certain tasks.

"Now when we run training sessions for our own staff, we ask these suppliers to send any of their own staff along."

Vivian de Klerk, the proprietor of Vestido Clothing, which has been producing for Sparks & Ellis for the past four years, said the group's support had helped his business grow into a medium sized factory employing 100 staff members.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


South Africa;
A new day dawns for schools


BYLINE: Sabata Ngcai, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Cape Town - In the old system of education, schools were controlled in an authoritarian and fragmented way. Teachers, pupils and parents had very little say in how schools were run and even less say in the policy- making process.

The introduction of the Schools Act in January this year brought hope to parents, teachers and pupils.

The act demands that all public schools introduce representative and democratically elected governing bodies to replace the old (sometimes unrepresentative) structures which were in place at schools. 

The aim of the new governing bodies is to involve parents and make sure they take part in decisions affecting the education of their children.

The governing bodies will have the power to decide on admissions, religion and language policies, a code of conduct for learners (pupils) and school hours.

They will also control the school property and buildings and support the work of the principal and educators (teachers).

Governing bodies will have to supplement State funding by raising money or charging fees, or both, and will be responsible for improving educational equality at the school.

The governing body membership will consist of three groups of people - the elected members, the school principal and co-opted members. The elected members are parents of learners at the school, educators at the school, administrative staff - including gardeners - and learners at the school.

The co-opted members will be members of the community and owners of school property, or their representatives, if the property is privately owned.

The Schools Act stipulates that the number of parents on any governing body must be one more than half of all the members who may vote. Parents who are employed at a school cannot represent parents on a governing body.

Co-opted members are optional and are there to help the governing body with its functions. They may not vote.

Learners on the governing body must be elected by the representative council of learners.

The number of members on a governing body will vary from one school to another.

Provincial education authorities will tell schools in each province the exact composition of their governing bodies.

A governing body must elect office bearers, including at least a chairperson, treasurer and secretary. A parent may only be chairperson of a governing body if he or she is not employed at the school.

Membership of the body is for a limited period of time - no longer than three years for a member other than a learner and not more than a year for a learner.

The new governing bodies will perform the functions of their predecessors until they begin functioning under the Schools Act on a date to be decided on.

For their part, the provincial education ministers must ensure that school principals and officers of the education department help governing bodies perform functions specified under the Schools Act.

The governing body may allow the reasonable use of school facilities for community, social or school fundraising purposes.

A governing body may be allocated additional tasks.

If a governing body wants additional tasks, it must apply in writing to the provincial education minister, who may refuse to give permission for the extra tasks to be taken on, and may also withdraw a function of a governing body.

In emergency cases, the provincial head of department may withdraw a function without communicating the decision as long as he or she gives the governing body reasons, reasonable opportunity to make representations and duly considers the representations.

The provincial head of department can suspend this action, and any person aggrieved by the decision can appeal against it. If a governing body ceases to function, the provincial head of department must appoint someone to perform its functions for not more than three months.

This period can be extended by three months, but the total period cannot be more than a year.

A member of a governing body is obliged to withdraw from a meeting if any issue in which he or she has a personal interest is being discussed and decided.

Expenses incurred by governing body members in performing their duties may be reimbursed by the governing body.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


South Africa;
A new strategy for fighting crime (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - Police in the Western Cape have set strict new crime reduction targets and have identified crimes that will be given special attention this year

Slowly, but inexorably, a coherent and credible plan to fight crime seems to be emerging. The lifting of the moratorium on recruitment for the SAPS, the appointment of a high-powered executive from the private sector to reorganise and manage the police and, most recently, the setting of crime fighting priorities and crime reduction targets in the Western Cape, all point to the measured implementation of a national police strategy to deal with what is the country's most disturbing problem.

In the Western Cape the plan has been finely honed. Housebreakings, thefts from motor vehicles and the confiscation of illegal drugs and firearms will be among the crimes which will be specially targeted this year. And in each crime category, specific targets have been set for the number of arrests. At the same time the police hope to reduce by 20 percent the number of cases withdrawn in the region's courts due to incomplete police investigations. This approach makes maximum use of police manpower and resources and appears to offer the prospect of effective action against at least the most prevalent crimes in the region. 

But there can be no long-lasting solution to the scourge of crime while the two other legs of the criminal justice system - the courts and Correctional Services - remain seriously handicapped by a lack of funds and manpower. This week the Department of Justice warned that it might have to limit its activities because of a critical lack of staff and funding, and the premature release of prisoners points to chronic overcrowding and staff shortages in the country's prisons. These problems will have to be addressed urgently and purposefully as a logical extension of the national crime strategy now being put into effect by the police.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Desire Samaai: all for the love of the dance


BYLINE: Gill Lord, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Cape Town - On meeting Desire Samaai, soloist and principal dancer with the Cape Town City Ballet, people invariably ask "but what do you really do? Just dance?"

"So then I tell them what my working day is like, from start to finish," says this petite professional.

It's not an easy day, either. If the company isn't performing, they do class from 10am until 6pm, and that's hard physical work in itself. If they are performing, they work and rehearse until it's time to go to the Nico to get ready for the evening's performance. 

They do all their make-up and accessories themselves, then it's curtain up at 8pm, perform until 10.20pm, and after that they put all their costumes away safely for the next day. Only then can they take their aching bodies home to rest.

The life of a professional ballet dancer is extremely demanding. Like sportsmen, they have to be in peak physical condition all the time. It's a rigorous and exacting discipline, where perfection is the goal. Besides mastering the difficult technique of classical dance, they also have to learn to act, as their expression and interpretation of their roles is all important.

Desire Samaai is the first dancer in the Cape Town City Ballet company to be adopted. It's called the Adopt-a-Dancer campaign, and the idea is to get a business to sponsor pointe shoes for the women dancers. Liz McGrath, owner of The Cellars Hohenort and The Plettenberg hotels, was the first to take up the challenge, sponsoring Desire's pointe shoes for a year by donating R6 000.

Desire hopes it will set the ball rolling.

"Shoes are the most important things that a lady dancer needs. A dud pair can make or break a performance. A huge part of City Ballet's money goes towards shoes. We get 24 pairs per annum, which is two a month. It's quite shocking, really, as overseas girls get 10 or 12 pairs a month!

"Bear in mind that some roles can take a pair a performance," she adds.

Desire was born in Paarl and matriculated at the Klein Nederburg Senior Secondary School. She started dancing at the age of 8 and joined the UCT Ballet School after matric. Originally, she had planned to be a ballet teacher, but auditioned for Capab Ballet (now Cape Town City Ballet) and was accepted. She has been with the company since 1989.

"I'm not sure what decided me to dance," she says. "I guess I just kept going, inspired by performances I saw and by my teachers."

Her family initially felt that teaching would be a more secure profession - a career in the performing arts is a risk, and they felt that a dancer's performing life is very short.

"We are plagued by injury," Desire points out, "and because our performing life is over quite soon, we're all forced to look at something else in the long term. Also, it's not a very lucrative profession in this country."

At the moment, Desire is a rising star in the City Ballet company, and it's probably quite a while before she'll have to consider doing anything else.

"The reason I enjoy dance so much is the feeling of achievement it gives me. As a dancer, no matter who or how good you are, you'll never achieve perfection, you can only try your best and start each day all over again."

Desire is satisfied with her career here. She's not harbouring ambitions to dance overseas, she believes that it's a bit late in her career, and frankly thinks she's too short, anyhow.

"Most overseas companies like dancers taller than me. I'm 5ft 2inches, and the French companies start at 5ft 6 inches. Also, I'm quite old for a dancer - I'm 27."

It's a worrying time for professional dancers now. If private sponsorship is not forthcoming, the Cape Town City Ballet may be forced to close its doors.

"It's so important that we get sponsorship. If only people realised how important private funding is. We can't not have a ballet company in Cape Town. We have the audiences. If the government allowed business tax relief for sponsorships to the arts it would make it easier, too."

To take part in the Cape Town City Ballet Adopt A Dancer campaign, the company can be reached on tel 689 4346.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Big business gets stuck into crime war


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - A high-powered Business Against Crime initiative, spurred in part by the Olympic bid, is to be launched in Cape Town today.

The BAC initiative will effectively channel private sector expertise and resources into the anti-crime drive, and is likely to enlist support from all key sectors of the province's economy.

If it follows the pattern established elsewhere, a four-pronged strategy will cover short and long-term objectives - fighting crime; researching and advising the Government on legislative measures; developing initiatives to secure economic upliftment; and steps to achieve community rehabilitation. 

Today's launch will be attended by Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi, and his Western Cape counterpart, Gerald Morkel.

A Who's Who of prominent city business executives, as well as top city and provincial government officials, will serve on the BAC board. Bid Company chief executive Chris Ball will also be a member of the board.

Crime was highlighted by the International Olympic Committee in March as one of several key concerns about Cape Town's bid.

Although individual IOC members have indicated that they do not consider crime an impediment to the city's Olympic hopes, the bid team has sought to use the Games project to promote strategies aimed at improving security and curbing crime.

John Pemberthy, co-ordinator of the bid team's security task group, and a key figure in the BAC project, said success in fighting crime would depend on measurable strategies to boost policing as well as to tackle the causes of crime.

Highlighting the benefits of business-backed initiatives, he noted: "These are not people who stand on ceremony. They want things done. They ask two things: what's to be done, and when? Their role will be to identify practical steps and find the resources to achieve them."

Mr Pemberthy added: "The bid, the police and the business sector have joined hands to work together.

"Law enforcement will always be the responsibility of the police, but they need help."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - General;
IOC men impressed by Cape Town's Bid


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - International Olympic Committee visitors from France and Switzerland left the city today with a "very positive impression" and certainty about Cape Town's capacity to organise a technically good, secure Games in 2004.

But they made it clear that hosting the Games was an awesome challenge that meant "everyone has to pull in the same direction". Nevertheless, their overall impression was "fantastic".

"This could be a good Olympic city," said French IOC member and chief executive of the Tour de France, Jean-Claude Killy, who also spoke on behalf of his Swiss counterpart, Rene Fasel.

Both Mr Killy and Mr Fasel - who is also president of the International Ice Hockey Federation - became IOC members in 1995.

Mr Killy noted the "professionalism" in the bid team and that the proposal was "compact" and "makes sense, technically".

"We came with two concerns," he said. "We wanted to be reassured about your capacity to organise the games and we wanted to be assured that the games would be well secured, that there would be security.

"And, yes, absolutely, those conditions have been met."

He added: "We know there are problems, but what country does not have problems today?"

Asked if Africa's exclusion from hosting the Games so far was a significant factor, Mr Killy replied: "The Olympics is well represented throughout the world. But I think it is important that nobody is left out."

He added: "I expected this city to be exactly what I saw in the Bid Book. But the beauty is absolutely breathtaking. We flew over Cape Point, and it is absolutely magnificent."

Sports - General;
Games will mark Africa's recovery - Mbeki


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

Cape Town - Deputy President Thabo Mbeki says holding the 2004 Olympic Games in Cape Town will signal that the world has agreed the next century will be African.

Such a decision, Mr Mbeki said during his budget speech to the National Assembly yesterday, "will mark the recovery of our continent from an experience of many centuries, some of the distinguishing features of which have been the slave trade, colonial domination and exploitation, apartheid, bad African governance and the identification of what is bad with the colour black".

Africa News


June 11, 1997


South Africa;
Stanfield tax shock


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes and Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - Attempts by gang leader Colin Stanfield to avoid tax evasion charges, by taking advantage of the Government's tax amnesty, have failed after he allegedly under-declared his income to the Receiver of Revenue.

Last year Western Cape Attorney-General Frank Kahn said he would use the "Capone option" to bust drug dealers for tax evasion. At the time he was investigating charges against Mr Stanfield for allegedly owing the revenue services R10-million. 

The Government's amnesty policy, which allowed defaulters to register as taxpayers without being prosecuted, raised the possibility that people like Mr Stanfield would escape prosecution.

Now commercial crime unit detectives are investigating charges of fraud and tax evasion against Mr Stanfield, who could end up like notorious American mobster "Scarface" Al Capone, who was jailed on tax evasion charges during Prohibition in the 1930s after the authorities failed to make other charges stick against him.

Informed police sources say Mr Stanfield, who is facing drug-dealing charges in connection with a Mandrax bust which involved 87 000 tablets, is believed to have only declared R11-million of his R17-million assets to the Receiver of Revenue.

Mr Stanfield, 42, had not been asked to plead on allegations of dealing in Mandrax in connection with the bust in Beaufort West and is on R500 000 bail. He is expected to appear in court in August.

If Mr Stanfield has made a full declaration of all his assets it will be almost impossible for the the authorities to pursue the "Capone option".

The investigating officer for the commercial crime unit, Clayton Thomopoulos, said this new investigation was initiated after a complaint of fraud, alternatively contravening section 104 of the Income Tax Act, and a contravention of the Value Added Tax Act, were received from the SARS.

"We are in the process of verifying the allegations against Mr Stanfield and because the matter is sub judice, I cannot furnish more information regarding the investigation," Sgt Thomopoulos said.

He said the investigation was nearing completion, after which the docket would be sent to Mr Kahn's office for a decision whether to prosecute.

Mr Stanfield's lawyer, Reuben Liddell, said he was aware of the investigations, but as the matter had not yet been contested in court, he could not comment.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


275 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Daimler Benz clinches Mpumalanga airport deal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Nelspruit - Daimler Benz and Mpumalanga's provincial government is scheduled to enter "highly sensitive" negotiations today (Wednesday) to thrash out the specifics of a R300-million international airport near Hazyview, after Premier Mathews Phosa reached a principled agreement with Daimler Benz executives at a meeting in Germany on Tuesday.

The negotiations, which will take place in South Africa, are aimed at ensuring that Daimler Benz agrees to upgrade Nelspruit's municipal airport in a linked development and also allows for more local participation in the Hazyview scheme. 

"We want to ensure that local residents really benefit both through shareholding and in the development itself. Because the airport is 40km from Nelspruit, the existing municipal airport needs to be upgraded to act as a shuttle terminal," explained Phosa's spokesman, Oupa Pilane. Pilane refused to comment on what the announcement means for a competing airport development at Primkop near Nelspruit.

Mpumalanga currently has no international airports and has only been granted license to approve one by national aviation authorities.

Although Primkop is nearer the provincial capital at Nelspruit, Hazyview is regarded as better suited for tourism and fruit exports.

The Hazyview project has been dubbed the Kruger Park International Airport.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 11, 1997


South Africa;
Sadtu asks Phosa to investigate shortage of classes


BYLINE: Lucky Ngomane, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nelspruit - The South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) in Matsulu, near Nelspruit, has called on Mpumalanga premier, Mathews Phosa, to investigate a delay in classroom provision at local schools.

Sadtu executive secretary in Matsulu, Lindiwe Sibiya, said the Department of Education had promised in 1994 to build extra classrooms at Tikhontele High School within two weeks.

"That was three years ago, and now we are faced with a problem where pupils can't attend the required number of periods per week, because of a shortage of classrooms," Sibiya said. 

She said some pupils no longer wanted to pay the same schools fees as others, as not all pupils were receiving the same number of lessons.

At the moment, teachers work a full day from 7am to 4pm, giving morning as well as afternoon classes in an attempt to give all Grades their required lesson time.

Dr CG Shube, Nelspruit district manager for education, said on Tuesday he remembered visiting Tikhontele High School three years ago, but could not remember promising to build additional classrooms.

"How can a person promise to build additional classrooms within two weeks when there are department procedures that have to be followed?" he said.

According to Nkululeko circuit manager, Mrs Hlophe, under whose jurisdiction Tikhontele High School falls, the building of additional structures takes time.

"First, there's a priority list on which things are prioritised," Mrs Hlophe said.

"If there is a need to build a structure, a procedure must be followed, and if you don't know the procedure, you must ask," she said.

She said building projects had to be checked and re-checked by various offices before being approved, and that it first had to be determined whether there were enough funds to embark on such projects.

"Even if there is no money, and you are on the priority list, then you know you will be the first to be considered by the department when funds do become available," she explained. .
