South Africa;
Seven jail breaks across Mpumalanga


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MIDDELBURG - Seven prisoners escaped from police cells across Mpumalanga on Monday, bringing the total number of jail breaks to 29 over two weeks.

Police said James Twala (26) and Aaron Dlamini (28) who had been sentenced to Barberton maximum prison for murder, escaped from the Middelburg court cells on Monday. 

When police checked the cells, they found only the prisoners' prison- issue clothing and ankle- and handcuffs lying on the cell floor.

Also on Monday, five prisoners escaped from the police holding cells at Elukwatini, near Ermelo.

The prison bars had been sawn through with a hacksaw.

Over the weekend, three prisoners escaped from the Sundra police cells, and another five escaped while being transported between the Dennilton police station and Paxton prison in Witbank.

Another 11 prisoners escaped from the Marble Hall police station after assaulting a police officer and stealing his service pistol. .

South Africa;
Mpumalanga police launch anti-corruption toll free number


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

MIDDELBURG - Mpumalanga police have established their own anti- corruption toll free number in an effort to combat crime in the province. 

The toll free number is manned during the week between 7:30am and 4pm, while an answering machine would record urgent information after hours.

Police appeal to the public to report corruption or criminal activities to the number.

Callers may remain anonymous.

The toll free number is 0800 11 43 69.

In case of an emergency, the national crime stop number 0800 11 12 13 can still be used. .

279 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


South Africa;
Under-funding turning Mpumalanga into a 'banana republic'


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi & Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's finance MEC Jacques Modipane warned the provincial legislature on Tuesday that his R92-million budget for the 1997/98 fiscal year was only enough to pay his staff their salaries and not enough to equip them to actually work effectively.

Insisting that the stringent financial constraints placed on the provincial government by national planners were proving to be counter- productive, Modipane said that he needed at least another R18-million to deliver effective services.

"We run the risk of creating a banana republic by under-funding our departments and forcing up to five officials to share the same office. The situation is completely unproductive and inefficient," he said. 

Modipane also stressed that while his budget for the current fiscal year was theoretically R92-million he actually only had R72-million for core services after "earmarked funds" for centralised services such as a the provincial service commission, a youth commission and religious desk were subtracted.

"These items total 20,3%, or R18,8-million of my entire budget but gives outsiders the impression that that we receive a far higher allocation than we actually do," he explained.

Besides calling for additional funding for a better and "healthier" working environment for his staff, Modipane also said that the department needed funds for new furniture, computers and "suitable vehicles".

Conceding that fully owned Government vehicles were costly because staff tended to abuse them and the province had to cover all maintenance and fuel costs, Modipane said that Mpumalanga was considering boosting its vehicle subsidy scheme to combat these costs.

"When officials own or even partly own the vehicles they have to use for work, they tend to look after them better than if they were state owned and also are obliged to cover the maintenance and some of the fuel expenses themselves," he said.

He also confirmed that an internal audit had been launched to investigate the control measures currently being used to manage state vehicles and warned that any officials found guilty of fraud or of abusing the system would be prosecuted.

Amongst the most common abuses were fraudulent transactions on government petrol cards and the supposed theft of government vehicles.

"This happens when officials report their state vehicle as stolen to the police but that have actually sold the thing illegally," said Modipane.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Simulambo ready to revamp Zambian soccer


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - FORMER national team captain, Jani Simulambo, wants to come back to Zambia and help redeem the shattered image of Zambian soccer.

Simulambo, currently coaching the Swaziland national team, said he was greatly disturbed by Zambia's 0-3 loss to South Africa and is ready to help the national team in what ever capacity. 

"This is terrible...I am ready to come back home and help in what ever way," Simulambo said in an interview on Sunday.

He said South Africa football is streets behind Zambia's and for Zambia to go down 0-3 to Bafana Bafana is an indication that all is not well in Zambian football.

"Something is definitely wrong somewhere and it requires all of us Zambians who have got something to offer to sit down and find out where we have gone wrong," the former Green Buffaloes hardman noted.

He was supported by former national team and Power Dynamo's striker, Bonnie Muma, who is currently coaching a South African first division side, Western Platt Rangers.

"We taught South Africa how to play football and there is no way they should be beating us today," Muma who trekked to South Africa in 1988 along with Roan United coach, Fighton Simukonda and John Mofya.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Sad night for Zambian fans


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - IT was surly Sunday night for Chipolopolo loyalists who travelled to Johannesburg, South Africa, after Zambia was humiliated via a 3-0 drubbing by South Africa's Bafana Bafana.

A planned victory party at the Chez Nthemba night club in the sprawling Hillbrow suburb organised by the Zambia-South Africa Friendship Association turned into a rather sad and somewhat despicable spectacle reminiscent of a funeral gathering.

Scores of disconsolate fans hurdled together, pondering what had gone wrong. 

"This is a massacre," cried Charity Akakandelwa, "I never thought a day would come when Zambian would lose by such a big margin."

Although some fans took to the dance floor and the laughter levels were high in some cases, the pain was evident every where.

Chipolopolo fan club chairman, Elijah Chisanga, was a forlorn figure as he flopped into settee and drowned his sorrows in steins of Castle lager.

"This is a disaster," he lamented, "I will now find it very difficult to mobilize fans to go and cheer our team during away games."

Lusaka Province deputy minister Christopher Chawinga who, quite evidently had knocked back one too many, tried in vain to assuage the disconsolate fans.

"Even if we have lost we should rally behind our boys," Chawinga said, "let's us not blame the coach or the players. The better team carried the day."

Prominent Lusaka lawyer Mumba Kapumpa, however, had the solution to the unfolding nightmare.

"Let us just enjoy ourselves and open a new chapter," Kapumpa said as he tossed bones to the sounds of Wenge Musica.

For some fans, however, it was double tragedy as the bus in which they had travelled in was burgled and their property, including passports, stolen after it was parked metres away from the Chez Nthemba night club.

At least three people-Maureen Ngombo, David Mulanda and Newton Makukula-confirmed losing their property.

"I have lost everything, including my passport," Cried Ngombo, "I don't know how I will travel back home."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: FAZ Polls On


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - AFTER last Sunday's burial of Zambia's hopes of qualifying for the France '98 World Cup finals, all roads now lead to Kabwe to elect leaders who will guide the squad for the African championship in Burkina Faso next year.

Zambia Tender Board boss Teddy Mulonga who is also super league, Lusaka City Council (LCC) trustee has rejuvenated his attempt to get to Anchor House for the highest office.

Mulonga's campaign coordinator Fisho Mwale, a patron at LCC is optimistic the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) electoral regulations would not bar Mulonga from the race on June 28. 

The FAZ electrol regulations bars Mulonga because his nominations papers were signed by Zanaco treasurer Collins Shamutete when the requirement says the club chairman or his secretary are supposed to endorse while the vice-chairman could only sign in the absence of the chairman with an accompanying letter.

Mwale who is also Lusaka City mayor, however, said as far as LCC was concerned Shamutete was also the vice-chairman and was therefore vested with powers by his club to second a candidate.

Mwale said the fact that he has not received any communication from the association over the impending disqualification of Mulonga goes to show that his nomination was acknowledged and valid.

"We have not been informed at all by FAZ that our candidate has been disqualified," Mwale said in an interview Monday. "Mr. Mulonga is standing in his own right as a man who has been in football for the past 24 years and we shall not demean ourselves by getting involved in smear campaigns."

Mwale who travelled to South Africa to watch the Zambian side go down to Bafana Bafana by 3-0 said the soccer standards in the country would remain mediocre if the leadership is not changed in the coming FAZ elections.

"The Zambia national team will remain second best in the region if we don't put the people with a vision of improving the sport," Mwale said.

If FAZ relax the regulations against Mulonga, the contention will be among former FAZ general secretary Herman Mphashi and the incumbent president Micheal who has since accepted blame for Zambia's 'dark Sunday'.

LANGUAGE: English

283 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
Councils' Finances (Editorial)


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - One of the most popular decisions which came with independence was the discontinuance of the hated Poll Tax and the Pass Book system(Chitupa).

But then more than the Poll Tax and Pass Book went with that decision. The only principle and basis for effective financing of local government and one that actually worked efficiently in this country went with it.

During the last constitutional review exercise, some petitioners suggested the re-institution of the "native authority" system. In what they did not state explicitly they were very right. 

That system, in retrospect, now appears to have been efficient. But that is not because of its name. It is simply because it encompassed the principle that was destroyed in the "struggle for independence" that of giving local authorities powers to levy and spend revenue from local taxes in the areas where such monies are collected.

The bulk of the money that the hated District Commissioners (DCs) collected under the Poll Tax system was in fact spent in the districts where it was raised. Very little of it was passed on to Lusaka. Independence seemed to reverse that. Local authorities now started looking to Lusaka for money and that was the beginning of the end for local government.

They lost financial autonomy and this system has succeeded in destroying local government altogether. If it is not reversed there is absolutely no chance that councils will be revived. They will go under and many of them are already in state of effective voluntary liquidation.

They need greater access to all revenue raised in their own areas. Such monies should not all go to Lusaka and only later be recycled in dribs and drabs back to the source. This has killed the councils because the money they get from Lusaka is rarely what they need to put them on an even keel, particularly the bigger ones.

Council financial problems would not of course be wiped out because some are quite small and there is little activity in their areas. Still, it would allow for some financial autonomy and reduce government subsidies in a number of cases.

Local councils regardless of size have identical problems today. Throughout the country they are broke and are unable to deliver public services or meet basic financial obligations.

Every once in a while the central government releases a few millions to select, more crippled councils. Such money is usually enough only to cover salaries of workers who remain unpaid, many times, for months.

These days too they are paid mainly for being on the payroll. They are no longer able to do any real work because of the larger financial problems councils face.

This has rapidly transformed most councils into nothing more than agencies for the payment of salaries.

Delivery of services, to the communities which are the primary function of councils has ground to halt and the urban environment, in particular, is becoming progressively more unlivable. It now requires only a few more years before all the cities and towns are transformed into shanty compounds.

It is a truly frightening scenario and the country is threatened with regression to the dark ages.

It is time for bold decisions that will serve this vital arm of the government. Burying heads in the sand will not do.

Councils must be allowed greater and direct access to at least a reasonable portion of all taxes levied in their areas.

The present system where the Central government has virtually all the access will only sink the councils further into financial woes.

There appears to be no way of escaping giving councils greater access to revenues raised in their areas.

It is a system that worked well once before and without something along those lines councils will collapse one by one under the weight of debts and other financial problems.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
UNESCO donates video van to ZIS


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The concentration of news media organisations in urban and peri-urban areas has created a critical shortage of information among the rural dwellers, said information and broadcasting deputy minister Ernest Mwansa yesterday.

Mwansa, receiving a video van on behalf of Zambia Information Services (ZIS) from United Nations Education and Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), said rural areas are information starved. 

"Video vans are good alternatives for visual information for rural people who do not have access to television because ZNBC (Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation) fails to reach all the corners of the our country," Mwansa said. " This has been compounded by the fact that national newspapers have concentrated in urban areas dotted along the line of rail."

Mwansa said the UNESCO donation was appropriate and would help the government in social mobilisation as well as communicating with rural masses on its various programmes.

He assured UNESCO that the van, a Land Rover Discovery, equipped with loudspeakers would be utilised for the benefit of the rural communities.

And UNESCO country representative, Lusite Deware, said her organisation was happy to contribute in the area of information because it was a crucial sector.

June 11, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Money laundering increases in Africa


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - CitiBank's New York financial institutions vice-president, Maurice Menasche, yesterday advised Commonwealth countries and all African governments to come up with necessary legislation to curb money laundering.

Menasche, presenting a lecture on money laundering at the Bank of Zambia yesterday, said money laundering was on the rise in Africa and there was need to put in place relevant laws to fight it.

Menasche advised bankers to keep the basic rule of good banking which he said demanded knowledge of clients. 

Menasche is on a tour of 15 African countries in CitiBank's efforts to enlighten bankers on the continent on money laundering.

Bank of Zambia's director of bank supervision, Jonathan Muke, commenting on money laundering in the country in an interview yesterday, said he was hopeful that appropriate legislation would soon be tabled in the House.

"We are happy that the Ministry of Home Affairs has already shown commitment towards ensuring that there is adequate legislation against the activity," Muke said. "We expect the draft act to be debated when Parliament resumes as this will help address the problem."

Although there were no ready figures on money laundering in Zambia, Muke said there was information that it was rife, especially with the rise of drug trafficking activities in the country.

"It is of great concern that currently we have no legislation against laundering and we only hope that Parliament can quickly enact the law," Muke said.

CitiBank Zambia Limited managing director, Sanjeev Anand, in an interview yesterday, appreciated the commitment shown by the government.

As long as we continue dragging the formulation of the law against money laundering, we will just be paying lip service to the problem," Anand said.

"We should realise that its has become widely accepted that Zambia has become a transit point for drug trafficking and it is through such activities that laundering is place."

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
UNZA workers strike


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda and Mike Wasa, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia (UNZA) workers yesterday went on strike and locked up the offices of vice-chancellor Andrew Siwela and other nine top administrators.

The striking workers appealed to President Frederick Chiluba to immediately remove vice-chancellor Siwela and some of his senior officers for alleged maladministration.

The workers resolved to stage the strike action during a meeting held yesterday to address their grievances after the non-appearance of a representative from the administration. 

They had earlier called for the UNZA council chairman, Dr. Mashekwa Nalumango, to represent the administration to explain why he had failed to dismiss vice chancellor Siwela and some senior members of his administration even after an Auditor General's report which incriminated them in financial irregularities.

The workers urged President Chiluba to intervene in the matter and take a political decision to dismiss the current management for financial mismanagement and failing to address the workers welfare.

The furious workers also called for the dissolution of the University of Zambia Council for " failing to take remedial measures in the face of rampant irregularities".

Among the resolutions made at the meeting were to immediately go on strike, lock up the administration officers and block senior management staff from withdrawing money at any of UNZA's 48 bank accounts.

The resolutions were made after a lengthy meeting which started at 09:00 hours yesterday and went on until later in the afternoon and was addressed by all the workers' representative bodies - UNZA Lecturers and Researchers Union, UNZA Workers Union and UNZA Professional Staff Association.

The meeting also resolved that until President Chiluba removed the "rot" no senior management official would be allowed to "get near their offices".

And in a letter to President Chiluba, the workers demanded for the immediate removal of the current UNZA administration.

"We recognise that you may have no legal authority in the University Act to intervene in the affairs of the University," the letter read in part, "but we also note that the financial mismanagement and incompetence of management at UNZA are not issues about legalities but moral standards for the safety of public resources."

They singled out the vice-chancellor, the registrar and the bursar, including their deputies, as having been behind the mismanagement of the institution.

But UNZA registrar, Michael Tandeo, reacting to the workers' action in a press statement, said administrative staff were not aware of yesterday's meeting.

Tandeo charged that the workers' action was a ploy to bar UNZA administrators from presenting their submissions to the ongoing UNZA and Copperbelt University Commission of Inquiry.

"The events of Tuesday 10th June (yesterday) are clearly part of a plan to prevent management from making its submission on Wednesday June 11 to counteract the many unsubstantiated allegations and distortions that have characterised the submissions from staff of the University of Zambia," Tandeo's statement read in part.

He also accused the workers' representatives of divulging confidential information given out by the Auditor General to the University Council on which they were members.

"It is highly irresponsible and unethical of the workers' representatives on the Council to have made the confidential verbal brief by the Auditor General a subject of a public meeting clearly intended to arouse workers emotions and to disrupt the work of the University," Tandeo said, urging all workers to resume work immediately.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Chamber to host investment fora


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Eastern Province chambers of commerce and industry is to host investment fora next month as part of its efforts to increase awareness of the investment potential of the province.

Chairman Mr Idris Ugrader said yesterday, that the fora would be held in the province to afford businessmen there a chance to meet investors and representatives of various organisations. 

The chamber would invite various organisations and potential investors to attend the meetings to give them an opportunity to see for themselves the work the chambers were making to develop the province.

"We realise that there is stiff competition in all areas of the country to attract investments and that is why we want to bring investors here." he said.

He said that the chambers had come up with four main areas in the province that needed massive investments to reach their full potential and would concentrate on these areas during the fora.

He listed some of the areas as tourism, small scale mining in aquamarine and other precious and semi precious stones which had been underutilised for a long time.

Other areas that the meeting would look at include agriculture commercial and industrial concerns that had been on the decline for many years.

Mr Ugrader also said the second Zambia-Malawi trade exposition would take place in Malawi later this year.

The chambers hoped the exposition would become a permanent feature because it would boost trade and exports between businessmen from the two countries.

The last exposition that had been held in Chipata last year had been a success and had opened opportunities for a number of businessmen from the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambia's Chilanga seeks production cash


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lusaka - Chilanga Cement Plc is in dire need of $50m to double its present production capacity of 350,000 tonnes a year in anticipation of high demand for cement by ZCCM and Gecamine of Congo-Kinshasa in the next four years.

A report in the latest issue of Investec Securities obtained by the Times in Lusaka yesterday says whereas at present ZCCM orders 12,000 tonnes of cement a year from Chilanga Cement, the figure is expected to rise to more than 500,000 tonnes within four years.

Demand for cement is further expected to increase with the rehabilitation of the Congolese copper mines in the former Zaire and the report says that Chilanga Cement will fail to meet the demand from the two mining provinces of Zambia and Congo. 

For Chilanga to meet this demand the company would have to increase its capacity by doubling production, a doubtful prospect at present but which might be embarked upon by the year 2002.

In the meantime, shortages of cement within the Southern African region will become pronounced that even South African companies will find huge new potential markets.

"The case for investing in new capacity is strong, but the funding will be difficult. Chilanga's management estimates that it will cost $50m to double capacity. This does not seem to be too daunting a prospect except that it would have to be done off Chilanga's capital base.

"At K105 a share, it has a market capitalisation of just $16m. Hence it will have to raise over three times its existing worth to proceed with its expansion," the report says.

The major shareholder, Commonwealth Development Corporation (CDC) with 50 per cent, is unlikely to be able to support an equity raising of that size.

The domestic money markets are too small and too short-term to provide more than token amounts of capital. Therefore, Chilanga must look off-shore.

To do this there must be a properly marketed international offering while the balance could be sourced off-shore and a combination of a direct investment from a strategic partner.

"All this would require the cooperation of the CDC. Unfortunately, this may not be forthcoming. The CDC seems to be obsessed with a need to control its investments even when it does so to the detriment of their perfromance.

"Chilanga has already missed the most favourable period to invest because of the CDC's reluctance to countenance its capex plans. We are also aware of at least one key strategic deal that has been vetoed by the CDC," the report says.

It warns that any further delay would be disastrous as the long-term prospects are astonishing. The nature of the host rock encountered in the copper mines is such that it needs total support to prevent roof falls.

The most effective solution is cemented backfill. This requires that roughly three tonnes of cement is used to produce one tonne of copper. It is expected that copper production in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Zambia will reach 500,000 tonnes a year within 10 years.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


289 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian exports to US duty free


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian exports to the US will for the firs t time enjoy duty free treatment, the Office of the US Trade Representative has said.

The latest issue of Washington Line, a publication of the American Embassy released in Lusaka on Monday said the U S Generalised Systems of Preferences (GSP) programme had given Zambian goods easy access into the American market.

The US will allow 1,783 products from the reprieved countries to be imported duty-free. 

The move would impact on 30 sub-Saharan African states which belong to the world's 38 poorest nations.

"In addition to Zambia and 29 other least developing countries in sub-Saharan Africa, the other countries newly eligible for the additional trade benefits under the programme include Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Yemen, Cambodia, Tuvalu, Vanuatu and Kiribati," the report said.

Though GSP technically expired at the end of last month, the U S administration was seeking a multi-year renewal of the programme, which would provide benefits retroactively to the countries involved.

"The administration is committed to building strong trade partnerships with sub-Saharan Africa's rapidly growing and reforming economies, relationships which will benefit both Africans and Americans.

"In an increasingly competitive global economy, the U S cannot afford to neglect a largely untapped market of some 600 million-plus people and the world cannot afford to see a vast region marginalised," Charlene Barshefsky, U S Trade Representative said.

Only 0.3 per cent, about $588 million came from the sub-Saharan countries last year, while 64 per cent of total GSP imports come from Asian beneficiaries.

Under the competitive need limits provision, an individual beneficiary country can lose duty-free access for a GSP product if the country accounts for more than 50 per cent of total U S imports.

A country loses the facility also by having exported more than $75 million worth of the product to the U S in 1996.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - General;
Motor rally in $15,000 boost


BYLINE: Okechukwu Nwankwo, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The 1997 Castrol-Spectra International rally yesterday got a $15,000 boost from the main sponsors, Spectra Oil Corporation, for the the rally's preparations.

Making the donation to Zambia Motor Sport Association (ZMSA) in Lusaka, Spectra managing director Yuyi Lishomwa said the amount was an initial contribution to the rally which revs off next month. 

Lishomwa, whose company distributes Castrol products in Zambia, said ZMSA had demonstrated its ability to promote very well organised events under unfavourable financial conditions.

The donation was an initial of the K30m Castrol, the largest lubricant dealers in the world, pledged last month to be the main sponsors of the Zambia international rally for the next two years.

ZMSA president Lee-Ann Singh received the donation and said she was grateful for the financial support her association was getting. She assured the sponsors all the money would be put to good use.

ZMSA treasurer Aaron Chungu, who unveiled the K100m budget for the rally, said there was competition in bidding for the sponsorship but they picked Castrol because of its long-term commitment.

Lee-Ann said about 25 drivers, most of whom would come from Zambia, were expected in the 1000km rally.It has also attracted drivers from Uganda, South Africa and Kenya. The defending champion is Mobil sponsored Satwant Singh. The rally starts on July 4 to July 7.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

June 11, 1997


Sports - General;
ZRFU gets coach


BYLINE: Martin Musunka, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Rugby Football Union (ZRFU) has made steps to engage a full-time coach.

ZRFU president Peter Manda confirmed at the weekend that Zimbabwean trainer Temba Mliswa would be appointed coach on a full-time scale. 

He said Mliswa would be involved in, among other national programmes, helping all the clubs in drilling their players.

The Zambian-born Mliswa has already offered himself in shaping up players in all the clubs that are affiliated to the ZRFU.

Mliswa who was invited to Zambia by the union, Manda said, would be at the disposal of all the ZRFU clubs who should utilise him during their training sessions.

"The idea to bring in Temba is well intended. He is available and his role would entail seeing to it that rugby was being developed and all the clubs are free to invite him anytime," Manda said.

But some clubs have expressed reservations on the appointment.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nyirenda transfer wrangle erupts


BYLINE: Yuyo Kambikambi, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - Nchanga Rangers striker Wedson Nyirenda is at the centre of a 15,000 rand transfer cash wrangle allegedly owed to South African club Hellenic.

Hellenic are demanding a down payment of the 15,000 rand from Rangers who they also accuse of fielding Nyirenda illegally.

The wrangle is as a result of Nyirenda's transfer from Hellenic then to Kaiser Chiefs before the player finally found a home at Rangers. 

Nyirenda transferred from Hellenic to Kaiser Chiefs for 45,000 rand but Chiefs only made a payment of 30,000 rand, defaulting by 15,000 rand.

But since Nyirenda moved to Rangers, Hellenic feel the FAZ Premier Division side should settle the oustanding amount.

Hellenic secretary Collin Gie has written to FAZ, seeking to recover 15,000 rand from Rangers.

In his letter to FAZ dated May 25, Gie claimed that despite writing to FAZ, no help has been forthcoming.

Hellenic have warned that if the matter remained unresolved, they would take legal action to recover the money.

Rangers secretary Friday Silavwe said in Chingola executive committee was working on the matter and were waiting correspondence from Hellenic.

Silavwe said there was a bit of complications in the Nyirenda issue and the club had tried to communicate with the South Africans but had no response from them, reports Melody Mwala.

"We have tried to communicate with Hellenic many times but they have not been responding, making things more complicated," Said Silavwe.

Nyirenda who joined Rangers last season as a guest player has not been playing this season.

Silavwe said as far as Rangers were concerned there was nothing wrong with Nyirenda featuring in local games.

"Nyirenda can feature in local games and not international games. He played in the league last season while he has not been featuring in any international games we have played this year," Silavwe said.

And FAZ general secretary Julio Chiluba denied having seen any letter from Hellenic and said the matter was supposed to be settled by the two clubs.

Chiluba said in Lusaka that "I think Hellenic and Rangers are dealing with this matter because we only deal with associations and unless the South African Football Association steps in, that is when we will also get involved."


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


293 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
CSUZ cry foul over delinkage


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - The Civil Servants Union of Zambia (CSUZ) has said the statutory instrument signed last Friday on the delinkage of Health Management Boards (HMB) from Government is anomalous.

The union has demanded for an immediate meeting with Government to correct the anomalies and warned of industrial unrest if the issue was not resolved quickly.

CSUZ general secretary Japhet Moonde said in a statement jointly signed by national chairman Leonard Hikaumba that it was illegal to transfer workers without them knowing their conditions of service or understanding the nature of the transfer. 

Mr Moonde said the statutory instrument signed by Health Minister Katele Kalumba contradicted section 35 of the Laws of Zambia which stated that before a worker could sign a contract of transfer, he should first understand the nature of the transaction and his consent should not be obtained by coercion or undue influence.

"Government has, however, disregarded all this and in fact workers do not even know the conditions of service under management boards and have not fully understood the nature of the transaction," he said.

He said the instrument purported that transferred workers would continue drawing salaries from Government until January next year and yet the contracts were expected to be signed by August 1, which meant that the boards were broke and could not sustain themselves.

The instrument did not make any provision for those to be rejected by the boards and was silent on their severance packages.

The pensions contributions would also be inconsistent with Public Service Pensions Act since contributions would be paid despite signing new contracts.

"It is because of such glaring anomalies that CSUZ has repeatedly called on government to sit down with all concerned parties and jointly redress these anomalies for the good of the workers as well as for the success of the reform programme.

"It is for this reason that we will, after making all necessary consultations with our members, reserve the right to take measures that will serve to speak to Government that enough is enough," he said.

Dr Kalumba announced at the weekend that after the final delinked of management boards on August 1, all workers would have to re-apply for their jobs and sign new contracts.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
Be self-reliant, pardoned prisoners told


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Prisons Fellowship of Zambia (PFZ) has advised newly- pardoned prisoners to exploit their potential through self-employment because the present economic environment does not allow for formal jobs.

Vice-chairman of PFZ Mathews Chikwanda told 28 prisoners, who included those pardoned in January, to be self-reliant because seeking employment would prove frustrating and they would be tempted to go back to their old ways. 

Rev Chikwanda said in Ndola this at a seminar organised for ex- prisoners on entrepreneurship.

He said companies in Zambia were downsizing through retrenchments and employment levels were slowly waning.

The hard economic times were felt by everyone and he warned former prisoners not to go back to their old ways to make ends meet.

The PFZ was concerned with the welfare of ex-convicts and wanted to make a change in their lives.

Most of the pardoned prisoners had been incarcerated for a number of years and many felt their time was up, but as far as potential was concerned, it was not too late.

Most of the ex-convicts at the seminar said they had undergone tailoring courses at Kabwe's Good Samaritan Centre but they were lacking capital to begin businesses.

They said they would not go back to crime as it never paid.

The course content of the seminar includes introduction to entrepreneurship, developing business ideas, business plans and hope for survival .

A total of 488 prisoners were released under presidential prerogative at the occasion of the last Africa Freedom Day in May, following an earlier 600 in January when President Chiluba opened the first session of the eighth National Assembly.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian bank says money laundering a menace


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - The Bank of Zambia (BOZ) yesterday called on Parliament to quickly pass a law against money laundering to safeguard Zambia from dirty money estimated in billions of dollars circulating globally.

BOZ registrar of banks Jonathan Muke said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday that Zambia risked being a major money laundering centre because of her liberalised banking system.

Mr Muke was speaking after a money laundering awareness seminar addressed by Citibank International vice-president Maurice Menasche who is on a tour of Zambia and Tanzania. 

Although there were no statistics to show the magnitude of the laundering problem in Zambia, the lavish life-styles of some citizens were a source of suspicion that they had joined cartels of money launderers.

"Zambia is vulnerable and can be used to launder the money because of her liberalised banking system. Dirty money can easily be brought into the country, cleaned and sent back to the owners," Mr Muke said.

Addressing the seminar held at the BOZ in Lusaka, Mr Menasche said Zambia should quickly legislate against money laundering with the rest of the world.

He said global statistics indicated that 90 per cent of the money changing hands without paying tax was associated with the scourge of drug trafficking.

Although Zambia had passed a series of laws against drug trafficking, there was need to legislate specifically against crimes like embezzlement, racketeering and illegal gambling.

Mr Menasche said: "It is estimated $1 trillion of illicit funds are circulating worldwide and between $400bn and $500bn of this is associated with the drug trade." The Mafia in the US, Italy, Russia, Bulgaria and Poland as well as the Japanese Yakuza, Asian Triads and South African drug cartels were involved in laundering and needed stiff laws to be checked.

He said there was need to open up banks to money laundering probes because launderers were also tightly connected to illegal arms trade, terrorism, corruption and political distabilisation.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambia Airlines' row rages


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The stand-off between Aero-Zambia and Kenya Airways over flight schedules and landing rights between the two countries has persisted despite Government call for the two airlines to arrange for an equitable sharing of business.

Aero-Zambia managing director, Youndewossen Mengistu, said in Lusaka yesterday that Kenya Airways has not cooperated with his firm in finding an amicable and lasting solution to their differences. 

Acting Communication and Transport Minister, Suresh Desai, on Friday said the controversial Kenya Airways flights to Lusaka would remain suspended until the two airlines agreed on an equitable mode of sharing passenger traffic.

"The two airlines have been asked to make arrangements for equitable sharing of passenger traffic. As long as these arrangements are not in place, the status remains the same," said Mr Desai.

Mr Mengistu explained that his firm would be meeting Government to present its case and offer suggestions following Kenya Airways' alleged uncooperative stance.

"We cannot comment much now lest we pre-empt ourselves. All we can say is that our friends are not being cooperative at all and we shall be informing Government accordingly," said Mr Mengistu.

He denied a June 9 story in the Daily Nation of Kenya that his firm and Kenya Airways have resolved their differences after an understanding reached between their governments.

"These reports are totally untrue as we are already not agreed," said Mr Mengistu.

Sources told the Times that President Chiluba last week met a Kenyan government delegation led by Transport and Communication minister, Wilson Ayah and ordered the lifting of suspensions of Kenya Airways flights.

Kenya Airways is said to be losing more than $25,000 per round trip following the row which was brewed after Kenya's request for further frequencies approved by Communications Deputy Minister Gilbert Mululu.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
Parties set 'detente' timetable


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian political parties which attended a two-day high- level inter-party meeting in Stockholm, Sweden, have resolved to begin dialogue between Government and major opposition parties within 21 days from yesterday.

The four parties, MMD, UNIP, National Party, and Agenda for Zambia, adopted and signed the agreement known as the Stromsborg statement at the close of the meeting yesterday.

In a statement released by the International Institute for Democratic and Electoral Assistance (IDEA) which organised the meeting, the parties agreed to allow the MMD to initiate the first inter-party meeting to establish the agenda and programme of action. 

The first meeting which would comprise all secretary generals of major political parties would be overseen by a facilitator from IDEA.

It was agreed that the new dialogue would focus on, among other things, questions about the design of the electoral process and ways of increasing the democratic capacity of institutions.

Also in attendance at the round table meeting were representatives of Sweden, Denmark, the European Commission, Finland, Germany, Ireland, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Britain, the United States, United Nations Development Fund (UNDP) and the World Bank.

Finance Minister Ronald Penza, who led the MMD delegation, said after the agreement was read out, "I am very excited by this event, the beginning of a dialogue to carry forward the process of democratisation.

This is a very good development and I appreciate very much the work of IDEA for facilitating this round table." And UNIP secretary-general Sebastian Zulu echoed Mr Penza's sentiments.

"I am very pleased with the outcome of this unique round table because the interest of the people in Zambia demands that there must be meaningful dialogue," Mr Zulu said.

IDEA secretary-general Bengt Save-Soderbergh said the breakthrough in the impasse on dialogue was due to the willingness of all political parties involved to talk to each other and demonstrated a real example of peaceful conflict resolution.

Inter-party meetings failed twice last year at the Mulungushi Conference Centre over the issue of chairmanship.

And President Chiluba yesterday urged Christians to dedicate more time to prayer if they are to overcome the current intra-denominational wrangles that have dogged churches in Zambia.

Mr Chiluba said in Lusaka that the current intra-denominational rows were a manifestation of Satan's work and Christians would only defeat this by dedicating more time to prayer.

He was speaking when he officiated at the annual general meeting (AGM) of the Fellowship of Christian Councils in Eastern and Southern Africa (Foccesa) comprising 12 countries.

He said the devil had failed in the fight for inter-denominational conflict characterised by the rift between Catholics and protestants in the 1960s and was now busy trying to divide individual churches.

"The intra-denominational conflicts that we are witnessing are the work of the devil and he should not be allowed to succeed. Christians should dedicate more time to prayer," he said.

Mr Chiluba said Christians needed to pray for all their preachers and avoid being selective on who should be their pastor because the word of God was universal.

He urged Foccesa members drawn from Angola, Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Swaziland, Lesotho, Zambia, South Africa and Zimbabwe to venture into conflict resolution.

Mr Chiluba said the church had a duty to promote human rights, ecumenism, literacy and other projects that would improve the well-being of the people.

He deplored the high illiteracy levels in the country and called on the church to take up the challenge of liberalisation and venture into management of tertiary education.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
Money Laundering by the Rich (Editorial)


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Money-laundering for drug-trafficking or other purposes has never been a crime of the poor. It is an exclusive crime of the rich. 

One of the apparently guaranteed advantages that high society criminals enjoy in this business is that law enforcement agencies rarely pounce on them and spark processes that land them in jail. This is how prison has been variously seen as an exclusive penalty for the poor.

And all the advantages that money-launderers and drug-traffickers enjoy tend to fizzle out in their inability to profit from their illicit gains.

The realm of money-laundering is a blood-and-death domain in which there is no joy for all the financial power available.

It is a deceive-and-get-deceived territory in which trust and honesty are simply impossible, in which lying and treachery are the one way of life.

Personal freedom disappears immediately one enters into the vice, in which the vice-grip of threats and warnings keeps the individual on the run. Laughing all the way to the bank, but tormented all the way to the grave.

The minors in the field are in easy reach of law enforcement agencies, and even in Zambia the Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC) is yet to display high society influentials the way it has displayed and humiliated lightweights.

This situation has tended to show, over and over again, that certain people will always live above the law. Be it in Zambia or elsewhere.

Criminals of sheen may enjoy many advantages as a consequence of this, but even they cannot always escape.

Where international law enforcement agencies fail, the criminals destroy themselves.

But for the cruel ruin they sell to societies worldwide, there is a serious need for our Government to make high class criminals like the largely unknown money-launderers practically - not merely philosophically - liable to prosecution.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Zambia;
UNZA councillors quit as workers down tools


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Five University of Zambia (Unza) council members resigned yesterday as over 2,500 lecturers and general workers went on strike locking up offices of vice chancellor Andrew Siwela and 10 other management officials.

The employees who gathered at the forum resolved to lock up offices of management officials and immediately go on strike.

They want Professor Siwela and his vice Professor Jorry Mwenechanya to cease to be signatories to all the 48 Unza bank accounts. 

They will be gathering at the forum at 09:00 hours everyday and only return to work when the officials are removed.

The employees removed chains from poles at the forum to use for locking up offices as some suggested they weld the grill doors to all the 11 offices so the officials cannot have access to them.

University of Zambia Workers Union (UNZAWU) president Darlington Banda and University of Zambia Professionals and Senior Administrative Staff (UNZAPROSA) president Pearson Banda all publicly announced their resignations.

UNZAWU general secretary Michael Kaluba said Dr Cecilia Shinondo and Mr Yakub Deedat had also resigned. The five officials quit citing the council's inability to discipline the Unza management following glaring financial irregularities unveiled by the Auditor General's report last week.

The employees resolved they would not return to work until President Chiluba intervened. The three unions have written to Mr Chiluba requesting him to step in.

University of Zambia Lecturers and Researchers Union (UNZALARU) vice president Gwala Phiri disclosed at the gathering that one management official awarded himself a K4m loan on Monday. Another senior manager got K7m for his family's holiday at Mosi-O-Tunya Hotel in Livingstone.

The workers want the following people removed, Prof Mwenechanya, Prof Siwela, Bonaventure Beleshi (purchasing manager), Dominic Chinukwe (purchasing officer), Ian Banda (resident engineer), Fred Zyambo (acting chief internal auditor).

Other are Bizeck Phiri (Dean of students), Mafken Tembo (bursar), Ramesh Bhavnani (deputy bursar) Mike Tandeo (registrar) and special assistant to the vice chancellor Mr Peter Mphande.

But Unza council chairman Mashekwa Nalumango said it was up to the vice chancellor to accept the resignations of five council members.

Zambia;
Petitioner calls for busaries committee probe


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - A petitioner has described the bursaries committee as a total mess and urged the Bobby Bwalya commission of inquiry to investigate the registers of sponsorship at the two universities.

But in-service student Alex Simumba, 28 failed to substantiate his claims that the bursaries committee had ghost sponsored students.

He said the bursaries committee needed to be investigated and restructured to make it more efficient and responsive to student demands. 

But when commissioner Dr Wilfred Lombe asked for specific examples, Mr Simumba said he had none but disclosed that students who graduated still appeared on the sponsorship pay roll.

Mr Simumba who is also an employee in the Ministry of Agriculture charged that the Unzasu leadership was immature because of the populist tendencies when electing leaders. He said they were elected mostly by fellow "monks" and "lumpens".

At this stage commissioners took time to find out the meaning of the terms. Mr Simumba explained lumpens were drunkards while monks were hard-core students who had nothing to do with women.

"Are they homosexuals?" queried Commissioner Steven Muliokela. "No, they just do not have time for women," he replied.

Commissioner Tom Kamwendo wondered what the name was for ordinary people and was told " walking timber or logs".

Mr Simumba also suggested that Unzasu accounts be audited to ensure subscriptions were not misused.

Unza librarian Dr Hudwell Mwacalimba said the vice chancellor and chairman of the council should be appointed by the Head of State.

He described as unrealistic a senate regulation empowering it to close the university if a stand-off with students exceeded three days.

He said the state of the library at the universities deteriorated after a management decision to drop librarians from the academic salary scale.

Lusaka Water and Sewerage Company (LWSC) customer information manager Martin Liywalii 26, urged Government not to tolerate mismanagement wherever it surfaced otherwise standards of education would continue to decline.

And in a written submission, Unza senior counsellor Hector Chiboola suggested that the academic calendar commences in September because the current February time-table did not coincide with the Government financial year resulting in delayed funding and payment of student stipend.

Mr Chiboola said the bursaries committee lacked a clear policy on payment of allowances to students and proposed that supplementary funds be made available at the start of each academic year.

He said Government grants be given to the university directly from the Ministry of Finance.

On administration, Mr Chiboola proposed that the council be empowered to discipline the vice chancellor.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Namibia;
Little girl wins struggle for life after horror rape


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao and Oswald Shivute, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Windhoek - The condition of a two-year-old girl who was brutally raped in the Tsumeb district in April is no longer life-threatening after the toddler underwent a specialised operation, a senior medical doctor told The Namibian from Tsumeb last night.

Nangombe Kalukambe is being held in connection with the horror sex attack.

In a telephonic interview yesterday, head of the Tsumeb State Hospital, Dr Mahmoud Eltawik, said the two-year-old victim had been discharged from the Oshakati State Hospital where she had won her struggle for life. 

Nonetheless, she will still need to undergo another operation.

Eltawik said that during the rape the little girl's attacker had "ruptured the floor of the vagina resulting in the vagina and the rectum becoming one hole".

Doctors at Oshakati Hospital had performed a colostomy on the two- year-old, in which a tube had been inserted into her colon to prevent "the wound being contaminated" by excreta.

The operation also served to prepare the girl for another operation aimed at repairing damaged organs.

In the meantime, Eltawik said, the child was receiving special medication.

Asked about her chances of making a full recovery, especially after the next operation, the Medical Superintendent said: "As she is a child we hope she will recover. I hope she will become alright."

Police at Tsumeb yesterday named the suspect as Nangombe Kalukambe from Otamatshau village. Although initial reports said the man was 45, the Police yesterday gave his age as 24.

Kalukambe is accused of raping the toddler at Omutsewonime village in Oshikoto Region on April 22. Both Otamatshau and Omutsewonime villages are along the Oshivelo Ondangwa main road, west of Oshivelo.

Police at Oshivelo told The Namibian that Kalukambe was only arrested on May 15 as he had gone into hiding after the rape.

According to the Police, Kalukambe has appeared in the Tsumeb Magistrate's Court twice already and is being held in custody until his next hearing.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 11, 1997


Namibia;
Desert Express rolls out in September


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Windhoek - A world-class luxury train, the Desert Express, which will offer a luxury scenic train journey between Windhoek and Swakopmund, will start operations in September.

Manager Bruno de Comarmond revealed yesterday that the N$21 million project was the first of its kind in southern Africa. 

"What differentiates this from other existing tourist trains is that Desert Express is not a nostalgic journey to the glorious days of steam travel. It is an ultra-modern train fitted with the latest technology, with the comforts associated with such a product," he boasted.

De Comarmond said the Desert Express would provide much-needed foreign currency for the country and put Namibia on the map.

Desert Express has two classes, the Spitzkoppe and the Starview Class.

The Spitzkoppe class consists of four sleeper coaches, each with six fully air-conditioned, heated cabins. The Starview class has a unique glass-panelled roof which will allow passengers to view the magnificent desert skies.

On the way to Swakopmund, the train will stop at Okahandja to allow passengers to visit an ostrich farm. There will also be a sunrise excursion to the 'moon valley' landscape in the desert near Swakopmund.

The highlight on the eastbound journey from Swakopmund will be a visit to the Spitzkoppe mountains for a tour of the San paintings and an opportunity to experience Namibia's magnificent sunsets against the Spitzkoppe mountains.

The luxury train will depart from Windhoek in the early afternoon and arrives at the coastal town at 10h00 the next day.

The Desert Express was designed by a leading European engineer, Dr Karl Dieter Bodack and 50 jobs for Namibians were created during the building of the train. After its completion, 25 train attendants will be employed.

"Desert Express will contribute greatly to promoting Namibia as an attractive tourist destination," said De Comarmond.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Namibia;
DTA slams President's 'travel toys'


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Windhoek - The DTA of Namibia has condemned a third term for President Sam Nujoma, saying that he did not exhibit the qualities expected from a 'father of the nation'.

In a statement yesterday, DTA president Mishake Muyongo said that Nujoma's supporters maintained that he should serve another term because he was the father of the nation.

"As father of the nation he should set an example to his people regarding the eradication of poverty that he is constantly preaching." 

Muyongo said that the eradication of poverty was not high on the President's list of priorities, taking into account the N$4,8 million spent on new vehicles for Nujoma's motorcade, as well as the approximately N$200 million which will be spent on his new jet.

"The DTA wishes to point out that for the price of these travelling toys for Mr Nujoma, some 4 000 sub-economic houses could be built for the homeless; or some 20 fully equipped and staffed clinics for the rural population; or hundreds of classrooms; or every learner could have his own set of schoolbooks; or teachers, nurses and police staff could receive the salary increases that have been denied them. The list of needs of the Namibian people is endless when measured against the waste of taxpayers' money on such uncalled-for luxuries."

Accusing the Swapo government of showing signs of following in the footsteps of other African governments who wasted their resources, Muyongo asked whether Nujoma wanted to be remembered in history for the same spendthrift habits as Mobutu Sese Seko.

"The DTA of Namibia wishes to urge the people of Namibia not to keep quiet about the things they see going wrong, the way the people of Zaire did. They should speak out now against this waste of money that could be spent on far more urgent things that will benefit thousands instead of only one person," he concluded.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Forbes Group lists on Namibian Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Helge Schutz, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Windhoek - The Forbes Group yesterday became the 31st company to list on the Namibian Stock Exchange when 215 million ordinary shares were made available for trading, opening at N$8 per share.

The group has two major operations in Namibia - Alexander Forbes Namibia and Price Forbes Namibia. They are wholly owned subsidiaries of Forbes Financial Group (Namibia), which in turn is part of the greater Forbes financial group. 

Alexander Forbes currently provides services to more than 60 pension funds in Namibia with over 10 000 members and employs 19 full-time staff.

It has offices in both Windhoek and Walvis Bay and is the only employee benefit consulting firm to establish an office at Walvis Bay.

Alexander Forbes is also the only firm in the country to employ a full-time actuary.

Price Forbes has operated in Namibia for 21 years, growing from one employee to 30, of whom 28 are Namibians.

The Forbes Group conducts the business of risk management and short- term insurance broking and its major clients in Namibia are the fishing industry, municipalities, NamPort, mining, oil and other corporate clients.

Forbes is the leading independent professional and financial services company in southern Africa and was last year voted as the 15th best in the world, while it was also the only one in the top 20 which was not based in the developed world.

It currently operates 31 centres in South Africa and is also based in Namibia, Botswana, Zambia and Mauritius, with associate companies in Lesotho and Swaziland.

According to its chief executive Paul Heinamann, Price Forbes' revenue went up by 12,6 per cent in the last financial year while Alexander Forbes' revenue went up by 29,1 per cent.

The attributable profit of the Forbes Group grew by 34 per cent to N$74 million, while earnings per share grew by 25 per cent.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Frothy results for Namibia Breweries


BYLINE: Helge Schutz, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Windhoek - Namibia Breweries Limited achieved excellent results for the financial year which ended on January 31, with turnover rising by 31,9 per cent from N$205,2 million to N$270,7 million.

Operating income increased from N$34,9 million to N$40 million while total financing costs decreased by 20,6 per cent, mainly due to the repayment of short term borrowings. The net income attributable to shareholders increased by 28,5 per cent to N$34,7 million. 

The beer division again contributed the major portion of operating income. Turnover for this division increased by 27,3 per cent to N$207,6 million, while volume in hectolitre terms showed a 17 per cent increase, from 628 000 to 735 000 hectolitres.

In the softdrink division, turnover went up by 28,2 per cent to N$39,6 million while the schnapps division also showed significant growth with an increase in turnover of 111 per cent to N$5,5 million, mainly as a result of substantial volume increases in the South African market.

Tabling the company's annual report last week, Namibia Breweries' chairman Werner List said the focus would continue to be on export markets with long term growth potential.

He said that more and more beer drinkers in South Africa were beginning to appreciate the taste of pure Namibian beer.

"Our brands continue to achieve growth far above budgeted forecasts, especially so in the premium market where the support of the discerning beer drinker is on the increase," he said.

List added that other countries in the subregion had all been identified as prime potential export markets. Improvements in the distribution network of the respective markets, as well as regionalised promotions had contributed to a sales volume increase of 28,2 per cent in the company's export performance.

Referring to the domestic market, List said that all sales regions in Namibia had reported solid volume growth. The company's position as market leader in Namibia has been further consolidated, while performance in the domestic beer market had exceeded sales volumes for the previous year by 6,3 per cent. This had occurred despite a negative macro-economic environment, resulting from adverse climatic conditions, low fish stocks, the ongoing high interest rates and the persistent deterioration of the Namibian dollar in relation to other foreign currencies.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
