Africa News


June 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Dramatic growth in Nambia Stock Exchange local market


BYLINE: Helge Schutz, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Windhoek - Nico Tromp, outgoing chairman of the Namibia Stock Exchange, called on the private sector to seize opportunities to create economic growth and more jobs, when he addressed the fifth Annual General Meeting of the NSE last week.

He said Namibia's economic growth was forecast at over three per cent this year and possibly even higher in 1998. A bumper harvest should boost the agronomic sector, while ocean conditions and fish stocks appeared to be improving. 

In the annual report for the year to February 1997, Tromp said that diamond production should increase while prices remained healthy. Other mining projects were also being discussed, including one of the biggest copper mines in southern Africa, on which a final decision could be expected soon.

Tom Minney, NSE's general manager outlined the figures of five years of dramatic growth in the annual report.

"The most significant development of the last year has been the dramatic growth of the NSE local market, made up of the shares of companies which are owned in Namibia or have the majority of their operations here," he said.

Namibia Breweries and CIC, which were both listed in May 1996, have boosted local liquidity. The 1997 International Finance Corporation handbook puts NSE liquidity at 11.5 per cent, which was higher than the Johannesburg and Zimbabwean stock exchanges. The NSE local index was the 19th best in the world for US$ investors in 1996, after climbing 74 per cent for local investors.

Total NSE income was up 71 per cent to N$1.08 million, while total expenditure went up by 32 per cent to N$488 884. This left a net surplus of N$480 349 after N$109 985 was transferred to the NSE guarantee fund. Some of the surplus and other reserves were budgeted for a new computer system, on which project specification work was in progress. This would speed trading, cut risks and move the market towards scripless settlement.

Transfer Secretaries (Pty) Ltd, an NSE subsidiary, also saw big increases in business. Overall the NSE had increased staff numbers and capacity and would continue the process as trading volumes were expected to soar.

An active secondary market in government debt and legal changes to allow limited liability corporate membership were in the pipeline.

According to Finance Minister Nangoloh Mbumba, the time was right for new developments in the financial markets.

The speech was delivered on his behalf by Helmut Angula to an appreciative audience of 230, including leaders of business and finance.

The Ministry had launched an invitation for proposals on consolidating existing government debt. It planned to combine issues, extend maturities and take other steps to build secondary trading. The primary market for gilts was already working well and a money market was also active in Namibia.

The broking membership would be transformed if planned amendments to the Stock Exchanges Control Act were passed early next year. These would allow limited liability corporate stockbroking firms, including banks and foreign-owned stockbrokers. Capital requirements would be raised. Dual-capacity trading may be considered later for brokers who want to be both agent and principal.

Mbumba also called for discussion on widening share ownership, "both as a way to increase savings to be put into risk capital and to prepare for later privatisation exercises." He praised a joint government- private sector initiative called "Emerge 2001" to develop Namibia's financial markets over five years.


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 11, 1997


Namibia;
Botswana 'Electric wall' sparks probe


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Windhoek - Namibian officials have launched a top-level probe into the 'negative impact' of an electrified fence Botswana is building along the Namibia-Botswana border at the southern side of the West Caprivi Game Park.

Although the fence is not yet complete, it is already sparking controversy and

is resulting in Namibia losing valuable game. It is also disrupting the migratory routes of the elephant population in the region.

Added to this, well-placed sources said the 'electric wall' was set to disrupt the lifestyle of the Kxoe people in the area. 

The N$4,8 million fence is ostensibly being built to prevent the cross-border "spread" of foot and mouth and lung sickness disease among cattle following a devastating outbreak of lung sickness disease in Botswana in 1995.

Opposition to the project has also emerged in Botswana because there has been no environmental impact assessment study, or consultation with potentially affected communities.

Namibia initially gave conditional support for the erection of the 'electric wall' as long as it did not interfere with the migratory routes of elephants or with the environment.

But now the Caprivi border fence plan is raising concerned eyebrows in conservation, community, tourism and other circles.

A senior ranger stationed in the Bagani area in Caprivi said that in April alone three giraffes and an elephant died while struggling to free themselves after becoming trapped in the fence. The animals were following their natural migration path along the game corridor from Namibia to Botswana.

Although the animals reportedly died on the Namibian side of the border, a group of Batswana apparently sneaked into the country and carted away the elephant and giraffe carcasses.

The fence, which will only be electrified once it is fully completed, will stretch from the area around the Mahango game reserve to the Kwando river in the Caprivi. Work on the fence started in December and was initially due to have been completed by the end of this month.

In the face of mounting game losses, Namibian authorities have launched a probe to ascertain the seriousness of the issue.

"Our office in the Caprivi is looking into the seriousness of the situation so that appropriate procedures will follow between the two governments," a senior Ministry of Environment and Tourism spokesperson, Sackey Namugongo, told The Namibian yesterday.

"We are discussing the losses incurred in our game and our Ministry is investigating the situation," he revealed.

Namugongo said the probe, being carried out by Ministry officials, was focusing on the impact of the fence on game migration and was aimed at rectifying the situation.

He said that although his office did not yet have exact statistics on the number of game losses being caused by the fence, the matter had become worrying enough to be brought to his Ministry's attention.

"The area being fenced is a free movement area or a corridor for the immigration of elephants, buffaloes, lions and other animals migrating between Angola, Namibia, Zambia and Botswana," he observed.

Unconfirmed reports have also surfaced that portions of the uncompleted fence have already been destroyed by elephants as they move to and from Botswana.

Before Botswana started putting up the electric barrier, authorities from the line ministries in that country consulted Namibia's Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Rural Development.

Personal assistant to the Minister of Agriculture, Samuel Goagoseb, said the Ministry had initially given Botswana a green light on the move, but only on condition that "migratory routes for elephants should be left open" and that the fence should not interfere with the environment.

The Ministry had also agreed to the project because the fence is apparently not being erected on the international boundary separating the neighbouring states, but on the Botswanan side of the border.

Agriculture, Water and Rural Development was consulted because the issue pivoted around controlling the spread of livestock diseases, which falls under their jurisdiction.

Initial issues pertaining to environment were apparently ironed out with the Environment and Tourism Ministry.

Contacted for comment yesterday, Botswana's High Commissioner to Namibia, Edward Matenge, said the matter had not been brought to the attention of the Botswana Mission in Windhoek.

However, Matenge added, the Namibian authorities had raised the issue with his country's government. But, he said: "I don't want to go further than that."

A report in the Okavango Observer earlier this year quoted Botswana's Agriculture Minister, Roy Blackbeard, as saying the fence was the only "practical step" that could be taken to prevent the free movement of cattle.

However, conservation organisations in Namibia's eastern neighbour believe there are alternatives as well as ways of making fences "wildlife friendly".


LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Science and Health;
Japan Cannot Control Illegal Ivory Trade


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 789 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Japan, which is willing to buy ivory from the three Southern African nations pressing for the removing of the elephant from the list of endangered species, does not have enough controls in place to check illegal trade, the leading environmental pressure group, Greenpeace, said.

In its position paper to the on-going conference on the Convention in International Trade on Endangered Species, Greenpeace said it supported the findings of the panel of experts on the African elephant, set up by the convention, that downlisting could trigger poaching activities. 

Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe, which together have 155,000 elephants, want to animal downlisted from Appendix I to Appendix II, which will allow limited and controlled trade in ivory.

Greenpeace said the Japanese market was insufficiently controlled to stop illegal ivory trade while control in the three nations pushing for downlisting seemed to be problematic.

"In the event of a partial relaxation of the international trade ban on ivory and other elephant products, poaching is likely to restart," It said.

Recent reports of up to 280 elephants killed in Cameroon at the end of 1996, it said, say poachers claimed that they had killed the elephants assuming that trade in ivory would become legal in 1997.

With a population of 66,000 against a carrying capacity of 35,000 elephants, Zimbabwe says it has become increasingly difficult to manage in a sustainable manner, the ever increasing elephant population.

On the question of controls in Japan, Zimbabwe says it is prepared to have two ports established - one in Harare and the other in Japan - with officials and witnesses appointed to accompany the ivory until it reaches its final destination.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Mbeki Says Developed Countries Must Help Reduce Poverty


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


CAPE TOWN, South Africa (PANA) - South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said Thursday developed countries would likely be unable to sustain their long-term stability if they failed to help reduce poverty in Africa.

Mbeki was speaking at the global ceremony to launch the United Nations Development Programme Human Development 1997 report. The ceremony was held simultaneously with that in Bonn, Germany via satellite link. 

He said measures to eradicate or reduce poverty should involve the public.

"A people-centered society is important," he said. "We have to talk to people who are negatively impacted by policies we introduce."

Mbeki later told a news conference that if the developed world was serious about helping develop Africa, then they should forgive debts owed by these countries.

"If they don't it will be difficult to talk of progress in Africa," he said.

Africa, he said, could help by making itself attractive to foreign investment so as to manage its high budget deficit.

According to the U.N. agency, Africa's debt stands at 215 billion U.S. dollars, up from 55 billion dollars in 1980.

South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission chairman, Bishop Desmond Tutu, said in a live satellite message to Bonn and Cape Town that if it were possible to end apartheid in South Africa, it should also be possible to eradicate poverty in the world.

"Some years ago, some people thought it was a dream to get rid of apartheid," he said.

Poverty would disappear, he said, if governments spent less on arms and spent more on gender development, social, economic and environmental issues and if there was a more equitable economic order.

"My call to you who helped to end apartheid is let's join to end the scourge of poverty," Tutu said.

The U.N. Development Programme's report, which was launched throughout the world, could be used by governments to formulate policies aimed at reducing poverty.

The agency said only a fraction of the global income was needed to eradicate poverty the world over. It said it would cost about 80 billion dollars to provide universal access to basic social services to alleviate poverty.

The additional cost of achieving basic social services for all in developing countries, it said, was about 40 billion U.S. dollars a year over the next 10 years.

It said that this sum was less than 0.2 percent of the world income of 25 trillion dollars.

Another 40 billion dollars is required if the gap between the annual income of poor people and the minimum income which would lift them from poverty is to be closed.

"Better collection, publication and analysis of statistics showing how countries are reducing poverty will be important for maintaining momentum," the agency said.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwean Says Inflation Threat To Market Stability


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The president of the Zimbabwe Economic Society, Kenias Mafukidze, has said the country's macro-economic stability is under renewed threats from inflation which has risen by more than 60 percent from 13.9 percent in November 1996 to 22.4 percent in April.

"What is disturbing about this rate is that there are no signs that the amount is going to come down," he said. "In fact, the rate is more than likely to rise above the April peg in subsequent months."

In the June issue of Megabuck, Mafukidze said the knock-on effects of the recent fuel price hike will definitely result in a spate of price increases in other items causing cost-push inflation.

Zimbabwe's fuel prices went up in May by between 12 percent and 24 percent despite a background of reduced oil prices from 247.50 Zimdollars (22.50 U.S. dollars) at the beginning of the year to 203.50 Zimdollars(18.50 U.S. dollars) in recent months.

Mafukidze said the expected increase in the budget deficit would have a serious inflationary impacts as it would have to be funded from domestic sources following the suspension of funds by the International Monetary Fund.

The budget deficit was set to rise to about 11 percent of GDP as opposed to the initial target of 8.5 percent.

"If it is not contained this rise in inflation figures will have devastating ramifications on the marketplace," Mafukidze said. "The impact of the unforeseen rate increases is likely to be met with confusion, alarm and uncertainty by the market."

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Congo;
Belgium Asks Congo To Solve Refugee Problem


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Belgium has requested President Laurent Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo to actively seek for a prompt solution to the refugee problem in his country in conjuction with the international community.

The call was made in Lusaka on Thursday by the Belgian ambassador to Zambia, Leopold Carrewyn, when he presented letters of credence to President Frederick Chiluba. 

He said that Kabila should also shed full light on the humanitarian situation in eastern congo which is plagued with the problem of refugees.

Carrewyn said that his government is in favour of a broad-based transitional government in Congo-Kinshasa, with a prospect of free and fair elections within a reasonable time-span.

"Our own position towards the new Democratic Republic of Congo, and President Kabila is, as you know, positive and constructive."

On Burundi, the Belgian diplomat regretted that since the military take-over by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, the situation in that country has remained worrisome.

Carrewyn said that Brussels welcomes ongoing Zambian efforts to restore legitimacy in that country. Zambia is among East and Central african states which imposed sanctions on Burundi after Maj. Buyoya's military coup on July 25, 1996.

The envoy said his government, as well as in the framework of the European Union continue to be ready to play an active supporting role in preventive diplomacy and peacekeeping in Africa.

Welcoming the new ambassador, Chiluba assured Belgium of his country's intention to promote cooperation and regional integration. He said, however, that it was not possible to have regional trade when there is instability in the region.

"Unless there is stability in the region, there is nothing much we can talk about in terms of trade. Zambia remains committed to the idea of regional integration," Chiluba said.

Congo;
Annan Calls For An End To Fighting In Congo


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations (PANA) - The United Nations Secretary- General, Kofi Annan has called on the parties to the current fighting in Brazzaville to cease hostilities and begin negotiations to settle their differences immediately.

"The Secretary-General is increasingly concerned about the deteriorating situation in Congo, Brazzaville, and the rising human toll of this conflict," UN spokesman Fred Eckhard said. 

"He welcomes president Omar Bongo's readiness to mediate, and appeals to other leaders in the region with influence on the parties to assist in any way they can," Eckhard said. The UN spokesman said that the Secretary-General had requested his special representative to the Great Lakes region, Mohamed Sahnoun, to support the peace effort in the country.

Hundreds of people have been killed in Brazzaville since fighting broke out last week between government forces and a private militia loyal to a former Congolese military leader, Gen. Denis Sassou-Nguesso.

The fighting started when President Pascal Lissouba, fearing a possible disruption of the country's forthcoming presidential elections, sent government troops to disarm the 5,000-strong "Cobra" militia.

On Tuesday, Annan briefed the Security Council on the situation in the country, and other African hot spots.

"We are worried it (fighting in Brazzaville) could spread to central Africa," he said after the briefing.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Poverty Still Afflicts Children, Says UNDP


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) says although poverty had begun to show signs of decline, its rise is caused by new global pressures such as AIDS, conflicts, retarded or stagnant economic growths.

In its 1997 Human Development Report, the UNDP said it was possible to eradicate poverty in the first decades of the 21st century if countries stuck to their promise.

"This may seem an extraordinary ambition, but it is well within our grasp," says the report. 

It said almost all countries committed themselves to eradicating poverty by the 21st century at the World Summit for Social Development held in Denmark in 1995.

At present, a quarter of the world's people remained in severe poverty.

"In a global economy of USD 25 trillion this is a scandal reflecting shameful inequalities and inexcusable failures of national and international policy," noted the report.

It said that Sub-Saharan Africa has the highest proportion of people in - and the fastest growth in - human poverty. Children are most vulnerable.

Half a million women worldwide also die each year in child birth - at rates 10 to 100 times higher than those in industrialised countries.

The report also indicates that a growing number of elderly people live their twilight years in poverty.

The report identifies some of the solutions to poverty as empowering economically both women and men, gender equality, globalisation, political and international support.

The UNDP has been producing an annual report on human development since 1990.

The reports are destined for policy makers, private organisations, academics, civil society and the media.

It was with this in mind that the UNDP organised a two-day workshop in Cape Town, South Africa, from Thursday to discuss issues raised in the report focusing on African development experiences.

The overall objective of the workshop is to raise the awareness of participants on the critical issues to be tackled in eradicating poverty and the policy implications.

Participants include high level government officials, non- governmental organisations, academics, parliamentarians, journalists, representatives of African institutions and UNDP officials from 19 African countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Military Junta Seeks Support From Ghana


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ACCRA Ghana (PANA) - A delegation from Sierra Leone has appealed to Ghana not to join the sub-regional force which is preparing to attack the military junta that recently seized power in the country.

They also asked Ghana to try and influence other African countries not to join any international invasion of the country.

Dauda Suleiman Kamara, leader of the eight-member delegation that flew into Accra Wednesday, made the appeal during talks with Victor Gbeho, Ghana's deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs and other government officials. 

The delegation is in Ghana to explain the causes of the May 25 coup d'etat which overthrew the elected government of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah.

Kamara said any international invasion on Sierra Leone will create serious difficulties for Sierra Leoneans.

There have been several international appeals for coup leaders to step down, and Nigeria is leading a west-African regional forces preparing an attack against the junta to dislodge it from power.

Kamara agreed that coups are not good but said that no government in Freetown has been able to stand the wrath of the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) whose actions, he said, has led to the overthrow of three governments in less than five years.

He said since the overthrow of President Kabbah, the rebels have entered into an agreement with the ruling military government and have stopped fighting.

Kamara said they have pledged their commitment to peace and democratic rule and asked the world to give them a chance to prove themselves.

Gbeho traced relations between Ghana and Sierra Leone and described the recent military coup as unfortunate.

He said Ghana would listen to the grievances of the delegation with a fair and open mind before taking a stand.

The meeting continued behind closed doors with Mahama Iddrisu, Minister of Defence, Kwamena Ahwoi, Minister responsible for Foreign Affairs and Kofi Totobi Quakyi, Minister of State, also attending.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court orders government-paid attorneys for Terror suspects


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Federal High Court has ordered the government to hire attorney for Colonel Fantaye Yehdego, who is on trial in connection with the gassing to death of 24 youths, and other Red Terror perpetrators of woredas 5 and 18.

The court ordered the office of attorneys of defendants to dispatch attorneys of defendants to dispatch attorneys to prisons where the suspects are being detained, so that they can consult their clients and come up with their defense arguments at the next hearing.

The trial of Colonel Fantaye and Leutaant Ambachew Alemu, another suspect in the gassing of the youth, has been adjourned for July 14. the later is still at large. 

The Third Bench of the Federal High Court, where the trial of Red Terror suspects from woredas 5 and 18 is proceeding also ordered the detaining prisons to produce proof that the defendants can not hire their own attorneys. The suspects claim that they do not have the financial capacity to hire attorneys.

The court overruled a request for bail by two suspects of the Woredas Five Red Terror suspects, citing that they are not entitled to the privilege under existing law.

The court said that it was not acceptable that police have not yet brought other suspects in both woredas before it, and ordered police to either deliver the suspects or produce proof that they are not living in their permanent residential place.

The trial of the suspects of both woredas was adjourned for July 30.

In a related development, the Immigration and Refugee Affairs Department said that it is facing difficulty to conduct its duty due to the incompleteness of a list of 102 suspects who have been banned from traveling abroad.

The list identifies some of the suspects with only their first name, creating impediments to the efficient functioning of the department and inconvenience to those who want to travel abroad.

The Special prosecutor Office acknowledged the problem and promised to come up with a solution as soon as possible.

June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Wegagen Bank launches operations in Addis


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Described by its owners as "the biggest private bank in Ethiopia to date", Wegagen Bank S.C. yesterday started operations following a brief inaugural ceremony held at its head quarters at Gofa Sefer and at its Maskal branch office. Ifs capital base stands at 60 million birr, wholly owned by Ethiopians and of which 30 million birr has been paid up.

The governor of the National Bank of Ethiopia, Ato Dubale Jale, said on the occasion that the starting of operations by Wegagen Bank S.C.

contributing to the expansion and development of the banking sector in the country and "the strengthening of competition between the major players in the national economy." 

Ato Dubale noted that as the success of a bank depends heavily on the sense of trust it builds in its customers, Wegagen Bank, S.C is expected to demonstrate utmost capability and faithfulness to the general public.

He added that, Wegagen should also to execute its responsibility for the healthy development of the banking sector in Ethiopia by working closely with other banks as well as operating in accordance with the policy guide lines set by the National Bank of Ethiopia.

The chairman of the Board of Directors of Wegagen bank S.C, Ato Seye Abrha said on the occasion that as the bank starts operation in the wake of "a new promising era" in the history of the nation, it will have as its primary goal serving, faithfully and with total commitment, every aspiring development agent, governmental or private, with the ultimate objective of helping bring prosperity to the nation. He said the Amharic word "Wegagen" literally, "Sunrise" was to denote this new trend in the country.

Ato Seye further stated that as the shareholders of the bank are renowned personalities both in Addis and other parts of the nation, Wegagen is sure to win great confidence and trust among the general public and hence a wide customer base. "though its capital base is not that large, this fact alone portends a good prospect to grow ever larger and larger," he added.

The president of the bank, Wzo. Bruktawit Dawit Abdi, said on her part that Wegagen has been established with the appropriate administrative structure, and branches that is sure to enable it contribute to the country's economic development. The bank has 16 shareholders out of whom seven are organizations, Wzo. Bruktawit said, adding that it gives full banking services and will participate in future competitions in foreign exchange transaction among banks.

It was noted that Wegagen Bank S.C. provides a wide range of domestic and international services and has a Broad of Directors elected by its shareholders and is managed by a team of experienced Ethiopian bankers who comprise the president and four vice presidents. It has branch offices in Merkato area, Dire Dawa, Awassa, Shashemene, Bahir Dar and Makalle.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
Draft electric law submitted to council of Ministers


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - the draft of the Ethiopian electric law, which is expected to break government monopoly in the generation and sale electric power has been submitted to the Council of Ministers, a department head at the Ministry of Mines and Energy disclosed.

the law will enable private investors and development associations to produce and sale up to 25 mega watts of electric power, said Ato Tesfaye Bedika, head of the energy department of the ministry. 

Ato Tesfaye added the generation of electric power to distribute it where it is needed requires huge amount of investment, and the government with its limited financial resources can not be expected to meet the ever increasing demand for electric power.

the proclamation, which will enter in to force after ratification by the House of Peoples' Representatives, provides huge business opportunity to those who want to engage in electric power services, he noted.

It requires an investment of 40-50 million dollars to build a 50 mega watt power plant, Ato Tesfaye said adding that such plant can provide enough power for a city the size of Addis Ababa.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
Parliamentary talks with aviation authority and airline


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A parliamentary team of representatives from various standing committee of the House of People's Representatives and led by the House Speaker, Ato Dawit Yohannes, visited yesterday the Ethiopian Civil Aviation Authority (ECAA) and Ethiopian airlines.

Briefing the honorable main offices members on the overall performance of the ECAA, the General Manager, Ato Meshesha Belayneh, pointed out that the authority administrating has been seven major and 39 feeder airports since its establishment in 1954 E.C. The general manager noted that plans like the expansion and coordination of economic and expeditious air transport service, regulating air traffic control and safety of air transportation, and establishing and expanding international and domestic air links and constructing airports are under its jurisdiction.

Ethiopia has signed, through the authority, air transport link agreements with 51 countries and initialed similar accords with 15 other countries, the general manager pointed out. 

"Ethiopian Airline, flies to 23 African, 4 European, 5 Far East and 9 Middle Eastern cities in accordance with agreements signed by ECAA." Ato Meshesha said, adding that eight foreign air lines have regular flight schedules to Addis.

According to Ato Meshesha, ECAA has launched a number of projects in line with its five-year aviation development programme (1987-1991 E.C.), including preparatory works to start the Addis Ababa airport expansion project, constructing airport facilities in Lalibela, Axum and Arba Minch which are already completed, as well as the start of construction in Makalle and Gondar.

Dr. Amhed Kello, General Manager of Ethiopian Airlines, told the visiting team that ETHIOPIAN is one of Africa's most prestigious airlines known for its quality service and efficiency. he pointed out that the national carrier operates 2 Boeing 767, 5 Boeing 757, one 737, 4 DHC-6, 5 Fokker-50 and 1 Lockheed 1-10 aircraft.

The visiting team toured the terminal buildings, engine overhaul shop, the assembly plant of "Eshet", a crop duster; and the test cell which is a highly sophisticated engine testing plant. The test cell which went into operation recently is reportedly the first of its kind in Africa and was built at a cost of 17 million US dollars.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
ZDC links MMD to expelled Mutukwa


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Expelled Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) Nalolo member of parliament Kasukwa Mutukwa has been accused of betraying the party by flirting with State House.

But Mutukwa has dismissed the allegations as "madness" and "hallucinations".

ZDC deputy national secretary Azwell Banda, in an interview yesterday, said his party was aware of the activities of Mutukwa, expelled party treasurer Dante Saunders and Susan Jere's alleged links to the ruling MMD through defence minister Ben Mwila. 

"It's important to make it clear that no single member of ZDC executive can flirt with the MMD and escape unnoticed," Banda said, insisting he was also speaking as a member of the steering committee. "We have the capacity to know whatever Chiluba is doing."

Banda further claimed that the MMD legal machinery has been empowered to seek ways of saving Mutukwa's parliamentary seat without going through a by-election. He also claimed President Frederick Chiluba was using Nakatindi Wina "to bring Mutukwa into the MMD" and he has been promised a big post.

Mutukwa, in an interview last night, said Banda's allegations did not have any foundation.

"That's madness. I'm sorry to use such words," Mutukwa said in an interview last night. "They better be serious. I don't want to be drawn in accusations and counter-accusations."

Mutukwa said he last met President Chiluba in 1992 when he was head of the Eastern and Southern African Management Institute (ESAMI) in Arusha and was not in the delegation which met the president before the November 18 elections last year.

And when asked about Mutukwa's position, ZDC president Dean Mung'omba said he was aware that the Nalolo member of parliament was meeting President Chiluba.

Mung'omba said, according to information before the steering committee, matters Mutukwa discussed with President Chiluba bordered on "betrayal of ZDC". He said the expelled vice-president for international relations "saw Chiluba to dissociate himself from the petition" currently before the Supreme Court.

"All those are hallucinations," Mutukwa said last night.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


320 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Government party to UNZA chaos, charges professor


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Lusaka - The government was party to the management problems the University of Zambia (UNZA) was facing, charged UNZA vice-chancellor Professor Andrew Siwela yesterday.

Professor Siwela, submitting to the ongoing commission of inquiry on operations of University of Zambia and the Copperbelt University appointed by President Frederick Chiluba, accused the government of not following communications channels and has contributed to the strained relations between management and workers.

Professor Siwela further charged that government ministries had been releasing "classified" information intended for the UNZA administration to union officials at the institution.

"My strong appeal and recommendation is that the ministries should respect channels of communication. 

Currently information intended for the management is being given to individuals frequenting ministry corridors," Professor Siwela said yesterday.

Professor Siwela cited a recent incident when the Ministry of Education released information that workers salary arrears would be paid out.

"While management was trying to work out the modalities for the payment even before the funds were made available, several copies about the payment were given to the union leaders which has now led to the strike at the campus," Professor Siwela said.

He told the commission that this situation had rendered the administration redundant as information had been going directly to the workers without the knowledge of management.

"If you are a political appointee you can absorb it but its not possible if you have been selected from a group to run an institution," Professor Siwela said.

And UNZA bursar, Mafukeni Tembo, in his submission defended the move taken to operate 38 bank accounts saying that the accounts serviced different wings of the institution.

Tembo said that among the 38 accounts, UNZA had 14 central accounts for direct use by the campus, 11 accounts for the various schools at the university, six for projects usually funded by donors, and three hard currency accounts.

"I am afraid we have to be bold on this matter. It is surprising that people I work with can come and say such things to the commission. I cannot believe there is any institution with a K14.5 billion allocation that can operate only one account," Tembo said.

He called on the commission to send independent auditors to the university to investigate the state of the accounts.

And Professor Siwela yesterday accused some petitioners in the on- going commission of inquiry of wanting to discredit his reputation by making false submissions.

He accused a petitioner who had earlier claimed that the UNZA was running without stationery had lied and further invited the commission to inspect the university's store room to prove his claims.

"I wish to draw your attention to the grade three lecturer who told this August house a truck carrying stationery and training aids bought from South Africa had not arrived and that the university had been operating without basic stationery including chalk," Professor Siwela said. "I wish to state that the petitioner told a lie and that is tantamount to perjury."

Professor Siwela charged that several petitioners had intentions of putting his reputation into disrepute. He was referring to the recent submissions that Professor Siwela's administration had mismanaged and plundered the university.

"I am being called a thief and being blasted left, right and centre and from the recent action at the university it is easy to see that most of the petitioners want to destroy my personal reputation," Professor Siwela said.

And UNZA administrators after giving their submissions, were yesterday taken to task on why they had not included the librarian in management as per the institution's Act.

According to the librarian's submission, he had been down-graded to the level of senior lecturer instead of that of professor as was the case in other universities.

UNZA deputy vice-chancellor, Professor Jorry Mwenechanya, said that the librarian was still in level of management but had been excluded from the daily management of the institution as he was not directly involved with the role. Professor Mwenechanya could not, however, fully explain why the decision was taken.

But Professor Siwela insisted that the librarian had only complained about his position because he had not been receiving some of the "fringe benefits" that management staff were getting.

Meanwhile, striking UNZA workers have refused to return to work.

Professor Siwela, in an interview yesterday, said the workers had stood their ground on not going back to work and called for government's intervention in the matter.

"They have refused to go back to work and are still denying us access to our offices," Professor Siwela said.

"We just have to wait until state intervenes to show them that anarchy cannot prevail."

And UNZA Lectures and Researchers Union chairman, Mark Mulenga, yesterday denied that their move to stage a strike was not aimed at stopping the university administration from giving their submissions in the on-going inquiry.

"There has been no evidence of violence in our protest. And we wish to deny the statement made by the registrar that we were trying to stop them from giving their submissions," Mulenga said. "In fact we actually advised them strongly to go and give their submissions."


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


321 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Expectations Of My Generation: Sinking Deeper (Column)


BYLINE: Sam Mujuda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Lusaka - JUST for that moment when South Africa's Bafana Bafana were thundering goals into our nest, I for a while started dying to have been a South African.

Patriotic I am. And if I was to classify my self (although I hate doing that because I do not see sense in the classes our constitution has introduced), I am a first degree Zambian.

But let us face the truth. South Africans believe they are not losers and they have reaped just exactly that. 

I could feel my innerself trying to praise South Africa as minute after minute was consumed without our players coming into the game. When the first thunderbolt was sent past Davies Phiri, I immediately brushed it as the biggest mistake South Africa had committed because they had heightened Zambia's anger. Seeing the second, I felt my intestines quacking. And with the third goal - I declared Zambia had been embarrassed beyond redemption.

Previously, I used to go to town with our soccer rating as that was the only pride I could boast of among other nationals. At least in sport, soccer was the identifying factor of Zambia. What can boast about now? The economy? Political leadership? Democracy? No way.

South Africans are champions, they also can boast about their economy and the leadership of President Nelson Mandela.

I think we had all the designs of going to lose. Our football association was in shambles coupled with ill preparedness of our players. Yes, we may have good players indeed but they seemed to have easily accepted defeat.

I for one would like to lump my blame on the players and the Football Association of Zambia. Not the coaching staff and I would echo the stance taken by people that coach George Mungwa should be spared.

What we saw last Sunday, was Zambian soccer at its lowest. But what is going to remain up in Zambia? Soccer has been brought down. Politics have gone to the dogs. The Presidency has sunk lower. The integrity of the judiciary is in tatters.

I do not dismiss superstitions but I would like to dismiss claims made by people that the Bafana Bafana were playing with the blessing of the sangomas. I think that is wishful thinking to use as an apology for our loss.

But Zambia is a Christian nation and God should have been on our side.

For once let us face reality, the South Africans did not win by fluke. When they lifted the African Cup, I was one of the people who wishfully said, had Zambia met South Africa and not Tunisia in the semi- finals - we would have definitely trounced the Bafana Bafana to earn a place in the finals. With all my patriotism, I think South Africa's win was not a fluke and they might prove to be better ambassadors of Africa than we would have been.

We are incapable of preparing for a crucial game.

One thing Zambia should not forget is that we owe the players who perished off the coast of Gabon a lot and one thing that can pay off is releasing the Gabon Report. At least for the sake of the families involved.

A lot has been played down, no wonder this misfortune Zambia is facing. We should not accuse the South African sangomas of sacrificing chickens to earn Zambia's defeat. Probably the biggest enemy we have embraced is the non-release of the Gabon report.

I think the whole plain truth we should know is that even if we change the executive in the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) we will not achieve anything to speak home about. We will always say we have to sit down and muse. But for how long when countries we used to look at as football minnows are today fattening their sport curriculum vitae.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


322 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Kasonka appeals for investment in soccer


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - FOOTBALL Association of Zambia (FAZ) treasurer Musa Kasonka Jr. has appealed to the government to invest heavily in soccer if the standards in the country have to improve.

Kasonka made the appeal on his arrival from South Africa on Monday where the Zambian side was humiliated by 3-0 bash in the World Cup qualifier at First National bank stadium. 

Kasonka who attributed the loss to the ill preparedness of the team compared to the South African counterparts said it was time to talk less and implement programmes that will boost sport in the country.

"Zambia has to invest heavily in the technical aspect of soccer and I think we should talk less and become action oriented," said Kasonka. "Our friends in South Africa have already started preparing the Under-23 team for the Olympics."

Zambia only played two international preparatory games prior to last Sunday's World Cup qualifier match in Johannesburg which Kasonka said was not enough to expect a victory over the Bafana Bafana who played their preparatory games in Europe.

And a soccer fan Mumba Kapumpa still clad in the Zambian colours on arrival at the International Airport advised the country to bury the humiliation and concentrate on the African championship.

Kapumpa also challenged the soccer administrators to rise to the occasion and prove their worth.

"We have talent but we need to harness it and FAZ should have people with a vision of improving the sport," said Kapumpa. "As long as FAZ remains in the doldrums we won't get anywhere."

Another fan Felix Khani who heaped the blame on the soccer administrators said that the country was not short of people who can run FAZ effectively.

June 12, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Muzungu tops BP Top Eight


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - "MIGHTY" Mufurila Wanderers utility player Alex Musungu is the man of the match of BP Top eight final played at Independence stadium on may 11.

A panel of Lusaka based journalists nominated aging Musungu, the scorer of the third goal when Zamsure was bashed 3-0 for his outstanding performance. 

Musungu, formerly of Green Bufallos was the most consistent during the match having engineered the second goal.

The BP presentation ceremony of the K200,000 prize money to the player will be done tomorrow in the BP Zambia Plc boardroom, the company spokesman, Ann Sakala has said.

Wanderers, 1996 winners of the BP Cup, successfully defended the title when they beat Zamsure and walked away with a staggering K5 million prize money while the runners up Zamsure got K4.5 million.

After the loss the Zambia State Insurance Corporation, sponsors of Zamsure relieved its coach Mike Sithole of his duties.

324 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sports - General;
Auto Racing: Zambia's Castrol rally attracts 25


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - TWENTY-five motor rally drivers are expected to rev in this year's Castrol-Spectra Zambia International Motor Rally on July 4, Lusaka Motor Club president Aaron Chungu has said.

Chungu said three international drivers from Zimbabwe have already confirmed their participation while some drivers from Kenya, South Africa and Namibia are yet to confirm their participation in the K100 million rich event.

"Three international drivers are definitely coming from Zimbabwe and more are expected from South Africa, Kenya and Namibia," Chungu said in an interview after launching a promotional programme of the rally at the Zambia National Broadcasting Cooperation studios Tuesday. 

Chungu also disclosed that the FIA, World's Motor Rally governing body has already ratified Andy Nagi of Kenya as the clerk of the course whose route will be announced later while Italian, Bruno Moretti will be an observer.

Andy was the Course Clerk in the international Equator Rally, a major event in Kenya which was last won by Zambian Guru, Satwant Singh who is also expected to lead this year's event.

Earlier Spectra Oils Managing Director, the co-sponsors of the rally, Yuyi Lishomwa presented a cheque of US$15,000 to the Zambia Motor Sport Association (ZMSA) president Lee-Ann Singh to assist with the preparations.

Lishomwa said that it was Castrol's, the lubricant dealers tradition to sponsor sports World over and more importantly to the deserving disciplines.

"We selected motor sport not only as a tradition but because we wanted to associate ourselves with an organisation which is accountable and run its affairs properly," said Lishomwa.

Lee-Ann Singh said the focus will be on Zambia because they are the current holder of the annual biggest event title.

"It is a premier competition because it is the biggest sporting event in the country," Singh said.

Chungu said the donation of US$15,000 by Spectra of the K30 million pledge the company made last month was a boost to the preparation of the event that will see the cream of the Zambian drivers enter the two days event.

"We thank Mr.Yuyi for taking up this challenge because it is through this that a sport can become a reality," Chungu.

Chungu said the Association will make up for the shortfall of K70 million and was very optimistic that the target will be met before the flagging off day on July 4, at Pamodzi Hotel.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Talking for aid (Editorial)


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - The meeting in Stockholm which brought together some of the country's opposition parties and the ruling MMD is a credit to the Swedish friends of Zambia.

But it came at a time when it is not easy to evaluate its true meaning and significance.

The most indicative time would have been during the run up to last year's elections. That in fact is when the problem of lack of dialogue started and also manifested itself fully. 

It is at that time when the MMD revealed and stood by its true colours. Even the most sanguine donors counted for nothing and were easily shouted down and denigrated. by not acting then, the Swedish friends of Zambia lost a real opportunity to test their true worth in the eyes of the MMD government and it is necessary to know that sort of dimension when dealing with an apparently opportunist regime.

There is nothing fundamentally wrong with the Stockholm meeting except that it comes at a time when the Zambian government is really desperate and will do anything that will enhance chances of a resumption of aid.

The repercussions of its misguided arrogance in the period before the elections are only now beginning to register. But it gotten what it wanted and now it can negotiate 'nothings" as its hold on power will not be affected in any meaningful way through such talks.

The MMD cannot possibly turn down an opportunity like the Swedes offered even for appearances sake only.

The resumption of Swedish balance of payments support is a sure fire incentive and the government will do anything to have it resumed.

The meeting therefore does not represent the true attitude of the MMD to either the Swedish initiative or the talks themselves. It merely suits its designs.

It is however a sad commentary, on particularly the government of Zambia, and a reflection of its utter desperation that it can only act because of the possibility of aid.

The issues involved in inter-party dialogue transcend hard self- interest considerations. They relate above all to the well being of the country as a whole. True Zambian patriots should require no plodding nor the dangling of balance of payments support before they can act on a matter of that nature.

Sweden does not owe Zambia a living at all. Why then should it take a foreign country for Zambians to act in their own interest? It is a profoundly troubling question.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


326 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Presidential petition


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, Chilombo Mwondela and Goodson Machona, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - AN Election Commission provisional results document revealed yesterday in the Supreme Court that one constituency had more than 2,000 extra voters from the registered number of voters.

Presidential election petition witness number 93, Dr. Steven Moyo, read out figures from the documents for Mansa Constituency which showed that the constituency had more people than were registered.

This was during the continued hearing of the presidential election petition in which five opposition parties are contesting the candidature and re-election of President Frederick Chiluba. 

Dr. Moyo said another Elections Commission document that showed the registered total number of people in each constituency showed that Mansa had 10,145 voters but after voting, it emerged that Mansa had about 12,000.

He tabulated the votes as follows: President Chiluba (MMD) - 10,433, Chakomboka Chama (MDP) - 188, Lewanika Mbikusita-Akashambatwa (AZ) - 69, Mulemba Humphrey (NP) - 146, Mung'omba Dean (ZDC) - 975, rejected ballot papers 511. This totals 12, 322, showing a difference of 2,177 votes.

Moyo also gave other examples of elections results having been changed from an earlier document he claims came from the Elections Office to the official provisional results.

He gave various examples, amongst which was Constituency number 87 Nakonde. It shows that President Chiluba got 5,896 from an earlier document but from the official provisional results he got 5, 894, two votes less and in Isoka East President Chiluba got 5,949 in the earlier result but reduced to 2,757 in the official results.

This difference is also reflected in all the other presidential candidates.

After Moyo finished his evidence, President Chiluba's lawyers, minister at State House Eric Silwamba and legal affairs minister Vincent Malambo, applied for an adjournment to today in the afternoon to enable them meticulously study all the documents that Dr. Moyo had referred to so that they would be able to adequately deal with him in cross- examination.

The application was granted.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


327 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia's aviation industry meets


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - STANDARDS in aviation safety should not be compromised because they are crucial to its smooth operation and sustainability, advised deputy transport and communications minister Gilbert Mululu said yesterday.

Mululu, officially opening the first Aviation Seminar organised by the National Airports Corporation Limited (NACL) at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel yesterday, said Zambia should not lag behind in aviation technology especially on air control management. 

The transport and communications deputy minister told seminar participants from the Zambia Air Force, Zambia Express, Aero Zambia and other private airlines that the relevance and importance of aviation towards socio-economic development of any country was unquestionable.

The theme of the seminar is Aviation Development in Zambia.

"Aviation in Zambia plays a pivotal role in our economic development particularly that our country is a landlocked country with a vast geographical area," Mululu said.

Mululu said the aviation industry, being the fastest mode of transportation today, was also very instrumental in the conducting of world business such as tourism and general transportation.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


328 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Kaunda meets Mugabe


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri and Sundie Sinkala, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda and Liberal Progressive Font (LPF) chairman Rodger Chongwe will today meet Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe to seek SADC's intervention in Zambia's "political crisis".

President Mugabe, who is chairman of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) and Southern African Development Community's (SADC) defence and security committee, is being asked by Zambia's opposition alliance to intervene in time to stop what is happening in Congo Brazzaville and what took place in Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo) from taking place in Zambia.

Opposition Alliance chairman Chongwe and former president Kaunda will discuss the political situation in Zambia with President Mugabe. The meeting will take place this afternoon at State House in Harare. 

"We feel that SADC should play a major role in reconciling political leaders in this country so that they can resolve problems on the constitution and the electoral process," said Chongwe in an interview yesterday before he left for Harare. "We want to persuade President Mugabe to take the initiative regarding what is happening here as chairman of defence and security committee."

And reached for comment at his Avondale home MMD national secretary, minister without portfolio Michael Sata, asked the name of the reporter adding: "Thank you and goodbye" and cut the telephone line without hearing the query.

But MMD Lusaka Province chairman nominated member of parliament Christopher Chawinga pleaded tiredness after his trip to South Africa where he watched Zambia beaten 3-0.

"I have just come from South Africa. Let me rest. Get me tomorrow maybe I will comment," said Chawinga.

Chongwe revealed that the Opposition Alliance, which comprises UNIP, LPF, Labour Party, National Party, among others, appreciated the efforts initiated by IDEA, a Swedish Non- Governmental Organisation, but did not think it essential in resolving the conflict.

Chongwe, who insisted that his organisation wanted "to avoid what has happened in Zaire and what is happening in Congo Brazzaville" said such destruction is now happening in Zambia.

"We do not think that matters can be resolved by using umpires outside the region like he meeting in Sweden," Chongwe said. "We feel the initiative should come from leaders of this region because the political situation here is serious and is an African problem. Why should people fly all the way to Sweden in order to talk to each other. It shows how immature the current Zambian leaders are."

Other opposition leaders have supported the alliance in its move to get SADC involved in the political impasse.

"We agree and entirely abide by the decisions of the Opposition Alliance," said National Party vice-president Daniel Lisulo. "We should emphasize in the regional aspect but the problems with Africans they listen to European instead of fellow Africans. The problem is Chiluba. He doesn't want to listen to fellow Africans."

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy general secretary Azwell Banda, in an interview yesterday, said he has no doubt about the necessity for a regional solution to the political impasse in the country.

Banda said he sees the Swedish meeting as fitting the MMD - Consultative Group agenda which has no relevance to the problems in the country.

"These are matters which are capable of spilling over to neighbours so SADC must be involved. At the end of the day SADC may be the only organisations which can guarantee the regional solution," Banda said.

MMD and UNIP leaders who went to Sweden to set pace for a possible 'dialogue' were simply there for a picnic because the ruling party has a history of dishonesty, ZDC general secretary Derrick Chitala said in an interview yesterday.

Chitala, in a walk in interview yesterday, said the trip was uncalled-for because the issues of dialogue between the government and other political parties could still have been dealt with at home.

"The history of dealing with the MMD has been that of dishonesty and cheating at all times and Zambians are aware about this," Chitala said.

He said the controversial issues that need to be discussed are well- known and these are the 1996 constitution, the 1996 elections and the electoral process which the MMD subverted through trickery and fraud.

Chitala charged that the MMD was massively plundering and mismanaging the country's economy to the extent where donors have stopped giving the Zambia balance of payment support.

Chitala said there is no way the country could progress with the current economy and accused President Chiluba's government of dividing the country.

"There is looming hunger in the country because of food shortage and the government needs millions of United States dollars, which it unfortunately does not have, to bring in maize and fertiliser," Chitala said.

He reiterated ZDC's call for President Chiluba to resign and suggested that a national conference be called where Zambians will decide what next course to take.

Former UNIP secretary general and diplomat, Mainza Chona, yesterday described the MMD delegation to Sweden as not being "high powered" and that whatever was agreed there would not be upheld but thrown out by "forceful elements" within the party.

"Unless the donors are close to the MMD dialogue will not take off," Chona, said adding that church leaders must "put pressure on the MMD" to accept dialogue.

And UNIP member of the central committee for political and legal affairs Mwangala Zaloumis yesterday expressed disappointment with the MMD delegation to Sweden.

"I am disappointed with the MMD delegation. Opposition parties have gone to Sweden genuinely but the MMD motive seems to be fun," Zaloumis said, adding: "We hope we are not being used as guinea pigs."

And ZDC, in a press statement signed by the chairman of the legal and constitutional affairs, Wynter Kabimba, says the idea of going to Sweden to agree on the date and the need for dialogue had not been seriously considered by the party.

ZDC welcomed the initiative of the Swedish International Idea for a dialogue in the form an inter-party meeting but it did not want to be hoodwinked into a mere preliminary meeting ahead of the Consultative Group meeting scheduled next month.

"As petitioners of the elections on 1996, the ZDC was of the view that there was a great need to consult with the lawyers to determine and analyse the implication of a dialogue on the petition," the statement said.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Rwanda;
Southern African Catholic Bishops in Rwanda


BYLINE: Ronnie Mamba, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 107 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Four Catholic Bishops from the Southern Africa Catholic Bishops Conference are in Kigali, Rwanda on a peace mission. 

The team is led by the Catholic Bishop of Swaziland who is president of the conference, will deliver a papal message to Rwandese bishops.

This is the second such mission by the Bishops. They have also visited the Sudan earlier this year where they held talks with the various warring factions there. They return Thursday (June 12).

330 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga in budgetary crisis with R900-million deficit


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's provincial government cannot pass five of its departmental budgets for the 1997/ 98 fiscal year and is in budgetary crisis after discovering that it will have a deficit of more than R900-million unless the province receives additional funds from national government.

Although officials declined to speak about the crisis on Wednesday, NP members of a number of legislative select standing committees confirmed that they would be attending an emergency meeting of all committee chairmen on Thursday to address the problem. 

Select standing committees review and pass departmental budgets before they are ratified by the legislature.

"In just one department (education) for example, we are R400-million under budgeted. If the province is forced to cut back to conform to national expectations, then not one road, school, clinic or other facility will be built in Mpumalanga during 1997," explained NP leader, Dr Lucas Nel.

Nel added however that national government appeared "sincere" when it insisted that it did not have the additional necessary funds.

Mpumalanga received a R5-billion total budget for 1997/ 98, which is an effective 8,5% cut on last year's allocation.

For every one Rand of this year's budget, 92 cents is spent on salary and other recurrent expenditure.

Capital expenditure, such as the building of schools and roads has already been cut by 36% but will have to be cut almost completely if the additional R900-million deficit cannot be covered by national government.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sports - General;
South Africa's first speed hangliding this weekend


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

NGODWANA - South Africa's first speed hangliding competition will be held at Sappi's Nooitgedacht plantation outside Ngodwana in Mpumalanga this weekend.

Event organiser, Frank Jaschinski, said on Wednesday that at least 30 hangliders from across the country were expected to participate in the competition, which would run from Saturday morning to Monday evening. 

He said speed gliding had never been done in formal competitions in South Africa, but that recorded practise times were as low as 3 minutes 30 seconds over a distance of 2,8 kilometres at 2 100 feet.

"The pilots will be expected to fly around 19 pilons, similar to snow skiers on downhill speed races," he said.

Also included in the competition line-up are spot landings, where pilots have to navigate their hangliders to land on markings on the ground.

"The speed gliding and spot landings are technically demanding and are guaranteed to wow spectators," promised Jaschinski.

The speed gliding competition will be held each day of the competition from 8:30am to 11:30am.

Prizes for the speed racing include R2 000 for first place, R1 000 for second place and R500 for third place.

Non-competitive free style aerobatics will also be staged as a spectator event each day at dusk, after the gruelling cross country events of the afternoon.

For further details, Jaschinski can be reached at Lowveld Hangliding Classic on tel: (013) 7472084 or email: skyhigh@iafrica.com.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Chinese investors scout Swaziland's sugar industry


BYLINE: Banele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - A team of Chinese entrepreneurs is expected to tour Swaziland at the end of the month to conduct feasibility studies for sugar related benefication investment.

The pending trip was announced by Republic of China Ambassador to Swaziland, Enti Liu, at the opening of a three day Data Warehouse Conference and Expo at the Royal Swazi Sun Convention Centre on Tuesday. 

Ambassador Liu said that ROC had realised that it is time for governments to shift attention to the private sector.

"Government has done enough, now we are encouraging Chinese private companies to come into Swaziland and share ideas with their counterparts," he said.

Swaziland has seen Chinese businesses opening up in the recent past, a case in point being the Tuntex Company which is the biggest private enterprise to come into Swaziland for garment manufacturing.

He said ROC is not put off by the "sometimes rocky" democracisation process Swaziland is currently going through and said he believed that it is natural for every country.

"Eventually all the problems will be sorted out as long as there is understanding between government and the labour movement", he said.

333 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
South Africa's neighbours ponder EU link


BYLINE: Banele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Government officials from the Southern Africa Common Customs Area partners met In Mbabane on Monday to discuss the implications of South Africa's strengthening links with the European Union.

The one day conference of officials from Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland (BLNS) on Monday discussed a confidential report prepared by a Zimbabwean consultant. 

The countries fear that the development will affect the revenue derived from the customs union.

"Given the current on-going negotiations, we are also considering this in the context of implementation of negotiations of the SADC Trade Protocol," an official at the conference said.

The purpose of the conference is to listen to the findings of the report and "discuss and identify a way forward to ensure the protection of interests of Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland (BLNS)."

The conference which was also attended by SADC observer countries as well as the EU, looked at areas that are of particular concern to Swaziland and the rest of the region.

Swaziland as well as Botswana and Lesotho have had preferential trade access to the European Union markets through the Lome Conventions since their independence.

"However, it has been acknowledged that the implementation of an EU(SA Free Trade Agreement will have a significant impact on other SACU members in terms of reduced tariff revenues and competition with European imports," it said.

It said both the EU and South Africa have made it clear that they will consider the legitimate concerns of other SACU members during the negotiations of the FTA.

Although South Africa's entry into the EU will affect SACU member states, it is believed that Swaziland is likely to benefit in the longer term from the dynamic economic impact of an EU(SA Free Trade Agreement on the South African Region.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Top world sweetener eyes Swaziland


BYLINE: Banele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

MBABANE - (Swaziland) - Leading international sweetener, Tate & Lyle, is considering investing in at least new four business product lines in the sugar and food industries in Swaziland, Royal Swazi Sugar Corporation (RSSC) Operations Manager Brian Webb disclosed on Wednesday.

Webb said the unspecified but "significant" investment had been clinched during several meetings between RSSC and Tate & Lyle. 

The discussions follow an initial announcement by Tate & Lyle chairman, Sir Neil Shaw one year ago that the multi-national was keen in principle to expand its presence in Swaziland because of the kingdom's "proven expertise" in sugar production.

Sir Shaw made the commitment after a personal meeting with King Mswati III said at the time that a series of possible investments had already been identified.

"We believe that being so efficient, the industry would be a base for developing other food products," Webb agreed on Wednesday.

Tate & Lyle are a Britain based company with 4,5 billion pounds sterling turnover and operate primarily in Western Europe and North America.

In recent years however it has embarked on a heavy investment drive to find new markets in South East Asia, Eastern Europe, Central Europe and Africa.

Tate & Lyle already buys about 30% of sugar produced in Swaziland for its refineries in England, Portugal and the United States of America.

Tate & Lyle also has a small equity interest in the Royal Swazi Sugar Corporation and also manages the company through associates, Booker and Tate.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
VAT to be introduced at the Swaziland / SA border posts


BYLINE: Benele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Swaziland is to introduce Value Added Tax (VAT) following a favourable feasibility study assessing the impact of introducing the new taxation system in small land-locked kingdom.

Ministry of Finance acting Principal Secretary, Noreen Maphalala said on Wednesday that this is in line with other members of the South African Customs Department and that goods entering RSA from BLNS countries will now be subjected to VAT. 

"The reason for not previously imposing tax on goods from Swaziland over the years was because South Africa had not manned their border posts with customs officials," she said.

She added however that South Africa had recently identified border posts which would be manned by Customs officials who will collect all duties and taxes including VAT.

Meanwhile, RSA and all BLNS countries will soon meet to discuss the modalities of how the tax will be collected.

"Preliminary talks indicate that the tax is likely to be collected at the border posts.

336 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


South Africa;
NP says MDC chairman lied about family relationship


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga Development Corporation (MDC) chairman Jabu Mabuza "blatantly lied" about his relationship with the parastatal's disgraced chief executive officer Patrick Mogorosi, the National Party (NP) said on Tuesday.

Insisting during a press conference in Nelspruit that Mogorosi had married one of Mabuza's sisters, the NP's Mpumalanga whip Chris MacPherson questioned how this personal relationship had influenced the MDC's decision to keep a R300 000 "golden handshake" package to Mogorosi secret.

Mabuza has repeatedly denied any direct personal relations with Mogorosi, who resigned from the MDC earlier this year after being slated by an independent financial audit for "gross irregularities" and for tampering with various internal audits. 

"We find it very strange that the MDC decided to allow Mogorosi to resign without pressing criminal or other charges when both a Coopers & Lybrandt report and their own internal investigations had found him guilty of gross personal misspending. Instead, they secretly paid him R300 000 of tax payer's money and promised never to speak about it in public," said MacPherson.

"We find it even stranger that Mabuza claims not to know that this man was married to his sister. He actually lied by denying the link at previous conferences."

Mabuza again denied any family other personal relation to Mogorosi on Tuesday night and told African Eye News Service (South Africa) that he was "dumbfounded" by the NP's charges.

"I have sisters but they're either all still married or have never been married. Even my cousins are still married to their first husbands and none of these men is Mogorosi," he said.

Mabuza did concede that the MDC has chosen to settle its dispute with the former CEO by paying him out R300 000, plus an unspecified sum for pension fund contributions and accrued leave but stressed that it "was the cheapest way for us to close the book on this matter and Mogorosi agreed in return to leave without a fight".

Pointing out that it had already cost the MDC R354 000 just to initiate disciplinary action against Mogorosi, Mabuza said that the amount could have doubled if it had been fought out in court.

He also stressed that the additional irregular personal expenditure which had been uncovered during the disciplinary action had only totalled R5400.

Mogorosi incurred the amount by illegally using his MDC credit card to buy clothing while in the USA.

A letter from Mabuza to the MDC board shortly after the settlement also commented that by paying Mogorosi out, they were "containing employee, press and political fallout."

Calling the "containment" unconstitutional and contrary to the government's state policy of transparency, MacPherson also asked why more than four of the officials who helped blow the lid on the irregularities were still being prosecuted for "leaking" information to an official legislative oversight committee.

"The obvious message being sent out ... is that if you stand up against corruption or try to fight corrupt individuals in Mpumalanga you will be hounded out of a job and out of government," he said.

"But if you steal, if you lie and if you cheat, then at worst all you'll have to do is pay the money back. To reward you for doing this, we'll give you a large package and promise never to speak about it again."

The Auditor General's special investigation into both the MDC and Mogorosi's term at the parastatal is expected to be released within the next three weeks.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
