Africa News


June 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
South Africa, Libya and Lockerbie (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa has confirmed that it is willing to serve as a neutral venue for the trial of two Libyans accused of being behind the 1988 bombing of an airliner over Lockerbie in Scotland

Given Libya's isolated and controversial position in the world - the United Nations Security Council has unanimously imposed sanctions on the country because of its refusal to surrender for trial two men accused of being responsible for an explosion on board a Pan American jumbo jet over Lockerbie in Scotland in 1988 - any country entering into a new agreement with the regime of Colonel Muammar Gaddafi could engender some measure of international disapproval.

But judging from the remarks made by Libyan Foreign Minister Omar Muntasser when he signed a co-operation agreement in Pretoria this week, there is a new eagerness in Tripoli to see the Lockerbie issue settled once and for all and for sanctions against Libya to be lifted. This presents the South African Government with a unique opportunity to help bridge the chasm which now separates Libya from much of the rest of the international community. 

Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo remarked this week that South Africa supported Libya's insistence on a neutral venue for the trial of the two Libyans accused of having been behind the Lockerbie bombing and a government spokesman confirmed yesterday that, if approached, South Africa would be willing to provide such a venue. This could be the catalyst in bringing about a reconciliation between major Western countries and an economically and strategically important country in Africa - a development which would be of undoubted benefit to the continent and the international community.

The South African Government has demonstrated its skill at helping to resolve seemingly intractable diplomatic and political disputes and it should take the initiative in attempting to bring to a conclusion the longstanding tragedy of the Lockerbie bombing.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Cosatu throws down gauntlet


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede and Thabo Mabaso, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Cape Town - The Congress of SA Trade Unions' (Cosatu) one-day general strike has come and gone, but questions about the federation's true motives for the action linger.

Observers have asked whether Cosatu is fighting against provisions in the Basic Conditions of Employment Draft Bill or pressing its ruling alliance partner, the African National Congress (ANC), to renegotiate its Growth, Employment and Redistribution (Gear) strategy.

The federation's parliamentary officer, Neil Coleman, says the strike can be seen as a protest against the ANC Government's shift in economic policy.

"To the extent that the elements of the Basic Conditions of Employment Act is based on the prescriptions of Gear - to undermine protection for the vulnerable, rather than extending them basic rights - then I suppose our strike on Monday is also against Gear," Mr Coleman told a meeting two weekends ago. 

"We don't need to apologise for that."

He said it was legitimate for Cosatu to protest against Gear, because the strategy represented a fundamental shift in economic policy from that outlined in the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP).

Cosatu was the main architect of the RDP policy.

The Gear strategy,unveiled last year, among other things emphasises labour market flexibility and stringent control over the budget deficit by reducing it to three percent by 2000.

The strategy also envisages the creation of a million jobs and a six percent economic growth rate by the year 2000.

But Cosatu says the Gear policy will lead to job losses and has asked the Government to renegotiate the strategy.

President Mandela consistently has maintained that Gear is not negotiable.

He has said that his government would not be held to ransom in its efforts to improve people's lives by a small group within South African society.

Cosatu said it went on strike to protest at the non-inclusion of six months' maternity leave, with four months paid, and a 40-hour week, which would be phased in over five years, on the draft bill.

Labour law expert Gavin Brown, however, has told the Cape Argus that Cosatu was deceiving the public by making out as if it had a dispute with the business sector.

"This disagreement is simply a mask for a much bigger dispute between Cosatu and the Government," said Mr Brown.

He said the strike was used by Cosatu to tell the Government they were not happy with Gear and that the federation needed more say in formulating economic policies.

"It is a mistake to see this as a dispute between Cosatu and business," he said.

Yet, in spite of Mr Brown's assertion, the Department of Labour has chosen to send out different signals about its response to the dispute.

Labour Minister Tito Mboweni told Business Argus that legislating a 40-hour working week, to which he had committed himself in the past, was still a priority of the Government.

However, he said Cosatu's 40-hour week demand could not be implemented in one stroke.

"The 40-hour week is a historical demand of the working class," said Mr Mboweni.

"Whatever I think on a personal level, I don't work alone. I don't determine what market conditions are," he added.

Monday's strike was the third national stoppage since the 1994 elections which brought President Mandela's government to power.

That there have been problems between Cosatu and the SA Communist Party, on the one hand, and the ANC on the other, is an open secret that appears to have strained relations in the alliance.

At issue has been the Government's economic policies and the pace of delivering essential relief to disadvantaged communities.

The secretaries of the Western Cape region of Cosatu and SACP, Tony Ehrenreich and Phillip Dexter respectively, openly admitted this during a National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union meeting last month.

The extent of the odds at which the alliance partners are, was demonstrated by the fact that the SACP fully supported the strike and hardly a whisper was heard from the ANC.

During Cosatu's march to Parliament last week, ANC leaders were notable by their absence.

The SACP went further and publicly chastised the ANC in a statement and said it had abandoned its constituency which consisted mainly of the poor and the working class.

"The SACP expresses its solidarity and support for the Cosatu 24-hour strike tomorrow," the party's central committee said in the statement.

"All attempts to block workplace democratisation in the name of competitiveness, flexibility or growth must be resisted," it added.

In spite of the reported problems in the alliance, Cosatu secretary- general Sam Shilowa has denied an impending break-up of relations among the partners.

"The alliance is united on the need to eradicate apartheid at the workplace and to extend worker rights and conditions that have systematically been denied over many years of oppression and exploitation," said Mr Shilowa.

Despite the apparent damage the disagreements have done to the alliance, Cosatu has stood its ground and threatened another strike if business does not accept its point of view on the draft bill.

"If they want to take a hard line, this is not a one-way street. We'll also take a hard line to challenge them," Mr Shilowa has said.

"If they have nerves to continue the argument around workers' basic rights we will use our steel nerves to fight them."

The debate over the draft bill has, however, taken an unexpected turn with the employer organisation, Business South Africa (BSA), saying last week that negotiations on the bill should be suspended until after the presidential job summit set for October.

BSA deputy president Leslie Boyd has said business was concerned that some aspects of the draft bill could have a bearing of the summit and therefore slow job creation.

Sources close to Cosatu have told the Cape Argus that the federation had expected business to take a hard line against the federation demands and did not expect a proposal to stall the negotiations until the job summit.

The sources said Cosatu would hold an executive committee meeting later this month to formulate a response to business's proposal.

Whatever the outcome of the Cosatu executive committee meeting on June 24, or business' response to the federation demands, one question that begs answering is how much hammering the South African economy can take, while parties settle old scores.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


South Africa;
Cattle slaughter plan after KTC attack


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - A top secret document sent to the State Security Council on the first day of the three-day "witdoeke" attack on the KTC squatter camp asked for R3 000 for a "victory feast" for the witdoeke in the form of a ritual cattle slaughter.

The document, dated June 9 1986, was sent from the Western Province Joint Management Committee (JMC) - the regional structure of the shadowy, nationwide security system of the former government.

It continued: "Finality, however, will not be reached before June 11 1986, when we will be in contact again." By that date, several thousand shacks in KTC had been razed and an estimated 60 000 of its residents were refugees. 

The document was one of several "top secret" and "secret" communications between the State Security Council and regional security structures which were submitted to the Truth Commission yesterday on the final day of its three-day "special event" hearing focusing on violence in informal settlements in the Peninsula in 1985/86.

In May and June 1986, KTC and three satellite squatter camps were attacked by witdoeke - also known as "fathers" or the conservatives - who were mostly from Crossroads and who owed allegiance to conservative leaders such as Crossroads mayor Johnson Ngxobongwana.

The police and other state officials have consistently denied colluding with the witdoeke in the attacks - also in their testimony during a Supreme Court action for damages by homeless squatters.

But some truth commissioners and a member of the commission's human rights violations committee said the secret documents provided clear evidence that the state had been directly involved in the conflict, which cost at least 57 lives.

Commissioner Mapule Ramashala said the June 9 document referred to a specific celebration anticipating victory for the witdoeke.

"It places the hand of the state right squarely in the middle of it (the conflict) This document in fact confirms complicity (in) the annihilation of the satellites, including KTC."

Commissioner Dumisa Ntsebeza, who heads the commission's investigative unit, commented afterwards: "It is quite clear in my mind that there was that kind of involvement by the State Security Council."

Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, a member of the commission's human rights violations committee who organised the KTC hearing, said both the documents and the forthright testimony by former Crossroads town clerk Ricky Shelhase yesterday had indicated that the state had been trying to create "a kind of bantustan" at Crossroads.

"It is very clear that the government was manipulating the violence, setting up the two groups ("comrades" and "witdoeke") and then pulling back so that it seemed like a war."


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Big business adds muscle to war on Cape crime


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - Western Cape Police Minister Gerald Morkel has warned criminals there will be an all-out war on their activities now that big business has joined the fight against crime.

At the launch of the Business Against Crime initiative at a Green Point hotel last night, Mr Morkel said the partnership between the police and the business sector was necessary to stop crime. 

"This is the first time organised business at the highest level has officially accepted that they have a vital role to play in this war we are fighting against criminals. These businessmen bring with them the expertise and skills which in conjunction with our police service must effectively fight crime," he said.

Prominent banker Mike Thompson, who was elected chairman of the initiative, said the time had come for the streets of Cape Town to reflect what most of its citizens wanted - safety and peace.

A four-pronged "attack" which had already been implemented in Gauteng, KwaZulu Natal and the Eastern Cape would now be launched in the Western Cape, he said.

"This four-pronged strategy will include fighting crime, researching and advising the government on legislative measures and developing initiatives to secure economic upliftment and community rehabilitation," said Mr Thompson.

Mr Thompson said that although they had the overwhelming support of the bid company and many of their objectives were the same as those of Chris Ball's team, the initiative was in response to President Mandela's plea that business play its part in fighting crime.

Paul Daniel from His People Church in Rondebosch, who was elected to handle the portfolio on community rehabilitation, said crime transcended religious and ideological differences. "The goal is crime rehabilitation and we will be working right from grassroots up to the prisons in the Western Cape."


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
SA the peacemaker tackles Libyan deal


BYLINE: Political Staff, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa's success in helping to resolve international disputes may soon be followed by an effort to get United Nations sanctions against Libya lifted.

This could be done by South Africa offering to provide a neutral venue for the trial of two Libyans accused of the 1988 bombing of an American airliner over Lockerbie in Scotland.

A Department of Foreign Affairs spokesman confirmed yesterday that, if approached, South Africa would be willing to provide such a venue. 

This follows the signing in Pretoria earlier this week of a co- operation agreement with Libya, and South Africa's initiatives in resolving disputes in Zaire, Angola, Mozambique and Northern Ireland.

At the signing of the agreement Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo and Libyan Foreign Minister Omar Mustafa Muntasser both referred to the Lockerbie bombing.

More than 250 people were killed when a Pan American jumbo jet exploded over the Scottish village of Lockerbie while en route to New York.

Libya, which has been sheltering the two men suspecting of being behind the bombing, has refused to hand them over for trial in either Britain or the United States, instead insisting on a neutral venue. The United Nations Security Council responded by unanimously imposing wide- ranging sanctions on Libya.

Mr Muntasser said this week that Libya was offering South Africa access to its crude oil - something specifically banned by UN sanctions - and said Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi could visit South Africa by the end of this year "if sanctions are lifted".

Under UN sanctions no country may assist in the flight of airliners to or from Libya.

South Africa supports an Organisation of African Unity resolution which backed Libya's call for a neutral venue for a trial of the Libyan suspects under Scottish law and with Scottish judges presiding.

Last year, The Hague - seat of the International Court of Justice - was suggested as a trial venue but this was rejected by the US. The constitution of the World Court does not allow it to hear criminal cases.

Foreign Affairs spokesman Pieter Swanepoel yesterday denied speculation in diplomatic circles that South Africa had already offered a trial venue.

But he confirmed that South Africa was willing to provide a neutral venue if asked.

A spokesman for the US embassy in Pretoria said that to the best of his knowledge there had been no communication between the South African government and Washington about such an offer.

The US had consistently asked Libya to comply with a 1991 UN resolution that the suspects should be handed over for trial.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Putting the world in the picture about South Africa


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Cape Town - It is difficult to categorise Daniel Silke. Too practical to be just an academic, too academic to be just a political dilettante and too honest-looking to be just a politician, he is a bit of all these and perhaps more.

A political analyst is how he would probably be described, one who has lectured on South Africa at universities, colleges, schools and think-tanks overseas.

"Explaining South Africa to the world has become my business," says Silke, whose academic background is in politics and political philosophy. 

"But I have also knocked on doors and campaigned and listened to people's problems in their homes (he stood as a candidate in the ward of Woodstock in the 1994 election).

"It's all very well to study politics in its academic form ... but frankly, there's a different world on the street, and the experience I gained from being a political candidate was probably one of the more humbling experiences of my life."

Silke has just returned from a cruise on board the Crystal Symphony, lecturing on South African politics (he lectured on two other cruise ships previously).

He tells me that he enjoys the interaction with the cruise passengers, and it's not difficult to see why.

A devoted Democratic Party member, newly elected city councillor and ardent protagonist of liberal values, Silke talks easily and is easy to talk to.

There is an insatiable interest in South Africa overseas, and everywhere this country is regarded as having made a successful transition from minority government to a multiparty democracy, he says.

"There is a standard three-course lecture series that I offer cruise companies - it is an introduction to South African politics ... there is a bit of history about the development of apartheid, a bit about contemporary South Africa and the new constitution, and then some crystal-ball gazing."

The last part draws the most response and is also a lot of fun, says Silke.

"As you know, everyone is their own political analyst and their own political fortune-teller, and the fun is to see whether my predictions tally with yours."

He laughs when asked whether he would like to share some of his predictions.

"One of the questions I am asked most often, and not surprisingly, is about a South Africa without Mandela.Will the country be able to hold together and not disintegrate into chaos and anarchy?"

Given that the African National Congress will in all likelihood be the majority party after 1999, we will probably see a fairly smooth transition to a new ANC leadership, he predicts.

"If (our new leader ) is to be (Thabo) Mbeki, I think we are going to see a smooth seamless move towards an Mbeki presidency which will have different characteristics to that of Mandela."

Our biggest problems and "critical issues" are going to be economic growth and the development of a free market policy that encourages foreign investment, he says.

On the omnipresent subject of crime, he worries that apart from the physical threat which affects "every person in South Africa on a daily basis", far worse is a process which demoralises "young and upwardly mobile South Africans who are able to emigrate" and causes people to withdraw from the community and to "bury their heads in the sand".

"There is too much focus on emigration prospects and too little devoted to constructive work within our own communities" says Silke, who advocates that young people "become involved, as participation leads to major rewards".

No one can accuse him of not practising what he preaches.

He serves on a local police forum, which he says helps him to better understand the problem of crime and "gives me encouragement and a degree of control" over the problem.

Recently elected as chairman of the Association of Liberal Democratic Councillors of South Africa, he claims that this country "desperately needs to apply liberal philosophies to governance".

"My interest in liberal politics began when I was about 13 when I joined the then Progressive Federal Party.

"More than half of my life (he is now 32) has been spent attached to one political party and working and actively campaigning for that party."

He is currently branch chairman of the Democratic Party in the Atlantic suburbs area and serves on various party bodies.

He is convinced that South Africa needs a resurgence of liberal values and a move away from ethnically based politics if it is to survive.

"We need to promote the individual as the cornerstone of society... that's something that is very important for me - the right to be an individual, the right to think what I want to, the right to dissent (very important in South Africa) and these go hand in hand with the free market economic policy, controlled privatisation and with preserving multiparty democracy in South Africa."

Africa News


June 12, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Commission: The awful truth


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - A photograph of three policemen posing hunter-style, one with his foot on their "trophy" - the body of a man killed in political violence - is proof that security forces treated black people "like animals" under apartheid.

This assessment comes today from Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, a member of the Truth Commission's human rights violations committee, after viewing photographs given to the Cape Argus by a Mitchell's Plain man.

The man, whose moral conscience was fired by the TRC's "special event" hearing this week into violence in the Peninsula's informal settlements in 1985 and 1986, said the photographs were taken in KTC while it was being destroyed by "witdoeke" (conservatives) in 1986. 

The man, a rigger by trade, acquired a set of photographs from a friend who worked at a picture processing business. They appear to have been taken by a policeman or soldier during the conflict.

The pictures, nearly all of which are too gruesome to publish, show victims who have been hacked to death with sharp instruments and "necklace" victims - some reduced to charred bones and others still alight. Other pictures show securityforce members with several bodies on the ground next to them and victims with hack wounds being taken to an ambulance.

One of the worst shows three policemen, armed with shotguns, clearly posing hunter-style with their "trophy", the body of a black man.

Truth Commission staff who were given a brief glimpse of some of the pictures yesterday said they did appear to have been taken around KTC.

The man, who gave the Cape Argus his name, contacted the newspaper this week. He said he had no problem with giving all his particulars to the TRC and asked to be put in touch with its investigators.

The Cape Argus today handed enlargements of some of the photographs to Truth Commissioner Dumisa Ntsebeza, who said the photographs would be useful - "especially because we are looking at expanding (our evidence) on the State Security Council connection with violence in the area".

Ms Gobodo-Madikizela said similar pictures had been presented at the inquiry earlier this year into the deaths of the so-called "Guguletu Seven", shot dead by police in 1985.

The photograph of the three policemen "demonstrates very clearly the brutality of the police, and the animalisation of black bodies that was so common at the time".

"It reflects the attitude of the police at the time, so it adds a very important dimension to our understanding."

If the photographs had been taken in KTC/Crossroads, they would be of use in the commission's inquiry, she added.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
Congo war bad for democracy - Chiluba


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - President Chiluba yesterday condemned the perpetrators of violence in Congo-Brazaville saying they should have waited for elections scheduled for next month.

Mr Chiluba said perpetrators of violence should have waited to be democratically elected instead of resorting to violence as a way of coming to power. 

He said the issue of violence in Congo was disturbing especially that it came at a time when the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) was calling for peace in Africa for it to develop.

He was speaking when the Congolese ambassador to Zambia, Celestin Goma-Fouton presented his credentials at State House.

Mr Chiluba appealed to the OAU to quickly find a peaceful solution to Congo to avoid loss of more lives.

Mr Goma-Fouton assured President Chiluba that he would strive to explore new areas of cooperation in Zambian businessmen to exchange goods with their counterparts in Congo.

Meanwhile, President Chiluba said Africa should strive to have governments founded on democracy where the stakeholders were involved in the running of the countries.

Mr Chiluba said Africa has numerous problems like international debt servicing which required consented efforts of all citizens to try and find resources to service the huge debts.

Mr Chiluba said Africa has a long history of mismanagement and a lot needed to be done to develop it.

He was speaking when the Cape Verde ambassador to Zambia Manuell da Rosa presented his credentials at State House.

Earlier, Mr da Rosa told President Chiluba Africa should start applying the OAU resolutions so that the economic integration could be a reality.

He said economic integration of the region was the only hope to development.- Zana.

384 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
It's all lies, says Prof Siwela


BYLINE: Janet Ilunga, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Lusaka - Embattled University of Zambia (Unza) vice chancellor Andrew Siwela has maintained his administration currently facing charges of embezzlement and mismanagement is clean and dismissed the allegations as blatant lies.

Professor Siwela, leading a delegation which included his deputy Jorry Mwenechanya, registrar Michael Tandeo and bursar Mafukeni Tembo also heaped the blame on Government for the ungovernable state of the campus because of its non-committal stance towards serious issues.

Prof Siwela, 50, Mwenechanya, Tandeo and Tembo all 41, appeared jointly before the Bobby Bwalya Commission of Inquiry yesterday and said most of the allegations could be substantiated with supporting documents but striking university workers had denied them access to their offices.

The two professors, Siwela and Mwenechanya said their controversial 25 per cent shares in Zamnet Communications System were held in trust because the two had a primary objective to ensure quality service to academics. 

And that by virtue of being a board member Health Minister Katele Kalumba was offered 12.5 per cent.

They named other board members as the director of the computer centre, former Zamtel managing director Swathulani Munthali, Siwela, Mwenechanya, the registrar and bursar.

They said in submissions which took a whole day the relationship between Zamnet and the university was strictly business as evidenced by the rent collected from Zamnet and Unza subscriptions.

On the alleged disappearance of dividends from York Farm, Prof Siwela confirmed management claimed an amount of K654m and were proposing to council to use the money to liquidate a $2.2m Government loan obtained to buy the farm.

He said Unza partners Commonwealth Development Corporation (CDC) held 17 per cent in shares and that after injection of $4.1m into operations CDC's shareholding would increase to 51 and Unza 49 per cent.

However a manager a Mr Youngson was being paid $25,000 per month to run the farm.

Mr Tembo said it was justifiable for the institution to hold numerous accounts considering it handled amounts close K14.5bn and maintained the accounts were currently 36 and not 48.

He said the K45m was paid to Carpet Centre Travel agency to clear a debt of K56m owed in air tickets.

Prof Siwela said all the allegations levelled against him which included an aborted trip to Livingstone in which he received K7m and Ghana, were lies and aimed at destroying his personal reputation.

"I am being called a thief and blasted left, right and centre but these allegations are all lies. And all this information is filtering to the international audience through Internet. This is a perfect recipe to destroy an academic institution," Prof Siwela said with a quiver.

He pleaded with chairman Bwalya to protect management against further humiliation from unruly workers who seemed to disrespect the commission's existence by denying the principal officers access to their offices.

He added that Government should urgently review the Health Services Act to recognise the University Teaching Hospital as a centre for medical training.

Mr Tembo recommended that Government should without delay establish a loans and scholarships board which should be a semi-autonomous to institute a more sustainable mode of student funding.

On student welfare, Mr Tandeo said to decongest the university, expansion of distant education should be promoted while some existing higher education institutions should be transformed to offer university programmes.

Mr Mwenechanya said to improve the working atmosphere at the institution Government should urgently consider the proposed scheme for the sale of houses to staff.

He said Government's delay to respond had resulted in mistrust of management by staff thus lowering their working morale Prof Siwela defended Health Deputy Minister Nkandu Luo for continuing to teach despite resigning to pursue politics as she did so because of the acute shortage of lecturers adding that pathology head of department Dr Cecilia Shinondo should have been more diplomatic on the matter.

Management said Government lent a deaf ear to their requests citing that salary negotiations for all category of staff had stalled because Government had not furnished them with the negotiation sealing causing anxieties among workers.

Government had not approved a university home ownership scheme, strategic plan 2001 and was dilly-dallying over student finance review resulting in student unrest and bursaries owing the institution about K454m.

Prof Siwela charged that the ministry was leaking documents to staff and students and said the permanent secretary had alienated the institution by not attending Unza council sittings on which he was member.

He said the leaking of documents was the source of the last week's strike by general workers.

During questions, the commissioners demanded to know why the librarian had been sidelined yet in the Act stipulated he was a principal officer to which Prof Siwela replied, the office had nothing to offer to central management.

He said historically the office had been excluded from management and said the librarian was only complaining because he envied the fringe benefits other principal officers like the vice chancellor enjoyed.

"Quite frankly I do not see what he (the librarian) can contribute to central administration. His job is just to manage a unit," Justice Bwalya adjourned the submissions to today.

And a former secretary to the bursaries committee said problems at Unza and Copperbelt University (CBU) could have been avoided if the two vice-chancellors had time for members of staff and students.

Mr Patson Simwawa said in a written submission to the Unza/CBU Commission of Inquiry that during his tenure he observed that the two vice-chancellors had no time to attend to students and staff.

Most often senior staff were not consulted over important issues leaving them to discover only through the Press.

He lamented that administration had a tendency to dissociate itself from student funding claiming that it was strictly between the sponsors and sponsored.

He said this was wrong as when disruption of studies occurred because of non-payment or delayed allowances administration was quick to move in and close the institutions.

Mr Simwawa also blamed Government for making contact with students only when there was a crisis.

"Ministry of Education should be more open and always tell the truth. They should not act under pressure and only in a crisis as is always the case," he said.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Zambia;
University Strike (Editorial)


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - The striking workers at the university of Zambia Great East Road campus in Lusaka have acted irrationally by persisting with the strike in which they are demanding the removal of the entire administration.

It is strange that while a Government appointed commission of inquiry is gathering evidence on the problems of the institution and that of the Copperbelt University, the employees have elected to go on strike.

Among their demands include the call to President Chiluba to intervene in the crisis. 

But it is President Chiluba who appointed the current commission of inquiry that is probing the problems of the university, how else would they want the matter resolved? We feel that workers have taken the matter too far. If they have a case at all it is positive to allow the current commission to finish its task.

Demanding the removal of an administration using rather unorthodox means is not the humane way of resolving issues.

by appointing the commission of inquiry Government recognised that there was a problem at Unza that needed a lasting solution. We do not think the Unza workers will achieve anything by trying to use short cuts.

We feel that by insisting with the strike the employees are creating a crisis where there is none. Making the institution ungovernable at the moment is no solution in anyway.

In fact after the employees blocked management from going into offices police should have moved in to restore order.

Whether or not the workers have a case, there is no excuse in resorting to hooliganism. Moreover the current arbitrator over the Unza saga is the commission of inquiry.

The workers are still free to go and testify, otherwise the most positive thing to do now is to call off the strike and allow management officials that have been barred to go to the offices and begin work.

Unza has enough problems without creating any more. The continued strike will delay progress being made on the efforts to seek solutions on the issues there.

Already a lot has been lost by the continued closure of the institution. It is with this in mind we appeal to the University of Zambia Workers Union (Unzawu) to restrain its militant members and advise them that there is a more rational way to seek a solution to the problem at Unza.

The union should entice members to do one thing sensible; call off the strike and allow sanity to return to the campus.

Unrealistic demands are not just hollow but will retard progress made and just delay the reopening of the university.

For the moment the strike is unjustified the earlier it is called off the better. Enough damage has bee caused to the institution the intergrity of its administrators and the workers too.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sports - General;
Boxer Chingangu London bound


BYLINE: Timothy Sichela, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's Commonwealth heavyweight hopeful Joseph Chingangu leaves for London tonight for next Tuesday's crack at the 'club' title against Briton Julius Francis.

Boxing Board of Control (BBC) chairman Hilary Matyola who confirmed the departure in Lusaka yesterday, said Chingangu flies out with his trainer Mike Zulu.

Matyola said Chingangu, whose camp received two tickets from British promoter Frank Maloney on Tuesday, was ready for the 12-rounder set for Grondy Park Chesnont. 

"Chingangu, whom I've seen train, is more than ready for the fight. We hope that he wins so that he gives the Zambians something to cheer about after last weekend's soccer debacle in South Africa," Matyola said.

The BBC chief said the new Sport, Youth and Child Development Permanent Secretary Gerald Nyirenda who flies to London on business on Saturday would watch the fight.

Chingangu, the Iron Nkhoma Promotions boxer, has been in intensive training at Evelyn Hone college gymnasium in Lusaka for about a month under Zulu and Alpha Kasonde.

The Zambian heavyweight boxer-who out of his 17 professional fights has won 15, 12 of which were knock outs and lost two- admitting that he knew nothing about his opponent, said he was ready for the fight.

"I am ready for the fight as I am set to make a new beginning in my career.

The junior IBF title I won last year was just there to fool me into believing I was a world champion I never was," Chingangu said.

Chingangu and Francis were chosen from 13 top contenders, who included Lenox Lewis, to fight for the title which fell vacant after British boxer Scott Welch failed to defend it.

Chingangu is the second Zambian after light welterweight Felix Bwalya, who lost on points, to fight for the 'Club' title in two months. In his last fight, Chingangu knocked out Zimbabwean Anderson Saizi in the second round last December.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Wanderers whacked fifth time around


BYLINE: Melody Mwala at Arthur Davies stadium, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Power (1) 3 Wanderers (0) 1 MUFULIRA Wanderers loss to Power Dynamos in Kitwe yesterday, the league champion's fifth consecutive defeat left more questions than answers.

Is everything alright at Wanderers? Wanderers were disappointing, disjointed in all departments and their supporters were left admiring the swift Power side extend their lead at the top of the table.

Not even the inclusion of internationals Paul Chellah and Nelson Banda could redeem Wanderers who allowed Power to dominate the afternoon earlier thought would be used to open a new leaf. 

Wanderers who have not won a game since losing to Zamalek in the African Club champions league match two months ago, only helped Power extend their unbeaten run and points tally to 23 in nine outings.

Veteran Linos Makwaza's header in the 20th minute sent Wanderers on the slippery road to defeat before Peter Chitila and Douglas Chiwaya sealed the victory in the 73rd and 89th minutes respectively.

Wanderer's face saver came through substitute Boscher Chibwe who caught Power goalkeeper Pelewe Delamogo off guard in the 80th.

Chibwe, relatively unknown, had come in for another recruit Leo Mukwasa at change ends.

Wanderers goalkeeper Collins Mbulo was sent off after a crude tackle on Simon Mwansa in the box which earned Power a penalty neatly tacked away by Chitila.

Mbulo's departure left Wanderers one man down after referee John Commander of Luanshya who ruled the foul constituted dangerous play.

The Wanderers bench could not hide their anxiety and quickly sacrificed Banda to infuse in reserve goalkeeper Charles Mwila.

Mwila was later to concede two goals as Wanderers slipped to defeat.

While Peter Kaumba, the Power trainer was expressing happiness, Wanderers coach George Lwandamina said the loss was very painful and unfortunate because the players were playing like were protesting.

Wanderers disciples revealed that Lwandamina whose team lost 4 - 2 to Zamsure soon after the Zamalek 6 - 2 aggregate defeat, 2 - 1 to Lifebuoy Strikers and 2 - 0 to Nchanga Rangers had been given the Power game to win or else...

Sources said the Wanderers executive held a meeting with players at which Lwandamina was top on the agenda.

The fans trooped out of stadium wandering what had befallen their team.

Zamsure 2 Rangers 2 At Woodlands stadium in Lusaka, Zamsure and Nchanga Rangers battled to a 2 - 2 draw after some intelligent play displayed by the visitors, reports TIMOTHY SICHELA.

Zamsure, enjoying home ground advantage scored first through Kelvin Mutambo after only 12 minutes of play after White Mbewe was brought down for a penalty.

But Laughter Chilembi equalised four minutes later, sending the match into an exciting climax as both teams fought head on.

Zamsure however shrugged off a Rangers challenge and took the lead in the 39th through defender Kingsley Ntosha and they were not so lucky when their foe Daddley Fichite split the points in the 46th minute.

The match between Roan United and City of Lusaka at Kafubu stadium in Luanshya was not played.

City said they were only informed about the encounter yesterday morning which made it impossible for them to travel to Luanshya.

Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
British Airways launches new identity concept


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - British Airways (BA) has changed its corporate identity as part of the *1bn investment in new services, aircraft, facilities and training in the next three years.

BA displayed its new image in Zimbabwe, London, New York, Dubai, Bombay, Bangkok, Australia, France, Germany and Hong Kong on Tuesday, June 10.

The launch of the new concept of the company, dubbed "painting the skies" was centred on donning of its aircrafts' tails in colours and designs derived from different destination countries. 

New paint technologies, new processes and advanced technology have been harnessed by a team of 36 BA engineering paint technicians to convert the original designs from sketchpad to the skies.

At the core of the new identity is the use of the original world images, which have been applied to the tails of 308 aircraft in the BA fleet. The aim is to represent BA as a community passionately committed to serving the communities of the world.

The launch in Africa was characterised by pomp and splendour at Victoria Falls town in Zimbabwe where a BA aircraft painted with a Japanese design was flown over the Victoria Falls which is shared with Zambia.

The Zimbabwe event coincided with the unveiling of the recently announced Comair service. In London the event involved unveiling of newly painted aircraft at Heathrow.

BA chief executive, Bob Ayling, noted that the world was getting smaller, technology was changing the way people communicated and competition was getting tougher but most important of all was that expectations of customers had changed and so BA had to change its identity accordingly.

Under the *6bn investment for the next three years, 43 new aircraft would join the airline's fleet including 29 Boeing 747-400s, nine 777 and five 757s.

Hundreds of millions of pounds would be spent during this period on new services and products, new routes, a new approach to customer service and new ways of working with employees, all aimed at providing better levels of service.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambia's export earnings plummet 20 pc


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's total export earnings last year plummeted by 19.5 per cent and Government has been urged to get out of its slumber and help draw strategies for the business community to flood the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) with Zambian goods.

Speakers at the Economics Association of Zambia (EAZ) monthly discussion decried that Zambia always lagged behind in exploiting export opportunities to markets where the country had great advantages such as Congo-Kinshasa had become after the political changes there.

In 1995 Zambia's total export earnings including copper and cobalt amounted to $1,237,980,000 but this fell to $996,755,022. The decline was attributed to the decline in production of copper and cobalt. 

Export Board of Zambia (EBZ) director, Mutale Musonda, said the DRC was Zambia's single largest market in the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) region with 37 per cent of total non- traditional exports (NTEs) going to that country in 1996.

The DRC was followed by Zimbabwe at 29 per cent. There was urgent need for the Zambian Government to conclude bilateral trade agreements with the DRC to ensure a firm grip on the Congo-Kinshasa market.

Other countries with which Zambia must conclude bilateral trade agreements are South Africa and Zimbabwe.

Out of total NTE earnings of $242,555,022 the Comesa region represented $88,241,985 of which the DRC was highest at $32,848,092 compared to Zimbabwe's $25,479,845.

"The DRC is currently Zambia's largest single market. The potential that the market presents is far from exhausted and the onus is on Zambian business to attack the market much more aggressively.

"To improve trade relations with the DRC it would be extremely useful and beneficial for Zambia if a bilateral trade agreement were entered into as soon as possible," Mr Musonda said.

Zambia Association of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) chief executive, Gideon Phiri, echoed Mr Musonda's sentiments and warned that Zambia was not ready at present to exploit its full potential in the Congo market.

South Africa, Zimbabwe and Mozambique were now looking north and Zambia must move fast to dominate the DRC market but Government must lead the way by putting in place the vital trade agreement for business to take over.

The rich Shaba province of the DRC has a population of nine million people and that was a huge market for Zambia.

There was need for establishment of a Zambian bank in Lubumbashi to facilitate financial transactions, business people must build factories and warehouses close to the border with Shaba province of the DRC.

Alex Mwanakasale from the Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNUF) said 70 per cent of Zambia's exports to the DRC comprised agricultural products including maize, mealie meal, cotton lint, eggs, chickens, chicks, stockfeeds, beef, potatoes, sugar and onions. The exports go to Shaba province which has a population of nine million people.

Out of the $32.8m worth of exports to DRC in 1996, $25m or 76 per cent were agricultural products : Sugar $16.6m, maize $6.6m, mealie meal $0.98m and other products $0.9m.

Government must ensure that it hammers out customs formalities with its DRC counterpart for standard business to flourish between the two countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


390 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian Economics Association condemns fuel hike


BYLINE: Choongo Moonga, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The 24 per cent fuel hike effected yesterday will distort the Zambian economy which was cementing its stability, the Economics Association of Zambia (EAZ) has said.

The EAZ believes the National Oil Company's (NOC's) reasons for the increase were not convincing, taking into account that economic indicators were reflecting stability. 

The monthly inflation rate running below 25 per cent last month, and exchange rates having been stable were signs of an improved economic performance.

EAZ chief executive Amos Nakalonga said in Lusaka yesterday that the NOC could be unduly spreading their operational problems to the ordinary citizens.

"It is unfair for National Oil Company to start spreading its own problems to the ordinary Zambians. The cost of living has already been too high in Zambia.

"It is likely to distort the general economic performance of Zambia because the hike is too high. We have not seen a fuel increase of this much before," Mr Nakalonga said.

The factories would be equally affected because the cost of production automatically goes up and therefore, their products would be more expensive. Fuel was a major input in any process of production.

"Personally, I think the increase is unjustifiable. The company has been pouring money inTO sports, creating problems for itself. And now they want to use the public to offset their losses. It's disgusting," he said.

The NOC increased prices of all petroleum products by 24 per cent, attributing it to the upward adjustment of refining and pumping rates by Indeni Petroleum Refinery and Tazama Pipelines to cater for capital maitntenance costs.

The NOC claimed the petroleum price adjustments had not been reflecting the obtaining international prices and costs.


LOAD-DATE: June 13, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


West Africa;
Gambia, Senegal Confer On Border Security


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA)- Gambia and Senegal reaffirmed Friday the need to tighten frontier security as a measure against organized cross-border criminal activity. 

This commitment came at a ministerial meeting in Dakar, the Senegalese capital, between the two neighbouring countries. The meeting was part of the itinerary of the two-day visit Thursday by Gambian Interior Minister Mamadou Bojang.

"Development is impossible without security", Bojang said.

Senegal's Armed Forces Minister Cheikh Hamidou Kane called for more frequent meetings. Both ministers said that the socio-cultural heritage common to Gambia and Senegal should help in building trust between the two countries.

LANGUAGE: English

392 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Uganda;
Drought Slows Down Uganda Economic Growth


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Uganda's economic growth dropped to 5 percent this fiscal year from 6.5 in the 1995-96 period, the country's Finance Minister Jehoash Mayanja Nkangi announced in Kampala on Thursday.

In his budget speech read in parliament, Nkangi blamed the decline on drought and the cassava mosaic virus, which led to food shortages.

Mayanja Nkangi said the average rate of inflation for 1996/97 was expected to be around 7.5 percent, up from 6 percent. 

However, the minister expects the economic growth for next fiscal year to be 7 per cent and inflation 5 percent.

In his speech, exerpts of which reached PANA on Friday, the minister announced a stringent budget in which he slashed government expenditure by an average of 23 percent from last year's actual expenditure.

Overall internally funded government expenditure is budgeted to be 922 billion Uganda shillings, a drop from 1,203 billion spent during the 1996/97 fiscal year (excluding taxes paid by the government). (1 USD=1000 U sh)

He also froze wage increases for civil servants and vowed not to allow supplementary expenditure during the new financial year.

The minister also attributed to the drop in economic growth to unusually heavy rains in Western Uganda and the low coffee prices for the I996/97 season.

There were no major tax increases except a 20 percent increase on vehicle licence fees.

Mayanja Nkangi announced modest reduction of about 10 percent in fuel duty, petrol to 215 percent and the diesel and paraffin to 160 percent and 105 percent respectively.

He said this has been done to check smuggling of petrol products into the country. Excise duties on soft drinks were reduced by 20 percent to 30 percent and beer by five percent to 65 percent. Value Added Tax (VAT) remains almost the same.

Maximum import duty was reduced from 30 percent to 20 percent. Excise surcharges on imports will be harmonised at 10 percent.

The Minister also proposed amendments to the Investment Code, abolishing tax holidays and introducing a low uniform corporation tax rate of 30 percent with generous depreciation provisions.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


393 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Limited Food Distribution Starts In Freetown


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The united Nations World Food Programme (WFP) says it expects to start Friday a limited relief food distribution in Sierra Leone, where the army seized power on May 25.

A WFP news release received by PANA here on Friday said the operation will be targeted at tens of thousands vulnerable people in Freetown and other urban centres like Kenema, Bo and Makeni, most of whom are in hospitals, clinics, orphanages and schools.

Many of these people were being assisted by WFP before the current conflict, but thousands more have recently arrival in the centres in need of help. 

"Security permitting, various WFP commodities will be distributed tomorrow through the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), plus NGOs and community groups who are still able to operate in Sierra Leone," the release said.

Most foreign agencies, including those of the UN have been forced to withdraw their personnel from the war-ravaged Freetown because of insecurity.

Since the Sierra Leonean army seized power from the elected President Hamad Tejan Kabbah, the price of staple foods has doubled, and supplies of imports such as rice, sugar and flour are dwindling.

"Kerosene and petrol are also in short supply and it is expected that many essential products such as fuel and rice will run out within two weeks," said the WFP release.

WFP is also making preparations for rural areas of Sierra Leone where people affected by the conflict may decide to leave their home and trek into neighbouring countries or other locations within their country.

"We are rushing relief food stocks to Conakry (Guinea) and San Pedro (Cote d'Ivoire) in case we suddenly start to see large refugee movements, " the news release quoted Jamie Wickens, WFP's regional manager for West Africa, as saying.

"We may launch a cross-border operation from those countries to feed internally displaced people, and curb the flow of those who might decide to seek asylum in neighbouring countries".

The UN food distribution agency said that it still had 10,000 tons of food, enough to feed 600,000 people for one month in Sierra Leone.

"An additional 11,000 tons of relief food belonging to other relief agencies is also available in Sierra Leone," it added.

Before its warehouses were looted when fighting broke out in May, the WFP had 1,600 metric tons of food in Freetown.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Annan Renews Call On Freetown Coup Makers to Quit


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has said that the coup makers in Sierra Leone cannot successfully cling to power in the face of international isolation. He renewed his call on them to give up now.

"I did appeal to them very early in the game to reconsider their position, particularly given the fact that the people do not accept them," Annan said Thursday at a news conference in New York.

"So for them to really persist with this enterprise is going to be extremely difficult for them and for the people," he said. 

Annan expressed hope that the simultaneous threat of force and efforts to seek a negotiated resolution to the conflict would convince the coup makers to return power to the country's legitimate government.

Sierra Leonean army officers, led by Maj. Johnny Koromah, allied with rebels of the Revolutionary United Front toppled the country's elected President, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, on May 25. He fled to neighbouring Guinea.

The coup, the third in the country in five years, has attracted unprecedented international condemnation. The 16-nation Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas), to which Sierra Leone is a member, has vowed to restore Kabbah to power.

Annan and the African leaders who met recently in Harare, Zimbabwe, have expressed support for any action that could restore Sierra Leone's legitimate government.

"Obviously if all else fails force as a last resort may not be avoided, given what is happening on the ground," Annan said.

He restated that the U.N. was not directly involved in the negotiations being undertaken by West African countries with the coup plotters.

"I think it is the Ecowas countries that are leading the negotiations and they are also the ones with the troops on the ground," Annan said.

"The U.N. has tended to allow regional organizations to lead where they take a situation in hand and we usually do not get involved and compete with them," he added.

Annan, who was briefing U.N. correspondents on his trip to harare to attend the O.A.U. summit, praised African leaders for their unity in condemning the coup.

He said it was remarkable in the sense that barely two years ago there was a coup in The Gambia and there was no reaction.

"But this time the leaders seem determined to discourage coups in Africa," he added.

Meanwhile, the U.N. World Food Programme announced it would likely begin limited relief food distribution in Sierra Leone on Friday.

The agency said it would try to feed the thousands of vulnerable people in Freetown, Kenema, Bo and Makeni, most of whom are in hospitals, clinics, orphanages and schools.

Many of these people were being helped by the agency before the current conflict but thousands more have arrived recently.

Most foreign agencies, including those of the U.N. have been forced to withdraw their personnel from the war-ravaged Freetown.

Since the army seizure the price of staple foods has doubled, and supplies of imports such as rice, sugar and flour are dwindling.

"Kerosene and petrol are also in short supply and it is expected that many essential products such as fuel and rice will run out within two weeks," the agency said.

It said it was preparing to send help to rural areas where people affected by the war may decide to flee to neighbouring countries or other locations within Sierra Leone.

"We are rushing relief food stocks to Conakry (Guinea) and San Pedro (Cote d'Ivoire) in case we suddenly start to see large refugee movements," said Jamie Wickens, the agency's manager for West Africa.

The UN food distribution agency said that it still had 10,000 tons of food, enough to feed 600,000 people for one month in Sierra Leone.

"An additional 11,000 tons of relief food belonging to other relief agencies is also available in Sierra Leone," it added.

Before its warehouses were looted when fighting broke out in May, the agency had 1,600 metric tons of food in Freetown.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Angola;
Lack Of Funds Hampers Angolan Demobilization


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The International Organization for Migration said Friday that it might suspend the transfer of demobilized UNITA soldiers to their homes in Angola by the end of June because it had no money for the operation.

The organization, which deals with the return and resettlement of displaced persons and returnees in conflict situations, said that it has been able to return to their home 28,000 of the 159,000 demobilized UNITA soldiers being held in assembly areas. 

From its Geneva headquarters, the agency said it had received just three million U.S. dollars of the 15 million dollars it requires for the operation.

It said the return of a group of 22,000 demobilized soldiers in the southern Cuando Cubango Province, set to begin June 24, would not start unless funds were received in time.

"Unless additional firm pledges are received soon, the IOM's director general will have to decide shortly on suspending the operation or bringing it to a halt at the end of June." it said.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Science and Health;
CITES: Delegates Eager To See Wild Animals


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Safari and tour operators in Zimbabwe are making jumbo-sized business from the two-week conference on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, being held for the second time in Africa.

Between 1,500 and 2,000 delegates from 138-member nations of adhering to the convention are in Harare to decide on 75 proposals involving 85 species, including the elephant, which Zimbabwe wants downlisted to allow controlled trade in ivory and other products. 

The official tour operator for the conference, Tourism Services Zimbabwe, reported Friday that they had not experienced any "downlisting" of business since the meeting began June 9.

The company's marketing executive, Raymond Chimhandamba, told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency that their tour packages to the legendary northern resort of Victoria Falls and Hwange National Park were proving popular. Delegates going to these sites are from places such as the Pacific Ocean states of Tahiti and Vanuatu, eager to see wild elephants, lions and leopard in their natural habitat.

When they were not pouring through stacks of documents on the exotic species such as the north atlantic minke whale or the edible-nest swiftlet, some delegates took time off for day trips to the lion and cheetah Park, and the Imire Game Reserve.

Although all within close proximity to Harare, the Zimbabwe capital, the are stocked with impressive variety of animals that normally roam Zimbabwe's forests, game parks and wildlife conservancies.

"Business has been very, very successful," Chimhandamba said.

A spokesman for United Touring Company also reported brisk business, saying their tour packages to Victoria Falls, Hwange and the scenic Eastern Highlands were always fully subscribed.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Science and Health;
CITES: South Africa Gives Position On Rhinos


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - South Africa voiced support Friday for a strictly controlled legal trade in the rhino horn and other products saying that would reduce illegal activities.

The chief executive of the Natal Parks Board in the South African province of Kwazulu-Natal, George Hughes, gave a lengthy presentation at the 10th conference of Cites in Harare, Zimbabwe. He said that the availability of a legal source of rhino horn would provide a strong disincentive to consumers to buy horn on the black market.

South Africa, which has a Southern White rhino population of between 7,200 and 7,500, is proposing that restrictions preventing international trade in the animal and other products be lifted.

Hughes told the conference that the trade ban had been ineffective in protecting rhinos. He said only those populations that had been effectively protected and managed had maintained or increased their numbers.

The use of rhino horn was deeply entrenched in Chinese traditional medicine, he added, and this measure would ensure that demand would persist.

He added that the sustained increase in Southern White numbers from 20 to at least 7,500 over the last 100 years, and the stabilization of black rhino numbers in Africa since 1992, could be attributed to the contribution of well protected and managed populations in a number of range states, especially South Africa.

However, Hughes said that South Africa did not want to trade in the rhino horn immediately. What it wants now is a zero quota once a strictly controlled marketing system has been accepted by Cites.

He said that at current growths rates, the South African white rhino population would double to 14,000 within a decade.

Economic incentives were required, he said, to ensure that sufficient private land was managed for wildlife and was made available to rhinos.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Science and Health;
CITES: U.S. Proposal On Fish Rejected


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Delegates at the ongoing conference on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species voted 50-49 Friday to shoot down a United States proposal to set up a working group on marine fish species.

"It's premature and unnecessary to establish the working group now because that is already being looked after by FAO and not Cites," said Hiromisa Isa, head of the Japanese delegation on marine fisheries. 

"Maybe we can consider the establishment of the working group in the long-term," he added.

The group would have been responsible for marine fish and invertebrate species subject to international trade. It would have included small and large fishing nations that were parties to the convention, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, regional fisheries management and conservation organizations to champion issues concerning marine fishing.

The group would also have prepared an analysis of technical and practical implementation concerns associated with the potential inclusion in Appendix II of marine fish and invertebrate species. It would also have made recommendations for consideration at the 11th meeting of the conference of the parties.

The U.S. is one of the major powers, at conference, opposing proposals by Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe to have elephant downlisted from Appendix I, which does not allow trade in ivory, to Appendix II, which allows controlled trade.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Two journalists into hiding; two papers resume


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

New York - During the week of June 9, 1997, Ojukutu Macaulay, host of the on-air talk show "Good Morning Freetown", which broadcasts Monday through Friday on FM 106.6 (Skyy FM) was confronted by a group of AFRC soldiers two hours after his public argument with an unidentified fellow journalist at No. 1 Short Street.

During the argument, Macaulay stated that he does not and will not ever support the recent coup led by Major Johnny Paul Koromah. As Macaulay returned to his home the AFRC soldiers confronted him and threatened that "they would divide him into four parts" if he does not cease making statements against the coup. Macaulay has gone into hiding and is no longer residing at his home. 

British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) Makeni-based stringer Sylvester Rogers is reported to have gone into hiding because AFRC soldiers are trying to locate him as a result of his reports, broadcast on the BBC. The reports were about the AFRC supplying local gin and marijuana to potential supporters who they were enticing to attend a rally in support of the recent coup. According to Rogers, the majority of civilians refused to attend the rally.

As of June 7, 1997, the independent newspaper "For di People" resumed daily publication, except Sunday, in a 4-page format (reduced from the usual 8-page format). The resumption of publication is reportedly due to the newspaper's ownership of a printing press. However "For di People" is not granting other independent newspapers access to their printing press.

A lead story in the June 11, 1997 issue of "For di People" about AFRC representatives traveling to Libya led to an AFRC press release warning journalists that if they want to publish sensitive security issues they must contact AFRC headquarters for clarification before publishing their stories.

The independent newspaper "Expo Times" has also resumed publication, on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, in a 4-page format.

For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina (x 103) or Selam Demeke (x 118) at CPJ, 330 Seventh Ave., New York, NY 10001, U.S.A., tel: +1 212 465 1004, fax: +1 212 465 9568, e-mail: kkerina@cpj.org, sdemeke@cpj.org, Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.

The information contained in this alert is the sole responsibility of CPJ. In citing this material for broadcast or publication, please credit CPJ.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj.org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.
