Africa News


June 13, 1997


Congo (Kinshasa);
Annan Says Kabila Pledged Cooperation on Refugees Probe


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

United Nations - Comments by Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Congo (Kinshasa) at a press conference at the United Nations Headquarters on 12 June

QUESTION: I have a question about the killings of refugees in Congo- Kinshasa. How confident are you that United Nations human rights investigators are going to be able to achieve their mission? 

SECRETARY-GENERAL: I did speak to President Kabila personally in Harare, and I also brought in -- as I mentioned to some of you -- the Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees. He did promise me that he will cooperate, and I pressed him to appoint a senior official with authority, with access to him, who can take decisions to work with the UNHCR. There and then he indicated that he would appoint the Minister of Construction, and he has since done that. The UNHCR has also named a focal point, Assistant Secretary-General Sergio de Mello, and they are already in the region and are hoping to sit down with the representatives of President Kabila to discuss a plan and move on with this implementation.

I think President Kabila has begun to realize the importance and urgency of resolving, and the need to resolve, these issues - not only the humanitarian issue, but also the question of human rights and the investigation into the alleged mass murders.

At the end of my discussions with him, he said: "Mr. Annan, I understand. I also want to get this albatross off my neck". He did, in effect, also offer this same commitment to Ambassador Richardson when they met subsequently in Congo.

I have Ralph Zacklin -- the Acting High Commissioner, coming into town today, and we are going to pursue this issue aggressively, and send in an advance team on 20 June and the full investigators on 7 July.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


401 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Annan Reiterates Call for End to Freetown Coup


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

United Nations - Comments by Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Sierra Leone at a press conference at the United Nations Headquarters on 12 June

QUESTION: Given that negotiations between West African leaders and the coup plotters in Sierra Leone do not seem to be going anywhere, would you support the use of force, perhaps as a last resort, to dislodge the coup plotters? And also, are you concerned about the effect this will have on the Liberian peace process?

SECRETARY-GENERAL: I think that my position on this has been very clear, and I did appeal to the coup makers very early in the game to reconsider their position -- particularly given the fact that the people do not accept them, the neighbours do not want them, the region doesn't welcome them and neither does the international community. So for them to really persist with this enterprise is going to be extremely difficult for them, and for the people. I would hope, therefore, that the combined effort of negotiations and the military presence on the ground will bring them around to giving up power and returning it to the legitimate Government. Obviously, if all else fails, given the constellation in the region and the forces on the ground, force as a last resort may not be avoided, given what has happened on the ground. 

QUESTION: In some of your comments recently you had indicated that you might be willing to consider the use of the more respectable mercenary organizations to help out in various tasks normally associated with peace-keeping. For example, one mercenary group did assist in security around Kinshasa recently. I was wondering if you could clarify your views on when and how and if mercenaries should be employed by the United Nations.

SECRETARY-GENERAL: First of all, I don't know how one makes a distinction between respectable mercenaries and non-respectable mercenaries.

Secondly, I am not aware that I have made any recent statements implying that I will accept mercenaries in these situations.

What happened was, about two years ago, when we were trying to see what could be done to separate the armed elements from the refugees on the Rwandan-Zairian border and no Governments wanted to offer troops, one of the options that was looked at was the possibility of bringing in other elements -- not necessarily troops from Governments -- who might be able to provide security, assist the aid workers in the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and protect them as they did their work. That was discarded, and this was two years ago. Recently, I have not had any such discussions. . . .

QUESTION: To go back to Sierra Leone for a moment, what exactly is the United Nations involvement right now? I understand that early on in the crisis your representative, Ambassador Berhanu Dinka, was involved in negotiating with the coup plotters. What is the situation on the ground, in view of the fact that the United Nations has evacuated? Is the United Nations system still officially engaged in negotiations, and are there plans for post- resolution of this crisis?

SECRETARY-GENERAL: We are not directly involved with the negotiations. I think it is the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) countries that are leading the negotiations, and they are also the ones with the troops on the ground. The United Nations has, in practice, tended to allow regional organizations to lead where they take a situation in hand.

We usually do not get involved and compete with them. There have been situations where we have done it together. For example, this morning I instructed Ambassador Mohamed Sahnoun to go to Kinshasa and then to the Central African Republic to join President Omar Bongo in the negotiations between the protagonists in Congo- Brazzaville. But in the case of Sierra Leone, it is entirely in the hands of the West African countries. I know that Ghana sent in a team from Ambassador James Victor Gbeho, who was a Permanent Representative here, to meet with a group of generals to negotiate the situation. We are staying close to it, but we are not directly involved in the negotiations.

You may also recall that prior to the conflict, we had prepared a peace- keeping force to go in and help implement the agreement that was signed with the Revolutionary United Front (RUF). Obviously, when all this has settled down we will need to reassess the situation and determine what steps the United Nations should take, whether the agreement still exists, whether the agreement is implementable, whether the RUF -- which has now joined the coup makers -- will still honour the agreement.

So we will have to reassess the situation to determine what we do next.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


402 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Annan Describes Trip to OAU and Great Lakes


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

United Nations - Statement by Secretary-General Kofi Annan on his recent Africa trip at a press conference at the United Nations Headquarters on 12 June

SECRETARY-GENERAL: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. It has been a while since we met. I thought it would be helpful if we met today, and for me to share with you some of the discussions I had in the Organization of African Unity (OAU) with regard to what is happening in the Great Lakes region and in Sierra Leone. 

The OAU discussions were particularly interesting this year. In addition to discussing the crises around Africa, there was quite a lot of discussion on human rights, democratization and economic issues. We, in fact, had a brief summit where the Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) briefed the Heads of States on economic issues and what he thought the African Governments have to do to move their region forward in the area of economic and social development. There was quite a lot of sympathy for the work that needs to be done in the Republic of Congo to help President Laurent Kabila and his team rebuild the nation, get the infrastructure going, and eventually organize elections at an appropriate time. But I think what was most remarkable was the reaction of the Heads of State to the coup in Sierra Leone.

They were at one in condemning the coup and encouraging the Governments in the region that everything should be done to restore the legitimate Government back to power. It is remarkable in the sense that, barely a year ago, there was a coup in Gambia and there was no reaction, but this time the leaders seem determined to discourage coups in Africa. In fact, I did make a statement in Harare which really covered the issues of human rights, democratization and the rule of law. I hope Fred Eckhard will make copies available to you.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


403 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Liberia;
Annan's Message to Liberia Peace Support Conference


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

United Nations - Following is the text of the message of Secretary-General Kofi A. Annan to the opening June 12 in Geneva of the Special Conference to Support the Peace Process in Liberia:

Welcome to the United Nations. I would like to begin by expressing my deep gratitude to you all for your dedication to the peace process in Liberia. You have already achieved much and the challenge now is to see the peace take genuine root. 

We have all been reminded in these last few weeks of the fragility of peace and democracy in West Africa.

In Sierra Leone, a democratically elected Government was overthrown by a junta of soldiers without any support, either within or without their country. Their illegitimate, misguided grab for power must be reversed -- peacefully, if at all possible -- for Sierra Leone's sake, for Liberia's sake, for the sake of all of Africa.

I have just returned from the Organization of African Unity (OAU) summit in Harare and I can report that Africa is speaking with one voice in support of democracy and against the rule of the gun.

The promise of a third wave of democracy, human rights and development for Africa is present. It is for Africa and her friends in the international community to make it a reality.

Your efforts in Liberia are central to that process. Representing the key partners among the international community -- the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the International Contact Group, the United Nations System -- your Conference signals the determination to restore lasting security and the rule of law to Liberia.

Free, fair and credible elections are the next, crucial step in this process. An ambitious timetable has been set, culminating in elections on 19 July and making the task even more challenging.

The electoral season raises the stakes for us all -- demanding more security, greater resources and a determination not to allow delays or disruptions to alter the basic course to representative government.

If we succeed -- as I am confident we will -- Liberia can become a model of post-conflict reconstruction involving national leaders, regional organizations and the United Nations. Its neighbours near and far will know that it can be done, even in the most difficult of circumstances.

Let us redouble our efforts in this last stretch of the process to bring peace to Liberia. The hopes of the continent are with you.

I wish you all success in your deliberations.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


404 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Rwanda;
ICRC restores water supply for Nyanza


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Geneva - Water is flowing from the taps once again for the residents of the southern Rwandan town of Nyanza. Less than 24 hours after receiving a request from the local authorities, the ICRC had a new pump delivered from its Kigali warehouse. 

Nyanza's 29,000 residents were suffering from a severe water shortage after two of the three pumps feeding the municipal reservoir had broken down.

The new pump, with a capacity of 35 cu.m/hour, has restored the water supply for the town's population and for its schools, hospital, health facilities and detention centres. The construction of the cement base, the plumbing and electrical connections were handled by the national utility company, Electrogaz. "Over the past few years we have done our best to provide emergency assistance to those in need", said Nicolas Stein, head of the ICRC's water and sanitation unit in Rwanda.

Issued 12 June 1997


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sierra Leone;
ICRC activities in Sierra Leone


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Geneva - Following the coup of 25 May, political and military negotiations regarding possible solutions continued in Abidjan, Ctte d'Ivoire, and Abuja, Nigeria, between the authorities there and delegations of the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC) in control in Sierra Leone. Representatives from Gambia and Ghana were also involved in the talks in Nigeria.

In the meantime, the situation throughout the country remains chaotic, with no government offices and few schools open.

Hospitals are functioning at only a very low level, if at all. No supplies are entering the capital, fuel is running short and there is no commercial traffic. Thousands are said to be leaving Freetown towards the north, Bo and Guinea. In addition to the problems of daily life (lack of supplies and medical care, risk of electricity failures and subsequent water supply problems), the population fears the possibility of renewed armed confrontation. 

The ICRC has maintained and stepped up its contacts with all parties (those manning the checkpoints, commanders, AFRC representatives, special forces, RUF members, Liberians, Nigerians, Guineans and Kamajors) with a view to obtaining adequate security guarantees for its work.

On Tuesday, 3 June the ICRC addressed a memorandum on respect for international humanitarian law to the Executive Secretariat of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) in Abuja, Nigeria - to be forwarded to member states with troops in Sierra Leone - and to the Chief of Defence Staff in Lagos. The memorandum was also submitted to ECOMOG (the ECOWAS Monitoring group) in Monrovia.

Medical activities: arrival of a surgical team

The ICRC is following the case of the six wounded soldiers whom it evacuated from the Mammy Yoko hotel and subsequently visited on 3 June in a military hospital, along with six more who had made their own way there.

An ICRC surgical team, consisting of a surgeon, an anaesthetist and a theatre nurse, was brought in to Freetown on Thursday evening, 5 June by helicopter from Monrovia. The team started work immediately at the Netland hospital.

The ICRC's presence in Freetown throughout the events has enabled a minimal level of surgical care to be maintained and has had a definite impact on the morale and availability of local doctors. Medical supplies have been distributed to the Connaught, Netland and Wilberforce hospitals. On 5 June, as blood bank supplies were low, the Sierra Leone Red Cross Society (SLRCS) put out radio requests for voluntary donors, and provided blood to the Connaught hospital. To assist the minimal staff there, six SLRCS first-aiders were deployed, as well as four others at the Netland hospital. On 6 June the SLRCS and ICRC transferred two war wounded from the medical ward of an army training centre in Waterloo to Wilberforce hospital.

Since the water and sanitation situation in Freetown is likely to give cause for concern, as no refuse collection service has been in operation for ten days, the ICRC is to send an engineer next week to assess the situation.

In the Pujehun, Kailahun and Kenema districts, the ICRC has continued to support ten local clinics. In Kenema, however, staff in the government hospital more or less stopped working on 27 May, and the hospital remains closed. In the only other medical facility, the Nongowa clinic, the ICRC nurse, along with two local doctors, has been giving basic medical treatment and changing dressings for the patients. The SLRCS, supported by the ICRC, has opened a dispensary at the Nongowa clinic to provide basic care.

Food and seed distributions

Food from ICRC stocks was distributed on 6 and 7 June in Zimmi to vulnerable groups of people (pregnant women, nursing mothers, children and the elderly). In all, over 17 tonnes of oil, beans, corn meal, etc., were distributed to about 5,000 beneficiaries.

In addition, in Kenema, Segbwema and Zimmi, the ICRC is preparing to continue with the rice and groundnut seed distribution, to coincide with the onset of the rainy season, under its agricultural rehabilitation programme. It will start on 10 June in Zimmi.

In Freetown, the ICRC on 4 June gave bulgur, lentils and oil to the Connaught and Netland hospitals and to a feeding centre.

Segbwema and Daru

On 5 June the ICRC visited all the camps for the internally displaced to assess the humanitarian situation. In all, over 3,000 people are reported to have arrived recently. Food and other basic provisions are in short supply. In view of the events, the ICRC in Segbwema gave further assistance to a centre for unaccompanied children, even though the planned 12-week distributions for the centre had already been completed.

Personnel

Since 3 June the ICRC has increased its expatriate staff by the three members of the surgical team and a new medical coordinator. In all, 16 expatriates (three French, two Icelandic, one each from the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal, and eight Swiss) are based in Freetown (nine), Kenema (five) and Zimmi (two).

Issued 12 June 1997.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Congo;
ICRC urges respect for humanitarian rules in Congo


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Geneva - The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is extremely concerned about the fighting that has been raging in Brazzaville for more than a week, undoubtedly claiming numerous civilian lives in this highly populated urban area, and the ICRC fears that further hostilities will have disastrous consequences in humanitarian terms.

The ICRC calls on all the parties involved to abide by the rules of international humanitarian law, and in particular to make a clear distinction between combatants and civilians and to respect persons who are not or are no longer taking part in the hostilities. It also emphasizes that it is prohibited to launch indiscriminate attacks endangering the civilian population, to use civilians as human shields, and to terrorize the population. Individuals no longer participating in the fighting, such as wounded or sick combatants, must be collected and given proper care, and those captured must be treated humanely.

The intensity of the hostilities has compelled the ICRC and the Congolese Red Cross to suspend their activities in the capital. If the Red Cross teams are to be able to resume their work, the parties must show respect for the red cross emblem and guarantee the safety of humanitarian workers.

The ICRC urges the warring parties to do everything possible to ensure compliance with these basic rules and principles.

Issued 12 June 1997


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Congo;
ICRC back at work


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Geneva - After being trapped indoors for several days by the heavy fighting in Brazzaville, ICRC delegates were finally able to reach the airport on 10 June and begin to help evacuate foreigners from the town, using an ICRC-chartered plane.

Priority is being given to women, children and the ill. Fourteen people were taken across the river to Kinshasa on the first flight and further trips back and forth are now taking place. 

The authorities in Congo Brazzaville have meanwhile granted the ICRC permission to resume its flights from Kinshasa to Lukolela, where Rwandan refugees have gathered after crossing the river from the former Zaire. After a six-day interruption, the ICRC plane will start up its round-trip journeys again on 11 June to deliver food and medical supplies that will be distributed by two ICRC expatriates and volunteers from the Congolese Red Cross.

Homeward bound

Planes, boats, trains, trucks, cars... just about every means of transport imaginable was brought into play for the ICRC's transfer of more than 6,500 people displaced within the Democratic Republic of Congo (formerly Zaire).

The operation began on 15 April with an airlift: using a Hercules, a Boeing 727 and a DC3 (later joined by another transport plane dispatched from Nairobi), in six weeks the ICRC transferred a total of 6,019 people from Kisangani and Kindu to Bukavu, Goma, Isiro, Bunia and Lubumbashi. Other displaced persons were taken from Kisangani to Lubutu and Walikale by truck, and to Bafwasende by smaller vehicles. The ICRC also paid the train fares for 150 people from Lubumbashi to Kalemie.

In a new phase of the operation, which got under way on 2 June, a further 6,000 displaced people will be taken from Kalemie to Uvira. The whole undertaking is expected to continue for several more months, and forms part of a global assistance programme for the displaced population in the region.

Each family of returnees has been given a kit of essential items to help them settle back into their homes. The ICRC is also continuing to provide food and other assistance to the most vulnerable, in places affected by the passage of large numbers of people, looting and insecurity. A seed distribution programme is planned for the most affected areas.

All these assistance activities are aimed at helping between 250,000 and 300,000 people in the east of the country over the coming months. The ICRC is also continuing its rehabilitation and support work -- begun before November 1996 and maintained during the conflict -- for medical facilities in the east. This programme is seen as a vital contribution towards helping returnees resume a normal life.

Issued 11 June 1997


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


United States and Africa;
Oxfam Welcomes Washington's G7 Africa Initiative


BYLINE: Justin Forsyth, Oxfam International, Oxfam International (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


London - Oxfam today welcomed US success at getting Africa's future on the agenda at the G7 Summit in Denver this month.

In a briefing paper released today, the international development agency said that the United States was showing long- overdue world leadership in recognizing the "silent crisis" of Africa's deepening poverty, economic decline, and marginalization from the international stage.

"For too long, G-7 leaders have turned a blind eye to Africa's acute problems. The new winds of change that are sweeping through Africa now give the G-7 a stark choice between responding to the tragedies associated with Sudan, Liberia, and Sierra Leone and grasping the opportunities created by Uganda, Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Mozambique," said Justin Forsyth of Oxfam International. 

Oxfam is encouraged by US attention to Africa's problems. However, the agency pointed out that the trade concessions and the new aid commitments in the US are minimal. The agency also has reservations about certain parts of the initiative:

- The plan only deals with a small cluster of countries regarded as success stories. Participation in the initiative is conditional on implementation of policies promoted under World Bank/IMF structural adjustment programs that have failed to generate sustained growth and have undermined investment performance and food security in Africa. Under these terms, we estimate that only five to seven countries would qualify.

- The plan's call for maximum debt relief for countries under the World Bank/IMF Highly Indebted Poor Country Initiative is welcome. However, this position is at odds with attempts by the United States last month to delay relief for Uganda, the first country to be considered for relief.

- Trade concessions for African goods are encouraging, but the plan fails to address the problems faced by African exporters as a result of collapsing economic infrastructure and high transport costs. Without an integrated trade and increased development aid package, Africa will remain dependent on wildly fluctuating primary commodity prices.

- The plan fails to reverse the steep decline in US aid to Africa. In the last three years, US aid has declined from 0.15 percent of GDP to 0.10 percent, the smallest share of the OECD countries.

"In its current form, the initiative lacks real substance. Deeper debt relief, more aid, and better terms of trade are needed if the initiative is to deliver real benefits to Africa's poor," added Mr. Forsyth.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Senegal;
Journalist Group Protests Senegalese Court Ruling


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), June 12, 1997, to President Abdou Diouf of Senegal

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the June 4, 1997 decision of the Appellate Court to fine Sud Communication 500 million CFA (US$ 1 million) for public defamation of The Mimran Group, a sugar-importing company. This decision upholds the Magistrate Court's verdict of June 27, 1996 that in addition to the 500 million CFA fine included one month prison sentences for Abdoulaye Ndiaga Sylla, first vice-president of Sud Communication and director of Sud Quotidien; Sidy Gaye, editor in chief of Sud Quotidien, and reporters Bocar Niang, Mame Oll Faye and Ibrahim Sarr. Babacar Toure, chairperson and president of Sud Communication, was acquitted. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the fine and prison sentences as unprecedented in sub-Sahara Africa and excessive for a civil case. The potential damage of this action to press freedom and journalists' right to hold and express opinions and ideas is immeasurable. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Senegal is a signatory.

We strongly urge Your Excellency to do everything in your power to facilitate the reversal of the Appellate Court's decision and to restore your government's reputation for fostering an environment where unrestricted press freedom can flourish.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj.org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 13, 1997


Kenya;
Journalists Group Protests Police Assaults in Kenya


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), June 12, 1997, to President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the May 29, 1997 police assault of Jacob Otieno and Jacob Waweru, photojournalists for The East African Standard who were covering a rally for constitutional reforms at Uhuru Park in Nairobi. Otieno and Waweru sustained injuries and were treated at the Aga Khan Hospital. 

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the promotion of press freedom worldwide, CPJ condemns the assault of Otieno and Waweru as a grave attack on press freedom and a blatant violation of their right to gather information and express opinions and ideas. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind," and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Kenya is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we strongly urge you to do everything in your power to ensure a prompt and thorough investigation into this case and to bring the perpetrators of this assault to justice.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj.org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.

Uganda;
Journalist Group Condemn Threats in Uganda


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), June 13, 1997, to President Yoweri Kaguta of Uganda

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to express concern over threats made, on May 9, 1997, toward Betty Nambooze, a freelance journalist with the state-owned daily Bukedde. The threats were made by two local Council III officials of Goma sub- county (in Mukono District) and were in connection with articles, published in the May 8, 1997 edition of Bukedde, reporting on the reappearance of armed men in Makono and the displacement of Kolo village residents as a result of plans set by an Indian investor. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the threats against Betty Nambooze as a violation of press freedom and her right to hold and express opinions and ideas. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Uganda is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we urge you to do everything within your power to ensure that threats against Nambooze cease. We also urge you to guarantee the protection of journalists' sources and the media's right to practice their profession freely and safely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj.org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Councils told to engage road builders


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Government has with immediate effect empowered local authorities in the country to engage contractors and consultants in road rehabilitation and maintenance, Works and Supply Deputy Minister, Major Celestino Chibamba announced in Kabwe.

Addressing senior officers from municipal and district councils in Central Province, Major Chibamba said all councils were authorised to award tenders for road rehabilitation and maintenance. 

"From now, councils have the power and authority to interview contractors and consultants and award tenders to deserving companies to rehabilitate and maintain roads in their areas," Major Chibamba said.

He was flanked by Central Province Minister, Abel Musonda Chambeshi.

However the central Government would have to approve the contractors and consultants to ensure they were of reputable experience.

"We want quality work on roads during this five year road rehabilitation and maintenance programme ending in the year 2002," he said.

He told the meeting in the Kabwe municipal council chamber that each council must supervise work on the project and ensure that money was only paid after satisfactory work had been done.

Major Chibamba called for early proper planning so that work on projects could begin on time. He also urged stakeholders to coordinate their programmes and ensure that funds allocated to projects were spent properly and accounted for.

He assured the councils that money would soon be released and work on rehabilitating damaged roads must begin.

Discussing Central Province, he said Kabwe Municipal Council would receive K200m for road rehabilitation this year, and each district council K100m.

The roads department would spent K700m during the period.

He said councils must be employers and supervise all the projects."Consultants engineers are the eyes and ears of the councils and make sure they are physically on site to supervise and monitor progress of projects," he said. -Zana.

June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Chiefs hail house reintroduction


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - Chief Nkweto of the Bemba in Chinsali district has welcomed the reintroduction of the House of Chiefs by the ruling Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD) government to enhance good governance in Zambia .

He said in Chinsali the decision was in the right direction to discuss national issues. The Government should be praised for the re-introduction of the House of Chiefs as the decision was long overdue.

The house would enable traditional rulers and Government to share and exchange views on national issues. He has appealed to his colleagues to elect capable chiefs to represent them effectively in the house.

This was important if the full benefits of their house were to be realised. The chief emphasised that only enlightened chiefs were able to make democratic traditional laws for their people.

And MMD youths in Solwezi central constituency have praised President Chiluba for appointing former finance and economic development deputy minister Koshita Sheng'amo Zambia's new High Commissioner to Namibia.

Solwezi central constituency MMD youth chairman Richard Mufwabule said that the youths who had confidence in the former Solwezi East member of parliament have welcomed Mr Sheng'amo's appointment wholeheartedly.

Mr Sheng'amo's apppointment clearly demonstrated that although the voters in Solwezi East rejected him in preference for a National Party candidate, Patrick Kangwa, President Chiluba and the MMD still want to utilise the potential in Mr Sheng'amo.

He said that the youths in Solwezi still remember and have great respect for Mr Sheng'ambo for the influential role he played in convincing the Government to start tarring the controversial Mutanda/Chavuma road. -Zana/ZIS.

Zambia;
Tourism potential delights EDF team


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - A team from the European Development Fund (EDF) which is currently carrying out feasibility studies in Luangwa district says it is delighted with the tourism potential in the lower Zambezi National Park and the Lufunsa management area.

Team leader Hasukile Kajuni who is management planning co- ordinator for EDF/NPWA sustainable wildlife management project, says his delegation was pleased to see the abundant natural resources and tourism potential in the two areas. 

The team is in the area to familiarise itself with projects being undertaken by EDF in conjunction with the local people.

Mr Kajuni's organisation has been given the task of re- organising and restructuring the department of national parks and wildlife services in Zambia.

Meanwhile, Feira constituency Member of Parliament Mr Fidelis Mando, has praised the Luangwa district co-ordinating committee for compiling a documentay which would attract investors to the area.

Mr Mando who is Deputy Minister of tourism, praised the committee at a special full council meeting which was held in the council chamber yesterday. -Zana/ZIS.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Bank to honour players tonight


BYLINE: Yuyo Kambikambi, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The prestigious Finance Bank soccer award presentation ceremony is finally on tonight at the Cosmopolitan in Lusaka.

A total of seven awards being jostled for by 35 deserving players and administrators are up for grabs.

Finance Bank Marketing and Public Relations director Noel Nkhoma said in Lusaka yesterday that the awards failed to take off last week because the national soccer team were busy preparing for the World Cup match against South Africa. 

"We are definitely having these awards tomorrow night at the Cosmopolitan because for one they are long overdue and I believe people should know who the various awards go to," Nkhoma said.

The awards include Footballer of the year, Administrator of the year, Coach of the year, the most promising player, Referee of the year, Top scorer and Most disciplined club in the 1996 soccer season.

Those in contention for the footballer of the year award include midfield wizard Dabid Chilufya from Konkola Blades, Zamsure's robust Andrew Tembo, Kabwe Warriors goal-minder Davies Phiri and Mufulira Wanderers Paul Chellah and Nelson banda.

In the administrator category Lusaka Dynamos Hanif Adams is once again in the race while others tipped to be in high contention include City of Lusaka boss Simataa Simataa and City Snipers James Mazumba. The rest are Ndola Wanderers chairman Andre Mtine and Wanderers Joseph Menzu.

Paul Kinematic is top on the list in the Referee of the year category but closely following behind are the likes of Major Benson Chapenuka, Lovemore Mwanza, Ignatius Mukumbuta and Goshen Hatimbula.

The 1996 most promising player award may go to left-footed Shy Kumwenda of Zamsure, Nkana keeper Emmauel Mschili, Lusaka Dynamos Perry Mutapa, Under 20 sensational Moses Lungu and Gibson Shikilwa.

Nkhoma said the bank was ready to continue encouraging sports in the country and this was one way of showing it.

"Despite our dismal performance at national team level it would not be right to forget about football. We still very committed to continue sponsoring the awards," he said.

Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Fans to fly to Maputo


BYLINE: Sports Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - A flight has been arranged to ferry soccer fans to Maputo for the June 22 Africa Cup qualifier between Zambia and Mozambique. 

Mosi Lager Chipolopolo Soccer Fans Association (CSFA) general secretary Willie Malasha said in Lusaka yesterday that the flight which will depart Lusaka on Friday June 20 and return on Monday June 23 will cost $386.00 or the Kwacha equivalent for the return fair.

The fans will also be required to pay K17,000.00 for the Mozambiquan visa.

Malasha urged all the travelling fans to provide two passport size photos for the visas which should be ready before departure.

All payments should be made to Malasha at Axis Centre on Cairo Road in Lusaka before June 18.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Law Association backs new judges pay


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) has backed the recent salary increments to judges as justified as they will help instil confidence and avoid corruption in the judiciary.

LAZ president George Kunda said in Ndola yesterday, his association had for sometime been concerned with the poor and scandalous judges' salaries which had failed to attract lawyers in private practice. 

Mr Kunda condemned recent attacks from some quarters including opposition parties who claimed the salary increases were unjustified.

"The consequence of inadequate remuneration is that the independence of the judiciary is undermined to an extent where judges do not feel secure and confident. To instil confidence and avoid corruption, judges must be properly paid ," Mr Kunda said.

The increments were made under the judges conditions of service Act which constituted a "slight and insignificant" improvement. Members of the judiciary deserved respect as they shouldered heavy responsibilities.

It was quite clear that Government had over the years failed to put in place sincere and deliberate policies to improve judges conditions of service.

The judiciary had been relegated to a somewhat inferior arm of Government in both the first and second republics Mr Kunda said.

LAZ appealed to Government to show genuine commitment to improving the judges conditions, so that the judiciary could continue to attract the best legal brains in Zambia.

He warned against politicians trying to exploiting the poor conditions in the judiciary for their selfish ends.

"Judges' conditions of service must be improved continuously and without ulterior motives," Mr Kunda added.

LAZ reiterated its confidence in the Zambian judiciary and hoped that judges would continue to dispense justice fairly.

Zambia needed a strong and respected judiciary where everyone would run for arbitration.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
The need for an independent judiciary (Editorial)


BYLINE: Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - It is indeed ironical that the same politicians who have repeatedly stressed the need for an independent judiciary are among the first ones to condemn Government for offering improved perks to judges.

Such ambivalent posturing just goes to show how inconsistent some politicians are. The recent mouthings from disaffected political elements over increased salaries for judges are totally uncalled for. 

There is absolutely nothing scandalous about paying judges reasonable salaries which are still far below what could be termed commensurate with their services.

To the contrary, what should be deemed scandalous is to deliberately underpay judges and thereby make them vulnerable to manipulation by the corrupt ilk in our society.

The degree of autonomy and independent-mindedness exhibited by the Zambian bench depends, to a large extent, on the integrity of individual judges.

They know that theirs is, indeed, a noble calling.

However, a concomitant prerequisite for the strengthening of the judiciary is adequate monetary reward not only for judges but magistrates and other judicial officers.

There are far too many corrupt elements in Zambia who think that there is nothing which money cannot buy. Such people can do just about anything to pervert the course of justice if there are no sufficient checks and balances.

Attractive monetary perks for judges should not be perceived as a recipe for corruption but a form of insurance against the scourge of corruption which is quite prevalent in Zambia.

It is immoral for politicians to drag the bench into partisan politics by suggesting that any judge who passes a verdict they disagree with has been bribed by the State.

The independence of the judiciary can best be guaranteed by ensuring that judges are well-paid for their services and not reduced to paupers dependent on the benevolence of the government of the day.

We fully concur with the stand of the Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) on this matter. It is consistent with what the association has been advocating for a long time.

The recent mouthings of frustrated politicians who over- politicised the issue of judges' salaries should be ignored with the contempt they deserve.

An independent judiciary is a vital pillar in democratic governance.

Improved perks can only enhance the degree of autonomy. Veiled threats and brazen acts of intimidation will erode the desired independence and weaken the bench.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Zamnet formation: We were misled, says Siwela


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia (Unza) vice chancellor Andrew Siwela has admitted that there were anomalies in the setting up of Zamnet Communications System in which he and his deputy Jorry Mwenechanya hold shares.

During submissions running into day two, Professor Siwela said management was in a hurry to set up Zamnet and that the lawyer who drew up the articles of incorporation misled them into thinking all legal formalities were followed.

Prof Siwela, 50, in a joint submission with his deputy Prof Mwenechanya, registrar Michael Tandeo and bursar Mafukeni Tembo before the Bobby Bwalya Commission of Inquiry was quick to mention that the university had not lost any money as a result of this anomaly.

He said since management had no expertise in registering a company, services were sought from a part-time lecturer in the School of Law while negotiations with the sponsors, World Bank were handled by Minister of Health Katele Kalumba. 

Prof Siwela said the documents were prepared in haste and that he, Prof Mwenechanya and Dr Kalumba were advised to hold shares to fulfil a World Bank condition that Zamnet shares be gradually transferred to private individuals.

He said even the composition of the board of directors was selected in haste but management was given the impression that all was well.

"We were in such a hurry but because we had no expertise in incorporating Zamnet we had to rely on a part-time lecturer in law. Out of ignorance we thought the legal requirements were followed. Now we realise there have been anomalies," he said.

He regretted that the registration of incorporation with the registrar of companies reflected Siwela and Mwenechanya as businessmen when in fact they held Zamnet shares in trust. He said former registrar Jean Calder held shares to protect Unza's interest in Zamnet.

Prof Siwela said management was eager to rectify the mistakes and hoped the Unza Council would reconstitute the Zamnet board in conformity with the law.

He said the board had been considering to reconstitute the Zamnet shares but did not elaborate.

Mr Justice Bwalya cautioned Unza management against dealing with non-qualified and non-practising lawyers to draw up legal documents for body corporates.

"From your submission, it is clear that the person you engaged did not know what he was doing. Next time use practising advocates registered with the Law Association of Zambia (LAZ), and ensure that all university workers are informed right now they are in the dark," Mr Justice Bwalya said.

Earlier Prof Siwela said the scrapped human biology degree under the School of Medicine was useless as student graduates were unable to find employment afterwards.

He was responding to a question from commissioner Steven Muliokela who wondered why management had not re-introduced it after medical students complained.

And Prof Siwela said five-year tenure for the vice chancellor is too long and should be restricted to two terms.

He described his job as thankless and proposed that the term of office be reduced, renewable only once to give chance to others.

Commissioners queried why Prof Siwela incorporated his relatives in committees such as the University of Zambia Restoration Project (Unzarespro) which was set up to raise funds for the university.

"What is wrong with my wife sitting on the committee when I am the vice chancellor and she knows the problems the university is facing? After all she mooted the Unzarespro idea in my living room," he said.

His "excessive" trips abroad were justified as that was the only way to scout for supplementary donor funding.

Prof Mwenechanya admitted that some lecturers were incompetent but efforts were being made to improve the quality of education.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Police seal off UNZA campus


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Paramilitary police in riot kit yesterday ringed the University of Zambia (Unza) Great East Road campus in Lusaka and barred striking workers from entering the premises.

Only medical staff for the Unza clinic and employees of Zamnet, a Unza subsidiary, were allowed to go in. 

Education Minister Syamukayumbu Syamujaye said in an interview that Government expected the Unza Council to deal with problems that have rocked the institution.

Government has told the Unza administration to re-open the institution but refused to release any funds until the commission of inquiry completes its work.

Yesterday employees who were supposed to be addressed by Unza Council chairman Mashekwa Nalumango were blocked by uncompromising policemen who said they had been instructed not to allow the workers into the campus.

Union leaders vainly tried to reason with the police to allow their members entry to prepare for the 09:00 hours assignment with Dr Nalumango.

Dr Nalumango who arrived at the campus to address the employees was surprised to find police had cordoned the place. He turned down pleas by unionists to reason with the police to allow the employees in the campus ground so he could talk to them.

"I do not know who instructed the police to be here so I have to talk to the minister and find out what is happening," he told union leaders.

The workers broke into song and dance denouncing the administration of Unza vice-chancellor Andrew Siwela.

Later in an interview, Dr Nalumango said it was impossible for him to meet the workers as he had not met Dr Syamujaye.

Police spokesman Standwell Lungu said police moved into the Unza premises to ensure there was law and order. He however, acknowledged the striking workers were peaceful.

June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia's stance cheers Belgium


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - Belgium yesterday hailed Zambia for offering to evacuate its nationals from the Shaba province in what was then Zaire in the heat of President Laurent Kabila's struggle for power.

Belgian ambassador to Zambia Leopold Carrewyn said when he presented credentials to President Chiluba at State House that his government had asked him to convey deep gratitude in this regard. 

Mr Carrewyn said Belgium attached great importance to continuing good relations with Zambia.

"Only recently those good relations became once more apparent when your Government showed its readiness to lend a helping hand if need would have arisen to evacuate Belgian nationals from Shaba province," he said.

Mr Chiluba said Belgium was one of the few trading partners whose balance of trade was in favour of Zambia.

Zambia would continue crusading for regional peace because there could be no development in war situations.

Receiving credential from in-coming Japanese ambassador, Yoshihiro Nakamura, Mr Chiluba said Zambia was using Japanese aid with a view to become self-reliant.

He said Zambia would continue implementing the on-going economic reform programme.

Mr Nakamura said Japan was committed to assisting Zambia in her endeavours of nation-building despite the many economic hardships presently being experienced worldwide.

Swi tzerland ambassador to Zambia Catherine Polejack who also presented her credentials said her government was monitoring Zambia's progress in economic reform.

She said Switzerland would approve 120 projects worth K1.3bn to Zambia by this month.

Zambia;
Commuters to pay 25 pc more


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The United Taxis and Transport Association of Zambia (UTTA) has increased all bus and taxi fares by 25 per cent across the board, national chairman Willy Nsanda announced in Kitwe yesterday.

He said the association arrived at the costs after a heated meeting attended by all districts. 

He said members initially demanded a 75 per cent rise but the executive fought to bring it down to 25 per cent.

But commuters contacted yesterday complained it will be difficult to cope with the new fares which Mr Nsanda said would be distributed today to all transporters.

The Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) has described the recent fuel increase as unjustifiable and has called on people to join the protest to bring pressure on Government to rescind the decision.

In a statement yesterday, the labour movement regretted the price increase which came at a time when there was relative stability in the price levels as indicated by the exchange and inflation rates.

The ZCTU called on Government to look into the possibility of eliminating unnecessary middlemen in operations and supply of fuel.

Zambia National Oil Company (ZNOC) has no justification to hike the price of fuel unless there were major movements in the prices of crude oil from its sources of supply.

The fuel increase was a catalyst to inflation as it would rekindle a chain reaction in the country.

ZCTU wondered whether Government would treat workers demands for an increase in their salaries as unjustifiable under these circumstances.

Meanwhile ZCTU president Fackson Shamenda has described the labour movement in Zambia as fragmented and not disorganised.

He said the fragmentation had made the labour movement weak hence the need to strengthen it through unity.

Zambia;
Society for health trust launched


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - The Pharmaceutical Society of Zambia (PSZ) and the Population Services International (PSI) yesterday launched the Society for Health (SFH) Trust aimed at institutionalising the social marketing of maximum condoms.

PSZ president David Phiri said the Trust would build on the success of maximum condoms social marketing project launched in 1992 which had afforded thousands of people with access to quality and affordable health products. 

Speaking at the launch at Pamodzi Hotel in Lusaka yesterday, Mr Phiri said the Trust would have the advantage of tapping a wider donor funding resource base which would ensure a sustainable social marketing of health products.

"We believe this is a practical demonstration of what is meant by building public/private sector partnership in the delivery of health care.

"We are proud to be part of this very exciting partnership and believe that it will go a long way in supporting and complementing the efforts of Government in curbing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV and promoting maternal and child health," he said.

And Society for Health executive director Bradford Lucas said although the launching of Maximum social marketing in 1992 was received with nervousness, it had now succeeded in empowering thousands of people to protect themselves from STDs, HIV and unwanted pregnancies.

"With the introduction of SafePlan oral contraceptives, SFH is expanding access to this important contraceptive which can help parents plan and manage their families and improve the health of children and mothers," he said.

The launch was officiated by Health Minister Dr Katele Kalumba.

Zambia;
Society increases fees for Lusaka show


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Show Society of Zambia yesterday announced a 33 per cent increase in entry charges for the Zambia Agriculture and Commercial Show due in seven weeks time.

Society president Ian Miller said gate charges had ben pegged at K2,000 per person over five years. Show membership will be K9,500 for adults and 4,500 for juniors from five to 16 years.

He said the show society would spend K80m. This would include organising a number of entertainment with what he described as an 'exciting display from the Zambia Army lined up.' Mr Miller said 200 local exhibitors have so far confirmed their participation.

The show society is expecting international participation from The Netherlands, Botswana, India, South Africa, Zimbabwe and France which will be participating for the first time.

"Applications for stands should be lodged with the general manager's office as soon as possible to ensure potential exhibitors are not disappointed.

"An important new development is the exhibitors car park next to the PTA village which we feel will greatly assist the commercial exhibitors through out the show," he said in a statement.

Mr Miller said the theme for this year was "Sustainable Growth" which the show society management felt was a topical theme in the present business atmosphere in Zambia.

Gates for the show open on August 31. The first two days will as usual be for trade when and exhibitors will be encouraged to invite their business partners.

However, gates will during this period be open to the public.

"We are recording a resurgence from the farming committee and expect a healthy display of cattle and small livestock," he said.

June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Move squatters now, says ZCCM


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) has asked Kitwe City to evict more than 10,000 illegal settlers from all mine areas in readiness for potential investors who might want to utilise the areas.

ZCCM is further asking that all squatters be removed from its areas in at least a month's time, Kitwe Town Clerk Ali Simwinga confirmed yesterday. 

He said the company has since written to council asking it to help resettle the more than 10,000 families elsewhere outside the ZCCM areas.

A meeting between ZCCM and the council held in Kitwe yesterday resolved that council quickly finds an alternative place in which to resettle the squatters while ZCCM said it was prepared to make a number of provisions to enable the squatters make permanent infrastructures where they were going to be resettled.

Mr Simwinga said council had already identified an area in Kawama which was big enough to accommodate all the families which faced eviction.

The affected townships are St. Anthony, Kandabwe and Lute.

Mr Simwinga said ZCCM had indicated that the potential buyers might want to explore and develop the areas alongside the mines after buying them because they were part of the mine restricted areas.

The resettling of squatters in the ZCCM areas, especially St. Anthony is an old problem which both ZCCM and the council have jointly tried to tackle.

A few years back, some squatters were settled in other parts of the city when ZCCM said it wanted to develop the area while others refused to move.

They are still occupying their houses while a few other settlers have since joined them in the area.

Business and Finance;
Telecel enters Zambian market


BYLINE: Times Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - Telecel, a private telecommunications company to enter the Zambian market, will start operations later this month and has assured would-be customers of unmatched service and lower costs.

Telecel commercial director, Clive Shamwana, said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday that Telecel was here to stay and would be guided in its provision of services by what the company was allowed to do and what the market forces demand. 

The new company would provide competition to the parastatal monopoly, Zamtel whose services have frequently come under fire from its customers.

"We are here in a big positive way. Our aim is to broaden telecommunication services in Zambia. We are backed by our global capacity as one of the largest telecommunications companies in the world.

"We are used to providing services to large populations in developed and developing countries since we operate in many countries in Africa and elsewhere in the world," Mr Shamwana said.

Telecel was given a licence by the Communications Authority to deal in cellular telephones. This means that at present it cannot offer landline telephone services which Zamtel will continue to monopolise.

Telecel had entered into an inter-connection agreement with Zamtel so that customers receive and send calls regardless of the origin or whether they are connected to Zamtel facility or to Telecel facility.

Mr Shamwana said Telecel customers would enjoy 10 to 20 per cent lower telephone charges than at present.

Business and Finance;
New owners take over Zamdet


BYLINE: Business Review Reporter, Times of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) has handed over Zambia Detonators (Zamdet) to the new owners Dyno Industrier ASA of Norway and Nitro Nobel AB of Sweden after selling it for $1.26m .

Zamdet was a joint venture between the Zambian Government through ZCCM (70 per cent) and Nitro Nobel AB owned 30 per cent by Dyno Industrier ASA. 

Now Dyno Nobel own the company 100 per cent after acquiring the 70 per cent shares which were owned by Government. The company was incorporated in 1992 to produce non-electrical detonators for ZCCM.

ZPA chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, said Zamdet was a profit making company since its inception and in 1995 started exporting to Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The new owners had pledged to invest more money in the company to increase capacity and would not declare any of the existing staff redundant.

The company would eventually list some of the shares on the Lusaka Stock Exchange for Zambians to buy and be part owners of Zamdet.

Present during the hand over were Swedish ambassador, Kristina Svensson, Norwegian ambassador, Jon Lomoy, senior vice president of International Dyno Nobel Europe, Knut Nilsen and ZCCM Konkola Division general manager, Benedict Chileshe.

Mrs Svensson said the purchase of Zamdet was a good example of the partnership between Zambia and Sweden as it showed that good investment should create jobs in Zambia and in Sweden.

Mr Lomoy said the investment was a good example of commercial links between countries which should be beneficial to both partners. He hoped that the new investors would bring with them the work culture from Norway and help Zambia develop.

Ethiopia;
News in Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


DIRE DAWA (ENA) - Contraband goods worth half million birr intercepted The East Shoa customs office said it has intercepted contraband goods worth half a million birr Wednesday when being smuggled from Dire Dawa to the central parts of the country.

The office said it caught 485 bales of textiles with the help of members of the defence force.

Court sentences murderers on various counts

ASEBE TEFERI (ENA) - The High Court of West Hararge zone has sentence a man to life imprisonment for stabbing to death the mother of his three children in Asebe Teferi town. 

Meanwhile, the same court sentenced a person to 12-years of imprisonment for killing his friend by slashing his throats in Welo Woreda.

Similarly, the court said it sentenced an individual to 13 years of imprisonment after finding him guilty of killing his friend by cutting his head off.

In a related development, the court disclosed that it sentenced two individuals to 10 12 years of imprisonment after finding them guilty of killing two individuals people at different times.

AAU calls for inter-industry faculty relationship

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Addis Ababa University has called on the government to open an inter-industry-faculty relationship where students can practice during their summer vacation.

Such a progrmme will enable students and instructors to a first hand experience of industrial activities, and will enable them to seek solutions for the nations industrial problems, Dr. Engineer Hailu Ayele, head of the chemical engineering department of the Faculty of Technology said.

Dr. Hailu said such programmes are widely used in other countries to enable students carry out practical applications of what they learn in classrooms, and thereby improve their competence.

The programme will help improve the standard of education, and give an opportunity for students to have an overview of the status of Ethiopia's industries, he noted.

Dr. Ayele also urged for the opening up of a forum of discussion between leaders of industry and engineers with the view to improving the quality of industrial products.

Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: coffee supplies net 12.7 million


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

DILLA (ENA) - Some 17 coffee supplying cooperatives in Gedeo Zone have earned this year a total profit of 12.7 million birr from the supply of washed coffee to the central market, the zonal agricultural department announced.

According to the deputy head of the department, Ato Bekele Jarso the cooperatives have netted the stated amount by preparing and dispatching to the central market 25,850 quintals of washed coffee. 

The cooperatives have pledged to undertake various infrastructural development activities benefiting coffee producing farmers in the zone, Ato Bekele said.

Although in the amount of coffee the cooperatives supplied the market this year was less by 1,040 quintals from that of last year, the profit exceeds the previous year by far due to better quality, he said.

Some 21 coffee supplying cooperatives in the zone incurred loses last year and were unable to repay the 4 million birr loan they had obtained from the bank, he indicated.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Human development report 1997 launched


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Human development report (HDR) 1997, which is the eighth in a series commissioned by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), has been delivered yesterday at the organization's branch office in Addis Ababa.

The report, delivered by Mr. Christian Lehember, resident representative of UNDP, shows the extent, severity, and complexity of global poverty and proposes a new feasible strategy known as "the human poverty index (HPI)" in a bid to eradicate it. 

The new measurement HPI, ranks countries by three variables: vulnerability to death at an early age, the prevalence of illiteracy, and access to health services, safe water and adequate food, according to the report.

HDR 1997 launched globally in the 134 country offices, indicates that although poverty has been dramatically reduced in many parts of the world during the 20th century, a quarter of the world people still remain in severe poverty.

Delivering the report, Mr. Christian Lehember, said the world in general and Africa in particular face a lot of daunting problems "as we enter the 21st century." He, however, said, if governments, NGOs, donors and the UN, can work together, eradicating poverty in the 21st century will be feasible.

Speaking on the occasion, Ato Mekonen Manyazewal, vice Minister of Economic Development and Cooperation appreciated the introduction of the human poverty index (HPI) which unlike previous strategies analyses the root cause of poverty and suggest an action plan for its eradication.

"HDR 1997 is very much in line with the new programmes and policies designed by Ethiopia's government with a view to eradicating poverty," Ato Mekonen said adding that presently the government and the UNDP are for the first country cooperation frame work (CCFI) which covers the period 1997-2001.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Ethiopia;
Witness said even corpses were beaten


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A prosecution witness told the Federal High court yesterday that tortures were beating the corpse of an individual, a Jehovah Witness, even after his death in their hands, claiming that the victim "was pretending to be dead".

The witness who claimed to have been imprisoned in Kebele 07 of Woreda 22 in 1978 said he would never forget the scene at which the victim, Ato Woube, was beaten to death and his body stamped by his tormentors.

The witness who appeared before the First Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court said another victim who belongs to the same faith, had been severely tortured. His finger nails were pulled out and his skin was peeled by the tortures. 

The witness has testified that Ato Berhanu, the victim who could no more bear the torture had secretly written a letter exposing the atrocities against him to the World council of Churches through his family.

However, the witness said, the letter was intercepted prior to reaching its destinations.

After the discovery of the letter, the victim had confessed that he did write the letter with Ato Girma Worku, the witness himself. "I was also beaten along with the victim for being an accomplice in writing the letter," he told the court.

The witness said, an inmate, Kifle Gebre-Mariam was tortured while suffering from fresh wounds he sustained during examination.

"It is immoral to wish somebody his death but when they killed Kifle we said it was deliverance," the witness told the court.

Another witness told the court that he son, Ato Elias Zerihun, who had been working at the Anbessa City bus corporation along Tinsae Birhan was killed by the latter in 1977 after being jailed for one month.

Woizero Emebet Demelew, another witness said on her part that members of the army of the defunct Derg regime had killed her brother, her niece and her friend during a search launched in January 1976.

Another witness said her son Teketel Mehiretu had been imprisoned in Woreda 8 and added she had been supplying him with food for six consecutive days. She said the detainers one day drove him home.

"He (her son) said I came here to bid fare well, he screamed and fell over the ground, and detainers had killed him there on the spot," she said.

The trial was adjourned until June 17.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Bid report flawed - environmentalists


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town - Environmentalists fear that the long-awaited strategic environmental assessment of Cape Town's bid for the 2004 Olympic Games could be flawed.

The government's withholding of a report by the Development Bank of Southern Africa, coupled with the confidentiality of the Bid Company's financial records, "effectively prevents any rigorous financial and economic review", says the chairman of the Western Cape region of the Wildlife and Environment Society of South Africa, Graham Avery.

The "potential for the assessment to provide a conclusive analysis has been fundamentally undermined", he said. 

"The public needs substantive answers from the Bid Company and the government to convince it of their sincerity and of the economic and environmental soundness of the bid."

Dr Avery said the society was unable to decide whether it was for or against the bid in the absence of "sufficient information".

Bid Company spokesman Ameen Akhalwaya said it was false to claim that there was no public oversight of the bid's finances, since public representatives served on the bid board, and all records were scrutinised by the board.

"We are committed to accessibility, and any organisation is free to approach us for information."

But he added: "There are certain things we cannot disclose without undermining our strategy in what is a tough, international competition for a multibillion-rand investment. It would be irresponsible to overlook that."

* The Development Bank report predicts that a Cape Town Games will generate 100 000 permanent jobs - half in the Western Cape - tax income to the government of about R8-billion over 10 years from 1997, and a R30-billion gross domestic product boost over the same period.

Questioned about these figures, bank chief executive Ian Goldin has indicated to the International Olympic Committee that even in a "worst-case" scenario of cost over-runs and lower-than-expected revenues, the Olympics would still be good for South Africa in generating higher incomes, jobs and higher state revenue.

"We have done a lot of number-crunching, sensitivity analysis, what-ifs on cost over-runs, revenues not coming in ... and in the worst-case scenario we believe it will still make sense. The country as a whole will do better."


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
