Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Down the barrel of a gun


BYLINE: Johan Schronen, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - The owner of an Athlone petrol station has described how the staff of his forecourt shop stared down the barrel of the gun of the alleged killers of Simon's Town couple Ratilal Kessow and Henrietha Millward - and survived.

In a bizarre twist, another armed gang hit the same shop just two days later while the area was swarming with police searching for clues in a hunt for the first gang.

"Once is enough, but twice in two days is just too much," said owner Jaleel Sayed. 

Dr Kessow and Mrs Millward were hijacked and murdered and their bodies dumped in Mitchell's Plain. A short while later a gang of five men in Dr Kessow's car attacked a garage 2km away. They then hit the Athlone petrol station, taking R2 200.

On Tuesday Mr Sayed's staff again had to face armed robbers - who stole R1 700. "Both times my closed-circuit video monitoring system captured the perpetrators on film," he said.

"The tapes show the robbers' every move and their faces are as clear as in a photograph. But it's frightening to think what could have happened - especially in the first attack when the gang had already pulled off attacks, including a double murder."

The video showed the gang pulling up in Dr Kessow's BMW at 4.52am. Then three men got out of the car.

"The driver, who wore a black jacket and a black cap, bent down as he got out of the car and put on white surgical gloves.

"Then all three entered my shop together. Inside, they spread out, with one waiting in the middle of the shop while the other two moved to the cash point and asked for cooldrink - as if they couldn't see the huge cooldrink fridges on the other side of the shop.

"One of the men, who had a moustache, then pulled out a gun, and two of them moved behind the counter. My assistant looked straight down the barrel of the man's gun."

At that moment another car stopped outside. The forecourt staff were still unaware of the drama in the shop. The customer took out R20 and sent a petrol attendant into the shop to buy cigarettes.

"On the video you can see how the dozy attendant walked right into the robbery with his head down. He realised what was happening only when one of the robbers grabbed the R20 out of his hand and told him to put his hands in the air.

"The customer saw this and pulled off at quite a speed. That was the funny part - if there could ever be anything funny about a robbery," said Mr Sayed.

But on Tuesday, two men pulled up in an old Volkswagen Beetle, masked themselves and pulled off a second robbery. "One was a midget and the other was clumsy, dropping the gun - which went off, waking a resident nearby," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
The awful truth that still haunts us (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Cape Town - A photograph showing three policemen posing like trophy hunters with the body of a black person is being investigated by the Truth and reconciliation Commission

It is often much easier to forget than to remember, but there are some things which we forget at our peril - like the appalling pain and suffering inflicted on so many South Africans in apartheid's name.

This is at the heart of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's mandate: seeking and promoting reconciliation in a brutally fractured society, through a full and candid acknowledgement of the often painful truth about its past.

No-one suggests the commission will be able to uncover the full truth of the years between 1960 and 1994; clearly, that would be an impossible task, and truth is an ephemeral and elusive concept at the best of times. 

But what the commission can do - and is doing - is to uncover and bring us face to face with events and incidents from this brief period of our history that were sometimes deliberately concealed from sections of the population, while all too obvious to others, or which were blatantly denied by the powers-that-be.

The grim photograph which this newspaper carried on its front page yesterday of three policemen posing "hunter-style" with the body of a black man - apparently taken during the violent conflict that wracked the KTC squatter settlement in 1986 - is one such incident.

It is a nauseating image that is likely to evoke deep anger and outrage in anyone who sees it . But even more disturbing is the fact that it was by no means an isolated case during the apartheid era.

More and more hard evidence is coming to light in TRC hearings of a pervasive brutality in the apartheid police force, giving the lie to the National Party's repeated claims that illegal activities were the work of a "rogue" few, and demonstrating anew the daunting task that still lies ahead for those seeking to promote national unity and reconciliation.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Water and sewerage projects in the pipeline


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - The Cape Metropolitan Council (CMC) is considering raising about R150-million on the capital market next year to fund major water and sewerage projects.

At a meeting this week the council's finance committee decided to recommend that agency Duff & Phelps be asked to give the CMC a rating ahead of an approach to the capital market. 

Acting chief director of finance at the CMC Hennie Smit said the rating would help the council raise money on the market at competitive interest rates.

The funds would probably not be needed in the 1997-98 financial year, he said. But from next month the CMC, which was taking on responsibility for bulk water and sewerage services for all six municipalities in the area, would probably need loan finance to cover costs in the future.

"For instance, we are taking on all sewerage and pumping works in the Peninsula, including the Cape Flats sewerage works, which we have taken over from the Cape Town municipality and which has to be extended.

"The municipality has financed these extensions with loans of about R150 million from Investec and the Development Bank of Southern Africa, but we are looking at further extensions in mid- 1998 and we may need to approach the capital markets then."

The loan would be "of the same order" as the current extensions, he said, and the CMC might also need money for water provision.

Duff & Phelps, which is charging the CMC R25 000 to do the rating, was one of two agencies which submitted proposals. The other was IBCA.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

436 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Joe Mangcu: a dedicated worker for a world safe for animals


BYLINE: David Yutar, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Cape Town - Joe Mangcu wishes he was living in a world where no animal had to suffer, but since he is not, he dedicates himself to easing their plight.

Born in East London, Joe came to Cape Town in 1984, living first in the township of Langa and later in Khayelitsha.

Even as a child, Joe grew up learning to love pets.

"I grew up in a family that loved animals, and had a dog and a cat, and I was taught to respect and care for animals from an early age," he said. 

For the young Joe, learning about animals was almost part of his rites of passage, if you will.

"To gain acceptance as a young man one would have to leave one's home in the city and spend time in the country learning about all the different kinds of animals.

"In those days few people kept dogs or cats in their homes."

With the passage of time, Joe has learnt much about animals and has come to love them and care for them.

A receptionist for a city electronics company, Joe spends most of his free time running an animal care clinic in Khayelitsha, and helping all the township's sick and wounded animals.

The clinic, which is staffed by professional vets, operates at weekends only, although Joe would like to see it expanding its activities to include weekdays.

But how did this all begin?

"At Langa I used to pick up the stray dogs at the station and take them to the Athlone animal clinic," he said.

"When I moved to Khayelitsha, I was shocked to find that there was no animal clinic there, but only a mobile clinic for an hour at each township."

Realising the dire need for a permanent clinic, Joe began to lobby for one and to make representations in the relevant corridors of power.

Joe even wrote to President Mandela, telling him of the plight in the township but wherever he went, he was sent elsewhere on a wild goose chase.

On Saturday mornings you will find Joe at the modest clinic, often attending to the sick and injured himself.

"If it is something minor, I can attend to it myself, but if it is serious I have to wait for a vet."

Because Joe doesn't drive a car, he gets around the city either by train or on foot, and so it is often that he comes across sick or wounded animals.

"Some of them have been run over by cars, others bitten by other animals, and some even stabbed by people.

"I cannot understand why people would want to stab a dog.

"I have come across small dogs (he gestures with his hand to show the size of a small lapdog) that have been stabbed or injured by people."

Often on his way home from work, he might come across a stray dog or one that is clearly in need of medical attention and will take it home and to the clinic.

"There is not a dog that has been through the clinic that does not remember me afterwards, and greets me with a friendly lick - even those that are regarded by some people as vicious."

Joe feels that there is an urgent need for education about animal rights and the importance of looking after animals.

"People need to be taught about this from an early age and children need to be shown programmes about animal care on television."

Stray dogs are a common sight in Khayelitsha, says Joe, and the situation is not improving.

He estimates that about 70 percent of the dog population are strays and that the figure for cats is about 25 percent.

"What we need so badly is to go through the township, find all the unwanted or animals and find homes for them.

"I do not believe in killing animals", says Joe.

"Most of them are starving and once they get food they will pick up weight and become beautiful animals."

Another aspect that concerns him is that of giving pets the right food.

"The days when one cooked meat and pap and give the scraps to the dogs are gone.

"One needs to give them proper (nutritional) food."

And one of the major problems facing Joe is the lack of transport for bringing in sick animals.

"Without transport, I am simply not able to reach all the animals.

"Sometimes I am phoned late at night, but I am unable to reach a sick or injured animal because I do not have any transport.

"If I ask the taxis they say 'this taxi is not for dogs, it is for people'."

Apart from being a selfless and gentle man dedicated to easing the suffering of all those creatures smaller than himself, Joe is also ambitious.

Although his home language is Xhosa, he is fluent in English and he attends night school, where he is taking classes in languages and mathematics.

Sometimes he gets home as late as 10pm, exhausted after a busy day at work, as well as by his classes.

What is Joe's dream?

To "learn more about animals," he says with a broad smile.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Southern Africa;
Apartheid campaign created refugee crisis


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga premier, Mathews Phosa, on Thursday blamed apartheid for the sub region's refugee problem.

Addressing an international conference on refugees in Nelspruit, Phosa said apartheid created the refugee problem through a campaign to destroy the economies of the sub region. 

He said today, South Africa deported 400 Mozambicans daily, at a cost of R450 to R600 per person.

"But 300 of them return within 24 hours," he said.

He said the South African National Defence Force spent R700 million of its annual budget for border protection.

In 1996, he said, the Department of Home Affairs spent R7,6 million to deport illegal immigrants.

Quoting a writer, Phosa said: "'The impact of apartheid in the region represents a holocaust that few people outside the region know about or comprehend.'"

"I believe that any solution to the problem of refugees, ignoring the reality, will be superficial and will not stand a chance of succeeding," he said.

He said no country could solve the refugee problem in isolation.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Mozambique;
More than half of Mozambique's refugees still in South Africa


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Nelspruit - More than half of the Mozambican refugees who registered to be repatriated to Mozambique four years ago, are still in South Africa, said Mozambique's deputy minister of social welfare, Felipe Ricardo Monjate on Thursday.

Addressing an international conference on refugees in Nelspruit, Monjate said only 65 000 of the 175 000 Mozambican refugees had been repatriated since an agreement was signed between Mozambique, South Africa and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) in 1993. 

Director of UNHCR Operations in Southern Africa, Nicholas Bwakira, said repatriated Mozambicans had created a massive influx into seven of Mozambique's 10 provinces.

He warned that the return of refugees to their countries of birth had to be sustainable and not lead to another outflow of refugees.

He said problems affecting refugees in most countries related to socio-economic factors and political instability.

He said the UNHCR would use the shift to democracy in Africa to foster peace and tolerance, and to allocate sustainable resources to affected communities and help them strengthen their capacity.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Hani allegedly ordered killings of top ANC men


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Nelspruit - The Truth and Reconciliation Commission's (TRC) amnesty committee heard on Thursday that Chris Hani, the late secretary general of the South African Communist Party, ordered the killings of two of Mpumalanga's leading ANC politicians.

Amnesty applicant, Derrick Skosana (26) told the committee that Mpumalanga's former ANC secretary, Joe Nkuna, said Hani issued an order that all "enemy" agents be killed. 

Included in the list of alleged double agents were Mpumalanga's current MEC for Finance, Jacques Modipane, and MEC for Public Works, Jackson Mthembu.

Skosana said the list of double agents also included ANC treasurer at the time, Johannes Shabangu, whose house was the only one actually attacked.

Skosana said Modipane's house was not attacked, as he was not home.

Six people were in Shabangu's house during the attack on Novemer 11, 1992, including Mpumalanga's current MEC for sports, culture, arts and recreation, Lassy Chiwayo.

Skosana told the TRC on Thursday that his cousin, Peter Mnisi, was also in the house at the time of the attack.

"I know I did something wrong but I was under the impression that it was right thing to do for our movement at that time. And I am really sorry for what I have done," said Skosana.

He said he would not have attacked Shabangu's house if Nkuna had not said that the instructions came directly from Chris Hani and that Hani was asking for a progress report on the elimination of double agents.

Skosana is serving five years in jail for the attack.

Nkuna, who is serving seven years for the attack, and his brother, Conrad, who is serving five years for the same attack, have already testified before the committee.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Illovo to be listed on Swazi stock exchange


BYLINE: Banele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - Illovo Sugar announced on Wednesday afternoon that it is to be listed on the Swaziland Stock Exchange.

The announcement follows shortly after Illovo acquired the majority stake in Swaziland's Ubombo Ranches Sugar Company, which plans to diversify its product range by concentrating on sugar based by-products.

Illovo the stock exchange listing and consolidation with Ubombo will give additional impetus to Illovu's plans to increase support for more small-holder sugar cane growing schemes to boost production at their plant at Big Bend in the South East lowveld. 

The formalities of the acquisition of 94 percent of Lonrho Sugar shares by Illovo are expected to be completed next Friday (June 20th), creating the biggest sugar company in Africa with annual sugar production over 1.6 million tons.

The development follows a successful meeting on Monday between Illovo and the 40 percent shareholder in Ubombo Ranches - the Royal investment fund, Tibiyo TakaNgwane to discuss the acquisition.

That briefing was also attended by the Swaziland government.

Illovo now owns 60% of Ubombo Ranches while Tibiyo owns 40%. "As a regional player, Illovo operates in 15 sugar mills throughout Africa. Swaziland will therefore benefit from the transfer of technology and expertise from the professional team already servicing the existing sugar mills of Illovo," a statement from government spokesman, Meshack Shongwe said.

Illovo's industry position is expected to sweeten current sour relations between the Swaziland Sugar Association (SSA) and the South African Sugar Association (SASA).

At Monday's meeting with the Prime Minister, Dr Sibusiso Dlamini, Illovo was represented by Chairman, Richard Williams and Managing Director, Don Mcleod.

Tibiyo was represented by Managing Director, Themba Dlamini and his personal secretary, Sibongile Magagula as well as two officials from the Central Bank of Swaziland (CBS), Vinah Nkambule and Esther Magagula.

The Prime Minister paid tribute to Ubombo Ranches Managing Director, Dr Jerry Gosnell and his management and also briefed Illovo on the Swaziland Government's intentions to encourage higher participation in the sugar industry by indigenous Swazis through the Maguga Dam and Usuthu River developments.

"Both of these projects are a priority to the government...the presence of Illovo will therefore have a significant role in these projects and will boost the sugar industry in the Kingdom," he said.

441 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Swaziland;
South Africa to close 5 border posts with Swaziland


BYLINE: Banele Ginindza, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - South Africa is to close five of its borders with Swaziland as part of a drive to combat crime.

South African Customs Union spokesman Christo Henning told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Thursday that the closures formed part of a national exercise to scale down the number of exit and entry points into South Africa. 

"This is part of the SA National Strategy For Crime Prevention aimed at reducing the influx of smuggled and fake goods such as cassettes and sneakers," he said.

Also to be reduced, are the number of international airports.

"South African airports have been scaled down to nine from 36 and border posts have been reduced from 52 to just 19," he said.

He said only six of the current 11 border posts with Swaziland would be retained. They are Oshoek, Nerston, Mahamba, Golela, Mananga and Jeppes Reef.

Henning stressed that some of the border posts marked for closure were still operating, but said that they would be phased out before the end of the year.

These include Botha's Hoop-Gege, Emahlathini, Josefdal-Bulembu, Waverley-Lundzi and Onverwacht-Nsalitshe.

The closure announcement comes in the wake of Swaziland's biggest drug bust ever, in which a dagga shipment estimated to be worth over R7,2 million destined for South Africa was found by Royal Swaziland Police last week.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

442 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Swaziland;
Violent hijackings spread to normally peaceful kingdom


BYLINE: Ronnie Mamba, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

MBABANE (Swaziland) - An unprecedented surge in violent vehicle hi-jackings in Swaziland have prompted police to launch a series of spot roadblocks and vehicle searches in the kingdom.

Confirming that 107 of the 299 vehicles which had been stolen since January were taken at gun-point, police spokesman Sergeant Victor Dlamini stressed, however, the Royal Swaziland Police's recovery rate was over 50 percent. 

He said that police had already recovered 165 of the 299 stolen vehicles, and were still looking for only 134 cars.

"The worst months for vehicle theft this year January, when thieves stole 69 cars and for some reason during May, when they took 65 vehicles," said Sergeant Dlamini.

Last year, Swaziland police cracked a syndicate using Swaziland as a transit conduit for their operations, which channelled stolen cars from Southern Africa to as far afield as Tanzania.

Swaziland's 11 border posts with South Africa are favourite routes to staging points in Maputo before being shipped on to east and central Africa.

Because of the trans-national nature of the thieves' operations, countries in the region have established a "front- line" crack police squad to combat the syndicates master minding the trade.

The squad, which will initially deal mainly with hi-jack cases, comprises of officers from South Africa, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and Zambia.

General crime has also escalated in the Kingdom of Swaziland over the past few years, with violent crime showing a particular upswing. With a population of just under 1 million people, the Kingdom has only one policeman for every 700 citizens.

South Africa;
Taxi passenger caught in the cross-fire


BYLINE: Dumisane Lubisi, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

PIET RETIEF - A taxi driver and one of his passengers, were shot in the legs during a taxi dispute in Piet Retief on Thursday morning, police reports.

Piet Retief station commander, Captain Alex Gouws told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Thursday that and unnamed driver and Winnie Kunene were injured after an argument about routes "turned ugly" at the town's official taxi rank. 

"Just after 10h00, drivers from Dondonald and Fernie started arguing about their routes and who was allowed to use them. When things became heated, one of the men allegedly pulled his pistol out and shot a Fernie driver in the leg," said Captain Gouws.

Kunene, who was sitting in taxi waiting to depart for Klipwill Trust, was also hit in her leg by a stray bullet.

Gouws added that police had the gunman's identity and would be arresting the man as soon as enough statement had been collected.

Police were still investigating and the situation is also being monitored by police patrolling the area

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Science and Health;
Kruger Park opposes slurry pipeline


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Nelspruit - National Parks Board (NPB) officials and environmentalists on Thursday strongly opposed the possibility of a slurry pipeline being dug across the Kruger National Park into Mozambique.

Representatives of the Kruger National Park (KNP) called for a petition on the issue, which they said was of international, and not just local interest.

"About 900 000 people visit the Kruger National Park every year and spend their money here, and they should also have something to say about it," said KNP representative, Ralph Culver. 

Environmental concerns about the pipeline, which would be part of a 30-year iron production project, were raised at a public meeting in Nelspruit organised by the Independent Development Corporation (IDC).

The envisaged pipeline could transfer nine megalitres of water and finely milled magnetite each day from Phalaborwa, through the park, to an iron production plant in Maputo. According to Etienne Roux of the IDC, three possible pipeline routes, two of which pass through the Kruger National Park, were being considered as options.

He said the option of laying the pipeline along the border of the Kruger National Park did not seem viable, however, as it was the longest of the three routes at 370km, and too many stakeholders were involved.

"The route around the park would require negotiations with hundreds of landowners, while the routes through the park would only involve the National Parks Board and Mozambican government," Roux said.

The route outside the park would also increase the cost of laying the pipeline from R90 million to R190 million.

Roux said the route outside the park could, however, be more viable if Spoornet made an affordable offer to rail the magnetite to Maputo.

Roux stressed that should the pipeline be laid in the Kruger National Park, it would be buried 1,5 metres under the ground and then covered with vegetation.

The two possible routes through the Kruger National Park would cross a distance of either 94 km or 144 km and it is not yet known if an access road to the pipeline would be necessary.

Roux added that the pipe itself would be maintenance free and could only be damaged if accidentally hit by ploughs or earthmoving equipment.

The magnetite itself was not toxic, he said, and therefore would not pose a serious problem if a leak should occur.

Kruger National Park officials are concerned, however, that the project may create a precedent for other industrial development in the park and have a cumulative impact on the ecology of the area.

The manager of the NPB's environmental services, Murray Macgregor, added that the construction of the pipeline would also contravene the National Parks Board Act.

"In terms of the law, we cannot sanction any activity or development that could compromise its (the Kruger Park) conservation ethics and objectives, or the integrity of any of the national parks," he said.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Mill burnt to the ground in ongoing border dispute


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

BUSHBUCKRIDGE - A saw mill burnt to the ground in Bushbuckridge on Thursday morning after it was allegedly petrol bombed by pro- Mpumalanga demonstrators.

Police spokesperson, Supt Phuti Setati, said the Geldenhuis Saw Mill was attacked between 1am and 2am and that damage was estimated at R1,5 million. 

"We condemn this violence because only innocent people, who know nothing about the border dispute, are being attacked daily," Supt Setati told African Eye News Service (South Africa).

Pro-Mpumalagna demonstrators have been demanding for the past two months that Bushbuckridge be transferred from Northern Province to Mpumalanga.

On Friday, President Nelson Mandela told members of the Bushbuckridge Border Committee that Bushbuckridge would not be transferred to Mpumalanga.

The pro-Mpumalanga demonstrators are arguing that they are economically linked to Mpumalanga as most of them work in Hazyview or Nelspruit and do their shopping there.

Supt Setati said six houses belonging to workers from the Geldenhuis Saw Mill were also petrol bombed on Monday, killing two people.

The workers were allegedly part of a stayaway in support of the call for Bushbuckridge's incorporation into Mpumalanga.

No arrests have been made in either case and police are still investigating, Supt Setati said.

The manager of Geldenhuis Saw Mill, Giel Geldenhuis, was unavailable for comment as he was engaged in a meeting. .


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


446 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga Housing chairman a "ghost" employee


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Nelspruit - The man who engineered Mpumalanga's contentious R200-million rural low cost housing development with Motheo Construction, Saths Moodley, doesn't theoretically exist in Mpumalanga's finance systems.

Neither the province's housing department nor the Provincial Service Commission have the required records and Identity numbers on their computer systems to legally pay Moodley for his two years of service on the province's now suspended Housing Board.

Moodley retired from the board three weeks ago after Mail & Guardian revealed that the Auditor General was investigating the Motheo scheme, which is the biggest rural development of its type yet in South Africa. 

Housing department finance director, Belinda Mojabelo, confirmed on Wednesday that "something went very wrong with Moodley's appointment".

"The proper channels weren't followed and we didn't get all the necessary information and documentation. We don't have his Identity Number."

According to public service regulations, even casual labourers have to supply a there Home Affairs ID number before being paid by the state.

"It appears that Moodley was paid as a creditor and not as an employee or contract worker. You see, he was appointed as a politician and not as an employee," she added.

Mojabelo also confirmed that the department has never deducted any form of income tax from its payments to Moodley and that "we cannot now deduct the necessary tax because Moodley has left the department and we no longer have any power over him".

She also confirmed that Moodley was paid for his services out of a special suspense account and that all payments were personally authorised by department chief director, Steve Ngwenya.

Ngwenya failed to return a series of urgent messages and his assistant, assistant director Bonniface Dlamini, twice told Mail & Guardian that both he and MEC Craig Padayachee were "out of town".

Various other officials in the department, including Padayachee's secretary however said that they were in office and were in a meeting discussing the Motheo issue.

Padayachee also failed to return M&G's numerous messages.

Departmental spokesperson, Leon Mbangwa, conceded that Moodley's appointment had been "unusual" but insisted that it had been a conscious political decision aimed at "fast tracking housing delivery".

Insisting that it was unnecessary for the department to have Moodley's ID number and other details before paying him, Mbangwa said Moodley was never paid a salary, only an "allowance".

He also denied that it was the department's responsibility to deduct income or other tax from the payments.

Mbangwa also insisted that Ngwenya was no longer connected with his previous legal practice, Steve Ngwenya & Themba Kwayo Attorneys, despite the practice continuing to operate under both men's names.

He insisted that there was no conflict of interests that a large percent of the legal practice's business involved conveyancing low cost housing subsidies for the department.

"Look, Themba bought the right to continue using Steve's name when he joined the department because Steve is very popular and influential. You are just targeting Themba because he is black," said Mbangwa.

"Themba was clever enough to link up with Steve and use his name and that's all there is to it. Housing applicants have a choice to go to any other conveyancers or to this one, so there's nothing wrong with it."

He denied that applicants may be swayed by the fact that Ngwenya was a highly visible public figure within the department which granted the subsidies.

Themba Kwayo was unavailable for comment at the time of going to press.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

447 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga's corruption rot spreads


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Nelspruit - Yet another of Mpumalanga's embattled government institutions is set to crumble after details of "wild & irresponsible" advances and financial management are revealed later today (Friday) in the province's legislature.

Internal investigations, sparked by media reports earlier this year, have discovered that the speaker of the legislature, Elias Ginindza, authorised R272 000 worth of alternations to his personal home at State expense.

An audit of the work performed, however, indicates that the value of both material and labour is less than R75 000. 

Ginindza insists that he was forced to carry out the alternations, including the installation of an electric gate, due to police concerns about his safety.

Legislative officials however point out that if this was the case, then the police should have paid for the alternations.

Ginindza concedes that there was "overspending" and has reportedly suggested that the construction company which did the alternations perform additional work for the legislature to the value of R200 000 to make up the difference.

Ginindza is not the only senior official implicated in serious irregularities. Deputy speaker, Cynthia Maropeng, has taken personal advances from the legislature for more than R75 000 over the past eight months.

She has yet to pay the amount back but vehemently denied ever taking advances when initially quizzed about the issue by Mail & Guardian in January.

She instead suggested, at a confrontation attended by Ginindza and the two other most senior legislative officials, that the questions were racially motivated and aimed at "maliciously smearing" black leaders.

According to internal documentation, Maropeng first took relatively small advances. Then, without explanation, she took three R10 000 advances in quick succession, followed by a single R45 000 advance.

Of special concern to investigators, however, is the method in which the advances are being repaid.

Instead of having payments deducted off salaries or being repaid via bank loans, S*** and other officials are 'paying' back their advances by running up additional travel and accommodation expenses with the legislature.

Then, instead of being paid out for their theoretical discomfort, they simply deduct the sum off what they owe.

Maropeng, for example, stayed at Cape Town's Mount Nelson hotel with her child and it's nanny for an unspecified period and claimed the stay as official accommodation to be deducted off her advance.

The advances are also now been granted to MPLs and even junior staff members. Officials were unable to tell M&G exactly how much was still owing.

More details of the irregularities, including the disappearance of a substantial number of computers ordered by the legislature, "massive" abuse of overtime claims and the irregular appointment of staff, will be discussed at a press conference in Nelspruit later today.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

448 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Bus fares up by 25%


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda and Dickson Jere, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - A 25 per cent bus fare increase was yesterday announced by United Transport and Taxis Association (UTTA).

UTTA national chairman, Willie Nsanda, in an interview with ZNBC television yesterday, said the hike would be effected from Thursday midnight. 

The UTTA fare increment follows a 24 per cent fuel price effected Tuesday midnight by Zambia National Oil Company.

Nsanda said UTTA had considered raising the fares over the 25 per cent but were mindful that commuters were also going through economic hardships.

And Kitwe Chamber of Commerce chairman, Boniface Chibeza, said he was disappointment with Zambia National Oil Company's decision to increase fuel prices in the light of low World oil prices.

He said he did not understand why the company had decided to increase the already high fuel prices when even the foreign exchange rates had stabilised.

Chibeza said the fuel price increase destroys any hope for companies to pick up following increased costs.

UNIP administrative secretary, Basil Kabwe, said most prices of commodities will soon go up.

"Come July this country will be like the former Zaire because the kwacha will be devalued to an extend that every one will be talking of leaving Zambia," Kabwe said in an interview yesterday.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy national secretary, Azwell Banda, said this week's fuel price increment was an indication of more serious problems to come due to the withholding of balance of payments support by the country's donors.

"Zambians should actually expect increments in all the domestic utilities because our cooperating partners are not willing to release the balance of payment support ," Banda said in an interview yesterday.

LANGUAGE: English

449 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Presidential petition


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, Chilombo Mwondela and Goodson Machona, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - PRESIDENT Frederick Chiluba's lawyers yesterday in the Supreme Court produced evidence to dispute part of petitioner's witness Dr. Steven Moyo's evidence.

Legal Affairs minister Vincent Malambo, who led the cross- examination, referred Dr. Moyo to government gazette notices of 1987, 1994 and 1996 which basically disputed his earlier evidence that polling districts had been shifted around in certain constituencies in Ndola. 

The notices also discounted Dr. Moyo's evidence that the numbering of the polling districts was not serialised.

A government gazette notice for the 1991 elections showed that polling districts even at that time were not serialised.

Another notice showed that certain polling districts which Dr. Moyo had said were not gazetted but were only found in one of the documents he had, was not actually correct but that they were gazetted in Isoka.

But Dr. Moyo insisted that they were gazetted in the wrong constituency. He said his complaint yesterday had been that they were not listed under Nakonde as was supposed to be the case but were gazetted in a different town, Isoka.

The examples of such polling stations were Musele, Mbokoshi and Chitambi in Northern Province.

This cross-examination finally degenerated into Dr. Moyo disputing some of Malambo's statements and the court adjourned at a point of the 1996 gazette notice which the petitioners wanted to verify before their witness could be questioned on it.

Dr. Moyo said that notice did not have Government Printers mark written on the back of it to show that it was really printed by them and his lawyer State Counsel Edward Shamwana, after examining the said notice, said they needed to check it out.

Cross-examination continues today.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
ZDC advises opposition


BYLINE: Fred M'membe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Lusaka - If opposition parties are not careful they may find themselves being fooled and used by ruling MMD again, warned Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy general secretary Azwell Banda yesterday.

Banda, in a walk in interview yesterday, said the agreement reached in Stockholm, Sweden between UNIP, Agenda for Zambia and the National Party, as opposition, and the ruling MMD to meet within 21 days is simply designed to help the MMD meet its Consultative Group (CG) meeting conditionalities.

"The whole arrangement is as a result of the haste of (finance minister Ronald) Penza to meet CG conditionalities," Banda said.

The ZDC deputy general secretary said his party will not be tricked by MMD over these negotiations the way they were fooled over last year's "fraudulent" elections. 

"Nothing short of concrete movements towards resolving the problem of the constitution through a constituent assembly and a complete overhaul of the current electoral regime will suffice," Banda warned. "Opposition parties who have been calling for dialogue and it is well known that it is the MMD that walkout of the meeting called to address the issue of the constitution and electoral process."

The International Idea invited the ruling MMD and some opposition parties to Stockholm for a Roundtable to initiate an all-parties dialogue which was aborted in May last year.

The MMD was represented by finance minister Ronald Penza, tourism minister Amusaa Mwanamwamba, information and broadcasting minister David Mpamba and the party's deputy national secretary Paul Tembo.

UNIP was represented by the secretary general Sebastian Zulu, central committee member Rabbison Chongo and special assistant to the party president Muhabi Lungu.

The National Party was represented by secretary general Ludwig Sondashi and the Agenda of Zambia was represented by its president Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika.

ZDC was not represented because Kasuka Mutukwa who had been arranging for the Stockholm meeting had been expelled from the party.

Zambian political parties agreed in Stockholm on June10, 1997 to work together and establish a programme of action for sustainable democracy.

At the end of a two day meeting sponsored by the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (International IDEA) an agreement was reached to begin dialogue between the government and representatives of the leading opposition parties in the country.

"I am very excited by this event, the beginning of a dialogue to carry forward the process of democratization," stated Penza.

UNIP secretary general Zulu agreed: "I am very pleased with the outcome of this unique round table talks because the interest of Zambia demands that there must be meaningful dialogue."

The agreement, which was adopted and signed Tuesday, states that within 21 days the ruling party will initiate an all-party meeting "to establish an agenda programme of action to address sustainable democratic development". The MMD will initiate the first meeting and a facilitator from international IDEA will be present.

The new dialogue will focus, inter alia, on questions about the design of the electoral process and ways of increasing the democratic capacity of Zambian institutions.

The process of democratization in Zambia, since the early 90s, has run into a number of obstacles. The largest was the lack of a dialogue between the leading political parties.

Over the last few months IDEA has played a mediating role in Zambia.

"I am extremely pleased that IDEA could play a facilitating role, but the real credit goes to the political parties who have achieved this breakthrough and demonstrated a real example of peaceful conflict resolution," said IDEA's secretary-general Begt Save-Soderbergh.

Also present at the round table were representatives of Denmark, the European Commission, Finland, Germany, Ireland, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the United Kingdom, the United States, UNDP, and the World Bank.

Agenda for Zambia president Mbikusita-Lewanika told the Stockholm meeting that "the importance of democratic development and values can not be over emphasised, as an integral part of this dialogue initiative".

"Agenda for Zambia and other democratic agents on the Zambian scene want the country to advance on, by first establishing a solid and comprehensive democratic constitutional and electoral regime by a broad national consensus," Mbikusita-Lewanika said. "This is what the present Zambia ruling party is being called upon to endorse and facilitate through genuine and inclusivist dialogue."

"Our objection to the constitutional manipulation of 1996 in Zambia is essentially on account of the measures having been taken to reduce rights and freedom of selected victim citizens," Mbikusita-Lewanika said. "This forum comes after the abortion of an all-party conference which was attempted to try and resolve problems on the constitution and electoral process before the rigged 1996 Elections. There was also an abortion of the ruling party-cum-government proposed one-to-one presidential level dialogue, before the rigged 1996 Elections."

"Issues of any further reformation of the electoral process or of capacity building for political party cannot be undertaken in isolation and outside the frame work of a comprehensive revisiting of the constitution," Mbikusita-Lewanika said.

Mbikusita-Lewanika told the Stockholm meeting that efforts towards the advancement of political freedom, economic progress and human security need to be applied locally and worldwide.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
Stability crucial to trade, says Chiluba


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Cooperation and stability is crucial if trade is to flourish among Southern Africa Development Countries, said President Frederick Chiluba yesterday.

President Chiluba, receiving Belgium Ambassador to Zambia Leopold Carrewyn's credentials at State House, said that Zambia believed in regional cooperation as a necessary factor in enhancing trade among member countries. 

"Zambia is committed to political interaction with other countries because, as a nation and a region, it needs a large market through organisations like SADC (Southern African Development Community)," President Chiluba said.

The President noted that lately trade between Africa and Europe has started favouring the former as many countries on the continent were now slowly finding their markets in Europe.

Ambassador Carrewyn lauded the role Zambia was playing in the peace process in central Africa, especially in Angola and the Great Lakes Region, where it has participated in a number of important deliberations.

Ambassador Carrewyn said Belgium's stance on the new Democratic Republic of Congo and President Laurent Kabila was constructive and in favour of a broad based transition government with an eventual free and fair election.

"We believe that President Kabila's government should seek, together with the international assistance, a prompt solution on the refugee problem and shed light on the humanitarian situation in eastern Congo," Ambassador Carrewyn said.

Switzerland Ambassador to Zambia, Catherine Kreg Polejack, during the same ceremony, said that her country was aware of the economic problems Zambia was facing and that it would assist in the modest way it could.

President Chiluba, in reply, said the Swiss had assisted in Zambia's school rehabilitation programme and Ambassador Polejack's coming to Zambia should help strengthen the two countries relations.

June 13, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: 14 barred from FAZ elections


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - MORE than fourteen candidates for the June 28, Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) executive membership polls will be barred following the anomalies in their nomination papers.

FAZ interim executive treasurer Musa Kasonka is among the candidates who are not eligible while Zambia Tender Board boss Teddy Mulonga still tops the list.

According to an inspection of nomination papers conducted in Lusaka last week, Monze businessman Harish Naik like Mulonga used Zanaco treasurer Collins Shamutete to sign his papers while Kasonka falls out of favour because he has not served enough years in soccer administration at club level to back his candidature. 

Bennet Simfukwe of Nkana Football Club and Donald Mulenga, Profund Warriors chairman are some of the candidates ruled out because they were seconded by 'wrong' people.

Other names include David Chiti, Peter Nyongani, G. Mwene, A. Pandor, Ishmail Pandor and Andy Sitali from youth football association who signed the nomination papers for themselves.

"This inspection was done in the presence of the acting general secretary of Football Association of Zambia, Mr. Chiluba as per constitutional clause 6. and electrol rules," reads the statement which was made available to The Post.

Mulonga and Naik may, however, successfully contest for their positions if FAZ waives the ban following a June 6, letter from Shamutete which indicates that he is acting chairman of Zanaco.

FAZ is expected to publish a full list of the successful candidates on Monday, two weeks before the elections in Kabwe at Masiye Motel on June 28 and committee member Kangwa Mutupa is among those disqualified for flauting the electral procedures.

The interim president Micheal Chiti is still in contention for the topmost seat with division one south Green Buffalos chairman and former FAZ general secretary Herman Mpashi.

With the disqualification of Mutupa and Pandor for the vice- presidency, the race is on between City of Lusaka vice-chairman Simon Phiri and former Kabwe Warriors chairman Lasky Mwandu.

For the treasurer position those still in the running are Charles Mushabati from Ministry of Finance FC, Mwiya Songiso, Sam Phiri (Lusaka Tigers) and Andrea Mtine, Ndola Wanderers boss.

Prominent among the committee membership race include George Kasengele, Joel Kabika, Masiye Masiye, Henchel Chitembeya, Musonda Shonga, Mwansa Mulubwa, Jeff Chipilingu and Mada Banda.

Meanwhile, FAZ has published the full list of all the candidates, fourteen days before the polls date in compliance with the constitution.

Announcing the full list FAZ general secretary Julio Chiluba has disclosed that the invalid and valid nominations will be made public tomorrow.

June 13, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Zambia: ZAPOTA receives K10m from CICIBA


BYLINE: Sam Mujuda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - THE Zambia Popular Theater Alliance (ZAPOTA) has received K10 million for its second and final phase from the International Centre for Bantu Civilisation (CICIBA), European Union/Zambia.

ZAPOTA has also been picked to represent Zambia at the up coming Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) festival to be held in Maputo, Mozambique. 

ZAPOTA national chairman, Richard Mwanza with the funds having been released, the second phase takes off this Monday.

"In the second phase we are going to involve Lusaka, Luapula and Western provinces. Country widely we have between 400 and 500 registered groups and in Lusaka alone we have 25 groups," Mwanza said.

Mwanza also said the theme of their performances would boarder on the importance of voting with more emphasis on the local government elections.

And ZAPOTA travels to Maputo for the festival that starts on June 20 running to June 27 with a play entitled What Went Wrong .

"ZAPOTA was picked for the festival after auditions that were conducted in Lusaka. We will be traveling with a group of 14 participants with an inclusion of Butondo theater of Nkana Kitwe Arts Society," Mwanza explained.

What Went Wrong focuses on the erosion of the African society in relation to the western, modern and influential cultures.

454 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
More to go up (Editorial)


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Lusaka - The 24 per cent increase in the price of petroleum products which became effective at midnight on Tuesday will lead to a general escalation of costs throughout the economy.

Bus and taxi fares are up by 25 per cent already and that is just the beginning. Virtually all costs will rise and price adjustments to meet that quite massive rise will be unavoidable. 

In the final analysis it is the costs of living and doing business that will have risen and by more than 24 per cent.

The question is where does that leave Zambia, a country struggling to attract investment and breathe life into critical sectors of the economy crippled by structural adjustment?

The answer may be that it leaves the country at least 24 per cent more unattractive for investment now than before that increase.

Typically, such increases are effected without any serious thought to what obtains in neighbouring countries in the region.

Yet time has come for Zambia to be a lot more conscious about the economic situation in neighbouring countries. Zambia is in competition with them for the much needed investment as well as bilateral and multilateral assistance.

Investors have a choice and are persuaded by other considerations than verbal eloquence and lies.

Ever spiraling costs in the local economy work against Zambia in favour of those neighbouring countries where the cost of doing business may be lower and economic factors generally are more stable. They will be a more attractive destination for investment and even aid.

Liberalisation may mean facing economic realities in the face and responding to them in line with the rules of supply and demand. But it is no license for pricing oneself out of the market or making an economy unattractive for investment.

While keeping costs artificially low will help nobody, it is in Zambia's interest to proceed with extreme caution in this area. Both the cost of living and doing business are already high. The infra-structure is in a sorry state and there appears no capacity to repair it.

Further deterioration in the investment and business atmosphere cannot be in the country's interest. It can only ensure that most of the elaborate plans to attract investment remain a pipe dream and life unaffordable.

It is therefore wrong to view the increase in the price of petroleum products as just one of those period adjustments which have become part of Zambia.

It could be a most serious setback for all well laid plans to put the economy back on the rails. It goes to the heart of everything that the country wants to achieve and what may still be on the drawing boards.

It is a measure of the continuing crisis in the management of the economy that the price increase even though having far reaching implications was announced in an off hand manner. It was really a take it or leave it thing .

Zambians have no choice. They will have to take it. But the investors have and may decide to vote with their feet.

Perhaps the real crying need is for more coordinated planning at higher levels so that various efforts are not undermined so easily.

But above all there should be a clearer definition of what the country really wants and a more defined way of getting there. There is little evidence of this at present.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


455 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Economy Watch: Zambian mine workers may lose out (Column)


BYLINE: Dominic Ksanda, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Lusaka - I write regarding Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) privatisation pronouncements, the looming denial of terminal benefits payments for those who will remain in employment with new investors and an urgent need for ZCCM employees (miners) to unite.

It is common knowledge that majority of miners are for privatisation of the giant conglomerate to instill discipline at managerial level and lease a new life of viability in the company.

However, miners are not happy with the pronouncements made so far concerning payment of terminal benefits and Mukuba Pension Scheme (Mukuba) due to affected members. Statements from the four stakeholders (actors), viz; ZCCM board, politicians/government, ZPA and MUZ are shifty/inconsistent, hollow, flaccid and cowardly (in the case of MUZ). 

It is an open fact that only an insane/crooked investor can agree to pay for service not rendered to him/her or else the whole ZCCM privatisation issue is bogus and smells to the core. Where on earth has one heard of a same investor committing himself/herself to services that did not benefit him/her in any way?

Additionally, only a trick-star (the likes of Mukuba Trustees) can agree to prevail over the scheme when ZCCM is no more and members/Coy stop contributing to the scheme when exit pension salaries remain static) as at 30 June 1997 as revised when ZCCM will be dissolved.)

Going by current developments, therefore, miners must take ZCCM at law, before the case is overtaken by events. My passionate appeal is for miners/MUZ at Divisional level to form ZCCM dissolution division committees that will in turn form the industry committee to spearhead the suing of ZCCM. These committees will discuss issues of mutual interest and agree on an amount of money to be contributed by each miner (K10,000 per U). Once this money is raised miners should engage more than two law firms to prevail on contentious issues on their behalf, i.e. payment of terminal benefits and dissolution of Mukuba/payment of Mukuba benefits. In the event of MUZ-Industry being unsupportive of the move it will be the next target for litigation.

Finally, if some miners are skeptical of the above and want further information before they can move, here are a few highlights for consideration:

a) Privatisation

1. When Chingola School of Accountancy, Vision Consult and others were privatised all affected employees were given terminal benefits. The issue is not the number of individuals involved but a precedence that has been set. Therefore, why should miners benefits be kept in a Trust Fund as the government is insisting?

2. New investors have a tendency of firing employees at will or ditching them if things get touch, e.g. SAMAT at Mufulira, Premium Oil Company's saga, Lonrho, Anglo-American at Zambia Breweries), etc.

3. ILO conventions to which Zambia subscribe protect employees' rights and emphasise payment of benefits when companies change hands.

4. US$4.3 billion will be realised from the sell of ZCCM whilst terminal benefits bill is US$420 million. yet the government tells miners that it can't source for this, which is only one-tenth (1/10) of the amount to be realised from the sell of the mines. What a gray lie.

B. Mukuba Pension Scheme

1. When members and ZCCM stop contributing to the scheme, the scheme will cease to be viable since its value will slowly erode due to inflation/payment of salaries that will lead to the Scheme's liquidation and the dilapidated assets will be sold at uneconomical prices where members/beneficiaries will lose out.

2. The board changes rules arbitrary without consulting members, eg. the company is no longer meeting its 10.8 per cent equivalent obligation for each member instead it is only meeting the administration cost of the scheme (revised members handbook - May 1996). this is a condition that was rejected by the Walamba Industry MUZ executive that the current industry MUZ executive has not bothered to challenge.

In the absence of MUZ, following dissolution of ZCCM, we expect serious omissions and commissions by the trustees.

3. It is doubtful if ZCCM was remitting its 10.8 per cent contribution equivalent obligation up to April 1996.

However, what members know quite well is that ZCCM has borrowed billions from Mukuba. Money which ZCCM has for sometime now been using to pay miners salaries, bonuses (for the eligible employees) etc.

4. Mukuba contributions have been mismanaged. The Board members, trustees/employees of Mukuba, government and other high ranking personalities and institutions have borrowed heavily from the scheme hence the board's reluctance to dissolve the scheme and its stance that members stand to lose if Mukuba is dissolved, assets sold and proceeds distributed proportionately.

5. The Union is happy with the asset base of Mukuba and wants the scheme to survive the privatisation process. unfortunately, some MUZ officials (including those at industry level) are not members of Mukuba. Can these negotiate effectively? Isn't MUZ's future bleak following privatisation.

6. some ZCCM top management officials have pulled out and have paid themselves full benefits.

The ongoing negotiations are crucial and are being monitored carefully for tangible results. however, the outcome will not be as is anticipated. The negotiating team is too weak. Therefore, employees should fight for their rights.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Zambia;
LAZ Supports Judges Perks


BYLINE: Amos Malupenga, Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Inadequate remuneration is undermining the independence of the judiciary, said Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) chairman George Kunda yesterday.

Kunda, in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday, said inadequate remuneration has undermined the judiciary to an extent where judges do not feel secure and confident.

The LAZ chairman, supporting recently gazetted salary increments for Supreme Court and High Court judges, hoped the judiciary will continue dispensing justice fairly regardless of the type of cases and litigants involved. 

"Judges in Zambia sacrifice a lot and shoulder a heavy responsibility and work load in spite of the inadequate remuneration," Kunda said. "It is the view of the Association that the current salaries earned by judges cannot attract lawyers in private practice to the bench."

Kunda added: "To instill confidence and avoid corruption, judges must be well remunerated."

Kunda said LAZ has for a long time been concerned about the inadequate "and even scandalous remuneration that has been paid to judges of the High Court and the Supreme Court in Zambia".

Kunda condemned "the contemptuous attacks on the judiciary whether in relation to their remuneration or otherwise".

"The poorly paid judiciary deserves respect," Kunda said, adding that

unwarranted attacks of the judiciary will only lower its image and integrity.

President Frederick Chiluba, through statutory instrument no. 67 of May 28, 1997, increased Supreme Court judges' salaries by more than 207 per cent. Opposition parties are opposed the increase, claiming President Chiluba has bought the judges.

Nine months ago, judges - through statutory instrument no.140 of August 21, 1996 - were awarded another salary increment.

Liberal Progressive Front chairman, Rodger Chongwe, and National Party secretary general Ludwig Sondashi - both lawyers - urged the judges to reject the salary increment, saying it was a "bribe".

And Zambia Democratic Congress President Dean Mung'omba charged that if the judges will accept President Chiluba's "corrupt" salary increment then they should consider themselves "useless."

"But if they should accept they should consider themselves totally useless and irrelevant to both the political and economic difficulties in this country," Mung'omba said.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


457 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
No chance to rest and dream of France


BYLINE: Andrew Muchineripi, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Johannesburg - Coach Clive Barker and Bafana Bafana have come through a torrid time triumphantly, but there is still much work to be done.

When the Egyptian referee blew his whistle to end the South Africa-Zambia World Cup encounter, national coach Clive Barker must have longed for the solitude of his farm outside Durban.

Since April, Bafana Bafana have constantly been in the limelight with cup ties against Congo, Zaire and Zambia and high- profile friendlies against England and Holland.

The record shows that although South Africa lost three of these matches, they won the two that mattered most - the World Cup clashes with Zaire in neutral Togo and Zambia at FNB Stadium. 

Barker may have seen a little gloss disappear from what remains a highly successful record in charge, but he is on the verge of leading South Africa into the promised land.

A victory or draw at home to Congo on August 16 would take Bafana Bafana to France in June 1998 as one of five African representatives. Nigeria, Tunisia and Morocco have qualified and Cameroon or Angola will fill the other slot.

Sometimes, Barker, his players and supporters must pinch themselves and wonder if it is all not just one never-ending dream. It seems like yesterday that Zimbabwe, Nigeria, Zambia and Mexico were humiliating us. Of course the heaviest home defeat came only a week ago when the Dutch dished out a football lesson on a freezing Johannesburg evening as they romped to a two-goal victory in a contest between severely weakened teams.

Not that the result could have worried Barker too much as one undisputed strength of the squad he has methodically developed is their ability to bounce back from adversity.

After consecutive losses in Australia, they became the first national team in 10 years to leave Madagascar triumphant; after losing to Egypt in the Nations Cup, they overcame Algeria to reach the semi-finals. After falling to Brazil in the unforgettable Nelson Mandela Inauguration Challenge, they defeated Malawi at home and away in the World Cup; and after the Congo debacle, they conquered Zaire to get back on track for France.

If a team mirrors its coach, then this attribute comes as no surprise. Whatever the technical shortcomings of Clive Barker (and his critics have yet to spell them out), the man born 53 years ago in Durban is a fighter and a patriot.

He may also have become over sensitive to what he considers "criticism", but is often nothing more than comment from the print and electronic media.

Last Sunday we were told that Barker had proved his critics wrong. Wrong about what? No two football people, be they coaches, players, officials, members of the fourth estate or supporters, will pick the same 11 to represent Bafana Bafana and that is the way it should be. We are not living in North Korea.

Is the veteran soccer journalist who opined last week that Barker should have used fullbacks rather than midfielders in wingback roles a traitor? Rather that honesty than the ill- informed, sycophantic ramblings of certain media members.

You can understand the occasional annoyance of the coach because when he recently asked one Sunday newspaper reporter what system he used in the Congo, there was no reply, only a deafening silence. Talking of criticism, it would be constructive to note that while Bafana Bafana untimately overwhelmed Zambia, there are weaknesses needing attention in many areas of the team.

The quality of crosses is not exactly world class (Sizwe Motaung please note); too many Eric Tinkler passes go to the opposition; and too much "clever" football is being attempted in defensive areas.

While Helman Mkhalele was rightfully taking much of the praise last Sunday, it was the old warhorse, Neil Tovey, who provided some of the most telling contributions, especially the first-half tackle that foiled Kalusha Bwalya.

African qualifiers are fortunate to have almost one year to prepare for the finals and presuming Bafana Bafana take at least one point off Congo, Barker and his staff will have time to reflect and react. Teams that qualify for the finals often bear little resemblance to those that play in the finals and it certainly is not inconceivable that players on the fringe of Bafana Bafana selection will force their way in by June 1998.

What qualification will do is heighten awareness of the game throughout the country and the days when Shoes or Doctor could walk unnoticed through most northern suburbs shopping malls will surely end forever.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


458 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Sports - General;
Adapting to new styles and stars


BYLINE: Steve Morris, Mail And Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Johannesburg - The Springboks are adapting to a new coach and being without some ditched World Cup stars, while the Lions are coming to terms with a new style of play

What we have right now in the build-up towards next Saturday's first Test between the Springboks and the Lions at Newlands, is two potentially good rugby teams trying to come to terms with the way the game - and the circumstances around them - have changed.

The South Africans are slowly coming to the realisation that the marvel of a World Cup win at Ellis Park close on two years ago is history; a catalyst for the future perhaps, but of little help in the immediate present.

The coach has changed twice since that memorable day when Joel Stransky kicked the heart out of the New Zealanders in extra time. The analytical mind of Kitch Christie is no longer there for his charges to feed off. The brooding laager mentality of Andre Markgraaff has been summarily lost in a welter of foul-mouthed racism. 

Instead we have the gentlemanly calm of Carel du Plessis, a prince of a player, but, in many respects, a mere pretender to the throne as a fledgling coach who took over the Springboks without having guided a provincial team. Du Plessis has only the evidence of the devastation of Tonga at Newlands earlier this week on which to gauge his dreams of success. And the more cynical would argue that perhaps he would have sustained fewer injuries and more competition against Mpumalanga, even if the province had not suspended both their locks for laying into the Lions with such apparent malice aforethought.

The Springbok pattern is gradually changing, as first Markgraaff and then Du Plessis have re-staffed the national side, looking for a form of total rugby and discarding the seemingly essential services of World Cup skipper Francois Pienaar, match- winner Stransky, the broken-field mental mastery of Hennie le Roux and the rampaging physical presence of Kobus Wiese.

The Springboks face the reality of the fact that Bob Dylan had it all too right so many years ago when he warned that the times they are achanging.

It is a state of flux that showed some gaps in the Test against the willing but woefully outgunned Tongans. There was the sight of a Springbok side so totally in control in the first 20 minutes that, like Australian cricket captain Mark Taylor, a century began to look like a very real threat.

Then came the almost arrogant spectacle of them relaxing, slowing down and doing just enough. In the analysis, no All Black side ever chosen would have been guilty of such a lapse. The game, as wily New Zealand captain Sean Fitzpatrick is so wont to observe, is played across a full 80 minutes.

The rugby canvas, as painted by the All Blacks, allows no time for pondering which corner to put the signature in, until long after the paint has dried. Du Plessis must realise this and it is an aspect he will surely drill home to his squad before the whistle sounds for the first of three confrontations against the Lions.

The tourists, too, have some urgent thinking to do about the changing face of the game before they run out in Cape Town. If they don't, they risk the same fate as their lion mascot ... a stuffing. The Lions have struggled to come to terms with both the speed and intensity of the game in the southern hemisphere, and the sheer physicality of it all.

It is well that both Marius Bosman and Elandre van der Bergh have been heavily fined for the hooligan tactics of Witbank - even if the Mpumalanga officials were rightly forced to act following the strong denunciation of the dirty deeds by Lions manager Fran Cotton.

Cotton, in his summation of the crippling of Scots lock Doddie Weir, was dead right. This type of play has no place in the game of rugby. Certainly not South African rugby. And this from a man who was never considered a panty-waist angel in his own playing days, as shown by the Lions management refusing an appeal against the one-match ban centre Scot Gibbs earned for over-vigorous use of his fists against Northern Transvaal.

One tends to agree with Weir's mother Nan on the R10 000 fine dished out to Bosman. A suspension would have been far more relevant.

Yet, sad as the return home of Weir, Paul Greyson and Scott Quinnell through injury may be, Cotton, again, recognised that this aspect is very much a part of a tour of South Africa. What he still has to understand fully - strange this from one of the world's premier front-rankers of his playing era - is that the major problems facing the Lions emanate from the men in the front three.

There is no possible way that the Lions can win the series unless they sort out their front row. These are, after all, the storm- troops of the game, the foundation of any battle plan. And yet this department of the Lions has seemed to wilt against even the most tepid of opposition.

But then few of their props have had to face Auckland, ACT or Wellington on a regular basis.

Without clean ball in the set phases, even a scrumhalf as agile and quick as Robert Howley will struggle to give his backs something decent to work with in the way of flowing ball. The Lions have serious problems in this regard ... and they have yet to face the full might of a Springbok tight five intent on pushing them backwards up the slopes of Table Mountain.

To once again use the benchmark of the New Zealand game as the grail modern rugby should aim at, there are no scams in an All Black front row. They come at you like a wall. And the famed "black blanket" of the tight and loose forwards in tandem, devised by Ivan Vodanovich all those years ago, has been refined to an art-form.

This, the northern hemisphere sides have yet to fully realise. Tries e and weft of the game, if not the fabric itself, have been very rapid ght be the preserve of the sparkling three-quarters, but games are won and lost in the grind of the engine room. The difference is that it is now done with skill and pace.

Through the catalyst of Super 12 and the Tri-nation series, the sides of Australia, New Zealand and South Africa - incidentally, the only three sides to have triumphed in the World Cup - the changes in the warp indeed.

The de-limitation of one man's specific task has, in many instances, blurred into that of another. And while specialisation has not brought us back full circle to the days when the first forward to the scrum took unknown ground named Telkom Park - to square the series against But, hooker's position, and whoever was next filled in as prop, there is a new openness about the ability of forwards to run with the ball in their hands.

No better illustration of this is necessary than the sight of Springbok tighthead Adrian Garvey coming up with two tries in the rout of Tonga. You cannot discredit the thinking of Cotton and coach Ian McGeechan in picking the hardest men they could find to make the tour, scouring the ranks of former league players for battle- hardened recruits.

The Lions have begun to change themselves during their tour of this country. They have simply had to allow the silky skills of backs like Jeremy Guscott to engage the opposition. one feels this change will not be enough and will not come soon enough for them to make any significant impact on the Tests, although this type of long-distance analysis has proved wrong in the past, most significantly in 1955 when the South Africans had to fight their way back in the final Test at Boet Erasmus - a stadium incidentally not far o not expect a massacre in line with that which faced the Tongans, but Robin Thompson's Lions.

But, even in a state of flux, the Springboks look just that bit too strong, too fast and too well-schooled in the modern thinking in every department. Traps await Tiger as he chases Grand Slam do not bet too heavily on the British tourists either.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
