Africa News


June 13, 1997


Namibia;
Nujoma accused on seal saga


BYLINE: Christof Maletsky, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Windhoek - The United Democratic Front yesterday expressed support for its Henties Bay branch chairperson Peter Whitham, who exposed suspected illegal activities at a seal meat processing plant earlier this year.

UDF Secretary General Allan Liebenberg stated that President Sam Nujoma had acted unconstitutionally by preventing the law from taking its due course once the matter had been reported to the Police and health authorities.

Liebenberg said the law had been broken and the Police and the judiciary should have been allowed to decide on the matter, and not Nujoma or the Inspector of Hospitals and Health Facilities, Dr Iyambo Indongo. 

"Appointing Dr Indongo does not conform with the constitutional method of investigating criminal deeds. Allow Nampol to perform their duty.

According to the Constitution of the Republic of Namibia, every accused person will be heard in a free, fair and competent public court. The President and Dr Indongo do not satisfy this constitutional requirement," Liebenberg said.

For his part, Whitham said his actions in exposing the dubious sealing activities were not politically motivated but part of his civic responsibility.

He described the State House response as "preposterous and not worthy of any serious contemplation".

"The facts are that I saw and smelled an illegal operation being conducted which was a public health hazard and reported it to the authorities as is my civil duty," Whitham responded.

He pointed out that although State House admitted that the seal processing operation was indeed unauthorised, illegal and contravened health regulations, it had prevented action against the perpetrators.

Whitham refuted allegations that he had supplied photographs to the Times of London and added State House must be "confused". The Times had never published any photographs of the suspect seal meat operation.

"I supplied photographs to Dr Jan Jurgens (of the Ministry of Marine Resources), the health authorities, department of sea fisheries, the Police and the International Fund for Animal Welfare," he said.

State House on Wednesday announced that the 'experiment' to establish whether seal meat can be processed for human consumption had been terminated pending the granting of a permit.

The State House statement did not address concerns about the alleged insanitary state of the seal meat plant and possible health risks to town residents.

Instead the statement launched a personal attack on Whitham whom it accused of trying to sensationalise the issue by contacting the media before the matter had been dealt with by health authorities.

State House said Nujoma had been satisfied with the outcome of the investigations by Indongo.

The seal meat operation was set up by the seal concessionaire at Cape Cross, Aldred Brink. It was hastily abandoned once reported to the authorities.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Namibia;
Cop poaching suspects suspended


BYLINE: Chrispin Inambao, The Namibian (Windhoek)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Windhoek - Two Policemen stationed at the former Buffalo military base in West Caprivi are to face charges of poaching and the violation of firearm restrictions, among others, a Police spokesperson confirmed to The Namibian.

Nampol's Chief Inspector Hophni Hamufungu said the case was being probed by Detective Sergeant Mukube from Rundu. He added that the two suspects would also be suspended. 

One of the suspects, Protection Officer Mungeri, is charged with poaching a buffalo, illegally hunting in a protected nature conservation area and with using trapping apparatus to ensnare game.

His co-accused, Protection Officer Temba, is being charged with possessing buffalo meat and in violation of the Nature Conservation Ordinance.

Apparently Temba was found "cooking and eating buffalo meat".

Hamufungu said Police at Rundu had informed him that they "are still at the beginning of the investigation".

He said some members of the Police unit guarding the former military facility would have to be transferred to Rundu, including the two accused.

"Despite being suspended the two will be put under the direct supervision of the Rundu office," the NamPol spokesperson added.

Detective Sergeant Mukube last week met with Environment and Tourism officials who blew the whistle on the Policemen.

Earlier last week game rangers stationed in the area told The Namibian about the seizure of fresh and dried wild venison and said they were considering laying charges against the Policemen.

The officials acted on a tip-off from their network of informers and pounced on the Policemen while they were feasting on the game meat.

However, Hamufungu denied claims by members of the Kxoe community that they were being harassed and victimised by members of the Buffalo Police unit.The Kxoe have said that impromptu house searches were being conducted in their houses on the grounds that cops were looking for fire-arms.

According to Hamufungu, the house raids not only targeted the Kxoe people, but also other tribal groups, and that they formed part of routine Police searches.

The Police spokesperson revealed that in 1996 a record 53 illegal fire-arms, mostly old army issues, were impounded from members of the Kxoe community.

So far this year five unlicensed weapons had been impounded from the community, he said.

Hamufungu added that this had resulted in a number of dockets for illegal possession of fire-arms being opened against some Kxoe "who are not co-operating with the Police and they are not happy".

While Hamufungu said the searches had the blessing of the Kxoe traditional leadership, last week members of the Kxoe traditional leadership complained about what they termed the harassment and victimisation of their people.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Ethiopia;
The Unfinished History of the Aksum Obelisk Return


BYLINE: Dr. Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2054 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Background of Post-Fascist Italy

The struggle for the return to Ethiopia of the Aksum obelisk, looted by the Italian Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini in 1937, is at long last apparently reaching a successful, and auspicious, conclusion. The time has therefore perhaps come for some of those involved in that struggle to publish views, and reminiscences, on the matter.

The Fascist Legacy

It was apparent to any serious observer of Post World War II Europe that Italy at the end of the war was still deeply influenced by its Fascist past. Despite the growth of the Italian Communist party, perhaps the strongest in the world, many Italians could not free themselves from their country's Fascist legacy. The Communists were more successful, but were no less principled in matters colonial, for they were quite prepared to give support to Italy's return to Africa if it would win votes. 

War Crimes

Many Italians, "educated" by 20 years of Fascism, with a rigidly controlled press, failed to understand that Fascist Italy's invasion of Ethiopia was not a "Civilising Mission". They did not realise that Fascists had been guilty of war crimes. Italy's failure to understand this was in no small part the fault of the victorious Allies, who promoted the retention in power of Mussolini's immediate successor, Marshal Pietro Badoglio. As the Italian commander at the time of the Fascist invasion of Ethiopia in 1935-6 had been responsible for the extensive use of poison-gas but, after Mussolin's fall, received the support of the British and Americans, who, preoccupied with the Cold War, were supremely uninterested in promoting historical justice in relation to Ethiopia. The British in particular consistently opposed any attempt to try Italians for war crimes committed during the invasion of Ethiopia, insisting that it was "another war". Nay, they went further. There was the occasion, little-known, but fully documented in the British Foreign Office archives, when the British Embassy in Rome actually gave Badoglio asylum to prevent him being apprehended by the post-war Italian authorities.

Thus was it that though the Allies instigated show trials for German and Japanese war criminals, not one Italian was ever tried for a crime in Ethiopia (though there can be no denying that many such crimes occurred). Italy, unlike Germany and Japan, was in this way denied the political education afforded by war crimes trials. Many Italians, denied access to the truth during Fascism, were left ignorant of the fact that their compatriots had been guilty of any atrocities.

Poison Gas

The post-war Italian Government, like its Fascist predecessor, furthermore consistently refused to admit that the Royal Italian Air Force had ever used poison-gas in Ethiopia. It was indeed not until 1995, almost exactly sixty years after the event, that the Italian Ministry of Defence finally admitted that gas had been used: on this see Angelo Del Boca's recent important study, I gas di Mussolini. Il fascismo e la guerra d'Etiopia.

Colonialism

Another consequence of Italy's failure fully to break with its Fascist past can be seen in the question of the ex-Italian colonies: Eritrea, Somalia and Libya. The post-World War British and French Governments, under pressure from unquenchable nation- liberation movements, were coming, albeit grudgingly, to recognise the inevitability of the end of colonialism. The Post- War Italian Government, by contrast, adopted a colonially grasping attitude, reminiscent of the Scramble for Africa, and struggled actively to regain the former Italian colonies. Italy was thus significantly out-of-step with much of colonial Europe.

The British Premier Harold Macmillan, referring to decolonisation in Africa, coined the famous term "Winds of Change". His Italian contemporary, Count Sforza, was quoted as declaring, very differently, "Gentlemen of Europe, you have lost Asia by your stupidity; see that you do not lose Africa also!"

The Fascist Residue

Symptomatic of Italian continuity, in relation to Ethiopia and the ex-colonies, was the case of Enrico Cerulli, the leading Italian expert on Ethiopia (and unquestionably a scholar of distinction). In the immediate aftermath of the Wal Wal incident of 1934, which Mussolini had used as a pretext for the invasion of Ethiopia, Cerulli served as adviser to the Fascist delegation to the League of Nations. The delegation's objective was to gain time for Mussolini to build up his invasion forces unhampered by League action.. Cerulli later served as Vice Governor of Italian East Africa under Mussolini. Later again he served as adviser to the post-Fascist Italian Government, during its attempt, at the Paris Peace Conference of 1946, to regain Italy's former colonies. It was no less symptomatic that the Italian delegation to that conference had the effrontery to distribute a fascist publication entitled La civilisation fascist en Afrique Orientale Italienne, a highly partisan work, describing Italian construction and other activity in Ethiopia, which had been published by Mussolini's Government in 1943, the twenty-first year of the Fascist Era, as the title page stated.

The Italian Peace Treaty

Given the strength of the Fascist legacy, post-war Italian Governments, almost inevitably, displayed little good faith, in relation to either Ethiopia or the former Italian colonies.

by the Peace Treaty, of 1947, Italy was obliged to renounce its African colonies. However, on the day after signing the agreement, the Italian Government gave orders to despatch delegations all over the world, in a diplomatic drive to regain the very colonies over which it had renounced claim.

The Treaty likewise made provision for the trial of Italians charged with war crimes in Ethiopia. When, however, in the absence of diplomatic relations between Italy and Ethiopia, the Ethiopian Minister in London, Ato Abebe Retta, attempted to deliver a note on the matter to the Italian Embassy in London, on 6 September 1949, the Italian Ambassador refused to accept it. This the Ambassador, according to "The Times", had the right in international law to do, but was scarcely in keeping with the spirit of the Peace Treaty.

It was, and, as far as I know, still is, symptomatic that the film of the Libyan patriot Omar al-Muktar, murdered on orders from the Italian colonial commander Graziani, has never been shown in Italian cinemas.Lutz Becker's notable documentary film "Lion of Judah", depicting the Ethiopian war (and available at the British Council in Addis Ababa) has likewise been denied the exposure in Italy which it deserves.

The Missing Crowns, the Lion of Judah statue, and the Aksum Obelisk

The Italian Government's lack of good faith was no less apparent in the question of loot. The Peace Treaty specified, in Article 37, that Italy, within 18 months, should return to Ethiopia all loot taken after 3 October 1935, i.e. the date of the fascist invasion. The post-war Italian Government was, here too, scarcely distinguished for its cooperation. There was, on the contrary, much prevarication. Mussolini, when captured by Italian Partisans at Dongo, near the Swiss frontier, in April 1944, had been in possession of four Ethiopian gold crowns. These were duly photographed, but then mysteriously disappeared.

Confronted by this loss of what should have been some of the most valuable items of loot due for return under Article 37, a Government wishing to display honorable intent would surely have hastened, as fast as possible, to return the remainder of the loot. Instead of this, the Italian Government, if we can believe the testimony of Ato Emanuel Abraham, Ethiopian Ambassador in Rome from 1952 to 1955, was almost insultingly uncooperative. In his recent autobiography, "Reminiscences of My Life", he recalls how officials of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs told him that the statue of the Lion of Judah, looted from Ethiopia, and then in Rome, could not be found. This caused him to reply that of course the Italian Government could not find it if they did not look for it.

As for the Aksum Obelisk, Ato Emanuel also recalls, in vivid detail, how the Italian Government persistently tried to evade his requests for its return. When he raised the matter with Mendola, the Director-General of the Ministry, the latter "stared at the floor for about one minute but could not bring himself to utter one word". Another Foreign Affairs official suggested that the obelisk should be retained in Rome, with a small notice to say that it was a "Gift from the Ethiopian People".

The question of the obelisk could not, however, be dismissed so easily. A dramatic, and entirely unexpected, manoeuvre was, as we shall see next week, soon to take place!


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


494 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Giorgio Gaslini was Superb, Mavilia Dazzling


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Addis Ababa - A dazzling jazz performance was presented by a group of Italian musicians at the Italian Cultural Institute last Monday.

Present at the concert were prominent figures including the Italian Ambassador, H.E. Mr. Maurizio Melani, the Canadian ambassador, H.E. Mr. Gabriel Lessard, the Yugoslav Ambassador, H. E. Mr. Igor Jovovic and many other distinguished personalities from Ethiopia and abroad. The attendence proved that the Ethiopian community is keen toward jazz music.

The world renowned jazz composer , Giorgio Gaslini, put on two solo superb piano performances that left the audience spellbound. The group which included Andrea Dulbecco at the vibraphone, Roberto Bonati at bass and Barbara Mavilla at the drum presented around eight pieces that featured both the festive and the dark side of life.

The concert was unique to the Ethiopians as the talented Giorgio Gaslini presented a magnificent musical piece which he wrote nearby Lake Hora about 45 km from Addis Ababa. The music completely captured the hearts and the minds of the audience.

Ethiopia's own vibraphone player, Mulatu Astatcke, also presented a magnificent musical piece during the presentation. The crowd was enthusiastic about the performance shown by the drummer, Barbara Mavilia, whose expert handling of the drums was a performance that one must not miss.

Giorgoi Gaslini's final solo made use of the unusual combination of a piano with musical box to create a music that was delightful to the ears.

Indeed, a statement made by one distinguished guest after the concert captures the essence of the program. He said, "I wish I had a family here to see the concert."

The credit should go to the Italian Cultural Institute which is one of the active groups in Addis Ababa that initiates activities for the promotion of culture.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


495 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Ethiopia;
Moges Admassu - Building Society through Computers


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ato Moges Admassu is one of the few Ethiopians who give the information service its rightful place - a place of prominence.

Being a veteran computer engineer and the manager in the internationally renowned computer brand name of the Hewlett Packard Computer branch in Ethiopia, Ato Moges is an authority to talk of the information issue.

Ato Moges, 49, had as a child, always felt that vocational training would go a long way toward success in life. He grew up under the influence of his father who used to tell him an educated person will never sleep hungry and that knowledge is something that nobody takes away from some one. These sayings guided him to undertake vocational training. He joined Addis Ababa University and graduated in 1978 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering. 

Collected and full of confidence, Moges sits still while talking of the complexities and pleasure of life. Moges is the product of trainings he had in different countries such as France, the United Kingdom, Japan and Poland. Talking of the various trainings he had taken during the early stages of his career, Ato Moges said his time in France was mainly devoted to HP 3000 hardware and network training, while in the U.K. training focused on UNIX.

His stay in Japan greatly influenced his career while he was studying microwaves. What impressed Moges most in Japan at that time (late 1970's) was the way the Japanese used to sell computer chips, transistors and so on, in the streets just as seasoning spices are sold in the streets of Ethiopia. In Poland, he was trained in broadcasting technology which he said was not beneficial for him, for the computer hardware used in the training course was not modern and up-to-date. Moges remembered how he used to try to fix the out-of-date computers.

Information to Ato Moges is part of the ongoing process of development. Factors of production do not only include the three components of manpower, capital and land. It also incorporates a fourth most important component, that is, information.

Without information, Moges affirms, individuals, businessmen and even the government will be in a dark alley. Just like food and water, an individual needs information in order to survive in the present world. More importantly, Ato Moges emphasised the need for the right information at the right time in the right way. Wrong information, says he smilingly, "is like dirty water that causes stomach upset to the person who drank it." Water, a life-giving resource, is turned to something that is harmful to the human body. In the same way, wrong or distorted information is the cause for the many obstacles that face the world at large.

Moges sees Ethiopia lagging behind in the development of information services. Particularly, in the field of computers, the country is at its infancy. Although the hardware are available and computers are being imported in great numbers, the optimum use of computer services are desired. He mentioned, for instance, the recent introduction of Internet in the Ethiopian information services. The Internet is only used for collection of news, a position which other African countries have long passed.

Many Ethiopians view computer as something to be feared rather than a utility machine to be used and made to work. The cause, in Moges' view, is lack of exposure. Talking of the purchase of computers, he sees many people buying computers because others have already bought it or because it was the "latest". Fortunately, situations have improved with many computer training centers and institutions that have mushroomed in the last 3-4 years. Brand confusion that mostly characterise selling of computers are being cleared up. Ato Moges recalls the time when IBM brand computer was taken as synonym for all computers. Change is the order of the day when a brand name like Hewlett Packard is becoming a household name.

During his 13 years experience as computer engineer and manager of ACPSERIC, Ato Moges has worked as the representative in many African countries such as Sudan, Tanzania, Rwandaand Mali. He greatly regrets that Ethiopian engineers who are given contracts in such countries as Sudan and Rwanda are unable to work because of certain polices.

Despite the know-how and required skill and the computer spare parts needed in any kind of installation, customs rules and regulations do not permit electronic equipmentto be exported. Moges sees these limitations as preventing the generation of foreign currency to the country.

Ato Moges is at present the general manager of ACPSERIC, a support computer foreign company. He is married and has a son and two daughters.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


496 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Sumner Presents Lecture on Oromo Literature


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Addis Ababa - On Saturday evening 7 June, a lecture was presented on "Songs, Proverbs and Fiction of Oromo Literature" by the world famous intellectual, Professor Claude Sumner. at the Alliance Ethio-Francaise.

The presentation marked the launching of the Professor's book. Present at the lecture which was held at the Alliance Ethio-Francaise were several prominent figures including the officers of the French Embassy and lecturers in the Addis Ababa University.

The lecture featured slide displays that depict the professor's views and ideas on African and Ethiopian philosophy. Ethiopian wisdom was discussed as it was presented in his book entitled "La Sagesse". The book portrays wisdom as a means that ensures truce if not peace in the society. The Professor's work appreciates the Ethiopian traditional philosophy that has its basis on the wise sayings of the aged.

In the lecture, professor Sumner said Ethiopian philosophy is practical and often suitable for even those obstacles that seem impossible. Such wisdom is also a belief and has its origin on the experiments of the descendants and the old people on their last road to death.

Professor Claude Sumner has written books on of African and Ethiopian anthropology and philosophy: 'The Ethiopian Wisdom', and 'Ethiopian Source of the African philosophy: The Philosophy of Man' among others.

The professor is a doctor of Linguistics of the University of Montreal and honorary Doctor of the University of Windsor.

Professor Sumner is an authority on linguistics and theology and has been professor of philosophy at the Addis Ababa University since 1953.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's Largest Private Bank Begins Operation


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Wegagen Bank, said to be the biggest private bank in Ethiopia, commenced its banking operation on Wednesday, 11 June, in Addis Ababa. At a brief inaugural ceremony held at its headquarters at Gofa Sefer, south east of Addis Ababa, and at Meskel Square, the bank launched its banking business in all types of deposits, loans for the establishment of business and industries, international banking, consumer loans for the purpose of vehicles, household goods as well as other kinds of loans. 

Wegagen's capital stands at 60 million birr ( about 9 million US. dollars) wholly owned by Ethiopians and of which 30 million birr (over 4.4 million US. dollars) has been paid up.

On the occasion of the inaugural ceremony, the governor of the National bank of Ethiopia said that the starting of the operation of the bank S.C. contributes to the expansion and development of the banking sector in the country. It will also strengthen the competition between the major players in the national economy.

The bank's president and chief executive officer, Ms. Bruktawit Dawit Abdi, on her part said the bank has 16 shareholders out of whom seven are organisations. Wzro. Bruktawit added that the bank would participate in future competition in foreign transactions among banks.

To celebrate the occasion, the president also invited prominent guests to a cocktail party at the Hilton Hotel this evening, June 13th. Many prominent businessmen and government officials from the country and abroad are expected to attend the meeting.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Bamboo Said Able to Replace Steel Bars in Construction


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - A breakthrough research has proved the possibility of replacing steel bars by bamboo for concrete reinforcement, announced the Ethiopian Science and Technology Commission.

According to Ato Shumu Tefera, head of the industry department at the commission, research conducted on the huge amount of bamboo found in the western part of Ethiopia proved that the resource has the standard quality needed for concrete reinforcement. 

Such innovative use of the bamboo for construction purpose could cover the shortage of steel bars beside minimising the country's foreign currency, Ato Shemu added.

Another research also proved successful by proving the possibility of producing pesticides and insecticides from pyrethrum, a flowering plant species which grows in the highland regions, he disclosed. This production will also go a long way towards the saving of foreign currency the country is spending on the import of pesticides, he added.

Young researchers under the sponsorship of the government came up with various tool inventions, among which is a multicrop thresher. The thresher proved to be effective by the commission, has the capacity of threshing 10 quintals per hour, he said.

The tool will remain effective as its spare parts are easily available in the country at reasonable prices, Ato Shemu added.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Canadian Company to Explore Gold in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa - An exploration agreement was signed on Monday between the Ministry of Mines and Energy and St. Genvieve Resources Ltd., a Canadian private firm.

The agreement, signed by Ato Shemsudin Ahmed, Vice Minister of Mines and Energy, and Ato Tesfaye Chemir, local representative of St. Genvieve, gives the company an exclusive right to explore gold and base metals in Agusha-Gumu Donga and Basha areas of the Benishangul-Gumuz regional state. 

The company will invest over 1.75 million U.S. dollars during the next three years at the project site, which cover 450.36 sq. km.

During the signing ceremony, Ato Shemsudin expressed hope that St. Genevieve will work in accordance with the agreement towards the mutual benefit of both sides. The representative of the company on his part said the company will make its utmost effort to make the project worthwhile.

The company was also granted a licence for gold and base metals exploration at Serikole locality in the same region and is reported to have been conducting preparatory work since February 1996.


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


500 of 1321 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia Registers Export Earnings of 2.2 Billion Birr


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia recorded the unprecedented earnings of 2.2 billion Ethiopian birr ( about 327 million US dollars) from traditional export commodities during the last nine months, the Ministry of Trade and Industry said on Thursday, June 6.

The bulk of the export earnings has been made from coffee, hides and skins, oil seeds and grains said Ato Kasahun Ayele, in his third quarterly report to the House of Peoples' Representatives. 

According to Ato Kasahun, the present year earnings are up by 306 million birr ( about 45.5 million US. dollars) as compared to the same period last year. He also noted that 64 percent of the earnings (about 1.4 billion birr or over 209 million US dollars) was made by private exporters.

Comparing the present year's figure of the issue of licences with that of last year, Ato Kasahun added that about 1700 exporters, importers and commission agents were issued licences which represented 80 percent increase over last year's.

In order to improve and encourage micro-enterprises that have a pivotal role in the economic advancement of the nation, the minister said a national committee chaired by the Prime Minister has been established.

In response to the query whether any measure has been taken to boost foreign demand for Ethiopia's textile products, the minister said the industry is afflicted with many problems, including backward technologies and quality shortcomings. A study has been conducted and submitted to the Prime Minister's Office to solve the problem.

The House also approved two bills, one establishing the Ethiopian Agricultural Research Organisation and another for re- structuring the Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA).


LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1997
